title: AECTech NYC 2025 Recap
content: AEC Tech NYC 11/11 ‚Äì 11/16/2025 AEC Tech NYC 2025 brought together designers, engineers, and technologists to look closely at how technology is actually being used in practice today. Rather than centering on tools in isolation, the conference focused on workflows, decision-making, and collaboration across firms. Perkins&Will participated in several parts of the conference, including the Tech Crawl, Symposium, and Hackathon. As part of the Tech Crawl, Perkins&Will hosted one of the open-studio visits at the New York office. The session was informal and discussion-driven, offering visitors a view into how digital tools and processes are developed and tested within live project conditions. The focus was less on finished solutions and more on how teams work through complexity, adapt standards, and balance experimentation with delivery. The Symposium formed the core discussion event of the conference, with Perkins&Will hosting one of the sessions in its New York studio. Talks and panels covered a range of topics, including computational design, data-driven workflows, environmental analysis, and the growing role of automation in design and engineering. Much of the conversation centered on how these technologies are changing the structure of practice‚Äîhow decisions are made, how responsibilities shift, and how designers maintain authorship and accountability as systems become more complex. The conference concluded with a two-day Hackathon that emphasized making over presentation. Interdisciplinary teams formed quickly and worked intensively to prototype tools and workflows responding to real challenges in the AEC industry. Perkins&Will team members participated alongside peers from other firms, contributing design insight and technical experience while testing ideas through rapid iteration. Taken together, these moments reflected a shared interest in openness, practical experimentation, and learning through doing. Perkins&Will‚Äôs involvement across the conference reinforced the value of engaging directly with evolving technologies‚Äînot as finished products, but as part of an ongoing, collective practice.

title: File Sharing Permission Changes
content: Updated SharePoint Link Permission Guidance SharePoint Sharing: Default to People You Choose (External Sharing) When sharing files externally in SharePoint, the default mindset should be intentional access . In nearly all cases, ‚ÄúPeople you Choose‚Äù should be your go-to option for external sharing‚Äîensuring the right external partners have the right level of access while keeping our documents secure and compliant. Sharing settings can be adjusted by clicking the gear icon in the Share screen. Taking a moment here helps prevent access issues, protects sensitive information, and keeps collaboration predictable‚Äîespecially when working with consultants, clients, and vendors. Internal sharing guidance remains unchanged: For internal collaboration, continue to prioritize ‚ÄúPeople in Perkins&Will‚Äù to provide seamless access for colleagues while maintaining firmwide security standards. Note: Some Clients/Projects have ‚Äúneed to know‚Äù requirements in our contracts. ¬†This means that use of the ‚Äú People in Perkins&Will‚Äù link cannot be used due to the lack of our ability to audit who has accessed the information. Please verify with your Project Manager and/or CEL if your project has this type of restriction. SharePoint Link Usage Policy (External Sharing) 1. Default: Controlled External Collaboration For documents or folders that require editing, commenting, or ongoing collaboration with external partners , always use ‚ÄúThis link works for‚Ä¶ People you Choose.‚Äù Access is granted only to named individuals by entering their email addresses. Permissions are clear, auditable, and aligned with our security standards. Recipients will be required to sign in with Microsoft to verify they are the intended receiver. This is the only approved method for granting edit or collaboration rights to external users. Using ‚ÄúPeople you Choose‚Äù ensures accountability, minimizes risk, and avoids accidental oversharing‚Äîparticularly for active project work and contractual deliverables. Note: Once you have shared a folder with someone using ‚ÄúPeople you Choose‚Äù , you can send them links to individual files and subfolders by picking ‚ÄúPeople with Existing Access‚Äù. 2. Exception: View-Only External Dissemination In limited situations, external recipients may have trouble accessing files due to client IT policies, security incompatibilities, or contractual constraints . If this occurs, pause and confirm with the Project Manager before proceeding. Once confirmed, a view-only ‚ÄúThis link works for‚Ä¶ Anyone‚Äù link may be used for external dissemination only . ‚ÄúAnyone‚Äù links are view-only and cannot be used for collaboration. Links automatically expire after 30 days. For sensitive or confidential content, apply a password before sharing. This option should be treated as a fallback , not a default. Note: Some Clients/Projects have ‚Äúneed to know‚Äù requirements in our contracts. ¬†This means that use of the ‚Äò Anyone ‚Äò link cannot be used due to the lack of our ability to audit who has accessed the information. Please verify with your Project Manager and/or CEL if your project has this type of restriction. Sample of the additional share settings accessed by clicking the gear icon Why This Matters By defaulting to ‚ÄúPeople you Choose‚Äù for external sharing and ‚ÄúPeople in Perkins&Will‚Äù for internal collaboration , we reduce confusion, strengthen security, and keep access aligned with project needs and contractual obligations. The ‚ÄúAnyone‚Äù link is a tool‚Äînot a shortcut ‚Äîto be used thoughtfully when standard access isn‚Äôt possible. When in doubt, stop and check your sharing settings‚Äîor confirm with your Project Manager. A few extra seconds upfront can prevent access issues, rework, and unnecessary risk later on.

title: Core eXchange 2026 Q1 Recap
content: 2026 Q1 Core eXchange Recap! Core eXchange: Back to Basics and Building Shared Understanding Last month‚Äôs Core eXchange presentation series focused on strengthening shared foundations across the firm. The sessions were intentionally designed as introductory and refresher content, creating space for teams to align around core tools, workflows, and ideas that support effective project delivery, digital practice, and sustainable design. Returning to Fundamentals A central theme of the series was expanding the ‚ÄúBack to Basics‚Äù approach from last October. Presentations revisited essential concepts such as early digital planning, right-sizing effort to project complexity, and establishing clear expectations at the start of work. These topics reinforced the importance of proactive decision-making and consistent setup as a way to reduce risk, improve efficiency, and support teams throughout the life of a project. Shared Tools and Common Platforms Another focus of the series was building familiarity and confidence with firmwide tools and platforms. Sessions emphasized how shared systems support people, projects, clients, and knowledge, and how small, regular interactions with these tools contribute to better visibility, coordination, and reporting. Rather than positioning these platforms as destinations, the series highlighted their role in supporting quick, everyday tasks that collectively strengthen firmwide insight and alignment. Knowledge, Learning, and Accessibility The series also reinforced the value of accessible knowledge and shared learning. Presentations showcased how guidance, research, and practical resources are organized to support teams in solving problems, exploring new approaches, and applying lessons learned across projects. By making expertise easier to find and apply, the series underscored how knowledge sharing supports consistency and continuous improvement. Sustainability and Emerging Practices Several sessions connected foundational workflows to broader environmental and design goals. Topics explored how materials, data, and decision-making intersect with sustainability, health, and long-term performance. These discussions positioned emerging practices not as isolated innovations, but as extensions of core design principles that can be integrated into everyday work. Looking Ahead Across all sessions, the consistent message was that strong digital and design practices are built on clarity, shared understanding, and intentional choices. By revisiting fundamentals and aligning around common approaches, Digital Practice and the Core eXchange lecture series continues to support teams in delivering high-quality, resilient, and forward-looking work. All session recordings and slides are available in the Exchange Library on the Digital Practice site . Thank you to all our Presenters! View the Recordings on The Digital Practice Exchange Library Back to Basics Series Five Back to Basics sessions formed the foundation of this quarter‚Äôs program, each highlighting the essential workflows that aid with project delivery: Back to Basics with Area Sync ‚Äì Explained how to use Area Sync to track, validate, and reconcile program and design areas throughout a project lifecycle. Click here for this session. Back to Basics with Concept Analysis ‚Äì Focused on using early-stage analysis to test design assumptions, evaluate options, and inform decision-making during schematic design. Click here for this session. Back to Basics with CCA ‚Äì Reviewed core CCA workflows and how consistent model checking, coordination, and issue tracking support quality, efficiency, and risk reduction. Click here for this session. Back to Basics with Pull Planning ‚Äì Covered collaborative pull planning methods to align teams around milestones, dependencies, and realistic project schedules early in the delivery process. Click here for this session. Back to Basics: Teams and SharePoint ‚Äì Demonstrated practical approaches for using Teams and SharePoint to organize files, manage communication, and maintain clear project documentation. Click here for this session. Together, these sessions reinforced the importance of consistent, shared workflows and demonstrated how thoughtful use of core tools and processes supports clearer coordination, stronger decision-making, and more reliable project delivery.

title: FacadesPlus Los Angeles 2025
content: Tina Giorgadze and Luc Deckinga were onstage at the last FacadesPlus conference of 2025 in Los Angeles on December 12th. They presented ‚ÄòFrom Artwork to Architecture: Translating Community Identity into Facade Design‚Äô which shared the inspiration behind and design process used to create a tiled mosaic artwork for the Kaiser Permanente Watts Medical Building & Watts Counseling and Learning Center. Their presentation was followed by a hands-on workshop that walked the participants through the Rhino and Grasshopper files used to create the mosaic tile patterns. For an overview of the other speakers and presentations at FacadesPlus Los Angeles see this article in The Architect‚Äôs Newspaper.

title: Chicago Innovate Hackathon
content: Chicago Innovate 2025: Tools, Tech, and Two Days of Hacking Chicago Innovate returned this September with a full week of talks, panels, workshops, and a two-day hackathon focused on pushing digital innovation forward across the AEC industry. Running from September 22‚Äì28, the event brought together architects, engineers, technologists, and software developers to explore how emerging tools can meaningfully improve the way we design and deliver projects. I was fortunate enough to be invited to the Tools & Technology track as a presenter and panelist alongside Kevin Kosciulek (bKL) , Alexandra Pollack (CORE Studio) , Ann Schuessler (AssemblyBuilt) , and culminating in a keynote by James Coleman (SumPoint) . My talk focused on a simple idea: creating and rolling out tools isn‚Äôt about the tools themselves. It‚Äôs about understanding the people who rely on them. Empathy, timing, and good implementation matter far more than features. ‚ÄúTechnology succeeds when it meets people where they are.‚Äù Inside the Hackathon Our Chicago studio was represented in the two-day hackathon by Jason Pieper , who had just come off a month-earlier hackathon in Boston. That experience shaped how he approached this one: clear pitches, the right mix of skills, and just enough prep to give a team a running start. In Boston, Jason‚Äôs group prototyped an early-stage embodied carbon calculator. It was a collaboration built across architects, engineers, and software developers. That early exposure informed how he framed his pitch in Chicago, where polish and clarity proved essential. ‚ÄúA good idea helps. A good 30-second pitch gets a team.‚Äù For the Chicago Innovate event, Jason‚Äôs team built a web application that combines Rhino Compute, Grasshopper, Karamba, and OpenAI . Designers could describe a structural goal in natural language, watch the tool iterate on solutions, and see results as charts and a color-coded 3D model. It was a proof of concept, but a compelling one: bridging expert workflows with intuitive, conversational interfaces. Across both hackathons, a consistent theme emerged: the industry isn‚Äôt short on tools. It‚Äôs short on tools with purpose that people want to use. The teams gravitated toward removing friction, simplifying complex analysis, and building bridges between specialists and everyday project workflows. Jason summed it up well: ‚ÄúThe goal is always the same: better design. The barrier is usability.‚Äù These events also broke down the usual silos. Architects teamed with structural engineers, software developers, even competitors. The result: fast prototyping, unexpected insights, and momentum that continues after the weekend ends. Chicago Innovate reinforced what many of us already know: progress in AEC comes from mixing disciplines, testing ideas quickly, and keeping people‚Äînot technology‚Äîat the center of our digital decisions.

title: Speckle-Con 2025
content: SpeckleCon 2025: Putting data to work with Speckle SpeckleCon 2025 made one thing clear: data interoperability and automation are no longer experimental concepts reserved for computational specialists ‚Äî they are becoming everyday tools in architectural practice. Held at CodeNode in London, our London Digital Practice Colleagues, Adam Burnham, Osman Sahinbozkir, Xiaoheng Li attended the conference. SpeckleCon brought together architects, engineers, developers, and builders to explore how open-data workflows are transforming design and construction. For architects in particular, the event highlighted a shift toward more fluid collaboration, faster iteration, and an emerging culture of ‚Äúdesign intelligence‚Äù ‚Äî using clear, connected data to inform better decisions. Key Themes From Collaboration to Construction A recurring theme throughout the sessions was the ability to bridge conceptual design and real-world construction using unified, real-time data streams. Presenters showed how Speckle enables early-stage design models, simulations, and analysis to feed directly into engineering and fabrication workflows. Examples ranged from automated quality checks on construction models to generating performance insights (daylight, energy, carbon) during early massing studies. For architects, this means the gap between design intent and execution is narrowing. Instead of exporting, translating, and coordinating across disconnected tools, teams can work through a shared digital backbone ‚Äî one that remains consistent from concept to construction. Design Intelligence Over Data Volume Several talks emphasised that data only becomes powerful when it‚Äôs understandable. Architects are often overwhelmed by data-rich environments: simulations, BIM models, material databases, cost information. SpeckleCon speakers pushed for clarity instead of complexity ‚Äî highlighting workflows that present designers with clean dashboards, simplified analytic snapshots, and curated datasets. The message was simple: the goal isn‚Äôt more data; it‚Äôs better design decisions . Scaling Automation in Practice A highlight of the event was the introduction of Speckle Automate , a system for triggering automated tasks whenever a model changes. For architects, this could mean: instant daylight analysis every time a massing model updates automatic model audits before internal reviews automated geometry clean-up before sharing with engineers continuous carbon feedback during fa√ßade development These tools support a future where repetitive tasks disappear from a designer‚Äôs plate, freeing teams to focus on creativity and problem-solving. Why SpeckleCon Matters for Architecture For architects, SpeckleCon 2025 underscored three major directions for the industry: Interoperability is becoming a baseline expectation. No firm wants to be locked into single-software workflows anymore. Automation will redefine productivity. Architects will spend less time translating, exporting, validating, and cleaning models ‚Äî and more time designing. Data-driven design is maturing. Instead of overwhelming dashboards, designers will get actionable insights embedded directly into their process. Architectural practice is shifting from drawing-centric workflows to data-centric ones ‚Äî and Speckle is positioning itself at the heart of that transformation.

title: CDFAM
content: CDFAM was historically known for its focus on Computational Design For Added Manufacturing which had a strong focus on added manufacturing across all industries, architecture, manufacturing, product design, aviation and space to name a few. The organization seems to be rebranding itself and expanding its reach into Computational Design For: A dvanced M odeling A rchitectural M odeling A rchitected M aterials A I Driven M aterials A I Driven M odeling A I & M achine Learning A dditive M anufacturing A dvanced M anufacturing A _______ M ________ This recent symposium held this Fall in New York at Newlab in the Brooklyn Navy Yards had a wide range of speakers from different industries. This year‚Äôs keynote speakers Markus J. Buehler from MIT and Ian Pegler from NVIDIA each shared their perspectives on AI and product development respectively. Buehler makes the case that LLM‚Äôs will give us ‚Äúbrilliant parrots‚Äù, but they will not give us discovery. Behler defines discovery as the art of ‚Äúasking the right question to express ideas. LLM‚Äôs cannot express ideas‚Äù. AI models cannot be trained on data and expect it to discover something outside of that data. Discovery requires outside perspectives. AI can help convert complexities into principles and create graphs which humans can use to help discover relationships. Pegler claims that a lot of innovation happens at one‚Äôs desk √† people at work, by themselves in momentary isolation, able to think and question, something that AI cannot do. A selection of the presentations can be found on this youtube playlist . AI and the Battle for the Soul of Design Chris McComb, Carnegie Mellon University Chris McComb from Carnegie Mellon University thinks that AI and automation will help us reallocate time for better task. We neglect the value of subtractive changes when aiming to make improvements, often we look at adding tasks or adding features, but it‚Äôs critical that we consider subtractive changes. When it comes to the integration of AI into our work, humans have the unfair advantage of empathy. Design as Dialog: Form Jamming with AI Agents Matthew Goldsberry & Juling Zhuang, HDR HDR recently presented their explorations using the Rhino Model Context Protocol (MCP) in combination with external databases containing architectural domain knowledge. While Rhino is an excellent modeling tool and AI can help automate tasks, neither inherently understands the context of building assemblies. By injecting metadata into the MCP and connecting it to these specialized databases, the system becomes far more context aware. Designers can then interact with their models using architectural terms such as curtain wall or fa√ßade and the AI model can interpret what the discrete components are required in the model and how they behave. The result is more intuitive and efficient working collaboration. Running Revolution: Computational Design Behind Puma Fast-R NITRO Elite 3 ‚Äì Moon Rabbit Lab x Puma Jesus Marini, Moon Rabbit Lab Moon Rabbit Lab is a computational design studio based in Milan Italy that focuses on pushing the boundaries of performance products through innovative design and engineering. Marini‚Äôs presentation focused on the six stages of a project: Data Collection Computational Data Processing Product Insights Product Development Prototype & Physical Validation Signoff Marini demonstrated how the Puma Fast-R NITRO Elite 3 shoe design followed these six stages to achieve a better performing product for athletes to achieve greater success. The result was a product where athletes where able to break their own personal records. Digital Twinning a Living Lab David Gerber, University of Southern California Dr. David Gerber presented the Living Lab Project which focuses on latest work done by USC, converting Ginsburg Hall building into a building with an api. The research project is meant to ‚Äúprovide practical learning experiences through real-time monitoring and analysis‚Äù. By deploying a wide range of IoT sensors, the university is able to track energy usage, water consumption, building health, and occupant well-being and more. The comprehensive dataset allows researchers to understand how a building changes and evolves over different time periods, both short and long. The dataset is made publicly available for collaborative research. A Parametric Structural Genome: Using Computational Design To Manage Compound Tolerances Of Multiple Materials To Create The World‚Äòs Largest Double Curved Outdoor LED Screen Gustav Fagerstr√∂m, Walter P Moore & Steve Reichwein, Severud Associates The duo of presenters took a deep dive into the structure and fa√ßade for the Las Vegas Sphere project. The project consists of a 360-degree sphere shaped LED fa√ßade that acts as an immersive screen. The exterior dome has a three-tiered structural system, with each tier increasing in its level of accuracy to maintain the high precision tolerances required for the screen to¬† function as planned. Casting the primary nodes helped reduce the overall weight of the structure while increasing the level of accuracy and reducing overall cost. When it came time to install the final structural piece of the sphere, the engineers and builders were concerned about the thermal expansion of the structure due to the extreme temperature swings associated with Las Vegas. The local building officials were on hand and there was talk about calling¬† the local fire department in case the team needed to replicate the same procedures required for installing the keystone for the St Louis Arch . Fortunately, the final piece was installed early in the day before the temperatures started to climb.

title: Smarter Estates, Smarter Care ‚Äî Reflections from IHEEM 2025
content: Smarter Estates, Smarter Care ‚Äî Reflections from Healthcare Estates 2025 This year‚Äôs Healthcare Estates Conference in Manchester brought together the people who design, manage and operate the NHS estate at what feels like a critical moment. With ageing infrastructure, growing clinical demand, workforce pressures and a maintenance backlog approaching ¬£16bn , the focus has understandably shifted from what could we do? to what must we address first? It created exactly the right context for the two sessions Perkins&Will delivered in the Design & Construction Theatre: ‚ÄúSmarter Estates, Smarter Care‚Äù , which I presented alongside Gonzalo Vargas, and ‚ÄúMaster Planning for the Future‚Äù , presented by Rachelle McDade (Currie & Brown) and our colleague Rafael Marks. A huge thank you goes to Thomas Kearns and Aprameya Pandit , whose preparation, analysis and technical support underpinned both presentations and helped ensure the content was grounded, accurate and genuinely useful for Trusts On the Exhibition Floor One of the most interesting parts of the event was the exhibition floor, which this year felt even more connected to the challenges and ambitions of the NHS estate. The standout feature was the New Hospital Programme‚Äôs ‚ÄúHospital 2.0‚Äù single-bedroom prototype ‚Äî a full-scale inpatient room designed to show what future repeatable hospital components could look like. The mock-up demonstrated everything from standardised room layouts and modern materials to integrated medical equipment and clearer staff sightlines. Alongside this, there was a noticeable increase in digital vendors showing real-time location systems, asset-tagging solutions, IoT-driven monitoring and CAFM/CMMS platforms. Even without physical robots on the floor, AI, automation and robotics were highly visible in the keynote programme. NHS England‚Äôs Day 2 keynote explicitly referenced them as emerging technologies set to influence the way healthcare infrastructure is designed, delivered and maintained ‚Äî signalling a decisive shift in mindset across the sector. Our Presentations Master Planning for the Future ‚Äî Rachelle McDade & Rafael Marks Against that backdrop, Rachelle and Rafael‚Äôs session focused on how Trusts can take a more strategic, long-range approach to their estates ‚Äî moving beyond the piecemeal, reactive decision-making that has shaped the NHS estate for decades. Using their work with the Royal Free Hospital as a case study, they outlined a clinically led, digitally enabled strategic toolkit that helps organisations understand their estate in the context of clinical priorities, future service models, sustainability pressures, and operational risk . They walked through a structured process that runs from vision-setting and clinical engagement , through scenario testing and cost modelling , to Board-ready reporting . The result is a planning framework that gives Trusts genuine clarity and confidence when evaluating options. A standout element was their use of interoperable digital tools ‚Äî including Portfolio Explorer, Area Sync, Campus Planner and Dorian ‚Äî which together enable real-time scenario modelling and provide decision-makers with a clear view of value, constraints and opportunity . Their message was simple and convincing: the NHS needs strategic, clinically anchored planning frameworks that help Trusts make smarter decisions, maximise limited resources, and build estates that can stand up to future pressures. Based on the strength of this work ‚Äî and the recent presentation to Worcester NHS Trust ‚Äî we expect to undertake a small feasibility study across multiple sites from January to March 2026 , followed by a full Estates Strategy for the Trust. Both pieces will adopt the same Campus Planner methodology applied at the Royal Free. In parallel, we‚Äôve also been approached by a Trust in Wales to deliver a similar programme. These opportunities are being led by Currie & Brown Smarter Estates, Smarter Care ‚Äî Myself & Gonzalo Vargas Our own session, ‚ÄúSmarter Estates, Smarter Care‚Äù , picked up the thread from a different angle: the operational layer beneath estates planning. We focused on a challenge almost every Trust faces ‚Äî the basic data foundations simply aren‚Äôt strong enough to support the decisions estates teams need to make every day . Across programmes, SOA requirements, room layouts and assets, information is often held in different places, authored by different people and updated at different times. We showed how that fragmentation forces estates teams to rebuild data repeatedly, rather than trust it. A live demo from our platform illustrated how programme, spatial information and assets can be synchronised into one coherent view, giving teams real-time clarity and removing hours of manual reconciliation. From there we explored asset visibility, which remains one of the biggest operational inefficiencies across the NHS estate. Many Trusts still rely on partial inventories, outdated spreadsheets or repeated resurveying simply to understand what they have and where it is. By connecting asset data to spaces, tagging and RFID systems, we demonstrated how Trusts can eliminate unnecessary repeat work, improve response times and reduce costs associated with poor information quality. That idea tied neatly into our discussion of ERIC ‚Äî a dataset with huge strategic value that is rarely used to its full potential. We showed how linking ERIC to spatial and asset data creates a live operational picture rather than an annual reporting exercise, helping estates teams identify risk, model investment and respond to ongoing pressures. We finished by focusing on what we believe is the missing link in many NHS projects: a lifecycle-wide digital backbone . Planning, design, construction, handover and operations are still too often disconnected, with every phase producing its own version of the truth. We showed how a common digital language ‚Äî built around structured, reusable, validated information ‚Äî allows Trusts to capture data once and reuse it everywhere, unlocking the operational benefits people expect from digital twins and smarter estates without the costs or complexity that often get in the way. Key Takeaways from other Sessions Taken together with the wider conference content, a few themes stood out strongly. First, AI, automation and robotics are now firmly part of the national estates conversation ‚Äî not as futuristic concepts but as tools that will influence how assets are monitored, maintained and managed. Second, digital innovation is becoming a core expectation rather than a side topic. And finally, workforce and financial pressures are accelerating the need for better information: Trusts simply can‚Äôt afford inefficiencies caused by fragmented data or disconnected systems. Across the exhibition, the keynotes and the sessions we contributed, the message was consistent: the NHS doesn‚Äôt just need new hospitals ‚Äî it needs smarter, data-enabled ones. And the smartest estates aren‚Äôt the ones with the most technology; they are the ones built on structured, reliable, connected information. Better data = better decisions = better estates = better care

title: ACADIA 2025: Computing for Resilience
content: ACADIA 2025 came to Miami this year and included 3 days of workshops, research paper presentations, panel discussions at the University of Miami and Florida International University. Perkins Will was a Silver Sponsor. We‚Äôre also proud to mention that one of our Senior Project Designers in the Miami Studio, Juan Yactayo , was a chair through his affiliation with the University of Miami. Computing for Resilience ACADIA 2025 centers on COMPUTING for RESILIENCE, a theme inspired by Miami‚Äôs urgent physical, economic, and climate challenges. As a city facing rising seas, political pressures, and historical erasure, Miami has become both a hotspot for risk and a proving ground for innovation. The conference explores how computational design and advanced fabrication can help architects and technologists develop adaptable, future-ready solutions. By leveraging digital tools to address climate impacts and shifting social conditions, ACADIA 2025 aims to expand community knowledge and position Miami as a model for resilient urban transformation. Sessions included in-person workshops at both the University of Miami and Florida International University, and online workshops. Florida International University hosted paper sessions, project sessions, panel sessions, and award sessions. Workshops In-person workshops explored cutting-edge fabrication techniques from bio-based and concrete 3D printing to robotic design and marine restoration highlighting innovative, sustainable, and adaptive approaches to material and structural creation. Online workshops covered topics ranging from neuroscience and climate intelligence to AI-driven design, timber joinery, and adaptive assembly. Behind the scenes at the ACADIA 2025 workshops hosted at the University of Miami School of Architecture Paper Sessions Technical papers accepted by ACADIA were presented in 10 sessions during the course of over three days. Cloud Garden: Neural Rendering and Point Cloud Modeling of Landscapes Day One Paper Sessions highlighted 3D printing and robotic fabrication, AI-driven landscape and coastal resilience strategies, and innovative material and biofabrication techniques. Day Two Paper Sessions highlighted robotic and textile-based fabrication, innovative timber construction and material reuse, and human-AI collaborative design and construction workflows. Day Three Paper Sessions highlighted the integration of AI and computational methods in architecture, spanning sustainable design, resilient housing, human-centered tools, and the cultural and social impact of emerging technologies. In thr first session of Day Three, PW Senior Researcher Marcelo Bernal presented ‚Äú Predicting Embodied Carbon Using Early Design Parameters and Machine Learning‚Äù . Marcelo worked on this paper with other PW notable researchers Jesce Walz , Victor Okhoya , Spyros Ampanavos . From Marcelo, ‚ÄúUnlike LCA which occurs at the end of the design process, early predictions can provide feedback on demand during conceptual design helping designers to indentify trends and make decision when matter they most.‚Äù Click here for more: Predicting Embodied Carbon Field Notes The Field Notes category is designed as an alternative publishing venue within ACADIA that welcomes experimental, provocative, and not-fully-polished ideas . Instead of traditional peer-reviewed technical papers, it creates space for shorter, more reflective, critical, and exploratory works that respond to the uncertainties, constraints, and shifting conditions of contemporary research and design practice. The work presented showcased innovative architectural research combining AR-enhanced pedagogy, playful and bio-inspired prototyping, and sustainable fabrication using natural, recycled, and growth-based materials. Some of the topics included Physics simulation for enhanced AR to teach students how to work with gravity instead of against it. Architectural reinterpretations of oyster shells to create modular interlocking systems. Training robotic arms to play with soap bubbles Utilizing Sargassum as an additive to concrete to enhance thermal performance. Projects Another series of published work that was presented was Projects which was divided into 3 sessions called Material Resilience, Crafting Resilience, and Territorial Resilience . They collectively explore how designers rethink assembly, craft, and inhabitation across scales‚Äîfrom wearable bio-materials to building systems and city-scale carbon futures‚Äîusing computation, digital precision, and material intelligence to challenge conventional practices and model new, enduring approaches for an uncertain future. Material Resilience explores how innovative bio-based, computational, and performance-driven materials, from wearable bioplastics and living composites to porous glass facades and 3D-printed ceramic enclosures, redefine assembly across scales, demonstrating new possibilities for sustainable, adaptive building systems. Crafting Resilience investigated climate-responsive design, adaptive and reversible construction, and bio-driven architectural systems from cooling furniture, kinetic structures, and AR-guided timber assembly to biodiversity-supporting facades, low-carbon vaults, kerf-bent frames, and architectures that grow or reconfigure over time. Territorial Resilience explored digital and robotic approaches to adaptive, resource-conscious architecture, including digital twins for live experimentation, AI-supported urban reuse strategies, frameworks for commercial-to-residential conversion, robotics that expand architectural practice, and feedback-driven methods for architectural recycling. DUAL Pavilion DUAL 3D Printed Pavillion 3D printed from recycled car tires, DUAL is the result of a collaboration between Pininfarina , Alpha Additive , Florida International University, and the University of Miami. This pavilion was on display at FIU‚Äôs Paul Cejas Architecture Building Summary ACADIA 2025 ultimately showcased how designers, researchers, and educators are redefining resilience through computation, demonstrating that innovative materials, adaptive fabrication, and forward-looking technologies can help shape more responsive, equitable, and climate-ready futures for Miami and beyond.

title: Revit Survey Winners
content: Revit Survey Prize Drawing Last month Digital Practice reached out to conduct a survey on how we can improve our design and deliver processes and tool development. We had an incredible number of folks respond and provide their valuable insights into their day-to-day work. As a thank you for taking part in the survey, we held a prize drawing with 3 randomly chosen winners and would like to take a moment to congratulate and thank each one of them! title: Core eXchange Q4 Recap
content: Q4 Core eXchange Recap! Thank you to all our Presenters! View the Recordings on The Digital Practice Exchange Library Back to Basics ‚Äì Setting a Consistent Foundation The most recent Digital Practice Core eXchange series focused on strengthening the fundamentals that connect our projects, tools, and people. Over the quarter, twelve sessions brought together 1,449 attendees representing 575 individuals from across studios, guided by 20 presenters sharing workflows, firmwide standards, and lessons learned. Across the full year, 47 Core eXchange sessions featured 65 presenters and reached 1,367 unique participants , totaling 5,662 attendees and 847 AIA Continuing Education Units . Together, these programs continue to reinforce our shared commitment to digital literacy, consistency, and collaboration across the firm. Looking Ahead The next Core eXchange cycle will continue to build on these foundations, introducing deeper content around automation, data visualization, and AI-assisted design workflows. All session recordings and slides are available in the Exchange Library on the Digital Practice site . Back to Basics Series Five Back to Basics sessions formed the foundation of this quarter‚Äôs program, each highlighting the essential workflows that drive coordinated project delivery and model health: Back to Basics with Revit ‚Äì scheduling, coordination, and model setup fundamentals. Back to Basics with Rhino ‚Äì modeling precision, Rhino 8 updates, and interoperability through Rhino.Inside Revit. Back to Basics: Visualization Tools ‚Äì choosing the right platform among Enscape, Twinmotion, V-Ray, Muse, and Firefly. Back to Basics with Area Sync ‚Äì synchronizing program data between Revit, Rhino, and Power BI. Back to Basics: Documentation, Publishing, and Printing ‚Äì firm standards for Bluebeam Studio, BIM 360 publishing, and sPRINT printing. Together, these sessions anchored the quarter‚Äôs learning, complemented by focused presentations on AVAIL content management , code compliance workflows , and an Introduction to Digital Practice . Collectively, the quarter‚Äôs content generated 178 AIA Continuing Education Units , reflecting strong participation and practical skill-building across studios.

title: Buildings That Breathe, Robots That Care ‚Äî Highlights from Sidara London 2025
content: Last month, our very own Leigh Stringer , Global Director of Advisory Services, and Raja R. Kadiyala , Sidara‚Äôs Global Head of Digital Solutions, hosted The Digitally Enabled Built Environment event at 150 Holborn ‚Äî a half-day that somehow managed to feel like both a research symposium and a tech show-and-tell. In a few short hours, we moved from robots supporting people living with frailty , to soft-robotic environments that sense emotion , to AI monitoring biodiversity in cities , through to technology disruption in AEC , the digital twin of 150 Holborn , and finally building analytics and portfolio-scale decarbonisation . It was fast, fascinating, and occasionally a bit mind-bending ‚Äî but every talk circled back to the same question: How do we use data and automation to make environments that care, respond, and learn? Jump to a session: ü§ñ Robots for Care and Frailty üèóÔ∏è Soft Robotic Architecture üåø Sensing Garden: AI for Biodiversity ‚öôÔ∏è Technology Disruption in AEC üè¢ 150 Holborn: The Living Smart Building üß† Automated Building Analytics üåé Decarbonisation at Scale Robots for Care and Frailty ‚Äî UCL Bartlett & Centre for Behaviour Change Dr Evangelia Chrysikou and Dr Vivi Antonopoulou reminded us that innovation in care is as much about empathy as engineering. Their UCL‚ÄìCardiff collaboration studied how people living with frailty interact with commercial robots like Mylo and Pepper in real homes ‚Äî not pristine lab conditions. They found that people liked the friendly presence and simple voice control ‚Äî in fact, robots were seen as ‚ÄúStar Trek-like‚Äù companions. But poor connectivity, narrow corridors, and an understandable reluctance to rely on tech too much all created barriers. A key image showed The Robot House, mapping where these robots could actually move ‚Äî mostly living rooms and corridors, rarely kitchens or bathrooms. The message was clear: our homes aren‚Äôt designed for robots, and robots aren‚Äôt yet designed for our homes. The takeaway for us as designers? We need to think about how people, places, and technology work together ‚Äî not in isolation. Soft Robotic Architecture (UCL PEARL) If the first session was about robots living with people, this one was about spaces that behave like robots. Dr Valentina Soana and Professor Nick Tyler showcased ELAmorph , a shape-changing environment that uses sensors to respond to human movement, stress, and emotion. Participants literally watched the space breathe with them ‚Äî and the physiological data backed it up. The team combined biometric sensing and motion analysis to track brain activity, heart rate, posture, and temperature. It sounds futuristic, but the response was very human ‚Äî participants described the experience as calming, fun, and emotionally uplifting. All of this took place at PEARL (Person‚ÄìEnvironment‚ÄìActivity Research Laboratory) in Dagenham ‚Äî a full-scale research facility designed by Perkins & Will London . It‚Äôs purpose-built for exactly this kind of experimentation: exploring how light, sound, and movement affect perception. The bigger idea? Architecture as a living interface ‚Äî spaces that don‚Äôt just measure performance, but respond to emotion. It‚Äôs a glimpse of where our own digital-twin and sensor-driven projects might evolve ‚Äî buildings that genuinely listen, learn, and adapt Sensing Garden: AI for Biodiversity (MIT / Sidara) The Sensing Garden , from MIT‚Äôs Senseable City Lab in partnership with Sidara, took us outdoors ‚Äî into cities and ecosystems. It asks how technology can help us see and measure biodiversity in real time. With global COP biodiversity goals and the UK‚Äôs 10 % net-gain requirement, this research feels especially timely. https://digitalpractice.perkinswill.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/Video-Project-18.mp4 Treepedia visualises the ‚Äúgreen view‚Äù from street level, helping cities measure and compare visible canopy cover The project layers several sensing methods: ‚Ä¢ Infrared and satellite imagery to track vegetation and temperature patterns. ‚Ä¢ LiDAR and vegetation indices to measure canopy density, health, and moisture. ‚Ä¢ Acoustic and visual AI models to identify insects and birds by sound or movement, plus e-DNA sampling to confirm which species are actually present. Together, these datasets create a live ecological ‚Äútwin‚Äù ‚Äî showing how life interacts with streets, buildings, and microclimates. MIT‚Äôs earlier tools ‚Äî Treepedia (‚Äúgreen view‚Äù), Diversitree (biodiversity tracking), and Green Bias (access inequality) ‚Äî now combine into a single platform for biodiversity intelligence . It‚Äôs a shift from symbolic greening to evidence-based ecology ‚Äî quantifying how design decisions really affect urban ecosystems In short: the next generation of smart-city tools won‚Äôt just count people or carbon ‚Äî they‚Äôll measure life itself. Technology Disruption in AEC (Sidara) Dr Raja Kadiyala‚Äôs session reframed ‚Äúdisruption‚Äù as something to harness, not fear. He began with a story from science: at Cyclotron Road in Berkeley, a group of physicists, chemists, and engineers built one of the first particle accelerators nearly a century ago ‚Äî sparking innovations from X-ray imaging to CRISPR The point wasn‚Äôt nostalgia ‚Äî it was perspective. True disruption happens when disciplines collide Raja then unveiled Sidara‚Äôs Periodic Table of Disruptors ‚Äî a taxonomy of over 100 emerging technologies grouped into: Data Ecosystems Extreme Automation Human Augmentation Human‚ÄìMachine Interactions The Smart Planet Each ‚Äúelement‚Äù links back to research and industry examples ‚Äî from IoT and 6G to building cybersecurity and edge computing. Rather than chasing every trend, he proposed a simple framework: Hold ‚Üí Assess ‚Üí Pilot ‚Üí Adopt. That structure turns innovation into a living roadmap , helping teams invest deliberately rather than reactively. For us, the message hit home: digital is horizontal. It crosses disciplines, workflows, and mindsets ‚Äî and transformation depends as much on culture as on code. 150 Holborn: The Living Smart Building ‚Äî Sidara / PARA The day‚Äôs theory met reality with 150 Holborn ‚Äî Sidara‚Äôs new HQ and our own London studio ‚Äî positioned as a Living Lab for the group. The PARA team described the journey from blue-sky concept in 2016 to a fully connected, data-driven workplace in 2025. A single converged network now links lighting, access, occupancy, energy, and ESG reporting. Over 650 sensors collect data every five minutes across 18 500 m¬≤ , feeding a live digital twin that visualises performance, comfort, and sustainability. For the London studio , this was also the first outing for our Digital Advisory service ‚Äî where we managed design and construction data to ensure handover through a structured platform rather than a folder of PDFs. It proved how information can be captured once, structured properly, and reused throughout the building‚Äôs lifecycle ‚Äî and that process has since become a model for other clients. The result is a workspace that continuously learns and adjusts ‚Äî reducing energy, improving wellbeing, and supporting FM decisions with evidence rather than instinct. PARA called it the building‚Äôs digital nervous system , which feels about right. And while claims of being ‚Äúone of the smartest buildings‚Äù are hard to measure, the Living Lab idea is real. It‚Äôs where our digital-twin thinking moved from theory to practice , proving that data-centric delivery can create lasting value for both owners and occupants. 150 Holborn is now where clients come to see the art of the possible ‚Äî where design, data, and operations truly meet. Automated Building Analytics (CopperTree Analytics) If 150 Holborn shows what‚Äôs possible when you design smart from day one, CopperTree Analytics (part of Sidara) shows how to make existing buildings smarter. COO Derek Mullassery presented a platform that unifies disconnected systems ‚Äî BMS, meters, CAFM, CMMS ‚Äî through an Independent Data Layer . Once everything‚Äôs speaking the same language, Fault Detection and Diagnostics (FDD) finds inefficiencies, and Automated System Optimisation (ASO) fine-tunes performance in real time. Results: ‚Ä¢ ¬£623 000 gas savings at a UK healthcare facility in five years ‚Ä¢ 15‚Äì30 % energy reductions across US university campuses ‚Ä¢ Continuous commissioning replacing reactive maintenance With ageing FM workforces and growing ESG pressures, this kind of automation frees teams to focus on strategy, not spreadsheets. It delivers digital-twin benefits after handover ‚Äî bridging the gap between design ambition and operational reality. For portfolio clients, CopperTree effectively becomes a digital retrofit for performance ‚Äî a scalable way to measure, benchmark, and improve every building, not just the newest ones. Decarbonisation at Scale (Carbon Signal) Where CopperTree optimises one building at a time, Carbon Signal scales that intelligence across entire portfolios. Carbon Signal applies physics-based modelling and AI to help organisations decarbonise building portfolios at scale. Dr Shreshth Nagpal introduced a method that blends physics-based energy modelling with AI autocalibration , closing what he calls the building-energy intelligence gap. Traditional consultancy models are accurate but slow; AI-only tools are fast but often fuzzy. Carbon Signal merges the two ‚Äî rapid, rigorous, and repeatable. Feed it a handful of metrics ‚Äî size, climate zone, energy use ‚Äî and it infers insulation, air-tightness, and lighting efficiency, generating reliable simulations across thousands of buildings. Already used by MIT, Yale, and Amazon , the platform has modelled over 10 000 buildings covering 1.5 billion ft¬≤ , cutting analysis time from months to minutes and enabling science-based retrofit strategies. If 150 Holborn shows how a building can be born smart , and CopperTree shows how an existing one can learn , then Carbon Signal shows how whole portfolios can act together ‚Äî intelligently and at speed ‚Äî to achieve net zero. Final Thought Across every session, one theme stood out: digital transformation is still about people. From robotics to biodiversity, from smart workplaces to portfolio analytics ‚Äî the common thread was empathy and intent. The challenge for us isn‚Äôt just to build smarter tools; it‚Äôs to keep asking smarter questions ‚Äî about who benefits, how systems interact, and how we design for change that actually lasts.

title: AECTech+ Boston 2025 Recap
content: AEC Tech Boston 9/19 ‚Äì 9/21/2025 In September, AECTech+ Boston represented the launch of a new regional chapter of the AEC Tech community. Co-hosted by Perkins&Will and Thornton Tomasetti, the inaugural event brought the energy and ethos of the long-running New York conference into a new city with a strong academic and innovation ecosystem. From the start, the focus remained true to what makes AEC Tech distinct: practitioner-driven content that shares real workflows, real challenges, and real breakthroughs from design technology professionals. This first edition introduced Boston‚Äôs growing network of computational designers, sustainability leaders, and digital practice innovators to the AEC Tech format: a multi-day program including workshops, a Tech Tour, a symposium, and a hackathon. Attendees represented a mix of leading firms and ambitious students from local institutions, affirming Boston as a natural home for this expansion of the conference series. The speaker lineup highlighted both global thought leaders and emerging voices, demonstrating an emphasis on the future of design computation. Across sessions, presenters showcased automation strategies, data-driven design, interdisciplinary research, and entrepreneurial tools accelerating change in the built environment. Perkins&Will played a central role throughout the event, contributing organizers, speakers, and participants for the workshops and hackathon. The studio also partnered on the Tech Tour, creating opportunities for candid discussion about integrating advanced technology in live project delivery. AECTech+ Boston‚Äôs success in its first year signals a growing regional hub for AEC innovation. The energy from this inaugural gathering set a strong foundation for continued collaboration and reinforces the value of practitioners shaping the next generation of design technology together. Hackathon Participation A hackathon brings architects, engineers, and construction professionals together to rapidly experiment, prototype, and solve real challenges in the built-environment. Teams form around shared ideas and apply computational tools, automation, and creative problem-solving to push the boundaries of how we design, deliver, and operate buildings. The AECTech+ Boston hackathon ran as a 26-hour sprint from Saturday to Sunday morning. Nearly 40 participants hit the ground running, pitching ideas in a lightning round that quickly sparked collaboration. By early morning, seven teams emerged, with Perkins&Will contributing talent to more than half of them. The atmosphere was energetic, focused, and full of possibility. Thanks to our Perkins&Will teams who made it to the event (and even won some of the awards!) (Okay, all of the awards!). FirstPass Perkins&Will Participation from: Elif Unsal, PW NYO Rubber Duc(t) Perkins&Will Participation from: Anthony Samaha, PW NYO Victor Wanderley Barbosa, SHL Monkeys on Keyboards Perkins&Will Participation from: Luke Gehron, PW Corporate Harish Palani, PW DAL PreVu Perkins&Will Participation from: Jason Pieper, PW BOS Nirvik Saha, PW Corporate Thank you to all participants! Hackathon: Abhishek Shinde (TYLin) Nirvik Saha (PW I/O) Jason Pieper (PW CHI) Raja Kadiyala (Sidara) Luke Gehron (PW Corporate) Elif Unsal (PW NYO) Anthony Samaha (PW NYO) Victor Wanderley Barbosa (SHL) Charlie Portelli (PW I/O) Harish Palani (PW DAL) Special Help from: Daniel Prager (PW BOS) Sergio Riccardi (PW BOS) Iffat Mai (PW Corporate)

title: Innovation Incubator Fall 2025 Open Comment Period
content: Now in its 15th year, the Innovation Incubator program helps staff across Perkins&Will‚Äîand our partners at McLennan Design, Nelson\Nygaard, Portland Design Associates, PYR, Schmidt Hammer Lassen, and Access Planning‚Äîpursue original ideas through small grants of time and resources. These micro-grants support focused investigations that test new methods, explore emerging technologies, and address meaningful questions in design. The program aims to nurture creativity and curiosity across disciplines, encouraging projects that advance sustainability, social purpose, and design excellence within the firm and the broader industry. Each proposal is evaluated on innovation, relevance, and feasibility . Successful entries clearly describe what makes the idea new, why it matters to our work, and how it can be carried out within a realistic scope. While formats vary, the strongest proposals are concise, thoughtful, and connected to Perkins&Will‚Äôs research areas or active projects. The Innovation Incubator continues to serve as a platform for inquiry‚Äîencouraging experimentation, collaboration, and progress across all parts of our practice. The Fall 2025 Innovation Incubator Open Comment Period is now open. Forty-two proposals are available for review on the Innovation Submissions HUB App through Monday, October 13, at 11 a.m. ET . Take a moment to read through the submissions and share your feedback‚Äîyour comments can help shape which projects move forward.

title: Revit US template update and Avail 2025 release
content: Revit Template Update Last week, we rolled out our Revit US Template update. It was truly collaborative effort between a Technical Directors Community and a group of Revit experts from Digital Practice. Most notable improvements were made to Code Compliance Workflow . Code Compliance is a fundamental aspect of every project. This workflow improves consistency, traceability, and clarity in how occupancy and egress requirements are applied and communicated. It helps teams go beyond just ‚Äúchecking a box‚Äù by integrating code interpretation into the design process itself. By visually tying design intent to compliance, it reduces errors, increases confidence during permit reviews, and supports safer, more efficient buildings. It ensures code-related information is clearly represented in the model and coordinated across documentation. While not automated, the workflow helps teams illustrate and validate compliance with local code requirements‚Äîsupporting both internal reviews and conversations with AHJs. As your studios start using this new template, you may want to review the process. It is thoroughly documented in this Palette card Code Compliance: Occupancy & Egress In addition to revamping Code compliance workflow, there were some minor changes, including deletion of unused parameters, updates to Finish workflow, and general cleanup. All studio templates based on this version of US template will have a version number above 10 Avail Channel for Revit 2025 To improve findability and relevancy of Revit content, we released new channel for 2025 Imperial content. Items in this channel are already upgraded to 2025, so they can be used faster. We also discarded never used and outdated content. However if you need something for the projects in old Revit versions, the old channel is still there. To find appropriate channel, use channel groups. Below are some common scenarios for searches within new channel: Healthcare rooms with equipment Standard Casework Pack Sheets Code compliance Sheets For recorded training in Avail, please Click Here

title: BIM World Copenhagen 2025 Recap
content: On 16‚Äì17 September, a few of us from SHL attended BIM World Copenhagen. The event was full of inspiring talks and showcases that touched on digital innovation, AI, sustainability, and new regulatory frameworks shaping our industry. Here are some highlights that caught our attention: Exploring Solibri CheckPoint in BIM Workflows ‚Äì Max Thorup Due (DK), NTI For years, Solibri has been a reliable desktop BIM checker. Now, it‚Äôs stepping into the cloud with Solibri CheckPoint ‚Äî a browser-based, cloud-enabled model-checking tool. It supports native Revit and IFC files, allowing clash detection, data validation, and free-space checks directly in the browser, without heavy installs. It integrates with Autodesk Construction Cloud (ACC) and Procore, streamlining issue tracking and model syncing across platforms. Max showed how CheckPoint can be embedded into BIM workflows: federating models, applying rulesets, checking designs early, and managing issues collaboratively. For us in Copenhagen, this felt like a turning point: Solibri is finally catching up with the cloud-based, collaborative direction the industry has already taken. It hasn‚Äôt been released yet ‚Äî but it looks promising. Data Workflow in the Danish Context (Data in Action ‚Äì From Requirement to Impact) This session followed a state client project to show how data flows across all stages of the danish project cycle: ICT Manager/Client: collects requirements and documents them in an ICT manual for all disciplines. Consultants: set and update design parameters during development. Cost & Carbon Specialists: receive the data, which must be formatted to allow accurate analysis. Contractor: uses the data for validation, quantity take-off, and delivery. Client (handover): performs final checks and feeds data into facility management systems. The session underscored the risks of poor data practice, but also the benefits when structured processes are consistently followed by all disciplines in ideal project in ideal world. The Dirty Truth: How Much Do You Really Know About Carbon in Construction? ‚Äì Matthew Jackson, ZERO Construct Matthew Jackson made a strong case for carbon literacy. Construction accounts for ~12% of global CO‚ÇÇ (‚âà4.5B tons/year), and even a small share of decision-makers in our 275M-person industry have ~35√ó the carbon impact of the average person. Every decision ‚Äî from material specifications to site supplies ‚Äî matters. He introduced ZERO Construct, a 3,000-strong not-for-profit community creating a ‚ÄúWikipedia for carbon‚Äù with open knowledge, workshops, playful tools like Carbon Top Trumps, and the upcoming ZeroCon event. Importantly, he engaged the audience with a live quiz (complete with prizes! Which I won) that made the session fun, interactive, and memorable. We wish more presentations used this format: clear numbers, practical steps, and participation. Watch Matthew‚Äôs talk here (recorded at another event): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dBiPDnv4gBI Here is my dropping my reward on stage: AI and Opportunities for Women in Construction ‚Äì Elia Gonz√°lez Salas, CEO of KOSMOS & representant of Women in BIM Elia highlighted the urgent challenges in construction: women still make up only 9‚Äì10% of the workforce, while labour shortages are rising fast (the US alone will need 439,000 new workers by 2025). At the same time, AI is opening doors to new roles such as BIM Strategist, Data Translator, AI Product Manager, and Data Quality Lead ‚Äî positions that thrive on curiosity, communication, and leadership, where women are especially well-placed to excel. She showed how KOSMOS is already applying AI (or not really AI) in procurement, document management, data modelling, and risk analysis. But she also stressed that inconsistent data and labelling remain barriers to accuracy ‚Äî highlighting the need for standards and collaboration. Her closing message: construction is not just being digitized, it‚Äôs being rebuilt. If you‚Äôre in construction, explore technology. If you‚Äôre in tech, learn construction. And if you‚Äôre a woman questioning your place in this transformation ‚Äî you absolutely belong. Learn more about Women in BIM organization: https://womeninbim.org/ I‚Äôve personally been part of their mentoring scheme and found it a great experience in knowledge sharing. Sorry, We Had to Create a New Open BIM Format ‚Äì Antonio Gonzalez Viegas, That Open Company Antonio, an architect turned software developer, compared construction software to the video game industry. While games can be built by small teams using engines, construction software still relies on outdated, proprietary systems that stifle innovation. His question was bold: what if we built a ‚Äúgame engine‚Äù for construction? This idea became Fragments, a new open-source BIM format that overcomes IFC‚Äôs limitations. Unlike IFC STEP, which is heavy, inconsistent, and slow, Fragments is lightweight and fast: it allows gigabyte-sized models to load in seconds, scale from city view to a single bolt, and run smoothly in a browser. It also supports property data, compression, and interoperability with glTF and 3D Tiles. Long-term, it aims not just for viewing, but also editing and authoring ‚Äî and it‚Äôs all free and open source. The takeaway: construction deserves tools as modern, accessible, and flexible as other industries enjoy. With projects like Fragments sound and look promising. Watch the talk here(recorded at different event): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZUiG6Jz-X-w Explore Fragments documentation: https://docs.thatopen.com/Tutorials/Fragments/ Use of AI at Henning Larsen ‚Äì Jakob Str√∏mann-Andersen, Innovation & Sustainability Director Jakob shared how Henning Larsen uses AI to support both creativity and efficiency. In competitions, their creative teams use AI to produce visuals and test ideas quickly ‚Äî without losing creative control. For time-consuming tasks, like processing 50+ client documents, they used NotebookLM to answer questions and point directly to relevant files. This dialogue-based approach even worked across different languages, making collaboration easier for international teams. Jakob emphasized that AI doesn‚Äôt replace creativity ‚Äî it frees it. By taking on repetitive work, AI lets designers focus on design, while also strengthening decision-making. He described how AI can even be used in real time during client meetings to test ideas and visualize solutions on the spot. This presentation was intresting to watch as in SHL we worked on few of the same competitions. Data is King: Realizing Circular Dreams ‚Äì software showcase, Johana Rodriguez (JLL Design Lab), Brian Chiou (Reseat), Ren DeCherney (Cradle to Cradle Institute) This panel tackled a key challenge: sustainability data is everywhere, but often inaccurate or unusable. To make real impact, it needs to be accurate, structured, and actionable. Brian Chiou presented Reseat, a platform creating digital product passports for furniture. Every item gets a ‚ÄúReseat ID‚Äù to track its lifecycle: condition, location, and history. When no longer needed, the system supports resale, donation, or refurbishment instead of disposal, backed by a marketplace and dealer/manufacturer integrations. By making data shareable and trustworthy, Reseat helps quantify carbon savings and reduce waste ‚Äî a scalable way to bring circular economy principles into workplace design and operations. Learn more about Reseat here: https://www.reseat.com/ New EU Regulation: Digital Product Passports for Construction Products ‚Äì Lars Christian Fredenlund, Co-founder, Cobuilder As part of Europe‚Äôs green and digital transition, the revised Construction Products Regulation (CPR) will require Digital Product Passports (DPPs) for all construction products in the EU/EEA market. Product data will now include Environmental Product Declarations (EPDs), structured via a European Data Dictionary, making it machine-readable and interoperable. Lars explained how these passports will link directly into BIM, EDI-order systems, and digital twins ‚Äî embedding product data across design, construction, operations, compliance, and sustainability reporting. For us in Copenhagen and across the EU, this feels like a big step forward: moving from static PDFs to standardized, connected, and actionable product data. This will reshape procurement, compliance, and carbon reporting in the built environment.

title: Data Dash 2025
content: Last week, we wrapped up Data Dash 2025 ‚Äîa firmwide effort to make our project data more accurate, consistent, and accessible. Over the course of the initiative, teams across the firm strengthened more than 700 project records , contributing to a total dataset of over 1,300 projects spanning studios and practice areas worldwide. The effort was truly collaborative: studio leads, project managers, and ‚Äúdata dashers‚Äù worked together to review and enhance information such as project names, hero images, keywords, team members, construction costs, and awards. Keywords received a major refresh, ensuring more reliable search results going forward. A live leaderboard kept momentum high, and the competitive spirit fueled accuracy and completion across studios. All of this work lays the foundation for the launch of our new project database, Portfolio , coming this fall. With searchable, marketing-ready project records, we‚Äôll be able to produce stronger proposals, tell our project stories more effectively, and save valuable time for design and delivery. Thanks again to everyone who contributed their time and expertise, we couldn‚Äôt have done it without you!

title: Digital Practice Open Office Hours
content: A Space to Ask, Share, and Get Assistance: Digital Practice Office Hours Sometimes all you need is five minutes with the right person. That‚Äôs the idea behind Digital Practice Office Hours . A simple format that‚Äôs become a consistent, low-barrier channel for support across our studios. Structured as a series of daily 1-hour virtual sessions, they are a direct line to Digital Practice expertise and are designed to be informal, low-friction sessions where anyone in the firm can drop in with a question, roadblock, or idea and get the help you need. No tickets. No prep. Just time set aside to help each other out. Whether you‚Äôre troubleshooting a modeling issue, need a second opinion on a coordination approach, or are looking for a quick walkthrough of a digital tool, Office Hours are a space to ask questions and get support when you need it. Each session is hosted by two Digital Practice representatives and follows a consistent weekly schedule: Time (ET) Mon Tue Wed Thu Fri 5am ‚Äî ‚úì ‚úì ‚Äî ‚Äî 6am ‚Äî ‚Äî ‚Äî ‚úì ‚úì 9am ‚úì ‚úì ‚úì ‚úì ‚úì 12pm ‚úì ‚úì ‚úì ‚úì ‚úì 3pm ‚úì ‚úì ‚úì ‚úì ‚úì 6pm ‚úì ‚úì ‚úì ‚úì ‚úì Sessions take place in our Digital Practice Teams general channel . Just look for this banner: You can join for a few minutes or stay for the hour‚Äîwhatever fits your need. Open Office Hours are firmwide and all are welcome to attend!

title: The Current State of Generative AI at Perkins&Will (2025 Edition)

author.name: Nick Cameron
author.description: American trucker who has been featured on the History channel reality television series Ice Road Truckers and its spinoff series IRT: Deadliest Roads.

content: In our previous blog post, titled ‚ÄúTrust but Verify,‚Äù we emphasized the importance of verification when working with generative AI tools. Today, we will delve deeper into how Perkins&Will is actively exploring the use of generative AI throughout the firm and how we can facilitate the sharing and learning process in this rapidly evolving technology landscape. Additionally, we will introduce the Perkins&Will guidelines for using generative AI. At Perkins&Will, various groups including the Project Delivery, Research, & Technology Boards and Human Resources are fully engaged in prioritizing a comprehensive understanding of generative AI‚Äôs potential and its impact on our firm and industry. Furthermore, studios like Boston and Vancouver have been hosting internal discussions, exchanging insights, and collaborating to explore the possibilities of generative AI. We extend an invitation to join and contribute to the broader conversation happening within our studios and across other teams in the firm. By gathering diverse perspectives, we enable a critical evaluation of generative AI‚Äôs capabilities. To promote wider engagement and ongoing conversations, we have established a new AI channel in the Digital Practice Teams space, click here to join in . This channel serves as an open platform for everyone to participate, contribute ideas, and share knowledge. By opening up the conversation, we tap into the collective intelligence and expertise of our firm, expanding our understanding of what may be possible while also being mindful of potential pitfalls. Looking ahead, our upcoming Core Exchange in July (email invites to follow) will feature a keynote address by an external AI expert. We also have plans to organize panels that will discuss the current state of AI within our firm and explore the future possibilities in our industry. These panels foster collaboration within Perkins&Will and encourage dialogue with external experts, ensuring our firm remains at the forefront of technological advancements. Lastly, we are pleased to include a copy of the Perkins&Will guidelines for using generative AI below. These guidelines serve as a reference for employees, contractors, and third parties who use generative AI technology on behalf of our firm. They suggest parameters within which the use of generative AI aligns with our values, legal and ethical standards, and protects the interests of all stakeholders involved. By nurturing collaboration across boards, studios, and through the Digital Practice Teams Channel, Perkins&Will leverages its collective intelligence to ensure the responsible use of generative AI. Together, we will navigate this exciting technological landscape while delivering exceptional solutions to our clients and elevating the AI employee learning experience.

title: Innovation Incubator Autumn 2024: The Immersion Lab
content: The Immersion Lab: Redefining Design Interaction As part of the Autumn 2024 grantees, we were selected to develop our idea/ project called the Immersion Lab. The Immersion Lab aimed to create an animated platform based on Design Options using open-source tools. While the animation aspect wasn‚Äôt fully completed, we developed a fully cloud-based framework and website outlining our workflow. The application integrates with Speckle, allowing staff to log in, connect their Speckle account, select design options, and view them in a customizable viewer. The client section provides restricted access to specific design options. This foundation sets the stage for future customization and animation within the same platform. 3 Simple-ish Steps Step 01 Tools Tools Google Tile and Blender 3.JS Interactive Viewer Tools Tools Step 02 Step 03 Tools Tools Speckle Embedded Viewer Immersion Lab App Heart Heart End Goal Step 01 BLOSM -> Blender Step 02 BLOSM ->Blender -> Javascript -> 3JS Viewer Step 03 Software of choice -> Speckle Auth -> Speckle ->WebGL ->Speckle Viewer Immersion Lab App Try it now by clicking the link below! Vite App More information click here: Hub ‚Äì Innovation Library Snagging Authentication through speckle could be smoother page composition and sizing stability faster load times with the viewer Wishlist Client-Side App Simpler Process to start up Gismo ‚Äì Move elements in the viewer Customisable landing page/ dashboard Thanks to Will and Preston on kicking off this 3JS PW Journey Victor Barbosa and Daniel Boba on troubleshooting and advice To the wider DP team for support LDN Magdalen Street Team for letting us use this project as an example. title: Core eXchange Q3 Recap
content: Q3 Core eXchange Recap! Thank you to all our Presenters! View the Recordings on The Digital Practice Exchange Library This quarter‚Äôs Digital Practice Core eXchange brought together twenty colleagues from across the firm to share updates, workflows, and experiments shaping our project delivery. Over the course of twelve sessions, we covered a wide range of topics from accessibility standards and sustainable materials to hands-on tools for project planning and visualization. Many sessions focused on practical improvements to daily work, including updates to PMTK , Portfolio Explorer , and AVAIL , along with documentation workflows for Finishes and Casework . Others provided a deeper dive into specialized areas like Barrier-free Design , biological materials , and Building Integrated Agriculture . Across the board, the level of engagement and willingness to share real-world use cases stood out. These sessions continue to create space for experimentation and cross-studio learning, helping us improve both how we work and what we deliver. Thank you to the 1,271 participants who showed up! All the sessions are saved to the Digital Practice Exchange Library: Click Here Theme Sessions: AI in Practice Three sessions from this Core eXchange focused specifically on how teams across Perkins&Will are using AI tools in real project work. If you‚Äôre still figuring out where AI fits into your day-to-day, these are a great place to start. In ‚ÄúVibe Coding,‚Äù Harish Palani and Michael Honyak shared how they‚Äôre using large language models to automate repetitive, high-effort tasks‚Äîlike scripting in AutoCAD or processing data in Excel. They walked through how to frame a problem clearly for an LLM, how to vet the output, and when it actually makes sense to use AI in production work. Meanwhile, ‚ÄúElevating AI‚Äù with Brian Parish and Sergio Riccardi focused on firm-wide guidance, including what tools are approved, how to use them safely, and examples of in-house tools like Muse and RFP Navigator. ‚ÄúApplied AI Visualization,‚Äù led by Harish Palani, Anthony Samaha, and Michael Honyak offered a look at design visualization using platforms like Adobe Firefly‚Äîhelping teams bridge the gap between sketches and early concept visuals, all while staying mindful of licensing and client privacy. If you‚Äôre wondering how AI fits into architecture and design beyond just headlines, these three sessions are a solid starting point. They‚Äôre focused, practical, and directly tied to the work many of us are already doing. Watch the AI Visualization presentation here Watch the Elevating AI presentation here Watch the Vibe Coding presentation here AI Sessions

content: Exploring AI‚Äôs Potential at Perkins&Will: A Core Exchange Overview For over 90 years, Perkins&Will has been a leader in technological innovations that advance the design and delivery process. Our exploration of Artificial Intelligence (AI) continues this tradition, focusing on amplifying creativity and quality while ensuring client satisfaction. At the same time, we are vigilant about addressing critical issues such as bias and energy consumption, ensuring we remain true to our values. As we shift from experimentation to implementing AI-powered workflows, our recent Core Exchange sessions have highlighted several promising areas of exploration. Recent Sessions The ‚Äú Elevating AI ‚Äù session focused on aligning AI, data platforms, and automation with our design processes and client requirements, showcasing our current initiatives and future goals. The ‚Äú Vibe Coding ‚Äù session offered a hands-on exploration of visual programming and code-based design, emphasizing parametric logic and the role of intuition in shaping design. Invitation for Collaboration and Feedback In this fast-evolving field of AI, maintaining a robust feedback loop with everyone in the firm is crucial. We particularly encourage our design teams to share their insights, ideas, and concerns. Please reach out via email, Teams, or by scheduling a meeting with your local digital practice leaders. Our AI guidelines , are below. Additionally, you can review our latest Digital Innovation blog post to learn about past experiments. Loading... Taking too long?
