title: Revit Add-In Monthly Shoutout ‚Äì JOTools
content: JOTools We‚Äôre starting a new segment this month. Welcome to the first ever Digital Practice Revit Add-In Shoutout! This month we‚Äôre going to shine a light on JOTools. ‚ÄúAn advanced way to transfer content and standards between one file and another.‚Äù This is a very simple tool with only three features, but very powerful. Let‚Äôs take a look. Mass Load Families Pretty straightforward. Need to load a large number of families into your project? Don‚Äôt load them one by one, load them all at once. Mass Save Families Just finished a project and your team created an amazing set of families and now you want to upload to your studio‚Äôs Avail Revit library. Mass Save Families is your best friend now. Transfer Single Ok, Transfer Single is going to be your new jam. Ever wanted to transfer just one material from one project to another, but Transfer Project Standards only lets you copy the entire material library? Well now you can. How about copying Levels? Yup. Worksets? Absolutely. Take a moment to open up JOTools and see how powerful this simple tool is.

title: Revit plugin of the month: Avail content management
content: üöÄ Exciting News from Digital Practice! Avail Just Got Better! üöÄ One of the most widely used Revit plugins at Perkins&Will is Avail ‚Äì our powerful Content Management System. While it can handle just about any file type, we primarily rely on Avail to organize and distribute our Revit content: loadable and system families, drafting views, live legends, standard sheets, and even view templates. Over the years, Perkins&Will has developed, organized, and published a vast library of high-quality Revit content using Avail. We continue to work closely with the Avail development team to make content easier to find and use. With our global scale and diverse regional needs, Avail plays a crucial role in ensuring everyone across the firm can access the right content for their projects. üåü New Avail Version Released ‚Äì June 1 üåü If you haven‚Äôt updated yet, please head over to the Company Portal and install the latest version today! Improvements in this version are: ‚úÖ Channel Grouping Easily browse channels with improved structure! For example, U.S. users will now see only two streamlined channels: ‚Ä¢ Regular & Most Popular Revit Content (2022‚Äì2023) ‚Ä¢ Patterns Channel (yes‚Äîwe have a whole channel for patterns!) Visualization content (like RPC) is now grouped together too. ‚úÖ Multi-Object Downloading You asked, we listened! Now you can select multiple objects and download them in one go‚Äîmuch faster and more efficient. ‚úÖ Introducing: Palettes! Palettes are an exciting new feature that lets users create custom, temporary collections of content, even across multiple channels. Perfect for project-specific bundles or team collaboration. Best of all‚Äîanyone can create one! Expect this feature to get even more powerful as Avail rolls out additional management tools. The training refresh for Avail was flawlessly delivered by Devon Bush . üõ†Ô∏è Upcoming Improvements to PW Revit Content We‚Äôre working hard to upgrade and re-publish our content in the Revit 2025 format. This includes: Updated drafting views and sheets Refined workflow-related packages A more intuitive content structure Launch is targeted for August‚ÄìSeptember. Don‚Äôt worry‚Äîolder channels for previous versions will still be available for ongoing projects. üîÆ Looking Ahead: Avail‚Äôs Roadmap for Even Better Searchability ‚ú® Managed Palettes ‚Äì Share and control shared palettes with ease ‚ú® File Sets ‚Äì Automatically get the right content based on your Revit version ‚ú® OCR-Powered Search ‚Äì All text in views and sheets will be indexed and searchable! üí¨ We Want Your Feedback! Your input drives improvement. Please continue to share your thoughts and suggestions with the Digital Practice team. Let‚Äôs build the best Revit experience‚Äîtogether!

title: A Fresh Start: Updated PowerPoint Template Now Available
content: We‚Äôre excited to roll out a refreshed PowerPoint template that aligns with our focus on simplification ‚Äîa key pillar of Phil‚Äôs 2025 Strategic Agenda. This isn‚Äôt a dramatic redesign, but rather a purposeful refinement that‚Äôs cleaner and easier to use so you can spend less time formatting and more time doing what matters: improving the world through design. What‚Äôs Changed‚Äîand Why? Gone are the hand-drawn doodles, arrows, and underlines. They had their charm, we‚Äôre pulling back on superfluous graphics to make your content clearer and reduce visual noise‚Äîso your ideas can shine. What‚Äôs New? Bug Fixes: Some of the quirks from the previous version (yes, we noticed them too!) have been addressed. Text alignment issues, inconsistent font sizes, and broken placeholders are all squashed. Simplified Design: We‚Äôve removed unnecessary visuals to give your content the spotlight it deserves. The updated template provides a sleek, polished look that reflects our brand and expertise. Improved Team Slides: Expanded grid layouts make it easier to present people and roles without manual formatting. Improved Layout Options: New slide layouts that include sidebars allow you to call out supplemental or comparative information without clutter. So Fresh, So Clean! We know it‚Äôs tempting to reuse old decks‚Äîbut we encourage you to embrace the clean slate this new template offers. Starting fresh ensures you‚Äôre working with the most efficient tools and keeps your presentations aligned with our updated visual standards. It‚Äôs easy to find: simply open PowerPoint and go to File > New and like magic you‚Äôll be in the new template. Our presentations are an extension of our brand and our expertise. By using the new template, you‚Äôre helping us communicate with greater clarity and impact‚Äîwhile saving yourself time and effort in the process.

title: Dispatch from AIA25: Technology and Climate Take Center Stage

author.name: Nick Cameron
author.description: American trucker who has been featured on the History channel reality television series Ice Road Truckers and its spinoff series IRT: Deadliest Roads.

content: At the AIA National Convention, over 13,000 architects gathered to discuss the future of design, technology, and sustainability. Among the numerous sessions, a daylong symposium organized by the Technology in Architectural Practice (TAP) and the Committee on the Environment (COTE) focused on how digital tools are shaping environmental outcomes. The event brought together architects, engineers, and technologists for in-depth discussions on design performance, regulatory changes, and emerging workflows. As a past chair of the TAP knowledge community, I was proud to see this collaborative effort come to fruition. The symposium began with a keynote address by Corey Squire, who explored the roles of humans and computers in sustainable design. He highlighted the importance of aligning technology with the values outlined in the AIA Framework for Design Excellence. Following the keynote, a panel on regulatory compliance and certification strategies featured Alejandra Menchaca, Jessica Zofchak, Kjell Anderson, and Z Smith. While the session primarily focused on green building systems, such as LEED and WELL, much of the discussion centered on professional agency and the influence of design teams on policy and performance. Later, Jack Rusk participated in two sessions, sharing insights from his work at CScale, a platform with which we‚Äôve partnered to explore early-phase carbon modeling. His contributions emphasized how integrated and accessible tools are enabling design teams to incorporate emissions analysis into their decision-making processes rather than treating it as an afterthought. Throughout the day, additional panels covered topics such as carbon accounting, life cycle assessment, and data-informed workflows. An afternoon session addressed strategies for small and medium firms in adopting performance tools, with speakers sharing their experiences in navigating resource constraints while pursuing environmental objectives. The day concluded with a series of brief presentations on innovative approaches to climate-responsive design, including AI-driven analysis, dynamic visualization, and evolving project delivery models. A consistent theme throughout the symposium was that digital tools, including emerging AI technologies, are merely tools. It is the responsibility of designers to master these tools to create healthier, more resilient solutions for our clients and the communities we serve.

title: NXT BLD/DEV 2025 Recap
content: NXT BLD/DEV June 11/12 2025 Earlier this month, a team from SHL travelled to London to meet up with colleagues from Perkins&Will London studio for NXT‚ÄØBLD and NXT‚ÄØDEV, two conferences at the cutting edge of architecture, design technology, and the future of digital tools in AEC. From thought-provoking keynotes and emerging software demos to shared reflections on how we work, where our tools fall short, and how the next generation of software might finally catch up to the way we want to design. The energy was high and the pace of change even higher. Here are some of our key takeaways from the week: Ellen Berglund UX Design Lead Digital Practice ‚ÄúEveryone‚Äôs trying to build the next-gen BIM platform, and many are led by ex-Autodesk people who know what‚Äôs missing. The future is user-friendly, multiplayer and fast. Tools like Hypar and Motif are pushing things forward. From Autodesk, Forma stands out to me from a UX point of view. When we introduce it in the office, people pick it up right away and get to work, that‚Äôs what good UX should do. Now the challenge is keeping users: focus on what works, drop what doesn‚Äôt. AI isn‚Äôt just an idea anymore, it‚Äôs actually useful. And it was great to see Nick Cameron highlight the people behind our digital practice through the lens of Expand, Elevate, Educate, Execute.‚Äù ‚Äú Attending NXT BLD 2025 confirmed what we have sensed for a while: the BIM landscape is shifting. This is no longer incremental improvement‚Äîit‚Äôs a reinvention. The contrast with NXT BLD 2024 was striking. While NXT BLD 2024 introduced BIM 2.0, a broad exploration of future tech and AI possibilities, this year marked a decisive pivot. NXT BLD 2025 moved beyond ideation into execution. BIM 2.0 is no longer a future vision; it‚Äôs now being realized through tangible, usable tools. Startups are no longer in stealth or concept mode. They‚Äôre delivering credible, functioning alternatives to legacy platforms‚Äîsolutions that reflect how interdisciplinary teams actually work today. These new tools feel lighter, more agile, and fundamentally smarter. They signal a broader industry move from document-heavy workflows toward fully data-centric ecosystems. AI naturally took centre stage‚Äîbut this time as a deeply integrated force, not just a buzzword. From design augmentation to the automation of routine tasks, AI is being deployed to support and accelerate human decision-making‚Äînot replace it. This aligns closely with our thinking at Perkins&Will, where we see AI as an enabler of better design, not a substitute for it. ( Amplifying Creativity ‚Äì NIck Cameron ) If NXT BLD 2024 was the introduction to BIM 2.0‚Äîhighlighting cloud-native collaboration and interoperability‚Äîthen 2025 revealed its maturing form, while also offering a glimpse into BIM 3.0: intelligent systems that adapt, optimize, and evolve through real-time data and digital twins. (it‚Äôs a tech conference‚Äîof course we need a new version number!) But beyond the tools, what stood out most was the tone. The AEC industry feels more open, aligned, and energized than ever. We‚Äôre not just modeling buildings‚Äîwe‚Äôre modeling intelligence, relationships, and living systems. The future of BIM isn‚Äôt just smarter software‚Äîit‚Äôs a smarter, more connected industry. And it‚Äôs a future that strongly aligns with our values and aspirations at Perkins&Will‚Äôs Digital Practice Team.‚Äù David Sewell Sr Digital Prac Mgr Digital Practice Osman Sahinbozkir Digital Prac Spec II Digital Practice ‚ÄúAttending NXT BLD and NXT DEV this year, being immersed in the keynote presentations, product demos and expert forum discussions has been an invaluable experience, providing us all with key insights about the current state and the future of our fast-changing sector. My key takeaway from the discussions around BIM2.0, the disruptive abilities unlocked by AI, advancements in Open-source frameworks and how all these interact with the traditionally established norms of the industry is; keeping up with the Digital Transformation in AEC can no longer simply be about acquiring and using the newest tools on the market. It‚Äôs clear that in the current landscape, the boundaries between traditional vendor and user roles are dissolving, the resources for building complex tools are increasingly decentralized, the super-users of yesterday are becoming user-developers of today. This theme, which was echoed throughout the conference, implies to me that the competition will increasingly be about which organizations can more effectively cater for the rapidly evolving user-developer community.‚Äù ‚ÄúNXT BLD is one of the standout events in the calendar for BIM and AEC Digital Tools. Developed from AEC Mag which is a free publication where you can see the newest and improvements in the AEC Tech Landscape. This year was particularly fascinating and a definite improvement on last years showing. Last year it was ‚ÄúComing Soon‚Äù or ‚ÄúThis is a taste of what to come‚Äù, ‚ÄúThis is what BIM 2.0 could look like‚Ä¶‚Äù now a lot of companies are raising the game and coming out of alpha and beta testing. Motif, Qonic, Snaptrude, Hyper, Arcol are just a few of the ones trying to compete with Autodesk for that no.1 BIM spot. It was a unique event for the AEC industry that focused more on collaborating and that distanced itself from company and project competitiveness but instead with a full focus on raising industry standards, building better, faster, safer whilst being more openness and datacentric. It was great to catchup with like minded individuals and share stories and reflect on seen presentations.‚Äù Adam Burnham Digital Prac Spec II Digital Practice Victor Barbosa Sr Digital Prac Mgr Digital Practice ‚ÄúRemember when you did a lot of work one day, and you forgot to press ‚Äúsave‚Äù? Or that occasion, you were working late with a teammate and when you finished your files conflicted when you tried to save them? Well, I was really excited to see Motif, Hypar, Forma and Arcol which do not have the save button . Wait? But how do I know when to save? You don‚Äôt have to. That‚Äôs solved. It‚Äôs always saved. What you see, is what your team sees and you can both work at the same time, no sync to central. I believe architects excel on collaboration, and finally modelling and drafting is gonna feel more like pin-up walls, or shall i say Miro boards?‚Äù ‚ÄúNXT BLD and NXT DEV 2025 were a great opportunity to get a clear view of the broader state of the industry and where it‚Äôs heading. It was also inspiring to explore the next generation of AEC technology up close. While many tools are still evolving, they‚Äôre becoming more advanced and professional with each iteration. The sessions offered valuable insight into the tech stacks and nuances of these platforms, helping us stay at the forefront as a practice.‚Äù Daniel Boba Computational Designer Digital Practice Previous Previous Previous Next Next Next 1 2 3 4 5 6 Open image in lightbox: IMG_4474 Open image in lightbox: IMG_4474 Open image in lightbox: IMG_4479 Open image in lightbox: IMG_4479 Open image in lightbox: IMG_4486 Open image in lightbox: IMG_4486 Open image in lightbox: Image (8) Open image in lightbox: Image (8) Open image in lightbox: Image (7) Open image in lightbox: Image (7) Open image in lightbox: Media (2) Open image in lightbox: Media (2)

title: Dynamo Hackathon Report
content: Osman Sahinbozkir from the Digital Practice team in our London studio had the pleasure of attending the Dynamo Hackathon organized by Autodesk on the 19 th of May in Amsterdam, which took place at the venue a day before the Autodesk‚Äôs esteemed 2-day Software Development Conference DevCon2025. Whats a hackathon? ‚ÄúA hackathon is¬†a collaborative, intensive event where individuals or teams come together to build software, applications, or other projects within a short time frame, typically 24 to 48 hours.¬†The goal is often to develop a working prototype or proof-of-concept, focusing on problem-solving, skill-building, and networking. Create extensions, plugins, and innovative solutions while collaborating with a community of brilliant minds.‚Äù Previous Previous Previous Next Next Next 1 2 3 Open image in lightbox: Picture1 Open image in lightbox: Picture1 Open image in lightbox: Picture2 Open image in lightbox: Picture2 Open image in lightbox: Picture3 Open image in lightbox: Picture3 The focus of this year‚Äôs DevCon was Autodesk Platform Services (APS); which enables processing of the Data generated by widely used authoring tools and allow building bespoke applications through their integration into Cloud based services. As Autodesk summarizes it: ‚ÄúAPS powers custom and pre-built applications, integrations, and innovative solutions. The growing set of APIs and services unlocks your Design and Make Data and connects workflows.‚Äù In line with this theme, the focus of the Hackathon was also around exploring and pushing the boundaries of the interconnectedness of the different tools by Autodesk through Dynamo, the visual programming interface that now powers an extended range of tools as well as a conduit that allows these tools to speak to one another. After 8 hours of intense coding by groups of experts focused on a theme, supported by the Developers of the very tools we were pushing the limits of; the outcome was an awe-inspiring series of technical explorations, working Proof of Concept tools developed by all teams, and overall, a mind-bendingly productive day with so many ideas to reflect and build on! Previous Previous Previous Next Next Next 1 2 Open image in lightbox: Picture4 Open image in lightbox: Picture4 Open image in lightbox: Picture5 Open image in lightbox: Picture5 The particular focus of Osman‚Äôs group was to develop a proof-of-concept tool in relation to the 10-minute city concept, score Walkability and expand Autodesk Forma‚Äôs Contextual Analysis capabilities. The team extracted context buildings‚Äô massing of a geolocated project site from Forma (utilizing the Open-source OpenStreetMap datasets), reconstructed the context into natively editable Dynamo geometry, injected additional meta-data from external sources that are currently not natively available (such as land-use/typology and walkability) and then sorted/filtered based on these properties and built highlight/color override capabilities and shortest distance calculations directly in Forma. The proof of concept at the end of this effort was a working Script in Forma with Context buildings highlighted in color in the viewport based on their land-use/typology and the closest distance to any given Typology from the selected site. (i.e. the closest hospital: 45m). It was an incredible opportunity to meet and collaborate with Dynamo experts from around the world, and exchange innovative ideas with the team behind these awesome tools at Autodesk. The rigor with which our team pushed the capabilities of Forma‚Äôs Context Analysis capabilities were highly commended by the Autodesk team and it was a privilege to represent the Digital Practice Team at Perkins&Will in the big league among the best of the best. All coded natively in Dynamo, and more importantly, it worked!

title: Perkins&Will at Facades+ 2025 NYC
content: Facades+ 2025: New York City, April 4-5 Last month, our Perkins&Will team headed to Facades+ in NYC‚Äîthe premier conference on fa√ßades and building envelopes. Between inspiring keynotes, hands-on demonstrations, and spirited hallway conversations, and running our own computational design workshop, we came away energized by the industry‚Äôs drive to push material, performance, and computational boundaries. Here were some of our conference highlights and takeaways: Charlie Portelli iO Group Digital Practice ‚ÄúA team from RDH Building Science gave an interactive workshop where they discussed the different types of glass failure. The workshop covered topics ranging from spontaneous glass fracture due to nickel sulfide inclusions, delamination due to water infiltration. and edge protection for exposed edges. The team also supplied instruments used for measuring the amount of argon gas in an insulated glass unit (IGU) and moisture detection. It was a great experience to learn more about the science behind some of these failures and how minor tweaks in specifications can help mitigate these issues.‚Äù ‚ÄúAYON Studio presented a case study centered on their use of Vacuum Insulated Glazing (VIG) panels as replacement lites for an adaptive reuse / historical preservation project where the full window frame couldn‚Äôt be replaced. On-site thermal testing showed that VIG performed extremely well, reducing the overall U-value of the system by 75%. A team from Arup (including a sustainability consultant we are working with at BAT) presented their circular economy guidelines, which included redlist materials, design for disassembly, the creation of a post-consumer material economy, and a circular toolkit for NYEDC. The second half of the workshop was a group work session in which reused materials are proposed for a project, triggering new means of designing within a limited but broad set of materials.‚Äù Anish Reddy Project Architect Digital Practice Yash Akhouri Sust. Design Advisor Digital Practice Climate-Responsive Design and Energy Optimization ‚ÄúAt this year‚Äôs Facades+ conference, discussions centered on how fa√ßade design can adapt to climate zones while reducing carbon impact and improving performance. In cold regions like Boston and Philly, triple glazing and dynamic shading systems (such as ETFE panels) were explored to balance solar control with energy efficiency. Marine and hot-humid climates emphasized natural ventilation and overhangs. Speakers highlighted the growing importance of energy modeling in meeting NYC‚Äôs updated energy codes and Local Law 97, with detailed simulations used to optimize envelope performance and avoid added costs. Case studies like Amherst College‚Äôs mass timber retrofit demonstrated how thoughtful sequencing and low-carbon material strategies can breathe new life into existing structures. A key takeaway: effective facade strategies must align with climate, code, and carbon‚Äîwithout over-optimizing at the expense of design integrity.‚Äù Our Workshop: Computational Geometry for Glass Fa√ßades I joined my colleagues, Anthony Samaha and Anish Reddy, in putting on a hands-on workshop in the ‚ÄúTechnology: Research, Development, and Design Tools‚Äù track. Our two hour workshop looked at the York University School of Continuing Studies for inspiration and as a great example of leveraging computational design to help rationalizing a complex facade. We briefly spoke about the project to provide the group some context. We then dove in to the hands-on part: We walked through the design and creation of a parametric design surface We broke down the tools and logic (in this instance Rhino+Grasshopper) to help us understand what rationalizing geometry really means in context to project delivery Finally, we walked through how we can then take this rationalized geometry and fully panelize and document it in a way to coordinate with fabricators. As we got to the hands-on Grasshopper portion, two of us would walk through the rooms assisting anyone who ran into any script trouble. Workshop Materials Download Download Workshop Rhino and Grasshopper Files The Perkins&Will Facades+ group. Charlie Portelli, Perry Ashenfelter, Anthony Samaha, Anish Reddy, Yash Akhouri, Gigi Singh, Mario Romero Facades+ 2025 offered a powerful reminder of how collaboration, research, and hands-on experimentation continue to elevate building envelope design. From emerging materials and sustainability frameworks to the expanding role of computational workflows, the event sparked new ideas and renewed our commitment to innovation. We‚Äôre grateful to have shared our work‚Äîand to have learned so much from peers pushing the boundaries of fa√ßade performance, resilience, and beauty‚Äî and are also grateful for the local attendees that helped showcase the technological and technical acuity that Perkins&Will strives for.

title: Core eXchange Q2 Recap
content: Q2 Core eXchange Recap! Thank you to all our Presenters! View the Recordings on The Digital Practice Exchange Library During April‚Äôs Digital Practice Core eXchange, we welcomed an outstanding 1,604 participants across 11 dynamic sessions, featuring 26 presenters from across the firm and beyond. This quarter‚Äôs eXchange continued our mission of sharing expertise, elevating digital workflows, and fostering cross-disciplinary learning‚Äîwith each session offering AIA CEU credit and a direct link to practice. Highlights from the week included a firmwide Earth Day Webcast presentation on April 22nd, an in-depth walkthrough of the Switch List tool, and continued development of our Best Practices series with updated guidance on Barrier-Free Design and Video Editing . We also reintroduced the Innovation Incubator Spotlight , showcasing two exciting projects coming out of our Minneapolis studio. New sessions explored emerging technologies and strategies, including a Keynote from Matteo Cominetti , Cofounder and COO of Speckle, a firm-focused presentation on Interoperability at Perkins&Will , and applied creative tools in Leveraging AI in Adobe . As always, all recordings and slide decks are archived in the Digital Practice eXchange Library for ongoing access and reference. We look forward to seeing everyone again in July for our Q3 eXchange! Theme Sessions: Interoperability in Practice April‚Äôs Digital Practice Core eXchange offered an inspiring look into the real-world application of digital tools and the future of data-driven collaboration. These themed sessions began with a dynamic presentation by the Chicago studio titled ‚ÄúInteroperability at Perkins&Will,‚Äù which spotlighted how teams are leveraging Rhino.Inside, Grasshopper, and Speckle to bridge software gaps across design, documentation, and fabrication. Through case studies ranging from responsive fa√ßades in Saudi Arabia to the digitally coordinated limestone panels of Ryan Field, presenters demonstrated how seamless tool integration enhances precision, preserves design intent, and empowers cross-disciplinary teams. Following this, keynote speaker Matteo Cominetti, cofounder of Speckle, expanded the conversation by exploring the broader vision of interoperability in AEC. Matteo shared how Speckle‚Äôs open-source, cloud-based platform is transforming collaboration by moving beyond files toward flexible, connected data ecosystems. His perspective illuminated how democratizing access to design data opens new possibilities for project delivery, analytics, and future AI-driven workflows. Together, these sessions underscored the critical role of connectivity in design practice and offered a compelling roadmap for evolving our digital processes. As always, the discussions are now available in the Digital Practice eXchange Library to inspire continued experimentation and innovation across the firm. Watch the keynote recording here Watch the Interoperability presentation recording here Interoperability Sessions Theme Sessions: Living Design Living Design Sessions During April‚Äôs Digital Practice Core eXchange‚Äîheld in conjunction with Earth Day‚Äîwe experienced a timely and urgent call to environmental action through the Earth Day Webcast, where keynote speaker Jason McLennan reflected on the planet‚Äôs ecological crisis and challenged designers to use their agency for measurable impact. Building on that momentum, the Core eXchange session, ‚ÄúSwitch List: Ditch It and Switch It,‚Äù highlighted the firm‚Äôs internal leadership in material health, unveiling the updated Switch List and its app-based library. This collaborative effort empowers teams to phase out materials of concern and adopt healthier, market-available alternatives across product categories‚Äîfrom flooring and sealants to upholstery and insulation. Together, these two events reinforced Perkins&Will‚Äôs commitment to aligning design excellence with ecological and human health. As both sessions are now available in the Digital Practice Library, they serve as a springboard for deeper integration of sustainable practices across our firm. Watch the Earth Day Webcast recording here Watch the panel presentation recording here

title: Latest Hub updates ‚Äì May 2025
content: With spring hitting us in the northern hemisphere it felt like time to share all the new Hub features that have been blooming over the last couple months.¬† We are always making small improvements to many of the Hub apps on a regular basis.¬† ¬†This is primarily done through all of your ideas given to us through the black feedback button on the right side of each page.¬† ¬†Thank you to all of you who think to contribute to small daily progress to make our single source of truth and information better. Some of the larger updates listed below continue to find ways to make the organization and discovery of basic important information about our people, projects, and clients easier for everyone through Hub. In early spring we added some minor but important usability functions to our home page of Hub.¬† ¬†You will notice the apps or organized into various categories.¬† ¬†You can use the pin next to the all section, favorites or any of the others to have that be your own personal default starting point in Hub based on what you are personally most focused on.¬† ¬†There is also a star in the upper left corner of every app icon so you can create your own favorites list.¬† ¬†We also have some apps already favorited for everyone since our firm and business is our people doing projects for our clients. People app ‚Äì major updates A few weeks ago we rolled out a major update to the people app.¬† ¬†The first reason for doing this was to get it on the same modern technology and code that most of our recent apps run off of.¬† ¬†In addition to this and other backend improvements we have a list of new features and functions. We have more information for you and more basic information that you can share with the firm to help run the business and find the right people for the right tasks quicker. Please take a few minutes and hit the edit my profile button at the top of the people app right now to go and share what languages you speak, any awards you have personally won, any outreach or speaking engagements you have been a part of or any publications you have been in.¬† You can also share an audio of the pronunciation of your name or your pronouns.¬† ¬† The about me section allows you to share who you are as a person with the firm while the RFP profile is a workflow with your marketing teams to prep our resume content we share in pursuit of work.¬† ¬†Finally a reminder that some of the information is updated and comes from our UKG platform and we spell that out from the edit my profile page. You will notice a few new tabs at the top of the people app now that shows how groups of people relate.¬† The first one shows the leadership, business teams, and champions at the studio levels so you know who does what in your own studio or in another you are visiting. The third tab at the top showcases the firmwide groups and councils we have that lead up various aspects of running our firm.¬† ¬†From these views of each council you can download single images of all the people in the group through a settings button in the upper right.¬† ¬†We are keeping these lists of people updated on the backend as we work with each council chair to identify their team and their purpose and strategic actions year after year. Practice Toolkit Back at the beginning of the year we introduced the practice toolkit as a single location to aggregate all the information we were collecting about each practice in one spot from all the various apps and locations in Hub that it was entered.¬† ¬†This also introduced places for general knowledge, a calendar of events, key clients, top 10 lists and overall goals and progress practice by practice.¬† ¬†We are working to also do the same for our different disciplines as well. The Switch List Hopefully you heard a few weeks ago on Earth Day that we transitioned our material approach from ‚Äòprecautionary‚Äô to positive action, utilizing the market‚Äôs readily available alternatives.¬† ¬†This new app was showcased on the last Core eXchange has updated internal program guide, new vetted materials library and app, new guides for project partners and product manufacturers, and review of project requirements. We continue to also update and introduce other small improvements and apps like DEAR process updates Transcendent Detail Competition App More collaboration features in Pipeline Client & Consultant app org relationship features AI features in the Strategic Action Plan app We continue to prep more updates to PMTK, Studio Staffing, Pipeline and Portfolio as we do a lot of background work to make this move to Deltek VantagePoint successful.¬† ¬†Keep engaging all of our apps on Hub to enrich the knowledge and information available for many different workflows and needs on our single source of truth, Hub.

title: Matt Krissel on Design for AI Podcast
content: Design, Disruption, and the Future We Choose Dive into AI with Matt Krissel on the Design of AI Podcast On the Design for AI podcast, I explored what it means to be an architect in this era of rapid technological disruption‚Äîand why design matters more than ever. We live in a world obsessed with speed and surface appeal. Yet the built environment does more than exist as something to be optimized‚Äîit shapes our values, culture, movement, experinces and sense of belonging. If we don‚Äôt pause to ask better questions, we come up short and risk creating environments that separate rather than connect. This isn‚Äôt merely a design failure‚Äîit‚Äôs a failure of imagination, intentionality, and culture. In these early days of generative AI over-indexing on image generation, with fast imagery and seductive forms, we risk mistaking the output for insight. ‚ÄúThey are fast, but not always good. Provocative, but not meaningful. Seductive but not compelling. There is no causality to the image and the reality it suggests.‚Äù Provocative isn‚Äôt the same as meaningful, and speed without values is just noise. As I shared, the real promise of AI isn‚Äôt faster rendering (though helpful‚Äîis this what we want from an emerging superpower?)‚Äîit‚Äôs deeper thinking, new ways of making, and increasing agility, our reach, and our capacity. As we seek to seperate the vital few from the trivial many, design should help us turn down the volume and tune into what matters. Design software is a vast ecosystem of general-purpose tools and highly technical, complex, bespoke software, and we rely on people to move across this messy landscape of methods. Right now, the gains from AI workflows are incremental, in silos of productivity burst from the tools of the moment. We must evolve past ‚Äúhot-rodding‚Äù our old workflows as the most viable path forward. This isn‚Äôt just automating what we already do ‚Äîit‚Äôs about reimagining what we do, how we do it, and with whom. The real gains will likely be in how we organize ourselves and work in ways we have not yet invented, in the choices we make in how we orient our gains, in expanding our fluidity between intuition and computation, and in seeing AI more as a creative partner than only a tool. But we need to be intentional. In this fog of AI frenzy, there‚Äôs a danger of tools leading the process instead of values. Software in search of problems rarely serves the public good. As Peter Drucker warned, ‚ÄúThere is nothing so useless as doing efficiently that which should not be done at all.‚Äù Efficiency cannot be the goal as it‚Äôs too easily misapplied. Design is inherently inefficient. That‚Äôs not a flaw‚Äîin many ways, it‚Äôs a feature. While everyone wants to move faster, we need to be critical of where we speed up and where we should actually slow down. The outcomes and impact are too significant and lasting for a one-size-fits-all, speed-at-all-cost approach. Some things need to gestate. We need the friction, the debate, the pauses, the rethinking. Design is more than a means to an end‚Äîit‚Äôs our agency in action. If we sacrifice the rigor of that process in favor of chasing speed alone, we‚Äôll fill our world with buildings that feel like first drafts‚Äîrushed, underdeveloped, functional, maybe, but forgettable. In times of rapid change, we want to focus on ‚Äòfirst principles‚Äô and be less concerned about specificity and more¬†concerned¬†about trajectory. In other words, we should be clear on the vision and loose on the details to ensure we aim in the right direction, aligning our resources, intellect, and¬†grit with the flexibility to correct course as technology develops. We must embrace our agency and position to design the future of practice to ensure a future we actually want to live in. Matthew Krissel Design Principal, Practice Leader Digital Practice

title: Enhance Your Design Skills: Rhino Training Series Recap
content: Enhance Your Design Skills: Sketchup to Rhino Training Series Successfully Concludes From March 17th to April 11th, we hosted a focused Rhino Training Series designed specifically to elevate our design processes. The core goals were clear: streamline our Rhino workflow and significantly improve integration with Revit , boosting overall efficiency and collaboration. 12 Focused Sessions Across 4 Weeks Adopting a dynamic format, the series featured short, impactful 15-30 minute sessions held three times a week at 8:00 AM EST. This bite-sized approach allowed attendees to dive deep into specific topics without major disruption to the workday. What We Covered: The curriculum spanned foundational techniques to advanced integrations, ensuring a comprehensive learning path. Here‚Äôs a breakdown of the sessions: Week Session Topic 1 Session 1 Importing SketchUp Blocks into Rhino Session 2 Texturing Basics Session 3 Advanced Texture Mapping 2 Session 4 Modeling Essentials ‚Äì PushPull Session 5 Advanced Navigation and Visualization Session 6 Integration with Enscape 3 Session 7 Material Editing and Refinement Session 8 Precision Modeling Session 9 Scene and Lighting Setup 4 Session 10 Handling Complex Geometries Session 11 Working with Rhino Inside (Revit Integration) Session 12 Advanced Tips and Q&A Bridging Design Tools for Greater Efficiency A key focus was mastering Rhino Inside for Revit , enabling a smoother transition between platforms and unlocking new levels of interoperability. From foundational modeling and texturing to advanced visualization and integration techniques, the series aimed to equip everyone with practical skills for immediate application. Resources Available Now Whether you missed a session, want to revisit a specific topic, or share with colleagues, all resources remain available: Recordings: Catch up on any session here: View Training Playlist Questions & Discussion: Check out the Miro Board used during the series: Link Class Materials: Access sample files (including SKP to Rhino examples) here: SKP to Rhino Keep Learning & Integrating This training series was a fantastic opportunity to refine our collective Rhino and Revit skills. We strongly encourage everyone to review the recordings and materials, practice these techniques, and integrate them into your projects. Improving how we use these powerful tools together is key to our continued success and innovation. Meet Your Instructors This valuable series was led by experienced members of our Digital Practice team: Mario Romero : Based in Chicago, Mario serves as a Digital Practice Manager and Senior Associate. With 17 years of experience and a background in Architecture from the University of Illinois ‚Äì Chicago, Mario brings a wealth of knowledge to our digital workflows. He is also a LEED Green Associate. Lincoln Jyo : Our Digital Practice Coordinator located in Sao Paulo. Lincoln holds degrees in Architecture & Urbanism (Universidade de Sao Paulo) and Business Administration (Shanghai University), complemented by 13 years of experience. He is a LEED Green Associate and a Licensed Architect in Brazil.

title: AIA NY ‚Äì Value/Values
content: Artificial Intelligence in Architecture Salon 1: Value/Values Last month, Perkins&Will was invited by the AIA New York Future of Practice committee to discuss at the ‚ÄúArtificial Intelligence in Architecture (AI+A) Salon 1: Value/Values,‚Äù a series aimed at bridging the gap between AECO practice and the explorations in AI‚Äôs potential. As part of a four-part series, this session featured Charles Portelli from the New York studio, alongside Dan Reynolds from Walter P. Moore, and Murat Melek from Suffolk Construction. These panelists represented the three primary sectors of the built environment, contributing to an informed discussion that cut through the hype around AI. They emphasized how professionals could leverage technology to enhance design and problem-solving without replacing human ingenuity. The discussion was moderated by Elizabeth Bowie Christoforetti, Assistant Professor at Harvard GSD, focusing on three key questions: What are your hopes and fears vis-√†-vis AI integration in the field? How will it change our skills? How will it challenge our expertise? ‚ÄúAI has the potential to simplify our lives. For instance, the convenience of having one‚Äôs calendar automatically updated after booking a flight or hotel is a small but powerful example of seamless integration. Similarly, AI can enable smoother, more contemporary project delivery methods by focusing on data rather than files. By breaking down data silos and integrating various sources, designers can uncover previously unforeseen insights, leading to better-informed decisions. These decisions can have a positive impact on both the environment and human well-being.‚Äù Charles Portelli, AIA, RIBA, CDT Digital Innovation Strategist at Perkins&Will ‚ÄúAt Suffolk Construction, AI is being harnessed to enhance knowledge accessibility for site teams, enabling them to make quicker, more informed decisions and adapt to unexpected site conditions. Improved supply chain management can reduce downtime and waste while controlling costs. With access to larger, cleaner, and fuller datasets, the construction industry can use AI to streamline scheduling, estimating, and preconstruction processes. Understanding the unique risks associated with each project can inform the selection of subcontractors who are best suited for the specific conditions, setting the project on a path to success.‚Äù Murat Melek, PhD, SE Director of Design AI at Suffolk Construction ‚ÄúEngineering faces unique challenges, and AI offers the opportunity to transform ‚Äúhindsight 20/20‚Ä≥ into foresight, providing engineers with preemptive insights to prevent issues before they arise. This proactive approach allows for greater creativity and the ability to solve high-impact problems. By eliminating unnecessary obstacles like data access, AI can enhance speed and efficiency. With the ability to manage larger, more complex datasets, engineers can improve optioneering by considering more alternatives.‚Äù Dan Reynolds AI Leader at Walter P Moore The panel concluded that AI offers significant benefits across all AECO sectors. Echoing the sentiment ‚Äúwith great power comes great responsibility,‚Äù they urged industry professionals to drive innovation by leveraging their expertise to shape AI‚Äôs integration into practice.

title: Taking Mobile Computing to the Next Level!
content: At Perkins&Will, we‚Äôre always listening to our staff‚Äôs needs, and lately, there‚Äôs been a consistent demand: more power for generative AI applications and lightning-fast renderings. We understand that not everyone can be tethered to a desk, waiting for their processor to churn through data or graphics. So, in the spirit of innovation, we‚Äôre thrilled to unveil our groundbreaking solution: Desktop Backpacks! Why Choose Desktop Backpacks? Forget about the latest ultrabook or the sleekest workstation. Why limit yourself to mere laptops when you can carry an entire desktop on your back? With our new Desktop Backpacks, we‚Äôre turning mobile computing on its head! Features Include: Top-Tier Processing Power: Equipped with the latest in CPU and GPU technology, our Desktop Backpacks ensure that you‚Äôre never left wanting for more power, whether you‚Äôre rendering complex 3D models or training the next big AI. Built-In Cooling System: To keep you cool and your processor cooler, each backpack comes with a state-of-the-art ventilation system. Say goodbye to overheating with wind tunnel technology that‚Äôs both silent and effective. Ergonomic Design: Who says comfort and efficiency can‚Äôt coexist? Our backpacks are designed with the modern architect in mind, featuring weight-balanced construction that makes carrying your desktop as easy as pie. Style Meets Function: Each backpack is crafted with high-quality materials and is as stylish as it is practical. Choose from various brand appropriate colors and finishes to match your personal style or to stand out in a crowd. The next iteration of Mobile Desktop Computing ‚Äì coming soon. Imagine the Possibilities! Also ‚Äì Please note that it is April First. Sorry.

title: Speckle London Meetup 2025
content: Speckle London Meetup 2025 The London Speckle Meetup happened on the 26th March 2025 at the pinnacle of the new Sidara/ Perkins&Will London Studio. A beautiful sunset overlooking the London Skyline, set of a great night of collaboration, learning, sharing and connecting! 60 + Attendees 60+ Architects, Engineers, Software Developers, Computational Designers, BIM Specialists and AEC Enthusiasts came together from across London and flew from around Europe to share, learn and connect. Some key companies in attendance was AECOM, Allies and Morrison, BDP, Benoy, Dar, Eckersley O‚ÄôCallaghan, Gensler, Grimshaw, Hopkins Architects, Jacobs, Metaverse, Price&Myer, Thornton Tomasetti, WATG and many more Introducing 8 x Pecha Kucha Presentations We hosted 8 quickfire presentations at the event from the following: ‚ÄúPower to the People‚Äù Joroen Janssen ‚Äì Thornton Tomasetti ‚ÄúSpeckle on Streamlit via Rhino.Compute‚Äù Denitsa Stefanova ‚Äì Strabag ‚ÄúBridging the Gap‚Äù Alex Richards ‚Äì Stantec ‚ÄúCommunicating & Collaborating‚Äù Balazs Bicsak ‚Äì Price&Myers ‚ÄúSpeckle at DAR‚Äù Karim Safar ‚Äì DAR ‚ÄúData Dashboard‚Äù Maciej Konrad Sochacki ‚Äì Allies and Morrison ‚ÄúEarly Stage LCA with Automate‚Äù Daniel Boba ‚Äì Perkins&Will / SHL ‚ÄúSpeckle at EOC‚Äù Charlotte Phillips Salvador & Jun Wen Loo ‚Äì Eckersley O‚ÄôCallaghan Introducing Stantec Price&Myer Allies and Morrison 2.5 Hours Conversations flowed, new friendships were formed, and exciting collaborations sparked. It was incredible to see so see how much can happen when passions people come together. Speckle is all about opening the industry, breaking silos and connecting with one another. Katherine from Price and Myers spoke passionately how we shouldn‚Äôt just use Speckle as a tool for us to use, but we can use it to communicate more effectively with our partners and colleagues. Sharing project data for openly with our consultants and contractors can only improve the industry and improve the process! 1 AEC Tool A huge thankyou to the Speckle Team for developing such a great product and for making all of this possible. At Perkins Will we are seeing a huge uptake in the use of Speckle. Working directly with the development team and having such a close relationship with them, helps us to develop something that works better for us. If you are reading this, Please test/ use/ complain if needed, only then can we provide feedback and get it working the way we want for us! 1 Daniel Boba A special Shoutout to our own Daniel Boba who created ‚Äì in his own words ‚Äì ‚Äù A tasty little automate‚Äù for the event. Daniel spoke about how he created a Speckle Automate function that runs based off an AreaSync project for Early LCA Analysis using C.Scale. (Please see his presentation below) Download [20.52 MB]

title: Enscape 4.2
content: We are excited to announce the availability of Enscape 4.2 for everyone¬†on Company Portal . This new release brings powerful enhancements to design visualization, as well as a new licensing system that makes access to advanced features more efficient for everyone. New Chaos Licensing System Enscape has now transitioned to the Chaos licensing system. The new system uses cloud-based floating licenses , allowing you to sign in from anywhere‚Äîwhether you‚Äôre in the office, working remotely, or on-site‚Äî without needing a VPN or network connection back to the local studio. Simply install Enscape 4.2 from Company Portal and log in with your P&W email to activate your license. If you are a member of one of the other domains, please create your account from the email invitation you have already received. Please note that you may receive a notice about No Licenses Available.¬† This is normal and does not impact your ability to use Enscape. What‚Äôs New in Enscape 4.2? With this upgrade, you‚Äôll gain access to a range of new tools and improvements designed to enhance your workflow and design presentation: Artistic Visual Mode Enhancements ‚Äì The Watercolor mode now includes texture controls, and both Watercolor and Colored Pencil modes feature improved transparency handling, allowing for more refined conceptual renderings. Chaos AI Enhancer ‚Äì A new AI-powered tool that¬†refines render quality, delivering more realistic and detailed visualizations with minimal effort. Animated Vegetation & Asset Updates ‚Äì An expanded library of 72 animated plants and trees , plus seven new wire grid assets , helping bring greater life and realism to your projects. Revit Filters Integration ‚Äì Enscape now supports Revit Filters , bridging the gap between visual storytelling and data analytics , making it easier to communicate design intent in real time. Multiple Section Planes for Rhino Artistic Visual Mode Improvements Next Steps We encourage everyone to upgrade to Enscape 4.2 and start exploring these new features. This update is a fantastic opportunity to enhance your design presentations and workflows with the latest rendering and visualization tools. If you have any questions about the licensing process or need assistance with installation , please reach out to your IT department for support.

title: PowerBI and Fabric Summit 2025 ‚Äì Virtual
content: PowerBI & Fabric Summit 2025 ‚Äì Virtual The PowerBI & Fabric Summit 2025, a virtual event for data professionals and enthusiasts, took place last week, drawing a global audience for a comprehensive dive into the latest PowerBI technologies and practices. The summit featured an impressive lineup of expert speakers who presented advanced analytics techniques, shared best practices in data visualization, and unveiled the latest PowerBI features and updates. As the community of PowerBI users continues to grow, this event provided a platform for participants to network, share insights, and explore innovative solutions in the world of data. Among the attendees were Jason Diamond and Daniel Prager, representing their respective studios in Atlanta and Boston. The summit offered them a unique opportunity to engage with thought leaders and peers from around the world, enhancing their understanding of PowerBI‚Äôs capabilities in addressing the complex data challenges our clients face. The sessions covered a range of topics from AI integration in PowerBI to optimizing data models for performance, giving them a wealth of knowledge to bring back to their teams. As they continue to process the information and insights gained from the summit, both Jason and Daniel are enthusiastic about applying the new techniques and strategies they learned to enhance our Project Teams capabilities and help deliver greater advisory services to our clients. For more information on the Global PowerBI Summit, please refer to this link .¬† Additionally, if you are interested in PowerBI or Microsoft Fabric, consider attending the Power Platform Community Conference happening later this year.

title: Area Sync 2.3 ‚Äì New Visuals, Smarter Workflows & More Stability
content: We‚Äôve packed this update with new visualization options, improved PowerBI templates, and several fixes to make Area Sync smoother and more powerful than ever. You can learn more about the tool here: https://perkins-and-will.gitbook.io/areasync Here‚Äôs what‚Äôs new: Key Features & Enhancements -PowerBI Templates ‚Äì Smarter Data Insights We‚Äôre introducing new PowerBI templates to help teams analyze projects effortlessly: Room & Area Dashboard ‚Äì Get a detailed breakdown of total areas, rooms, and assets within them. Asset Catalog ‚Äì Track furniture, equipment, and other elements in your space‚Äîperfect for interior and workplace teams. Access them here: AreaSync and look up examples files here: https://hub.perkinswill.com/6674046efd586212619aa8dd/search/668fab6edbf358e672f46b9d/examples ‚Äì New AreaSync Visual for PowerBI Now, Rooms and Areas are more clearly displayed in PowerBI , with a new refined look for better insights. Plus, you can display assets inside the Viewer , giving you a full picture of your project. The visual also has multiple displays including: Top View ‚Äì A classic overhead look at your project. 3D View ‚Äì Navigate models in three dimensions. Top View (All Levels) ‚Äì See all levels stacked together. Exploded Axo ‚Äì Breaks apart levels for better visualization.The visual is part of the new PowerBI templates. ‚Äì Improved Multi-Model & Sync Visualization View multiple models or syncs together on the web, making it easier to compare and overlay data. Track active models in Revit , so you always know which file you‚Äôre working on. More flexible syncing in Rhino , allowing you to choose which model to sync to. Bug Fixes & Improvements Fixed double error messages on failed sync attempts Resolved login issues where redirection wasn‚Äôt waiting properly Checkboxes are now fully visible Fixed untyped references not responding Better handling of area and room geometry parsing errors Prevented conflicts when loading the same panel multiple times Ensured webview doesn‚Äôt handle events when it‚Äôs not visible Fixed issues with GeoJSON parsing Updated logic for area schemes Improved UI stability, including collapsible UI fixes More to Come! This release sets the stage for even more improvements. We‚Äôre excited to hear your feedback , especially on the new PowerBI templates and Viewer functions. Stay tuned‚Äîmore updates are on the way!

title: Lessons Learned from ACADIA 2024
content: Victor Okhoya and August Miller shared their ACADIA 2024 presentation, and an overview of the other conference presentations, with the Perkins&Will computational design community on their bi-weekly check-in on February 25th. Topics ranged from 3D printing and other digital fabrication methods to a range of innovative workflows that incorporate Artificial Intelligence. Their presentation, entitled ‚ÄòCase Study of an Integrated Parametric Approach in Affordable Housing‚Äô highlighted the Corazon del Valle 180 unit affordable housing project executed by our Los Angeles studio. Parametric and computational methods were utilized throughout the life of the project, creating a highly detailed and responsive design. Building forms were sculpted in smooth curves to guide wind through an interior courtyard. Masses were subdivided into an optimized unit mix and facade elements were parametrically located according to spacing rules. All these elements were coordinated in a complex generative script so a change to one element would ripple through the creation and location of the rest. For more information about the Corazon del Valle project reach out to August Miller in the Los Angeles studio. To stay up to date with all the computational design efforts at Perkins&Will join us on our bi-weekly community calls on Tuesdays or send a message to the entire community on the Computational Design Teams channel . Previous Previous Previous Next Next Next 1 2 3 4

title: Advancing Computational Design Conference 2025 ‚Äì Austin, TX
content: Advancing Computational Design Conference 2025 ‚Äì Austin, TX This year‚Äôs Advancing Computational Design Conference, hosted by Hanson Wade in Austin, TX, explored a range of computational design strategies and team management approaches. The three-day event began with a Pre-Conference Workshop Day, featuring nine workshops divided into two sections. Section A focused on kickstarting the computational design journey, while Section B delved into mastering advanced computational strategies. On the day one I hosted one of the workshops titled ‚ÄúMastering Scripting to Streamline Automation & Optimize Workflows‚Äù. This workshop focused on introducing the participants to various interoperability workflows with step-by-step guidance to make scripting a simple and manageable task. Days two and three featured open conversations and presentations on the structure and strategies of Digital Practice Teams across firms of varying sizes, from 20 employees to over 30,000. The differences in scale and practice led to diverse approaches, with two notable strategies emerging. The Integrated Approach embeds computational design specialists into the design process from project inception to completion, ensuring seamless collaboration. In contrast, the Specialized Team Approach designates a dedicated team to support the design process with digital expertise as needed.

title: Integrated Quality Program App
content: Integrated Quality Program App What is it? : It‚Äôs a better, and more organized, way to Request Schedule and Track elements of the Firmwide Quality Program Why Should You Use It : Until now, all of this was done somewhat ad hoc and differently from Studio to Studio. With a single, integrated, app it‚Äôs much easier for every project team to take steps to improve the quality of our work. We can also collect data on adoption of the Quality Program so we know where we are excelling and where we need improvement. As with many of our current tools, the App can be found on your My Apps page: When you click on the app, you start with a splash screen that automatically transitions to the request page. From here, you can request individual Quality Program events and reviews. Check out the embedded slide deck to learn more!

title: Core eXchange Q1 Recap
content: Q1 Core eXchange Recap! Thank you to all our Presenters! View the Recordings on The Digital Practice Exchange Library During January‚Äôs Digital Practice Core eXchange, we celebrated a fantastic turnout with 1,338 attendees across 12 engaging sessions. The eXchange offered a wide range of topics, from optimizing models for rendering and advanced video editing, to the latest updates in Revit, and our ongoing Best Practice series with a focus on Barrier-Free Design. Highlights included the launch of the Circular Design Primer as part of our Embodied Carbon series. Additionally, we featured two spotlights this exchange, one on our Research Team and another on the i/O team. We also presented two Hub presentations, one discussing the current and future states of PMTK, and another introducing our new knowledge and process sharing platform, Palette. The Core eXchange continues to exemplify the vibrant exchange of ideas and collaborative spirit within our firm. As we reflect on this successful event, we are excited about the new skills and tools being developed and shared across the firm. All session recordings have been archived in the Digital Practice eXchange Library for ongoing reference and review. We look forward to seeing everyone in April for our Q2 eXchange! Theme Sessions: Crafting Innovations During January‚Äôs Digital Practice Core eXchange, we experienced an insightful exploration of technology‚Äôs role in architecture through the keynote on ‚ÄúCrafting Innovations‚Äù and the panel on ‚ÄúApplied Innovation: Citizen Developers in Practice.‚Äù The sessions illuminated the transformational impact of hackathons, likened to historical charettes, showcasing how rapid, collaborative problem-solving through technology drives architectural innovation. Keynote speaker Charlie Portelli highlighted the evolution from traditional design methods to modern digital collaborations, while panelist Anish Reddy shared practical applications, detailing his hackathon experience that led to the creation of ‚ÄòUp Zone‚Äô, an AI tool that streamlines zoning analysis for architectural projects. This eXchange proved to be a dynamic platform for fostering community, enhancing skills, and pushing the boundaries of architectural practice with technology. As we archive these enriching discussions in the Digital Practice eXchange Library, we anticipate continued growth and innovation within our firm from these collaborative ventures. Watch the keynote recording here Watch the panel presentation recording here Theme Sessions

title: Speckle-Con Collaboration
content: SpeckleCon 2024: PW at the Forefront of AEC Innovation SpeckleCon 2024 brought together AEC technology leaders from around the world to share invaluable advancements and knowledge aimed at accelerating the application of technology in the AEC industry. This year, the meetup took place on November 13-14 in London‚Äîthe global hub for innovation in design, construction, and BIM. From major product launches to hands-on workshops, SpeckleCon was more than just an event‚Äîit was a global gathering of innovators driving real change in the industry. Perkins&Will was honored to contribute, showcasing how we‚Äôre leveraging Speckle to innovate, streamline workflows, and actively shape the future of design and construction. Speckle as the AEC Data Hub Speckle has grown from a simple Grasshopper plugin to a comprehensive ecosystem of tools designed to streamline collaboration and connectivity. At the conference, Co-Founder and CEO Dimitrie Stefanescu emphasized Speckle‚Äôs evolution into the backbone of AEC data workflows. Perkins&Will at SpeckleCon 2024 Perkins&Will took the stage at SpeckleCon with a presentation by Jordana de Castro Rosa and Adam Burnham , showcasing how we leverage Speckle to accelerate AEC workflows. They highlighted tools like Speckle Connectors and the Speckle Viewer, which have become integral to our projects by enhancing data connectivity and collaboration. Award-Winning Innovations The presentation also spotlighted AI2Speckle and ARK . AI2Speckle: AI-Powered Design Integration This innovative tool uses AI to convert text prompts into realistic renderings and BIM-compatible data, enabling seamless integration of design elements into BIM workflows. AI2Speckle eliminates time-consuming manual searches for design elements and streamlines the design process, allowing architects to focus on creativity and precision. Team: Jordana de Castro Rosa, Abhishe k Shinde, Josie Harrison, Marwan Elzainy ARK: Accessible Data Management Built on Speckle‚Äôs open-source platform, ARK allows users to drag and drop Rhino and Revit files directly into a web interface, converting them to Speckle objects viewable without native software. ARK also extracts and displays drawing sets from models, streamlining documentation.¬† ARK reduces reliance on costly software and enhances accessibility for smaller practices, with future plans to support additional file types and improve the user interface. Team: Victor Wanderley Barbosa, Adam Burnham, Ellen Berglund, Zuzanna Czapla, Daniel Boba Speckle for JavaScript/TypeScript Geeks In addition to the presentation, Victor Wanderley Barbosa conducted a hands-on workshop titled ‚ÄúSpeckle for JavaScript/TypeScript Geeks.‚Äù The session introduced attendees to practical applications of Speckle for developers, covering tools like the Viewer, Object Loader, Object Sender, and Automate. Victor demonstrated how Speckle empowers users to create efficient and innovative workflows, emphasizing its versatility for developers working within the AEC ecosystem. Speckle Announcements at SpeckleCon 2024 Workspaces Workspaces, Speckle‚Äôs centralized team collaboration tool, is soon exiting beta. Offering features like Single Sign-On (SSO), data residency, and secure role management, it is set to transform team workflows. With flexible paid plans, Workspaces caters to teams of all sizes while ensuring compliance with strict data requirements. Next-Gen Connectors Speckle introduced its new-generation connectors for platforms like Archicad, Civil3D, and Tekla. These connectors boast incredible speed improvements‚Äîover 1000% faster for updates‚Äîand a 50% reduction in data size and memory usage, making workflows smoother and more efficient. Speckle Automate Speckle Automate‚Äôs public beta empowers users to streamline repetitive workflows with curated and customizable functions. Automate simplifies tasks like data transformation, model checks, and report generation, helping teams save time and focus on design innovation. Curated Public Functions Learn more at https://www.speckle.systems/blog/everything-we-announced-at-specklecon-2024 Our Role a s Speckle Collab orators Perkins&Will‚Äôs integration of Speckle reflects our commitment to embracing cutting-edge technology to enhance efficiency and collaboration. From award-winning hackathon projects to new applications in design workflows, we are proud to be recognized as a key player in Speckle‚Äôs evolving ecosystem. The innovations unveiled at SpeckleCon reinforce our belief in Speckle as an essential tool for the AEC industry. As we continue to adopt and expand its applications within Perkins&Will, these advancements will help us maintain our leadership in digital transformation and deliver better, faster, and more sustainable designs. title: International Facility Management Association World Workplace Conference
content: IFMA World Workplace 2024 Recap Showing off our Data Analytics Tools to Potential Clients Last month Leigh Stringer, Brad Rogers, and I presented Using Data Analytics to Drive Real Estate Consolidation at the IFMA World Workplace Conference & Expo in San Antonio, TX. We were excited for the opportunity to speak with this particular audience about our capabilities with managing data and using it to help our clients solve problems that look to optimize the use of their facilities and assets. We presented several case studies that were all at different scales and using different tools with different types of clients.¬† One example showed how we use Area Sync to extract design data from our digital apps on a single corporate interiors project, while another showed off our Campus Planner tool with a higher ed client that handles data from multiple facilities along with other client data. What we found from the questions and dialog from audience members after the presentation is that the pain points are real when it comes to organizing data from different systems or sources. Some are working within typical FM applications (like Maximo) that don‚Äôt connect with other data sources in the organizations, and that information tends to be siloed for them. Some expressed that the BIM data coming from the design or construction team isn‚Äôt always in a format for their FM apps to receive it. The feedback from our case studies and holistic approach to our projects was very positive and well received. We think there are opportunities out there to provide digital advisory services for our existing clients. If you think a client might need these services, please feel free to reach out to Leigh, Brad, or myself. We would be happy to speak with clients or project teams if needed, or provide some marketing materials to help facilitate the conversation. In the meantime, we will continue to look for other opportunities like IFMA to share our processes and tools with a larger audience of potential clients.
