title: New Revit template for US offices
content: The new Revit template for US office is a treasure trove of efficient workflows. The Digital Practice team has made many improvements, making project work more efficient. Below are just some highlights. Highlights of improvements Technical Design leaders have reviewed all sheets included in the template. The template contains a lot of discreet guidance , which can be turned on and off. QA/QC sheets help the team to keep the file clean and organized, and check their work Color and patterns were used to make graphics more readable. The combination of color and patterns keeps the drawing readable for color-impaired people, especially when printed at greyscale. Last, but not least, the team reviwed and streamlined two important workflows. Documentation of finishes Code Compliance documentation Why we rebuild Periodic rebuilding of Revit templates is necessary because every few years, Revit gains additional functionality we can take advantage of, and also, after several upgrades, the template can accumulate glitches. Even more importantly, we embed new optimized workflows, review/modify standard sheets, and introduce the most efficient documentation methods as a firmwide standard. The Digital Practice team worked with Technical Directors to make it the best P&W Revit template to date! Next steps The US-based Digital Practice and technical design studio leaders have extensively reviewed the new template and provided feedback, which has already been implemented. Look for the roll-out in your studio and provide additional feedback that can be implemented in your project. The new US template will be released today, April 2. Then the studio DAs in collaboration with studio TDC will add local flavor (codes, details, etc.) and publish studio templates. The firmwide training session is scheduled for April 19. In the next few weeks, we will be publishing new mK cards, working on Quickstart, and refining other supporting documentation. Thanks to everyone who helped with ideas, feedback and constructive criticism. The team

title: AEC Hackathon @ BLOXHUB 2024
content: AEC Hackathon @ BLOXHUB 2024 LIM Over this past weekend our team participated in an AEC Hackathon hosted by BLOXHUB in Copenhagen. We worked with a pretty diverse crowd to come up with the best overall project that weekend! Check out what we came up with (starts at 33:20): ‚ú®üå± Planning for biodiverse urban landscape ‚ú®üå± Cities worldwide face a significant challenge: integrating biodiversity into urban design in a consistent and measurable way. The struggle to balance aesthetic urban spaces with ecosystems that support a diverse range of life forms is real and pressing. üèôÔ∏è‚û°Ô∏èüåø The Challenge: This problem has several layers from ecology, to civic, planning and all the way up to politics. The difficulty in planning lies in measuring and implementing biodiversity throughout the design process. Traditional approaches often overlook the critical role that wildlife, species diversity, and vegetation play in creating sustainable urban environments. ‚ú®üå± Landscape Information Modelling (LIM) ‚ú®üå± LIM, was awarded the best overall project at AEC Hackathon at BLOXHUB! LIM is designed to enhance how urban spaces are planned and developed, ensuring biodiversity is a core consideration from the outset. Key Features: üõ†Ô∏è Design Tool Integration: Seamlessly attaches to Rhino and Revit, bringing biodiversity data right into the heart of the urban design process. üìö Database Connectivity: Provides access to an extensive data sources like Map of Life species and biodiversity information, enabling informed design decisions. üå≥ Carbon Absorption Analysis: Offers detailed measurements of carbon absorption by medium and large trees, displayed through an easy-to-understand dashboard. üêæ Species Diversity and Distribution Assessment: Ensures a balanced ecosystem by analyzing the variety and distribution of species across a site. üó∫Ô∏è Urban Site Data Integration: Utilizes data sources like Cetopo to inform designers about existing species on site, advocating for their preservation over replacement. üåê Why This Matters: LIM embodies our commitment to reimagining urban spaces that not only meet human needs but also enhance the natural environment. By embedding comprehensive biodiversity metrics into the planning process, LIM paves the way for cities that are sustainable, vibrant, and life-supporting. We couldn‚Äôt have done this without the dedication and expertise of our team Daniel Boba Ellen Berglund Zuzzana Czpla Mateusz Binkowski Arvis Brunavs Oswaldo Hernandez Victor Wanderley Barbosa (all above from SHL) Riccardo Piazzai (NORDFY) Michal Stysz (COBOD) Andy Andor (SWECO) and together we turned this 2-day hackathon into loads of learning and collaboration at BLOXHUB . title: ROB|ARCH 2024: Work in Progress
content: ROB|ARCH 2024 This year Perkins&Will and Zahner will expand up on our Deliver Different partnership and fabrication workshop in Kansas City last August by offering a 3-day workshop as part of RobArch 2024 , happening in Toronto May 21-25! DESCRIPTION Zahner and Perkins&Will, have been pioneering co-authoring tools and workflows to bridge information silos within the AEC industry. We are thrilled to bring you a multi-track workshop that allows you to step into various roles, including surveyor, installer, designer, engineer, and fabricator. In this immersive workshop, we will explore diverse methods for seamless interaction between the digital and physical realms. We‚Äôll cover techniques for reconciling digital models with existing field conditions and delve into node-based workflows, leveraging on-site robotics, sensors, smart tools, and real-time AR information delivery. Key Workshop Highlights: Site Selection and Scanning: We kick off by selecting a site, whether it‚Äôs a column or ceiling, and utilize the cutting-edge Leica MS60 3D scanner to capture precise data. After meticulous post-processing, we employ the point clouds to drive our surface modeling. Structure Design and Fabrication: Building on the surface model, we proceed to design and fabricate a structure for our modular skin system with a strong emphasis on precision. Field Installation: Our proprietary field installation tool, SurveyLink, takes center stage, ensuring precise placement of structural components according to the existing field conditions. Field Condition Updates: After the structure is installed, we conduct scans of the updated field conditions, which guide the aggregation and design of typical skin parts. Skin Assembly: With the skin model now complete, we utilize SurveyLink, node-based smart tools, and a robotic arm to accurately position and assemble skin members. This workshop offers a unique opportunity to explore the heart of digital-physical integration, encouraging creativity, innovation, and efficient collaboration in the AEC domain. Join us for an unforgettable journey into the future of construction and design. PREREQUISITES Basic knowledge of Rhino3D/Grasshopper Prior experience in point cloud processing is a plus, but not required Prior experience with digital fabrication is a plus, but not required The Team Behind the Scenes The team is currently working through the fabrication system that they will use for the workshop. Take a look behind the scenes at their prototypes and experiments with auxetic structures!

title: Advancing Computational Design Conference 2024 ‚Äì Dallas, TX
content: Advancing Computational Design Conference 2024 ‚Äì Dallas, TX The 2024 Advancing Computational Design Conference, hosted in Dallas by Hanson Wade, zeroed in on the core aspects of computational design through a technical and strategic lens. This event drew a notable crowd, featuring over 30 experts from the field, including speakers like Shajay Bhooshan of Zaha Hadid Architects, Robert Otani from Thornton Tomasetti, and Marcelo Bernal of Perkins&Will, alongside experts from leading firms such as Stantec and Gensler. Structured into two principal tracks, the conference offered a deep dive into computational design‚Äôs various facets. ‚ÄúComputation in Action‚Äù showcased the practical applications of computational design, with discussions on enhancing interoperability between software, refining scripting processes, and case studies demonstrating the significant impact of computational design. The ‚ÄúStrategic Leadership and Development‚Äù track explored broader themes, such as the formation and optimization of computational design teams, the advantages and disadvantages of in-house versus off-the-shelf tool development, and strategies for engaging end-users to transform complex design issues into innovative computational solutions. I contributed to a panel discussion titled ‚ÄúConsidering the Landscape of Off-The-Shelf Add-Ins to Select the Best Tools for Your Organization.‚Äù This discussion centered on evaluating the current market‚Äôs computational tools, their strengths, and limitations, and the rationale behind choosing between in-house development and off-the-shelf solutions. Highlight innovations at the conference included a Surrogate Machine Learning model that significantly accelerates climatic analysis, marking a significant advancement for sustainable design. Arup introduced their InForm tool ecosystem, offering a comprehensive suite of building simulation tools. Furthermore, Snaptrude was presented, a web-based platform designed to foster real-time collaborative building design and provide insightful data analytics.

title: AEC Hackathon ‚Äì Zurich Edition
content: AEC Hackathon ‚Äì Zurich EditionüèÜ Best Project that solves a big AEC problem üèÜ ùó®ùóªùóπùóºùó∞ùó∏ùó∂ùóªùó¥ ùóïùóúùó† ùó±ùóÆùòÅùóÆ ùóÆùòÅ ùòÅùóµùó≤ ùòÅùó≤ùóøùóÆùóØùòÜùòÅùó≤ sùó∞ùóÆùóπùó≤ üöÄ This weekend in Zurich, our team achieved a big feat at the AEC Hackathon. We introduced the ùóîùòÇùòÅùóºùó±ùó≤ùòÄùó∏ ùóñùóπùóºùòÇùó± ùó¶ùóΩùó≤ùó∞ùó∏ùóπùó≤ ùóñùóºùóªùóªùó≤ùó∞ùòÅùóºùóø ‚Äì a transformative solution that seamlessly integrates your Revit data from the Autodesk Cloud directly into Speckle. Speckle, known for its prowess as an open-source, accessible data platform, now serves as a real-time hub for your data, connecting a rich ecosystem of applications. Here‚Äôs how our innovation stands out: ùóòùó≥ùó≥ùóºùóøùòÅùóπùó≤ùòÄùòÄ ùóúùóªùòÅùó≤ùó¥ùóøùóÆùòÅùó∂ùóºùóª: Operates headlessly ‚Äì no need to open Revit. ùó≠ùó≤ùóøùóº ùóõùóÆùòÄùòÄùóπùó≤ ùó≥ùóºùóø ùóóùó≤ùòÄùó∂ùó¥ùóª ùóßùó≤ùóÆùó∫ùòÄ: Continue your usual sync to BIM360/ACC, and our solution takes care of the rest. ùóúùóªùòÅùó≤ùóπùóπùó∂ùó¥ùó≤ùóªùòÅ ùó®ùóΩùó±ùóÆùòÅùó≤ùòÄ: Always in sync with the latest model versions, ensuring your data is up-to-date. ùó£ùóºùòÑùó≤ùóø ùóºùó≥ ùó¢ùóΩùó≤ùóª ùó¶ùóºùòÇùóøùó∞ùó≤: Employs open-source IFC libraries for data conversion. But‚Ä¶ we didn‚Äôt stop there. To showcase the full potential of our solution, we developed‚Ä¶ BOOM BOOM is a sophisticated, extensible data table designed for precise quantity takeoffs from BIM models. What makes it remarkable? It operates independently of Revit, Rhino, or Grasshopper licenses, fully harnessing the accessibility of the Speckle data platform. This monumental achievement was made possible thanks to the exceptional dedication and expertise of our team: Adam , Christian , Cosmin , Daniel , Knut , Martijn , and Sylvain . Together, we turned this 2-day hackathon into loads of learning and collaboration. Thanks opensource.construction and AEC Hackathon for the event organization. title: New Pipeline Updates on Hub
content: The middle of January brought a significant update to our Pipeline app which tracks our future projects that are still leads and pursuits.¬† ¬†We are improving our customer relationship management ecosystem of applications on Hub to improve the continuum of engagement with our clients.¬† ¬†The tracking of these pursuits alongside the active work in the Project app, the completed work coming in the Portfolio app soon, and the client dashboards in the Clients & Consultants app give us a 360 view of the firm‚Äôs relationships with our clients. This update starts to line up our future projects with our active projects to make it a single-button step to move from Pipeline to Project apps and from future state to active state of any project.¬† ¬†We have also introduced a new interface that lines up with the experience you have in the Project app.¬† ¬†To see more about the updates check out the new quickstart here on the digital practice website with some info and all the recordings from intro sessions held with the marketing department and firm. In addition, this update has created a single project record moving forward that starts in the pursuit and goes to the active and completed state as a single record.¬† We have updated the revenue breakdown to match the 3 tier model of tracking the firm started in 2024 which also includes disciplines.¬† There are new views to track upcoming events and pursuit deadlines with a calendar view, a view to edit basic opportunity information right on the screen to utilize during marketing meetings and other occasions, tracking basic hit rates, seeing add services from PMTK that are categorized as draft status to understand what is in the pipeline from our current active work and an algorithm to push more detailed pursuit revenue forecasting out to more accurately predict work loads by studio and practice over time in the future.

title: Spatial & Data Analysis Community
content: In response to the dynamic growth of our community of analytical designers, we recognized the need for a more cohesive platform to facilitate interaction and collaboration. This led to the creation of a new channel within the Digital Practice MS Team, aptly named ‚Äú Spatial and Data Analytics .‚Äù This space is designed as a hub where enthusiasts and professionals alike can share insights, seek advice on Excel formulas, and showcase their innovative projects, such as PowerBi dashboards developed for tracking seat counts among various design options. The introduction of this channel marks a significant step forward in not only enhancing our collective expertise but also in fostering a culture of continuous learning and knowledge sharing. By leveraging powerful tools like AreaSync, Excel, and PowerBi, our firm is at the forefront of adopting advanced analytical methods. This channel serves as a testament to our commitment to innovation and excellence. As we continue to navigate through the complexities of data and spatial analytics, the channel will increasingly become a valuable repository of shared knowledge. We anticipate the Files area will evolve into an organized collection of resources, further enriching our community‚Äôs skillset. Moreover, the initiation of monthly meetings represents a pivotal development for our community. These gatherings are an opportunity to present project work, exchange ideas, and discuss methodologies and approaches, thereby enhancing our collective understanding and application of analytical design. The first of these meetings has already been recorded and is available for viewing. We encourage all interested members to reach out via the channel to express their interest in participating in future meetings. This is more than just a channel; it‚Äôs a growing ecosystem of analytical designers eager to push the boundaries of what‚Äôs possible with data and design. P&W Data Analysis ‚Äì Community of Practice meeting

title: Decarbonization,  Keynote and Panel discussion theme for Core eXchange 2024
content: The Theme for the first Core eXchange of 2024 was Decarbonization. On Tuesday January 16 th, we had our keynote presentation, Disrupting Concrete Construction , by Philippe Block, followed by a panel discussion about the ‚ÄúDecarbonization at Perkins&Will‚Äù, moderated by Amina Helstern with experts Dalton Ho, Amy Brander, Jesce Walz, and Trevor Butler as panelist. Our keynote speaker, Philippe Block, is a full professor and head of the Institute of Technology in Architecture (ITA) at ETH Zurich, where he co-leads the Block Research Group (BRG) with Dr. Tom Van Mele, and director of the Swiss National Centre of Competence in Research (NCCR) on Digital Fabrication. Philippe presented innovative use of concrete in vaulted floor application that created strength through geometry, increased material effectiveness and achieved reduction of embodied carbon and lower GWP through circular construction. The Decarbonization panel discussion convened experts from across Perkins&Will to look at the various Decarbonization efforts being pursued across the company. They delved into the strategies for optimizing material use, reducing embodied carbon, and exploring operational carbon. Key topics include the impact of construction materials on the environment, innovative approaches to reducing carbon emissions, and the utilization of advanced modeling techniques in design and construction. To watch the keynote and panel discussion, please visit the digital practice website or follow these links: View Philippe Block Keynote Presentation View Panel Talk: Decarbonization at Perkins&Will

title: Revit 2024 Announcement
content: Important Update on Revit 2024 Deployment at Perkins&Will Revit 2024 will not be deployed at Perkins&Will. In a departure from previous years, we are opting to skip the Revit 2024 version due to an unresolved error within the Revit 2024 code. Should this error occur, drawing elements may vanish without alerting the user. Such incidents pose a serious risk to the integrity of our work. Firm Directive: Do Not Use Revit 2024 You may encounter situations where collaborating firms propose using Revit 2024. It is imperative that you do not consent to this. The error behaves contagiously and is particularly hazardous in collaborative environments; prevention is impossible. This measure is critical to ensure that our drawings maintain the highest standard of care. We are collaborating with other leading firms and Autodesk to resolve this issue in upcoming releases. If you have any questions, be sure to get in touch with Nick Cameron or your Digital Practice leader immediately. Positive Outlook Fortunately, we identified this issue early, thereby preventing any upgrades of live projects from being affected. This proactive decision ensures that our projects remain free from the risk of data loss. Furthermore, the latest improvements developed in the 2024 template will be added to a new 2023 template. This means all your ongoing and upcoming projects will be able to leverage these enhancements. Keep an eye out for updates on the Digital Practice training program, as it will provide you with a preview of the new features and efficiencies available in the updated Revit template.

title: Digital Practice Core eXchange ‚Äì Q1 2024
content: The first quarter Digital Practice Core eXchange is almost upon us, running from Tuesday January 16 th through Friday January 19 th .¬† We will kickstart this year‚Äôs exchanges by taking a look at Decarbonization at Perkins&Will, starting with a Keynote presentation from Philippe Block on Disrupting Concrete Construction: digital, sustainable, and circular .¬† From Philippe: Concrete is an artificial stone, and like stone, it does not want to be a straight beam, it wants to be a masonry arch. Following the motto ‚Äústrength through geometry‚Äù and the principles of traditional unreinforced masonry construction, this talk will show how translating the (lost) knowledge of the Gothic master builders into today‚Äôs praxis results in truly sustainable, circular and economical structures, addressing climate change by significantly reducing embodied emissions, utilizing fewer single-use resources and minimizing construction waste. We will follow our Keynote with a Panel discussion on our decarbonization efforts at Perkins&Will and a Workshop on the tools at our disposal. The week will then continue with a few returning classes on updates to HUB, the best practices surrounding SharePoint, and Emerging Digital Tools.¬† We will have new sessions on Large Project Strategy and Management, Video Editing, BIM Management and Collaboration, and the new PW Revit Template. We will also be hosting our first semiannual Innovation Incubator Spotlight session, highlighting two of our recently completed Spring Innovation Incubators. The invites for the Digital Practice Core eXchange will be trickling in over the next few days, so stay tuned!

title: Area Sync 2.16.1
content: We‚Äôve been hard at work improving Area Sync. Since our last update, we‚Äôve added several asked-for features and eliminated some bugs that should hopefully make your use of Area Sync even smoother. Better overall support for Multi-models We have added features all over the app to support the cases where a team is working on several files, or even several apps like Revit and Rhino at the same time. On the web, is possible now to display multiple syncs using Diagrammr . On Revit, you‚Äôll see what model is active if you have several files opened. Syncing from Rhino is now more flexible since you are able to select to which model to sync to. On the visualization tab on the web is now possible to overlay multiple models (or syncs together). Metrics Until now, on the main Area Sync tab you would see a total area representing all rooms from the latest sync or the current Revit model. Area Sync now is capable of filtering, trimming and narrowing down these total by using what we call a Metric. Metrics help teams keep an eye on what‚Äôs relevant at a given time, or for a particular stakeholder. This feature is still in beta and will likely change a little before reach stability. Please tell us what you think! Excel workflows imports/exports The visualization tab (also known as Diagrammr ) now offer way more options for importing and exporting your data from Area Sync or even from/to Revit and Excel. Handling bulk edits on spreadsheet applications like Excel is way easier and some project managers take it even further to develop analysis on top of this data. Assets tracking PowerBI dashboards We have started developing dashboards combining Speckle and Area Sync to track assets and furnitures inside Revit/Rhino models. You can download our current version of this dashboard from [INSERT-LINK-HERE]. New features: Included support for Revit 2024 Pie chart visualization on Diagrammr Filtering capabilities on Diagrammr Export to PowerBi from Diagrammr Import rooms and areas from Excel Multi-model/sync visualization on Diagrammr Auto populate column with AI (Beta) Sort model by Column Default color scheme Metrics (Beta) Display current active model in Revit Fixes: Ignored rooms without levels during sync. Find and replace issues Color palettes from Revit Incorrectly sync model naming We‚Äôre excited for the coming year and for all of the new features we‚Äôre planning on adding to Area Sync!

title: SpeckleCon 2023
content: SpeckleCon 2023 SpeckleCon is an online conference that gathered over 1,500 people to engage, discuss, and collaborate on topics that matter to us in the AEC technology space. Centering around the utilization of Speckle . Over two days, we had the chance to hear from fellow colleagues and experts who shared specific use cases and demoed how Speckle enabled them to unlock and own their data to deliver projects faster and more efficiently. We closed our first day with a Panel Conversation inviting experts from DAR, Jacobs, HENN, and Speckle to discuss data strategies in AEC. On Dev Day, Speckle announced a new service called Automate, an iterative tool designed for developers, engineers, and architects. It allows workflows to run automatically after every model change in Speckle, removing the need for manual intervention. This announcement included demos and interactions with the tool, showcasing its value for the AEC industry. Also during dev day, Victor and Daniel from Schmidt Hammer Lassen / Perkins&Will hosted a one-hour live coding session building and app from scratch on top of Speckle, the app is a catalogue for furniture used inside Revit/Rhino models. The whole conference is available online at SpeckleCon: It‚Äôs A Wrap!

title: Field Report: From AU 2023
content: In the VanCal Digital Practice Monthly Update, Elton Gjata discussed the future of Synology and digital tools, suggesting a shift towards multiple specialized tools over a single comprehensive tool like Autodesk‚Äôs Revit. Johanna Becker introduced an innovative use of chat technology for preliminary data analysis in building estimation. Gjata also highlighted a tool called ‚ÄúPocket Engineer,‚Äù which integrates ChatGPT for querying mechanical data and retrieving information like product discontinuation and preliminary pricing. The meeting concluded with discussions on data exchange tools, with a focus on the flexibility and Autodesk-centric nature of current solutions, and the potential for more platform-agnostic approaches.

title: Holiday Hub Happenings
content: With the holidays upon us and the new year on the horizon, we‚Äôve been hard at work adding new features, squashing bugs, and preparing for our transition away from Pulse to Hub. Speaking of bugs, we‚Äôd like to thank all of you using the Feedback button to provide those valuable bug reports and feature requests. On to the update! Benefits We added the Benefits app back in October to assist our US-based studios during their Open Enrollment period. Thrive For this year, we rolled all of the constituent parts of Thrive into a single, unified app to help you get more from your Thrive reviews. Job Descriptions We‚Äôve also added a new job descriptions app to better clarify what it is we all do and help us all get a baseline understanding of each others skills, experiences, and responsibilities. Clients & Consultants The Organization app has been renamed to Clients & Consultants . It‚Äôs still keeping the functionality of the Org app while allowing us to add dashboard capabilities for clients and eventually consultants in order to better align with our client executive program and the CRM tools they may need. Firmwide Calendar We added the capability of displaying a studio calendar. Studio‚Äôs will need to request that this be enabled for your people. Once enabled, it can be used to manage local events and happenings in your studios! Project App We‚Äôve made the DEAR submission and management process easier within the Project app by adding a wizard as well as consolidating it all into a submissions page. We‚Äôve also added an Export to CSV button in the staffing section (under PMTK)! Lastly, in October in preparation for the RAMP committee review we made a number of small changes in the RAMP page. Now you can see risk management notes and actions. Innovation Apps The Innovation Library received a bit of a visual touchup. We also went back and consolidated all previous data that had been on soon-to-be-retired knowledge repositories into the library app. We also launched Innovation Submissions to streamline the Innovation Incubator submission and review process. Design Management The Project¬†apps design-focused counterpart. Storyboard, Living Design, and Design Review can all be found here and is intended to act as a quick studio overview dashboard for design directors and leaders. Strategic Action Plan The SAP app has been updated for this year and should reflect all studio‚Äôs latest strategic action plans.¬† ¬†We have revised per our nine-dimension grid of focus areas as well as summarized all the studio‚Äôs action plans using AI. Client-Facing Design Guidelines Recently, we built out a forward-facing app for one of our corporate clients to act as their global design standards playbook. Rather than relying on previous static processes to design and deliver the guidebook we created a flexible, smart, and easy to use site that‚Äôs easy to navigate and can be data-driven. We agreed to host this playbook for the next 5 years and they can continue contributing to it. We can now use this frame to deliver similar services to the rest of our clients! Plus Survey Finally, quick reminder that the Plus Survey app can be found on Hub.

title: Naming, classification, AI, sentence transformers and other boring things at AECTech Hackathon 2023
content: The problem Naming things is Boring. How many times you name something on a building? Think of a room and how stakeholders could name the same room: John Kennedy Conference Room (Client) Conference Room 101 (20p) (Architect) Conference (Energy Engineer) Office (Structural Engineer) C-NYC.101 (Facilities Management) The process of labelling all this is tedious and prone to mistakes. By practicing in an increasingly world of standards, classification systems and regulations to comply, we saw an opportunity that could help various stakeholders of the AEC industry. Boring ‚Äì AI real-time naming and classification Boring is an innovative AI-powered application designed to revolutionize how we understand and process textual data. Utilizing advanced Sentence Transformers (sorry, not the usual Midjourney/GPT tech, but still extremely useful) this application excels in identifying text similarities and classifying words with remarkable precision. It delves deep into the nuances of language (mispelling, different language, etc), enabling users to uncover hidden connections between different texts and to categorize words based on context with a high degree of confidence. Whether it‚Äôs for environmental analysis, structural engineering, life cycle assessments, or cost estimations, Boring offers a powerful tool for anyone looking to extract deeper meaning and insights from textual data. The app was designed to be available for users in Revit, Rhino, Pollination, Web and so on. We looked at this solution at the CORE studio at Thornton Tomasetti # AECtech hackathon, and got an honorable mention üèÜ among the other very interesting proposals. The team was composed by Nick Cameron, Jason Diammond, Ellen Berglund, Daniel Boba and me from Perkins&Will, we teamed up with Mostapha from LadybugTools/Pollination and Alexander Matthias from BIG. The hackathon application has been open sourced and some of the participants are still contributing to this project. Maybe you can join it as well! Github: https://lnkd.in/efJdGij3 ‚ÄúWorking‚Äù on hackathons Participating in hackathons is a thrilling and educational experience, blending creativity, technical skills, and teamwork. These events, typically lasting from 24 to 48 hours, require participants to quickly identify a problem and devise a solution. The first step is usually pinpointing a relevant problem that is both challenging and achievable within the given timeframe. Forming a balanced team comes next; it should comprise individuals with diverse skills, including coding, design, project management, and domain-specific knowledge. This diversity ensures a holistic approach to problem-solving. It also makes the process much more fun, when a team is diverse in skills and expertise, each member brings a unique set of abilities to the table, reducing the likelihood of anyone feeling left out or idle. Effective time management is vital, as is maintaining a balance between ambition and practicality in the proposed solution. Regular communication within the team and with mentors, if available, helps refine ideas and overcome technical hurdles. The intense, collaborative nature of hackathons not only fosters innovation but also offers a unique learning environment, where participants can expand their skills and network with like-minded individuals. There are several of other hackathons hosted around the world, both focused on the AEC but also other industries. I hope you consider joining one of them sooner rather than later. In Copenhagen we usually join the AEC Hackathon BLOXHUB event that happens on Spring. See you there!

title: AU Presentation: ISO Believe 19650 Can Improve Project Delivery
content: David Sewell and I had given a class on Autodesk University about working on the projects towards¬† ISO 19650, mainly sharing our personal, practical experience but also explaining fundamentals about the standard. Our London office has been pioneering project leadership in adherence to ISO 19650 since 2016. This international standard holds the key to fostering commonality in work practices, streamlined delivery teams, and interconnected datasets. However, as promising as it sounds, ISO 19650 has often been accompanied by challenges such as a new language, complex standards, and the emergence of siloed BIM experts. The class aimed to bridge the gap, ensuring that professionals across diverse locations could grasp the essence of ISO 19650 and apply it strategically rather than adhering to a rigid, one-size-fits-all approach. A key takeaway from the class was the emphasis on aligning with a strategic and pragmatic approach, as opposed to a mandatory verbatim implementation. We highlighted real-world examples, offering a nuanced understanding of how ISO 19650 can be integrated seamlessly, from different roles perspective, without the need for excessive additional hours. What is ISO 19650? The ISO 19650 standard is a framework, set by the International Organization of Standardization, to outline the recommended processes for managing information about buildings and assets, throughout the asset lifecycle. The successful implementation of ISO 19650 hinges on collaboration among project stakeholders. This collective effort encompasses the entire project team ‚Äì the client, project managers, designers, constructors (from Tier 1 down to package/trade), cost consultants, key manufacturers/suppliers, and of course asset/facilities managers. Effective teamwork demands a structured and open collaboration. The ISO 19650 standard is a key player in this landscape, aiming to ensure that the right information reaches the right people at the right time for informed decision-making. It promotes a consistent approach across all project stages, streamlining the delivery of handover information in a standardized format for use in other business platforms and applications. While the many pages of the standard can seem confusing initially, the premise of the standard is there to benefit everybody and identifies key tasks for all project stakeholders. In super simplified terms: ÔÇ∑ The client defines What ‚Ä¶ is required through design, construction and into operation stages. ÔÇ∑ The delivery team, led usually by one named organization depending on project stage, responds with How ‚Ä¶. the requirements will be delivered by a collaborative project team. ÔÇ∑ The delivery team then generates the information via common platforms with approval gates to ensure the delivery of solid information. There is often a strong focus on the continuous operation and maintenance of the asset. Working this way means that requirements are clear from project outset and better, fit for purpose information is produced progressively by the appropriate party. An audit trail can be captured showing when decisions were made, by who and at what time during the project delivery process. This all means better collaboration and coordination along with consistent outputs being delivered at handover ready for reuse in operation. Watch the full class here: If you would like to know more about the standard here is the link for really useful guidelines.

title: Portfolio Explorer
content: The lightweight, data-driven, 3D map-based portfolio planning + exploration tool Data Driven Styling With Ease Creating data driven maps used to require experts your team might not have, now you can see your data visualized in the map with a only a few clicks. Thematically render your data with numeric and categorical styles for quick control of synchronized map and chart based visualization. Geometry and Data in the Map Portfolio Explorer is the foundation for web based, 3d map experiences driven by data. Create a portfolio of assets from your project data, style it, and share it with your stakeholders. It is that simple. If you have a project in Revit or Rhino, use the Area Sync plugins to push your data to the cloud. Portfolio Explorer is directly connected to the same source, making it possible to bring your models and all their data to the map.

title: Finding and Using Your AI Voice
content: Like fast food and fast fashion, fast design is accessible, convenient, with endless varieties. However, there is a deep social impact of feeding into the culture of consumerism and disposability as well as raising questions of authenticity. However, fast design with AI can generate an echo-chamber effect without the right guidance of prompts. This is how biases and stereotypes are perpetuated through a spiral of validating results by generating similar outcomes that continue to add to the statistical data. Developing a process and having an understanding the prompt composition is part of how to find your personal AI voice. It is in the personalization of the process that keeps the human at the center of the design story. There is a high responsibility to write our digital heritage with a rich blend of voices from our diverse collective. It is this ongoing collective of individual and personal design voices that promote equitable and inclusive practices.

title: Field Report: From ACADIA 2023 ‚Äì Habits of the Anthropocene
content: ACADIA 2023, Habits of the Anthropocene The Association for Computer-Aided Design in Architecture, ACADIA, is an international network of researchers and professionals exploring the role of computation in architecture, planning, and building science and its impact on innovation, creativity, sustainability, and education. Every year, ACADIA organizes an international conference to share the most recent research peer-reviewed articles and experimental projects. This year the 2023 ACADIA conference was held in person at the University of Colorado Denver College of Architecture and Planning in Denver, October 26-28, sponsored by Perkins&Will. The 2023 Call, Habits of the Anthropocene, was an invitation to migrate from a Building-Centric to a Human-Centric perspective, examining suppressed voices, indigenous and feminist thinking, unconventional theories, and new trends in technology. The three-day event, preceded by a week of online workshops, was structured around three main tracks: Biomaterials, production processes, and the impact of AI in design. The first day explored how to harvest, grow, and apply all kinds of new biomaterials in design, The second day investigated production approaches ranging from controlled growing techniques to printing and assembling methods. The final day was divided between human-centric topics and AI applications in Architecture. Perkins&Will Design Process Lab presented the article ‚ÄúA general-purpose deep-learning surrogate model for annual daylight distribution‚Äù by Spyridon Ampanavos, Marcelo Bernal, and Victor Okhoya. This research is intended to accelerate the time-consuming daylight simulations and facilitate easy access to designers by implementing predictive models while preserving the accuracy of the results

title: Exploring the Model as the Deliverable
content: This past quarter‚Äôs Core eXchange theme day was all about exploring and investigating how we can use the models that we generate as potential high resolution design intent figures. In our keynote session for the day we had several of our designers as well as Zahner facilitators share their experiences, lesson‚Äôs learned, and key takeaways from their time spent at Zahner‚Äôs Kansas City lab as well as the continuing working efforts of their working partnership. For our panel discussion we were excited to have Mark Walsh, our global director of technical design, as well as Zahner‚Äôs President, Tom Zahner, to discuss the potential impact of advanced modeling on the AEC industry. They delved into automated design processes and the ever-evolving role of modeling in our project delivery methods as well as how we can collectively contribute to shaping the future of design and technology through advanced modeling techniques. The final session for the Model as the Deliverable themed day, was all about getting hands-on training in using the PWZ toolkit, co-developed by Perkins&Will and Zahner, followed by instructions on how to best get in contact and get your projects working with Zahner.

title: Grasshopper Snippets 2.7
content: We‚Äôre finally bringing Snippets into Rhino! We‚Äôve updated snippets with 13 commands that should save you tons of time while working within Rhino 1Layout1PDF Dealing with a lot of layouts? This will batch export them all for you. 1Layout1JPG Same as before but with JPG‚Äôs, for a quick review of the layouts. Srf2Hatch Creates a hatch from a surface. SelectObjectsLayers Select the layers of the objects you currently have selected. CreateLayoutsLandscape Automatically create Layouts for your 2D Drawings in Landscape mode using a rectangles as frames. CreateLayoutsPortrait Same as before but for portrait layouts. PrintManyFiles Print all .3DM models on a folder in one go. ExportManyCAD Export all the .3DM models on a folder to DWG. MoveBlockObjectsToLayer Lost control of the objects inside your block? Move them all to one layer. MoveBlockObjectsToInstanceLayer Same as above, but move objects to the selected instance layer. PasteToCursor Paste things with your mouse. RenameBlock Lets you easily rename a selected block. UnrollMany Takes a 3D object and unrolls it into a plane. You can install Snippets by using the PackageManager command found inside Rhino and then searching for Snippets . Have fun and let us know if you have any other ideas for features we can add in the future!

title: Computational Design Working  Group: Designing with Physics!
content: Computational Design Working Group: Designing with Physics! The Bi-Weekly Computational Design Working Group has been meeting in the Teams/DigitalPractice/Computational Design channel for the past several months. We‚Äôd like to thank everyone who has attended and reinvite anyone who hasn‚Äôt attended. No prior experience necessary! Anyone interested in advanced design workflows is encouraged to join us. The agenda is available here (and also in a tab at the top of the Teams channel). Feel free to add a discussion topic and put your name next to it so we can discuss it up on the next call. Undulating Glass Courtyard Roof Here is one example of a design exercise that was discussed on a recent call. The design challenge was to enclose an interior courtyard with an undulating glazed diagrid roof structure, similar to the inspirational examples of the Smithsonian Kogol courtyard and King‚Äôs Cross station roof shown here. For more information about this computational workflow reach out to Luc Deckinga. For information about the overall project reach out to Dan McTavish and Ugonna Ohakim. Smithsonian Kogol Courtyard King‚Äôs Cross Station Rhino & Grasshopper Rhino was chosen as the design platform because of its ability to create smooth, flexible geometry that can be easily modified. Grasshopper, a visual scripting platform integrated into Rhino, provides an even faster way to investigate design options. Key parameters, like the number of surface subdivisions, can be linked to sliders in Grasshopper to quickly achieve the desired surface resolution. Sliders in Grasshopper control the number of points in each direction. Kangaroo Physics The design team investigated several different ways to translate the design surface into a diagrid, eventually deciding on a form-finding method that relies upon Kangaroo, a Grasshopper plugin that enables you to apply real-world physics forces to your geometry. Kangaroo can convert a surface into a grid of points, connected to one another by springs. This effectively turns the surface into a piece of fabric that can be draped, pinned, stretched, and deformed based on the forces that you apply to it. In the example below the perimeter points have been ‚Äòanchored‚Äô in place so they do not move. All points are connected to one another with lines that try to maintain the same length. This turns the surface into a spring network. Finally, a uniform ‚Äòup‚Äô force is applied to all the points, stretching the springs, eventually arriving at a catenary surface that is fit to the courtyard. The physics simulation runs, slowly stretching the spring network over time. It will eventually stop moving when all forces are resolved and the network comes to rest in a catenary shape. Solid Body Collisions There are many different forces within the Kangaroo library. For additional control over the diagrid shape the design team used a technique called solid body collision, which forces the points in the spring network to stay outside of another object in the scene. In the example below there are two spheres being used as the solid bodies. You must start with the bodies away from the points and slowly push the solid bodies towards the points. If you start with the points inside the bodies they don‚Äôt know which way is ‚Äòout‚Äô and so they don‚Äôt know which direction to move. Before After The Before image shows the solid bodies and deformed surface. The After image shows the final diagrid form. Stay Tuned‚Ä¶ This project is still in the early stages so it will change and develop over time. Join us on the bi-weekly computational design call to stay up to date on this, and many other interesting projects and workflows being executed throughout the firm. See you at our next meeting on October 10 in the Digital Practice/Computational Design teams channel !

title: Hub August Updates
content: Hub continues to evolve with the Project app and other apps in the ecosystem. A few minor items that show up in the last couple of months. On Hold Status has been updated in the app with a better UI to reflect confirmation and updates to hold dates. Showing design and construction start and end dates from the schedule info on the Info Center page. Small updates to include more data about 3rd party certifications and Media Hits which can be found under the marketing section of the app. Started to tag DEAR Stage 1 projects per the Design Leadership Council based on general thresholds of size and project stage of all projects firmwide. Requesting a new project phase in Deltek right from creating a new phase for your project in Hub. Added K-12 specific project keyword tags to go along with the other market sectors we have keywords for. We have introduced a new Social Purpose app .¬† ¬†This app pulls in projects from PMTK that are defined as a program type of Social Purpose.¬† This is to showcase the work the firm does for those who need design services that don‚Äôt have the budget.¬† We also have an area to plan and track all volunteer events that your Service + group may be planning and engaging in at the local studio level.¬† We also highlight studio leaders who help organize and maintain the culture Social Purpose provides in our firm. We have introduced a Year End Planning Calendar app (limited access) which is simply to communicate the events and steps for all the efforts around wrapping up the current year and planning for the next.¬† ¬†This includes leadership meetings, business planning, US Open Enrollment, DEAR, Technical Design Reviews, PLUS for clients and teams, Thrive, MOD Reviews, Leadership program, and Incentive Compensation Program. The Project Delivery Manual app is coming soon as we lift it up off of Pulse and shift it over to Hub in an effort to decommission Pulse by the end of this year. The Contracts app (limited access) is being introduced as a place to track what projects have client and consultant contracts uploaded.¬† It also gives a single interface to manage all project contracts for your studio if you have a point person or team that works with those files. A reminder that there is a Studio calendar option within the Firmwide calendar app.¬† ¬†Many studios have set this up as a way to have a single point of all the studio events going on.¬† ¬†If you don‚Äôt see this option for yourself in the Firmwide Calendar app, please coordinate with your studio management to see if this would be a good solution to set up for your own studio to help communicate the culture of what is happening around here.

title: PWZ Workshop 2023 at Zahner Headquarters
content: Hands-On Fabrication Workshop at Zahner Headquarters in Kansas City August 16-18 Designers from several Perkins&Will studios gathered in Zahner‚Äôs Kansas City headquarters for a 3-day workshop August 15th to 18th. The goal of the workshop was to introduce our designers to advanced metal manipulation techniques that you can achieve working with a sophisticated partner like Zahner. Experimentation was focused on digital-direct-to-fabrication methods that Zahner uses on their ImageLines , ImageWall , and PrecisionPatina to perforate, deform, and pattern their metal surfaces. (Online tools are available for you to play around with each of those. Try the links!) Each design team started by designing a 2‚Äôx2‚Ä≤ panel to become familiar with the various surfacing techniques and then scaled up to a 5‚Äôx10‚Ä≤ zone on a mock-up tower that Zahner prepared to install the final results of the workshop. Check out some photos from our time there and stay tuned for presentations from our designers, or reach out to them directly and ask about their experience in Kansas City. We would like to make this a recurring workshop, so if you would like to attend a future iteration let us know! Check out this video that Zahner produced of our time there! If you‚Äôd like to learn more about the Perkins&Will partnership with Zahner or to contact Zahner in regards to a project you are working on, reach out to the workshop organizers and they can get you in touch with the right people. Attendees: Mahdiar Ghaffarian, Charlie Portelli, Thiago Silvino, Nick Cameron, Stefan Burnett, Ron Stelmarski, Mark Walsh, Wyatt Beard, Thomas Mozina, David D‚ÄôAndrea, Andrew Frontini Organizers: Mario Romero and Luc Deckinga along with Burcin Nalinci, and Nathan Barnes of ZahnerLabs Scroll to the bottom to load image gallery‚Ä¶

title: Exploring the World of AI in and Outside P&W

author.name: Nick Cameron
author.description: American trucker who has been featured on the History channel reality television series Ice Road Truckers and its spinoff series IRT: Deadliest Roads.

content: Thanks to all who were able to join us for the Core Exchange Artificial Intelligence Keynote and panel discussions. Your presence and active participation made these events truly remarkable. For those who couldn‚Äôt join us we are excited to share links to the recorded sessions, so you can catch up on all the valuable insights and thought-provoking discussions. Phil Bernstein Keynote: In our first session, Phil Bernstein, the Associate Dean of Yale University‚Äôs School of Architecture, shared insights from his new book Machine Learning: Architecture in the age of Artificial Intelligence . His keynote provided a comprehensive overview of how AI is and will shape the design industry. Click Here to Watch Now Our Use of AI at Perkins&Will Our second session delved into how AI is already being used in our studios to generate ideas and perform redundant tasks. Our panel of experts shared their first-hand experiences, insights, and potential concerns related to AI‚Äôs transformative impact on the AEC industry. The session was a captivating exploration of the vast potential that AI holds for design and technology. If you‚Äôre curious about how your colleagues are already working with AI tools then check out this session. Click Here to Watch Now The Future of AI in Project Delivery The final panel discussion featured experts both within and outside our firm, engaging in a fascinating dialogue about the potential disruption AI will bring to the AEC industry. The discussion covered automated design processes, AI‚Äôs evolving role in project delivery, and how we can actively shape the future of design and technology. Click Here to Watch Now Once again, thank you to everyone who participated in these AI panel discussions. Your curiosity and passion for AI have made these events special. We believe that AI will continue to play a crucial role in shaping the future of design and technology, and we look forward to exploring further possibilities with you.

title: PMTK July Updates
content: PMTK: New Features 2Q We are excited to be adding some more new functionality to the PMTK.¬† We have been doing many small requests and minor improvements from your feedback along the way since the initial rollout in March.¬† This update introduces several new features all of which were suggestions by all of you through the feedback button or in prior meetings.¬†¬†Thank you everyone for keeping the conversation going and letting us know how we can keep making this tool better. The following is a list of the significant improvements that have been added to the toolkit last week. Details by Phase This feature introduces a new page under the PMTK portion of the navigation that brings together items from the schedule, budget, and staffing pages filter phase by phase.¬† You can choose to switch and look at whatever phase you want to in this focused view.¬† This also makes progress metrics more prominent to understand where you are at in any given phase. Snapshot Staffing We have added to the snapshot function on the budget page the feature to save multiple versions of your staffing plan.¬†¬† You can use this what-if scenario building to create multiple labor plans that test options you are considering before adjusting your working plan budget and staffing. Bill Rate Costing This feature is found in the actions drop-down of the staffing page and has a function to change the visibility of the related rows on the budget page.¬† Now you can model your labor costs based on bill rates in addition to cost rates which you have control over to adjust the bill rates to reflect your specific contract on your project. Add Services Table This new feature can be found under the actions drop-down on the top right of the Budget page. ¬†This was modeled after the countless Excel table examples many of you shared with us to track add services with the breakdown of fees between our firm and our consultants.¬† This will allow you to track the progress of a proposed add service as you draft it and seek client approval. Inflation Factor The details of this can be found in the actions drop-down on the Budget page.¬† We are now building in standard factors to account for the yearly raises at the firm that increase our own labor and overhead costs into the future.¬† This will be added to our ETC numbers and will be opt-in for active projects and default for new projects. Consultant Management Fee/Markup This new feature can be found under the actions drop-down on the top right of the Budget page. ¬†It allows you to add a markup fee that will be added to the contract total based on a percentage of your reimbursable consultant feeds. There are several other small improvements like milestone imports and templates on the schedule page.¬†¬† The ability to request a new Deltek phase directly from the schedule view after you make a phase later in the project after the initial setup.¬†¬† Others have been introduced over the last couple of months and more are to come in the coming weeks and months. We will continue to have training series happening to cover these items.¬† Please watch for invites on the PWU channel. As always keep using the feedback tool to share your ideas and report bugs.¬†¬† We have also introduced a PMTK Teams channel under the Digital Practice Microsoft Team if you want to connect directly to someone to ask any how-to questions.

title: Goodbye Hive, Welcome AVAIL
content: Better Content Management System for BIM and other apps In July we completed migration to our new cloud BIM content management platform ‚Äì AVAIL All content from HIVE was migrated to AVAIL, metadata was captured, and objects tagged. All US content is published in the PW Imperial 2022 channel, and each international office maintains their own channel. Digital Practice created the QuickStart Guide and conducted series of trainings. Feedback has been very positive. Users noted significant improvement in responsiveness, adaptive search using dynamic filters, and in general better ‚ÄúFindability‚Äù of the content. User‚Äôs favorite features are Hi-Rez preview of sheets and details, packages, ability to share a link to an object with your collegue, and tips for finding relevant Autodesk out of the box content. This was a first step of the migration , we are already working to refine previews where needed, and to create additional packages based on your requests and feedback. This refinement process will continue. Do not be shy! Help us to make our content better. Please let us know if you find any issues with objects by flagging them and commenting. If you want to add/publish additional content, please talk with your local DA. If you need a¬† package spanning multiple offices, let Helen Gorina know. AVAIL is content agnostic, and is not limited by one application . Revit content migration was just the first phase. We are exploring workflows for other types of objects and other applications, and will update you as new channels will be published.

title: Artifact User Interface Updates & Project Viewer
content: Artifact User Interface Updates & Project Viewer Artifact helps designers find existing drawings that solve current design challenges. To accomplish this the Artifact interface was designed to search, filter, save, and share the drawings that have been added to the database. Aiprentice, the developer of Artifact, has just released a new, cleaner search UI that incorporates your feedback over the past several years. Another thing we have discovered as more of you use Artifact, is that many of you want to view an entire drawing set at once, similar to flipping through a PDF. To accomplish this we‚Äôve created a Project Viewer . Click on the project name or sheet number in the right-hand info sidebar of any view in Artifact (see image below). Check out the recent Core eXchange presentation for more info on the UI changes and Project Viewer. Navigation has been consolidated to a sidebar on the left. All the actions available in the drawing sidebar, including links to the new Project Viewer interface. What is Artifact? How do I log in? Artifact is the Revit drawing search website that turns your text notes and metadata into search terms, so you find exactly the drawing you‚Äôre looking for and adapt it to a new project. Artifact is a collaboration between AIPrentice, a software developer, and Perkins&Will‚Äôs Digital Practice department.¬† To log in automatically with your Perkins&Will credentials, go to Pwitter (green arrow) > Microsoft MyApps > Artifact. Add Your Work to Artifact Artifact is only as good as the content within, so we are asking you to contribute your studio‚Äôs work. Please talk to the technical and design leadership within your studio to identify projects to include, and coordinate with your Digital Practice representative, or Digital Practice Manager Luc Deckinga, to add your content. As of this article, we have 106,248 drawings in the Artifact database, taken from 161 completed projects designed by twenty different Perkins&Will studios. Let‚Äôs see how long it takes us to get to 200,000! Thanks for all your help and support! We will continue to improve Artifact and add new features. Stay tuned.

title: Latest PMTK and Hub updates

Most of the recent updates have been minor items in PMTK Embed the project‚Äôs Miro board as a page under the Design area of the project app On Hold assignment process on the schedule page with email notifications to confirm Adding ad-hoc consultant types as needed Contact work phone field Social purpose program type for upcoming social purpose app Import milestones function for the schedules Ability by PM to revise and resubmit budget for approval before they are reviewed labor by phase and labor by studio information on the staffing page exclude staffing plans from the studio staffing app function better contract organization for multiple files automated a few more RAMP questions based on other PMTK data fields We are bringing a bundle of July updates to PMTK that were requested previously and just were not part of our version 1 rollout. Add services tracking matrix Inflation factor projection for staffing and overhead ETC numbers (and ultimately EAC) Consultant Management fee for projects that have those for their reimbursable consultants. Phase focus page that brings together the schedule, budget, and staffing info filtered down to the phase level Cash management page that reads basic invoice information from Deltek P drive folder setup process for starting new projects found on the Info Center page Bill rates alternative rates used for managing labor by a different factor We have also been introducing updated PowerBI dashboards based on PMTK and financial numbers.¬† ¬†All of these will migrate over to Hub as we move our OneView platform to be a Hub app as well from where you can find our firm‚Äôs dashboard information.

title: NXT BLD/DEV 2023 Recap
content: On the 20th and 21st of June some of our European teammates gathered in London to attend the NXT BLD and NXT DEV conferences. NXT BLD is known for being an event which explores emerging technologies for the built environment, beyond BIM. The talks and panels were recorded and made available on the conference website: NXT BLD: https://nxtbld.com/live-stream-2023-register/ NXT DEV: https://nxtdev.build/view-on-demand/ Here‚Äôs some of the most interesting talks: NXT BLD Part: 3 Assemble This talk continues from two previous parts given in the previous conference years. Greg Schleusner from HOK advocates for an Entity Component System pattern for AEC to share data between various software applications. This pattern is the standard for the Gaming industry and the talk goes through how this could also be applied in our industry. One for the key elements highlighted is the use of USD, the data schema developed by Pixar and still most popular on the filming and gaming industry to transfer data. Towards Sustainable Design Technologies Michael exposes how the design technology team at **Herzog & De Meuron** operates and exposes some of the design tooling developed in-house to assist designers in various tasks in both Rhino and Revit world. They are approaching BIM standards by using configuration files to quickly generate BIM templates that can adapt to different locations and regulations. This could potentially be a game changer for BIM implementation in the industry. Michael talks about different approaches to BIM depending on the project stage or client requirements. They work within three categories: **BIM Light, BIM Standard and BIM Maximum**. BIM Light usually happens early stage during design concept, while BIM Standard falls into normal BIM practice and BIM Maximum defines customized workflows and advanced data modelling. The talk also gives an overview on how this processes evolved during a decade. Cloaked in Bureaucracy: The Emperor‚Äôs New Clothes in the World of BIM? This presentation reveals the consequences of excessive bureaucracy on BIM projects. Jens from BIG shed light on the paradoxical situation where BIM, intended to enhance efficiency, can paradoxically lead to delays, cost overruns, and frustration. By examining real-world case studies, Jens will expose some of the underlying causes and manifestations of bureaucratic bottlenecks that impede the realization of BIM‚Äôs transformative power. This is a must watch for people reviewing BIM contractual requirements. NXT DEV Future Design Software ‚ÄúShopping List‚Äù This talk and panel goes over an engagement of large architectural firms in the UK to develop a specification for design software based on current needs. It goes into details specifying a data framework, sustainability goals, computation, deliverables generation and commercial aspects. It is a good package of problems faced in practice that could be addressed by software companies. Panel: The Future of AI in AEC Probably the most talked topic in the industry at the moment. The panel highlighted how problematic and complex issues like ethics, trust and security are on a different level and should be addressed not by architects but by long experienced AI academics. This seemed like a bucket of ‚Äúcold water‚Äù for some attendants in the crowd, but in my opinion an extremely angle on of this topic. Another point was made about how the AEC lacked the capacity to have its own data stored and how this could be an opportunity for current practices. We have been witnessing mind blowing AI models perform tasks which were only possible given training data available on the web (images, text, etc).

title: The Current State of Generative AI at Perkins&Will

author.name: Nick Cameron
author.description: American trucker who has been featured on the History channel reality television series Ice Road Truckers and its spinoff series IRT: Deadliest Roads.

content: In our previous blog post, titled ‚ÄúTrust but Verify,‚Äù we emphasized the importance of verification when working with generative AI tools. Today, we will delve deeper into how Perkins&Will is actively exploring the use of generative AI throughout the firm and how we can facilitate the sharing and learning process in this rapidly evolving technology landscape. Additionally, we will introduce the Perkins&Will guidelines for using generative AI. At Perkins&Will, various groups including the Project Delivery, Research, & Technology Boards and Human Resources are fully engaged in prioritizing a comprehensive understanding of generative AI‚Äôs potential and its impact on our firm and industry. Furthermore, studios like Boston and Vancouver have been hosting internal discussions, exchanging insights, and collaborating to explore the possibilities of generative AI. We extend an invitation to join and contribute to the broader conversation happening within our studios and across other teams in the firm. By gathering diverse perspectives, we enable a critical evaluation of generative AI‚Äôs capabilities. To promote wider engagement and ongoing conversations, we have established a new AI channel in the Digital Practice Teams space, click here to join in . This channel serves as an open platform for everyone to participate, contribute ideas, and share knowledge. By opening up the conversation, we tap into the collective intelligence and expertise of our firm, expanding our understanding of what may be possible while also being mindful of potential pitfalls. Looking ahead, our upcoming Core Exchange in July (email invites to follow) will feature a keynote address by an external AI expert. We also have plans to organize panels that will discuss the current state of AI within our firm and explore the future possibilities in our industry. These panels foster collaboration within Perkins&Will and encourage dialogue with external experts, ensuring our firm remains at the forefront of technological advancements. Lastly, we are pleased to include a copy of the Perkins&Will guidelines for using generative AI below. These guidelines serve as a reference for employees, contractors, and third parties who use generative AI technology on behalf of our firm. They suggest parameters within which the use of generative AI aligns with our values, legal and ethical standards, and protects the interests of all stakeholders involved. By nurturing collaboration across boards, studios, and through the Digital Practice Teams Channel, Perkins&Will leverages its collective intelligence to ensure the responsible use of generative AI. Together, we will navigate this exciting technological landscape while delivering exceptional solutions to our clients and elevating the AI employee learning experience. Loading... Taking too long? title: Autodesk Accelerator ‚Äì Chicago
content: A diverse group of coders and designers from Perkins&Will‚Äôs i/o and Digital Practice groups along with our partners at Introba and DAR convened in Chicago on May 22-27. They were joined by the Autodesk Platform Services (formerly Forge) team for a week-long accelerator where the P&W team learned how to use the Autodesk APIs to create their own web applications. Attendees broke into groups focused around a particular API to explore or an app to develop. One group created a method for on-demand PDF creation from Revit models on BIM360 using the Model Derivative API. Their working prototype is now being developed into a fully functional add-in that will be deployed across the entire Perkins&Will BIM360 hub. Stay tuned for more information about this exciting project. To find out what else is possible using Autodesk Platform Services follow the link below: Autodesk Platform Services Thomas Kearns, Victor Wanderly-Barbosa, and Charlie Portelli on Accelerator Day 1 Elton Gjata consulting with the Autodesk developers while Keith and Zuzanna work. Lunchtime along the Chicago river. Victor, Zuzanna, Daniel, and Nirvik

title: The Team Game of Digitizing Design
content: Technology in the architectural industry is often related to process efficiency. Great, fast is good. But, what amazes me is the bridges that technology can build within a work community, at SHL ‚Äì Schmidt Hammer Lassen Architects and Perkins&Will we are architects, designers, technologists, engineers, advisors, communicators, software developers, and whatnot. We speak English mostly, but the daily duties require these roles to communicate in different ways. Some talk through sketches, others through spreadsheets, and others through plain text or computer code. My goal with this post is to share with you the importance of digitalizing the platform of architecture, and not only design. And how it‚Äôs a team game. Just this week we iterated over 4 pieces of technology that our team is shipping/updating. Here‚Äôs how they are modernizing the way we address our clients and problems. 1. Area Sync Hospitals, large mix-use buildings, university campuses, and master plans are often projects with a high level of ‚Äúprogram‚Äù complexity. Taking client briefs with thousands of spaces that need to be built is sometimes overwhelming and a creativity killer within a project. Area Sync streamlines the data from inside our design apps (#Rhino, #Revit) down to the client‚Äôs desk where they can make changes and decisions using #PowerBI dashboards filled from our internal #GraphQL API. 2. Sustainability Practice Cards The sustainability process at SHL uses a game of cards to get clients to think more deeply about their goals and intentions on a project. Are they targeting a specific certification? What are the main sustainability concerns? We have processes, questions, and tools. All in a card deck. We have introduced #Airtable to our Sustainability and Business Development teams as a low-code cloud-based solution to manage the data behind this system. 3. Library Cards It‚Äôs a spin-off from our practice cards! SHL is known for its work with libraries and soon we will be hosting a workshop as part of the Next Library Librarians conference in Aarhus. We developed a workshop #webapp tool where participants will be able to design their cards to help design the next generation of libraries, using only their phones. Straight back to #Airtable. 4. Snippets Let‚Äôs talk about #Grasshopper. That‚Äôs where I started my journey with technology and many other architects and engineers as well. The best way to learn is by trying, looking at samples, and getting inspired. #Snippets is a library of computational design workflows that are designed to inspire, teach and grow. It has already +60 scripts and continues to grow. We have recently added new facade scripts and also a bunch of #RhinoInsideRevit helpers. Shoutout to this team of silo breakers: Nick Cameron Zuzanna Czapla Daniel Boba Ellen Berglund Viviana Padron Esaa Enlai Hooi Helena Jingyi Bj√∏rn Christensen Michael Atzen Elif Tinaztepe Sanne Wall-Gremstrup Jens Buch-Dohrmann Ricardo Ruiter Kanamori Oswaldo Hern√°ndez Bueno

title: Avail Revit Content Management System
content: Goodbye, Hive! Hello Avail! Digital Practice is excited to introduce Avail, Perkins&Will‚Äôs new Revit content management system. Your Digital Practice team members have been working hard behind the scenes to move content from Hive, our previous content platform, into Avail. They have also prepared an‚Ä¶ Avail quickstart guide ‚Ä¶with all the info you‚Äôll need to make the transition. You will still have access to Hive through June, but it will go away at the beginning of July. Avail is available now and can be installed through Software Center. Once installed, log in to Avail will be seamless with your Perkins&Will credentials. No more separate passwords! Content in Avail is organized into Channels. Revit Content in Imperial units is in the 01 PW Imperial 2022 Channel for all US studios. Metric content is organized into Channels for each international studio. Double-click on a Channel to open it. A search bar at the top lets you search to find exactly what you‚Äôre looking for. The search is very intuitive, and the response time is lightning-fast! Within each Channel or search result, content can be further narrowed using Filters found at the bottom of the screen. Package, Source, Object Type, and Revit Category can be specified to narrow the content library down to a specific set of desired elements. We will have several training sessions over the next few weeks to demo Avail usage and answer any questions you might have. Training 1 Thursday June 8 th 10am EST Training 2 Thursday June 8 th 4pm EST Training 3 Tuesday June 13 th 11am EST Training 4 Wednesday June 14 th 5pm EST Adopting a new system always requires a bit of adjustment, but the studios that participated in our Avail pilot program over the past month have unanimously agreed it is easier to find what they need in Avail. Try it out for yourself and let us know how we can use this new platform better! Avail, available now!

title: Using AreaSync to integrate Program and Drawing Data
content: AreaSync is a tool designed to synchronize the design data between the various tools our planners and designers use to program and design the project. Whether one starts the design as program data inside Excel or creates a model by laying out walls, rooms, and areas inside Revit , AreaSync is there to synchronize the data between Excel and Revit and consolidate the data into a more analytical dashboard using PowerBI. By tracking the rooms and areas of the project, we can easily visualize the progress of the building design and ensure the team has not deviated too far from our original program target size thus minimizing rework and redesign. Let‚Äôs start with the program data that the planners have carefully crafted with our client in Excel. Using the AreaSync Excel plugin, the program data in Excel can easily integrate with the design data from Revit. With three simple steps of AreaSync Setup, Download, and Upload to DB. Once the programmed rooms are uploaded into our Cloud database, they are ready to be used by our Designers. After running the AreaSync Setup, the Excel file connects directly to our Cloud Database and allows you to download any drawing data extracted from the Revit model or models of the same project, or to upload programmed room data to the Database. Before uploading the program data, a few quick steps of data cleanup is needed. Luckily, we have figured out the best way of using power query to transform the program from a report summary into an itemized room-by-room list of room data more digestible by the database. Imagine a tool that can automatically bring in all your programmed rooms and their attached room data (room name, number, department, target size, etc.) from Excel and place them inside your Revit model as a room object on the designated floor level in the correct target size. Using AreaSync, a designer can import 3000+ rooms and place them into the Revit model after one or two clicks and a few minutes of waiting while he/she is getting some afternoon tea and biscuits. AreaSync ‚Äì Import Data is designed to do just that. The AreaSync Revit Plugin‚Äôs Import Data Setup allows you to select which parameters you wish to bring in with your room data, and how those parameters will be mapped to which Revit‚Äôs Room Parameters. New Rooms can be imported as placed or unplaced rooms. If you want to place the rooms, you can specify the room size (default size vs. custom size using Target Area) and the level (default level vs. custom level using the level parameter), next the rooms can be sorted by department and then by size from large to small. Once the rooms are placed in the model, the designers can drag and move the pre-populated rooms into walled areas they have designed without having to retype anything. Next, change the Color scheme of your floor plan view, and all the rooms are color-coded by the their department or any other property you have pre-filled. Round Trip back to Excel After the rooms are moved and placed into the actual building, the rooms are marked as ‚ÄúASR_Placed_on_Plan‚Äù, and the Revit model is synced to the database. Planners can open Excel and download the latest Revit data, using ASR_ID to synchronize with the latest Rooms from Revit, reflecting the drawn room areas vs. the target area. This bi-directional update process allows both designers and planners to work with the latest and greatest room data in their preferred programs, Excel and Revit, at the same time. While our Dashboard in PowerBI taps into the same data extracted from both programs and presents a consolidated real-time analytical view for the whole team. Now everyone can see the three thousand feet high overview of the project based on realtime data.
