title: Trust, but Verify

author.name: Nick Cameron
author.description: American trucker who has been featured on the History channel reality television series Ice Road Truckers and its spinoff series IRT: Deadliest Roads.

content: Staying up-to-date with the latest technological advancements is crucial for Perkins&Will, especially with the clear emergence of generative AI. The increasing accessibility of generative AI tools, such as ChatGPT and Dall-E 2 from OpenAI , and the soon-to-be-released Co-Pilot from Microsoft , make it apparent that they have the potential to impact the future of designing and delivering projects for our clients. However, it is important to approach the latest technological trend with caution and remember the old adage, ‚ÄúTrust, but Verify.‚Äù The term ‚Äúhallucination‚Äù refers to the phenomenon where generative AI tools produce results that may seem impressive but are not entirely accurate. As a result, we must be vigilant in verifying the accuracy of the AI-generated output. If this is all new to you here is a link to an AI 101 video from the Wall Street Journal. We have also compiled a short list of available tools and ideas shared from across the firm for you to explore and consider how we may begin to work differently. Please feel free to email me or leave your thoughts in the comments. Let‚Äôs embrace the potential of generative AI while remaining mindful of its limitations. Let‚Äôs challenge ourselves to explore new ways of working and delivering projects, always with a critical eye and a commitment to excellence. And remember by adopting the ‚ÄúTrust, but Verify‚Äù mindset, we can navigate this new technological landscape while continuing to innovate and provide amazing solutions to our clients. Automated Meeting Notes and Action Items // MS TEAMS Runway ML [storytelling] Tome.app [storytelling] Veras [rendering engine] Code Research [trax] Writing Excel Functions [chat gpt] Midjourney [text to image] HugginFace [a social network for AI models]

title: PMTK in the Project App live now on Hub
content: We rolled out the Project Management Toolkit (PMTK) portion of the project app in the month of March.¬† ¬†This launch replaces our vision resource planning portion of Deltek Vision as the way the firm will staff and budget our projects.¬† ¬†This single source of truth will be the driver for connecting and setting up all our cloud platforms and pulling together all key aspects of delivering projects effectively and successfully.¬† ¬†In addition to a more modern and intuitive interface, we also are intending to deliver insights to project leadership in order to make more informed decisions as well as awareness to the project team as to how they contribute to delivering a successful project both from a design excellence point of view as well as a financially profitable project. We have continued to provide orientation sessions and build more documentation to guide your use of the PMTK in the Project app.¬† ¬†You can find these through the Help buttons on the top right of any page as well as through these links here. https://digitalpractice.perkinswill.com/quickstarts/pmtk-quickstart/ https://digitalpractice.perkinswill.com/docs/project-app/general/ While the Project App is the main interface that project leaders and teams will be interacting with your project data and information there is a host of supporting apps that will also facilitate some of the workflows we have around the firm and within our projects. Client Hub ‚Äì We have been piloting a client Hub to seamlessly share basic project information around design progress, schedule, meeting minutes, project area, and other key items a client would want to keep track of in a beautiful and easy interface. Studio Staffing ‚Äì This roll-up of project staffing information gives a single view of where our designer‚Äôs assignments are in order to make sure we are not giving too little or too much work to anyone in order to effectively deliver all of our projects on time and on budget. Finance App ‚Äì This app supports the budget review and approval process the firm has in place for Operations and Finance to do their quality control checks of initial plans and updates created by our Project Managers.¬† ¬†It is also a rollup of key project budget numbers into a single view to allow studio leaders to track which projects are trending in a bad direction in order to give support and guidance to correct the course. Deltek Sync Management ‚Äì This app supports the project number request and creation process, the phase mapping, project mapping, and vendor mapping between Hub and Deltek to allow Finance to make sure the right numbers are going to the right locations in your project. Timesheet Tracker ‚Äì This app helps target communications with those of us that are tardy on getting our timesheets done which is the way our projects earn their revenue.¬† ¬†This helps the rest of us not get additional communications when we have been submitting them on time. Time Off ‚Äì This app logs the approved holiday or annual leave time you have taken so that we can properly staff our projects in your absence.¬† ¬†This info then shows up in our studio staffing app, the calendar view of your projects schedule, and the Firmwide Calendar studio view. My Schedule ‚Äì You can see your own personal planned schedule for work for the upcoming weeks as a roll-up of all the project staffing assignments and time off you have put into the system. Storyboard and Living Design ‚Äì These two apps are undergoing some improvements in order to roll into a single view the current project visuals as well as the design excellence framework metrics we are entering into our projects in order to help anyone understand the current status of any project‚Äôs design. FIR (First Incident Reports) ‚Äì This app rolls together all FIRs for our internal legal team that are submitted through the RAMP page of the project app so they can help give you guidance should something occur on your project. RAMP (Risk Assessment Management Program) ‚Äì This project rolls together all risk metrics that are entered or tracked for firmwide leadership to focus their attention on the projects that need additional support or guidance to successfully deliver their project through higher levels of riskiness. There are many other improvements planned for the Project app and other supporting apps to continue to improve and streamline our existing workflows.¬† ¬†Please continue to use the black Feedback button on the side of any page on Hub to let us know if anything isn‚Äôt working or if you have an idea to improve the tools all teams have able to deliver for our clients.

title: March Studio Innovation eXchange ‚Äì LA and Seattle

title: The Resources at Perkins&Will to improve your digital skills

author.name: Nick Cameron
author.description: American trucker who has been featured on the History channel reality television series Ice Road Truckers and its spinoff series IRT: Deadliest Roads.

content: Technology and workflows are forever changing and there is a demand to improve our craft and our career paths. Digital Practice has many tools for the users to help with these ever-changing technology needs and teach the skills required to deliver more diverse equitable design more efficiently. The Digital Practice teams see software education in three concentrations, software fundamentals, Perkins&Will fundamentals (PW-isms), and Studio Software workflows. Everybody learns technology differently we at Digital Practice have created, assembled, and supplied methods to support these concentrations in software education. Software Fundamentals When it comes to software fundamentals Perkins&Will supplies LinkedIn Learning to every employee. LinkedIn Learning gives you unlimited access to online course content. The LinkedIn Learning library has an extensive collection of courses on the tools we use here at Perkins&Will taught by industry professionals. Some courses offer CEU credits and certifications. This option gives you the freedom to learn anywhere on your schedule. Teach yourself any software that interests you or reach out to your studio Digital Practice person. We can curate paths or content for your individual needs. You can take full courses, watch a specific topic video, or use it as a reference. All Videos are transcribed so you can search for words or phrases for a quick specific refresher. LinkedIn Learning course videos are available in English, French, German, Japanese, Spanish, Mandarin, and Portuguese. To get access submit a Help Request and request your license to LinkedIn Learning Perkins&Will Fundamentals (PW-isms) Perkins&Will Fundamentals are taught through a series of live Core eXchange or Lab eXchange sessions and collected resources. All collected resources can be found on the Digital Practice page . Digital Practice delivers Core eXchange Classes that are given live each quarter as a part of PWU. Core eXchange has a rotation of topics and speakers and sometimes a presence live in studios, these sessions can all be found on the PWU Microsoft Team. Digital Practice also has weekly Lab eXchange courses for a hands-on sessions. Lab eXchange sessions are short, hands-on software demonstrations worked on together for better retention. All eXchange classes are collected in the Continuing Education Library on the Digital Practice page, where you will find the recorded video and all resources used for the classes. There are many resources on the Digital Practice page along with the ones mentioned above. Microknowledge cards are step by step How To‚Äôs on a specific piece of software. Quick Start Guides are an introduction or informational guide to most key software used at P&W. Studio Level resources Digital Practice has resources at the Studio level, Most studios have a local Digital practice person for specific one-on-one training needs or direction. There is also the Microsoft Teams Digital Practice Channel where a person can post a question or issue and get a response from anyone of Digital practice folk around the firm. We also have host open office hours for one hour 5 times a day where anyone can drop in and share the issues they are having with a Digital Practice person directly. Office Hours are EST 5am, 9am, 12pm, 3pm, & 6pm. Digital Practice Team

title: The Firm‚Äôs new Project Management Toolkit
content: During the last firmwide webcast, Phil talked about our new in-house developed PMTK or Project Management Toolkit. This portion of the project app is replacing the vision resource planning module in Deltek that helped us budget and staff our projects across the firm. We are making this change to make the management side of our projects as simple and agile as possible. Bringing together the staffing, schedule, budgets, and contracts into one tool will allow PMs a holistic view of their project(s). We are currently in the data migration period this week and starting next week we are excited that we will be managing our projects through the PMTK in the Project App on Hub. This change brings many supporting apps and upcoming improvements to the Project App as well. This is not changing where we do our timesheets and expense reports, which will still all happen in vision for everyone. The supporting apps will include the following Finance app ‚Äì For budget approval process by operations and finance Studio Staffing ‚Äì for overall staffing at your studio level to make sure everyone is busy MySchedule ‚Äì to see your upcoming assignments of projects and hours Time Off ‚Äì to record approved time off to feed the calendars and staffing apps Request Vision Number (future) ‚Äì to review and create new numbers for projects Other supporting apps are upcoming Project Map ‚Äì to lay out all our project locations geographically Storyboard 2.0 ‚Äì to manage design at the studio level Living Design 2.0 ‚Äì to manage performance design aspects of projects at the studio level ClientHub ‚Äì to share basic aspects of the project with our client in one central and simple location This is initial release is not the end of development to make management agile and simple but instead the beginning. Please make use of the feedback button on the side of any Hub page to let us know if something is not working or if you have an idea to make the tools better for everyone.

title: Artifact Has 100,000 Drawings!!!
content: 100,000 Drawings in Artifact! Thanks for making Artifact such a success! Those who have been with us for a while have seen the site evolve, with improved harvesting, search functionality, and seamless Revit and BIM 360 Integrations. Thanks for your continued support. What is Artifact? How do I log in? Artifact is the Revit drawing search website that turns your text notes and metadata into search terms, so you find exactly the drawing you‚Äôre looking for and adapt it to a new project. Artifact is a collaboration between AIPrentice, a software developer, and Perkins&Will‚Äôs Digital Practice department.¬† To log in automatically with your Perkins&Will credentials, go to Pwitter (green arrow) > Microsoft MyApps > Artifact. Add Your Work to Artifact Artifact is only as good as the content within, so we are asking you to contribute your studio‚Äôs work. Please talk to the technical and design leadership within your studio to identify projects to include, and coordinate with your Digital Practice representative, or Digital Practice Manager Luc Deckinga, to add your content. As of this article, we have 103,462 drawings in the Artifact database, taken from 161 completed projects designed by twenty different Perkins&Will studios. Let‚Äôs see how long it takes us to get to 200,000! Thanks for all your help and support! We will continue to improve Artifact and add new features. Stay tuned.

title: SketchUp in our Studios

author.name: Nick Cameron
author.description: American trucker who has been featured on the History channel reality television series Ice Road Truckers and its spinoff series IRT: Deadliest Roads.

content: In July 2020, we made an announcement that Perkins&Will would no longer be upgrading SketchUp. Since then, many teams have transitioned to using Rhino for conceptual design and analysis, taking advantage of the recent interoperability improvements that connect Rhino and Revit. We have conducted several training sessions to help teams efficiently deploy design workflows on this new platform, and you can access them by clicking on this link . For those who are still using SketchUp, we would like to remind you that using files or plugins developed for newer versions of SketchUp, particularly Enscape, may lead to compatibility issues. There is no roadmap for determining which plugins will remain compatible with SketchUp 2020, and as new versions of these plugins are released, some may inevitably stop working. If you have any questions about SketchUp‚Äôs plugin compatibility issues or would like to arrange Rhino training to migrate your team to a more powerful design platform, please contact me.

title: Stage 1 of the PMTK release in the Project App
content: We have put the entirety of the PMTK in the Project App now.¬† ¬†The last two components are the budget and staffing pages.¬† ¬†These are currently in read-only versions as we finish reviewing the data and data connections between Vision and Hub.¬† ¬†We are dealing with many data integrity issues around phasing and multipliers and generic roles that are currently being addressed so that not only the application but also the information is in better condition when we first start using it.¬† ¬†We are working through our final rollout schedule with leadership to finalize the dates we will make the switch over from Vision resource planning to the Project App.¬† ¬†This will be our Stage 2 release where you will now be working with the data through the Hub to keep your plan organized and up to date.¬† ¬†This release will also come with a number of supporting apps that will help out various processes around our project finances which include; Studio Staffing, MySchedule, Time Off, Vision Number Requests, Timesheet Tracker, and a Finance app for the budget approval process.¬† ¬†For right now you can take a look at all this information and use the yes/no buttons at the top of the Staffing and Budget pages to let us know if anything doesn‚Äôt look right with your project plan and approved budget in Hub.¬† ¬†Thanks for all that have contributed and helped as we are excited that this will be a big improvement to simplify and enhance the current management of project plans.

title: Announcing our Studio Innovation eXchanges
content: What is a Studio Innovation eXchange? For a few years, Digital Practice has hosted a monthly firmwide meeting that acted as a platform to showcase a variety of projects/workflows. They were primarily focused on 3 distinct categories: Computational Design, Visualization, and Design & Delivery. We figured it was about time we consolidated and re-branded those conversations to match with our ‚ÄúeXchange‚Äù moniker and, at the same time, allow these meetings with some flexibility. We‚Äôll be hosted on our PWU channel from here on out. Ultimately, we‚Äôre hoping the Studio Innovation eXchange will: Acts as an opportunity for studio‚Äôs to present projects, workflows, or practices that they‚Äôre excited about to the whole firm so that we can collectively learn from them. With the intent to showcase all the great work that you and your studios are doing that don‚Äôt necessarily have a platform for The intent is to engage in a greater dialog and with that in mind, each Studio Innovation eXchange format will vary but will always be viewed as a discussion/forum first and foremost. What‚Äôs the General Format? 2 Studios will generally co-present 1 Digital Practice representative and 1 Designer from each studio will focus the discussion Every 2 nd Thursday of the month Time can flex to accommodate the team but generally will take place at 11am PST | 12pm MST | 1pm CST | 2pm EST What are Some Topics to Expect? title: Another Productive Year

author.name: Nick Cameron
author.description: American trucker who has been featured on the History channel reality television series Ice Road Truckers and its spinoff series IRT: Deadliest Roads.

content: It has been an exciting and productive year for the Digital Practice team at Perkins&Will. We have said goodbye to some old apps, including Newforma, and introduced some new ones, such as Power BI , Power Query , and Twin Motion . In addition to these technological advances, we have also partnered with Zahner metals to create new advanced workflows and released MicroKnowledge 3.0 , our updated repository of answers to frequently asked questions about our design applications. One of the major milestones of the past year has been the growth of our Artifact application, which has gained a wealth of knowledge and will soon surpass 100,000 drawing records. We have also conducted a user survey to gather feedback and create new features for the application. Another important achievement is further development of AreaSync ‚Äì¬† a tool for dynamic analysis and visualization of data from our Revit and Rhino projects which helps guide design decisions. One more highlight was the use of a robot from Dusty Robotics to deliver a 1:1 scale floor plan for the Enchanted Hills camp in San Francisco. In addition to these technological developments, we have also made great strides in continuing education and innovation. We have held four internal conferences, called Core Exchange, and introduced a new Computational Design library. We are also exploring the use of digital twins for our new London studio at 150 Holborn street. Our robotic arm, Armando, even helped the Vancouver studio design a space for Microsoft. Members of the digital practice team have also presented at numerous conferences, and sponsored a symposium focused on design, equity, and data for the national AIA TAP knowledge group. All of these efforts have contributed to our goal of staying at the forefront of the industry and delivering the best possible results for our clients.

title: AreaSync Rhino
content: Get ready to say goodbye to tedious and error-prone area calculations in Rhino with the release of AreaSync Rhino! This bad boy is here to make your life a whole lot easier by automating the process and giving you all the tools you need to calculate areas with speed and accuracy. One of the coolest features of AreaSync Rhino is the ability to import an area program spreadsheet. This means you can easily bring all your data into the software and skip the tedious process of inputting everything manually. But wait, there‚Äôs more! AreaSync Rhino can also auto-generate geometry for your program rooms, including both 2D curves and volumes. This gives you more control and flexibility over your calculations. Plus, you can assign custom parameters to your rooms to tailor your calculations to your specific needs. Visualization is key when it comes to calculating areas, and AreaSync Rhino has got you covered. It provides quick and easy visualization of totals and subtotals using charts and tables, so you can see how your calculations are progressing and catch any potential issues. Assign parameters to geometry and visualize it! And¬†the best part? AreaSync Rhino gives you instant feedback while you‚Äôre re-sizing your geometry and comparing options. This means you can experiment and fine-tune your calculations without having to wait for results. When you‚Äôre done, you can easily sync or export your data to Excel or our cloud platform for building PowerBI dashboards. This makes it easy to share your results with clients or collaborate with team members. To celebrate the release of AreaSync Rhino, our Danish office threw a little shindig on December 15th and even had an AreaSync cake (delicious!). We‚Äôre confident that this software is going to be a game-changer for Rhino users and make calculating areas a breeze. Don‚Äôt miss out ‚Äì give AreaSync Rhino a try today! Tust us, you won‚Äôt be disappointed. Stay tuned for AreaSync Core eXchange coming mid January! Want to try out AreaSync yourself? Follow this guide:

title: Revit and Autodesk 2023 availability

author.name: Nick Cameron
author.description: American trucker who has been featured on the History channel reality television series Ice Road Truckers and its spinoff series IRT: Deadliest Roads.

content: The Digital Practice team has prepared Revit 2023 for all new projects and recommends upgrading all existing projects. The software center has it for self-installation. Note that it is a big program, so it‚Äôs best to install it at the end of the day to allow ample time for downloading and installation. Add-ins will be installed on demand, and you can search for Revit 2023 add-ins using the software center‚Äôs filter. Autodesk Revit 2023 has introduced several new features that enhance the architectural design process. One notable feature is the inclusion of Twinmotion, a new visualization tool that allows designers to create more realistic renderings of their projects. This allows designers to better communicate their ideas and designs to clients, making the design process more efficient and effective. Another key feature of Revit 2023 is the ability to import and export data with other design software, such as Rhino. This allows for a seamless workflow between different design tools and allows for greater collaboration among team members. Additionally, the new version includes improved collaboration tools, such as real-time commenting and markup, making it easier for team members to share their feedback and suggestions. For more features check out this article . Each team should start planning and coordinating with external partners to find a time to upgrade to Revit 2023. Fortunately, upgrading using BIM360 is simple and only requires the click of a button. However, it‚Äôs important to note that all models for your project should be upgraded at the same time to ensure that everyone can continue to access all necessary information from each model. For new projects, it‚Äôs a good idea to start using the latest version of Revit from the beginning. Overall, the new features of Autodesk Revit 2023 improve the architectural design process by enhancing visualization, collaboration, and data interoperability.

title: Enchanted Hills Camp and Retreat, a Collaboration with Dusty Robotics
content: In 2021, our ongoing search for ways to Deliver Different led us to Dusty Robotics. Dusty has created a robotic system that receives digital plan information and prints it full scale on floor slabs, eliminating the need for manual layout of partition framing, electrical devices, plumbing fixtures and any other information that we typically deliver via plan drawings. Luckily for us, the Enchanted Hills Forest Commons project was just about to begin construction and its small size and proximity to Dusty‚Äôs Bay Area home base made it an ideal candidate for a pilot. Digital Practice and the EHFC project team collaborated with Dusty to translate our Revit data into a format they could use and printing went ahead in early June. The pilot has been a resounding success and both we and Dusty are very excited about the possibilities this technology could open up for streamlining our documentation and eliminating questions and errors in the field.

title: Haunted Project, Scary Halloween story.
content: Ghosts in the Project. Scary Halloween Story In a galaxy far away, one of the large projects was plagued by problems with disappearing dimensions and tags. Warning and errors like these were happening every day, and sometimes hundreds of elements were affected. This massive problem at 95% CD was very frustrating to the team. While team was battling ghosts in a very organized way (posting¬† and addressing warnings as they happen in the Teams chat), a group of Ghostbusters worked to uncover why it was happening so much on this particular project. Here is what we learned: The project was using Documentation model approach , where all sheets existed in Documentation model, tagging and dimensioning¬† was also happening in Documentation model. Exterior and Interior model were linked to documentation model. The users routinely opened a second (and sometimes third) session of Revit to work in both documentation a Interior/Exterior model. The annotation disappeared at the time the documentation model was synced. Moreover, the disappeared tags could not be reconciled when a link was reloaded because their elements IDs in reconciliation report were lost (set to ‚Äú-1‚Äù). Also, the team is particularly large, and count of users concurrently in documentation model was often more then a dozen. At this time it was too late to rethink¬† model organization. We had opened a case with Autodesk, but they could not provide quick fix, and were not able to reproduce the problem. The project team had good prior¬† experience with such model organization (couple of years ago), and so we suspected that this time the problem is somehow connected to this project being on BIM 360 and multiple session of Revit sharing the same cache. When we again encountered a situation where¬† syncing would orphan more then a hundred tags and delete some dimensions, one of the ghostbusters on the team had a genius idea to sync from a different machine (node). It worked! Lessons learned: Avoid organizing your models with ‚ÄúDocumentation‚Äù model. It is best to keep sheets in the files you will be actually editing If using ‚ÄúDocumentation‚Äù model, sync linked file first, then in the documentation model reload linked model prior to syncing. If you are still getting warnings about disappearing dimensions and tags, cancel sync, connect to the node and sync there. Then close Revit on your machine without syncing documentation model, clear BIM360 cache (script in Software Center) and reopen. If using keynoting on the project, install Keynote Manager for every user on the team, regardless of whether they need to edit keynotes. At this time the case is still under investigation with Autodesk Development team.

title: Fologram for Rhino and Grasshopper
content: Fologram for Rhino and Grasshopper Contributor: James Chadud Fologram is used to view and share Rhino and Grasshopper instantly in mixed reality on HoloLens 1, HoloLens 2, iOS and Android. Geometry, layers and grasshopper parameters can be edited in real time¬†in Fologram to create powerful tools for design, communication, collaboration and fabrication. Fologram works on any device running Rhino for Windows, no game engines, scripting or model exports are required. FULL FEATURES: View and modify Rhino and Grasshopper geometry in real time View and interact with Grasshopper parameters in real time (unlimited for subscribers) Save models to device for offline access (subscribers only) View material changes in real time Modify Rhino layers in mixed reality Support for model animation via streamed transforms View and modify a shared Rhino model on multiple devices Synchronize interactions between devices Track device positions in real time Create and track custom QR codes and Aruco markers in real time Accurately position models in physical space using QR codes Track 25 feature points per hand (HoloLens 2), palm positions (HoloLens 1) and multi touch gestures (iOS and Android) in real time Stream spatial meshes (HoloLens 1 and 2) and detected surfaces (iOS and Android) in real time Connect to any PC running Rhino with our free Rhino and grasshopper plugin. How to use it? Connect Rhino and Grasshopper to mobile and HoloLens devices running Fologram. Includes Grasshopper components for streaming and interacting with models, working with gestures and markers, modelling and controlling data flow. Free to download and install on any Windows PC running Rhino 5, 6 or 7. 1. Download the App for IOS or Google Play. Find the link below Fologram on the App Store (apple.com) Fologram ‚Äì Apps on Google Play 2. Download the plug in for Windows PC running Rhino 5, 6 or 7. Find the link below Fologram 3. Install and restart Rhinoceros Open Rhino, Right click on the toolbar, Show ToolBar, and enable Hologram 4. Connect your phone to the same internet as your pc. At PW office connect to the private wifi on you cell phone. Just make sure its on the same network as your PC. 5. Click on Connect Device 6. A QR Code will pop up on your PC screen. 7. Open the app Hologram on your phone and scan the QR Code The app will automatically ask to select a surface like your desk or floor or something else, to place the model from your rhino file. Select the surface and you should be able to see the model on your phone/tablet screen. It is possible to move, select objects/surfaces, scale and more.

title: Digital Practice Core eXchange ‚Äì 4th Quarter 2022
content: The Digital Practice team is again hosting our quarterly opportunity to raise everyone‚Äôs core skills to complete their daily tasks as part of their project team. Beginning on Monday, October 10th will have experts from around the firm sharing their knowledge with you on various topics. These continuing education sessions are designed to give our designers and especially new employees an awareness of the tools and processes available to us at Perkins&Will. We have again updated the lineup of classes to include more topics around Revit, Microsoft Teams, Rhino, Excel, and other design workflows.¬† ¬†All of these opportunities are registered for AIA continuing education units and other disciplines can self-report attendance if needed (attendance certificates are provided upon request).¬† If you have any topics you would like to hear more about in the future please let Matt Petermann or anyone else on the Digital Practice team know where we should focus some more attention.¬† All classes will be hosted on the PWU Teams channel, invites will be going out later this week.¬† ¬†Below is the current agenda of classes for the week-long event.

title: Power Platform
content: This past month Digital Practice represented Perkins&Will at the first annual Microsoft Power Platform Conference, held in Orlando.¬† The conference brought together power users and developers from across the globe to discuss and share their work within Microsoft‚Äôs emerging suite of tools.¬† But what is the Microsoft Power Platform?¬† The Power Platform is a suite of low-code products that work and connect to all of Microsoft 365s products, database storage, and third party applications.¬† This interconnecting web between programs allows teams to create customized workflows unique to either the team or individual users. That all sounds nice, but how does it help our teams.¬† How easy is it to pick up?¬† To understand that we need to breakdown the different parts of the Power Platform and open up our imagination.¬† At its core, we are talking about: PowerBI ‚Äì Business Analytics Dashboards PowerApps ‚Äì Low level of entry application development PowerAutomate ‚Äì Automation for workflows PowerPages ‚Äì Quick externally facing websites Power Virtual Agents ‚Äì Programmable chatbots for conversational data retrieval. The key components of the Microsoft Power Platform Primarily with the first three tools, we can interconnect our data sources with our Microsoft products, Teams included, and create tools in a matter of hours.¬† Not only does each tool come packed with templates to get your mind churning, the Power Platform community is extremely helpful in the public forums.¬† In a world of emerging technology, each of these tools is surprisingly user friendly, and the results of our workflows can save us valuable time throughout the design process. Available Templates within PowerAutomate This new area of exploration is open to anyone within Perkins&Will, and can be reached by going to the following websites: PowerBi , PowerApps , and PowerAutomate .¬† While you poke around the templates, here are some examples on how we can leverage these tools: Program solutions to create outward facing dashboards, such as AreaSync, with PowerBI Create applications to find the perfect wall type for your project, with PowerApps Automatically scheduling the next available meeting when someone messages you in Teams, with PowerAutomate Speeding up your CCA workflows by having Submittals automatically saved into a Sharepoint folder and creating a tracking line item in Planner or Lists, with PowerAutomate

title: Design and Delivery eXchange September 22
content: Link to recording On the Design and Delivery call experts like you share efficient workflows, design approaches, and tools they use in their projects. This call showcases work from different offices and promotes peer-to peer discussions. On Thursday September 22 we saw outstanding presentations from¬† three different offices: Austin, Miami and Seattle Austin Studio ‚Äì Sadra Dehghan presented Utilizing BIM360 for Campus Assessments. Miami Studio ‚Äì Damian Ponton did¬† a live demonstration of bringing geometry back and forth between Rhino and Revit using RhinoInside. Seattle Studio- William Franklin will showed a Grasshopper script to rapidly prototype skin design alternatives, then combined it with a script to randomly locate, scale and rotate Enscape entourage assets to render high quality concept imagery for projects in early design phases. Austin Studio Sadra Dehghan Sadra Dehghan from Austin Studio shared a great example of creatively using different tools for Campus Assessments. Austin‚Äôs Urban Design Team utilized BIM360‚Äôs Issues and Excel to perform building assessments. Once the data was collected, they used Area Sync and Power BI to present the information to the Client. The client was so impressed with results, the team was asked to do additional work utilizing additional facility management data provided by the client. Using the dashboard with this additional data, the client was able to better understand efficiency of their existing spaces, leading into informed discussion about how much square footage they need in new building. Miami Studio Damian Ponton Damian Ponton from Miami Studio did a live demonstration of bringing geometry back and forth between Rhino and Revit using RhinoInside. He showed us simple steps needed to create a Grasshopper script for bringing geometry created in Rhino as native Revit categories. Then Damian took us on the round trip journey taking Revit elements to Rhino for additional editing For the teams thinking of utilizing this workflow, Damian¬† analyzed and evaluated pros and cons of modeling in Rhino versus Revit. Seattle Studio William Franklin William Franklin from Seattle Studio tool us on the mind blowing journey from initial massing concept through rapid design iteration¬† to a rendering high quality images. He showed us quick look at a Grasshopper script used to interpret initial massing concepts and rapidly prototype skin design alternatives in real time by panelizing massing surfaces and creating Rhino block objects using Human/Elefront components. Then he showed us how to combine it with with a script to randomly locate, scale and rotate Enscape entourage assets to quickly test design ideas and render high quality concept imagery for projects in early design phases.

title: Zahner and Perkins&Will at Facades+ Denver
content: James Coleman, Luc Deckinga, and Nick Cameron gave a workshop demonstrating the Zahner/Perkins&Will collaborative workflow at Facades+ Denver Digital Collaboration and Instant Iteration Frustrated by loops of rework and wasted time, Perkins&Will envisioned a more collaborative and dynamic feasibility review process for its fabrication and construction partners. A process that would allow more design time and speed up decision. Working with like minded leaders at fabrication partner at Zahner, the two firms invented a shared workspace and feasibility model that produces higher design fidelity, shorter delivery schedules, and more joyful clients and communities. Learn more about this process and how it can be adapted for your work and how process improvements like this can be implemented between many partners for faster, better collaborations. In addition to the conference workshop, the broader team also wrote a whitepaper that goes into further depth on the collaborative process: Dynamic Design and Feasibility Workflow ‚Äì How to Optimize Concept Iteration to Realize Extraordinary Projects

title: Value of a our Design Models for Clients
content: We build 3D models to create our documents because we know that it is easier to coordinate. Contractors also want to use our models since they want them for pre-construction coordination. However, there is still another group of folks who are part of our project who still have not captured the potential of the models we produce ‚Äî our clients. Now it is worth acknowledging that not every client is going to be able to make use of a 3D model as effectively as others of our clients. Generally, the clients for whom a 3D model will have the greatest value are our institutional clients who have a large portfolio of buildings that are frequently remodeled, updated and for whom the operation aspect is a large part of their budget. For these clients, we have real opportunity to educate them about how using the models we generate to not only improve the flow of information through construction, but more importantly how it can improve the flow of information into the operation phase as old building equipment assets are removed and new ones are placed and commissioned. Additionally, for these clients who understand the value of a model for their long term operations, they will also find the ability to locate and view building equipment assets in 3D reduces the time it takes perform maintenance and inspections. Also, for these clients, having a model they can pass on to the next team (or back to us) will reduce the amount of effort it takes to start a new renovation project. While these are things we have talked about and theorized for over a decade now, we take it for granted that not all of our institutional clients have made this move. We have the opportunity not only to not only help this sector of clients who are likely to be frequent repeat clients and solidify our relationship with them, but we also have the opportunity to improve on our existing sales with these clients for work we are already well positioned to provide.

title: AI Generated Images

author.name: Nick Cameron
author.description: American trucker who has been featured on the History channel reality television series Ice Road Truckers and its spinoff series IRT: Deadliest Roads.

content: Artificial Intelligent generated images have been a hot topic in the news lately, supplanting NFT‚Äôs and the Metaverse. DALL-E2, Midjourney and others have taken the ‚Äúprompted‚Äù art-world by storm.¬† The reason is there have been many breakthroughs in this field that allow computers to learn and make decisions like humans. However, one area where AI has not yet made its mark is image creation. AI has finally reached a point where the technology can be used to create images based on an algorithm rather than just recognize them. The first step towards creating an image was recognizing what you were seeing in real-time, like when a camera could tell if your face was in the frame or if there was a dog running around behind it. This type of activity was called computer vision, and the results were pretty impressive for tasks like facial recognition and object detection (like seeing if there‚Äôs a cat sitting on your couch). But generating an image from scratch? That was another ballgame entirely. AI can be trained to create images from text prompts. The training data helps the AI understand how real people would form an image and this helps it to generate new ones. This new technology has many possible applications. With AI image creation, anyone can create unique new images without having to learn how to use complicated programs. For designers, uses cases may include material, vision or are what sometimes are called precedent boards, without infringing on copyright or showing our competitors work. Another use case may be to to generate¬† materials and entourage for renderings. Designers from across the firm, from Charlotte to Miami to Vancouver and more have been experimenting with this new technology. Examples from a recent workshop in the Vancouver studio are below.¬† Will Finley from the Dallas studio has set up a Discord server, so anyone can try out this new technology for themselves and see what they can create. Here‚Äôs How to try Midjourney: Join the Perkins&Will Digital Practice Discord server here . Chat directly with the Midjourney bot by typing ‚Äú/imagine‚Äù, follow by hitting ‚Äúspacebar‚Äù. This will activate the ‚Äúprompt‚Äù box where you can start typing. Type in any words that come to mind, then hit enter. Just wait for the program to render through a series of passes. You can click on your image to open it in a new page, or if you want to re-render, simply click the ‚Äúrefresh‚Äù icon in the prompt. The AI will regenerate a unique image based on the same prompt you used. Want to expand your conversation possibilities with the Midjourney bot, learn the language here: https://midjourney.gitbook.io/docs/user-manual

title: Passing the FAA Part 107 Remote Pilot Exam
content: The Miami Studio recently purchased a DJI Mini Pro drone for project documentation and existing site documentation. Is your studio considering getting a drone? Here are some things to consider. If you have a small drone that is less than 55 pounds, you can fly for work or business by following the FAA Part 107 guidelines. If you will be operating the drone, you‚Äôll need to Become an FAA-certified drone pilot by passing the Knowledge Test. You can get started here: https://www.faa.gov/uas/commercial_operators. Once you pass, you‚Äôre then eligible to apply for your Remote Pilot Certificate. Our insurance carrier will need to be notified of your studio‚Äôs purchase so the drone can be added to their coverage. You can reach out to Noah Green from our Seattle studio for more information. We‚Äôre happy to say that Shiyin Zeng from the Miami Studio recently passed her exam and is now awaiting certification. She was kind enough to put together some advice on taking the exam. It‚Äôs important to note that the studio invested in the Drone Launch Academy Online Course training material which made a difference in the studying process. We highly recommend it. https://dronelaunchacademy.com/ If you want to connect with other firmwide drone enthusiasts, join this Teams. UAV/Drone User Group Below are Shiyin‚Äôs recommendations. Good luck! ‚Äù Before the exam: Read the official Remote Pilot ‚Äì Unmanned Aircraft System Study Guide Finish the Drone Launch Academy Online Course (this is more helpful, finish it anyway) Regulation: Remote Pilot in Command (RPIC) Responsible for inspection/ must have certification/ other people person manipulating the controls must be under direct supervisor Careless or reckless: failing to take adverse weather into consideration See and avoid: Remote pilots are required to give-way and yield to ALL other aircraft in the sky. Flight at night: Your drone must have anti-collision lights that are visible from 3 statute miles and has a sufficient flash rate to avoid a collision. Remote ID: https://www.faa.gov/uas/getting_started/remote_id Remote ID broadcast module: A broadcast module is a device that broadcasts identification and location information about the drone and its take-off location in accordance with the remote ID rule‚Äôs requirements. Radio Communications Common Traffic Advisory Frequency (CTAF) : airport with no tower, self-report (and you can find the explanation of CTAF and ATIS in the legend if you don‚Äôt remember) MULTICOM: 122.9 UNICOM: non-government ground stations, generally found at low-traffic general aviation airports: Weather information/ Wind direction/ Recommended runway, and/ Any previously reported traffic Automatic Terminal Information Service (ATIS): recorded information relevant to a certain station ‚Äì usually an airport. Weather/ active runways/ navigation equipment outages/ and potential hazards Airspace and Reading Sectional Charts: Very important!! Need to understand all content in the online course. AGL & MSL!! Always check the legend if anything you are not sure Victor airway Altitude boundaries (All number on the sectional chart map are in MSL) Effects of Weather Temperature and Dew Point: fog/freeze precipitation/‚Ä¶ Low level windshear Temperature and performance: https://www.aeromotus.com/information-for-drone-users/how-weather-affects-your-drone-s-performance/ METAR and TAF: valid time/ wind info Loading and Performance The four forces: weight/ lift/ thrust/ drag The influence of the location of CG (center of gravity): Aft-unstable The relationship of center of gravity(CG) and stall: If the CG is too far to the rear on a fixed-wing UAV, the unmanned aircraft will have a very difficult time recovering from a stall Load factor calculation based on the chart. Airport Operations: Towered/ Uncontrolled Towered/ Non-Towered/ Heliport / Seaplane Bases Emergency Procedures: Frequency Interference: usually with office building in exam Lost of GPS: the sUAS may not automatically hold its altitude, correct for wind, or brake when forward control is released. Maintenance and Inspection: Record Keeping: This could be done by documenting any repair, modification, overhaul, or replacement of a system component resulting from normal flight operations, and recording the time-in-service for that component at the time of the maintenance procedure. Physiology Alcohol: Regulations require that blood alcohol level be less than .04 percent and that 8 hours pass between drinking alcohol and piloting an unmanned aircraft. Stimulants: produce anxiety and mood swings, both of which are dangerous when flying. Acute Stress and Chronic Stress Night Vision: The rods can take approximately 30 minutes to fully adapt to darkness. A bright light, however, can completely destroy night adaptation, leaving night vision severely compromised while the adaptation process is repeated. Aeronautical Decision-Making (ADM) Definition: ADM is a systematic approach to risk assessment and stress management. Risk management: ‚Äúthe part of the decision making process which relies on situational awareness, problem recognition, and good judgment to reduce risks associated with each flight.‚Äù(Google) Hazardous Attitudes: (important, appears more than once) Anti-Authority: ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt tell me.‚Äù Impulsivity: ‚ÄúDo it quickly.‚Äù Invulnerability: ‚ÄúIt won‚Äôt happen to me.‚Äù Macho: ‚ÄúI can do it.‚Äù Resignation: ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs the use?‚Äù Things not in the courses or study guide: Maximum Elevation Figure (not mentioned in the course or study guide): https://www.aerial-guide.com/article/calculating-the-maximum-elevation-figure-mef-on-a-sectional-chart Different altitude of the airway: (not mentioned in the course) https://www.flight-insight.com/post/mea-moca-oroca-ifr-altitudes-explained\ If my drone is lost, stolen, or destroyed, what do I need to do? You should cancel your registration through the online portal if your drone is lost, stolen, or destroyed. Definition of the cloud ceiling: The location above the surface of the earth where the lowest layer of clouds are reported as broken, overcast or obscuration (as opposed to thin or partial).
