title: VizR 2022 Q3 eXchange ‚Äì Denver Visualization Projects
content: For our 2022 Q3 VizR eXchange, Scott Schroeder shared an interactive display project as well as some of his explorations in Twinmotion. The Denver office was asked by their Pepperdine University client to help them create an interactive 3D model that facilitates their Donor Naming campaign for the new stadium project. Our team was asked to create an iPad application that visitors can use to interact with the 3D model. As they touch certain sections of the stadium map, the physical model of that section lights up, and a rendered scene of the field from that section shows up on a large screen monitor above the model. The team involved two consultant agencies to help with the project. Archtype3D created the physical 3D model and Neoscape created the iPad application that drives the interaction while our team produced all the visual imageries and animation content for the visual display. The final model was presented at a fundraising event and was wildly successful, and the model will eventually be displayed on campus for the public to interact with it. The second half of the VizR call was focused on the discussion of using Twinmotion for visualization projects. Scott is impressed with the new features of Twinmotion and listed some good reasons why Twinmotion could be used for future visualization projects. Scott discussed the ease of integrating Twinmotion into the projects through the use of Datasmith to link the live Revit/Rhino model to Twinmotion, and the access to the Sketchfab 3D library, especially for their extensive tree selections that can be used to swap out Enscape‚Äôs tree blocks. For more details, watch the recording of the presentation. Click HERE to watch the recording.

title: Data Journey for a Digital Twin
content: Back in 2016(!) we were asked by the DAR steering group what was possible technology wise, for our new London headquarters at 150 High Holborn. Via a series of high level ‚ÄúBIM‚Äù presentations we set about trying to show what might be possible. One presentation slide finished with the YouTube video of the Deloitte building in the Netherlands and I think that was a bit of a defining moment. The feedback was great. ‚ÄúWe want Smart We want Intelligent We want one of the most tech advanced buildings in the world‚Ä¶. ‚Äú If you haven‚Äôt seen this building it‚Äôs worth a scan of the QR code. Bear in mind this was 2016, there may have been some marketing applied to the video but you get the idea. We didn‚Äôt really know at that moment what technology would enable by the time we come to construct some 5 years later but we did know that to enable a smooth transition we would need to deliver robust and structured handover data in an easy to digest, open and useable format. So what do we mean by structured data? The easiest way to explain connected/structured data is to start at the end and show what is possible at Handover. The image above isn‚Äôt a BIM or Revit model this is just a view of a database . All objects contain predetermined fields of data for use in operation by the FM teams. As an example we have selected an Extract Fan here and all of the data attached to that piece of modelled equipment can be seen in the properties dialogue boxes on the right. Where it is in the building It‚Äôs Unique Asset Reference Who supplied and manufactured it It‚Äôs maintenance schedule And links to its o&m and user manual We are highlighting here that if all of this information comes out of a database, then we have a single repository rather than lots of fragmented unchecked information. And because we can set up this database right at the start of the design process it gives us the single source of structured data from the outset. BUT this doesn‚Äôt just happen, somebody needs to ensure that ALL parties enter the required information at the correct time by forming a set of rules known. The rules specify at a very granular level who needs to deliver what and when. Establishing these rules, setting up the requirements, making sure they are adhered to are all part of the role of the Information manager. This diagram above attempts to break the role down into simple steps. Step 1 ‚Äì is understanding what is required and then feeding into a database platform*. Teams will then be assigned a responsibility to provide the applicable information. Step 2 ‚Äì Is validating this information has been input as directed. Step 3 ‚Äì shows the output records/reports at each data drop / stage end ‚Äì The input required is minimal during early design stages and ramps up during construction. Step 4 ‚Äì is the goal of connected data we just spoke about The other important aspect of the information manager role is that an outside party aside from the main contractor is validating that the information has been input as required. * We work with a partner company who provides this platform https://digitalpractice.perkinswill.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/08/Media1.mp4 This short video shows our data model progression to date.  All elements are assigned a very simple unique identification code in Revit. This unique ID code is then the hook to all the other data types associated with handover / delivery information Things such as classification code, Fire Rating,  Location in the building etc. These can all be input via a variety of applications rather than just parameters in clunky Revit. As the video plays you will understand this is a geometric model view of the database , not the Revit model. When we select objects we have instant access to the other asset information that has been populated in the database. The video shows the user choosing the barriers and speed gates and as the objects are selected, we can see we have links to much richer, extended information. We are also able to view the same data via an O&M manual type of display. It is because the data is input in an organized and structured fashion that we are able to view it in a number of ways Just to expand a little on the flexibility aspect, once we have this in an open and structured format, the same data can be connected / imported / exported and viewed in a variety of formats and applications to display other information sets. Add in IOT / sensor devices and you can begin to monitor live building use, well being , comfort, performance , co2 levels etc etc The static design data can then be compared to live these live data feeds to see if the asset / room or function is performing as expected. Which starts us moving to the realms of what is known as Digital Twin. So has this asset information delivery caught on? Well yes it really has. What‚Äôs interesting is that when we take away all of the BIM nonsense (acronym, jargon, confusion) and explain in a simple way, what a client can get at the end of their project, there is often an instant understanding of the value this can bring. We have since embedded these processes on a number of other projects and are also seeing the requests for these standardized ways of working becoming the norm in any significant sized project RFP. It really does seem to be becoming more and more about the data. The next part to this post will attempt to show the plan for how this data will be connected to a smart platform in operation. Watch this space for further upcoming digital practice recaps

title: Artifact User Survey ‚Äì You Replied! We Listened
content: Thank You! Thank You! Thank You for taking the Artifact User Survey! Many of you rose to the call of our previous newsletter post to the Artifact User Survey and provided thoughtful feedback on how to make Artifact more useful for you. Here are a few responses to the most frequent comments we received. We will be implementing many of the requested features soon. Thanks for helping us make Artifact better! ‚ÄúLove Artifact! Can you add more content?‚Äù Your most frequent comment was that you wanted more projects in Artifact. With apologies to¬† Smokey the Bear ‚ÄòOnly YOU can add more content!‚Äô Ask the project leaders in your studio and your Technical Director for projects to add and reach out to Luc Deckinga for assistance in adding them. ‚ÄúCan you identify which drawings on Artifact have Revit content and which only have images?‚Äù When a Revit project is added to Artifact all views are converted to drafting views. We added the ability to download .RVT files containing those drafting views and all associated detail items and graphic styles from Artifact just over a year ago. It is our goal to provide Revit content for 100% of the views in Artifact, but projects that were added before that feature was implemented did not capture that Revit content. We are working through these older projects to bring in that Revit content. All projects added going forward will have this Revit content available. We are also investigating how to capture additional Revit content in the future, including 3D families. ‚ÄúIs there a mechanism for identifying standard drawings or content that has been approved by my Technical Director? We believe drawing sets from all completed Perkins&Will projects deserve to be on Artifact. If you want to curate a set of curated or approved views you can accomplish that in several ways: Create a Collection in Artifact. Add preferred views found throughout the entire Artifact library. Share with your team/studio. Create a Revit project with the desired views. Set the Project Name parameter in Revit how you want it to display in the Artifact sidebar under the ‚ÄòProject‚Äô filter. Add to Artifact using BIM360. We are looking at other ways to capture additional information about the content on Artifact. We encourage you to use the ‚Äòlike‚Äô button available now. Additionally, we are experimenting with the ability to comment on each view. Please reach out if you would like to have a voice in these development efforts. ‚ÄúSome of the sheets in my Revit file aren‚Äôt part of the final drawing set. Can I exclude those from being added to Artifact?‚Äù We currently add all views that have been placed on sheets in the Revit project to Artifact. You will soon be able to identify a particular sheet set to harvest. This is how we organize our drawing sets within Revit, so it makes sense to use that organization for Artifact. This will keep drawings that aren‚Äôt part of the final project deliverable out of the system. ‚ÄúCan we find a project on Artifact by project number?‚Äù If you have worked on a project for a significant time you have the project number ingrained in your brain. While it is not currently a part of the Artifact UI, if you type the project number with the 3-digit extension (e.g. 123456.000) it will show exact matches. We are upgrading the search function to return results without the 3-digit extension (e.g. 123456) ‚ÄòCan Artifact filter projects by location?‚Äù While there is not currently a way to filter projects by location you could get a rough project location by filtering to a particular studio. We realize this is not very precise and are looking at ways to sort by State, Country, or Region. ‚ÄúDoes Artifact understand drawings with keynotes?‚Äù Yes! Drawings with keynotes will show up in search results if you search for a term referenced in the notes. The tag to note translation is shown at the bottom of the Artifact right sidebar. What‚Äôs Next for Artifact? More content and more features to make it more useful for you. Stay tuned in the coming months for new updates and check back frequently for new content that I‚Äôm sure you will all be adding! Thanks for making Artifact a success!

title: Robotics Prototype ‚Äì Microsoft Swing Space
content: Armando, the firms robotic arm has been stranded in Vancouver for months due to Covid. The studios in-house experts in robotic and digital fabrication have continued to¬† experiment and search out practical uses for robotics in architecture.¬† Last month, Armando had a big day: it performed a live demonstration session for a Vancouver client! The live demo was a significant proof-of-concept for a feature wall in the Microsoft Swing Space project. Marc Johannknecht and Babak Manavi captured the demo session ‚Äì check out this awesome video by Marc: The Robotics Prototype is part of a larger swing space project, intended to be a temporary space for Microsoft for the next 3 to 5 years. The temporary nature of a swing space (higher risk tolerance) presented an opportunity to experiment with atypical methodologies. The site has a dramatic entry portal from the previous fit-out: We set out to salvage and re-use as much as possible on this project due to its temporary nature. For the portal, the question we asked ourselves was: is it possible to introduce a new design without using new materials? Instead of using the default paint / film to re-clad or re-finish the portal, we proposed a subtractive method: to carve into the existing painted MDF panels with a new design. The team worked closely with @Manuela to provide embodied carbon assessment for each of the design options: paint, film, new wood cladding, etc. The graphic film option, a popular default material, was ruled out because of its relatively high global warming potential. A subtractive option, in a conventional delivery model, requires skilled labour to de-construct/re-install the panels, carefully transport to/from the millwork shop. This quickly became cost-prohibitive. The¬† millwork contractor also warned of high likelihood that the panels will be damaged from the process because they were not designed for dis-assembly. Armando, stranded in Vancouver thanks to Covid, and our in-house expertise in robotic and digital fabrication made it possible to continue to pursue our preferred approach. A lot of effort went into making this possible. Huge thank you to everyone on the team: Core team ‚Äì Naomi, Manuela, Wendy Experiential Graphic Design ‚Äì Colette Research & Robotics Prototype Team ‚Äì Yehia, Mahdiar, Sebastien, Janna, Marco, Thomas Armando‚Äôs Gallery ‚Äì Mahdiar, Marco, Rick, Akiko

title: OSHLO TRIP
content: Our two Danish studios visited Oslo for a three-day study tour at the beginning of June. The main aims of the trip was to learn more about building in timber, adaptive transformations, urban development and explore our own projects. Interesting places that we visited on the first day of the trip: Storhamarl√•ven Storhamarl√•ven is designed by the pioneer in adaptive transformation and Norwegian architect ‚Äì Sverre Fern. It is a restoration project of an old barn build on top of the bishop castle form over 1000 years ago with a lof of contrasting steel, glass and concrete. Valle Wood Valle Wood is 60 000 m2 office + business complex located in northeast of central Oslo. Valle Wood distinguishes out as a pavilion in the vicinity with a noticeable, solid wood construction. The structure has a BREEAM excellence certification and uses 40% less energy than comparable office buildings. When Valle Wood was constructed, it was the largest all-wood commercial structure in Norway. Ingierstrand bath The first day finished with the dinner by the Oslofjord in Ingierstrand Bad Restaurant. It is an icon in Norwegian modern architectural history and is considered one of the main works in Norwegian functionalist architecture. The architects themselves stated that their goal was to adapt the buildings to the hilly terrain ‚Äúso that the landscape beauty is emphasized and the area is not over-furnished‚Äù On a second day we were joined by inspirational speakers, held an internal¬†sustainability¬†workshop prepared by Enlai Hooi and Ellen Berglund and explored the city with local guides. Sustainability workshop The goal of the sustainable workshop was to share knowledge by instructing all staff members on how to use our SHL Cards and our sustainability procedures. We regard talent development as a vital asset that will help our studio advance. Additionally, a flat hierarchy fosters an ambitious and secure environment for experimentation because knowledge across disciplines is disseminated widely rather than held by a small number of experts. By implementing our SHL Cards, which map out qualities, processes, tools, blind spots, and questions in every project we design, we ensure a studious, analytical, and innovative approach and tailored outcome. The great¬†diversity¬†of our team is an invaluable strength and a workshop and trip such as this highlights how a workplace thrives on the¬†cultural¬†enlightenment and creative clashes that come with it. Explorer During the trip we also launched our new web tool Explorer ‚Äì created in collaboration between Digital Practice and Business and Development department. Explorer helps BD team, project leaders and designers explore sustainability stories behind our projects so that we can replicate the success on the new projects and recall how they were implemented. SHL‚Äôs awesome projects in Oslo: VIA VIA is a mixed-use building in the modernist Vika area in Oslo and in a larger scope the most recent project in the ongoing transformation of Rusel√∏kkveien and Vika. The project successfully creates a new public plaza in the middle of a previously closed city block. The visual links through the site are anchored in the four open corners that lead people into the center. The fa√ßades respond to the two different environments: towards the streets, a stone-clad grid fa√ßade fitting for the modernist Vika heritage, towards the courtyard, a warm vertical ‚Äúforest‚Äù surrounding the 12 m skylight. More on Via here: https://www.shl.dk/ruseloekkveien/ NIO The Chinese car brand NIO are expanding to the European market and opened in 2021 their first European showroom in Oslo. The interior concept is based on friendly Scandinavian traditions, natural materials and with the notion of a fjord landscape where the dominant elements are water, mountains and the sky above. The NIO House is open to public and its centerpiece is the large community wooden staircase. And cars! Link to out app if you want to check out more spots we visited during the trip: https://indd.adobe.com/view/a20f2b1b-378e-4059-9b3b-1e6c9d15e4ea

title: News of the world: DBEI conference
content: Perkins&Will Digital Practice team was invited to speak at¬† Digital Built Week ‚Äì International conference focused on AEC technology. Helen Gorina and Luc Deckinga presented a class ‚ÄúFrom Managing Content to Capturing Institutional Knowledge‚Äù in collaboration with developer of our favorite tool Artifact Dr. Yichun Wei. It generated a lot of interest and was one most attended classes. It was followed by lively discussion. Matt Petermann was participating in a panel discussing Digital Twin and steering it in the right direction. We also attended many great classes and are planning to implement with improvements some of what we learned for PW environment to keep innovating and leading our industry technology. This was a first post-pandemic BiLT conference, and the quality of the classes was exceptionally good. Unfortunately, there were some AV glitches, so there are no video recording of classes. But we have downloaded handouts¬† and posted them here for you to use.

title: Design and Delivery eXchange June 22
content: Link to recording This quarter Design and Delivery call was packed with outstanding project presentation and multiple tools and workflows updates . Presenters Sao Paulo Studio Antonio Guglielmo Carlos Marroquides Lincoln Jyo Sao Paulo team has presented Sabar√° Childrens Hospital and Residencial Platz project It is a mixed use project located at Pinheiros neighborhood in S√£o Paulo, Brazil. It was designed by the C.C.C and Health Care teams from S√£o Paulo office , alongside the Atlanta design team . The co-designing scenario required organization, communication and the rationalization of resources at all times. The team gave us a brief overview. This presentation was a teaser preview, and more detailed presentation and discussion is scheduled for August 22 ‚Äì stay tuned. Tools and resources updates We did not have DD calls for a while, so there is quite a lot of updates to our tools and resources Superdoors update for 2022 was presented by Helen Gorina. These doors are now available from HIVE as well as Supedoor tool. The most significant improvement is the fact that the panels nested inside the door assembly will not tag, so there is not confusion, no extra clicks or tabbing, and no swearing when tagging the doors. And you can use Tag All commands with superdoors now. Updates to PW casework pack was presented by Helen Gorina. Initially Firmwide casework package was introduced in April 2021, here is the link https://vimeo.com/536850888 password ‚ÄúDA‚Äù Since then, we rolled out significant improvements Casework tag is now stacked We developed and published additional cabinets requested by Practices additional details for Practices are in development and will be published soon Added images for recycling decals We thank everyone who gave us feedback and guidance which made these improvements possible. Jeremy Luebker gave an overview of Code compliance workflow which was developed, improved and rolled out in all 2022 US templates. Thanks everyone who gave us feedback to make these improvements possible, and please continue to give us feedback so we can make your workday better.

title: LinkedIN Learning Focused Learning Paths
content: LinkedIn Learning at Perkins&Will Most of you know that Perkins&Will greatly invests in their employee‚Äôs continuing education. One of the many tools available is LinkedIn Learning (LIL). LIL is a one-stop hub of software resources and courses to help you and your team get the fundamental skill required. ¬†The platform offers endless topics and courses for everyone, with access to all course material and offer the courses in 24 different languages LIL can be used a as an informational resource when learning. Key word searches can scan though transcripts of courses and teach you a specific topic. This feature can save you ours of searching through YouTube videos. If you wanted to look deeper into the topic you can quickly switch to the whole video or the entire course. How does Digital Practice help with this LIL You have the freedom to learn anything you want on your own time at your own pace where ever when ever which can be to much for some.¬† If you need to learn a specific task in a short amount of time, contact your offices Digital Practice person . In The Boston Studio we have been using LIL to deliver focused¬†¬†Learning with paths and Collections Paths If you are familiar with Revit but have never used it as part of a team and need to learn¬†quickly how to use Revit in the workshare environment. We can create a Path which is a focused concentrated Teach you segments of a course that focuses on just that topic of working in the workshare environment. Your digital practices person can send you a suggestion for the personalized focus training path Via a link ‚Äú Working with a team in Revit ‚Äú. If you needed to quickly understand the basics of using Revit on BIM360 I can suggest you review a path, I put together for you called ‚Äú Working in the BIM360 Environment ‚Äù Collections We can also set up a Collection for the studio which¬† people can just focus on or see what others are doing in the Boston studio. Here is a collection we are putting together for the Boston Studio ‚Äú Boston Studio Tools ‚Äù Perkins&Will Page If you just want to see all of the Perkins&Will library, just go to the Perkins&Will Page under Browse. Here you will see what your fellow employees are interested in and focusing on LinkedIn Learning is a resource that has thousands of courses on most any topic you¬†can think of both hard software skills and soft skills like public speaking, to Kanban Management system. You can get CEU classes and publish accomplishments to your LinkedIn Profiles. Links in the Article only work if you have a license Contact your Helpdesk For a License Today

title: Zahner Material Composer
content: You‚Äôve probably heard that we‚Äôve been working very closely with Zahner, a world-class metal fabricator. We‚Äôve developed a set of software tools that plug into our shared design platform to support a frictionless, collaborative workflow. Check out this post about our recent workshop at the FacadesPlus conference in New York City. Outside of our collaboration, Zahner has additionally developed tools to accurately visualize their range of metal materials. ‚ÄúExploring the ecosystem of material combinations can be a monumental undertaking and a rabbit hole for design professionals. In an effort to address the challenge, the Zahner Labs team has built a web tool to explore the vast design space of material selection and comparison. The MaterialComposer project aims to make exploration effortless, surprising, and fun ‚Äì while making sourcing, selection and specification a breeze.‚Äù Go to https://www.azahner.com/labs/materialcomposer/ for an online preview, then download drag-and-drop Rhino materials to visualize these materials on your own design.

title: Artifact ‚Äì 800 Users! 40,000 Drawings!
content: 800+ Users and Over 40,000 drawings! Thank you so much for making Artifact a success! Help us make it even better by taking this short survey. It‚Äôs six questions and won‚Äôt take more than two minutes. Honest. https://forms.reform.app/480arH/make-us-better-artifact Artifact was made for you! We want to know how you use Artifact and what additional features you would like to see added. Those who have been with us for a while have seen the site evolve, with improved harvesting, search functionality, and seamless Revit and BIM 360 Integrations. We want to continue these improvements and need you to guide our efforts. Thank you for taking the time to help! I Forget, What is Artifact? How do I log in? Artifact is a collaboration between AIPrentice, a software developer, and Perkins&Will‚Äôs Digital Practice department. ¬†As a reminder to anyone who hasn‚Äôt logged in for a while, Artifact is the drawing search site that turns text and metadata in your Revit drawings into searchable terms, so you find exactly the drawing you‚Äôre looking for and adapt it to a new project. To log in with your Perkins&Will credentials, go to Pwitter (green arrow) > Microsoft MyApps > Artifact. Add More Drawings to Artifact, Please? Artifact is only as good as the content within, so we are asking you to contribute your studio‚Äôs work. Please talk to the technical and design leadership within your studio to identify at least one or two projects to include, and coordinate with your Digital Practice representative, or Digital Practice Manager Luc Deckinga, to add your content. Show off your work to the rest of Perkins&Will! We currently have 44,847 drawings in the Artifact database, taken from 69 completed projects designed by ten different Perkins&Will studios. It would be great to hit 100,000 drawings (mostly because we like round numbers :), but it is a more important milestone to have every studio represented in Artifact with at least one project. Thanks for all your help and support!

title: Zahner and P&W Workshop at Facades+ New York
content: Nathan Barnes, Luc Deckinga, and Mario Romero gave a workshop demonstrating the Zahner/Perkins&Will collaborative workflow at Facades+ New York on March 31, 2023. Frustrated by loops of rework and wasted time, Perkins&Will envisioned a more collaborative and dynamic feasibility review process for its fabrication and construction partners, a process that would allow more design time and speed up decisions. Working with like-minded leaders at fabrication partner Zahner, the two firms invented a shared workspace and feasibility model that produces higher design fidelity, shorter delivery schedules, and more joyful clients and communities. Learn more about this process and how it can be adapted for your work and how process improvements like this can be implemented between many partners for faster, better collaborations. In the design process, details inevitably change. Big or small, these alterations can cost everyone extra time and money if they aren‚Äôt communicated clearly. We asked: ‚ÄúIs it possible to exchange model and design data directly with fabricators so they better understand our intent?‚Äù Together we developed a cloud-enabled 3D modeling workflow that reduces design revisions and achieves higher-quality results for our clients. Dubbed the ‚ÄúDynamic Design and Feasibility Workflow,‚Äù this process is centered on workspaces and tools shared by the teams, as well as regular reviews of both Perkins&Will‚Äôs and Zahner‚Äôs work. By adopting this process both teams realize increased efficiency and more design confidence, along with precise cost estimates and accurate production schedules. Whitepaper: Dynamic Design and Feasibility Workflow ‚Äì How to Optimize Concept Iteration to Realize Extraordinary Projects Workshop info: Digital Collaboration and Instant Iteration Documentation site with example files and step-by-step instructions: https://pwz.tools/faq

title: VizR 2022 Q2 eXchange ‚Äì Automating Dynamic Entourage Placement for Enscape Visualization
content: Presented by: Michael Vollrath To kickstart our 2022 Quarterly VizR meeting, Michael showcased his Grasshopper scripts that automate entourage placement inside Revit for Enscape visualization. Placing entourage elements such as people and cars to fill a scene can sometimes be a tedious and time-consuming task, Michael Vollrath set out to solve that problem by finding an easy way to automate the placement of these elements in a dynamic and intelligent way that doesn‚Äôt look too repetitive and robotics but just random enough to create a realistic scene. Michael created two grasshopper scripts with two very creative and descriptive names called ‚ÄúButt in Seats‚Äù and ‚ÄúLots of Cars‚Äù. Just as the name implies, ‚ÄúButt in Seats‚Äù will place seated people on elements identified as seats, and ‚ÄúLots of Cars‚Äù will fill the parking lot with many more cars. The concept is simple enough for anyone to understand and use. Michael then went a few more steps further to make the scripts flexible enough to allow customization in entourage selection to fit the need of project scenes. For example, the seated people can be filtered for age range and outfit style, so you can customize your corporate office scene with business people aged 18 ‚Äì 60 years old, versus a hospital lobby scene that will be filled with casual styled people of all different age group. The ‚ÄúLots of Cars‚Äù also offer customization, such as filling the parking lot to the level of density specified, and allowing you to identify doors as entrances to the facility, so the cars will fill up starting with spots closest to the entrance first. For more details about the scripts, watch the meeting recording HERE .

title: Newforma, the Last Days
content: Newforma passed away after a long battle with illness that left it slow and slow.¬† ¬†Newforma has been around for over 15 years which in technology years put it well into its 90s. Newforma has lived in the inboxes and file folders of our projects for many years.¬† ¬†It is survived by Outlook, Excel, and its grandkids Procore, PlanGrid, and others.¬† ¬†Newforma is preceded in death by ProjectDox, AutoCad, Vasari, Ecotect, Autodesk Impression, dRofus, and others.¬† ¬†In its early days, Newforma was a favorite of all the technical and organized people who wanted a better way to organize their project communication and information. Newforma will be laid to rest this June at which time all remaining project work should adopt younger more modern tools to find better value and efficiency in the requirements we must complete during construction contract administration.¬† ¬†Because of its passing if your project hasn‚Äôt already been completed you should have a transition plan in place.¬† ¬†It should include understanding what the contractors use as a project information management software platform, understanding what your client might want to look at for completed RFI responses or submittal reviews, knowing how much time is left in the schedule to have a good estimate if you will have 100s more submittals to review and 100s or more RFIs to respond to.¬† ¬†We have recordings in our CCA Quickstart on how to efficiently deal with our CCA process to make the process more efficient for the remainder of your project.¬† ¬†Please reach out to your local Digital Practice team member to help assist you in planning your transition if there are any complications to what might be most effective for your specific project situation.

title: Enscape 3.3+ New Features
content: Enscape 3.3.1 is available in Software Center, from our last release (3.1.2), it is bringing new features, most listed above. Install Enscape 3.3.1 and try these new features. Dynamic Asset & Multi-asset Placement Dynamic Asset Select, place, and edit assets from the Asset Libraries into your design via the Enscape rendering window. What is added to your rendering is reflected in Revit. Multi-asset Placement Over rectangular, circular, and surface (bucket) areas. Good for entourage elements such as Cars, Trees, People, etc. A: Choose the Assets B: Choose the shape (Rectangular, Circular, or Bucket) C: Choose the Width D: Choose the Density and Distribution E: Regenerate and Apply changes Panorama Tours & Batch Panorama rendering Batch Panorama rendering allows rendering multiple panoramas at once Panorama Tours Export Panoramas into Tour Mode provides an enhanced panorama viewing experience. Web-based does not need extra power from a Graphic card. Check here or read the QR Code Site Context Import surroundings from OpenStreetMap Database Show/Hide Buildings or streets by a specific layer Transparent Materials in Reflections Transparent Materials in Reflections Only for hardware-accelerated ray tracing (NVIDIA RTX series and AMD RX6xxx series) Alpha Channel Export Frequently used for changing the background of the renderings, Now Enscape allows to export with transparent background. Pin Enscape on Top If not working with two screens or more, the Enscape window can be fixated on top Material Overwrite Real-time Material Overwrite, replacing Revit material‚Äôs Appearance with Enscape materials Camera Sync Optimization Camera Sync Optimization:¬†No need to update the whole scene from camera to camera

title: How to Use the Render Farm at Perkins&Will
content: Get Started To access the render farm you will need to install an application called Deadline Monitor . This is the only way to access the render machines. Deadline Monitor helps maintain the availability of these machines for rendering, organizes past and present jobs, and maintains the rendering queue for everyone needing to render. Perkins&Will‚Äôs render farms are intended as a sharable resource. Deadline Monitor facilitates sharing. Supported Apps‚Ä¶ What do I need? Install Deadline Monitor, V-Ray 5 from Software Center. F.A.Q. No V-Ray Licenses Available?! If this happens, please message Digital Practice . We are prepared to expand the number of licenses as the need increases. Unfortunately, the V-Ray Chaos license server software provides no log or other means of informing Digital Practice when the number of licenses are too few. We are depending on you to let us know each time licenses are unavailable. Thank you in advance. Can I Render from a Computational Node? Yes. To avoid negative attention always check the ‚ÄòCap CPU Utilization‚Äù in Rhino and SketchUp or ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt Use Local Resources‚Äù in Revit when rendering from a computational node. Rendering Etiquette As a shared resource, it is important to practice good etiquette with others using the office render farm. This means splitting the resources for simultaneous use, refraining from escalating your job in front of others in the render queue and communicating with one another as needed. It is also important to clean up after your projects. Delete your old jobs once you no longer need them.¬†¬†If your job has errors and you plan to request assistance from a Design Application Manager or other, do not delete the job. Deadline jobs log errors. These logs may help identify the cause of your error. Feedback Constructive criticism is always welcome, but letting us know if our efforts have been helpful is important too. If you have a suggestion to improve these resources let us know. Also if our work has been helpful to you please share this. It helps us better help you. If you have a positive story share we would love to hear it. We may even feature your story in Digital Practice‚Äôs monthly ReCap. Message the Digital Practice on our firmwide Visualization Teams channel .

title: Digital Practice Innovation Showcase Series Part 2
content: Check out our update for our regular showcase in which we collect a few people from each studio to quickly share what they are doing on their project to employ new tools or reimagine their use of our existing tools to gain efficiency or value to our design, delivery, or communication.¬† ¬†We have completed four of these showcases so far and if you missed any of them we have heard from a wide range of people from Denver, Seattle, Los Angeles, and Chicago on topics like Rhino Inside Revit, Matterport for capturing existing conditions, Miro for running client engagement, virtual pull planning, power automate for CCA, and computational design workflows for facades. If you weren‚Äôt able to make the talks from the last couple of months check out the recordings below.¬† ¬†Also, think about what you and your peers are doing on your projects today that someone in another studio might benefit from knowing.¬† ¬†We have more showcases coming up every month this year to cover every studio across the firm.
