title: Evolving Technology in CCA ‚Äì Part 3
content: Introduction The last decade has seen a change in how projects are staffed, managed, and led. Through the use of file transfer protocol (‚ÄúFTP‚Äù) sites and cloud storage services, project teams are no longer tied to a single physical location. Today, it is more common to have a design team comprised of members from offices across multiple states working together on one project. This is especially true on projects of scale. The old but reliable way of communicating the construction progress was through field reports and digital photographs, transmitted via e-mail or posted to FTP sites. Some of the more sophisticated clients and contractors used webcams where anyone at any time could log on to check the status of construction. This later evolved into web-based platforms where daily logs, photographs, observations, and deficiencies could be uploaded and shared with anyone with internet access. The purpose of this document is to share some of the technologies and strategies used over a 6-year period during the Construction Contract Administration phase of the University of Virginia (UVA), University Hospital Expansion (UHE) project. It also includes some of the technological advances explored over the past 18-months of the pandemic. The Challenge The UVA UHE project included over 440,000 square feet of new construction and 90,000 square feet of renovation. The $268M project started in 2014 with the commencement of 7 enabling projects that made way for the new, 12-story patient tower. Fortunately, the owner requested full-time, on-site representation by the Design Team. At the commencement of the 6-year Construction Contract Administration (CCA) effort, the Perkins&Will DC Office Team set themselves the challenge of experimenting with the use of technology during CCA. Laser Scanning Laser scanning is an excellent example of a technology where while the quality of the scans has increased, the costs have become more accessible. What would previously have been a $250K exercise, laser scanning of existing buildings can now be performed for a fraction of the cost. The cost of the actual equipment, however, is not cheap. We recently worked with Skanska to have the exterior of the wind tunnel at Virginia Polytechnic and State University (Virginia Tech) scanned to import into Revit. Skanska uses the Leica RT360, which Leica describes as a ‚ÄúHigh-speed 3D laser scanner with integrated HDR spherical imaging system and Visual Inertial System (VIS) for real-time registration‚Äù 5. Weighing in at 11.7 lbs (w/o batteries), the Leica RT360 is capable of scanning up to 2 million points per second and has a range of up to 130 meters. The approximate cost of the Leica RT360 is more than 90 thousand dollars. Perkins&Will was awarded the Randolph Hall replacement project at Virginia Tech. In addition to the challenge of replacing the 1950s era engineering buildings, the Team is tasked with ensuring the existing wind tunnel, which is one of the largest university-owned stability wind tunnels in the United States6, stays operational 100% of the time during demolition and construction. The tunnel, which was originally built at the NACA Langley Aeronautical Laboratory in 1940, was acquired by Virginia Tech in 1958 and erected in 1959 in a specially designed wing of Randolph Hall. The as-built drawings only portray the overall shape of the tunnel and do not accurately depict the ribs, foundation piles, etc. As noted above, Perkins&Will worked with Skanska, the Construction Manager at Risk, to obtain a laser scan of the tunnel. Our hope was to obtain a point cloud scan of the structure to import into Revit for modeling. What we learned is that through inputting some survey points obtained by our civil engineer, we were able to scan the tunnel as it sits relative to the world: meaning that the scan/model is geospatially located. This means that when we bring the model into our Revit model, the tunnel is placed exactly where it sits within the world. Laser scanning is another example of an effective tool for on-site documentation and one where we expect the speed and quality of scans will only improve over time. The Pandemic No one would describe today‚Äôs Design and Construction Market as stable, consistent, and unchanging. Like most professions, the Design and Construction industry has been forced to adapt quickly to the ever-changing landscape of the pandemic: a landscape where working from home is now common and travel for work is limited. AIA Contracts state that the Architect‚Äôs role in construction is to: 1. Visit the site at intervals appropriate to the stage of construction 2. Become generally familiar with the progress and quality of the portion of the work completed 3. Determine, in general, if the Work observed is being performed in accordance with the Contract Documents7. Architects have therefore been challenged to find new and unique ways to complete their contractual obligations remotely. Using the previously mentioned strategies and technologies is an option but cannot and should not replace on-site representation. By way of example, once you see the quality of the Matterport or StructionSite‚Äôs virtual tours you may question why go to the site? The answer is because the technology is just not there‚Ä¶ yet. While the photo-realistic tours are great for giving you a sense of the space and the level of completion, it would be impossible to perform a thorough review, especially when it comes to punch. And while virtual online 360 tours may facilitate inspections by the local Authority Having Jurisdiction (AHJ), you quickly learn that they cannot replace an in-person substantial completion or final completion review as there is simply too much at which to look. In-person reviews are still preferred over virtual, no matter what strategy, platform, or application you use. UVA UHE Construction Team thanking healthcare workers, April 16,2020 Virtual Galleries Virtual Galleries are another product of the pandemic. Where project interviews were previously held in person, the pandemic necessitated a move to virtual. During a Miami office pursuit, our Digital Practice team created a 3D gallery for use in presenting during a virtual interview. The gallery was created in Enscape and features 9 bays radiating from a central node. Content on the walls of each gallery is pulled from PowerPoint slides of the presentation. 3D models were also displayed in the central node and several of the bays. The audience was thoroughly impressed by our innovation and the use of technology to facilitate the guided tour of the gallery and associated presentation. Since then, the gallery format has been used as a template to create countless virtual galleries, an example of which is the UVA UHE gallery. https://vizlab.perkinswill.com/tours/uva/ Like Matterport models, anyone with the web address and an internet connection can access the model without the need for any additional plugins or applications. The user navigates the space similar to Google maps or a Matterport model. The user can interact with the images on the walls by clicking to enlarge the image to full screen. 3D models can be rotated 360 degrees to view the model from multiple angles. Links to Matterport scans drop the user into the interactive model and videos play at the click of a button. QR Codes are also embedded to facilitate participants in a virtual tour to jump into the gallery themselves and/or access select features. Conclusion As illustrated in the various examples, the exploration of the use of Technology can reap wonderful rewards. We simply must have the courage to be open to trying new things and be receptive to change. This however cannot be accomplished alone and requires the support of your company to expend resources, be it time, money, or both. The hope is that by sharing our findings and experiences, we can push the industry as a whole towards more efficient construction progress documentation. As mentioned above, we highly recommend the Matterport camera. Originally developed for the real estate industry to create virtual tours, it‚Äôs an incredible time-saving tool. Where field verification previously required multiple trips and countless hours reviewing drawings, markups, and photographs, it now can be performed by a single person in one visit. And the ability to share walkable models of completed spaces with potential clients is a huge step forward. Laser scanning is another example of a technology that we as architects should fully embrace. However, where purchasing a Matterport camera is a small investment that yields big returns, it may not make financial sense for your firm to own its own laser scanner. This is where partnering with a technologically savvy construction team help. Especially in complex additions and renovations, the ability to scan with pinpoint accuracy buildings and their various components is of huge benefit to the entire project team. The value of tried-and-true technologies such as webcams should not be overlooked. On the UHE, Skanska used real-time images to plan just-in-time deliveries. We also learned that emergency medical service (EMS) used the webcams to see what traffic conditions were like en route to the facility. And for an Owner, the value of the webcam goes beyond the ability to know what is occurring on-site at any time. Webcams add another level to the existing security monitoring system. Changes stemming from the Pandemic to our way of life, our way of doing business, are real. If it has taught us anything, it is the need to be more flexible and to have multiple means of communication. Virtual galleries and virtual site tours are now an integral part of the new normal and I for one am excited to see the next advancements in Construction Progress Documentation. Jim Woody is an Associate Principal in Perkins&Will‚Äôs Washington, DC Studio. In the past decade, Jim has focused almost exclusively on the construction administration of healthcare facilities in this region. He provides technical oversight of the design and construction documents and will lead the construction phase for projects. Jim becomes an integral part of our internal team during the design phases so he understands the ‚Äòwhy‚Äô behind planning decisions and can ensure those are carried through in the field.

title: Towards Scalable and Reusable Computational Design Workflows with the Cloud
content: Have you requested or shared a computational design script/workflow with a colleague recently? Did it work right away? Chances are that at least some hiccups occurred. Sometimes I share scripts with myself and get them. Now, we all want to deliver more efficient and sustainable buildings, we want it so hard that we plug wires, write code, and do all sorts of automation so that we answer important questions regarding energy, daylight, wind, carbon, etc. Well, not everyone is excited about wires and scripting, and they are right. But, we still need to make sure everyone reflects on the environment and be efficient. The following research article is a summary of my thesis as MSc. Architectural Engineer from the Technical University of Denmark. It aims at scaling computational design workflows by delegating their use to cloud computers that don‚Äôt sleep, have coffee breaks and get stuck in meetings, while designers can access these workflows without the hassle of looking at wires or calling IT for installing plugins on very specific versions.¬† This responsibility stays solely with the folks who actually like doing this sort of work (like me ü§ì and other nerds I know across the firm). Here we go‚Ä¶ Computational Design (CD) is around for many years now. Its adoption is still increasing in #AEC (Caetano, et. al 2021). Not so recent, yet very relevant sources (Davis , 2011) already pointed to the fragility of parametric models, and its development issues. CD usage in #AEC is diverse (De Boisseu, 2022). Some use it to enhance modelling productivity (parameteric), or to generate solutions (generative), others just as conceptual sandbox (algorithmic). Common ground is that everyone write some sort of procedural computation (script). From a practical point of view, large firms deploy specialist teams to apply CD in architectural/engineering projects. Smaller firms without enough resources have individuals who are particularly interested and find a way to sneak CD in their workflow. These teams/individuals are a scarce resource.¬† Keough and Hauck (2017) shed a light in this issue. Specially if #AEC as an industry want to leverage CD into more projects. They mention a finite consulting problem. They also suggest using #cloudcomputing to scale things. At Perkins&Will and Schmidt Hammer Lassen (Copenhagen) and which supported this project, a library of CD workflows (mostly Grasshopper, Dynamo scripts) it‚Äôs been harvest, but it‚Äôs really hard to deploy them into projects. Here‚Äôs 4 issues I highlight: Only a limited group of people is able to use workflows. Workflows are not self-contained and often need to be reengineered from project to project. Execution of workflows is tightly coupled with the developer local machine The whole process is serial (and hard to parallelize). Enough talking about problems. It‚Äôs not like I discovered anything new really. In fact, many parties are already trying to address them. This is the case of Hypar and Pollination Cloud . They are cloud platforms that execute workflows. I reviewed Hypar, Pollination but also 3 other workflow systems that are not #AEC related. They are Argo Workflows , Apache Airflow and Luigi . They all help orchestrate and execute tasks. There‚Äôs also a whole world of workflow management systems. Essentially they are applications to assist the orchestration and execution of workflows. These systems have frameworks and common features. They usually have components like: UI, data and metadata management, execution engine, schedulers, container resource manager, monitoring and API. At some point I realized there was close to nothing in the literature pointing to how Hypar o r Pollination Cloud were designed, what assumptions they took and just general discussion. So I tried to help. I review these systems based on documentation or open-source code available and usage. I do the same with Argo, Luigi and Airflow. In fact Luigi/Argo are part of the Pollination stack. So I try to design a framework based on those systems, that can orchestrate CD workflows. I will describe what considerations I made: The usage and the development of CD workflows are decoupled. The CDner develops, encapsulates and deploy its workflow, and the system exposes it to who ever wants to use it. The system uses containers to encapsulate and schedule workflows. I find it more extensible, since this opens the framework to whatever programming language a CDner want to use (Python, JS, C#, etc.). The UI doesn‚Äôt expose any code complexity, but rather is used to ‚Äúfill the gaps‚Äù in the workflow blueprint. Meaning it can be simple for people who are not CD experts. There should be mechanisms to store persistent data, workflow definitions, and to pass data between workflow tasks. Data is passed either as parameters or artifacts (files). The system orchestrate the workflows/task. There are different ways to do it. Pollination/Airflow/Luigi parses code using a DSL. Hypar generates boilerplate code after you manually choose parameters/dependencies. Argo uses a manifest. I think they are all great üòä. I use ‚Äúsolution objects‚Äù to match parts of the framework with the issues we talked early: Reusability Encapsulation Extensibility Composability I test the framework with a small experiment. No way I could implement the whole thing by myself. So I pick some GH @ladybug_tools sample scripts, wrap them using Rhino Compute, dockerize them and deploy to a container registry. I then produce a workflow manifest that Argo reads as instructions for scheduling the containers and execute them in the right way I need. Unfortunately, I had to skip implementing a meaningful UI as the framework suggests. Also, I was particularly interested on the orchestration and executions. A few conclusions: The framework decouples usage from development of CD workflows. Therefore increasing reusability to more projects then currently supported. Encapsulation is important. In order to be executed, a workflow needs to be self contained (external dependencies included e.g.) Cloud resources can expose an infrastructure otherwise unavailable for comp. designers operating on their local machines. Workflow management systems can help orchestrate, trigger, schedule and execute these workflows. It‚Äôs smart to either adopt or adapt them to #AEC usecases. Some future work I foresee: Encapsulation has similarities with process mining for #digitaltwins . They will soon evolve to more dynamic rather then static representations. The two roles: the workflow coder and the user. I see those as two essential parts. While the coder takes the responsibility of encoding, the user is the one who compose the workflows in something meaningful. Containers, cloud computing is another layer of complexity for architects and civil engineers to digest. It‚Äôs not rocket science, but it‚Äôs not simple either. That‚Äôs it! If you are interested in hearing more about these things or need some help deploying your current workflows to the cloud just shoot me a message üëåüöÄ. References: Aurelie, B. D. (2022). Introduction to Computational Design: Subsets, Challenges in Practice and Emerging Roles. In M. Bolpagni, R. Gavina, & D. Ribeiro, Industry 4.0 for the Built Environment (pp. 55-76). Springer. Caetano, I., Santos, L., & Leit√£o, A. (2020). Computational design in architecture: Defining parametric, generative, and algorithmic design. Frontiers of Architectural Research , 287-300. Davis, D. (2013). Modelled on Software Engineering Flexible Parametric Models in the Practice of Architecture. PhD Thesis, RMIT University, School of Architecture and Design. Keough, I., & Hauck, A. (2017). From Pencils to Partners: The Next Role of Computation in Building Design. Architectural Design , 74-81.

title: Digital Practice Innovation Showcase Series Part 1
content: While planning our 2022 Digital Practice schedule we wanted to mix up the topics and presenters that we have had for the last few years on our monthly eXchange calls.¬† ¬†In doing this we discussed the idea of sharing new and innovative techniques that project teams were using to tackle their problems.¬† ¬†Out of this was born the idea of a regular showcase in which we collect a few people from each studio to quickly share what they are doing on their project to employ new tools or reimagine their use of our existing tools to gain efficiency or value to our design, delivery, or communication.¬† ¬†We have completed two of these showcases so far and if you missed either of them we have heard from a wide range of people from Toronto, San Francisco, Atlanta, and Minneapolis on topics like existing conditions assessments, drone photography, computational design for landscape analysis, rendering requirement framework, CCA without Newforma, robotics on-site for printing plans, and facade design process for fabric inspiration. If you weren‚Äôt able to make these check out the recordings below.¬† ¬†Also, think about what you and your peers are doing on your projects today that someone in another studio might benefit from knowing.¬† ¬†We have more showcases coming up every month this year to cover every studio across the firm. Ôªø

title: Future of SketchUp

author.name: Nick Cameron
author.description: American trucker who has been featured on the History channel reality television series Ice Road Truckers and its spinoff series IRT: Deadliest Roads.

content: Back in July 2020 we announced that SketchUp would not be upgraded any longer at Perkins&Will. Since that announcement many teams have transitioned to using Rhino in the conceptual design phase. Teams are also utilizing advanced workflows made possible by recent interoperability improvements connecting Rhino and Revit. We have recorded many training sessions focused on transitioning from SketchUp to Rhino, and how to efficiently deploy design workflows in this new platform. Click here to view the library. As we near the two-year anniversary of our announcement, we want to remind those still using SketchUp that you may begin to experience compatibility issues using files or plugins developed for newer versions of SketchUp. There is no roadmap for which plugins will remain compatible with Sketchup 2020. As new versions of those plugins are released some will inevitably stop working. To avoid disruptions, we will start to limit which plugins can interact with Sketchup, beginning this July with Enscape. If you have any questions regarding SketchUp‚Äôs plugin compatibility issues or would like to set up Rhino training to move your team to a more robust design platform, please reach out to me.

title: Evolving Technology in CCA ‚Äì Part 2
content: Introduction The last decade has seen a change in how projects are staffed, managed, and led. Through the use of file transfer protocol (‚ÄúFTP‚Äù) sites and cloud storage services, project teams are no longer tied to a single physical location. Today, it is more common to have a design team comprised of members from offices across multiple states working together on one project. This is especially true on projects of scale. The old but reliable way of communicating the construction progress was through field reports and digital photographs, transmitted via e-mail or posted to FTP sites. Some of the more sophisticated clients and contractors used webcams where anyone at any time could log on to check the status of construction. This later evolved into web-based platforms where daily logs, photographs, observations, and deficiencies could be uploaded and shared with anyone with internet access. The purpose of this document is to share some of the technologies and strategies used over a 6-year period during the Construction Contract Administration phase of the University of Virginia (UVA), University Hospital Expansion (UHE) project. It also includes some of the technological advances explored over the past 18-months of the pandemic. The Challenge The UVA UHE project included over 440,000 square feet of new construction and 90,000 square feet of renovation. The $268M project started in 2014 with the commencement of 7 enabling projects that made way for the new, 12-story patient tower. Fortunately, the owner requested full-time, on-site representation by the Design Team. At the commencement of the 6-year Construction Contract Administration (CCA) effort, the Perkins&Will DC Office Team set themselves the challenge of experimenting with the use of technology during CCA. 360 Photos and GoPro Video Technology is constantly advancing. Moore‚Äôs law is the principle that the speed and capability of computers can be expected to double every two years4. Over the course of the UHE, we certainly saw advances in several technologies including 360 pictures and videos. Almost immediately, Skanska accepted and offered to participate in our challenge to explore the use of technology in Construction Progress documentation. Initially, they used 360 photos via a GoPro to document the weekly site progress. This later turned into 360 GoPro Videos, an example of which can be seen here: BIM 360 GoPro Video https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kh1eza1Up9s Note while the video is hosted on YouTube, you can still interact with the video via your cursor. Simply click and rotate the image around. And to help illustrate how these types of videos can be shared with other offices, the following was a video Skanska put together to provide a virtual tour of the behavioral health unit of the Emergency Department: BIM 360 GoPro Video https://youtu.be/0pn8MXYP2yE Note this is one example of an effective way to communicate the status of construction to leadership or consultants in other offices and locations. UVA UHE Level 01 Walkthrough March 1, 2018 UVE UHE Behavioral Health Walkthrough December 14, 2018 StructionSite and OxBlue According to OxBlue‚Äôs website, they are the leading provider of professional construction camera services. On the UHE, we had three (3) webcams installed that permitted anyone with the web address to view the conditions on-site in real-time. The time-lapse video was also made possible via one of the cameras that took a photo every 15 minutes. As an additional service, OxBlue offers construction progress documentation services where they visit the site at defined intervals and photograph the project from a pre-determined set of locations. The photos are then mapped to interactive plans of the project where the user can view the photos taken during each visit. This allows the user to view the progress in a single room, for example, over the entire life of the project. Structionsite offers a similar service, except the photos can be taken by the Contractor and are linked together to provide a walkable, interactive model of the site. The following video illustrates the use of Structionsite‚Äôs ability to compare and sync 360 photos of the on-site conditions with the BIM. It also illustrates how changing the date of the photos permits the viewer to simulate ‚ÄúX-ray vision‚Äù, revealing what is in the walls and where. BIM Vs Actual Video https://vizlab.perkinswill.com/tours/uva/media/Bay%203%20Board%20A.mp4 StructionSite User Interface Matterport and Photogrammetry With the UVA UHE project, the Perkins&Will CA team set themselves a challenge of finding ways to use the Matterport camera during CA. The Matterport is a 6-lens camera that simultaneously creates a low-density point cloud. The camera is controlled via an app on your phone or tablet and the images are mapped to the point cloud. Each scan is connected to the previous one and the software stitches the photos together as you go. The product is a photo-realistic, walkable map of the 3D environment that can be shared via a web address. The final model can be viewed via any device with an internet connection and no special software is required. Here are some examples of how we used the Matterport and shared its output: To document a sacrificial first in-place mockup of an ICU patient room that had been constructed prior to dry-in. Being a finished mock-up that had been exposed to moisture intrusion, the room was completely rebuilt after the user signed off. Using the Matterport camera, we had a 3D, walkable model of the approved ICU room. There are a total of 84 ICU rooms on the project, so having the 3D model for comparison proved invaluable. Additionally, and because of COVID, there was a time when we thought we wouldn‚Äôt be able to get final photographs of the rooms. Our photographer was able to generate final photos from the Matterport model. To document the full-scale, off-site performance and visual mockup of the exterior. We have since used this model in presentations about the project at various conferences. To document the on-site conditions just prior to turn over of the plinth (Ground thru level 2M). This model was shared with the users, who in turn shared that they used it for training purposes in getting the staff familiar with the new layout. We also shared it with the 1st year med students, with whom we facilitated a VR Workshop on the project. Experimentally, to document the post-demo conditions of one phase of the renovation. We used Matterport‚Äôs ability to generate floor and ceiling plans to compare the post-demo conditions against the as-built drawings. Using the new iPhone app, we used it to document the existing conditions for an add-service and shared the model with the consultants to help inform their proposal relative to the very limited scope. The MEP consultant was based out of Boston, so this helped tremendously during the Pandemic. Additionally, we can‚Äôt tell you how many times we have pulled up a model on a phone at a conference and/or marketing event. It is a fantastic conversation starter. Consider that the Matterport camera we used on the UVA project is only the 2nd generation. Now imagine where this technology will be in 5 years! In our opinion, it is an amazing tool that everyone should be familiar with and be able to talk about its capabilities with existing and future clients.

title: Current software updates
content: As you may have noticed we have some updates to some of the firm‚Äôs main modeling platforms, Revit and Rhino.¬† ¬† We always try to strike the right balance between keeping the product functioning at all times and respecting the time it takes to ensure your own laptop is up to date. The Rhino update can be done relatively quickly depending on if you are in the studio or at home.¬† ¬†One thing of note is that this update will require a restart of your laptop within 10 minutes of the process in order to complete the installation.¬† ¬†Please take note of those so as not to do it while you are on an MS Teams call or have other time-sensitive work happening on your laptop.¬† ¬†You will also see this message in the dialog prompt when you confirm you want to run the installer.¬† ¬†This update will be required next week if you have been deferring the installation. In addition, there are also required Revit hotfix updates for 2019, 2020, 2021, and 2022 .¬† ¬†These hotfixes help with some issues Revit may see as it relates to BIM360 where we store all of our project models. Each of these is required on a day next week so you will be forced to install them all next week if you haven‚Äôt already.¬† ¬†One thing to note is, because of how Autodesk builds these installers the install process for Revit 2019 and 2020 can be extremely slow even with good broadband speeds.¬† ¬†Expect it to take many hours for those two, so it is recommended to run the updates at the end of your workday. You will also see the newest version of Lumion available in software center, updates to the Revit IFC exporter , Rhino Inside Revit add-in, Autodesk license manager, InternetClicker , Climate Studio , and Vray for Rhino and Vray for 3dsMax, and updates to Autodesk Desktop Connector .¬† ¬†All of these are available al la carte as you need them for your current project responsibilities.¬† ¬†Also next week we will be making all the titles that come with Adobe 2022 available for everyone across the firm. When application updates are required for something you already have installed the pop-up may show up on your laptop at an inopportune time that wouldn‚Äôt allow you to run the update right then.¬† ¬†We cannot control that timing as it has to do with how windows functions and all laptops check into the server at random times, however, you can always defer that pop-up and then open software center at any time that is convenient for your work to select the update being prompted and install it on your own schedule.

title: Design Forum ‚Äì Collaboration with Zahner Metals
content: We are continuously envisioning and pursuing a more dynamic design process ‚Äìone that speeds up decisions allows more design iterations and delivers design excellence to every client. Across our firm, we have been working closely with fabrication partners, including Zahner Metals. Together we have invented a shared workspace and dynamic design feasibility process that produces greater design fidelity, more precise lead time estimating, and more transparency in terms of feasibility, design excellence, and costs. Our Miami, Toronto, and Denver studios presented case studies showcasing this collaboration in our most recent Design Forum. If you missed it you can see the recording here. Contact Luc Deckinga, Mario Romero, or your studio‚Äôs Digital Practice representative to learn how to deploy this toolset on your current project. Presenters: Michael Blois (Toronto), Shabaan Khokhar (Toronto), Robin Ault (Denver), Pat Bosch (Miami), Damian Ponton (Miami), Ashley Stoner (Los Angeles), Luc Deckinga (San Francisco) Bonus! To further promote this effort and synthesize the knowledge that we collected through this collaboration Zahner has produced a whitepaper that explains it succintly. Download [52.10 KB] .

title: 3D Printed Benches for IDS Crystal Court
content: Custom Benches Inspired by the shapes of stones on the shore of Lake Superior, the custom benches for the Crystal Court were designed as a cohesive part of the biophilic design concept. The benches needed to be large enough to define a protected seating zone in the new tree grove while meeting the weight constraints of the existing structured parking below.¬† Intended as an impactful element of the refreshed space, the benches were designed at three different heights for sitting, perching, and to provide armrests for those who need a higher surface to assist with mobility. Collaborative Team Developed in collaboration with a team of consultants and fabricators with expertise in industrial engineering and generative design, the benches were fabricated using a 3D printing technology not previously used in architectural and furniture applications.¬† The process of the printing was embraced in the layered texture of the bases. Profiles were designed based on ergonomic studies. One of the benefits of 3D printing was that all of the benches could be cohesive but completely unique in form, similar to stones on a lakeshore.¬† Due to the nature of production, there were no cost or schedule implications to having 20 unique shapes.¬† The Design Team team collaborated with graphic designer J√ºrg Lehni to automatically generate hundreds of potential forms from which the final plan shapes of the benches were selected. Industrial Engineer Jonathan Olivares co-designed the benches with Perkins&Will, assisting to interpret the Basis of Design and adapt it to the parameters of the 3D printing technology.¬† The team collaborated on several iterations of side profiles and details at material transitions. The Design Team collaborated with fabricator Dimensional Innovations, one of the only fabricators with access to a 3D printing technology normally used for aerospace prototyping.¬† Designs were fine-tuned in Rhino before being approved for final printing. Materiality The benches are made of durable through-color materials designed to withstand the use of a busy public space. The bases are printed using two main ingredients: a non-petroleum based PLA bio-polymer that was originally developed by a local company, and wood pulp shavings from sawmills for reinforcement. The material was formulated to be BPA-free and is considered biodegradable using industrial processes. The waste from the printing/milling process can be processed into recycled pellets and used for other purposes. The bench tops are made primarily from compressed FSC-certified or recycled paper and the product is LBC Red List approved and GREENGUARD certified. The seating zone defined by the new 3D printed benches contributes to the increased diversity of seating in the Crystal Court, providing a moment of respite in downtown Minneapolis, an opportunity for users to meet and interact, and a space that belongs to the greater public.

title: Evolving Technology in CCA ‚Äì Part 1
content: Introduction The last decade has seen a change in how projects are staffed, managed, and led. Through the use of file transfer protocol (‚ÄúFTP‚Äù) sites and cloud storage services, project teams are no longer tied to a single physical location. Today, it is more common to have a design team comprised of members from offices across multiple states working together on one project. This is especially true on projects of scale. The old but reliable way of communicating the construction progress was through field reports and digital photographs, transmitted via e-mail or posted to FTP sites. Some of the more sophisticated clients and contractors used webcams where anyone at any time could log on to check the status of construction. This later evolved into web-based platforms where daily logs, photographs, observations, and deficiencies could be uploaded and shared with anyone with internet access. The purpose of this document is to share some of the technologies and strategies used over a 6-year period during the Construction Contract Administration phase of the University of Virginia (UVA), University Hospital Expansion (UHE) project. It also includes some of the technological advances explored over the past 18-months of the pandemic. The Challenge The UVA UHE project included over 440,000 square feet of new construction and 90,000 square feet of renovation. The $268M project started in 2014 with the commencement of 7 enabling projects that made way for the new, 12-story patient tower. Fortunately, the owner requested full-time, on-site representation by the Design Team. At the commencement of the 6-year Construction Contract Administration (CCA) effort, the Perkins&Will DC Office Team set themselves the challenge of experimenting with the use of technology during CCA. Virtual Reality In 1957, Morton Heilig developed a multimedia device called the ‚ÄúSensorama‚Äù, which is considered to be one of the earliest Virtual Reality (VR) systems. The term ‚ÄúVirtual Reality‚Äù was however coined by the researcher, Jaron Lanier, in 19871. In 2010, the Oculus Rift prototype was developed, which marked the commencement of the most recent decade of VR improvements and advancements. During the Design Development and Construction Document phases of the project, Perkins&Will used the Oculus headset to facilitate self-guided tours of the new facility. The use of VR to facilitate tours of the project was so successful, we were requested to set up the device on-site for the end-users, students, and staff to tour the project. Via projector, bystanders had the opportunity to observe the user‚Äôs experience. This was later used as a means of facilitating virtual tours of the project, which worked for large groups and/or for those who would prefer not to use the headset themselves. This also proved to be a viable alternative for those who experience motion sickness. During one of the sessions, the mechanical subcontractor asked if they could use the headset to determine if there was enough clearance on the 9M level to lift an air handler from the penthouse floor to a mezzanine. This request became the impetus for us to find a way to use the VR headset to tour the Building Information Model (BIM) in 3D. ‚ÄúThis comes at a great time. Our staff is exhausted and this will excite them in a different way.‚Äù ‚Äî Sharon Hardigree, UVA ED Nurse Manager, on the use of Virtual Reality Revizto Through trial and error, Perkins&Will tested various applications and file formats to find a way to tour the BIM using a VR Headset. In the end, Revizto‚Äôs ‚ÄúVR immersive, collaboration anywhere‚Äù application ended up being the best solution. Since the subcontractors‚Äô models were in different applications, file types, and formats, the Construction Manager, Skanska, used Autodesk‚Äôs Navisworks software to assemble the various models in one platform. Revizto‚Äôs software permitted us to import the Naviswork model and tour it using the Oculus headset. As a bonus, one could also tour the model using an Xbox controller. This dramatically improved the ability to tour the model when compared to mouse and keystroke. Accessing the BIM via VR opened many new opportunities for sharing the in-progress construction. It permitted us to: 1. Facilitate tours of the mechanical spaces by the facilities group prior to the completion of the project. 2. Resolve the end-users concern relative to the visibility into each of the exam rooms from a seated position at the nurse stations. 3. Confirm accessibility of above ceiling valves, junction boxes, panels, and equipment through access panels. 4. Resolve one surgeon‚Äôs concern that the specialty rooms were large enough to perform procedures. 5. Facilitate tours of the new Emergency Department by the staff and users who would ultimately occupy the space. Each of the above was completed without having to wear Personal Protection Equipment (PPE) or going through site-specific safety training. In several instances, it also saved the Team countless hours of trying to address concerns from the staff and users via meetings, drawing mark-ups, and site tours. ‚ÄúIncorporating VR as core to the design and development process in a Big Room environment has allowed our physicians, staff and my team to take virtual walks through the proposed design. This technology has not only equipped the team to better visualize what is being built, but has improved participation and communication bringing collaborative project delivery.‚Äù ‚Äî Josh Bullock, Facilities Planner UVA Facilities Planning Capital & Development QR Codes QR code is an initialism for Quick Response code. It was originally developed in 1994 by the Japanese automotive company, Denso Wave, as a machine-readable optical label that contains information about the item to which it is attached to. In 2002, the use of QR codes became widespread in Japan due to mobile phone companies marketing the inclusion of a QR Reader3. On the UHE project, we looked for interesting ways to include QR codes in the plans as well as the built environment. Some examples include: 1. Inclusion of QR codes on floor plans linked to the interactive renderings of the space. 2. Inserted into sketches of a patient lift study to illustrate via interactive design models how an alternate lift system would impact the overall design. 3. Placed on project information boards throughout the construction site with QR codes to the project blog, webcams and interactive renderings. Note that the location of the viewer in the interactive model was based on the location of the sign, thereby allowing the viewer to compare the interactive design model against the in-progress construction.

title: CCA Modernization & Newforma sunset Updates
content: We wanted to update you as we continue our CCA Modernization strategic initiative. As you may recall, our goal is to reduce the repetitive administrative work involved with the CCA process, which includes ‚Äúsunsetting‚Äù the Newforma application. We initiated the plan last July with the intent to be completed by June of this year; we are now roughly halfway. During this time, many town hall-style meetings and in-depth training & planning sessions have taken place across the firm. As of last week, there were about 300 Perkins&Will team members who had engaged with the Newforma application during January, we anticipated reaching 300 active users by the end of February, so thank you to everyone for helping to manage this transition. Most tasks in January were CCA functions; however, we still have non-CCA tasks occurring, which need to be discontinued. Also, in January, we amended our agreement with Newforma, which has created an unforeseen issue and thankfully only affected two new hires and two consultants. We have a small window of time to recalibrate our licensing requirements to counter this issue during February. We are in the process of reviewing, finalizing, and reporting the remaining number of projects using the Newforma platform in our North American studios.¬† We are also collecting a list of the Perkins&Will employees [by name or planned resource] with CCA tasks on those projects in each studio. Any projects that will continue with CCA construction activities should be transitioning or working with your local team to plan and execute a transition to the new tools and processes.¬†¬† Any project that completes all construction activities by June of 2022 should be listed and complete their tasks as they have been. Please check out our Quickstart guide for more information or reach out to someone on our CCA Modernization MS Teams channel .

title: New microKnowledge site!
content: Starting February 8th, Digital Practice‚Äôs new microKnowledge website will deliver improved searching and filtering. Not only that, it‚Äôs a refreshed user interface with a modern user app experience! And we will proudly be launching it on Perkins&Will‚Äôs own Hub365 alongside our other familiar tools‚Ä¶ microKnowledge or ‚ÄúmK cards‚Äù are visual, screen-sized answers to your design technology challenges. microKnowledge is a living website where content continually grows and evolves ‚Äì with your help. Using an mK card template, anyone can create and share their expertise in the same easily-digestible format. To contribute, simply download the mK Card Template and add to our library! Tip: try out the new mK site‚Äôs bookmark and feedback features! Please send feedback to any of the mK team members below‚Ä¶

title: Design I Equity I Data

author.name: Nick Cameron
author.description: American trucker who has been featured on the History channel reality television series Ice Road Truckers and its spinoff series IRT: Deadliest Roads.

content: As the new 2022 AIA Technology in Architectural Practice [TAP] chair, I was tasked with preparing the annual conference. This year the focus will not be on the design tools used across firms but how we as designers can take advantage of the Data available to us and ensure we are using it in a responsible way. This virtual conference will be held of three days, starting right after Martin Luther King Day on January 18th at noon easter. The first day will be a Keynote presentation by Vernelle A.A. Noel , followed on Wednesday with a panel discussion, featuring Perkin&Will‚Äôs own Gautam Sondaram. And finishing up on Thursday with an interactive workshop, leveraging digital tools to engage the communities we design in. Registration will be available soon on the AIA national site, click here if you would like to be notified. Read on for the full brief. Architectural practice is undergoing a digital transformation while at the same time, our built environment needs to become more resilient and equitable. Technology and data will be integral to these efforts, unleashing the ability to analyze the current state and simulate the future using new human-centric measures, essentially expanding the concept of ‚Äúsite analysis‚Äù.¬† Design outcomes will be based on health, diversity, accessibility, walkability, sustainability, and other measures to effectively develop better communities. As powerful as these new tools will be, we must recognize that the underlying data can be flawed and may reinforce stereotypes or exacerbate problems like racial bias. How will we as architects train ourselves in data literacy so we do not misuse [intentionally or not] data in our work? What data is available to you and your community now, and how can you leverage it in your next project? What tools can your practice use to interact and engage within the communities you are designing, so you can hear from everyone? Join us to explore these and other questions over three days in January at the virtual AIA TAP Building Connections Congress. Tuesday January 18th to Thursday January 20th @ noon eastern

title: Design and Delivery December ‚Äì Design Tools Synergy
content: Link to recording December Design and Delivery call was a real holiday treat. Our designers shared the projects where synergy of Rhino, Grasshopper¬† and Revit empowered project teams in solving design challenges. Presenters: New York Studio¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† Sao Paulo Studio Yuan Su Jordan Hanson Kun Chen Mattheus Lucchi Lincoln Jyo NYO team presented two projects where they used Rhino in synergy with Revit. These are two different projects for the same client: Connecticut Orthopedic Institute. Yuan Su shared Patient waiting room project and her experience of using Rhino and Revit from beginning of the project to project completion. The presentation demonstrated¬† how team utilized the two software tools to build the model, document the design, and assist in fabrication. Jordan Hanson and Kun Chen demonstrated use of Grasshopper and Rhino to design an organic canopy that moved throughout the project responding to different elements and conditions. This team pioneered Rhino with Grasshopper¬† and Revit in 2017 blazing the trail for other projects. Lincoln Jyo and Mattheus Lucchi from Brazilian Digital Practice Team presented Te√ßainda project where parametric facade was developed in Grasshopper. The fa√ßade consists of a series of panels that gradually angulate according to the building levels. The software allowed the designers to comprehend the relation between the visual impact of the building and its feasibility. This project is in the early design phase, and a first Grasshopper use in Brasilian office, however it promises to be a beauty!

title: CCA Modernization Effort Update
content: Earlier this year we began an effort to move all of the construction contract administration to modern tools and processes that take advantage of software automation so our designers can focus on the value add of an architect‚Äôs knowledge during the construction process. This month we are in the process of getting a full evaluation of all projects using Newforma in the construction phase and their timetable to either: complete construction in the next few months; or transition their work to other tools and processes. We are also identifying projects still in design stages and archiving all those Newforma projects to a read-only state. Instead of using Newforma, all projects across the firm should be using SharePoint and BIM360 to exchange files with the external project team members and filing emails in project-specific folders in Outlook. We are working with larger, long-term projects right now to set up their transition plan and new workflows outside of Newforma. We are also in the process of creating step-by-step process maps to help teams understand what to do and where to file information when we receive RFIs and submittals. If you have any specific questions please reach out to your Digital Practice team member or Technical Director for more specific directions. Also, refer to our CCA Quickstart guide for those items we have already covered extensively through various forums.

title: Rise & Spline
content: Rise & Spline What architects need to know is so much greater now than it ever was, even a decade ago. Not only do you need to know the science of architecture, but you now need to know, modeling, viz, computational design, the demands are huge. Rise & Spline is part of a process which is aimed towards elevating overall competency which in turn elevates opportunity & growth. It consists of 37 sessions of 30 ‚Äì minute modules, which covers fundamentals of Rhino, basic Rhino features & tools, and intermediate level of Rhino 3D modelling. Where can you find Rise & Spline Modules? Digital Practice Website: https://digitalpractice.perkinswill.com/quickstarts/rhino-quickstart/

title: Sao Paulo 2021 Education Recap
content: Throughout the year we faced various challenges related to sharing new knowledge and information due to the need to keep part of the team working from home. It required a new perspective of how to encourage people to watch and participate in our L&D talks. Surprisingly the response was very positive. The attendance rate was high and we were able to discuss doubts and tips from people who could add-in on the ruled topics. We aimed to level up our team‚Äôs abilities regarding tools and processes on different software. Our first training main focus was Rhino and it occurred in March. It was given by Luc and Mario and gave a good perspective of how to introduce it in our daily practices. Later in August our Digital Practice intern, Mattheus Lucchi, gave a four-session training directed to Sketchup users aiming to influence a change of software by presenting the main tools and modeling tips on Rhino. The following presentation was given by the Design Application Manager, Lincoln Jyo. The sessions introduced the BIM Manual to the team, which encourages standard practices on Revit, aiming for more efficient practice of the software and office organization. For two weeks in October, short pills of knowledge about the Quality Assurance Program were shared by Renato Siqueira. Every morning, for 10 minutes, technical information and processes were reviewed. In early November, Enscape 3.1.2 training was given by Lucas Davariz. In three sessions of half an hour, the staff could learn about the newest interface, as all main functionalities of the version. Weekly in November, two-hour sessions with 80% attendance of the staff, the Digital Application Management Continuous Education discussed relevant Revit topics, from basics to advanced, like workflows and QA standards. Sao Paulo Education Recap BIM Manual L&D Attendance Enscape Basics Rhino for Sketchup users BIM Manual L&D Quality Program Rhino Training Rhino for sketchup users Enscape Previous Previous Previous Next Next Next 1 2 3 4 5 6 7 8 9

title: NYO New Hire Onboarding Training
content: The Good News: Our NY Studio proved to be so busy, it justified the acquisition of a dozen new talented designers to come aboard and help on the various projects that needed support. We were fortunate enough to find the ideal crazy cats that fit our design appetite skillset! The Challenge: Lessons learned suggested we need these new team members to have a baseline of knowledge that complemented the bulk of the work produced on a typical project. This baseline knowledge was curated and vetted by our very own studio. The resulting syllabus was a result of those truly in the weeds and aware of the consequences when staff are ignorant to the challenges faced if these items were not taken seriously. To be clear, the goal of the training wasn‚Äôt to make these new hires especially proficient in Revit. The goal was to create a mini project that would only have them encounter the foundational pitfalls of bad ideas, when working in a team, using Revit. Proposed Solution: Spreading training sessions out (for a handful of reasons), we cover topics in a few ways. Constantly reflecting on what we should know and reviewing what we are about to learn. I speak to that sessions theme and relevance to the industry. I expand the theme and review the topics specific to each. Most topics have a description of why it has value. I do a live demo on functionality. We resource a customized exercise that everyone acts on during the session together. At the end of each session, homework is issued further complimenting the topics addressed and occasionally pushing the staff to figure things out to ensure they can troubleshoot. Each of the efforts end with querying the group as to whether there any questions or challenges. Furthermore, confirming we can move on, as the topic was ideally absorbed. Resource our summarized agenda below‚Ä¶ Moving Forward: Those that attend the training are asked to complete a spreadsheet specific to their understanding of each topic and holding them accountable to having put the effort into learning. See image below‚Ä¶

title: Enscape Custom Assets
content: Installation Instructions below The second half of 2021 has been busy for the Enscape Custom Assets team, and we have officially rolled out the Firmwide Enscape Custom Asset Library! This library is an expansion of the current Enscape asset library with custom, curated assets from some of us passionate 3D Perkins&Will folks. At the time of writing, we have 361 assets available to you with more coming every week. Recently added assets can be visually identified by the ‚ÄúNew‚Äù tag. The primary focus runs in parallel with our J.E.D.I. efforts by providing more diverse 3D human entourage for use in our design studies and interior renderings. Greater diversity is reflected in some of the following ways: ethnicity, cultural dress, mobility, activity, clothing style, age, etc. Secondary to this, assets may be brought in on a case by case basis where appropriate. An example of this may be a special piece of medical equipment, a police station squad car, specific furniture, etc. The PW Custom Asset Library‚Ä¶ Is optimized for use in Enscape and will continue to expand as needed. Works in all Enscape supported programs (Revit, Rhino, Sketchup, etc.) Supports work-shared models, meaning any team member with the custom asset library setup will be able to load Enscape and see the same models that you added from the library. You can search keywords in the library such as ‚Äúhealthcare‚Äù, ‚Äúsitting‚Äù, or ‚Äúcoffee‚Äù. We can always get more/specific assets as needed and if you have a special need on a project lets talk and see if its a fit for the asset library to share with the firm or a use case for that project alone. Installation instructions: Detailed instructions: Steps: Double check that Enscape is updated to the latest Perkins&Will supported version. If you are unsure ask myself or another DA to help check this. 1. Open any program that has Enscape installed and on the Enscape toolbar click the Asset Library Icon 2. In the Enscape Asset Library Dialogue window click on the ‚ÄúCustom Assets‚Äù tab. 3. Navigate to the bottom right corner and click the folder icon 4. Copy and paste the following network path into the dialogue prompt: S:\_Firmwide\Content\Enscape 5. Assets may begin loading at this time or may take a few minutes to finish loading if you are working on a remote connection outside of the office. 6. If no assets begin loading, close out of the program, the entire program, not just Enscape. So, if in Revit close out and restart Revit. 7. The library is now installed and next time you open the ‚ÄúEnscape Asset Library‚Äù from the Enscape toolbar it may take a few minutes to load the assets in but this only needs to be done once per program opening. Meaning you shouldn‚Äôt have to wait unless you close and reopen Revit (or whichever program you are using) 8. Place assets as needed and enjoy! Tip: try out the search feature! (At this time Enscape does not support Category Tags or searchable tags meaning any searched word will only work if the the title of the asset contains said word, this will likely change for the better in the near future.) Please send any feedback to the Enscape Custom Assets team on Hub365.

title: re-ADAPT

author.name: Nick Cameron
author.description: American trucker who has been featured on the History channel reality television series Ice Road Truckers and its spinoff series IRT: Deadliest Roads.

content: During the Halloween weekend a team from SHL, including Victor Wanderley Barbosa, Daniel Boba, Ellen Berglund and Zuzanna Czapla had joined AEC Hackathon in BLOXHUB Copenhagen. We collaborated with folks form HD Lab, Henning Larsen Architects and Velux on the #reADAPT project. We had 48 hours to solve the industry problem and decided to focus on reusability of building components and waste reduction during demolition. The reADAPT team won the competition for Best Overall Project! We explored the possibility of creating a database of recycled building components from a building that is to be demolished. Using a point cloud technology and parametric design process with Rhino Inside Revit we explored ways of fitting recycled components into an architect‚Äôs new design model and representing the changes in an IFC.js powered web viewer, making it easier for architects to design with recycled components! Recording to reADAPT presentation: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6oYAtC0v0uA&t=1290s Webviewer: https://readapt-a2656.web.app/ Github repository: https://lnkd.in/e4254eDf

title: VizR October eXchange ‚Äì Integrating Rhino and Revit for Design and Documentation
content: This month‚Äôs VizR topic is about integrating Rhino and Revit for Design and Documentation. Our first speaker is Yuan Su from our New York studio. Yuan shared two projects as case studies where design elements needed to be exported into Rhino then integrated back to Revit for documentation. Mario Romero also shared a useful tip on how to maintain the rendering assets for Enscape from Rhino to Revit to streamline model exchange between Rhino and Revit. The first project Yuan shared was a clinic‚Äôs waiting area with an organically curved partition. To optimize the curved partition for code compliance and fabrication control, the partition was exported into Rhino to be rebuilt using Grasshopper. To meet the ADA protrusion requirement for the visually impaired, she added three critical control lines, one at the base, one at 27‚Ä≥ and another one at 80‚Ä≥. Using these three curved lines, the final double curved wall was generated computationally. The script also offsets the outline and creates the wooden slats at the intervals needed, and the finished model is then transferred back into Revit using the Proving Ground‚Äôs Rhino Conveyor Tool. Once in Revit, the Curved partition was converted into a Generic Model family, where each sub-element can be mapped to a different material for rendering purposes. The 3D model was then used as part of the documentation, and the Rhino file was used by the fabricator for fabrication. By using the 3D model file, it saved the team from creating hundreds of details documenting the radius and dimension of each component. Instead, our team focused the documentation on design intent and the placement of the finished product. The finished installation came out to be exactly as we had designed and envisioned in our rendering, such that you could hardly tell the difference between our rendering and photographs of the actual built space. The second case study was an external staircase enclosure, due to the complexity of the design shape, the team needed to use Rhino and Grasshopper to recreate the model and generate the structural framing element of the cone shape for the contractors. By locating the framing element‚Äôs spot elevation and giving the fabricator the grasshopper file, the process of documentation was drastically simplified without sacrificing any design control or accuracy. Lastly, Mario Romero shared useful tips on a quick hack to recreate in Revit any Enscape asset blocks. Using his custom grasshopper script and Rhino Inside tool, he was able to help several teams recreate the Enscape assets in Revit¬† for Enscape visualization For more details, click here to watch the recording. Note: Starting October 2021, all VizR eXchange session has been moved to our PWU ‚Äì Perkins and Will University Channel.

title: Rhino 7.9 ‚Äì Available Soon in Software Center
content: Rhino 7.9 ‚Äì Available Soon in Software Center This month we‚Äôll release Rhino 7.9 on Software Center. This update will bring a host of new features as well as a unified layer standard and rhino template files. New Perkins&Will Template and Layer Standards With this new version we‚Äôve pushed brand new templates that should help to get you off and running quicker than ever. This includes Layout titleblocks! We‚Äôve also standardized a Perkins and Will Layer structure: New Rhino Package Manager! Alongside this new update, we‚Äôve also implemented our own Rhino Package manager repository. From here on out you can use the PackageManager command to gain access to all of the computational tools and workflows that you‚Äôve seen presented and utilized right at your fingertips! Finally, Rhino.Inside Will be Available in Software Center You‚Äôll finally be able to install Rhino.Inside yourself via software center. Rhino.Inside allows for a near seamless rhino to revit experience. Visit the Computational Design page to get started with our rhino.inside workflows.

title: VizR September eXchange ‚Äì Arkio Virtual Collaboration Platform
content: For the September VizR eXchange,¬† Hilmar and Johan presented Arkio in a live virtual demo. Arkio is a virtual collaboration platform where designers can meet with their project team and clients to explore and design in the same space at the same time using multiple devices and platforms. As explained by Hilmar, design firms have used Arkio for design meetings, client presentations, and coordination meetings for Architectural, interior, landscape, masterplan, stage design, and game design projects. In addition to gathering and exploring with a project team in a virtual 3D space, Arkio offers designers the ability to create and add new 3D objects into the existing space using dimensional accuracy, metadata tagging, and geographical location positioning. Everyone with editing permission can participate in creating and editing solid objects in the 3D space, making it easier for participants to engage in the design process where changes can happen in real-time. In VR mode, Arkio was designed with VR users in mind, making it very natural and easy for designers to create and change their designs in 3D with minimal training. However, users without VR headsets can just as easily engage in the virtual design and editing experience using their laptop or even an iPad. The most significant improvement is the ability to import and export to Revit and Rhino models, making Arkio a viable design collaboration and exploration tool that integrates nicely into our standard design workflow. For more details, please watch the recording below.
