title: Revit and Autodesk 2022 availability
content: It is fall and as leaves change colors and temperatures get cooler we move forward with the annual release of the newest Autodesk products to stay current with the newest features and security to advance our design work.¬† The Digital Practice team has looked at and testing Revit 2022 and is making that available for all new projects, to begin with from the firmwide or your studio‚Äôs template. You will see it available in software center to self-install. It is a large application to install and most of you will be installing it from home so I would suggest running it at the end of the day to allow for a few hours for the download time (which may vary based on your home internet speeds) and the installation. In addition to Revit 2022 being available all other typically used Autodesk applications 2022 versions will be made available in software center. 3ds Studio Max, Navisworks, ReCap, AutoCAD LT, AutoCAD, and Vehicle Tracker can be self-installed and utilized.¬† ¬†All addins will be installed by you from software center on an as-needed basis so you don‚Äôt have any more or less than necessary.¬† ¬†You can find those that are associated with Revit 2022 through a filter in the software center interface at the top of the list of available applications. Each team should begin making plans accounting for their project schedule and external partners to find a time to upgrade. Fortunately, in BIM360 it is literally the click of a button. More importantly, is that all models for your project will need to be upgraded at the same time to continue to allow everyone functionality of linking to all necessary information from each model. All new projects should strategize to begin from the start in Revit 2022. Revit 2022 New Features This year the Autodesk development team put a big focus on making improvements to the functions and features of our primary documentation tool.¬† ¬†You can step through this deck to see which features our team thinks are the most likely to be used by your team and then the rest of the new features that a smaller number of people will find value in utilizing. Here is a link to the entire list Autodesk has provided, which may show you where our consultants might see value in upgrading. This is an embedded Microsoft Office presentation, powered by Office .

title: AEC Tech Hackathon
tags: hackathon recap article computation design software develop aec ttcore thornton tomasetti
content: AEC Tech Hackathon Recap September 2021 A recent event held by Thornton Tomasetti CORE Studio saw people from all over the world virtually gather, form into teams and hack on innovative AEC technology solutions over a weekend in July. Hackathon judge and Digital Practice lead at the Copenhagen office Ryan Hughes recaps the event, highlighting some of the best tech and projects on show. Highlights Best Overall Hack: Spatial Scheduler A maintenance scheduling app that helps to create Augmented Reality (AR) enabled spatial persistent notes on locations in the real world. Taking home the overall win, the Spatial Scheduler team made use of a nice little package called Placenote (in the above video) to leave persistent AR notes in the real world ‚Äì meaning that using a simple AR-enabled device, one user could leave a 3D tag on an element in, for example, a building site, sync it up to a drawing set, and let someone else come along and find it in the future. This could be useful during construction or post-occupancy maintanence, for example. While they hadn‚Äôt developed much in terms of core technology, the robustness, quality of presentation and potential for applications snagged them the win. Team: Elcin Ertugrul, CORE Studio ‚Äì Amit Nambiar, CORE Studio ‚Äì Adam Chernick, SHop Architects ‚Äì Rolanda Villena, Thornton Tomasetti / Ezgi Sendil, Graduate Student Best Open-Source Hack: Bonobo A Grasshopper bridge for Blender simulations. Working on a completely open-source code base, the Bobobo team impressed the jury by building a realtime link to Blender, enabling the use of advanced features like particle simulations, mesh modelling tools, all of the cool features of a community-based subdivision-based modelling suite. Given the increasing maturity of Blender BIM tools, this could be an interesting project to develop on or watch, allowing a potentially well-featured BIM workflow beyond Rhino and back. Team: Sergey Pigach, CORE Studio ‚Äì Omid Farshadfar, CORE Studio ‚Äì Congzheng Zou, BIMtech ‚Äì Ardeshir Aliaskari, Freelancer ‚Äì Sahil Tadwalkar, Insite VR Ryan‚Äôs Choice: Hackuble A generative 3D modeling environment built to write and execute C# code in the browser. Falling just short of an actual award, and receiving something much less glorious instead ‚Äì the status of my favourite project of the weekend, the Hackuble team made use of a really exciting technology called Blazor. It‚Äôs been around for a while. Based on ASP.NET, Blazor allows you to import, write, compile and run C# assemblies and code in an otherwise web / Javascript-based environment. This means that effort put into .NET libraries for Revit or Rhino could be reused by web-native applications such as Compute. Team: Emil Poulsen, CORE Studio ‚Äì Hanshen Sun, CORE Studio ‚Äì Praneet Mathur, ARPM Design and Research ‚Äì Yankun Yang, iBuilt Group ‚Äì Yushi Kato, Turner & Townsend Notable Project: Recenseo A PDF Markup tool dedicated to Rhino that allows a list of PDF drawing markups to be directly referenced into a 3D Rhino model. Arguably the simplest yet most immediately useful project was Recenseo ‚Äì a tool developed by a team from CORE Studio and Structure Craft for marking up and directly referencing PDF drawings into Rhino. Team: Nick Mundell, CORE Studio ‚Äì Amit Nambiar, CORE Studio ‚Äì Mark Skepasts, Structure Craft ‚Äì Johan Reissmuller, Structure Craft ‚Äì Lukas Fuhrimann, Structure Craft ‚Äì Sahar Barzani, Structure Craft Judges Nicholas Desbiens, KPF Andy Watts, Grimshaw Martha Tsigkari, Foster & Partners Pablo Zamorano, Heatherwick Ryan Hughes, Schmidt Hammer Lassen Robert Yori, EnTech Engineering PC Workshops The event kicked off with two days of workshops on Thursday, July 8th, and Friday, July 9th. Recording of the workshops can be found on their YouTube channel . Attendees had the opportunity to take part in, amongst others, the following workshops: Interop Cubed | Grimshaw Architects The workshop will focus on interoperability and data visualization among AEC platforms. Leveraging the power of Rhino.Inside and Unity Reflect, participants will get the opportunity to learn how to query, modify and analyze Revit elements in Rhino using Grasshopper and explore potential ways of transferring, communicating, and visualizing environmental analysis data of their designs in an immersive Unity enabled VR environment. Rhino.Compute API | KPF The studio-based culture of design offices gives designers the freedom to approach design problems in a variety of ways. The challenge of solving these complex problems has led to an increase in specialist groups within the office, specifically experts in computation, urban analytics, and environmental performance, who are working alongside several project teams at once to improve workflows and design outcomes. Recent efforts to centralize computational tools through workflows such as Rhino.Compute and hops look to increase the number of projects that benefit from specialist knowledge, while at the same time increasing the impact of solutions developed within the context of a specific project. Using Rhino.Compute as a back-end solver for Grasshopper definitions, design studios can centralize and version control definitions while offloading heavy workloads onto remote hardware and providing end-users with a UI/UX set in their existing workflows. This workshop will review how to link a Python Script running in Jupyter Notebook to a Rhino Compute Windows Server to facilitate quick analysis and heavy computational workflows better. Rhino and BIM Interoperability | MKS BEAM BEAM extends the current Rhino and BIM interoperability workflow providing easy-to-use apps to organize data and geometry directly in Rhino, managing and simplifying the transfer to Revit or IFC. During the workshop participants will learn how to: Create Families with Parameters and manage BIM data in Rhino. Importing a Family in Revit, Advanced Revit workflows with Rhino Blocks and Adaptive Components. Automation with visual programming with BEAM for Grasshopper and BEAM for Dynamo. Workflows from Revit To Rhino. Rhino IFC data and export. Symposium On Monday, July 12 the event finished strong with a series of presentations by industry innovators in Architecture, Engineering, and Software development. Each presenter showcased how advances in technology and work culture are shifting the way projects are designed, developed, and delivered and spoke about the future trends in the industry they see emerging. You can find presentation descriptions below and watch the event at their YouTube channel . Grimshaw | Shifting Focus: Design Technology at Grimshaw Andy Watts, Director of Design Technology / Georgios Tsakiridis, London Computational Design Manager ShapeDiver | New Collaboration Workflows Based on Remote Parametric Algorithms Mathieu Huard | Head of Product & Co-Founder KPF | Distributed Design Intelligence: Broadening the Impact of Specialist Knowledge Cobus Bothma, Director / Luc Wilson, Director / Nicholas Desbiens, Head of Digital Practice McNeel | Peeking over the Horizon Scott Davidson, Business Development / Luis Fraguada, McNeel Thornton Tomasetti | Custom Toolkit Development for a Complex Fa√ßade EOR Project Alloy Kemp, Senior Associate / Viktoria Henriksson, Project Engineer Virtual Social Spaces As I am sure any of you who have previously attended a hackathon will attest to, the social takeaways of a weekend are some of the most valuable. Whether it‚Äôs discussions about projects and tech, networking, or just to have someone to work late into the night with, the common spaces are some of the most active of the event. This particular hackathon, given its virtual nature, presented quite a logistical challenge in providing this aspect to the participants, but the team at Thornton Tomasetti found a novel solution ‚Äì to provide exactly this sort of space online through the use of SpatialChat. Links TT Core Studio Recap: https://www.aectech.us/blog/aectech-2021-uk-carry-on Announcement link: https://blog.rhino3d.com/2021/07/aectech-summer-2021-virtual-event-july.html Archive of past hackathons: https://www.aectech.us/hackathon-archive

title: VizR July eXchange ‚Äì Leveraging Real Data for Realtime Visualization
content: Leveraging Real Data for Realtime Visualization Presented by Michael Vollrath Visualization tools such as Unreal are often disconnected from the real world and require manual configuration to set up a simulation based on real-world data. Michael Vollrath set out to build a simple tool to simplify data connection between virtual and the real world and enabling easy access to the real-world data to drive virtual world simulation. The first example is a widget that retrieves real world data by simply entering an address, pulling weather and daylighting data from an open source web API, Once the data is retrieved, one can use it to drive the rendering environment, to create the exact weather, day lighting, and sun location. Further expanding the capabilities of creating interactive experience, Michael demonstrated how one can embed custom interaction with elements within a 3D space, like adding an operable light switch, trigger short animation to demonstrate a folding table etc. All these interactivity can enhance our virtual experience within the 3D space. Other gadgets can be created to perform view point analysis for a building, and using section views to create simple 2D or 3d plan that clearly shows different views visibility through windows. For more details, watch the meeting recording below.

title: Partition Chooser, Charts and Revit families update
content: After several months of work by the TDC and Digital Practice, we have updated our partition families and partition type charts in Revit and have also revamped the Partition Type Chooser. Partition Family/Chart Updates: Updated Sound Transmission Class (STC) information ‚Äì only validated STC ratings are included in the charts, all others have been deleted Minor updates to graphics and notes in the partition type charts New high-acoustic-performance partition types U and V Revised partition type X and new partition type Y to make room for U and V above Partition families structure are updated in HIVE and in firmwide and office templates for Revit 2021 and 2022. The names are updated to not contain the description. Partition Type Chooser Updates: Greatly expanded Introduction and Instructions, including important information regarding STC ratings ( Please Read It! it explains how you should select partitions for your project!) Addition of MIL and Inch thicknesses (alongside gauge) in the Limiting Height Charts Addition of STC Options charts for most partitions, explaining options that increase and decrease the partition STC ratings Manufacturer source information for Limiting Height Charts and STC Options are included at the end New partitions and partition type charts are available NOW in HIVE for Revit 2020, 2021 and the forthcoming 2022. The Partition Type Chooser is on Teams here: Partition Type Chooser-2021.pdf Here are a few other resources: MK card explaining how to update the partitions on your project if it was started before the current release: mK-Rvt-HIVE- How to update your project with new partition charts and partitions.pptx Introductory presentation given to the Technical Directors: 2021 Partition Type Update.pptx There are subfolders including the source files for the Limiting Height and STC information in here: LINK We will be talking more about it and answering questions on a firmwide DD call on Thursday September 9th at noon EST

title: Data and Equity Panel Discussion ‚Äì Digital Practice Core eXchange
content: Our Quarterly Core eXchange brought a new format in sharing of knowledge through a panel discussion focused on data and the biased and unbiased use of it to help solve design problems. The term ‚Äúdata equity‚Äù captures a complex and multi-faceted set of ideas. It refers to the consideration, through an equity lens, of the ways in which data is collected, analyzed, interpreted, and distributed. It underscores marginalized communities‚Äô unequal opportunities to access data and, at times, their harm from data‚Äôs misuse. It raises the issue of data sovereignty and the democratization of data.¬† Data equity pushes us to consider the ways that data can reinforce stereotypes, exacerbate problems like racial bias, or otherwise undermine social justice. This panel got together and talked about how can we use data to represent every group in our society.¬† ¬†What we should look for to question our data and find out how or if it might be biased in any way.¬† ¬†Take a look at the recording if you were unable to catch it live and engage in this conversation that will continue to impact the design profession in more significant ways in the future. ‚ÄúMost data sets are biased.¬† ¬†Everyone has their own preconceived notions‚Ä¶‚Ä¶‚Ä¶.Teams working on these data models need to be more diverse in order to see things others on the team might not see.‚Äù¬† ‚Äì Serra Uzun ‚Äúlooking at the data by the numbers and come up with these bold statements that we feel are going to be transformational for our clients‚Ä¶‚Ä¶..how does this [data] impact our practice‚Äù ‚Äì Gautam Sundaram [We need people that are] ‚Äúbecoming more literate at taking large data sets and doing something with them, making sense of them.‚Äù¬† ‚Äì Jason Diamond ‚ÄúAsk yourself ‚Äòwhat might my biases be?‚Äô when looking at your data‚Äù ‚Äì Brad Rogers

title: Design and Delivery July Project Showcase
content: Design Presentation: PUBLICIS MEDIA 2TVC_LONDON Link to video recording Linzi Cassels and Andrew Guerin from London team presented one of their recent fit-out projects for a Media client that was bringing 7 of their agencies together under one roof. The client set an ambitious programme for the design team to deliver the 7 floors in just 9 months By adapting their typical approach to the design and delivery of a project, the design team succeeded in moving in the client‚Äôs 2,500 staff into the project on programme and on budget. The client was in a ‚Äúmad panic‚Äù¬† to move to the building they have selected, and the team took creative approach and used cutting edge digital tools to make it possible. The project was started in 2018, when new design tools like virtual reality became readily available, and the team took full advantage of them in their design process and communication with client which turned out to be critical in speeding up the sign off process. Building programming The team took blank canvas approach and incorporated brand design for each of seven brands in arrival areas and key areas on the floor Typical for each brand floor : Individual band design: arrival area and screens on the floor Typical joinery, different finishes. title: Sao Paulo BIM Manual Recap
content: In order to share baseline knowledge of our BIM and Revit guidelines, the Sao Paulo digital practice team created knowledge pills concerning the BIM manual for the Brazilian studio‚Äôs team. The content was divided into 10 sessions listed below each lasting 10 minutes spread throughout a few weeks in July. The goal is to keep the knowledge updated and fresh to the whole office, including best practices and common mistakes, avoiding the snowball effect on our projects. Online sessions, short length, as visual as possible, are meant to be quick, easy, and not boring. The sessions were recorded, allowing all staff to re-watch them and for those who couldn‚Äôt participate, surveys were made for each session to register attendance.

title: The Software Games: Present This!
content: The Software Games: Present This (commercial) Oh boy‚Ä¶ We might just have hosted the most glorious Software Games yet! We saw the ‚Äúremote worker‚Äù as an opportunity, not a challenge. So, hold on tight, I am compelled to want to get into the weeds on this one. This past year has triggered Digital Practice to rethink engagement. Whether communicating internally or externally, how do we successfully engage?!? #ZoomFatigue Of all the tools and workflows showcased over the year, the design technology leaders in Perkins&Will‚Äôs northeast region settled on OBS, MIRO and Spatial Composer to be the real potential game changers. Each tools having varying levels of adoption in the local studios, we decided a solid way to promote their existences and purposes would be via‚Ä¶ That‚Äôs right, another installment of The Software Games. This one would be titled ‚ÄúPresent This!‚Äù Let‚Äôs address the obvious challenge of a cross studio software games event‚Ä¶ As mentioned initially, it was this challenge that became the foundation for this event. We used OBS to replace everyone‚Äôs webcam with their display. The result, instead of seeing the 6 faces of that rounds competitors, we saw 6 live feeds of their desktops. As they cycled from one website to the next or toggled onto their desktop to launch photoshop, the audience was able to see all this live (refer to images below). ‚ÄúWorking together as a team was the best part about the competition, but the Miro-to-Spatial Composer workflow was extremely innovative and easy to follow. using such interactive platforms felt like opening a door to a new world of storytelling and presentations‚Äù Onyi Egbochue OBS has been used by the firm as a method to engage our clients differently. Whether interacting with one‚Äôs shared screen or showcasing multiple webcams and a PowerPoint in custom layout such that it compliments a presentation, OBS has proven to remove all limitations. Often intimidated by a completely new application, we asked those staff members wishing to play to merely install the application and load in a template that allowed them to share their display versus their webcam. A small, but delightful, step in the right direction. The rest of the event was almost butter in comparison. MIRO has arguably dominated the firm as a method of storyboarding. Vetted by Digital Practice, we believe this platform has the most pros over cons when it comes to online collaborating. How to define MIROs value‚Ä¶ Oversimplified, I would say it‚Äôs Pinterest meets Mindmapping meets Slack/Teams meets virtual pull planning meets‚Ä¶ I don‚Äôt know‚Ä¶ other helpful apps. It‚Äôs all online and can be accessed by anyone (without a membership). The only element MIRO lacks when it comes to communication, is a polished method of showcasing the result. Welcome Spatial Composer. Unlike OBS and MIRO, this tool is specific to Perkins&Will. That‚Äôs right, it was developed in house by our i/o team. No better way to stand out then with our own in-house custom presentation tool. Tailored to our own internal needs/demands, our i/o group built this online platform. Cate for an oversimplified overview of the tool? You got it‚Ä¶ Think google earth meets PowerPoint meets Prezi. Our mission defined (showcased in the above tools), we were only lacking objectives and an overall goal‚Ä¶ Easy peasy. To keep it simple and open to interpretation, we decided the theme was ‚Äúresilience.‚Äù We emphasized to the teams; this was open to interpretation (the sillier the response the better). After all, the objectives had less to do with the theme and more to do with the utilization of the tools. ‚ÄúThe software games was a great way to introduce miro, spatial composer, and obs to people who haven‚Äôt really used the programs before ‚Äì in a fun, fast-paced, friendly competition. it was great to see cross office participation and get to know some people from other offices as well!‚Äù Elaine Zhang Round 1 & 2 Graphic (via MIRO) Click to view actual MIRO Board used for the games! Round 3 & 4 Graphic Each round ended with a popular vote (handled via an online poll hosted by Menti). An overall poll was issued to the audience, but the judges had their own input that allotted points. View the recorded event! ‚ÄúIt was fun watching teams create interesting story lines on the fly and you could see everyone genuinely trying their best to do their part for their team‚Äù Nengi Njere Time to acknowledge the winners!!! The 2021 Software Games WINNERS!!!! Future events are inevitable. Is your studio up to the challenge?

title: VizR June eXchange ‚Äì SF Client Engagement Toolkit
content: SF Client Engagement Toolkit Presented by Patrick Bayer Patrick Bayer has been developing a Client Engagement Visualization Toolkit for the San Francisco office. The purpose of the toolkit is to help the SF studio establish consistent architectural graphics and define its studio presentation style. The toolkit is currently in the draft phase and consists of a menu reference for quality visualization, the available resources, and time and requirements to produce each level of visualization. The second half of the VizR call was dedicated to an open discussion to engage visualization experts around the firm and to share existing resources around entourage, material libraries, and such so that they can be harvested and pulled into a resources section for the toolkit. The toolkit introduces 7 tiers of presentation style from early concept sketches to fully rendered images. Each tier offers visual examples, descriptions, and purpose of using the style, common mistakes, and time and material resource information. Patrick welcomes all comments and suggestions on how the toolkit can be further improved. Click HERE to watch the recording.

title: Virtual Kaizen Process as a service for our clients
content: Throughout this past year, the pandemic has forced processes to go virtual to enable the ongoing advancement of work and ideas.¬† Since the nature of our work involves a team of individuals, we have adapted to technologies, tools, and platforms that facilitate the necessary communication required to produce the quality we did when we were all in the office together.¬† Our clients also have similar goals and desires but don‚Äôt always know the path to get there. Like many of our clients, University of Chicago Medicine holds large project meetings with designers, consultants, clients, stakeholders, etc. with everyone in the room in order to discuss and document important decisions on a project early on.¬† These will guide the life of the design efforts and ultimately the functionality of the building.¬† This was done with plans, renderings, and diagrams pinned up on the walls and participants putting up sticky notes, and facilitators documenting everything.¬† All this was done to use lean methodology to advance the design problem-solving process and move the project along. With online collaboration platforms like Miro , facilitating these meetings can be (in some ways) better than it was in person and continue to bring all the stakeholders together into an inclusive virtual space.¬† As a service, we have provided UCM the education and resources to take these Kaizen or continuous improvement events and go digital.¬† We were able to show them how Kaizen could be done virtually through Miro in conjunction with zoom.¬† This was done by templating their existing process on a board through preset cards, processes, virtual tours, and other in-person events that take place during an in-person Kaizen event.¬† We supplemented all of these templates with training playbooks for the facilitators, participants, and consultants.¬† In addition, some hands-on training for all UCM facilitators is planned to give them the confidence to run these events virtually.¬† UCM like other clients sees the need for a future hybrid approach even as more people are getting back together face to face.¬† ¬†This condensed digital version is much better than the 40 photos you took of the conference room with the in-person meeting.¬† This will only enhance and improve their kaizen process to continue to make the event lean and raise the process to hopefully raise the design that comes from the group effort involved.¬† In the end, the client is very impressed at our innovative use of technology‚Äôs seamless integration with our expertise and ideas which also provided us plenty of client engagement as we pursue their next big building expansion on campus.¬† ¬†If you think this type of engagement approach might be effective with your client reach out to Matt Petermann or Nick Cameron to get more details of how to be a trusted advisor to our clients through these digital consulting services. Templated Miro Frames to increase facilitator consistency and proficiency for their Kaizen events Using Digital Wayfinding to direct participants around a board just as if you would do the same in a conference space. Organizing the board to match the agenda and activities participants will collaborate on.

title: Design and Delivery June Project Showcase  and tools updates
content: Design Presentation: Museum House Seattle Iconic Leaning Towers of Seattle ‚Äì Art in Life Presented by Tad Neeser and Kevin Lo from Seattle studio Frye Towers project is located across from the Frye Art Museum in Seattle‚Äôs booming neighborhood First Hill. 707 Terry is a 34-story 605,000 SF residential project composed of two towers leaning away from each other that are linked by an amenity bridge near the top. The building is an armature for an unprecedented, complex array of 5,505 perforated sliding aluminum screens. The screens allow tenants to control shading and privacy of their balconies and units, while also providing them the ability to partially dismantle the 3-5 story tall perforated museum paintings that make up a portion of the screen composition. A careful balance between tenant experience and fa√ßade aesthetics created numerous challenges when it came time to puzzle out the operation and arrangement of the screens for their final design intent. Some of these challenges were: Careful attention was given to details: Presentation was followed by lively discussion In Tools portion of the call, we¬† talked about upcoming updates to Revit and other software and their roadmaps. Matt Peterman reminded us about updates process and revealed a new series of hands- on training provided by Digital Practice.

title: A building assessment approach
content: PROBLEM Over the winter of 2021 we were tasked with performing a building assessment for two campuses in Delaware, DSU (Delaware State University) and Wesley College in an effort to build the foundation for a Campus Master Plan that would show us the volume and condition of available spaces with the ultimate goal of combining the two campuses under one umbrella.¬† After a good deal of asking around, we found that our tools for such a task were limited or straight up lacking. TASK The goal was to assess the condition of 49 buildings at DSU over the course of three days, and another 32 buildings/facilities at Wesley College over the course of another three days.¬† Even though these are high-level assessments that is still a monumental task to take on in such a compressed time frame. ¬†We found that there were two apps that would aid us in this effort: PlanGrid and FastField.¬† There are other puchlist/field report apps that could also fill this purpose.¬† Both allowed us to work remotely throughout the day and upload results and findings when wifi or cellular signal was made available once again.¬† With three people, each carrying an iPad and their mobile phone we were able to canvas each campus in the time allotted and provide our colleagues back in the office with results and information in short order. PROCESS With the scanned plans, sections, and elevations provided by both facility departments, we uploaded the available content to PlanGrid creating a filter for each building.¬† This allowed each team member to focus in on a specific building without scanning through hundreds of sheets to orient themselves.¬† On each floor plan, we tagged photos taken with the app to indicate where we had taken the pic from.¬† In a number of instances, teammates used their phones to acquire better pics than the iPad was able to produce under low light levels or wide-angle lenses.¬† These photos were also tagged back into the PlanGrid app to maintain the consistency of the information that would be given to the rest of the campus planning team and eventually to DSU as part of the final document.¬† Once all the buildings were photographed and documented we exported a photos report that shows the overall floor plate where each photo tag was placed which was then followed by individual plan snippets and the associated photos for each location.¬† This proved useful for our colleagues who were unable to visit the campuses and gave them a good idea of the cross-section of available spaces and their potential. The FastField app was chosen for its flexibility in the creation of the survey, ability to work remotely, and the ways that it could be posted to the group once completed and submitted.¬† FastField allows you to customize your survey to cater to your needs such as: Written descriptions Incorporating photos Yes / No responses Setting up radio buttons to click one option under the established category. Setting up radio buttons to click all options that apply to a category. Scale ratings of various conditions.¬† For example, you could apply a scale of 1 to 5 of the building‚Äôs condition, sustainability practice, utilization for social interaction, or whether the building is even worth repurposing or being demolished. The administrator can also update the survey form in real-time and dispatch it to all or specific team members or post a completely different survey to the applicable staff. Due to the limited timeframe, the team decided to blanket the campuses and photograph all that we could, and then once we returned to our respective home offices use FastField to assess each building and facility while running through the volumes of pics taken.¬† Once that was completed the app allowed you to post that survey in various formats such as Excel, PDF, XML, etc. and forward it to specific teammates, or upload it to an FTP, send it to Dropbox, Send Files to SharePoint, etc..¬† For our efforts, we decided to export to Excel and copy each building report into a master excel file that would give us a greater overview of all the buildings in one location. SOLUTION This was the first time we had used these tools in this fashion, so the process was not perfect but was effective and adaptable for an on-site team of three people.¬† One of the challenges that may be worth noting was the limited and inconsistent data, plans, and documents provided by the university hampered and limited the effectiveness of the photo reports and surveys of a number of buildings.¬† Still, our documentation of each building permitted us to build a report, post site visit, in FastField within 30 minutes or less per building. The utilization of the PlanGrid and FastField was truly helpful in bringing the rest of the campus planning team up to speed on the existing conditions and the use of both campuses.¬† The cumulative excel file that brought together all the assessment reports was then filtered down into a matrix that will help the DSU leadership to begin to understand what they have at their fingertips, what buildings can be repurposed, and begin to refocus their funds and efforts toward building and strengthening the programs provided by the university.

title: Adding more punch to your software tool box
content: As we start to see return to studio finally happening, it is time to do some spring cleaning on your software toolbox and make sure you have the latest and greatest to keep you designing at the highest levels possible. We have made available updates to Revit that you can find in software center.¬† ¬†We do this to maintain security and reduce model errors and Revit crashes.¬† ¬†So while you won‚Äôt see great new features with everything we make available it is worth your while to effectively get your design work down with this tool.¬† ¬†Please find time to run this update before it becomes a requirement and you have to update it. We have improved two of our visualization tools to the newest versions that introduce new features to give you more options to communicate your design.¬† ¬†Take a look at the newest features available to us in Lumion and Enscape .¬† ¬†You can find these in software center as well for self install on your MSI laptop. You will also see in the coming weeks updates for Rhino, Climate Studio, Vray for Rhino, and Conveyor v2 which works with Rhino Inside.¬† ¬†As well as some hotfixes and updates for Autodesk products like Navisworks, 3ds Max and AutoCAD LT. Over the course of the summer, we will be releasing updates to prepare for the newest version of Revit with new versions of Clarity, Vray for Revit, Keynote Manager, CTC Suite, CTC Hive, pyRevit, and our own PW Tools. You can expect to see the Autodesk 2022 products becoming available at the end of summer or early fall with specific dates to be announced in the coming months.

title: Design and Delivery May 2021 Project Showcase  and tools updates
content: Design Presentations: Florida International University Validating Facilities Requirements During Design, Not in the Field Presented by Damian Ponton, Miami office One of our Miami Studio‚Äôs most important clients, Florida International University always looks to Perkins and Will to deliver innovative solutions. As part of their new BIM Standards, FIU requires the design team to engage with their facilities group. The intent is to make sure that their needs are met and addressed during the design phase, not in the field. Bypassing the traditional page flip, the team decided to invite facilities to walk inside the model, evaluate MEP equipment arrangement and clearances in real time. This required a tight coordination of the Revit model for the engineers. Using this approach, facilities was able to get a real feel for what the unbuilt spaces would be like and provide important feedback on what worked and didn‚Äôt work, avoiding costly construction re-work in the field by catching critical issues now. The client‚Äôs requirements included ensuring access for proper maintenance on building systems Team takes new approach coordination with engineers Client‚Äôs virtual walkthough CHoP Updates Children‚Äôs Hospital Of Pennsylvania computational design with adaptive components was presented earlier,¬† here are the links: https://digitalpractice.perkinswill.com/2019/08/09/computational-design-case-study-chop/ Dahmahlee Lawrence from New York Studio gave and update from the construction site: If it fits, it ships! In Tools portion of the call, we were talking about upcoming updates to Revit and other software and their roadmap

title: VizR May eXchange ‚Äì Easy Virtual Galleries
content: Easy Virtual Galleries for Everyone Presented by Mario Romero, Justin Benjamin, and Andrea Manzano For the past few months, Digital Practice and Vizlab have been collaborating together to create a workflow and template for design teams to easily create their own online virtual galleries. We‚Äôll walk through a few of the projects that have successfully used this new form of client engagement as well as talk about how you can quickly get started with your own! In the era of non-stop virtual meetings, how can you enhance your virtual presentation to make your presentation the one your clients will remember? By using the Virtual Gallery, we transform the simple 2D presentation into a rich and immersive 3D experience that one can walk through virtually and enjoy the presentation much like visiting a real gallery. Our Virtual Gallery solution creates a website that is lightweight and browser-based and is easily accessible to everyone. Using our pre-set Virtual Gallery template, the team can easily set up their project‚Äôs virtual gallery using their own content. The virtual gallery can host all kinds of content such as images, videos, 3D models, links, and QR Codes. The Gallery is designed with a nonagon center space attached to 9 separate wings, each wing is 30‚Ä≤ wide by 80‚Ä≤ long and can host eight large boards, four boards on each side of the wall. All the project team has to do is provide the image content for the boards by exporting the slides from your PowerPoint or InDesign presentation. Our experts then insert these images onto the boards and render out your 3D virtual gallery. With the help of our VizLab, we then upload the gallery into your own project website! For more information on how to set up your own virtual gallery, please visit the Digital Practice- Virtual Gallery Quickstart guide . Click HERE to view the recording.

title: LEED View Quality Grasshopper Script
content: Now you can easily perform a LEED View Quality analysis on your project using a script debuted at last month‚Äôs Computational Design eXchange. Check out the recording for a full walkthrough. Download the Grasshopper script here LEED Logic Achieve a direct line of sight to the outdoors via vision glazing for 75% of all regularly occupied floor area. Additionally, 75% of all regularly occupied floor area must have at least two of the following four kinds of views: Multiple lines of sight to vision glazing in different directions at least 90 degrees apart Views that include at least two of the following (A) flora, fauna, or sky (B) movement (C) objects at least 25 feet from the exterior of the glazing Unobstructed views located within the distance of three times the head height of the vision glazing; (NotImplemented) views with a view factor of 3 or greater as defined in ‚Äúwindows and offices; a study of office worker performance and the indoor environment‚Äú The complete LEED requirements can be found here: https://www.usgbc.org/credits/new-construction-commercial-interiors-schools-new-construction-retail-new-construction-ret-2 Geometric Elements Rhino elements for the building (Floor, glazing, opaque) are used in all three analyses. The external goal objects for the second analysis (flora, fauna, sky, motion, distant objects) are modeled as well. The rhino elements are referenced into nodes so they can be used in the grasshopper script. Floor surfaces are subdivided into an analysis grid. The tighter the grid the more accurate the analysis, but the longer the analysis will take. Check LEED requirements regarding the analysis variables. The main analysis is performed by a Ladybug component called ViewPercent. The Grasshopper Script The View Type parameter creates a different pattern of rays, which represent the lines of sight from each analysis grid zone. 0 ‚Äì Horizontal 2 ‚Äì Spherical 3 ‚Äì Sky Exposure The results of the view analysis are output as a Matrix. Combine that with a Dispatch node to get only the unobstructed vectors. Converting all the goal objects to a single mesh and then using the MeshRay node and the same dispatch trick as last time gives us the successful vectors. The final step of the script combines all the separate analyses into a single score and a colored visualization of the analysis grid.

title: VizR April eXchange ‚Äì Interactive Virtual Gallery
content: For our April VizR eXchange, Emre Aslan presented an interactive Virtual Gallery that was built using Unreal Engine, the gallery was automated with an Artificial Guide (think Siri in your model) that walks you through the exhibition space and narrates the displays as you walk around the gallery. The use of Unreal Engine enables you to create a virtual model that has a much higher quality of lighting, rendering, and material mapping. The main advantage of using Unreal is the ability to create a much more photorealistic virtual space and the potential to embed static and dynamic media files, such as images, PowerPoint, videos, and animation. With the ability to add custom interactivity, the model can present different design options with a simple click of a button to switch the virtual scene into another design option.¬† However, the downside of it is the enormous file size Unreal generates, and the need for a high-performance machine for viewing and experiencing the virtual space. One possible solution is to explore the Unreal Pixel streaming service to provide real-time cloud-based content distribution. Using the streaming service, the model can be shared with a much wider audience through the use of a browser on any internet device with minimal graphic capabilities. The exhibition space is designed with sensors that will trigger events, such as voice narration or animations. The event will only start as you walk close to the display and will end as you walk away from it. Emre also added different interactivity samples such as moving objects and drawing on panels. Some panels are movable, allowing viewers to interact with the panels to rearrange the display. Other panels can spin and rotate as you approach it or touch it. One main model even does an exploding axon as you walk up to it, and reconstructs itself as you walk away from it. (see image above). To learn more about this gallery experience, click HERE for the recording.

title: Digital Practice Core eXchange 2nd Quarter 2021 Recap
content: Digital Practice Core eXchange and Training Library Resources From April 13th to the 22nd, Digital Practice team members and other experts from around the firm completed another round of classes for our quarterly Digital Practice Core eXchange.¬† These continuing education sessions are designed to give our staff awareness and understanding of the tools and processes available to us at Perkins&Will. This quarter we started off with a featured keynote speaker, Randy Deutsch.¬† ¬†He is an architect and professor at the University of Illinois.¬† This was broadcast through the firm‚Äôs Vimeo account publicly on our website.¬† Randy covered many technology topics from career paths as they pertain to an evolving technology landscape to how AI is impacting the design profession.¬† Everyone was able to join the live sessions through Teams from wherever they are currently working and engage with the speakers to gain a better understanding in order to improve their work process. These live sessions were spread out over Tuesday, Wednesday, and Thursday for two consecutive weeks on our Practice Lecture Hall Teams channel for continuing education. If you weren‚Äôt able to make a session live or want to review one, you can find the recording in our ever-growing exchange library. If you are having trouble finding a recording in our library use the filters at the top of the thumbnails to narrow it down by category If you have any suggestions on topics we should cover or ways you think that this event could be more successful and valuable, please reach out to Matt Petermann on Teams. The sessions are categorized by topics and you can view the recording and a slide deck and also connect with presenters for a follow-up discussion We had many highly attended classes and engaging question and answer sessions with those attending.¬† ¬†Some new ones that are relevant to working from home are a couple of new topics around the hands-on how-to for the Miro platform, an introduction to data visualization using Microsoft PowerBI, and also a session on how to navigate the requests for BIMs and where we are heading as a firm. Overall this quarter‚Äôs exchange had just over 1400 total attendees for the 17 sessions and keynote.

title: WUFI training resources
content: The firm has access to WUFI software to help analyze your design.¬† ¬†This product allows for the realistic calculation of the heat and moisture transport in walls and roofs and other multi-layered building components.¬† ¬†It uses scientific research around vapor diffusion and moisture transport. Earlier this year some continuing education was provided to some of the staff in the New York studio.¬† ¬†You can find that recording here if you have a need for this analysis on your next project.

title: Design and Delivery April 2021 Project Showcase  and Casework Pack
content: Design Presentation: Belmont Middle-High School Project presented by Christopher Karlson and Cheney Chen Located in a suburb of Boston, it is a new 445,100 sf project conceived as a flexible and agile environment for learning. Emphasizing hands-on learning, the project co-locates students (both middle and high school age) on one campus while encouraging multi-age learning. This future-ready building was made to tackle climate change with its intent to achieve Zero Net Energy through comprehensive strategies including geothermal wells , roof-top PV panels and utilization of optimal daylighting solutions . To achieve this goal, Boston team worked together with PW energy lab This is a great example of collaboration between firm‚Äôs experts and achieving project goals by making use of PW pool of experts and research.The High School is expected to be occupied in the Fall 2021, followed by the Middle School in Fall 2023. Casework Documentation Workflow presentation Jeremy Helfert and Daniel Prager from the Chicago Studio unveiled¬†the new Casework family system and documentation workflow . These upgraded Revit families utilize a new tagging system for finishes and details, as well as centralized sheets for common Casework Elevations and Casework Details. Standard sheets available in Hive CMS Helen Gorina demonstrated how to utilize Hive CMS to get the content loaded into your projects .

title: VizR March eXchange ‚Äì James Brown Arena Visualization
content: For our March eXchange, Scott Schroeder presented the work in progress James Brown Arena project‚Äôs visualization. Using the new Visual Dataprep tools, Scott was able to import geometry from Revit/Rhino into Unreal Engine to create photorealistic rendering and animations. Scott started the presentation with a tip on how they used a model within a model for the Vanderbilt Project. Using a linked scaled-down model, one can take the viewer into the model at the reduced scale of the model and give the viewer a chance to walk around and experience the buildings as if they are inside the model. The main topic of the presentation is how Unreal was used to create real-time visualization of the massive James Brown Arena project. Scott walked us through the steps of using Data Prep to bring in the model from Revit into the Unreal Engine, and offered best practices in how to set up the lighting and scenery in generating photo-realistic renderings and animations. One of the questions that are often asked is why do you use Unreal vs. other software such as Enscape, Lumion, or Twinmotion. Scott answers this question by showing and panning in real-time a landscape scenery that is filled with vegetation, and explains that the strength of Unreal is in its ability to render complex scenes with a large number of complex vegetation or crowd in real-time. https://digitalpractice.perkinswill.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Unreal_landscape.mp4 and the clip below of the James Brown Arena demonstrates this clearly, as it would be impossible to achieve this level of visualization without using Unreal. https://digitalpractice.perkinswill.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/arena.mp4 For more details about the presentation click HERE to watch the recording.

title: Rethinking Architectural Modelling
content: Title slide, original background image: sergeytyapkin.com/ As architects, we spend a large amount of our time creating shared digital environments with the aim of one day affecting the real world through an ancient technique ‚Äì construction. We wondered if we could learn something from an industry that focus entirely on creating convincing, immersive, artificial environments ‚Äì video games. Hosted by the Technical University of Dublin, we spent a day in February questioning conventional modelling paradigms together with students from their Architecture & Technology unit. We introduced¬†alternative concepts for modelling architectural space whereby the design intent is shifted to the design of a modular spatial system. A specific algorithm is adopted from the games development industry and applied in the context of an existing tower structure in Dublin city center. Wave Function Collapse, explained on github.com/mxgmn/WaveFunctionCollapse Wave Function Collapse (WFC) is a special approach to constraint solving as a process of elimination. Each grid location holds an array of binary values for what tiles it could or could not be. During the observation phase, one tile is selected and given a single random solution from the remaining possibilities. This choice is then propagated throughout the grid, eliminating adjacent possibilities that don‚Äôt match the input model ‚Äì the wave collapses. The final feature is backtracking. If an observation & propagation result in an unsolvable contradiction, they‚Äôre reverted and a different observation is attempted. The technique is traditionally used to create infinite, procedural cities in games or movies. Because a designer has defined the style, connection rules and geometry, the algorithm can reconfigure the individual modules to create unique, convincing landscape segments, endlessly. We extend the original 3D implementation by discourse.mcneel.com/u/Alasdair The students were invited to design spatial voxels that form the input to the WFC algorithm, which resolves their distribution in the tower. The results are then analyzed and displayed in the viewport under a variety of lenses ‚Äì type distribution, solar access, views and daylight were a few of the parameters. Previous Previous Previous Next Next Next 1 2 3 Here, the architect becomes the curator of candidate proposals, that, while technically and logically correct, may not display spatial or environmental attributes quite in line with the designers ambitions. While algorithmic approaches may be a long way away from reliably outputting anything remotely close to what we would consider a natural solution to a design problem, we might start to ask ourselves if they can get us close enough. References: Link to the full workshop slideshow: https://perkinswillinc-my.sharepoint.com/:p:/g/personal/rhu_shl_dk/EfL4j_CVke5Ko05ul8Qv7m4BdadJufh4T5smii8qkgFXtQ?e=ekaLtj Original 2D implementation of the Wave Function Collapse algorithm: https://github.com/mxgmn/WaveFunctionCollapse Working repository for our 3D implementation: https://github.com/rhughes42/wfc-gh (soon to be updated with demo files).

title: Rhino.Inside, First Contact for Revit Users
content: Of all the new features available in Rhino 7, Rhino.Inside will have the greatest impact, especially for users who work in Revit. If you‚Äôve never used Rhino or Grasshopper before it may be intimidating. Here is brief description of how the three work together followed by workflows for first time users to send geometry both directions between Rhino and Revit. For more information about Rhino 7 and Rhino.Inside check out last month‚Äôs Computational Design eXchange call . Rhino.Inside: What is it? Rhino.Inside breaks down the barriers between designing in Rhino and documenting in Revit. Without getting too technical, Revit, Rhino and Grasshopper are all running in the same ‚Äòsession‚Äô, which means the data in one is available to all others.¬† Open a Revit file. Open a Rhino file. Pass geometry and data back and forth using Grasshopper. We no longer need to export/import through a third-party file format and lose data in the translation. How Do I Use It? We will have a one-click install for Rhino.Inside available soon in the software center. Until then download the latest Rhino.Inside build here . Close Rhino and Revit before installing, then restart Revit. OPEN REVIT FIRST! Rhino.Inside (and Grasshopper) must be launched from within Revit to connect the two environments. If you accidentally open Rhino separately the Rhino.Inside tools and menus will not appear in Grasshopper. Open Revit, Add-ins tab Rhino button Rhino Tab Grasshopper button Revit tab in Grasshopper What Can It Do? There are many ways to interact with your Revit and Rhino objects using Rhino.Inside. The first step is to select elements to operate on. Next, decide what you want to do with them. In this example, we are selecting all Revit elements of a single category (Floors). All floors (2) in Revit are passed out of the node. The yellow panel in the middle shows those elements (Revit Floor : Concrete). Every aspect of the Revit elements are available to be used or modified, including parameter values. In this example, we are simply extracting the element geometry (Closed Brep). Grasshopper holds data within nodes that are connected together to form a script. To make geometry available natively in Rhino or Revit it must be ‚Äòbaked‚Äô into Rhino or put in Revit using ‚ÄòDirectShape‚Äô. Both functions are very simple to perform. See the image below. The Revit to Rhino process is shown in blue; Rhino to Revit in red. There is much more that Rhino.Inside can do. We‚Äôre still exploring all of the options but wanted to get these basic workflows out to everyone and encourage you to explore more on your own. Reach out to Luc Deckinga or Mario Romero with any questions.

title: Matterport Test Case ‚Äì Atrium Health Union West Hospital
content: The Union West Hospital is a major Perkins&Will project located outside of Charlotte, North Carolina. Multiple Perkins&Will Studios across the US (Dallas, Charlotte, and Durham) are working collaboratively to deliver a state-of-the-art hospital to serve the North Carolina area. Construction began in April during the start of the COVID-19 Pandemic, although the pandemic was a major speed bump in the process, the team¬†was able to utilize the technology available to keep the project moving forward efficiently and effectively. One of the most valuable ways the team achieved this was by working with the Contractor to build a functional Mockup of the Patient Room with the Nurses Station. Once the mockup was completed, a local team member was sent to scan the mockup using a Pro2 3D Camera. Given the inherent size of mockups, it only took a couple of hours to scan and upload for viewing. Once the scan was uploaded, it was distributed to Perkins&Will project team members for review and comment. Project members were able to virtually ‚Äòwalk‚Äô the site in the comfort (and safety) of their home. Throughout the process of Construction Administration, the project team has shared the link of the scan with Brasfield & Gorrie (Contractor), Atrium Health (Owner),¬† WMBA and NBBJ (Partner Architects), and the Division of Health Service Regulation (DHSR). Each group used the scan in different ways and to date, the scan has 1230 impressions and 770 visits since August 11, 2020. A Mockup is a valuable tool for the Contractor and Architect as a way to ensure Quality Control. During the CA phase, there have been multiple virtual meetings using the scan to walk through and discuss defects, issues, finishes, lighting, etc. Because the 3D Scan Link was so accessible and convenient the mockup was used and talked about more frequently than a traditional ‚Äòon-site‚Äô mockup. It even created conversations earlier in the CA process like means and methods and contractor/sub-contractor scope.¬† This process also allowed us to share the link so more people can see and visualize the space, which especially helped the younger staff going through CA and understanding the overall coordination of the design. Finally, this process has helped us with design and CA creating a new perspective without being physically there while also saving time and money without having to travel. The Scan was sent to DHSR as part of their initial review of the Patient Room and Nurses Station ‚Äì The adjacencies and design will be the new standard for Atrium, Code officials were able to review the layout of handrail locations and review corridor requirements. The scan was also used in conjunction with the drawings to help visualize and ‚Äòplace‚Äô the officials in the space. The Mockup Scan was most effective in use with Atrium Health, Firstly they were impressed with the technology and Perkins&Will‚Äôs initiative to document and share the 3D scan. Secondly, The scan was distributed to decision-makers around the Hospital System and is being used in a Regional Conference presentation showing the new standard of their Interior Design. The Matterport scan essentially paid for itself in time, money, errors, and (hopefully) helped us win more work by showing that Perkins&Will has the latest technology available and is able to maximize its potential. Matterport Atrium Mockup Scan numbers (Third most in Perkins&Will in Active Spaces) ‚Äì You can view the scan HERE Impressions: 1230 Average Impressions Monthly: 205 Months Since Creation: 6 Visits: 770 Average Visits Monthly: 128 Months Since Creation: 6 Unique Visitors: 461 Average Unique Visitors Months: 77 Months Since Creation: 6

The project is located in the Tenderloin neighborhood of San Francisco and consists of academic space and 656 student beds. What began as a precast concrete facade evolved into a unitized system clad with extruded aluminum to create the distinctive shapes. The team worked with the Building Technology Lab to test the concept in full-sized CNC milled mockups. This projects of a girl scout camp is an example of a land stewardship and ‚Äúlight touch‚Äù design where Perkins&Will led the team of consultants to fulfill a beautiful, environmentally friendly, and highly functional vision. Listening to this presentation I not only admired the design as a professional, but wanted to turn time back and have an opportunity to experience the Camp Lakota as a camper. title: London Studios pursuit of Net Zero
content: The London studio is doubling down on its commitment to delivering all interiors projects as Net Zero embodied carbon by 2030. Ensuring our design team have the right tools and that we are working hard to improve the performance of our supply partners are at the foundation of our manifesto. A collaboration in London between Workplace Strategy, Digital Practice, Sustainability, and Corporate Interiors has created ‚ÄòNow‚Äô our database for capturing material and products, manufacturers sustainability data, and information.¬† The submissions are collated and scored by our Sustainability team allowing our designers access to a searchable measured database on the most sustainable materials and products to use on our projects. The database captures information on healthy materials, recycled and recyclable content, supply chain diversity, and circular design principles amongst others. The team developed a survey/questionnaire using Qualtrics and pushed supplier responses to a simple searchable excel database.¬† This database is stored on the London Team Net Zero channel for all to use.¬† While this product is in its infancy, If successful, it is hoped, it can be rolled out to more studios globally and developed into a more sophisticated and interactive online database system with the goal and overtime to become a public resource to complement our Transparency site. The system was beta-tested to a small selection of suppliers in December, soft-launched in January, and has been launched to the industry NOW!

title: VizR February eXchange ‚Äì Creating 360 Panoramic Tours
content: For our February eXchange, Dan Creekmore from our Viz Lab presented the latest tools and services in creating 360 Panorama experiences. Panorama images are 360-degree images either captured from a 360 camera or rendered using various rendering software, such as Enscape, Rhino, 3DSMax, Vray, and Lumion. A 360 Panorama tour, is basically a series of 360 images sequenced together to give the viewer a google street view experience, where one can hop from one point to another within the viewer. With the unfortunate demise of Roundme and Ptp tools, new tools such as Kuula.co and Pano2VR are replacing them to be the preferred tools in creating 360 pano tours. Kuula.co offers web-based 360 pano tours, it has a simple interface in creating the tours, and are able to add hotspot links to other 360 images, as well as additional information such as images, documents, videos, and URL links. If you need to deliver the 360 tour as a product for the client to host, or for offline viewing, Pano2VR would be a good tool to use. Pano2VR is a powerful tool that gives you options to further customize the 360 experience with all the bells and whistles you need. Lastly, there is Object2VR, which a quick tool to create an interactive experience in viewing a 3D model using a sequence of 2D images. Finally, one can recreate the Virtual Gallery experience using these tools in order to share the immersive experience online with the clients and consultants, without requiring them to download any heavy Enscape files. They only need to click on the link to the virtual Gallery website, and start exploring the Gallery using their internet Browser. To learn more details, watch the recording HERE , and feel free to contact Daniel Creekmore at our Dallas Viz Lab.

title: Virtual Pull Planning Resources
content: At the start of our Work from Home adventure, the Digital Practice team worked with several pilot projects to find a way to virtually recreate our Pull Planning sessions.¬† In the past, Pull Planning was conducted as half-day workshops in our conference rooms using premade task cards developed by our Technical Design Community.¬† During the workshop, design partners would pin these laminated milestones on the wall according to when they should occur in the project timeline.¬† Once the preliminary schedule was on the wall, the participants would discuss sequencing and deliverables to create a lean path towards the deliverables.¬† These meetings had been very helpful for our teams, and we did not want the hybrid work environment to stop this progress. Physical Pull Planning ‚Äì A mixture of premade cards and custom cards Utilizing Tasks by Planner, a product within our existing Microsoft Office 365 suite, we were able to replicate the process of pinning laminated cards with tasks cards in a digital environment.¬† Our three templates (SD, DD, and CD) are prepopulated with the milestone cards from our physical decks.¬† Using this digital method we were able to expand on the physical cards and allow each task to have assigned responsible parties, added checklists, tracked task completion, embedded Living Design links, and more. Premade CD cards in our Pull Planning Templates Going Virtual also gave us greater control of the workshop.¬† Instead of our design teams taking the better part of their morning to prepopulate all the major deliverables and deadlines on a pinup wall, our teams have ample time to vet deadlines, presentations, and required info exchanges beforehand.¬† Additionally, we can invite the design partners into the Planner environment a week in advance, allowing everybody to set their tasks prior to the workshop starting.¬† This prework lets the workshop become a discussion of everyone‚Äôs process and needs, without the time lost with crowding a pin-up space. Using the Tasks by Planner interface to move Tasks from Week to Week This method of Virtual Pull Planning has been presented at the last two Digital Practice Core eXchanges, which are available to watch on the Digital Practice website .¬† Additionally, the Technical Design Community now has access to the presentations developed for our pilot projects.¬† The Pull Planning Step by Step presentation covers both the setup and goals of Pull Planning for our design teams, while the Consultant Onboarding Presentation is meant as a takeaway boot camp for any consultants wanting to participate in the Virtual Pull Plan.¬† We have developed Pull Planning Templates that can be used on any project for Schematic, Design Development, and Construction Documentation phases. This is an embedded Microsoft Office presentation, powered by Office . Pull Planning Step by Step Guide This is an embedded Microsoft Office presentation, powered by Office . Pull Planning Consultant Onboarding Presentation

title: What is all that Buzz? New HIVE CMS is here
content: New HIVE CMS (content management system) is finally here! It is available to Install from Software Center Why HIVE CMS? The main reason for the update is that new HIVE CMS operates independently of Revit and cannot possibly crash it . In other words, if something goes wrong with HIVE, you can kill it in Task Manager, and continue to work in Revit without risk of losing your work. This is especially important in time of WFH, when the home connectivity is not as good as connectivity in the office. It is still Revit agnostic and will associate itself with the active Revit session. Search algorithm is working significantly faster, and there are multiple improvements to the user interface and functionality. Revit version compatibility the old HIVE is not available for Revit 2021 and will be retired in April New HIVE CMS works for versions 2019-2021 amd will remain operational in the future versions of Revit Content Database all 2019-2020 content was migrated from old HIVE to the new HIVE CMS and is available now 2021 versions of the content are also published We will keep 3 active versions of content in the future, and new version of Revit rolls out, the old content will be retired Training and question new HIVE CMS interface is similar to the old HIVE, with some improvements we will introduce new HIVE CMS on February 11 Design and Delivery call, and then follow up with mK cards and other training materials

title: Digital Practice Core eXchange 1st Quarter 2021 Recap
content: Digital Practice Core eXchange and Training Library Resources From January 12th to the 21st, Digital Practice team members and other experts from around the firm completed another round of classes for our quarterly Digital Practice Core eXchange.¬† These continuing education sessions are designed to give our staff awareness and understanding of the tools and processes available to us at Perkins&Will. This quarter we had many new topics, as well as updating and improving many other topics from previous core exchanges.¬† Everyone was able to join the live sessions through Teams from wherever they are currently working and engage with the speakers to gain a better understanding in order to improve their work process. These live sessions were spread out over Tuesday, Wednesday, and Thursday for two consecutive weeks on our Practice Lecture Hall Teams channel for continuing education. If you weren‚Äôt able to make a session live or want to review one, you can find the recording in our ever-growing exchange library. If you have any suggestions on topics we should cover or ways you think that this event could be more successful and valuable, please reach out to Matt Petermann on Teams. The sessions are categorized by topics and you can view the recording and a slide deck and also connect with presenters for a follow-up discussion We had many highly attended classes and engaging question and answer sessions with those attending.¬† ¬†Some new ones that are relevant to working from home are a couple of new topics around the hands-on how-to for the Miro platform, an introduction to data visualization using Microsoft PowerBI, and also a session on how to navigate the requests for BIMs and where we are heading as a firm. Overall this quarter‚Äôs exchange had just over 1800 total attendees for the 18 sessions.¬† ¬†We also had two health safety and welfare accredited courses in the mix of all the accredited sessions.¬† ¬†Next quarter we are looking to add accreditation for ASLA and IDCEC to see if these courses can cover more professional‚Äôs continuing education requirements.

title: Computational Design December eXchange ‚Äì Ryan Hughes
Perkins&Will Innovation at Autodesk Hackathon and Accelerator
content: By Thomas Kearns In the final months of the year, multiple efforts to expand our experience working with Autodesk‚Äôs forge cloud services converged. The I/O team won their category in the Autodesk University associated hackathon. Members of Digital Practice and I/O participated in an experimental accelerator hosted by Autodesk. The accelerator tested the developer experience (dx) working with new and emerging Forge Viewer extensions focused on IoT oriented data visualization. Both events served as catalysts for ongoing collaborative efforts between Digital Practice and I/O to create an automated time-series data pipeline and a scalable web based dashboard/visualization framework driven directly from Revit models and project data. AU Hackathon Satya Basu, Amanda Gentle, Thomas Kearns Tina Lam and Chan Youn, from I/O competed and won in the Innovative Digital Twin category, in the week long Hackathon. Building upon their efforts with Health Former (campus wide covid surge tracking application for Swedish in Seattle), the team created a working prototype for a mobile application which enables users to quickly survey rooms and spaces for critical assets. Aimed at healthcare workers who need a simple interface to contribute data spatially referenced to our project models, the application leveraged the Design Automation api (among others) to populate Revit models and our proprietary database with asset data and proxy geometry. Click HERE to learn more about the Asset Tracker project. ‚ÄúCandy Cane‚Äù Accelerator Just before the holidays, Autodesk accepted a small team of developers to participate in a virtual accelerator focused on Internet of Things (IoT), data. Driven by Dasher360 and researchers at Autodesk, new Forge Viewer extensions enable point cloud data visualization in the Forge Viewer including connectivity to cloud based IoT data services from Azure and AWS. With a variety of experiments in IoT sensor data for spatial tracking active throughout our organizations, especially those based on human activity and behavioral tracking using computer vision, our efforts focused on body tracking and data sets/interactivity which ultimately pushed the limits of the new Autodesk services. Beneficial feedback for AutoCAD, married with effective insight and education into how to more deeply customize the Forge Viewer for our team. Both Autodesk sponsored events provided training and technical support that has been helpful in the ongoing development of an automated, scalable web based dashboard and project data visualization framework. Collaboration between I/O and Digital Practice has brought the Forge and Bim360 services together with add-ons for Revit and modern web development tools for a foundation which can leverage our push to comprehensive Bim360 project usage. In early 2021 the prototype dashboard development team will lead a workshop and training session to establish the long term roadmap for the project and expand development efforts modularly.

title: VizR December eXchange ‚Äì DLC Winning Design and URMC Project Presentation
content: For our December VizR call, we have two exciting project presentations. DLC Winning Team Arroyo ‚Äì Vangel Kukov and Hala El Khorazaty discussed their winning design and their insight of participating in the DLC competition. URMC ‚Äì Kaitlin Knotts shared the award winning design for URMC while taking the audience on a virtual walk through. Hala El Khorazaty and Vangel Kukov shared their design process from site selection, concept design, to modeling and rendering the project using Lumion. With only two days to work on the DLC competition, the team decided early on to use Lumion which enabled them to spend more time on the research and design portion of the project, and less on the presentation side. With the use of Lumion, they were able to quickly put together the final presentation complete with landscaping, entourage, rendering and graphic styling with minimal efforts. For more information on the project visit the project DLC page (https://dlc.perkinswill.com/portfolio/arroyo/) Click HERE To watch the recording of the presentation (00:00 ‚Äì 21:00) University of Rochester Medical Center (URMC) ‚Äì Presented by Kaitlin Knotts URMC is an adaptive reuse project based at a former Sears location in a Mall renovation. By opening the new orthopedic clinic in a suburban mall, life and economic activity are brought back into the mall community. The project team used Enscape as a design tool throughout the entire process. Enscape was especially helpful when presenting to the client and guiding them through specific design features. Using real time fly-bys and walk throughs, the team was able to demonstrate design features such as the large canopy and entrance waiting areas, and how the space worked as the customers approach the facility for pickup and drop off. Instead of just using still rendering and floor plans, the team used live Enscape model and walked the client through the design space, to demonstrate how the design features helped in orienting patients and breaking down long monotonous corridors into light filled pleasant space. Kaitlin did a fantastic job at presenting the project while navigating the model live for our audience. Click HERE To watch the recording of the presentation (21:00 ‚Äì 55:00)
