title: Artifact Website
content: Revit Artifact Search Plugins! Artifact is now available directly from Revit! The Artifact plugins for Revit 2020 and 2021 can be installed from Software Center. Once installed open Revit. Go to the PW tab, Sign-in, then use the Search bar. A browser window will open and take you to your Artifact search results. Perkins&Will teamed up with AIprentice, a software developer, to create Artifact , a website that you can use to search Perkins&Will drawing sets. If you are reading this you already have access. Go to Okta and look for the Artifact link or bookmark this page . Drawings are collected from Revit projects using the ‚ÄòHarvest‚Äô plugin created by AIprentice. It creates images of the views in the active project and uploads them to the content database for the Artifact website. The ‚ÄòSecret Sauce‚Äô of the Artifact website is the way in which it associates metadata with the harvested views. Each view is tagged with parameters and text elements extracted from Revit. These tags are how the Artifact website finds and filters views. Text Notes Callouts View Name View Scale Project Info Project Address Perkins&Will Studio Start by entering a search term. Views that match your search will be displayed in the main window and can be filtered by Studio, Project, Units (Imperial/Metric), View Type, and View Scale using the left sidebar.

title: Grasshopper Snippets 2.0
content: Snippets is a collection of Grasshopper tools developed at Schmidt Hammer Lassen Architects, with the intent of making computational design accessible to all. The tools are collected in a custom toolbar, making it easy for everyone to get access. Snippets aim to enhance the design process in three ways; 1. Automating existing, repetitive tasks ‚Äì e.g. calculating areas or test fitting facade layouts on a massing model. 2. Enabling new design workflows and processes ‚Äì e.g. generating urban massing, terrain, or complex geometries. 3. Augmenting design decision making, by providing continuous access to relevant data and documentation as an integrated part of working on designs in Rhino. This includes daylighting, visibility, parking requirements, etc. Enabling Collaboration and Sharing At SHL, we want to help facilitate collaboration by providing a way for us to share the benefits of our collective work. Many studios invest their own time automating complex or repetitive tasks. Sharing this work between studios or even employees locally has historically been difficult, which has inevitably entailed an unnecessary duplication of efforts. Therefore, we have developed a template and method that allows you to easily save your scripts in a format that can be added to our custom toolbar. This template, based on our years of collaboration in computational design, includes guidelines on how to layout your script and suggestions as to what to make visible to the end-user. We hope that this template will foster sharing and reuse amongst the computational designers at Perkins&Will, giving us access to a huge, consistent library of tools and an edge over our competitors. Installation instructions You can find the latest version of Snippets and installation instructions in this folder: S:\_Firmwide\Rhino-Grasshopper\SNIPPETS Notes 1. Many of the Snippets have been developed to answer the requirements of specific projects, which means they have been tested on real-life scenarios and then refined to meet changing demands. 2. When completing a project, a good rule of thumb is that you will need to spend an extra 20% of your time to turn the raw grasshopper script into an easily accessible tool. 3. ‚ÄúDesigning‚Äù the Snippet greatly influences the attractiveness and usability of the tool for those who are not experienced Grasshopper users. Even for experienced users, immediately knowing the purpose and value of a tool will influence the degree to which it is used. Snippets have helped us to optimize and augment our design process at SHL significantly ‚Äì and we are just getting started! We hope that you will join us, share your ideas, and help us to deliver differently across Perkins&Will. View Digital Practice Core Exchange Presentation Video

title: Design and Delivery November ‚Äì New Tools
content: Holy cow. 67 comments Nick Cameron presentation recording New tools introduced on November Design and Delivery call were enthusiastically received by our designers, and have triggered lively discussion. Adam Hamilton (Minneapolis DA) demonstrated two Dynamo scripts which intelligently automate common Revit workflows. EnlargeElevatePlace This script automates creation of enlarged plans with elevations and places them on the sheet. It even places a callout around multiple selected rooms, and allows the user to select view templates for plans and elevations, elevation symbol, and a destination sheet. Real time saver and consistency champion! CADtoWalls Another Dynamo script shows the power of collaboration in Perkins&Will is CADtoWall. It was started by Jacob Werner from Boston office. Adam in collaboration with Jacob resolved many challenges. The script allows to intelligently convert CAD file to Revit walls. Not a trivial task‚Ä¶ It even recognizes and works around wall hosted elements like doors and windows and can create walls from curves. This script it gets you 80% from CAD file to real Revit walls, and Jacob with Adam are still perfecting and optimizing it, so get the latest version from them when you need to work on this task Perkins&Will Details Database Another great example of collaboration is a searchable online database of Perkins&Will details. This site collects drawings from past Perkins&Will Revit projects and delivers them in an online, searchable database. You can test drive it at Core.Aiprentice.com. It is now open to everyone at Perkins&Will! This site is the result of a close collaboration over the past year between the Digital Practice team and AiPrentice, a software developer. Our Technical Directors have taken the last few months to test drive the site and provide their input into how it can be used and how it should be developed. To add your office projects to the database, contact your office DA or Luc Deckinga (Digital Practice team). Please give it a spin and help steer this work in the right direction by sharing your ideas and comments! Below¬† one of possible workflows

title: VizR November eXchange ‚Äì Successful Project Pursuits using Virtual Galleries
content: Successful Project Pursuits using Virtual Galleries Presented by Alejandro Branger, Lorena Knezevic, and Damian Ponton In the Covid-19 Pandemic times, the need for social distancing has presented new challenges in project pursuits. How does a team maintain client engagement in virtual presentations and manage to stand out in an era of countless Zoom meetings? Alejandro Branger, Lorena Knezevic and Damian Ponton demonstrated how they created a virtual gallery to host a recent project pursuit for a new engineering and computing building at FIU. Members of the Florida International University selection committee were guided through a virtual gallery of wall mounted presentation boards, scale architectural models and wind and daylight analysis models all in real-time. This strategy proved to be effective and ultimately led to a critical project win for the team. The team wanted to create a more immersive experience than watching PowerPoint slides for their pitch, and decided to design a custom gallery where they can plan out the sequence of presentation, and layout all the visuals along the walls and in the space of the gallery, then virtually walk the client through the presentation inside this virtual gallery. The gallery space was built in Rhino, and rendered using Enscape, and presentation materials included 2D drawings and renderings that were brought into the gallery space and mounted on the walls as Decals. 3D design and analytical models were placed throughout the gallery space so they can showcase and walk around the models as they present and discuss the project design and analysis. Unlike using pre-canned animation, the real-time Enscape walk through provides the team the ability to jump around to different display in the space as needed,¬† to stop at a model and discuss specific topic when asked about it,¬† and thus making the presentation more engaging and memorable to the client. To learn more about this project, please follow the link below and watch the presentation recording. Click HERE to view the recording

title: Space Planning with Excel, Dynamo, and Revit
content: Create Program Blocks from an Excel Program Spreadsheet Many projects begin design exploration by validating the client‚Äôs program with blocking and stacking diagrams. Translating the program document, usually an Excel spreadsheet, into blocks sized to the desired program area is a time-consuming process. We have created a Revit and Dynamo workflow to do just that. Files will eventually be migrated up to this site, but can currently be found here: S:\_Firmwide\Dynamo\Scripts\DigitalPractice\ExcelSpacePlanning Excel Program Dynamo Script Revit Objects Previous Previous Previous Next Next Next Excel Program Document: The Program spreadsheet contains a list of spaces and their desired sizes. There are two different versions of the Dynamo script, one that produces a square footprint based on the area and one that allows you to define the length and width of the program element. You may have additional columns of information in addition to those used by the script: Space Name, Quantity, Deparment. Area Length x Width

title: Tech-a-thon recap
content: The various technology groups that support, innovate, and build tools for the firm met for a quick mini-hackathon innovation session last month.¬† ¬†We were paired up on teams that don‚Äôt typically work together on a daily basis.¬† ¬†Our goal was to come up with ideas and present them to some of our firm‚Äôs leaders to answer the question ‚ÄòHow can Technology help with talent enrichment?‚Äô¬† ¬†Below you can see the miro boards each team used to put together in 2 hours a problem statement and solution to that which might improve productivity, communication, culture, JEDI, mentoring, or engagement.¬† ¬†The recording of the shark tank type presentation we gave to our sharks can be found at the bottom to hear about these ideas. Team 6: Project Dashboard took first place in the competition with their solution to the problem of info and communication scattered everywhere needing to be centralized.¬† Let us know if any of these ideas strike you as highly valuable to your studio or project team. Team 01 Window into Workflow Dashboard of software use overlaid with project time. Team 02 Watercooler ‚Äì the organic/ephemeral app ‚Äì powered by AI Team 03 Among Designers ‚Äì modeled on Among Us Game ‚Äì impostor (design review) Team 04 Digital Playground ‚Äì a blackbox¬† in the studio Team 05 ThoughtSpot ‚Äì Structured knowledge seeking/providing Team 06 Project Dashboard ‚Äì Unified View of Project (in one place) Team 07 Token Time ‚Äì gamifying resources Team 08 MyCafe ‚Äì breakroom app Team 09 HEAR/Here ‚Äì spatial connections with Teams (organic) Team 010 DoWell ‚Äì app for connections and activities

title: Digital Practice 4th Quarter Core eXchange Recap
content: Digital Practice Core eXchange and Training Library Resources On October 13th through the 22nd Digital Practice team members and experts from around the firm completed another round of classes for our quarterly Digital Practice Core eXchange.¬† These continuing education sessions are designed to give our staff awareness and understanding of the tools and processes available to us at Perkins&Will. This quarter we had many new topics, as well as updating and improving many other topics from previous core exchanges.¬† Everyone was able to join the live sessions through Teams from wherever they are currently working and engage with the speakers to gain a better understanding in order to improve their work process. These live sessions were spread out over Tuesday, Wednesday, and Thursday for two consecutive weeks on our Teams channel for continuing education. If you weren‚Äôt able to make a session live or want to review one, you can find the recording in our ever-growing exchange library All sessions were registered for continuing education credits for you to meet your professional requirements through the AIA.¬† If you are part of another organization where you need continuing education units for your professional license you can typically self-report these classes but check with your organization for specific details.¬† ¬†The only limit is that you have to attend the classes live to gain course credit. The sessions are categorized by topics and you can view the recording and a slide deck and also connect with presenters for a follow-up discussion https://digitalpractice.perkinswill.com/digital-practice-exchange/#exchange-library We had many highly attended classes and engaging question and answer sessions with those attending.¬† ¬†Some new ones that are relevant to working from home are a couple of new topics around virtual engagement that looked further into the features of the Miro platform, and also a session on Bluebeam tips and tricks that had a big crowd in attendance. Overall this quarter‚Äôs exchange had just under 1800 total attendees for the 18 sessions which pushed our total attendance over the last year to just shy of 9000 employees attending a specific class over the 108 classes we have provided to the firm.

title: Enhancing our Virtual Pitches

author.name: Nick Cameron
author.description: American trucker who has been featured on the History channel reality television series Ice Road Truckers and its spinoff series IRT: Deadliest Roads.

content: Over the past few weeks, a small team has been working on how we can enhance our storytelling and showcase our innovation while presenting to clients via Teams, Zoom etc. We have found that folks in general struggle with the limitations of Microsoft Teams and Zoom functionality, and clients struggle with not being able to interpersonally connect with our team via the small Microsoft Teams or Zoom tiles. The big idea is to have the ability to control the virtual stage , similar to how we choregraph our movements when presenting to clients face-to-face. Our goals are 1)to control the size of the speaker image and enable rapid transition from one speaker to the next, 2) include more interactive events in presentations, such as ‚Äúlive sketching‚Äù, virtual model tours, and more, 3) create a easy to deploy audio/video kit of parts. Overall, we want Perkins&Will‚Äôs presentations to be innovatively presented, consistent with the quality of design and creativity our teams deliver once selected. To help resolve this, we have been collaborating with a production team who produce live/streaming events. Suffice to say, they are experts, and we have teamed up with them to craft a heightened experience. We have ‚Äúbattle‚Äù tested this technology twice, first for the firm wide Biennale Awards [below] and now with a mock interview which included an LA based Design team, with Zena Howard, Casey Jones & Gina Brendt as clients. Take a look at the final video below, and scrub through the timeline, there has been no post editing to this video, this was all done live in the interview. We now have the technology and process to include this type of presentation for our pursuit teams. For complex interviews we will need to continue utilizing the outside production team and depending on the complexities, the cost can vary. At the same time, we are developing inhouse resources so less complex meetings or events can be produced internally. To facilitate the enhanced nature of these productions we have also developed a new concept we call ‚ÄúStudio on a Stick‚Äù . This concept consists of everything you would need to capture high quality audio and video from remote locations as well as from home. The kit is designed to be easily delivered through mail and the lights are battery powered so it can be used in remote locations, such as onsite, a model shop or with other interesting backdrops. Email me if you have any comments or would like to discuss any upcoming pursuits.

title: Better in, Better out
content: A look at creating a high-quality presence in our virtual engagements through both analogue and digital tools. If we can‚Äôt present our best selves in person, we can present the highest quality video and audio virtually. Light is your friend A rguably the most important factor to influence a high-quality video experience is light. Simply put, the more light available, the better small digital sensors will handle your video. Whether it‚Äôs your internal webcam, a high-quality external webcam or a high-quality glass lens on a DLSR ‚Äì light matters. For my studio, I am situated in a small home office that has a floor to ceiling window. While I knew that window would provide great natural light, I also knew it would provide inconsistency throughout the day. Flat in the morning, and bright in the afternoon. I opted to install a fairly simple three-point lighting setup in my studio. And rather than use tripods which I would trip over every day, I installed ceiling mounts to hang the lights permanently. The premise with a three-point lighting setup is to have: a key light (the key source of light, typically brightest and closest to you ‚Äì left side of my face), a fill light (the light to balance the key, typically less bright and further away ‚Äì right side of my face), a hair light (a light situated behind my head, which provides a visual pop from my backdrop). This three-point light setup is tried and true and used in many studio photography and videography setups. And, with the right products, and location placement, are not bright in your eyes and are not hot to touch. Many people have asked me about ring lights or stand / webcam lights. I tend to shy away from them, as the actual light quality and impact is quite minimal, as well ‚Äì they are terribly uncomfortable to look at. In a pinch these solutions are ok, but not preferable for extended periods of time. What‚Äôs been so positive in having the three-point lighting setup, is no matter the time of day, my light is always consistent. And, with my floor to ceiling window, I can also choose to combine natural light with my overhead lights to changeup the visual appearance. I can control shadows, evenness, and other effects if desired. Your Camera Matters We all have different equipment. Some laptop webcams are more than sufficient, and some, are not. Having a high-quality camera provides you the opportunity not only to up-the-quality (resolution, sharpness and contrast), but also to have access to more comprehensive apps to control those settings. I opted go external with a Logitech Webcam. I change the settings almost daily, from zoom to exposure, brightness to saturation. An external webcam can be incredibly versatile and with a strong lighting setup, can be equally powerful. As the old saying goes, ‚ÄúThe best camera is the one you have with you.‚Äù This saying holds true when also speaking about webcams. The firm has access to an application you can install called iVcam, this app can turn your iPhone into a high resolution webcam. Sounding Good! One of the things I realized early in WFH was the importance of good audio. We‚Äôve all been in meetings where you couldn‚Äôt hear your colleague, or your client could hear you, or you can hear the trash truck picking up at your partner‚Äôs house. The importance of audio is paramount, possibly even more so than video. Not all microphones are created equal. Our laptop and webcam mics are typically omnidirectional, meaning, they pickup sound from everywhere. The baby crying, the dog drinking water ‚Äì or, even more incriminating, your typing (aka ‚Äúmultitasking‚Äù). I opted to increase the quality of my setup with a cardioid microphone, which by design picks up sound from the front and a little from the sides, but inherently not from the rear. It‚Äôs designed for vocal singing, or like what we do all day effectively ‚Äì podcasts. You can buy USB cardioid mics, or XLR in the event you have a more robust mixer and digital audio interface. In addition to the audio quality which comes from our microphones ‚Äì it‚Äôs equally important to hear each other well. Along those lines, our internal laptop speakers typically make it a challenge over the course of our 8-hour days to really hear well. External speakers are an easy way to dramatically improve your setup, and also, when combined with a more sophisticated digital audio interface can yield tremendous experiences to have our calls. Of course, we all have access to combination mic / headphones ‚Äì but who likes wearing these all day every day? Where can I download that Backdrop? I can‚Äôt tell you how many times I get asked this question. And, my answer is always the same ‚Äì it‚Äôs either ‚Äúmy wall‚Äù, or ‚Äúmy fabric‚Äù. All analogue, all the time. Rarely do I use a digital backdrop. Since my wife and daughter wouldn‚Äôt agree to me repainting my wall with charcoal grey, I retain the purple wall which was once the staple backdrop to a vibrant playroom for our daughter. Purple is nice. It changes tone throughout the day, in fact in the evening, it‚Äôs indiscernibly dark with my lighting setup. I prefer to have a plain color backdrop. I could‚Äôve added my personality to this by including my books, my drawings, artwork, etc., but I‚Äôve chosen my online presence to be minimal. I also opted to purchase foldable backdrops. I bought a chroma key green as well as a white backdrop. I use the green screen when I need to key out my backdrop (for dynamic or still backdrops, zoom interviews or OBS broadcasts). I use the white backdrop when I want a more welcoming ‚Äúpop‚Äù. And, I can change them by the hour, or by the day. Backdrops are an easy way to change things up and make a big impact. Like Photography ‚Äì the better your glass is, the better quality your photos will yield. Like Audio Recording ‚Äì the better your microphones and preamps, the better quality your audio recording will be. With WFH and having an online presence, I‚Äôm more excited about our analogue presence and the quality it delivers. Better in, better out. Products and Resources Lighting This video is the most comprehensive overview on three-point lighting. There are many LED lights on the market, a few we like are GVM LED lights for multiple uses at home or the studio especially with these ceiling mounts . For adjustable and powerful light For a portable solution Camera The Logitec Brio is the camera to get, but has had supply chain challenges due to Covid . Why not use your iphone ? You can, click here and ask for an iVCam install. Microphone / Speakers BlueMic make some amazing microphones including this one , and probably best in class Yeti Nano . In conjunction with a mixer and digital audio interface, professional podcasting can be achieved. Some folks have asked about lapel mics ‚Äì can also be a great addition and allow you to take the pesky airpods out of your ears. This one is a good one , and can be used with your laptop or iphone . If you have a upcoming interview and need equipment, please reach out to Nick Cameron and Al Anderson

title: 2020 Computational Design Case Study ‚Äì Suzhou Science + Technology Museum ‚Äì Weaving a Complex Facade
content: Suzhou Science + Technology Museum ‚Äì Weaving a Complex Facade Design Investigation Exploring the Weaving Pattern The Suzhou Science + Technology Museum project began as a design competition entry that emphasized the region‚Äôs historical use of silk for textiles through a fluid form with a ‚Äúwoven‚Äù facade pattern. Upon winning the competition, the challenge began with how to technically achieve this woven facade pattern in a rational manner. One of the first challenges was finding a way to simplify the doubly curved surface into fairly regular panel sizes to reduce the amount of unique panels required for fabrication. Grasshopper was used as the tool to both rationalize this surface and quickly test different facade patterns that could invoke the ‚Äúweaving‚Äù notion. Project Area Ciric + Cultural Office Chicago Project Suzhou Science + Technology Museum Team Ralph Johnson Thomas Mozina Marius Ronnett Aashit Shah Danny Mui Neil Rendel Ryan Fagre Tools Rhino Grasshopper Download Workflow 1 Above ‚Äì Each color represents a unique panel size 2 After these initial studies, it became clear the client desired the facade to look closer to the competition entry of weaving panels. We took a step back and re-evaluated how we might be able to break down the facade in a rational way that could also achieve this look. This led us to investigating how we could take a simple grid and create a tessellated pattern within that grid. 3 In the end, we were able to achieve a weaving facade pattern with around 10 unique panels. With this logic established, the final test for us was to have a mock-up created to ensure that this design could be achievable.

title: VizR October eXchange ‚Äì Getting to Most from the Matterport Platform
content: Getting the Most from the Matterport Platform For our October VizR eXchange, Dan Creekmore, Director of Perkins&Will‚Äôs VizLab, presented an overview of Matterport along with project team examples using Matterport from around the firm. Followed by a short Architectural Photography 101 tips. Using Matterport platform, one can capture 3D spaces and makes it easy to share it as an immersive experience, very much like the Google street view but for interior spaces . There are many ways to capture the 3D space into Matterport, one is not limited to using only the Matterport Pro device. In fact, you can even capture using an iphone device using Matterport app. Matterport can be used for existing condition survey and project site progress reports. The resulting images are not only navigable like the Google street view, you can even take measurement and get close up view of the space. One can create a custom virtual tour that is easily shareable with client and consultants, this is especially helpful during Pandemic times where on site visits are not always possible. For the second half of the session, Dan offered some very helpful tips for Architectural Photography. On how to setup a scene, take multiple exposure HDR photographs, and how to post edit the shots to merge different exposure images to achieve the best results. View the presentation below- Matterport: 00:16 ‚Äì 41:40 Architectural Photography 101: starts at 41:40

title: Pedestrian Simulation
content: Let‚Äôs Talk About Pedestrian Simulation and Pathfinding Pedestrian simulation is a powerful tool that can help us better understand how people move through and use the spaces that we design. Pathfinding can help us minimize lines of access to critical points in our plans (i.e. fire stairwells). In the past these sorts of simulations were relegated to highly specialized platforms. Fortunately we‚Äôve developed a grasshopper workflow that will allow everyone to integrate pathfinding and pedestrian simulation into their early schematic designs fairly easily and rapidly. A Few Things Before You Jump Into Pathfinding Simulation This tool is built primarily on Mouse. You will need to install it before you run the script. The Mouse plugin will be included in the download below. Install Mouse Have a Prepped Rhino Model Give the Tool a few Seconds to Run Getting Started Layer Watching: The script is setup such that it actively watches your rhino layers for the appropriate input to run so make sure to just add the required geometry types into their respective layer. Floor Surface Start Points Destination Points Settings Previous Previous Previous Next Next Next Floor Surface: Should be a single surface that mimics the floor slab minus any interior walls or inaccessible zones. Start: These are your starting points. So anywhere pedestrians would be coming into the building (elevator bays, stairs, exterior doors, etc.). These should be points . Start Points are designated by a cyan pin marker Destination: These are the desired destinations. Also should be points . Start Points are designated by a magenta dot marker Grid Size: This dictates the simulation grid size. A 1 foot grid is a pretty good balance between performance and accuracy. You can step it down to half a foot if you need more accuracy but keep in mind that it will take a little longer to run. Run Toggle: Toggling this to True will start the simulation. Do this once you‚Äôve set the grid size. Visualizations The tool currently produces four types of diagrams: A Heat Map A Heat Graph A Simulated Route Display A Travel Distance Diagram All you need to do is print any view of the diagram you want to either an image or PDF to use it in your presentations! Heat Map Heat Graph Route Display Travel Distance Previous Previous Previous Next Next Next The Heat Map is a generated graphic that represents pedestrian foot traffic and paints the floor from Red (more foot traffic) to Blue (little to no foot traffic). Th Heat Graph is a three dimensional version of the Heat Map. The Taller the bar the more foot traffic. It‚Äôs very useful when you‚Äôre looking to visualize the data and you have solid walls. The Route Display is a very simple visualization. It simply displays all possible pedestrian paths given the Start and Destinations. The Travel Distance diagram is probably the most crucial visualization. It paints each path based on the travel distance and allows you to easily visualize the most severe or extreme cases. If you run into any problems or have any questions please feel free to hop into the Computational Design Channel and ask! You can download v1 of the script here: Download Now

title: 2020 Computational Design Case Study ‚Äì Bell Museum Reflection Analysis
content: Suzhou Science + Technology Museum ‚Äì Weaving a Complex Facade Design Investigations Will a curved mirror concentrate heat from the sun? To make sure we wouldn‚Äôt have heat problems caused by a curved mirror inside the Bell Museum we simulated the sun position over an entire year to find out if any areas will become perceptibly warmer because of concentrated reflections? Will a shiny roof blind the neighbors? An analysis was run to find which days and times the sun would reflect off of a proposed Galvalume roof and onto the neighboring building. Project Area CCC Office Minneapolis Project Bell Museum Team Luc Deckinga Tools Rhino Grasshopper Download Workflow Solar Reflection Analysis 1 (Interior) A 3D grid of voxels (that‚Äôs fancy talk for ‚Äòboxes‚Äô) is built on the walkway next to the wall. Sun rays are projected against the mirror and reflected back through the voxel grid. Voxels turn a warmer color as more rays go through them. Green areas in the above images have no concentrated heat effect, increasing to yellow, and eventually red. The center image (Curved in 1 Direction) is representative of our actual condition in the Bell Museum, confirming the inhabitants are safe from spontaneous combustion. Diagrams below show areas that would receive concentrated reflections off of a surface that is: Flat, Curved in 1 direction, Curved in 2 directions Solar Radiation Analysis 2 (Exterior) Investigation: We used the same sun simulation method to discover if we will hit the apartment building on the adjacent site with sunlight reflected off of the shiny Galvalume roof. Result: All reflections onto the apartment building occur before 9 am, which the design team determined is acceptable. Below: An analysis was run to find which days and times the sun would reflect off of the Galvalume roof and onto the neighboring building.

title: BIM Guidelines (PDM Chapter 11)
content: Last month Digital Practice in collaboration with experts around the firm has published the updated and revised BIM Guidelines (PDM Chapter 11). You can find it under Resources>QuickStart Guides on digitalpractice.perkinswill.com This document consists of two parts: BIM Process Management in Perkins&Will and Revit Guidelines. The goal of this document is to give PW staff an overall understanding of the BIM process and Revit resources in Perkins&Will without going into picks and clicks of Revit as a tool. Please use additional resources: Microknowledge cards , eXchange training library , Digital Practice Office hours , and your office DA resources for specific questions and more in-depth focused training. For a guided tour of BIM guidelines, watch the video below This is a living document, and we think about it as Version 1. Please feel free to suggest edits¬† on the site ‚Äì we will review them periodically. Alternatively, you can reach out to your DA for clarifications.

title: Kaizen ‚Äì Virtual Process Design with Miro
content: Throughout this pandemic period, the way we collaborate has drastically changed.¬† Since the nature of our work involves a team of individuals, we have adapted to technologies, tools, and platforms that facilitate the necessary communication required to produce the quality we did when we were all in the office together.¬† We have done this successfully through virtual meetings and leveraging cloud resources like BIM360 and Sharepoint. Remember (pre-pandemic) those large project meetings with designers, consultants, clients, stakeholder, etc. with everyone in the room and we all discuss and document important decisions on a project.¬† We had plans, renderings, and diagrams pinned up on the walls.¬† A project manager documented decisions, brainstorming, and ideas on large blank sheets of paper with a marker.¬† Others would write suggestions on sticky notes and place it on a wall in the conference room.¬† At the end of the day, a lot was discussed and resolved, and progress was made on the project.¬† How can we achieve this without being in the same place?¬† How can we adapt to a virtual process that gives us similar results? With certain whiteboarding platforms like Miro , facilitating these meetings can be (in some ways) better than it was in person.¬† We recently had a call with University of Chicago, one of our healthcare clients, and discussed taking one of their regular events called Kaizen and making it virtual. Kaizen is a Japanese term meaning ‚Äúchange for the better‚Äù or ‚Äúcontinuous improvement.‚Äù¬† These meetings are usually in-person and involved 30-40 people, some of which travel from great distances to attend.¬† We were able to show them how Kaizen could be done virtually within a single Miro board.¬† All attendees would connect initially via Teams or Zoom meeting and link to the Miro board is posted in the chat.¬† Within one minute, all attendees are in the Miro board and navigating around the different areas which would basically be a digital representation of those large pieces of paper that you would have pinned up on the walls.¬† Each attendee can give input by placing sticky notes and typing text.¬† The project manager is still doing the job of keeping all attendees engaged in activities while another team member organizes content or documents good ideas being heard on the call.¬† The Miro board is versatile, and can show images, panoramic renderings, PDFs, Matterport scans, excel files, and many other file types.¬† There are also several templates for creating mind maps and simple diagrams on the fly.¬† For some mass interaction, we had some mentimeter polls accessible via QR code where people could respond with their smartphone.¬† At the end of the meeting, lots of decisions, ideas, etc. were documented and organized, and a digital version of the Miro board is captured and distributed to the attendees.¬† This condensed digital version is much better than the 40 photos you took of the conference room with the in-person meeting.¬† In the end, the client was very impressed at our innovative use of technology seamless integration with our expertise and ideas.

title: Learn About the September 2020 Performance Design on Circadian Daylighting
content: Presenters Tyrone Marshall gave a presentation with Marcelo Bernal and Cheney Chen during the September Performance Design Session on Circadian Daylighting Design Performance. Learning Objectives Understand the benefits of the natural sleep/wake cycles of the human body to mitigate the adverse effects of electric lighting that can positively affect occupants‚Äô health, alertness, and productivity. Learn the importance of how circadian daylighting can improve your project design Learn about the performance criteria related to circadian daylighting that you can incorporate into your project design Learn about the standards that address the use of circadian daylighting. title: San Francisco Fall 2020 Training Series Library

Topics will range from Rhino Basics, Rhino Conveyor, Rhino Analysis and Simulation, Matterport, two sessions of Intro to QA and QC with Sharon Lahr, Intro to Specs with Sharon Lahr, and finally Intro to Sustainable Concepts with Dalton Ho. title: Learn About the August 2020 Performance Design on Passive Design and Energy
content: Presenters: Tyrone Marshall gave an AIA approved presentation with Cheney Chen during the August Performance Design Session on Basic Building Energy Model Design Performance. Learning Objectives Learn the importance of incorporating building envelope characteristics and passive design strategies early in your design Identify passive design strategies to improve building energy performance Understand the concept of baseline and proposed design case for energy models Learn how to get your project on the path towards successful compliance modeling. Course Description The built environment uses nearly 36% of annual energy consumption and creates approximately 39% of all annual global greenhouse gas emissions, which leads to various climate-related hazards and health-related complications. The building sector has the highest potential for energy efficiency, consequently, it is essential to find ways to reduce load, increase efficiency, and utilize renewable energy resources in all types of buildings. This class will discuss the strategies for the design of your building relative to sustainability goals for whole-building energy simulation and design. The class will help you improve your project related to the massing and building envelope criteria to reduce the impact on operational energy use and carbon footprint. It also introduces a proprietary tool from Perkins&Will, called Simulation in Performance Energy Efficiency Design (SPEED), that provides accurate performance feedback and design information for various alternatives of your design. 1 AIA CES LU HSW Credits and LEED Self-Reporting Interactive Performance Design Strategies Matrix The matrix shows you the primary architectural dependent energy conservation measures with a direct relationship to a specific passive design strategy. Try it for yourself at the link here: Passive Design Matrix Excerpts from the Session Content Site Energy and Source Energy Discussion U.S. Electricity Grid Trending Towards a Rise in Non-Carbon and Natural Gas Sources Impact of Climate Change on Thermal Comfort 2020, 2050, 2080 Impact of Heating and Cooling Demand for Different Climate Zones for a Hospital Passive Design Energy Conservation Measures and Strategies Matrix Baseline EUI Discussion

title: Design and other software availability
content: A few weeks back we have released the latest update to Rhino 6 which should help reduce errors and bugs you may have experienced in some of your workflows.   You will find v6.28 in software center to install.   It is suggested to always get on the latest version of each application you typically use to increase performance and stability and reduce errors and downtime.  To help support our design workflows a Conveyor update has been made available that in addition to small improvements will also function with Revit 2021.   The final update to the rhino ecosystem is an updated version of Vray for Rhino which you can also find in software center. It is suggested that you run these updates at the end of your workday to allow for the additional time it takes for installation to run in our work from home situation.   Always check back in on the installation progress to make sure you press yes or next to move installation progress forward and finally always always always restart before or after any installation process to reduce problems. In addition to Revit and Max 2021 being available, you will find the newest version of AutoCAD LT 2021 and Navisworks 2021 in software center for self-install and on all comp nodes that still remain in our network.   Should you need other Autodesk 2021 tools, we have regular AutoCAD 2021 and AutoCAD Architecture 2021 available for unique needs as well as Autodesk Vehicle Tracker 2021 for layout out turning radius and parking lots and docks for our designs.   We also have had Autodesk SketchBook Pro 2021 in software center for most of the summer for those looking for a digital hand drawing tool to support the virtual workflows our teams are using now.   You will need the proper hardware to effectively use this software and the digital pen that makes it work properly.  Finally, we have an update to the Autodesk dwg file viewer that will open any cad file you want to view.   This remains the default program for any dwg file that is double-clicked to open on your laptop. There is also a long list of other products Autodesk makes available to us each year that is very specialized and rarely utilized given the other tools and workflows our firm has in place.   However, if you should need anything else please submit a request at help@perkinswill.com in order to engage someone to help you get anything installed.

title: Max 2021 and Deadline render farm update
content: The newest version of Max available September 14 As we make Revit 2021 available to the firm this also brings the release of 3ds Max and other Autodesk 2021 titles.   This will be available on the comp nodes as well as found in software center for self-installation on your MSI laptop.   In order to make this function with our existing render farm, we will be updating the deadline platform to support Max 2021 on September 18th .  Also to help support our rendering workflows we are getting some licenses of the newest release of V-Ray for 3ds Max.  Also for those of you that use the iToo addins RailClone or ForestPack, those are being updated to also function with Max 2021. Installation The installations for Max, Vray, and RailClone will all be found in software center to self install at your convenience and need.   Be aware that there is a need for plenty of free space on your laptop to get these all downloaded to install as we work from home.   Also please allow ample time for the download process (and installation) to occur which will vary based on your location related to our cloud servers and your internet speeds.   Expect this to take multiple hours to go through the whole process, first to download then to click yes to proceed with the installation itself.   Also if you intend to install Revit 2021 on your laptop the amount of cache available with this installation system won‚Äôt support you install that and Max on the same day due to how Microsoft manages data resources. If you are having any issues with your installations from software center try restarting your laptop and trying again during off-hours.    If that doesn‚Äôt work submit a help request to help@perkinswill.com New Features Max‚Äôs main strengths are really adopting the physically based rendering (PBR) workflow with the new render independent physical material. Hopefully, this starts to solve the universal material workflow we‚Äôve been seeking. Max now also includes the Substance plugin as part of the install, and these even further the universal material workflow. Max also has some updates to the chamfer modified which helps smooth edges on objects and this does it in a more effective manner. The chamfer is no longer ‚Äúbaked‚Äù into the geometry so you can modify it on the fly. The weighted normals modifier helps smooth out the appearance of curved surfaces without having to potentially rebuild the geometry. Vray 5‚Äôs main strengths are light mixer and layer compositing directly in the Vray Frame buffer. Essentially this workflow aims to remove as much of the noodling in Photoshop and be able to deliver HQ images directly from Vray.  You don‚Äôt have to rerender if you want change the look of your scene through lighting, you can now just adjust light values right in the interface without going to post-production tools. What is coming for your visualization needs iToo plugins update to be compatible with Max 2021 Vray 5 for Max licensing and installation availability All render farm machines will have Max 2021 and the associated addins listed installed Deadline will be updated on Friday, September 18th starting at 9:30 Eastern, 8:30 Central, 7:30 Mountain, 6:30 Pacific, 10:30 Sao Paulo, 2:30 AM (Saturday) London, 3:30 AM (Saturday) Denmark, 9:30 AM (Saturday) Shanghai.

title: Newforma v12 update
content: Newforma 12.4 update on September 11 Newforma releases small updates from time to time but because of our firm‚Äôs size and Newforma infrastructure we don‚Äôt update all the time.   It has now come a time that we will update going from v12.2 to v12.4.   This may seem like a small jump but it will introduce a few new features and compatibility that will make Newforma work better for those that need to use it.   This update will be occurring this Friday evening (Saturday early morning in some locations). This maintenance window will begin at the following times where our desktop clients and servers will no longer work till updated and the info exchange website will be unavailable to everyone on any team external to our organization (or internal) till all updates are completed. 6:30 PM Pacific 7:30 PM Mountain 8:30 PM Central 9:30 PM Easter 10:30 PM Sao Paulo 2:30 AM London (Saturday) 3:30 AM Denmark (Saturday) 9:30 AM Shanghai (Saturday) We expect this update to take a couple of hours for the server updates with some of the larger offices taking a majority of the evening.   This maintenance outage time all depends on the number of projects in each local studio and their database size.   You current version of Newforma will no longer connect to the servers once this happens. Installation There is very little you will have to do in order to get the new desktop client.   Please restart your laptop at the end of the day on Friday and leave it plugged in and on when you walk away for the day.   At a minimum, you must close the Newforma desktop application and Outlook for it to properly automatically update.   The install will happen silently in the background beginning around those maintenance window times listed above.   You may run into issues if you haven‚Äôt restarted your laptop recently and have pending windows updates waiting.   If you have not used Newforma in the last 3 months then we will simply be removing the application from your laptop.  You will still have the ability to choose to install it from software center on your laptop at any point in the future should you need it again. If you are having any issues with the Newforma Outlook addin after the upgrade try restarting your laptop, after logging back in opening the Newforma desktop application, then opening Outlook.    If that doesn‚Äôt work submit a help request to help@perkinswill.com New Features User Interface One of the most noticeable items you will see after the upgrade is the slight change to the colors and icons in the interface.   With a couple of exceptions, it is all the same buttons in the same places but it will look new and fresh at first. One other noticeable change to the user interface will be the project home dashboard which gives you visibility of the status of various activities are items coming due for response.   If you don‚Äôt want to see quick status info on your project activities that you can filter there is a toggle button in to change it back to just the normal activity list we have always been used too. Connection to Procore is on the horizon.   We are working with IT to but some infrastructure in place in the background in order for us to enable connections between a Procore project and the Newforma project to automate moving RFI and submittal information back and forth between the two platforms. Updates to email notifications HTML5 Outlook add-in to function with Office 365 online interface and smart email filing functions Better backend functionality with email filing BIM360 integration to view, search and manage files from your cloud project to connect items from your BIM360 project to activity items in your Newforma project Functionality with Revit 2021 Updates to mobile apps for iOS13 An updated user interface to the Newforma info exchange web interface (same icons as the desktop client) Set global fonts for all forms

title: VizR September eXchange
content: Innovative Virtual Presentation using Enscape and OBS This month, Mario and his ACAW team, Ted Hogan, Angelica Paleczny & Juliette Zidek, joined us on the VizR eXchange to share the unique way they presented their Terra Cotta panel design for the ACAW (Architectural Ceramic Assemblies Workshop) final presentation. As the annual in-person event turned virtual, our Perkins & Will team proposed a virtual 3D gallery model that all the participating firms can use to present their project in realtime using Enscape. On top of the 3D Gallery, our team used OBS studio (Open Broadcaster Software) and OBS Ninja to create a smooth streamlined virtual presenation that put our presenters front and center, while providing a common screen that showcased either the powerpoint or the 3D model live walkthrough, without ever having to switch presenters, or jump between screens and intefere with the presentation flow, thus providing a smooth and unified presentation that is both engaging and entertaining. The 3D gallery was designed as a nonagon (nine sided polygon) with a center space for common gathering. Nine firms participated in the workshop, and each firm has a wing of gallery space to showcase their design. Teams were able to be free of the typical limitation of budget and gravity, and be as creative as they want in creating their exhibition space. One thing our team wanted to avoid was any suggestion of the ‚Äúuncanny valley‚Äù, where things looks quite wrong because it is impossible in our world. So to help the viewer maintain the connection to reality, our team made sure that our display respected the rule of gravity such as creating pedestal to hold up the small model objects, and back ties that ties the ceramic samples onto the wall. Perkins&Will team‚Äôs presentation at ACAW event Here is the LINK to the powerpoint presentation on how they put the innovative presentation together, For more details on the actual ACAW presentation, click HERE to read the article Mario wrote about the event.

title: Revit 2021 and Friends
content: Revit 2021 available September 14th Each year our firm goes through extensive testing and preparations before we make the newest version of our primary documentation platform, Revit available for project teams.   We are at the time of the year that the Digital Practice team now releases the newest Revit for ALL new projects to start from.   Beginning Monday, September 14th you will find Revit 2021 installed on all of our remaining computational nodes and for those with MSI laptops, you will see it available in software center to self-install.  It is a large application to install and most of you will be installing it from home so I would suggest running it at the end of the day to allow for a few hours for the download time (which may vary based on your home internet speeds) and the installation.   In addition to Revit 2021 being available all other typically used Autodesk applications 2021 versions will be made available on the computational nodes and in software center as well.   3ds Studio Max, Navisworks, AutoCAD LT, AutoCAD and Vehicle Tracker, AutoCAD Architecture, and Sketchbook Pro can be self-installed and utilized.   In addition to new features in these programs year after year, the development teams at Autodesk work on fixing bugs and improving stability and speed for us which is another reason to always stay current. Each team should also make plans accounting for their project schedule and external partners to find a time to upgrade.   Fortunately, in BIM360 it is literally the click of a button.   More importantly, is that all models for your project will need to be upgraded at the same time to continue to allow everyone functionality of linking to all necessary information from each model.   All new projects should strategize to begin from the start in Revit 2021. Installation Another small change to how you get everything that comes with Revit is in the installer.   Previously Revit and every addin we have access to would be installed on every computational node that many people were using to get their Revit work done.  This will still be the case for the computational nodes remaining and the designers using them for Revit through the node selector.   However, for those of you installing Revit 2021 on your laptop, the basic install with Revit 2021.1 will include e-transmit, the basic CTC tools, the PW tools, and the Clarity client.   All other addins we have like Hive content library, CTC SuperDoor Configurator, Keynote Manager, JO Tools Transfer Project Standards, the pyRevit suite of tools, Metamorphosis model comparison, View AQC, and Autodesk Insight 360 analysis tool will all be separate installers from software center so you only install what you need.   This will prevent you from having to update an addin that you don‚Äôt use.   You can always come back and install any of these later when you have a need for them.   One other thing to be aware of with this work from home installations through software center is that not only do you have to account for a longer time frame to get applications installed but you have to have enough free space on your MSI laptop in order to do the installation.   You should have at least 40 GB of free space available on your laptop in order to install any of the Autodesk 2021 software packages.   You will also see the installation options for these Revit 2021 addins by using the software center filter at the top which will present all of them together for you so they are easy to find. New Features PDF & Raster Image Linking In previous Revit versions your only option was to Import these file types. The ability to link is a much welcomed feature. Where importing embeds files into the project, linking allows you to path to external files. This should help reduce your models file size, improve general model speed, and enhance graphic stability. The new Manage Links dialog In Manage Links, you will have two new tabs for PDFs and Images. Another cool feature here is we can path both of these file types to BIM360 just like DWG and Revit models. It is recommended that you host PDFs and Images on BIM360 for optimal collaboration and to make broken links a thing of the past. Shared Views Shared Views tool can be found on the Collaborate tab. Once toggled on, the Shared Views pane appears on screen. Comments and markups are visible inside Revit‚Ä¶ Shared Views are for rapid sharing of views which can be marked up and commented on for team coordination. These views can be accessed from inside the Revit modeling environment or through Autodesk Viewer, a free web-based viewer. This web interface allows for orbiting, view filtering, walkthroughs, markups, and comments. Each individual shared view comes with a unique URL which can be shared with anyone. The web viewer is nearly identical to the BIM360 model viewer. However, this feature holds promise and already seems to be a more viable method for design based coordination since the views and commenting are integrated into Revit itself. There are a few limitations to Shared Views: You can only create a shared view from a 3D camera view or axon so no plan views or detail views can be shared. Can be shared with outside parties, but they will not be able to markup or comment without signing up for a free Autodesk account. The Shared View pane is not project specific. Meaning it will show you all of the views that you have created or have been shared with you regardless of the project model you are currently in. Shared views expire after 30 days. But you can extend them in the web viewer. Slanted Walls Perhaps the biggest architectural design addition is Slanted Walls. Walls have two new instance parameters, ‚ÄúCross-Section‚Äù where you can change the default value from Vertical to Slanted. If Slanted is selected the new ‚ÄúAngle From Vertical‚Äù parameter will appear. A positive angle will slope the wall towards the interior and a negative angle will cant the wall out to the exterior. You can slant basic walls, stacked walls, and curtain walls. However, slanted Curtain walls have limited functionality. They cannot host door panels, they cannot be embedded into other slanted wall types, and adding mullion grids after slant is not user friendly. Elements hosted in a slanted wall, like Windows and Doors, will get a new ‚ÄúOrientation‚Äù parameter to specify whether you want them to follow the slant or to remain vertical. Left, slanted window. Right, vertical window (default.) In plan view, we see an accurate but distorted depiction. In summary, the slanted walls feature is long overdue but still lacks some usability. However, we may see some better functionality in future releases. Remember, it works best for basic walls and stacked walls but slanting curtain walls is clunky and doesn‚Äôt host door panels properly. For curtain walls and complex geometry, keep using mass with Wall by Face. Or Rhino with Conveyor. Generative Design Generative Design tools can be found on the Manage tab. The new generative design tool is basically Dynamo with a face lift. This is Autodesk‚Äôs first iteration of this feature so it is half-baked but may have potential. The current drawbacks are that the user interface is not very intuitive and the pre-loaded design studies are not relevant to our design work. Running generative design studies does not incur additional cost so feel free to test it out! In addition there are many other small improvements to Revit 2021: BIM360 opening and sync times 30% faster with 2021 models. Resetting Shared Coordinates tool allows you to break the relationship between files after coordinates have already been shared. All in-program dialog boxes are now re-sizable. Be sure to check out the Project Parameters dialog. Schedules have more functionality like zoom, freeze header, and row striping. Filters can now be enabled/disabled with a checkbox. This fix allows you better control filters without having to remove them from VG/view template. 90 new Dynamo nodes. Exporting models to native .STL filetype is now possible without installing add-ins.

title: ACAW 2020
content: ACAW 2020 This year Perkins&Will was invited to participate in the Architectural Ceramic Assemblies Workshop. The workshop‚Äôs main objective is to introduce and consider the properties of terra cotta earlier in the architect‚Äôs design process and to develop research and design models between manufacturing and architectural industries useful to the efficient production of high-performance facade solutions. It traditionally consisted of 3 separate phases: Design Phase : Between November and April all teams would work through their designs. This included having weekly calls with the ACAW coordinators and Boston Valley Terra Cotta. Fabrication Phase : Between April and Early August the teams work with the fabricators at Boston Valley Terra Cotta to optimize their designs and begin to fabricate. Workshop : In mid-August all teams would have flown to BVTC‚Äôs facilities to assemble their VMU‚Äôs and a showcase/presentation would have occurred. Unfortunately, due to the current pandemic we were not able to do this. We did, however, participate in a digital version and we had created a virtual exhibition space for our final designs. The Team The Participants Adrian Smith + Gordon Gill Architecture Handel Architects Kohn Pedersen Fox LMN Architects Pelli Clarke Pelli Architects PLP Architecture Skidmore, Owings & Merrill The Big Question What are the limits to controlling water flow on a vertical facade system? Intent and Precedent Sketching Through Possibilities As we experimented with different ways we could capture or control water we were also testing potential grid options for our panel. It was an interplay of geometry and surface articulation that was the primary driver of the panel design. Constant Iteration As we experimented with different ways we could capture or control water we were also testing potential grid options for our panel. It was an interplay of geometry and surface articulation that was the primary driver of the panel design. Water Flow Concept Conceptually the desire was to somehow control the flow of water across our panel design. Initially we had thought of also manipulating the glazing to some extent to achieve this control as well. With the design of a 3-point connecting system we knew we could create a consistent surface upon which water could flow. Surface Articulation Conceptually the desire was to somehow control the flow of water across our panel design. Initially we had thought of also manipulating the glazing to some extent to achieve this control as well. With the design of a 3-point connecting system we knew we could create a consistent surface upon which water could flow. Final Iteration The module‚Äôs evolution started with the desire to create a panel based on a 60 degree axis for consistent connection points. As the shape and definition of module became more defined, that connection and base geometries remained consistent. Orthographic Drawings Sections Structure We integrated 6 tapered support legs on the back of each panel. Each one of those tapered support legs then had offset holes removed from them such that we could thread through 1/4‚Ä≥ threaded rods and still allow full clearance of those rods. This meant that we could theoretically support or mount the panels in any configuration (horizontal, vertical, or hexagonal). 1 2 3 4 5 6 1 Tapered Support Leg 2 Silicone Footing 3 1/4‚Äù Threaded Rod 4 Bolt and Silicone Ring 5 Silicone Edge 6 Silicone Tongue Glazing Glazing and coloration was also very meticulously considered. Even from the beginning we thought of our design as a product. Something that could be mass customized and produced. Working with Boston Valley we pinpointed one glazing sample but produced a wide array of palettes . Form Glaze 1 Glaze 2 Resisted Previous Previous Previous Next Next Next By using the actual physical module, instead of the digital, any discrepancies caused during the terracotta‚Äôs shrinkage are able to be accounted for. The first glaze is applied at the inner portions of the module exposed by the resist. All other exposed areas of module are shielded, using the resist as guide. The second glaze is applied at the outer portions of the module exposed by the resist. The inner portions of the module with glaze 1 are now shielded to prevent any overlaps in glazes. The resist can now be removed and the module can be fired once more. Fabrication A majority of the fabrication is happening at a facility known as the Matter Factory out of Kansas City. We‚Äôve gotten a few process photos that we‚Äôre incredibly excited about! Overall the the VMU is coming togther. Making the Mold Slipcasting the Panel Digital Workshop Presentation Ultimately we could not meet our peers physically but we did have the opportunity to assemble a digital space to showcase all of our hard work. Below you can see the small center space online. If you‚Äôd like to get a more expansive view of the workshop, feel free to download and run the enscape model using the button on the right. Download Model

title: Design and Delivery August eXchange
content: I did not have to sleep under my desk Dahmahlee Lawrence We discussed two very interesting topics at our August Design and Delivery Exchange : Utilizing Groups for detailing in Revit Deliver Differently¬† ‚Äì CHoP¬† facade adaptive components from design to fabrication A detail group example for detailing masonry in plan Philip Chase shared Houston studio approach to detailing using the detail groups. The detail components and other graphic elements are grouped by the type of detail forming a ‚Äúkit of parts‚Äù and can be inserted using Hive. Since they are developed in the same container file, the visual language is consistent, and because they are grouped, you get everything you need in a particular detail in one collection without searching for individual components and ‚Äúborrowing‚Äù from other projects! You are probably familiar with Children Hospital of Philadelphia project: we talked about its computational parametric wall earlier here and here . In addition to many benefits realized during design process, we now can confidently say that precision of self-documenting parametric approach enabled worry-free reliable manufacturing of complex panels Complex geometry worked well all the way from design to documentation, fabrication and installation, Perkins&Will modeling helped in virtually removing geometry questions Rapid design iteration were fast and painless. I could go home at the end of the day and I did not have to sleep under my desk. By Dahmahlee Lawrence A good example of work smarter, not harder Link to the video is HERE

title: Clarity 2021 Upgrade ‚Äì Coming Friday August 28th
content: Clarity is the firm‚Äôs tool to automate repetitive tasks on Revit projects. In addition to automating our output tasks like printing, Clarity can also run model comparison reports and/or visualization, run model metrics to help improve the quality and stability of your project models and automate other tasks using Macros or Dynamo scripts. As we move past the upgrade and you now have all the new features in your hand, one I would like to point out is the ability to identify problem model events so we can track and analyze the data to help us collectively focus our efforts to prevent downtime from Revit issues.   On the home page of your clarity project, you can find a pencil symbol in the upper right of the screen that gives you a drop-down menu where you can choose ‚Äòreport model event‚Äô.   When doing this you will be prompted to fill in a few fields so that we can look at the model data from that point in time and compare it with other people having model issues to find the patterns and elements that cause Revit to misbehave. Clarity will be unavailable during the upgrade process, which begins Friday, August 28th at 9:30pm Eastern, 8:30pm Central, 7:30pm Mountain, 6:30pm Pacific time and overnight (or into Saturday morning) at our international locations around the globe. Please plan accordingly with your project needs as you will have to run prints manually during this time frame if you are trying to meet a deadline.  We will begin pausing servers and tasks 30 minutes prior to the outage to let the system cleanout.   Any task in the queue that hasn‚Äôt started will continue to run after the upgrade (unless it is on Revit 2017). This version of Clarity features many new enhancements including: Functionality with Revit 2021 More functionality and integration with BIM360 hosted models Tracking problem models and their metrics to identify future problem models Navisworks file conversion tasks Workset specific tasks on BIM360 In addition to the new features listed here, there are more that you can view¬†from the clarity help page here . We have been using Clarity for over 5 years now and it has saved the firm over 400,000 hours which equates to about 42 full-time employees for those 4 years.¬† Hopefully, this time was repurposed back to design tasks on all those projects by the team. Even with all that time saving we still don‚Äôt have all teams taking full advantage of this tool. Please work with your local Design Applications Manager or GTS support to set up your project in clarity is simple.¬† ¬†All you need to tell them in a help request is the path to your central files. After that is completed, it will only take about 10 minutes to get your typical project printing tasks set up and running. Please be aware that this upgrade means that the functionality of clarity will NO LONGER WORK WITH REVIT 2017 MODEL FILES (and older). If your project is in 2017 and going to continue on for a good amount of time please coordinate with your local design applications manager as well as your external project team members that work with your revit model file and consider an upgrade plan.
