title: Real Time Simulation Available Now
content: A new real-time daylighting simulation system that provides feedback as fast as you can design your project! ¬†Climate Studio takes advantage of our high-performance laptops and cutting edge software to deliver quick GPU-powered daylight simulations for pursuits, early design, late design, and compliance modeling for LEED V4 Daylight Credits and the WELL Building Standard . Climate Studio provides not only daylight but also glare, sun, and shadow analysis, including window blinds operation and impact on daylight quality. ¬†It is available in the software center. ¬†The training offers AIA HSW/LU credit for staff!  Contact firmwideprocesslab@perkinswill.com for more information and get your studio and staff ready to meet and exceed your daylight design goals.

title: InDesign LIVE Share
content: InDesign is one of the most widely used tools in our vast repertoire. Countless presentations, pursuits, marketing documents, and other important documents have been created using this platform with incredible results. Despite all this success, however, there has been a fundamental flaw with the InDesign workflow ‚Äì exporting and reviewing markups‚Ä¶ Anyone who has used InDesign knows this workflow‚Ä¶ Finish presentation changes, check spelling, double check formatting Export to PDF and wait 5 ‚Äì 20 minutes for the pdf to save Open the pdf and notice a mistake immediately Fix the mistake in InDesign Re-Export to PDF and wait Another 5 ‚Äì 20 minutes Open the new pdf and compress the file size ‚Äì save a new copy in the folder Write an email to the whole project team and attach the PDF for review Receive markups from several people each with slightly contradictory remarks Make the changes in InDesign and start the process all over again‚Ä¶ After many late nights of rapidly assembling content for review, I used to consider my workday ‚Äúdone‚Äù when I finished making changes in InDesign. Realistically, though, it would always take another hour to save and send the PDF ‚Äî it consumed loads of valuable time and there was no way around it. Until Now! The latest InDesign update provides a very powerful feature conveniently named ‚ÄúShare for Review‚Äù. It can be found in the upper right-hand corner under the ‚ÄúShare/Export‚Äù icon. Instead of exporting a large pdf file, this feature uploads a lightweight copy of your file to a web-hosted viewer. You can invite anyone you‚Äôd like via the InDesign panel (principals, team members, clients, friends, etc‚Ä¶). Once invited, users can view the document and add comments throughout. This live session allows everyone to see each other‚Äôs comments to avoid repetitive or contradicting notes. Web hosted document ‚Äì Available to everyone with the link InDesign Review Feature ‚Äì Available in the original file The great thing about this process is that it only takes seconds to share the file this way. Adobe used some form of magic to create a system that can publish a document to the cloud and share it to dozens of people in mere seconds, while exporting that same file to a simple pdf takes 20 minutes. The best part of all, though, is that the web document remains 100% live. Simply press ‚Äúupdate‚Äù in the InDesign panel at any point to refresh the file online. You no longer have to stress about those little mistakes that forced you to re-export the time-consuming PDF every time. Changes are synced with a single button and appear within seconds. Any comments that were in the file remain intact so there is no need to worry about overwriting the valuable feedback added by others. So, what‚Äôs the downside you might ask? There are a couple quirks, the biggest is Adobe‚Äôs relentless subscription licensing requirements. To share or view documents this way, you must have an active CC suite license. While this is simple to acquire, it could certainly be a hang-up for high level staff that have limited time to navigate subscription logistics. Be sure to coordinate this ahead of time so the whole project team is up and running prior to a deadline. The other quirk is not necessarily bad ‚Äî just something to be aware of. To remove completed markups you simply press the ‚ÄúResolve‚Äù button in the browser. The good news is that the comment disappears, the bad news is it is gone forever. There is currently no option to hide or archive any comments. ‚ÄúResolving them‚Äù completely deletes any record of it ‚Äì a little problematic for intricate notes and critical feedback. Lastly, whomever shares the document will receive an email update for every single comment that is made in the document. This is a good notification for occasional notes. It is extremely annoying, however, when hundreds of comments are added in rapid succession. You can circumvent this issue by changing your notification settings to turn this feature off, just be aware that you will have to remember to check the document regularly for any new comments. Check out the demo video in the InDesign home screen and try it on your next project, I think you‚Äôll be pleasantly surprised.

title: Practice Lecture Hall ‚Äì A Virtual Place to Gather and Learn
content: Since the beginning of the year, the Digital Practice community has been using a channel in Teams, Practice Lecture Hall , as a virtual gathering location to present concepts and ideas to build everyone‚Äôs professional skills.   As we have moved past the initial phases of working from home and realize that everyone is a little closer when few are in studios and everyone is connected virtually we see increased use of this channel by anyone to make their learning sessions more widely accessible to everyone around the firm.   We now see the NY technical studio training series joining the channel along sides the likes of the long-running PWU from our Boston studio and the Dallas Design Apps Continuing Ed series. You can find recordings from all of these presentations right in line in the chats and invites that you find on this channel.   You will also notice a tab at the top of the Practice lecture Hall channel called PWU Recordings with some curated courses from Boston and NY studios. If you would like to share your studio‚Äôs educational opportunities with a broader audience contact Nick Cameron or Matt Petermann to show you how to get setup.   This doesn‚Äôt require you to change your schedule or adjust your presentation content or topics.   It just gives more designers from other studios the opportunity to learn along side the people from your own studio. In addition to all of these studios, we have run many different series of continuing education from Digital Practice in this channel , including our monthly Visualization, Design and Delivery, Computation Design, and Performance Design calls.   We have held a series of Return to Studio classes on Microsoft Teams during the months of June and July in this channel.   We have also held two Digital Practice Core eXchange virtual conferences this year in this channel which have held 2,000 attendees for each quarterly offering. All of the Digital Practice recordings can be found in our eXchange library on our site or in Quickstart guides, such as the one for MS Teams on our site.

title: Digital Practice Third Quarter Core eXchange
content: Digital Practice Core eXchange and Training Library Resources On July 14th through the 23rd Digital Practice team members and experts from around the firm completed another round of classes for our quarterly Digital Practice Core eXchange.¬† These continuing education sessions are designed to give our staff awareness and understanding of the tools and processes available to us at Perkins&Will. This quarter we had many new topics, as well as updating and improving many other topics from previous core exchanges.¬† Everyone was able to join the live sessions through Teams from wherever they are currently working and engage with the speakers to gain a better understanding in order to improve their work process. These live sessions were spread out over many days over the course of two weeks on our Teams channel for continuing education. If you weren‚Äôt able to make a session live or want to review one, you can find the recording in our ever-growing exchange library All sessions were registered for continuing education credits for you to meet your professional requirements through the AIA.¬† If you are part of another organization where you need continuing education units for your professional license you can typically self report these classes but check with your organization for specific details. The sessions are categorized by topics and you can view the recording and a slide deck and also connect with presenters for a follow-up discussion We had many highly attended classes and engaging question and answer sessions with those attending.¬† ¬†Some new ones that are relevant to working from home are a couple of new topics around BIM360 that looked further into the features of that platform, and also a session on virtual interview skills as we chase project work via virtual meetings.

title: Changes to Sketchup Licensing

author.name: Nick Cameron
author.description: American trucker who has been featured on the History channel reality television series Ice Road Truckers and its spinoff series IRT: Deadliest Roads.

content: Sketchup will be changing its licensing model¬†over the next year. Because of this licensing change and several other factors we have decided¬†not to¬†upgrade Sketchup beyond the current version. This will¬†essentially phase Sketchup out of the firm‚Äôs tool-set after¬†June¬†2021 .¬†The Digital Practice team will offer training to studios, project teams, and¬†individuals¬†on¬†transitioning¬†from Sketchup to¬†Rhino¬†as a conceptual¬†modeling tool. Digital Innovation and¬†leveraging computational tools on all projects are¬†a core strategy of the firm. Additional training on advanced modeling, parametric modeling (Grasshopper), climatic and environmental analysis¬†and refined workflows utilizing Conveyor and RhinoInside will also take place over the coming months. Thesenimble design¬†tools¬†allow your¬†team more¬†flexibility¬†while creating efficiencies in¬†documentation, while retaining design intent. You should have now upgraded to the latest release of Sketchup , as this¬†is the last planned upgrade for Perkins&Will. Beginning on June 28th , a new¬†dialogue¬†box will appear when launching Sketchup informing you that the license is no longer under¬†maintenance,¬†this is to be expected and does not interfere with the operation of the application. If you have any questions, ideas or comments please feel free to reach out to me.

title: VizR July eXchange
content: Arkio ‚Äì Neil Reindel, Hilmar Gunnarsson and Johan Hanegraaf Diversity in Presentation ‚Äì Nick Cameron OBS Studio ‚Äì Mario Romero & Nick Cameron Arkio is a new design collaboration tool that we have been testing for a while. Neil Reindel, from our Chicago office has been actively working with Hilmar and Johan from Arkio in testing the software and pushing what the software can do for us, and how it can help designers explore design options in the early stages using a Virtual collaboration tool.  After Hilmar and Johan demonstrated the basic features of Arkio, where collaboration can happen in virtual 3D between participants using different devices such as a browser on a PC or an iPad, and other participants wearing VR headsets. Neil showcased a project that he was able to bring the model from Revit, imported into the Arkio virtual platform, made design changes through iterations of design sessions and then send the changes back into Revit for further development. Thus completing the round trip workflow of moving data between Revit and Arkio. Arkio virtual collaboration Nick Cameron shared the latest development effort of expanding ‚ÄúDiversity in Rendering‚Äù and how we can do better by challenging our vendors and the rendering services to increase the diversity in what they offer instead of paying them for the clearly non-diverse libraries they currently offer. Mario Romero and Nick Cameron also showcased OBS studio and demonstrated how using the OBS studio could enhance our virtual presentation capabilities. Using OBS Studio for Virtual Presentation View Presentation Video Presented July 2020

title: VizR June eXchange ‚Äì XR in Design
content: VizR June eXchange Presenters: Dan Creekmore from PW ‚Äì VizLab ‚ÄúUpdate on Perkins & Will‚Äôs VX App‚Äù Alex Coulombe from Agile Lens ‚ÄúUsing XR for Immersive Design in Architecture‚Äù Objectives: Learning how XR is used in Architectural Design Communicate design intent Pure creative expression Designing from the inside-out Solving old problems in new ways Bringing people together View Presentation Video Presented: June 2020

title: An Exciting Lineup of Continuing Education Sessions for this Quarter‚Äôs Digital Practice Core Exchange
content:
We have another great lineup of topics custom curated and focused on our firm‚Äôs process and resources.   In addition to allowing you to review a few classes live again that we presented last quarter, we have revived and freshened a couple of topics from last year as well as introducing some new topics to the event this quarter.   We have a good number of classes that can help you improve your Rhino and Computational Skills.   We are joined by some of our legal team to give us an overview of legal topics related to our digital practice.   We also have our first external speaking joining us in Meg Winch, who has been coaching many interview teams across the firm for years and will cover Virtual Presentation skills to adapt what you know for the social distancing environment we see ourselves in right now.   Check out the info below for all of the classes and times.   This quarter‚Äôs core eXchange will occur over 2 weeks in July on Tuesday, Wednesday, and Thursday the 14-16 and 21-23. title: Creating a Revit Dashboard in PowerBI
content: mK-Process-Creating-a-Revit-Dashboard-in-PowerBi Download For many designers, there is a reluctance (and struggle) to manage their project data in Revit schedules. Let‚Äôs face it, they aren‚Äôt very pleasing to the eye and scrolling through hundreds or thousands of rows in a spreadsheet to get a few key numbers isn‚Äôt ideal. Furthermore, when these numbers need to get passed along to a project manager, principal, or client, you might try to format this information manually in Excel or InDesign which isn‚Äôt very efficient from a process perspective. This is where Automation and Data Visualization can help us tremendously, and you‚Äôll see that the end result gives us meaningful information about our projects in a way that is interactive and visually stimulating. The video and PPT download link above can help you create a simple dashboard that tracks the square footage of rooms in your project. This process uses Dynamo to export data from the current Revit file to an Excel file.¬† In PowerBi, the Excel file gets linked and updates all the data visualizations (graphs, charts, tables, etc.) on the current report. DYN, XLSX, and PBIX files are provided .¬† As long as you have room elements placed in your Revit model, this will work on any project. Dynamo exports the following parameters from the Revit model: Room Name Room Department Room Area Room Level Example of the dashboard in PowerBI

title: Pedestrian Wind Comfort
content: Let‚Äôs Talk About Pedestrian Comfort and CFD Pedestrian comfort is a very important aspect of the built environment that has traditionally been outside of the immediate reach of designers and thus was relegated as something to be tested for ‚Äòlater‚Äô. CFD (computational fluid dynamics) software has been around for a while now but has been pretty inaccessible or somewhat difficult to integrate into the design process early enough to have a large impact. Fortunately we‚Äôve developed a grasshopper workflow that will allow everyone to integrate CFD and pedestrian comfort into their early schematic designs fairly easily and rapidly. The Lawson Comfort Scale So, how do you translate wind speed to pedestrian comfort? There are numerous comfort criteria scales that exist but for this particular tool, we went with the Lawson Comfort Scale. It‚Äôs really easy to read and understand without over complicating the diagram too much. 1 2 3 4 5 1 Light breezes desired for outdoor restaurants and seating areas where one can read a paper or comfortably sit for long periods. 2 Gentle breezes suitable for main buildings entrances. Suitable for pick-up/drop off points and bus stops. 3 Moderate breezes that would be appropriate for walking down a city center street, park, or plaza. 4 Relatively high speeds that can be tolerated if your objective is to walk, run, or cycle without lingering for too long. 5 Winds of this magnitude are considered a nuisance for most activities and wind mitigation is recommended. A Few Things Before You Jump Into CFD CFD is an incredibly nuanced thing. There‚Äôs a reason that a whole other profession exists just focusing on it. There are a ton of variables that could affect the outcomes of your simulation. This tool aims to reduce the amount of guesswork that would go into running CFD analysis and tries to simplify the process. With that, here are a few things to note before you start: Make sure your model units are set to Meters Make sure Eddy3D is installed Double-check your simulation settings Eddy3D This tool is built on Eddy3D. A really fantastic CFD suite built for grasshopper and being developed by Cornell‚Äôs ESLab. To find out more about it click on the gif. Controls, In Five Parts Inputs Simulation Settings Probe Plane Settings Run Simulation Visualize Previous Previous Previous Next Next Next Simulation Name: This can really be anything, just make sure to not use any spaces. I always just replace spaces with ‚Äò_‚Äô anyway. Mass: This is where you‚Äôd input your project mass. Works better if it‚Äôs a closed polysurface but doesn‚Äôt have to be. Context: Your project context goes here. Same as above, works better if the geometry is either closed polysurfaces or extrusions. Protip : a quick way to get context is to go to www.cadmapper.com and grab some. Set EPW: Finally, set your project weather file (.epw) here. Here‚Äôs two great places to grab .epw files if you don‚Äôt already have one: https://climate.onebuilding.org/ https://www.ladybug.tools/epwmap/ https://www.energyplus.net/weather Scale: Sets the scale of the project. This really affects the accuracy of the building meshes. Detail: Sets the detail level of each mesh. This is a representation of the features of each mesh. Such as how accurate the corners will be. Sim Speed: This sets how many times the simulation will iterate. Obviously, the more iteration, the more accurate the simulation but also the longer it‚Äôll take to run. Season: Right now we just have the ability to specify Summer and Winter but will add Spring and Fall/Autumn. This essentially allows the script to average the predominant wind vector for the season which you can visualize. Probe Plane Length & Width: Dimensions of your probe plane (which is just basically the grid of points you‚Äôre going to be using for your simulation). Test Height: The height of the probe plane. Should usually be at 1.5m-2m (5ft-6.5ft) if you‚Äôre testing pedestrian comfort. Grid Size: The size of the hexagons that you‚Äôll use to test the simulation. The smaller the size, the higher fidelity the simulation but also the longer it‚Äôll take to run. Usually 1m-2m is a decent size for tests. Show Grid: You can toggle between showing the grid or not. Useful for visualizing the grid before running the simulation. Generate Grid: Once you‚Äôre happy with the grid, toggle this to True to generate the grid for the simulation. 1.) Generate Mesh: Press this button to generate your meshes. Depending on your settings It should take about 5-15 minutes. 2.) Run Simulation: Runs the simulation based on all settings. Depending on settings, takes about 5-20 minutes. 3.) Visualize Probes: This generates the wind vectors on each point of the grid you generated (from the probe plane). You can visualize these separate from the pedestrian comfort diagram. 4.) Run Pedestrian Comfort: This calculates the pedestrian comfort on each hexagon (from the probe plane. Usually takes anywhere between 2-8 minutes. !!!Reset Simulation!!!: It‚Äôs red because it deletes your simulation data. You‚Äôll need to press this before re-running your simulation if you‚Äôve changed anything (usually if you‚Äôre testing a different massing. Each step in the simulation will look like this Show Pedestrian Comfort: Toggle to show the Pedestrian Comfort diagram. Show Wind Vectors: Toggle to show Wind Vectors. Show Wind Vectors Speed: Show the wind speed on each wind vector. Percent Comfortable: This is a nice little calc that spits out a percentage of the site that meets or exceeds the comfortability specified in the dropdown. Show Wind Rose: Toggle to show the wind rose generated from the .epw file. Show Average Wind Vector: Toggle to show the average prevalent wind vector. Visualizations The tool currently produces three types of diagrams: A Pedestrian Comfort Diagram A Wind Vector Diagram A Wind Rose Each diagram produces it‚Äôs own legend as well for easy legibility. All you need to do is print any view of the diagram you want to either an image or PDF to use it in your presentations! Pedestrian Comfort Diagram Wind Vector Diagram Wind Rose Previous Previous Previous Next Next Next 1 1 The pedestrian comfort diagram will automatically color the grid you generated based on the Lawson Comfort Scale. 1 1 The wind vector legend will be automatically segmented into 10 segments/colors. 1 1 The tool also generates a visual of the average prevailing winds. If you run into any problems or have any questions please feel free to hop into the Computational Design Channel and ask! You can download v6.0 of the script here: Download Now

title: Return to Studio in-depth Microsoft Teams training
content: As part of an effort to make the different time tables and steps every team member will be taking in returning to their studio we want to offer a more in-depth look at how to get the most out of one of the firm‚Äôs main collaboration tool, Microsoft Teams.   We will be holding a series of five more extensive classes looking closer at the ways Teams can help you Gather, Talk, Share, Accomplish, and Explore in a more complete way.   We have previously covered the basics and even intermediate sessions to help get everyone accustom to this platform when we all began working from home.  This will all be held on the Digital Practice Lecture Hall channel in Teams itself.   This is where we have been holding many continuing education sessions for the past couple of months, so look back for more new opportunities to grow your skills here. Get the most from your Teams Starting next week and for the following four weeks we will be breaking down the various aspects of what Teams can help you do.  In the first week will be talking about gathering and using meetings, calls, and the calendar in order to get together.   The second week will be all about talking and using channels posts and the individual and group chat features to communicate.  The third week will be all about sharing using the various things you can do with files through the Microsoft ecosystem.   The forth week will be about accomplishing your work and using tasks and the planner app to get things done.    The final week will be about exploring the rest of the ecosystem with the many tabs you can add to enhance your project‚Äôs workflow.   Things like the stream app, polly and forms to get feedback, using OneNote to compliment your project, adding PowerBI boards and its limitations and integrating other locations in the cloud into your interface. Each class will be offered that week during multiple sessions to make sure no matter what time zone you are in or what your current working schedule is that there will be an opportunity for you to join the conversation.   As always we will be recording these sessions for later viewing and posting them to our Teams Quickstart guide hosted on the Digital Practice site.   Please look for upcoming invites on the Practice Lecture Hall to get one of these sessions onto your calendar to make your project team a more cohesive unit virtually as if you were sitting in your pod in the studio together.  Below is the options for the First Session. Day Pacific Mountain Central Eastern UK Denmark China Wednesday (10th) 2pm 3pm 4pm 5pm 10pm 11pm 5am (Thur) Thursday (11th) 5am 6am 7am 8am 1pm 2pm 8pm Thursday (11th) 11am 12pm 1pm 2pm 8pm 9pm 3am (Fri) Friday (12th) 9:30am 10:30am 11:30am 12:30pm 5:30pm 6:30pm 12:30am (Sat)

title: Design and Delivery ‚Äì Sharpen Your Tools
content: Digital Practice holds a monthly Design and Delivery call which is a forum where we discuss productivity tools and share experiences, ideas and workflows. This monthly meeting shares exemplary workflows being leveraged across the firm to deliver our design intent. And we also give updates on Revit content and templates.  In the last couple of months experts from across the firm have presented and discussed various tools which can make you and your team more productive. On the latest Design and delivery call on May 14th , we talked about efficient use of Keynote Manager, its cloud component and new features that were developed in collaboration with Perkins&Will experts. If you have not attended that meeting and use Revit keynotes, the recording  of the training and user discussion are available here. Keynote Manager is a powerful  and intuitive tool which has multiple advantages comparing to Revit built-in keynoting, including interactive and easy keynote file editing, links and comments and Revit plugin  for applying keynotes in Revit, as well as tools for QA/QC. User feedback is amazing: everyone who have used KM on the project said they would never go back! However with WFH, we strongly recommend using KM cloud for hosting Keynote files, to avoid possible file locking. Next week, on Thursday, June 11,  experts from around the firm will share different tools and approaches that help our designers respond to Covid-19 crisis Please use this LINK to register for monthly calls.

title: Software Updates when Returning to your Studio
content: It has been a long time since most of us have been in our studios sitting at our desks.   As a result of this absence from office life, we have held off on many pending software updates, only making critical updates available and not required as we have typically done in the past.   When you find yourself returning to the office please account for some time at the start of your day to let your laptop catch up to all the optional updates that we have prepared and will improve the features, stability, and speed of your design applications.   You can find many of these in software center and in some cases, you will be prompted to update something on your laptop.   When running these please make sure you restart your laptop first do reduce unexpected reboots due to pending windows updates.   Also don‚Äôt move your laptop off your dock or close the lid until the updates have shown dialog boxes declaring the install is complete. In the coming weeks there are some updates we will be pushing out to the firm that will be required while you are away.   This will be an upgrade from Bluebeam 2018 to 2019 and an upgrade from SketchUp 2019 to 2020.  Both of these are required for all designers with the software and are a result of our licensing agreements.   Please keep an eye out for these to find a time to run them when you are away from your laptop as they will take a little longer than typical depending on your homes connection speed. As always we are trying to minimize disruption to your design work while keeping your applications up to date to maintain security, functionality, and add value to your design process.   You can always help us by remembering to regularly reboot your laptop often to reduce problems and avoid unexpected behavior when you need your machine the most.  Please let us know if you have any feedback to keep finding ways to improve this process for you.   Thanks.

title: VX App Version 2.0
content: The VizLab teaming with Digital Practice has released version 2.0 of Perkins&Will‚Äôs cutting-edge client engagement & virtual leave-behind app, VX.¬† The new update to VX includes a completely redesigned interface, reflecting the firm‚Äôs new brand, and adds support for bolder graphics and a more modern style.¬† VX was first introduced in 2017 as a tool for sharing all of a project‚Äôs media in a single location.¬† VX enables project teams to share mobile VR, pano-tours, interactive models, AR models, images, animations, videos, documents and much more, all in a single location.¬† VX allows projects to be shared privately, and uses ‚Äúsmart‚Äù links to simply and seamlessly share content with clients, regardless of platform or device.¬† This has proved to be a very effective leave-behind for pursuits and an easy way to engage clients. ¬†Any project team in Perkins&Will can take advantage of this platform by submitting their project to the VizLab. VX Website ‚Äì https://perkinswill.app.link How to Get your Project or Pursuit on VX ‚Äì VX Quickstart Guide Questions?  ‚Äì vizlab@perkinswill.com

title: Virtual Pull Planning
content:
While our entire world has
shifted quickly to Working From Home and conducting our day to day tasks
digitally, some aspects of our workflows are more difficult to transition over.
¬†A great resource for many large projects
is a Pull Planning session with our consultants.¬† Typically, the project team would use premade
laminated cards and a trackable surface to map out all the major steps and deliverables
from the start of the project to project delivery.¬† This multi-hour session involves dozens of
people in a conference room, which presents a new dilemma in our new normal.¬†¬† How do you make a large hands-on activity
interactive digitally? In steps Microsoft Planner,
a collaborative productivity tool built into Microsoft Teams.¬† Operating as a virtual pin up space, users
can create tasks akin to post-it notes, and populate them with checklists,
attachments, due dates, user assignments, and colored labels. Utilizing Planner, the
Digital Practice team worked with several pilot projects to recreate the Pull
Planning cards developed by the Technical Design Community as Planner tasks. ¬†Once set up, the teams were able to invite
their consultants several days in advance to view, manage, and place the tasks
in their preferred order of deliverables prior to a Pull Planning session hosted
over Microsoft Teams. While on a Teams call, the different team members were able to discuss each
task and assign them a Week of the project that it needed to be completed by. ¬†After weekly assignments were done, with extra
time to spare, the project team could flip to the Calendar view on Planner and
drag each task on specific days. Link to Planner 101 Presentation from Platform 3.0

title: Checking Out the Views
content: For the Sake of the View View analysis and view obstruction analysis are fairly critical in the early design process. They can provide a lot of feedback in regards to your massing and can easily help to inform massing changes. Unfortunately they‚Äôre a bit tedious to do over and over again after each massing iteration and, on taller projects, for each floor. Let Computation Help Fortunately we‚Äôve developed a pretty simple script to help you visualize these types of diagrams incredibly quickly. The script just needs context and your massing to run the analysis in real-time. You can specify the floor to floor height, what level you‚Äôd like to generate the analysis from and the distance the view cones should analyse. This will then generate the view diagrams with a text overlay indicating how far you can see before an obstruction is in view. Tightening the Feedback Loop It‚Äôs very simple to use and easily integrated into your workflow. It can be used in real-time to inform your design decisions and hopefully tighten that data to design feedback loop just a little more. Download v1.0 of Perkins&Will‚Äôs View Analysis script Download Now

title: Digital Practice Second Quarter Core eXchange
content: Digital Practice Core eXchange and Library On April 14th through April 24th Digital Practice and experts from around the firm completed a full year of our quarterly Digital Practice Core eXchange.¬† These continuing education sessions are designed to give our staff awareness and understanding of the tools and processes available to us at Perkins&Will. This quarter we had five new topics in the mix, as well as updating and improving a dozen topics from previous core exchanges.¬† Everyone was able to join the live sessions from their homes and engage with the speakers to gain a better understanding. This time live sessions were spread out over many more days than previously. We also moved them all to the Microsoft Teams platform which gave us a much better experience of giving and consuming these topics.¬† If you weren‚Äôt able to make a session live or want to review one, you can find the recording in our ever-growing exchange library In addition to offering theses sessions on a more dynamic platform we have also registered them for continuing education credits for you to meet your professional requirements. The sessions are categorized by topics and you can view the recording and a slide deck and also connect with presenters for a follow-up discussion In addition to quarterly eXchange events, we are working with many studios to make available PW U events that local studios are hosting for their designers to make available to all employees firmwide in our Digital Practice Lecture Hall . Look for upcoming schedules for additional ongoing training opportunities on various topics around design, building typologies, construction contract administration, office culture, and more. If you already have something going on in your local studio that you would like to share with the larger audience please reach out to Matt Petermann to help coordinate those efforts.

title: Guided Tour of Online Resources
content: When the pandemic caused our company to switch to WFH (work from home), we were prepared. We had a plan, ready-to-deploy technology, know-how and confidence to get it done very quickly and efficiently. Perkins&Will has maintained a lot of online resources before the current health crisis. During this WFH time, we developed additional resources, communication channels and support methods. This guide will help you to find a resource you need. Platform.PerkinsWill.com is a good place to start. There you will find up-to-date company information, best practices for communications, tips about working from home efficiently,  information about upcoming training and past training recordings (more of that at Digitalpractice.PerkinsWill.com/ ). This site is updated frequently with relevant information from management, Information Technology and Digital Practice. Please note quick links on top. Pressing Help here is just one more way to send a Help Request to the GTS Helpdesk. For more in-depth coverage or design applications and other self-help resources, go to to https://digitalpractice.perkinswill.com/ . Digital Practice has maintained this site long before WFH began and it is a treasure trove of information. Use the tabs on top to check out newsletter articles, future training schedules and past recorded training sessions delivered by digital practice in collaboration with subject matter experts around the firm. From the resources  tab, you‚Äôll find our Quickstarts ‚Äì concise landing pages for all of our major applications. The MicroKnowledge site is already a favorite of many PW designers. It contains more than 600 how-to slides answering many common questions.  This content is searchable and well organized by application/process. In Training Library you will find recordings of past training sessions and a schedule of upcoming events. In addition to online resources, we use Teams to stay in touch and provide interactive live support to answer your questions. In the General Channel you can ask questions and someone will get back to you with the answer. This channel is monitored by Digital Practice and many experts from around the firm. The Digital Practice Lecture Hall is a channel where all the scheduled training sessions are happening. When there is an active session in progress, you will see a camera icon text to it. During the last two weeks we were conducting our quarterly eXchange sessions there, and feedback showed that they were enthusiastically accepted and appreciated by PW staff. Digital Practice Virtual Office Hours is a hangout for anyone and everyone who has questions, concerns, or just wants to discuss something with a member of DP teams in-person. This ‚Äúwalk-in channel‚Äù is manned by our DP team.  The first session starts at 9AM EST, and then sessions happen every two hours. When it is ‚Äúin -session‚Äù, you will see the camera icon next to the Channel name. We have already migrated most of out projects to BIM360.  However if your project needs to be migrated, please fill out the information in t his spreadsheet , and someone will help you.

title: A New Kind of VR
content: On the most recent VizR call our guest speaker demonstrated a highly collaborative VR experience appearing to embrace the advantages of virtual workspaces. The Wild as it is called is promoted as a real-time, immersive collaboration even though an immersive headset is not a requirement. In addition to joining The Wild using a monitor or headset an iPad is also an option. According to Gabe Paez, CEO the environment can easily host more than nine simultaneous users. Unfortunately people have expressed feeling too crowded as numbers exceed nine. Still nine is not a small number of collaborators. Scaling plays a useful role within The Wild. The environments witnessed ranged from Revit and SketchUp designs to workspaces to inserting those designs into workspaces appearing to be scale models on a table. Each person also has the ability to change their scale within the environment which happen often in the demonstration. Changing scale appeared to have advantages for reviewing, editing and exploring the designs. Note the two people at smaller scale on the grass of the model The Wild is cloud-based and integrated with Revit, BIM360 and SketchUp. There is a Revit add-in which pushes your Revit project into The Wild where collaboration can occur across the office or the world. The Wild features menus to create, modify and insert. The menus are visible to each person operating the menu and others within the environment. The types of things  inserted into the projects or workspaces seemed unlimited. It is easy to imagine how people or teams could create virtual workspaces for each project filled with project related content.  These virtual workspaces would be like like physical workrooms or conference rooms where nothing has to be removed before the next meeting. Unconstrained by size or scale inhabitants could spatially order project information in a way we all  innately understand. The presentation ended with the offer for Perkins&Will designers to experience using The Wild. This offer has not been made to Perkins&Will in past demonstrations. We look forward to exploring The Wild in April. If you would like to participate please reach out to me and I will ask if there is availability.

title: Digital Practice Core Exchange ‚Äì Second Quarter of 2020
content: Digital Practice group is again hosting our quarterly opportunity to raise everyone‚Äôs core skills around the firm.   Beginning on Tuesday April 14th we will invite experts from around the firm to share their knowledge with you on various topics.   These continuing education sessions are designed to give our staff and especially new employees an awareness of the tools and processes available to us at Perkins&Will.   We have again updated the lineup of classes to include more topcis around many Revit items you told us were causing general pain to many teams and designers out there.   We also contiue to update previous classes on topics like BIM360 and Microsoft Teams to keep up with the changing software and increased usage by many staff as we have accelerated our adoption to enhance the work from home experience across the firm on Platform 3.0. In addition to a small change in the lineup of topics we will also be changing from our typical 3 day line up of classes to an extended two weeks of continuing education sessions.   This will cover from the 14th to the 24th of April with two sessions each day.   Each session will be hosted on our Digital Practice Virtual Lecture Hall channel in Microsoft Teams.   Each session will be recorded and posted to our growing libary of content on our education library .    Each day of this quarter‚Äôs exchange you will find a Join button in that channel at the appropriate time of each class.   ALL CLASSES ARE REGISTERED WITH AIA FOR ONE LEARNING UNIT FOR EACH CLASS! Microsoft Channel meeting Join button The lineup for this quarter will adjust appropriately to allow for all designers to join the firmwide Engagment Forum on Health, Workplace and Education topics which Phil announced last week on his weekly firmwide webcast.   We will general follow the same schedule each day with the exception of two times that these live events will be taking place on the 16th and 23rd.   See the schedule below for each day and note your local time zone for when to join the Digital Practice Lecture Hall channel .  You can find calendar invites on the Teams channel or from the calendar of events on this page on the Platform 3.0 site. Session Time Table by local times to join Channel As we always have done, all sessions will be recorded and posted to our exchange education library on the Digital Practice website.

title: Fast Convenient Help and Learning
content: Responding to our shift in March to work remotely Digital Practice introduced both Virtual Office Hours and the Digital Practice Lecture Hall. These unique offerings recognize how social distancing changes the way we interact and communicate. Instead of assistance and learning being limited by the circumstances these solutions create greater convenience and accessibility. If you have not already benefited from these new opportunities, read on to learn how to access them. Receive immediate answers and assistance from Digital Practice team members when posting on the Digital Practice Virtual Office Hours channel within Microsoft Teams. This new Microsoft Teams channel is staffed with Digital Practice team members waiting to assist designers. Designers posting their questions or requests may receive immediate answers or for more complex issues move to a private channel or call. There are five daily sessions every Monday through Friday spanning 14 hours. The first session begins at 5:00 AM EST and the last one ends at 7:00 PM EST.  To see a detailed schedule of times follow this link and scroll down to the Session Schedule to view the gray colored calendar items.  From Chrome or other browsers  simply click any gray colored calendar item to join the Digital Practice Virtual Office Hours channel in Microsoft Teams. To navigate to the Digital Practice Virtual Office Hours channel from within Microsoft Teams look for the channel name within the Teams section under the Digital Practice team. Or use the filter at the top of the Team category and type in ‚ÄúVirtual‚Äù to see and select the channel. The Digital Practice Lecture Hall channel hosts live and recorded training and professional development opportunities. The live sessions occur several times each week. Most recently the sessions have addressed the firm‚Äôs remote work needs covering multiple topics related to Microsoft Teams and BIM360. To view upcoming and past session follow this link . At the top are past recorded sessions. Scroll down to the Session Schedule to view the calendar items other than gray. Click any non-gray calendar item from within Chrome or another browser to go to out Digital Practice Lecture Hall within Microsoft Teams. On behalf of the Digital Practice Team we look forward to assisting more of you on these new channels.

title: Performance Design Monthly eXchange Meeting ‚Äì March 2020 ‚Äì Water
content: Our third meeting of Year Two Performance Design sessions explores the discussion of the water and energy nexus based on a few high-level topics from the Worldbank.Org and then a look into some of the processes available to the firm through scripts to assess our project‚Äôs performance relating to indoor water use and rainwater harvesting including a couple of case study projects from Seattle, Atlanta, and Washington D.C. studios: How do we get energy into our building designs? The availability and withdrawal of water for energy production from use in resource extraction, refinement, process, transportation and power generation. Water Consumption, Water Withdrawal, and Energy Consumption A discussion of expected energy, water consumption, and water withdrawal increase by 2035. The percentage of the global population with unreliable or no access to electricity The percentage of the worldwide population living in areas of high water stress The impact of energy consumption increases pressures on water consumption, population growth, and climate change. Water withdrawal versus fossil fuel and renewable energy Building design impact on water use Building design and cooling system impact on water use Indoor Water Use method, processes, and script Rainwater Harvesting method, process, and script Case Studies from Atlanta, Seattle, Washington, D.C., and the Design Process Lab. Pepper Canyon West | Seattle Studio Indoor Water Use method, processes, and script Rainwater Harvesting method, process, and script Case Studies from Atlanta, Seattle, Washington D.C., and the Design Process Lab.

title: Matterport for ‚ÄúDigital Twin‚Äù
content: The Washington DC studio and Digital Practice¬†has recently been piloting a new scanning process to create ‚ÄúDigital Twins‚Äù for our design teams and clients.¬†The Matterport Scanner and¬†its accompanying web portal has been used to scan over 30 projects¬†so far!¬†If you have shopped for an apartment or house in the past few years you have probably already experienced a Matterport scan.¬†Here are some takeaways on what we have been learning. Yes, laser scanning has been around for a while . However, the¬†old methods of scanning, required ample investment in hardware, proprietary software and complex workflows to open the scan in¬†design applications (ie¬†Revit).¬†Matterport¬†was developed for¬†the real-estate market,¬†continuously finding ways to¬†streamline the equipment and process, making it easier, faster and cheaper for our design teams to leverage scanning of commercial spaces. This type of scanning [for now] is best suited for interior projects, especially of existing spaces.¬†Besides the benefit of having a measurable ‚ÄúDigital Twin‚Äù for our design teams to leverage,¬†we also believe we can share a scan of the finished project with our clients.¬†Updating the ‚ÄúDigital Twin‚Äù periodically¬†after project completion can be a mechanism for¬†touch points with our clients between projects. Silas Haslam,¬†from the Washington DC studio¬†has been championing the effort of¬†scanning¬†during the¬†construction¬†phase. Each scan published¬†by Silas¬†to Matterport‚Äôs online portal has¬†allowed the design team to easily navigate the model¬†with their phone and an internet connection.¬†Needless to say, the¬†value was obvious, and it‚Äôs use cases seemed endless. See previous post for examples‚Ä¶ Like¬†Enscape, I tend to attribute the success of Matterport to¬†its¬†user friendly¬†infrastructure. Simply stated, we don‚Äôt have the time to learn a new software or workflow. The¬†MatterPort¬†process has¬†proven so simple and intuitive, training is almost not necessary, a¬†10 minute¬†overview¬†is normally enough to get someone scanning. If you have¬†an¬†upcoming project or a recently completed one,¬†and would like to create a Digital Twin, please reach out and we can FedEx a scanner to you. If you would like to learn more about the projects already completed and additional use cases, check out this earlier blog post and this eXchange¬†Presentation on Reality Capture . Save time on money and travel‚Ä¶ Remove user error when it comes to accuracy‚Ä¶

title: Computational Design February eXchange ‚Äì Rhino.Inside.Revit
content: This past computational design exchange we hosted Scott Davidson (McNeel & Assocciates) and Nate Miller (Proving Ground) . It was an incredibly exciting conversation pertaining to the current developments that have been happening at McNeel in regards to rhino to revit interoperability: Rhino.Inside.Revit Discussing Rhino.Inside.Revit and the Future of Interoperability Rhino.inside is a very exciting development from McNeel and it doesn‚Äôt stop with Revit. McNeel are currently developing Rhino.Inside for ArcGIS, Unity, and Unreal as well. Potentially closing the gap between design, documentation, and VR/AR visualization. More info can be found here: Rhino.Inside.Revit page: https://www.rhino3d.com/inside/revit/beta/ Rhino.Inside.Revit documentation: https://www.rhino3d.com/inside/revit/beta/guides/ Rhino.Inside github page: https://github.com/mcneel/rhino.inside Interested In Learning More? Digital Practice is still in the process of testing and developing workflows around Rhino.Inside.Revit but if you‚Äôre interested in learning more or even testing out this beta software let us know.

title: Augmented Urbanism: How to Build a Positive AR Future
content:
Technology is full of potential, with its opportunities
ranging from exciting experiences to convenient solutions. Its role in cities,
however, is often a topical issue to be discussed. Through our Innovation
Incubator Augmented
Urbanism: How to Build a Positive AR Future , Patrick Bayer and I take a
positive and solution-based approach in exploring what XR (extended reality)
will mean for urbanism. Inspiration to dive into this topic stemmed from the
concept film, Hyperreality , by
Keiichi Matsuda, which highlights XR‚Äôs potential for a frightening future. As
this technology will fundamentally affect the places we design, as architects,
designers and planners, we should see it as our responsibility to help guide
the extended reality industry toward a positive future for our cities. This past January, we hosted a design charette with our San
Francisco office as a kickstarter to our research. We asked what impact XR can
have on interiors, buildings, and the urban environment. The energy around the
conversations was exciting, as people discussed the many possibilities. Some
takeaways centered around the educational role that XR can play in teaching
others on topics such as climate change and the history of place. There were
also conversations about the flexibility in not only design but also the design
process. The charette ended with a discussion around the ethical implementation
of XR and how it will be important for us as designers to have a frank
understanding of what our values are. Our next steps are to take these conversations and analyze
what it means through a research paper. We will also be creating a series of
vignettes to connect the experience of XR with our goals for the future. Stay
tuned!

title: The benefits of a digital sketch process in design
content:
The Importance of Sketching: There has always been a fine line between process and representation in the architecture studio. One is often feeding the other. The importance of a fluidity between the mind, heart, hand, and paper cannot be overstated. The Promise of The Paper Free Architecture Studio The notion of a paperless studio has been around for decades. In 1994 ‚Äì under the direction of Bernard Tschumi ‚Äì the Columbia
Graduate School of Architecture, Planning and Presentation undertook a series
of experiments with the paperless studios. Tschumi proposed that how an
architect expresses themselves, is closely related to how they think. If CAD was the way of the future, then architectural thinking must adapt itself to this new method of representation. Coming at a time when the profession of architecture was rapidly computerizing, this was a powerful thought. But the experimental studios were eventually abandoned. The relationship between the mode of notation and the way of thinking is fundamental to the profession of architecture. Sketching is a mode of notation that‚Äôs much better able to take on a layer of abstraction that‚Äôs necessary. While analog tools like pen and paper have been doing a fine job of fulfilling this role, there are still numerous benefits to a digital sketching process in the design studio. A Pilot In the Vancouver Studio The MQCC team in the Vancouver studio has been piloting the use of the Tablet in their design process.  They currently share the use of 5 iPads that float between 12 people, in two offices. Here are some ways the team is making use of the tool: Quick sketches Brainstorming Optioneering Concept Design Design Process Diagrams Detail Design Markups Meeting Collaboration and Communication Apps and Workflows Morpholio Trace An example workflow using Morpholio Trace Past attempts to digitize the experience of paper have had
limited success in the architecture studio. Wacom tablets, touch capable laptop
screens, Smart Boards, Smart Surfaces, all failed because of one simple fact: real
paper is un-complicated. Of all apps we tested, Trace gave real paper a real run for
its money. It‚Äôs designed specifically for Architects. It‚Äôs simple to sketch, layer,
iterate. The app has rulers, scales, perspective guides, entourage stencils and
different brush presents that make it easy to go from shading to outlining. Today Trace is more popular than real trace paper with the MQCC team because it bridges the gap between digital and physical. How do you sketch over a computer model? You no longer have to print an underlay. Just hold the iPad up to the screen for a quick shot. Working in a layered system, and having undo and redo are also clear advantages to real paper. Procreate Some members of the MQCC team prefer to use an app called
Procreate. While quite similar to Trace, it‚Äôs designed for artists and
illustrators, so it can provide a bit more power and control for more polished representation. Procreate supports serious customization of the interface with shortcuts and touch gestures. Users that are more advanced and committed to the digital sketching process were able to reap these benefits. For others, having to learn an interface was a barrier to entry. Duet Display We had initially begun the pilot with a Wacom Tablet, but
quickly found it clumsy and impractical. Users had to plug in three different
cables every time they returned to their desk. Touch gestures were limited. The
software driver software was unreliable. It would often fail to recognize the Wacom
tablet as an extra display and force the user to restart their computer. When testing and iPad with Duet display as an alternative we
realized it was vastly superior experience. Designers were now completely
wireless. No more being tied to the desk you were plugged into to. If you want
to have a discussion with a colleague, you can just walk to their desk with the
tablet ‚Äì like a stack of trace paper. Multi touch gestures and the stability of
the software made the iPad feel as seamless as paper. Two successful workflows with Duet Display: As a pen tablet: for finer control Morpholio Trace
and Procreate are great, but sometimes getting that final level of control in
photoshop is just what you need. Duet enables an iPad and Pencil to act as another
monitor with pressure sensitivity and multitouch gestures. Like a Wacom tablet,
only wireless. This method is great for sketching, and marking up documents. Our team has successfully tested this in Photoshop, Affinity and Bluebeam. As a collaborative whiteboard The MQCC team spread over two offices. Previously, teams would draw on a whiteboard, alienating colleagues on the other end of a conference call. Duet display is being used to improve collaboration in meetings. Both teams cast their screen to a projector or TV in their respective meeting room. An iPad on each side is passed around the table for people to contribute to one shared drawing. Questions? Contact Elton Gjata in the Vancouver Studio.

title: Ricoh Theta Z1 Review and Theta S Comparison
content: Ricoh Theta Z1 Review and Theta S Comparison The information below focuses on the use of 360 photos for our practice.¬† To date the most common use of the Theta S camera in the Chicago office is for taking as built photos of education facilities.¬† Other Perkins&Will offices are taking 360 photos for markting purposes to showcase project work.¬† The Digital Practice group has been documenting the Perkins&Will offices with 360 photos and videos. One of the issues with the Theta cameras is with battery drain when at project sites taking photos of many spaces over a period of time.¬† Out of Chicago the Theta S is supplied with an Anker battery pack for charging.¬† The battery pack can charge the camera when moving between spaces to be photographed.¬† This is process is not ideal though because charging is slow and the teams may have to wait until the camera is charged enough to continue.¬† So specific tests outlined below focus on management of battery levels.¬† The project teams in Chicago also expressed that higher resolution and higher quality images would be helpful to capture as much detail as possible. The Theta cameras stich images to JPEG immediately after photos are taken which makes the camera very easy to work with.¬† The Insta360 camera, for example, saves images from the camera to an insp and dng raw format where JPEG images must be exported from an application.¬† The Theta can simply be connected to a laptop and JPEG files accessed directly.¬† The Theta Z1 now supports RAW DNG files that can be edited, enhanced and exported.¬† More information on DNG below. Additional Theta Z1 camera features include:¬† connect to camera via bluetooth, still image self timer, interval shooting, video shooting, live streaming, many typical camera settings are available such as exposure, HDR, white balance, etc. The Ricoh Theta Z1 and Theta V are compatible with Matterport.¬† Contact the Digital Practice group and the Matterport website for more information. Theta Z1 Theta S Price $1000 $300 Release Date 05/2019 10/2015 Sensor Two 1‚Ä≥ CMOS Two 2/3‚Ä≥ CMOS 23mp 14mp Image 6720 x 3360 JPEG 5376 x 2688 JPEG 7296 x 3648 DNG RAW Storage 19GB 8GB 2400 Photos Approx (JPEG) 1600 Photos Approx (JPEG) 350 Photos Approx (DNG) File Size Ave 8,250 KB (JPEG) 3,900 KB (JPEG) 47,500 KB (DNG) Battery 60 min. photos (approx) 90 min. photos (approx) Specifications Highlights ‚Äì¬† Large sensors on Z1 increases light and color capture capabilities ‚Äì¬† Z1 can be configured to save images in JPEG + DNG RAW format ‚Äì¬† OLED display on the Z1 showing photo count, battery life and functions Z1 Battery Life Battery drain on the Z1 is very fast when all of the default settings are used iphone connection to Theta Z1 over WiFi uses 360 live view by default in the Theta app ‚Äì¬† Battery will drain 10% every 6 minutes in this configuration (w/o taking any photos) ‚Äì¬† Battery drain is about the same if photos taken every minute Live view off in the Theta app doubles the battery life ‚Äì¬† Battery will drain 10% every 14 minutes in this configuration Battery charge from 0 to 100% is documented at 200 minutes ‚Äì¬† However, charging tests indicate 10% charge every 14 minutes Theta Z1 can be charged and operated at the same time ‚Äì¬† Battery drain with Z1 charging from an Anker PowerCore 20100 is 0% after 60 min Anker PowerCore mini charged the Z1 from 50% to 100% without completely draining ‚Äì PowerCore 3500 mini is a small ‚Äòlipstick‚Äô size charger To use the Z1 while charging on a tripod an additional accessory must be used because the USB-C charging port is next to the tripod hole ‚Äì See additional accessories on the Ricoh Site Theta Extension TE-1 Theta Stand TM-1 Image Comparison Theta Z1 Theta S Image Comparisons Theta Z1 Theta S ‚Äì¬† ‚ÄòSealed Air‚Äô text on box can be read on Z1 photo ‚Äì¬† Colors are move vivid from Z1 ‚Äì¬† HDR lighting better with Z1 ‚Äì¬† Blocks are more clear between windows ‚Äì¬† Purple halo affect around windows from older camera Notes:¬† ¬†Click on images for full size view VLC viewer can be used to view 360 images and videos.¬† JPG when dragged into VLC will be play as video.¬† Simply click pause to stop to pan and zoom Benefit of using VLC is zooming is not limited and view projection is automatically Perspective DNG Raw ‚Äì¬† DNG Raw files are higher resolution at 7296 x 3648 ‚Äì¬† DNG files can be edited in Adobe Lightroom Classic and exported using Ricoh Theta Sticher This video describes some basic editing techniques in Lightroom Classic ‚Äì¬† This workflow may be helpful for editing photos for marketing or other such purposes Theta Z1 Edited in Adobe Lightroom Theta Z1 JPG ‚Äì¬† Edited image ‚Äì hightlights reduced, noise reduced, sharpness increased ‚Äì¬† Pan to windows to see how highlights were reduced ‚Äì¬† Click on post-it-notes images to see difference in sharpness and reduction of noise Camera Usage Notes ‚Äì¬† If the initial connection to Theta Z1 over WiFi from an iPhone does not work then power cycle the iPhone ‚Äì¬† Theta Z1 is not operational for photos when USB-C is plugged into a laptop

title: Conveying Some Wisdom
content:
We‚Äôve all been there. You‚Äôve designed something pretty sweet
in rhino but now you need to incorporate it back into your project and document
it. So now what do you do? The age old .SAT export and CAD import, right? Only
if you love adding tens to potentially hundreds of megabytes of dumb mesh data into
your revit model. Or, you could just remodel your stuff in revit. If you
like not having any personal time at all. However, there‚Äôs a better way to do
this. In comes Conveyor . The old way of doing things So What is Conveyor? It‚Äôs this pretty handy rhino and revit plugin that allows you to very easily transfer rhino geometry to revit. All you need to do is simply setup your rhino file from Conveyor and you‚Äôre good to go. The great thing about Conveyor is that all geometry is imported as native revit data. So The easy Conveyor way When should I use Conveyor? Now there‚Äôs a few questions you‚Äôll need to ask yourself before you begin using Conveyor. Luckily we‚Äôve prepared a handy flow chart: How do I get started with Conveyor? Conveyor should already be installed on your machine (if not, ask your local DA! Once that‚Äôs up and running take a look at the recent Core eXchange presentation that Taylor Boyer and I hosted last month: Core eXchange ‚Äì Conveyor Things to Keep in Mind: While Conveyor is really simple to use once you‚Äôve familiarized yourself with it a little, the workflow requires a bit of a mental shift. Geometry in Rhino will have to be assigned to predetermined layers that represent the type of revit elements that the rhino geometry will be converted to (please see the below Conveyor Layer Key) Conveyor allows you to Origin Match to your revit file but you must prepare your rhino export file from within revit to get your projects origin, levels, and grid lines Keep note of what elements can and cannot be updated and replaced when going from rhino to revit (as listed in the Conveyor Layer Key) Lastly, Conveyor is a Rhino to Revit tool only. It does not do Revit to Rhino. Conveyor Layer Key

title: Black Friday Survey Results
content: Designers at Perkins&Will responded to a Digital Practice survey around Black Friday asking which tasks in Revit they found the most repetitive, time consuming or were among their least favorite. During December these survey results were analyzed and organized into like comments. Respondents were asked to type their answers followed by lists of known repetitive, time consuming and least favorite Revit tasks. The five most selected items from the lists were Sheet Naming / Renaming, Annotating and Dimensioning, Family Editing, Doing a Door Schedule, and Prepping CAD drawing for Revit import. Top 5 Responses Selected from a List Results for freely typed in answers were more challenging to calculate. Answers were grouped into like categories with some answers spanning multiple categories. In early December our first efforts to organize the type-in answers resulted in six key take-aways as follows below. Key Take-Aways from Early December Setting up / creating / populating Naming / renaming and/or numbering / renumbering Door schedules ‚Äì creating / revising Drawing indexes ‚Äì creating / revising Aligning views / plans on sheets Tags ‚Äì inserting and/or adjusting for legibility Review and organization of type-in responses resumed later in December. This was an effort to better address the frequent overlap of type-in responses across multiple categories. Near December‚Äôs end there was a similar, but new list. This late December list more accurately captures respondent‚Äôs type-in answers. Top 3 Type-in Responses from Additional Analysis in Late December Populating Projects and Project Templates Creating and Revising Door, Drawing and Other Schedules Annotation ‚Äì Tagging, Dimensioning, Keynoting including adjusting for legibility Efforts to respond to the items identified in the survey has already begun. Digital Practice is exploring possible solutions and communicating with designers whenever a better understand of the issue is needed. If you have a potential solution, suggestion or comment to contribute to one or more of these issue please email Iffat Mai, Nick Cameron or Dan Chasteen. Thank you to those that took time to respond to our survey. We are working towards potential solutions to the issues you identified.

title: Digital Practice Core eXchange and Library
content: Digital Practice Core eXchange and Library On January 14¬† thru January 16 Digital Practice and experts from around the firm conducted a third round of our quarterly Digital Practice Core eXchange.¬† These continuing education sessions are designed to give our staff and especially new employees an awareness of the tools and processes available to us at Perkins&Will. Each quarter we have a mix of topics, some sessions are new, some are updates, and our employees can join live session from their desk. This time live sessions ran earlier in the day than on previous two occasions¬† to give our international offices chance to participate in live sessions and ask questions. But do not worry if you did not catch the live session, you can find recording in our ever growing library The sessions are categorized by topics and you can view the recording and a slide deck¬† and also connect with presenters for a follow-up discussion In additions to quarterly eXchange events, there are interesting discussions and presentations hosted by Digital Practice every month, you can find them in UPCOMING EVENTS. These events are where subject matter experts from around the firm discuss best practices, share their experiences with new tools and workflows, showcase their projects, suggest solutions to problems that bug us. In short, this is the forum you should join if¬† you are interested and passionate about our design and delivery process. You can join our community by adding a call to your calendar. We are looking forward to seeing you on our calls- as a presenter or as a participant.

title: New Charlotte Studio Design ‚Äì Sharing Ideas with VR
content:
The Charlotte Studio
is moving! The Charlotte Studio of the North Carolina Practice is currently preparing for a location move and everything else that comes with it. As a Design Firm, the design of Perkins&Will offices is an important factor in portraying our values and beliefs. The design studio is a place for inspiration, collaboration, showcase for our clients, and most importantly‚Ä¶where we spend most of our day! With all this in mind, This is a difficult (but fun) challenge to the design team on how to incorporate everything that is wanted and needed and wrapped up in a beautiful design. The team is exploring the design of the space in all of the traditional ways is by sketching, modeling, material studies, and rendering. Since this is an article on the Digital Practice website, we would be remiss not to mention the use of the technological side and nontraditional design methods the team is using with the use of Virtual Reality and VR goggles. Axon Floor plans of the New Charlotte Studio Space Recently, the entire
Charlotte Studio walked over to the new space for an offsite Beer Time and a
chance to see where the new office would be. The Team presented everything that
they have been working on; Floorplans were pinned up, material boards were layed
out, and the VR goggles were used. At this time, the design was still in
Schematic Design so the concept and space layout were still being tweaked and
refined. The team presented their ideas to the rest of the office and also
received some helpful ideas and suggestions. Trying on the Oculus Rift-S Headset Eric Taylor entering Virtual Reality Material and Rendering Pin Up Discussions about Needs and Wants The team has been
using working mostly in Revit and using Enscape as the main render and VR tool.
With the new MSI computers the workflow of design, model building, rendering,
and VR has been seamless and efficient. The team has been able to work through
a lot of iterations and ideas by using all these tools together and pushing the
design forward. While on site the VR goggles and model were placed in a central
location and started in the same place Virtually. It was insightful for
everyone to look at the floorplans and also be able to ‚Äòstand‚Äô in the place
(Physically and Virtually) to truly understand the layout and new design of the
space. Even as Architects and Designers who are able to think spatially, the
use of VR was helpful to walk around in the model, take them off and see the
actual space. As an exercise this was helpful to the studio to share feedback
to the team,¬† get excited about the new
space, and think about how we can use all of our tools with clients. Stay tuned for more
design updates and pictures of the Charlotte Studio! Update: 1/24/20 Entry Entry & Lab Kitchen Lab & Small Conference Large Conference Open Lab Studio

title: Adding value and squashing bugs within our software toolbox
content: Adding value and squashing bugs Many items have already been updated the first month of this year, below is just a quick recap as to what some of those are that you should be aware of. Revit 2020 Update 2 This major release adds some new functionality.   There were improvements around the new path of travel feature as well as an attempt to resolve corrupt models with missing elements.  They also keep improving the desktop experience to be in line with BIM360 cloud improvements.   As with all versions of Revit you entire team should be on the exact same version to reduce issues with your model file. Max 2020 update 3 This update as with the previous continues to address a list of bugs in the software. Upgrade to Clarity 2020.1 This major release adds some new functionality including new tasks for BIM360 projects and a new task to export schedules.   Many other small bug fixes and items were added as well. Updates to all Insight 360 Revit addins including 2018, 2019, 2020.   This update can be found in software center for those users that utilize this cloud function as it relates to Revit.  These keep the addin consistent with the updates they are making to the product in the cloud. Keynote Manager 16 This update includes small improvements and compatibility with new licensing schema by the developer. PW Tools We have update our own Revit addin to make sure all functions are compatible with BIM360 models as well as improving the new project creation for the BIM360 process.  This update was made available for Revit 2019 and 2020. Enscape updates These updates are done for unseen items to how the application is compatible with some of the newest nVidia graphics cards which drives the visualization.   These cards are found in all of our newest generation of MSI laptops across the firm that are part of our Platform 3.0 Deadline 10 update This update was for background compatibility reason to make sure deadline functioned properly with other applications that are running on your laptop. There are more items coming soon with planned updates to Rhino 6, Convey, V-ray Next, Autodesk desktop connector, Navisworks, dRofus, and a handful of other application plugins.   The Digital Practice team carefully considers which updates our firm needs and is not always pushing every update to every machine in the firm.   This is to minimize the interference with your regular needs to use your laptop to design.  We will always need your help making sure you are finding the time to run these addins when prompted or on your own schedule through the software center on your laptop.

title: Adobe Creative Cloud 2020
content: Photoshop, Illustrator, InDesign and all other Adobe Creative Cloud applications will be upgraded to the latest version over the next month. This email marks the beginning of a two week phase that provides the option of upgrading at your convenience from Software Center . Beginning on February 6th you will begin to be prompted to install the update which you can defer each day for up to 2 weeks. All Computers will be upgraded automatically on February 20 th if not already complete. How to plan for this update The process will remove all Adobe 2018 apps installed on your computer except Adobe Acrobat and install all the same 2020 Adobe apps. You will be able to continue using any non-Adobe programs during the upgrade process.¬† The upgrade takes anywhere from 20 minutes (in the office with only the typical PS, AI, and ID) to 2 hours (outside of the office or on wifi with additional applications). Consider your project or team Please consider and communicate with your team members before upgrading.¬† Each application deals with differences in versions in their own way. ¬†Your team might be a project team or a proposal collaboration between design staff and Marketing.¬† Don‚Äôt put a deadline at risk due to poor planning.¬† An Adobe product version compatibility document is listed below. File type / Application Information Action PDF/Acrobat No changes No action required PSD/Photoshop Backwards compatibility seems to depend on whether you have used some of the latest functionality in 2020.¬† If you need compatibility with others who may not have yet upgraded please always choose ‚ÄúMaximum Compatibility‚Äù Always choose ‚ÄúMaximum Compatibility‚Äù option when prompted at save until the final upgrade deadline (February 20) AI/Illustrator Many elements, especially type, have been updated in the file format for Illustrator 2020.¬† The Illustrator file format for 2018 and 2019 is now called ‚ÄúIllustrator CC (Legacy)‚Äù INDD/InDesign Files are converted to latest version if saved in 2020.¬† Older versions of InDesign can convert 2020 files to be compatible but then a copy must be saved.¬† There is no collaboration between InDesign versions. Coordinate your upgrade with those you work with to maintain the ability to edit the same InDesign files. Premiere Pro The file format for 2020 is all new and not compatible.¬† Upon opening a file from an older version you are required to save a new file that is compatible with 2020. One issue that we found while testing is that video taken from phones (especially iPhones) shows as upside-down after the Premiere file was upgraded.¬† You can resolve the issue on affected clips by making them ‚Äúoffline‚Äù and then re-linking to the original file. Save the new copy of the file with a name that indicates 2020 and use the new version going forward. If you collaborate on video editing with others, coordinate your upgrade with them.

title: Will the next decade be ‚ÄúRoaring‚Äù?

author.name: Nick Cameron
author.description: American trucker who has been featured on the History channel reality television series Ice Road Truckers and its spinoff series IRT: Deadliest Roads.

content: As we look forward to a new decade, we thought it would be interesting to look in retrospect at technology in design over the last ten years and also think about what‚Äôs in store for us. In the 2010‚Äôs, we have seen the [re]introduction of VR but probably more importantly the ushering in of ‚Äúreal time ‚Äú rendering engines like Enscape and Lumion. The hope of interoperability between modeling tools Rhino and Revit have come a long way and we think it is almost [who has heard that one before] there. A lot of discussions over the past ten years have circled around Building Information Modeling ‚ÄúBIM‚Äù and still do, but the understanding of design modeling and its limitations has matured, will the next decade bring the necessary software solutions to finally deliver the model? Computational design was relatively niche back in 2010, but has become mainstream in universities, and now every studio has a handful of designers scripting, what will they craft in the 20‚Äôs. The firm has grown, the hardware we utilize has improved and the next decade will bring even greater improvements. So will we have a return to the ‚Äúroaring 20‚Äôs‚Äù; let‚Äôs see what may be to come: I foresee the design industry being disrupted by changes in how we manage, analyze and visualize big data sets. The move towards visual programming is making software development more accessible to design teams. I believe machine learning, and eventually full AI, will allow us to analyze large data sets to make educated design decisions. I believe these changes and advances in digital fabrication will lead to redefining the entire design and construction process from an end-to-end life-cycle and supply chain view. Razan Altiraifi Washington DC Studio In the next decade, I foresee a direct application of machine learning widely disrupting the design process as we know it. Machine learning is dependent on large, clean data sets and Perkins&Will has such an extensive data set (past projects) that have been successful and well documented. We will be able to leverage these data sets in a way that ML could be leveraged to automate a lot of the initial documentation; such that, as we design mock sets for those design will run in tandem. Mario Romero Digital Practice With the portability of VR that was introduced this year, I do not think it will take long for more of our DD meetings in VR than on paper, specifically in healthcare. VR allows us to communicate with end users more effectively than ever; streamlining the DD process and limiting the mock-ups needed. Integrations with BIM 360 make it easier than ever for platforms to piggyback off our models, making our models and their accuracy more important than ever. Though the contracts are slow to change, the construction industry will continue to push architecture and engineering to create models that are ‚Äúready to build‚Äù.
