It will be interesting to see how the industry standard contracts change to meet the ever-growing integration of technology in our industry. Rachel Gruber Dallas Studio The 2000s began with existing disbelief about the application of digital tools in the practice of architectural design. However, the 10s ended with excessive flourishing adoptions of The Digital while some were still considering. As a consequence, in the realm of design, rising global optimism to the performance added by utilizing the digital can mainstream digital collaboration, human-machine interaction, and above all, computational iteration and optimization in almost every design process. Ali Amirakbari SHL Our teams will be more diverse with users scientists psychologists sociologists, material specialists, construction managers, and architects, interior designers, urban designers, and digital masters. Robert Brown Boston Studio I foresee the design industry being disrupted by newer, experimental, and agile methods of direct-design-to-fabrication.  These make their best use of refinement of design intent down to the essentials of pure constituent elements that align with the use of location intelligence, automated fabrication, and a system of algorithms.  The algorithms in both bits and synthetics, but driven by human ingenuity and innovation, make the best match of construction systems, performance, material intelligence, embedded electronics, and environmental barrier suitable to a particular climate or harsh environment like off-world. In the end, we do not need the model, but rather the underlying design intelligence of the project. Tyrone Marshall Atlanta Studio I foresee the design industry being disrupted by companies like google, sidewalk labs and airbnb advancing into the AEC marketplace with new tech offerings that designers can tap into. The business model in our industry will continue to transform as more of a specialist services model and it is possible that companies that maintain the traditional approach of bums on seats may not survive. It will also be interesting to see if the huge investment in proptech and contech in the last two years will further continue and if these companies succeed or fail over the next few years. Robotics will continue to develop and play a big part as the technology that drives them becomes more cost effective, faster and common place. David Sewell London Studio In the next decade, I foresee the design industry being disrupted by ‚Ä¶‚Ä¶‚Ä¶climate change and how technology will help reverse the negative impact buildings have had with this issue. Jason Diamond Atlanta Studio The future is all about machines, very dramatic to say it in such terms. I believe that in the next decade Automation and Machine Learning will gradually take central stage, bringing with them a strong, very much needed, data driven foundation, and changing the way we approach the design process as we know it. The biggest challenges for each one of us will be first of all to be willing to embrace the change, to be ready to dynamically adapt to the fast pace of technology, and most importantly to be able to firmly take the steering wheel of these ‚Äúnew‚Äù emerging technology. Giancarlo Gastaldin SHL I see the next decade moving us forward with how we partner to create great buildings in the real world. We will start to provide construction instructions for robots as much as humans who will be doing the work. This will necessitate that we start creating true digital twins and allow for artificial intelligence to figure out the best means and methods by which objects and systems get built.   We will have to double down on our digital literacy in order to have even higher levels of accuracy in our digital information. Matt Petermann Digital Practice I see a leveling of the field. Renderings are not done by that one person who knows how to render. Real time render software like Enscape allows anyone to not just walk the model, but to render countless renderings in real time. Access to data from the model is no longer limited to those using Revit. BIM 360 allows all stake holders the ability to access the model. Client‚Äôs are no longer forced to understand design via abstract 2D drawings or fixed point perspectives. VR allows them to immerse themselves and ‚Äúget it‚Äù. Computational and generative design are no longer relegated to the office coder. Apps like Dynamo Player and Autodesk Refinery are opening up automation and iterative design to all designers. And this is at the beginning of 2020. Just where we‚Äôll be 10 years from now is anyone‚Äôs guess, but one can‚Äôt help but feel optimistic about a future where all levels of technology begin to be accessible to all. Damian Ponton Miami Studio I think the biggest change in how we deliver for clients will be surrounding BIM as a deliverable.¬†Despite all the technology at our hands, our industry is still crippled by the paper drawing set deliverable.¬†With Design Assist contractor and fabricator relationships, we might be at the dawn of Model deliverables for Construction. Daniel Prager Chicago Studio I believe the biggest change in how we deliver our designs for clients will be¬†in the design tools we use, the way we communicate these designs and the data exchange platforms that we work with. Even though we are only now seeing slow advances in interoperability between software, I‚Äôd like to think of tools as light weight and effective at freeform modelling as rhino but with the data and parametric capabilities of Revit. The outputs from these super tools would live in a decentralised, agnostic web based platform, connected to live data inputs from the ever changing physical world. It may also be that every designer has a virtual design assistant validating design ideas using AI and generative design processes. London Studio I foresee the evolutionary change where architectural design will be supplemented by AI checking codes, running rapid design iterations for optimization, and creating documentation for construction, which will become almost completely automated as well. There will be a focus on adaptive reuse of existing buildings in large cities, economic and efficient transportation for individuals. People will telecommute with much richer interactive experience (holograms?). Office space might become a virtual hangout, and architects will be busy re-purposing all the office space to other uses. Helen Gorina Digital Practice One area that I have taken a keen interest in over recent years is how our designs will be communicated as technology advances. With VR having only limited ‚Äúexperience‚Äù use case in our workspace, it is AR that will increase an expand. Some of the tools and AR-capable devices that have been proposed for more than a decade as becoming the norm, may finally realise the promise of now being only a few years away from mainstream. AR will assist us with design verification, making it simple to see how a variety of design options may impact the end user, town planning approval process, construction site or operations team, especially when lightweight hardware comes coupled with the Invisibility cloak‚Ä¶ Jordan Lane London Studio The next decade will mainstream the digital technology that picked up momentum in the late 10‚Äôs. We will see multiple variations of interactive modeling, implementation of digital documentation and AR, while countless options of generative design tools will assess the design problematics to ease some of our decision making. However as large sets of data will be collected and worked upon, I believe that the very big change is none of the above, rather ‚Äúto whom and what‚Äù will we design for? What shall the designers be designing when clients, developers, municipalities, etc, can themselves ‚Äúlayout the cards‚Äù and use the same design tools as previously only ‚Äúspecialists‚Äù could interact with? I guess that a true transformation of the future architectural practice will start with the digital services focusing on gathering data related to building performance (materials, environment, maintenance, etc) and most importantly, human behavior and the true usage of space. These will inform upfront the next design model, truly based on data evidence and no longer preaching empirical design approaches. But once all AI&ML is mainstreamed, and fully implemented Digital Fabrication and robotics is a reality, when all sectors of society will be affected by tremendous efficiencies, where will (especially but not exclusively) the blue collar worker be spending their time, now that this workforce became redundant? How will this affect work-life-leisure as we know it, with focus on those that are more vulnerable to the next generation technology taking over their jobs? So what shall we be designing, and to whom are we designing for? Tiago Pereira SHL

title: Wrong Node Alert
content: Wrong Node Alert i s a Perkins&Will Revit tool that alerts the user when they open a revit file on the wrong node. (Updated 1/28/2020) The term ‚ÄúWrong Node‚Äù means a user opening a Revit project on a node machine that does not match the city where the project file server is residing in. For example opening a Boston project (P:\Boston\‚Ä¶\Project.rvt), on a New York Node (NYOCN0204) would cause the wrong node alert to pop up and suggest that you log into the Boston node to work on the Boston project file. Or anyone of these other conditions: Opening a Project Cloud project on your local laptop instead of PWC nodes. Opening a project on a thin client (not an MSI laptop) Opening a project outside the office (offsite) The reason we care when a user is using the wrong node is because wrong node can causes some serious problems including: Slow performance: It takes longer to load a Boston file from NYO than it is to load a Boston file from Boston. Delay: Saving and synching to central may take longer than normal when working remotely. File Corruption: the delay in performance often causes corruption in the Revit file integrity, which will lead to unpleasant error message and major headaches for the project team down the road. Clearly, no one wants to corrupt their Revit project file. Often this happens unintentionally as people work on multiple projects from different offices and forget to change the node as they swtich between projects. They may have saved a few minutes for themselves from not changing the nodes, but as they corrupted the file by working on the wrong node, the team will have to pay for it by losing many more hours of work just to fix those errors. The moral of the story is don‚Äôt work on the wrong node, always match the node city with the project city and you will work smoother, be happier and live longer! What do I do if I see the Wrong Node Alert? If you see the wrong Node Alert. just Stop, Close and Change Node . Stop what you are doing. Close the Revit file. Log into the matching city Node (Open New York file on New York Node, Boston file on Boston Node, ProjectCloud on Project Cloud Nodes.etc.) Just as a precaution, an alert message will be sent to the Design Application Manager of the office that are affected by your action. You might be getting a call from them soon. Options Close All Documents and Exit Revit : When only 1 document is open, you will see the option to close all and exit Revit. This option will prompt you to save and exit Revit automatically. Close and Continue : This option will close the pop up window, send an alert to the DA, and let you continue as normal. When more than 1 document is open, this will be the only option given to you, since we don‚Äôt want to force you to close up any other Revit document that is still open. Kindly close the offending Revit file, and log into the proper matching node to re-open the Revit file on the correct node. Read More : Read more will bring you to this page on the pulse! What if I just need to copy a detail from my other project? Question : I‚Äôm working on the right city node, but I just need to copy a small detail from my other project that is not in this city‚Äôs projects, do I still need to change node? Answer : In this case, you can open the other project by detaching it, and that will avoid any problem from corrupting the other project file! and the Wrong Node Alert will ignore all detached file opening events. Note: Wrong Node Alert will only be installed for Revit 2018, 2019, and 2020

title: Around the studios: Leading edge technology in our projects.
content: Perkins&Will is known for our projects taking advantage of creative use of design technology, visualization, analysis, and automation. This year many projects benefited from advanced use of technology,  with our experts blazing the trail and disseminating know-how to the teams. We are proud to present several outstanding solutions implemented on the projects this year. Rapid design iterations with automatic documentation CHoP PAOB, New York Studio EXTERIOR DESIGN TEAM Rob Goodwin; Sean Erickson; Emma Peng; Eric Baker; Dahmahlee Lawrence COMPUTATIONAL TEAM Helen Gorina, Dahmahlee Lawrence CHoP PAOB  project utilized  computational approach using system of adaptive components for rapid design iterations of gradated curtain-wall. This approach allowed the team to quickly generate and study various design options and solve many design challenges. In addition, this approach allowed us automate the documentation, so instead of painstakingly re-dimensioning every time we adjust our design, we used much more efficient method: documenting with schedules. Computational design team: Helen Gorina (Digital Practice) and Dahmalee Lawrence (NY Studio). More details about this project challenges and solutions can be found here To see recorded session, click here (the project starts on 24th minute) Helen Gorina Digital Practice Extra Large Project Set Up MQCC Vancouver studio BIM planning for mega projects is always specialized due to the number of components and duration of projects. The key to breaking them down lies in finding simplicity within the chaos and complexity. Well documented processes help communicate to large teams the method in which they are to work. The framework must be robust enough to anticipate and adjust for change, as it is inevitable. The presentation of the Coquitlam Centre project walks through the set up and principles by which the team is working large scale and on tight and demanding deadlines. I expected change as a constant from the onset of this project. We went from 10 towers to 9 right from the start. The most surprising thing was how many times levels changed. The are roughly 500 levels in the project and they have been shifting up and down, sometimes daily, to handle the client‚Äôs changing demands. The system put in place has been robust enough that there have not been any major issues with the models. Eli Wolpin Senior Architect, Vancouver This workflow will be presented live on Thursday February 14 on a firm wide Design and Delivery eXchange conference call. You can join the community from https://digitalpractice.perkinswill.com/digital-practice-exchange/#upcoming-events

title: Digital Practice Core eXchange
content: Digital Practice Core eXchange The Digital Practice team has worked hard to prepare another quarterly Core eXchange.¬† These continuing education sessions are designed to give new employees as well as everyone else a heightened awareness of the tools and processes available to us at Perkins&Will. We have removed a few classes from the previous core exchange sessions which you can always find the recordings for on our site. There are many new classes to the lineup with topics like; Autodesk BIM360, Materiality, the Perkins&Will Speed platform, new Revit documentation subjects and more on Microsoft Teams.¬† We plan to livestream the sessions so you can view them from your desk and don‚Äôt worry if the session you want to check out interferes with another meeting, all the sessions will be uploaded to our growing library here . These classes will be offered by our team and other experts across the firm through live webcasts over the course of 3 days starting on Tuesday, January 14th and running on the 15th and 16th as well.¬† You can look for additional information from your local Design Applications Manager as the dates approach. The times for these live events vary depending on your location and are listed below. We will be covering a variety of topics from design to visualization and collaboration to production. Each of these will be in the form of a 45-minute presentation allowing for some time for question and answer at the end and a break before the next session begins.¬† We want to make sure that everyone across the firm is aware of the fundamental tools and process we have available to enable high performing teams. All Times Eastern GMT-5 Click Title to add to your Calendar You will be getting more information on the details of each class and other logistics for you to know what sessions might benefit you the most. These core skills are the building blocks to leverage our tools in more advanced ways. Don‚Äôt worry if you are not able to make some of these classes,¬† they will be recorded and found here .¬† Because everyone‚Äôs daily job is different the expectation is that you would only attend the classes that directly relate to your typical project/work tasks.

title: Mobile Robotic Assistant for Architectural Design, MRAAD, for short

author.name: Nick Cameron
author.description: American trucker who has been featured on the History channel reality television series Ice Road Truckers and its spinoff series IRT: Deadliest Roads.

content: Armando Here is an excerpt from a Redshift article published just before Thanksgiving about the  Mobile Robotic Assistant for Architectural Design (MRAAD) project undertaken by Hakim Hasan and Andy Tsay Jacobs. Over the years, architects‚Äô toolsets have evolved‚Äîfrom paper, pens, and rulers to modeling clay, scanners, and hot-wire cutters. While many of the tools and processes have changed, one thing has remained the same: architects build a physical model of the design before creating the final product. But what if you could feed your digital design to a small robotic arm equipped with all the tools necessary to bring your physical model to fruition? A researcher at Perkins&Will has created just that‚Äîthe Mobile Robotic Assistant for Architectural Design (MRAAD, for short). Watch the video to learn more about this innovative robotic arm for architects.

title: Winter Software Updates
content: Through the fall and into the winter many design applications have been updated. These updates include new releases with new functionality to bug fixing. Below are a few of the most notable updates. Whats new in Revit In addition to scaled up piloting of BIM 360 , many third party tools were updated to be compatible with BIM 360 and Revit 2020 . We continue improving our content libraries hosted on HIVE , and the latest enhancements to HIVE will allow content managers to distribute saved searches to their teams and studios, which will make search even more efficient. Additionally, to further  streamline the search we are consolidating versions ‚Äì specific Revit libraries , but do not worry: the content will be filtered automatically to ‚Äúsense‚Äù the current version of Revit you are using. There upgrades should be completed by the end of December. Whats new in Rhino 6 The long beta period is over: Grasshopper is now a full-fledged part of Rhino. Grasshopper provides the solid foundation for many incredible third-party components ranging from environmental analysis to robotic control.  Bundled with Rhino 6 is the same Grasshopper you have been using, plus many enhancements. It is compatible with existing components and includes new ones out of the box. This version also has improved visualization workflows ‚Äì major changes to Rendering, Materials and presentation tools. Display system can now take advantage of modern graphics hardware, display speed can be up to 300% faster. And as always some bugs are squashed and glitches resolved. Whats new in Enscape v 2.5 Many of our designers use real-time visualization feedback of Enscape. The latest upgrade to v. 2.5 brings more features: Expanded web based asset library ‚Äì free and very realistic. New material editing options, Video Editor improvements  and many other enhancements. Whats new in Lumion 10.0 In this release Lumion users will find many improved features . The top three are: High-quality preview feature can help save you from the guesswork when going through the render editing process, while giving you more confidence when setting up the lighting, weather, shadows, materials and photo compositions. WATCH Fin e-detail nature models ‚Äì Containing 62 tree and plant species, these nature models are high-polygon, finely detailed trees and plants designed for close-up views and for the foreground of your images and videos. WATCH Displacement mapping ‚Äì to 167 materials. With the movement of a slider, you can adjust the depth and geometry of the selected material, giving it a realistic, three-dimensional look and feel. WATCH

title: Augmenting Reality: Enhancing Hand Build Models with Digital Overlays
content: For our November VizR eXchange, Simon Chavez and Chance Heath presented their incubator project that created an augmented reality(AR) application with Unity. The AR application enables the user to integrate a physical model with digital content around that model to create an AR experience. Using a custom created holdout shader and a photogrammetrically scanned mesh, the physical model will be visible in the AR overlay and can even occlude and block virtual assets that are behind it. The framework is hosted on GitHub and is available for any Perkins & Will employees to download and use on their own project by simply switching out the scanned mesh and the digital model. Click HERE to learn more about this innovation incubator project. Click HERE for the github codes to download (only for Unity on Mac OS)

title: Dispatches from Autodesk University 2019

author.name: Nick Cameron
author.description: American trucker who has been featured on the History channel reality television series Ice Road Truckers and its spinoff series IRT: Deadliest Roads.

content: This year Autodesk attracted over 12,000 attendees to its annual design technology conference held in Las Vegas. The four day event covers many facets of architecture, engineering and construction technologies as well as media [think Hollywood cg] and manufacturing. The week packs in a tremendous number of demo‚Äôs, keynotes, presentations, round-table discussions and a expo floor full of various technology vendors. Autodesk leverages the conference to message what new technology is being developed on their road-map as well as reading the proverbial tea leaves for 2020 and beyond. Perkins&Will had over 10 speakers covering topics from robotic construction to cinematography techniques and were joined by colleagues from across our studios. Now we want to share what we learned, saw and thought you should know about from the pre-conference sessions to the keynote to the last day, when everyone is running on coffee. Below are the key takeaways from those who attended. ‚ÄúI went to Autodesk University wondering if Perkins&Will was at the forefront of technology. After attending several sessions with leading firms presenting their strategies and challenges, I discovered that we are in fact at the forefront through our use and research into Generative Design and Robotics. There are clear challenges all firms are facing when integrating multiple software such as Revit and Rhino. This will continue to be a challenge until there is a streamlined process for them to interact in dual directions. Where we can improve, is in the use of tools to both speed up work and do away with the mundane. Dynamo is critical in this task and must be more widely used to automate processes. Keyboard shortcuts can also speed up work, as demonstrated in one course, by more than 50%. Automation will allow us to be more efficient and let us focus on the design rather than the mundane.‚Äù Eli Wolpin Vancouver Studio ‚ÄúI attended the Forge DevCon pre-conference where I was excited about the potential to build custom applications and interfaces over BIM 360 using the Forge platform . I was particularly interested in the use of gaming engines such as Unity and Unreal to streamline the process of going from BIM 360 to AR and VR. Autodesk demonstrated the Forge AR|VR Toolkit which provides a set of APIs to develop custom augmented and virtual reality experiences, while Unity previewed their soon to be released Unity Reflect real-time 3D app. I also attended a few developer workshops that walked through the process of developing on the Forge platform. ‚Äú Razan Altiraifi Washington DC Studio / Digital Practice ‚Äù There were many excellent classes about BIM 360 efficiencies, best practices, management and troubleshooting. If you are new to BIM 360, I recommend this detailed overview . I also recommend two classes for BIM360 users who want to improve their productivity and troubleshoot  BIM 360 problems .‚Äù Helen Gorina New York City Studio / Digital Practice ‚ÄúThis was my first time attending Autodesk University and in all reality, I didn‚Äôt know what to expect. I filled my schedule with classes that I thought would help me and the studio streamline the process that we currently have in place with regards to document management during Construction Administration.¬† With Autodesk‚Äôs recent acquisition of Plan Grid a class that I found interesting and that could benefit Perkins&Will, is the Integration of BIM 360 and Plan Grid .  I am currently working on a project where the General Contractor is using Plan Grid and we are using BIM 360 so having the ability to push field observation reports directly to the GCs Plan Grid account would facilitate in tracking any field deficiencies that arise through the construction process. Another takeaway from AU is that virtual reality keeps having a major presence and finding the correct platform to best communicate with clients is a challenge. BIM 360 VR Collaboration with Insite VR takes the traditional 11√ó17 room data sheets out of the equation and allows owners to make immediate markups in VR, publish ‚Äúissues‚Äù and have them available to the design team live on the cloud. I am fortunate to have Rachel Gruber in the Dallas Studio who has worked closely with Insite VR to implement this powerful tool in her projects, can‚Äôt wait to implement this on my future projects.‚Äù Francisco Velasquez Dallas Studio ‚Äù This class, Dynamo from BIM Automation to Generative Design , really opened my eyes to what‚Äôs possible. The examples we got to play with would be very beneficial to the CCC team for massing. In addition, Project Refinery would benefit our CI team for layout options. The generative design workflows they shared with us are pushing the threshold on what‚Äôs possible in the early stages of design.‚Äù Stephen Grant Austin Studio / Digital Practice ‚ÄúThe Mercedes Benz EQ House by the Japanese firm Takenaka Corporation was an amazing example of a project encapsulating the latest technologies in all phases of design, construction and occupancy. Plus it was designed and built in under a year‚Äù Dean Demko LA Studio / Digital Practice ‚ÄúI was happy to see Virtual Reality being used to teach ADA codes and create empathy in designers by the firm Shepley Bulfinch. Arkio is making advances in the field of modeling using Virtual Reality. I attended a demo where they demonstrated how multiple people can be simultaneously immersed in the same environment, all modeling at the same time.¬†The live demo of Twinmotion blew my mind with how quickly one can populate an entire scene in real time, including high quality landscaping, weather effects, and entourage. Damian Ponton Miami Studio / Digital Practice ‚ÄúAutodesk University brings out the very best when it comes to technology for the AEC industry. It was thrilling to experience firsthand all the new advances in real-time visualization efforts, improvements in production workflows and efficiencies, innovative approaches to creative problem solving, and motivating lectures given by industry heavyweights.¬† I was pleasantly surprised to learn more about a new workflow between Civil 3d and Revit, which has tremendous potential to save us time by leveraging data we traditionally don‚Äôt consume. Geolocation, topography, survey points, and integration into the BIM 360 cloud are now being streamlined and integrated into the Revit workflow. The days of geometry exceeding 20km are limited! This is something to get excited about! ‚Äú Tyler Ostrozynski Dallas Studio ‚ÄúIt was refreshing to know how much further along Perkins&Will is with integrating BIM360 into our design process. At the same time, I appreciated the other firms tips and tricks on utilization. I walked away with a great deal of knowledge on how to better take advantage of some of the tools.‚Äù Justin Benjamin Washington DC Studio / Digital Practice ‚ÄúThe Design Automation API for Revit is a new set of tools that allows users to open, view and edit a Revit model in the cloud. Yes, somebody without Revit software, or the skills to use it, can access and change the linked database that gets updated in a Revit model. It is a very cool concept, and we will see some exciting new tools come from it.‚Äù David Sewell London Studio / Digital Practice ‚ÄúIt was evident that the ‚ÄúReal-Time‚Äù battle for the AEC market is in full force. Unity, backed by Autodesk, has made significant improvements with Unity Reflect.  Twinmotion now has the power of Epic Games with plans to allow a back-and-forth workflow with Unreal Engine. Enscape and Lumion continue to move forward with frequent updates. One class that had me thinking was ‚ÄúMaking Game Engines Work for Engineers‚Äù.  Before you write this one off, the topic was about using the game engine for more than just visualization.  It focused on the unique point of view that can be created in the ‚Äúgame‚Äù as well as the robust physics system that can be utilized.‚Äù Justin Cooper Atlanta Studio ‚ÄúI spent the majority of my time in the Expo hall meeting with existing Hardware vendors, like MSI and potential new partners. Spending time with experts and newer hardware, can really speed up an understanding of how this hardware would integrate into our platform. The expo also offers a bit of a crystal ball as to what we may be seeing in the not too distant future.‚Äù Gerald Van Benschop Houston Studio / Global Technology Services ‚ÄúAfter working with Angel Say at InsiteVR for months testing their new software with the Oculus Quest, it was great to finally meet him in person and demo the new updates they were testing at AU. Using Virtual Reality for Knowledge Transfer and Teaching Empathetic Design looked at using VR to train architects what accessible spaces feel like that the differences between the different codes. And Augmented Reality: Speeding Up Field Verification and Communication was a create case study on using the Microsoft HoloLens in the field for construction verification and site visits. The entire experience makes the future of our industry seem so much closer and you can‚Äôt help but be excited for it.‚Äù Rachel Gruber Dallas Studio ‚ÄúThe Forge DevCon exhibited some incredibly interesting developments. Two of note were a custom application to integrate BIM 360 with ARKit which streamlined creating USDZ models directly from Revit models. USDZ‚Äôs are super cool because they‚Äôre a easy way to jump into AR from any iOS device. Another cool development is that Autodesk is looking to make creating Forge applications a bit more user friendly by creating nodes for Node-RED which is a visual scripting platform very similar to Grasshopper and Dynamo. This will allow non-programmers to create pretty advanced, bespoke tools that integrate directly with BIM 360!‚Äù Mario Romero Chicago Studio / Digital Practice ‚ÄúI have two main highlights for AU 2019.¬† The first is the all-day Dynamo for Software Developers workshop, where we used Python and C# to manipulate geometry and data within Revit.¬† We also used C# to create a simple Add-in on the tab within Revit.¬† I had some experience with scripting in the past, but this workshop definitely challenged me.¬† The second highlight was Custom Computational & Cloud-Enabled Workflows for BIM Design Implementation, which was presented by Eckart Schwerdtfeger (BIM specialist from Zaha Hadid Architects).¬† This guy blows my mind every year, and did not disappoint this time around.¬† He was sending tasks to the cloud that would take a panel assembly created by Rhino/Grasshopper and create a revit file with the same assembly, but with native revit adaptive component families.¬† He was using Forge and cloud services to do other things, like print a PDF set.¬† He used an Amazon go button to print PDFs.¬† Then, he used Siri on the iPhone to create a PDF task to print a sheet set from Revit.¬† Amazing stuff!‚Äù Jason Diamond Atlanta Studio / Digital Practice

title: Pitching to a Wider Audience‚Ä¶..
content: ‚ÄòIncreasingly we need ways of differentiating us from our competitors. This was a tough pursuit where quality of design and our approach to co-creation really won the day. Having the ability to share our design proposals with a large group of people and invite comments showed our digital innovation.‚Äô Linzi Cassels, Principal, Design Director We were recently shortlisted on a large scale Interior Design project for EBRD‚Äôs new headquarters in Canary Wharf London. The last stage of the pitch was to compete against the other chosen design firms in providing a full concept design of the buildings interior, taking into account EBRD‚Äôs core values. The final presentation was to be exhibited over a 5 day period to allow as many members of EBRD‚Äôs staff as possible to review and engage with the scheme but also provide valuable feedback to both the designers and EBRD‚Äôs senior management. The presentation space itself was restricted to a maximum of 18sqm with the team electing to use 10No 2000mm x 610mm vertically hung boards and a LCD screen (Just for good measure everything also had to be fireproofed!) With a tight deadline, the team worked into the small hours over the space of the week and with the presentation material being finalized, the challenge of reaching an audience past exhibition area footfall, was met with the idea of packaging the entire scheme into a digital wrap via a bespoke PW project website and VX app. With only a one day timeframe‚Ä¶‚Ä¶ it was time to call the Viz Lab hotline. Following a flurry of emails, phone calls and frantic instant message chat between the newly formed ‚Äúdigital content team‚Äù late one evening, ideas were shared, a brief given and a plan formed. The result 24 hours later ‚Äì ‚Ä¢ One Branded Website ‚Äì Click to Preview ‚Ä¢ One VX Project App ‚Ä¢   Completed in One Day ‚Ä¢   With only O ne evening‚Äôs notice, by Andrea Manzano from the VIZLAB. In addition to the physical material boards being embedded into the website as separate web-pages the site also featured a feedback page and received a large number of responses and website hits. We know we reached those that hadn‚Äôt maybe seen the physical exhibition space as EBRD staff had asked for links to share with others. Staff Feedback Staff Feedback Feedback was good, QR codes were scanned, headsets worn and websites visited which all helped communicate a very strong design idea. So, what happened, how did it go ? ‚Ä¶ Well we only went and won it ! Contracts have been signed and it‚Äôs now time to get on with the task ahead but team feedback was good.  Not only did the digital content help communicate the design and reach a wider audience but it‚Äôs often a real differential. Our interior design competitors in London just do not have the resource of the Perkins&Will‚Äôs digital practice team and tapping into this is something we are striving to use much more to our advantage. Final ‚ÄúPitch Space‚Äù As I‚Äôm part of the Digital Practice team I am obviously a little bias in all of this but I do appreciate it might not be the sole reason for us winning the project‚Ä¶‚Ä¶‚Ä¶‚Ä¶.. so see below for some feedback quotes from those who were part of the presentation/exhibition team. ‚ÄòOur digital tools are such a useful part of the design and communication journey on live projects. It was excellent to be able to start the journey at pitch stage for EBRD; ultimately it was part of our success.‚Äô Joelle Laney, Senior Associate My final mention goes to my fellow members of the 24 hour digital content team, Joelle Laney (senior designer), Charlotte Nash (senior bid coordinator) and Andrea Manzano (VIZLAB) along with a thanks to Nick Cameron for help pulling the strings to make it happen. We are already sharing more ideas to deliver richer outputs, improve end user experience and create locally managed templates as we see this material becoming business as usual on must win presentations. Hopefully more will follow, so watch this (web)space‚Ä¶. Digital Practice can help shape projects from bid to handover so I‚Äôd always suggest reaching out to those associated folks in your offices. We have access to so much resource and may even offer new ideas, processes and solutions that are just a little different to those tried and tested old school methods, they may even assist you winning a project.

title: Do you Matterport?
content: The Software Games If the movies The Hunger Games & Karate Kid had a baby, the result would be The Software Games. What is it? Why do it? How were you able to pull it off? Who is Jordan Hanson? These are all great questions and I can appreciate the enthusiasm. If you are familiar with who I am (the Justin Benjamin), you know how well I can get to the point quickly‚Ä¶ üòâ Bare with me as I attempt to tackle explaining what could possibly replace the Olympics (this is quite the exaggeration‚Ä¶ but my heart was in the right place when I decided to make the comparison). The What. Consider ‚ÄúTrivia night‚Äù at your local watering hole. It‚Äôs success is likely tied to its social atmosphere (ie bonding with peers), a taste of competition (ie teamwork), a thirst for knowledge (ie training) and then a sprinkle of some type of monetary incentive (ie bribery). Now aside from the bribery (which still plays a part), the remaining reasons make for an ideal company outing‚Ä¶ In a nutshell, that is the atmosphere we are shooting for when it comes to The Software Games. We just focus less on history/pop culture fun facts, and more on design application utilization. The Why. The Software Games is an effort developed in our New York office as an alternative form of training. Instead of rambling on about the importance of implementation as it relates to all of our innovations and application acquisitions. I will assume we can all agree that a strategy for rolling out the new tool is critical and this strategy will always incorporate training‚Ä¶ Video tutorials are rarely watched. Documentation is rarely resourced proactively. Pushing staff into a room with me for multiple days as I run through Revit exercises‚Ä¶ Well, that is just mean. The How. There are 4 rounds (1 task is created for each round). Rounds are 5 minutes long (the complexity of each task reflects the allotted time ‚Äì contestants should have a reasonable chance in completing the task). Come game night, the audience is asked for volunteers (4 people can play per round). Those volunteers sit at one of the prepared laptops. All laptops are projected to a common screen for audience enjoyment. The MC makes them aware of the task and then calls it‚Ä¶ Ready. Set. Go! *If staff proved reluctant to volunteer when asked, the offices DTLs were made aware of their forced participation‚Ä¶ Just to get the ball rolling. That said, it wasn‚Äôt necessary to call upon them! The Result. Our first competition was focused around Affinity (lending to the title The Software Games: Affinity War). It was deliberately chosen because of the lack of adoption ‚ÄòAffinity Photo‚Äô has gotten since Perkins&Will adopted the software in December 2018.¬†Knowing that our office had many people confident in their photo editing skills, but lacked the basic knowledge of this program, made it a prime candidate for our first competition. The excitement during the competitions created a huge crowd to gather from the office to watch and support their peers. This setup allowed the competitors to learn the software, but gave the audience glimpses into the many different techniques that could be used to solve the challenges. Everyone Wins! Upon each rounds completion, the MC will review aloud the work completed by each contestant. He will ask for audience applause to help with any tough decisions. Prizes are awarded as follows: Was the task completed (minimum requirements)? Yes = $10 Amazon Who did the best job? 1 Person awarded another $10 Amazon Did you participate? No tangible prize is given, but respect from your peers for trying‚Ä¶ That is priceless. Oh yeah, you also likely picked up a skill from having tried. SHOUT OUT TO OUR FIRST ‚ÄúTHE SOFTWARE GAMES‚Äù WINNERS! The Future. We intend to do a couple more games internally (office specific). Once the kinks are worked out, we are going national. Washington DC‚Ä¶ NY is coming for you next. As for the rest of the studios‚Ä¶ Come time you are called upon‚Ä¶ Are you going to be ready? Or are you going to be scared? The Software Games. Come Compete. Come Watch. Come Learn. Jordan Hanson? Aspiring Architect. Lead DTL. Adequate ping pong player (yet to beat me‚Ä¶ its adorable). It was his attendance at Pixels of Fury that proved to be the foundation (architectural pun intended) for what we now refer to as The Software Games. Thank you Jordan (sorry about the ping pong player comment‚Ä¶)

title: VR Presentation and Coordination for Suzhou Science + Technology Museum
content: Visualization is always critical for design concepts‚Äô delivery. To assist clients and consultants in better understanding our design ideas, Shanghai office is pushing forward different kinds of visualization applications. On October 10th, we launched our first VR presentation with clients and consultants for Suzhou Science and Technology Museum‚Äôs CD discussion. Suzhou STM is a collaboration project between Chicago and Shanghai office with emphasizes on Suzhou‚Äôs long historical use of silk. Its detailed facade design was completed through rhino and grasshopper using computational design tools (To learn more about this computational design, please refer to this article: Suzhou Science + Technology Museum ‚Äì Weaving A Complex Facade ). Below are some pictures showing this project. Due to the complexity of facade and lack of BIM tools from structural engineers, clash detection was performed relatively late and there were a numbers of clashes between architectural and structural models which would need deep and complex modifications. On our side, we would like to keep our architectural facade consistent along the whole design process. Therefore, in order to give our clients, structural engineers and other consultants a more intuitive feeling of the actual space, we invited them to our office for an immersive VR trip inside our architectural working model. Facade patterns and materials (except glasses) were all removed to focus only on shape and space feelings, as shown in the GIF below. Examples of Scenes Showing to Clients We were pleased to see that everyone in the meeting really enjoy this VR tour. Both clients and structural engineers complimented the space feeling a lot and demonstrated that this kind of presentation gave them an unprecedented and direct perception about the whole project. They were always questioning that level heights might be a little bit low; but while experiencing in real scale, level heights seem to be exactly as they want. Our designers also had a chance to discuss specific curtain details with curtain consultants while walking through the entire project. The overall feedback from this first VR presentation is pretty positive. With these positive results, Shanghai office is also considering moving VR equipment to our largest meeting room permanently for a convenience to provide these kind of presentation more.

title: SPEED ‚Äì Energy, Solar, and Daylighting Analysis for Designers
content: What is SPEED and what can I do with it? SPEED is a web-based and cloud-based energy/daylighting/solar design and simulation platform for early design we developed for architects enabling a 1-day turn-around from design question to a data-driven design answer. SPEED is particularly useful for when you don‚Äôt yet have a mechanical or energy consultant, or do but budget and schedule constraints prevent them from meeting your project needs. You can quickly create a project, run shading and solar studies in seconds, run a parametric study with hundreds or thousands of design options on the cloud in a matter of hours including statistical analysis, and interactively visualize the results and compare them against your project‚Äôs EUI benchmarks and targets. We hope that you will start using SPEED immediately on your project work since it is available to everyone at the firm right now, it is free for everyone to use, and it was developed in house with the firm‚Äôs design and sustainability goals in mind.   If you want to see more on SPEED before getting started check out the wiki page here .

title: Cinematography for Architecture
content: Whether we realize it or not, all of our clients are film critics. As video and animation become more essential to the architectural design process, it‚Äôs important that we have a basic understanding of filmmaking and cinematography. If a camera movement looks unnatural or the editing is slightly off, your client will notice and will be distracted, missing the key points you‚Äôre trying to convey. This presentation will provide an overview of basic filmmaking concepts that you can use to improve the quality of your architectural animations. You‚Äôll discover the techniques and core concepts important to professional filmmakers, as well as how to apply them in the architectural profession. We will cover the basics of filmmaking: framing, camera movement, music, and editing‚Äîall of which are critical to creating professional-looking films. Attendees will walk away with a basic knowledge of filmmaking concepts that will take their animations to the next level.

title: Linking BIM360 and Massformer at Autodesk Forge Accelerator
content: MassFormer exports directly to BIM360 In mid-September, Perkins&Will‚Äôs developer team participated in the Autodesk Forge Accelerator in New York City. Our four person developer team consists of Satya Basu, Iffat Mai, Matt Chan and Chan Youn. This was a joint effort between our Digital Practice Group and i/o Team to integrate our cloud based planning tool known as Massformer with the Revit software, more specifically to create a direct link between Massformer with the cloud version of Revit also known as BIM360. The Forge Accelerator was a special event hosted by the Autodesk‚Äôs Forge team to work with their clients and third-party developers to accelerate their development of cloud applications using the Forge API. Tasked with the mission to build the next generation of apps and tools, our team worked with Autodesk Forge experts for most of the week and successfully developed a Forge tool that connects our planning tool , Massformer, directly to BIM360 in the cloud. The Forge Accelerator in New York City was the first one held in New York by Autodesk. With over a dozen of companies participating in this event. Participants included many Architectural and Engineering firms (such as Woods Bagot and SHoP Architects), Contractors, Vendors, BIM consultants and other AEC services and software developers.  As more and more of our AEC data and applications are moving into the cloud, the new frontier for the AEC industry is clearly focused on Cloud Computing. Our custom tools needed to follow the movement and transition into the cloud platform as part of our migration to the cloud. All the companies attending the Forge Accelerator came with a proposed project that involved using Forge API to create the new tools needed to optimize their workflow with BIM360. Linking MassFormer with BIM360 was our team‚Äôs mission. Massformer is our web-based tool designed by Perkins&Will‚Äôs i/o team. As an early planning tool, Massformer is designed to give our designers a simple tool to create building massing, programming, space calculation and design options without having to know how to operate in Revit. However, in order to make this tool truly useful for our designers, Massformer needed to integrate downstream with our standard design software such as Revit and BIM360. Our goal was to create an easy button that will automatically export Massformer‚Äôs building data and geometry and recreate them as a Revit file with native Revit walls and floors, so the rest of the team can access it through BIM360 in the cloud. All this was accomplished by leveraging the power of Forge API. Our developers created a custom library (.DLL) that reads in our building data from MassFormer as JSON files. Then using the Forge Design Automation API for Revit, which was still in beta at that time, we were able to automate the data creation inside Revit as native Revit objects. All the process is taken care of in the cloud. Once the conversion process is complete, the user receives a notification with a link to download the Revit file, or to view the file in the Forge Viewer and has access to the 3D model and floor plans in BIM360. After this experience working at the Forge Accelerator, our developer team is confident that we will be able to further develop other tools that can help our teams to integrate with BIM360 with more ease and efficiency. Download the Revit File Show model in Forge Viewer BIM360 Model with walls, floors and levels

title: Digital Practice Core eXchange Library
content: The Digital Practice group is excited to provide continuing education for the ongoing quarterly Core eXchange.¬† ¬† It will give new (and existing) employees a better awareness of the core skills on the tools and processes we have at Perkins&Will.¬† This is the second time we are holding this event, which happens the first month of each quarter.¬† ¬†There are two new classes in this exchange from the previous one on Autodesk BIM360 and Microsoft Teams.¬† ¬†The rest of the classes are the same topics and information as last quarters Core eXchange event. All 25 / Core eXchange 19 Digital Practice Core eXchange ‚Äì Innovation Incubator Showcase Digital Practice Core eXchange ‚Äì Back to Basics: Teams + SharePoint Digital Practice Core eXchange ‚Äì Back to Basics with Pull Planning Digital Practice Core eXchange ‚Äì Overview of Bio-Based and Natural Materials Digital Practice Core eXchange ‚Äì Back to Basics with CCA Digital Practice Core eXchange ‚Äì Back to Basics: Conceptual/SD Analysis Digital Practice Core eXchange ‚Äì Foundations of Accessibility in Design Digital Practice Core eXchange ‚Äì Hub Apps Overview Digital Practice Core eXchange ‚Äì Back to Basics ‚Äì Area Sync Project Performance Annual Review: Reporting Digital Practice Core eXchange ‚Äì Digital Strategy Digital Practice Core eXchange ‚Äì Introduction to Digital Practice Digital Practice Core eXchange ‚Äì Back to Basics: Documentation, Publishing, and Printing Digital Practice Core eXchange ‚Äì Back to Basics: Rhino at Perkins&Will Digital Practice Core eXchange ‚Äì Microsoft Folder Linking 101 Digital Practice Core eXchange ‚Äì Back to Basics: Visualization at Perkins&Will Digital Practice Core eXchange ‚Äì Being on Schedule in Revit Digital Practice Core eXchange ‚Äì Back to Basics: Area Sync Digital Practice Core eXchange ‚Äì Code Compliance Workflows Digital Practice Core eXchange ‚Äì Annual Project Performance Reviews Digital Practice Core eXchange ‚Äì Back to Basics: Revit at Perkins&Will Digital Practice Core eXchange ‚Äì Revit Add-ins at Perkins&Will Digital Practice Core eXchange ‚Äì Avail: More Efficient Usage PMTK ‚Äì Contract Review Process Digital Practice Core eXchange ‚Äì Loops 2: Loop Another Day Page 1 of 11 1 2 3 ‚Ä∫ ¬ª The first day of classes covered various topics on production, design, and visualization.¬† ¬†You can see the video recordings and slide decks above on this page. We are covering these classes and topics to make sure that everyone in the entire firm has these core skills themselves or on their teams so certain basic software use problems do not occur as frequently and we can free up our time for more design exploration. These classes will be offered again at the beginning of the 1st quarter of next year.¬† ¬†New employees should plan on joining as well as those that missed this offering.¬† ¬†You will see some edits to presentations as well as some changes in topics but we will continuing to build this library of resources for people to look back upon.¬† ¬†Our intention as the Digital Practice group is to raise the overall skills of everyone across the board so that we are all better masters of the typical tools and process we use to do great design.

title: Markups in BIM360
content: Markups in BIM360 Over the life of a project, we spend a great amount of time working with PDF files from troubleshooting failed Clarity tasks to sending marked up PDFs via email to team members.¬† What if you never had to worry about these files, and the creation, opening, or saving of these?¬† What if you never had to look through your emails to find that PDF markup?¬† All of these activities have no real impact on your project, yet they consume a valuable commodity: time. ¬†With using BIM360, no one has to organize and manage where the markups are located.¬† The markups always live with the project in the cloud and are accessible to all project team members. In addition, this workflow eliminates any PDF printing issues because there is no PDF to print.¬† Creating markups in the BIM360 viewer is intuitive, simple, and can streamline communication to the project team in a very transparent way. To create a markup, you will need to be logged into your BIM360 project in the web browser.¬† Within the Document Management module, navigate to the Revit file that contains the published sheets, and click on it.¬† This will open a viewer that displays all the published sheets and 3D views for that file.¬† As a side note, publishing 3D views from your cloud models is a great way to track progress or communicate changes of complex design components that can be otherwise difficult to explain with 2D drawings. Using the markup tools on the right side of the browser, you can place text, clouds, dimensions, and draw lines/shapes.¬† All line-based markup elements can vary in color and thickness.¬† Any closed shapes in the markups (rectangles, clouds, etc.) can have a fill color with options to change the opacity.¬† ¬†Also, there are text controls for font size, color, line thickness, and fill color/opacity.¬† When your markup is complete, click the Save Markup button.¬† Any other team member that looks at the sheet will be able to see the markup. Now that you know how to create simple markups without needing a PDF file, the real power comes with attaching that markup to an Issue in BIM360, which will assign it to project team members and establish a due date.¬† Project team members will automatically receive an email when they have been assigned to an issue.¬† On the Project Home page in BIM360, each team member will see any issues that have been assigned to them along with the due date.¬† You can think of these issues as an ongoing to-do list.¬† When the change has been completed, the reviewer can mark the issue as closed, which will remove it from their to-do list.¬† With using markups (and issues) on BIM360, collaboration has never been this easy.

title: Five people in the Same Different Room
content: In architecture, we often need to lead the clients through our proposed design and get their feedback on what works and what needs to change. Traditionally, we walk them through a series of plans, sections and elevation drawings. Rachel Gruber from our Dallas Office, did just that recently with her healthcare clients, except she led the group through the space in Virtual Reality. After a series of traditional Design Development user meetings, the project team let them experience the space in person but as a group together in the Virtual World. Taking advantage of InsiteVR‚Äôs Oculus Quest study offer, the team was able to introduce multi-user Virtual Reality (VR) technology into their healthcare project and use VR to engage their healthcare clients, especially the ones that are not architecturally trained. In Healthcare, it is important to engage the doctors and nurses, who are primary users of the spaces. However, doctors and nurses are not architecturally trained, and they often have a hard time understanding the plans, sections and elevation drawings presented to them. Using VR devices, the users can experience the space immersively. Instead of the traditional single user VR experience where only one person gets to experience VR while others are stuck in 2D, the Oculus Quest in conjunction with InsiteVR allows multiple users to meet in a VR space. As they walk through the space with their peers in the virtual world, they can see and hear their peers talking and moving in the VR world, they can even chat and interact with each other. Suddenly, the VR experience feels even more realistic and less intimidating. Using the VR Group Experience, the team was able to effectively engage up to 5 end users at a time and expedite the client review and sign off process. When Rachel heard about InsiteVR BIM360 study, she was intrigued to participate since her team was already using BIM360, and she was hoping that VR could help with communicating to her non-architecturally trained end-user clients. Through the InsiteVR Oculus Quest program, the team received five free sets of the Oculus Quest headsets to use for their project in exchange for feedback on the ¬†VR sessions using InsiteVR. Since the project team was already on BIM360, the team could easily turn their Revit model into a VR experiences with a quick click of a button. The Oculus Quest headset is a standalone, wireless headset that uses the inside out tracking system. It is lightweight, and easy to carry, and much easier to setup than the HTC Vive or Oculus Rift , as it does not require a computer or a tether. This makes it much more user friendly and less daunting for new users. To learn more about Rachel‚Äôs experience of leading multiuser VR sessions, click HERE to watch the recording of Rachel‚Äôs presentation on our event‚Äôs page.

title: Revit and Insight 360 Daylighting Analysis Best Practices
content: Architectural spaces should connect building occupants with the outdoors and reinforce circadian rhythms through design features that reduce electric lighting and introduce more natural daylight. This module uses Revit to provide accurate performance feedback and visual information for an indication of your design relative to sustainability goals for LEED reporting of Options for Illuminance or Spatial Daylight Autonomy (sDA) and Annual Sunlight Exposure (ASE). Process The general steps to best practices for using the Insight plug-in for daylight design involves the following steps: Optimize the Run Always check the cost estimate generated , if it is significantly higher than 100 credits, notify Digital Practice and Energy Lab to help optimize your model. Use the larger resolution of the 72-inch grid for initial studies, once it is time to submit anything for LEED, then use a 12-inch grid. For 72-inch grid, typical daylight analysis for a given floor costs 0-20 credits, or slighting higher and always less than 100 For 12-inch grid, typical daylight analysis for a given simple floor costs 4-20 credits or slightly higher and always less than 100 Only submit a single floor at a time to see if there are any issues with the model Submit a typical single floor for repeating floors in a tower, high-rise, or mid-rise If there are no model issues, then only submit unique and typical floors for any tower, high-rise, or mid-rise Model Setup Set Model Location Model Contents and Cleanup Create appropriate glazing criteria in the model for TVIS and opaque surfaces performance Select an Analysis with an appropriate grid resolution Run the analysis to create a lighting result of daylighting levels and 3D model with schedules for the floors and the rooms in the model Open the room analysis schedule and verify the regularly occupied rooms to include in the daylighting analysis Generate and View Results to update the lighting analysis design results with your routinely selected regularly occupied rooms Review the analysis with the design team for making decisions to improve the design Set Model Location Verify that the project model location is set and does not have the default city selected.  Check the true north to verify the project true north alignment. Model Contents and Cleanup Our work today usually starts with either model provisioned into links, or there is a plan for the model breakup in the Digital Execution Plan. For daylighting, at a minimum, we must have the rooms and floor in the same model that you will run the daylighting analysis. Often, the rooms reside in the interiors model and the floors in the shell and core model. First, we only work in a detached saved copy of the single Revit model or the interiors model if it is a split model workflow. There are a couple of things that will need to take place that differs from the active production model such as changing the glazing from ‚ÄúRender-Ready‚Äù to ‚ÄúDaylighting Design-Ready,‚Äù and we must have the rooms and floors in the same model. If you find that your rooms and floors are not in the same model, then it is best to copy and monitor the floors from the shell and core into the interior model after you work in a local copy detached copy of it. In the past, we have attempted use of the ‚ÄúBind‚Äù Revit models but in most cases it fails, and so the best option currently is to copy/monitor the floors. There are a couple of things that will need to take place that differs from the active production model such as changing the glazing from ‚ÄúRender-Ready‚Äù to ‚ÄúDaylighting Design-Ready,‚Äù The last check you should perform is to make sure you have ceilings, exterior walls, and roofs in a link that you can see and that there no transparent materials applied to any of these elements. The last item is to turn off all light fixtures or disable them appearing in the model from the view visibility settings as these will interfere with the daylighting analysis results. A cursory check and mitigation of the model avoiding misplaced items or elements that block glazing areas, or any other items that will interfere with the daylighting analysis. The model will require at least one level and a ‚Äúplaced‚Äù room and floor assembly element for an analysis run. In summary, floors must be modeled in a non-linked reference model with the associated room and not within a group.  The Copy/Monitor feature on a linked floor will work in a model with rooms. Glazing Criteria See the current reference for your Revit version regarding the transparent and opaque material RGB settings and additional instructions. As a first daylight design step, we only work on the glazing settings. The opaque material settings can be left as-is if the interior design specification of materials is present, only consider the step here if you are within a percent or two of your daylighting target as it can be time-consuming. We generally apply the following fundamental light reflectance values below; these can be different pending compliance for Interior Lighting credit option for lighting controls: Ceilings 80% Walls 50% Floors 20% See additional material light reflectance values here: Revit Daylight Glazing Product VLT Calculator Use the resource below to interpolate the best RGB settings between your actual product VLT glazing and the Autodesk Glazing Properties Table. Revit Glazing Properites for Illuminance Renderings Resource Weblink Revit Reflectivity of Opaque Materials for Illuminance Resource Weblink Grid Resolution For your first initial studies, please use a grid resolution of 72-inch grid.  Once it is time to submit anything for LEED, then we can use the 12-inch grid resolution. Daylight Analysis Preparation For your first initial studies, never submit all levels for any daylight analysis. Submit a single floor at a time to see if there are any issues with the model, such as a large ground level floor that may represent landscaping or a parking layout. Autodesk will charge for each analysis a basis of the amount of floor area that you submit. We often use floors for exterior landscape contours. If your project is a tower, high-rise, or mid-rise, then consider only submitting a typical single floor for repeating floors with the necessary documentation in your LEED narrative. For the 72-inch grid analysis, the daylight analysis for a given floor costs about 0-30 credits. For sDA and ASE analysis, the cost is in the higher end of the range. For the 12-inch grid analysis, the daylight analysis for a given floor costs about 4-30 credits. For sDA and ASE analysis, the cost is in the higher end of the range. If you see anything approaching 100 credits or more for a single study, please contact your local DA, Digital Practice, or Energy Lab for additional help for a determination of the high cost before sending the analysis to Autodesk. The analysis credit costs are real dollars that the firm pays so use your professional judgment and the guidance here whenever approving or accepting an analysis cost from Autodesk. The option for spatial daylight autonomy and annual sunlight exposure appear starting in LEED version 4.0 and 4.1.  Energy Lab advises anyone that will consider LEED V4.0 to apply for the V4.1 credit options which are less stringent and may provide a successful path to compliance. Analysis Run Before the first run of any daylighting analysis, your model will not contain any schedules or 2D and 3D model views. Run the analysis with careful credit cost evaluation to create your analysis which includes schedules and the model views Daylighting Schedule Open the room analysis schedules to verify the regularly occupied spaces to include in the daylighting analysis. For verification of which rooms are periodically occupied, you can use a pure determination of a person spending at least one hour a day to consider it as such and reference the following document: Always use the checkbox for ‚ÄúInclude in Daylighting‚Äù for indicating the regularly occupied spaces in your model. Illuminating Engineering Society ‚Äì The Lighting Handbook 10th Edition Weblink A resource here which uses data from the handbook may also be consulted: Resources Example Revit Daylighting Model for at least Revit 2019 and Upgradeable to Revit 2020 Get Daylighting Example Template Model Instructions Open in Revit 2019 or upgrade to Revit 2020 Transfer the following from the example model to your project or discuss with your DA to add to your studio Revit template using ‚ÄúRevit Transfer Project Standards.‚Äù Select ‚ÄúAnalysis Display Style, View Templates, and Materials‚Äù then look for the following after the transfer Daylighting Analysis Display Style LEED & WELL Daylighting Simulation and Illuminance Scale Use this instead of the other ones included in Revit for a simple three-color assessment for LEED and WELL ‚ÄúRED‚Äù for overexposed conditions above 3000 Lux or 278 footcandles ‚ÄúYELLOW‚Äù for the daylight target range of 300 to 3000 Lux or 27.8 to 278 footcandles ‚ÄúBLUE‚Äù for underexposed conditions below 300 Lux or 27.8 footcandles View Templates ‚ÄúDaylighting‚Äù for Insight Lighting Floor Plans ‚ÄúDaylighting Section‚Äù for sections that you wish to illustrate Materials for Daylighting Analysis Glazing with 2 Panes and an Airspace Exterior Glazing for up to 25.4mm/1in at 40% VLT Exterior Glazing for up to 25.4mm/1in at 50% VLT Exterior Glazing for up to 25.4mm/1in at 60% VLT Interior Glazing for up to 3mm/1/8‚Ä≥ in at >90% VLT, single pane Option sDA and ASE Generally for the illuminance option, the following table will provide the targets from LEED 2009, 4.0, and 4.1.  Energy Lab advises anyone that will consider LEED V4.0 to consider the V4.1 credit options which are less stringent and may provide a more successful path to compliance. Option Illuminance Examples Use of Revit Daylighting in Pursuits and Early Design Insight Review from Energy Lab Energy Lab published a review of Insight 360 and discusses what you should know about it when it comes to energy and daylight.  For the daylight sections, see chapter 9 and 10.  If you need help, please contact the Energy Lab directly for help.

title: Talk to me‚Ä¶ We are on the same team
content: Digital Practice on Microsoft Teams We know things change fast and it is hard to keep up with all technical issues, questions and problems we might encounter with rapidly changing technology and tools.  It has become more important to work as a team not only in projects, but as a extended team across all studios.  The Digital Practice team has begun leveraging Microsoft Teams to stay in touch and answer questions from designers and experts across the firm. Teams is agile, transparent and gets more eyes on challenges quicker. The Digital Practice Microsoft Team is open to everyone at Perkins&Will and you are encouraged to ask questions, bring up concerns and point out technology issues there. In addition we have a Revit tool which will automatically collect troubleshooting information from your Revit session. Updated DP Assist As we are moving to an even more collaborative environment by implementing BIM360 on our projects, we have overhauled and streamlined the DP Assist Tool so it can also support BIM360 projects and is integrated with Microsoft Teams. For 2019 Revit, the tool is located on the Perkins+Will tab, and for 2020, the tab name is shortened to PW. DP Assist collects diagnostic information from the current file and creates a report that can be instrumental in troubleshooting Revit issues. The report is saved to S:\journals\_DAAssist folder and can be viewed as needed. Copy of this report is emailed to your office DA so they can see it on their phone. In addition, for BIM360 projects, it pops up a dialog box containing information about the location of collaborators cache, project and file information. It then fires up Microsoft Teams in your browser and connects you to the Digital Practice Channel , where you can ask a question, describe your challenge, add a screenshot and get expert help. If you are on a computational node, stay in the browser, if you are on a laptop, use the Microsoft Teams app. A new microKnowledge button will open the searchable site containing a wealth of information and answers to many of your questions about different applications and workflows. This is a living and breathing repository of knowledge actively maintained by Perkins&Will experts hosted by the Digital Practice team . A new QuickStart button has also been added, this will link you to QuickStart guides , the fastest way to become proficient with new software. Note: Previous versions of the tool had the ability to request Revit Content Assistance. Since HIVE is now our Revit content search and  distribution tool, please use HIVE Content Request tool instead.
