title: VizR ‚Äì Best Practices with Scott Schroeder
content:
Scott Schroeder, Director of Visualization of our Denver
office, will share some best practice in creating high quality photorealistic
renderings using 3ds Max and Unreal Engine. Starting with the creation of
parametric models in 3ds Max then transporting the models into Unreal Engine
for high quality rendering and animation. He will dive into the following
process: Using RailClone to generate parametric
seating bowl. Creating animated people using Forest Pro . Transferring models from 3ds Max into Unreal Engine using various
plugins such as Datasmith , Optim , Substance ,
and GPU Lightmass baker. Testing with raytracing inside Unreal using RTX
cards. Getting animated people into Unreal using shared
rig and animations. Using Substance
Designer to create a master material library for all rendering software. Comparing Substance Designer workflow versus
other universal material formats such as NVIDIA‚Äôs
MDL and ILM‚Äôs Material X . Class Notes by Scott Schroeder Importing models into Unreal with Datasmith Datasmith is a plugin being developed by Epic, who are the creators of the Unreal Engine. This plugin is aimed at making the trip from CAD software to Unreal almost seamless. However, there are a few exceptions that this plugin does not do. This plugin does not organize the file for you. A messy CAD file will be messy in Unreal. Before going into any real time engine, taking a few extra steps to make sure the scene is organized, optimized, and generally contains only the objects needed to display in real time. More information about Datasmith and the use cases for software such as Max, Rhino, Revit, and SketchUp in this section of the documentation. https://docs.unrealengine.com/en-US/Studio/Datasmith/SoftwareInteropGuides/index.html Automated Datasmith Optimization with Optim Optim is a tool that runs inside the Unreal Engine that scans a Datasmith file and gives an overview of what is included in that file. The primary function of this plugin is to take scene optimization that had to be done manually in Unreal or the software used to create the geometry and automate the process. What used to take 20+ hours in Unreal, can now be done in just a few hours if not under an hour. Once inside the Optim Dashboard, there are specific areas that will give more detailed information about the geometry, lights, and materials in the Datasmith file. A user can create rules to tell Optim to merge similar geometry, or generate LODs(Level of Detail) for any piece of geometry over a certain number of polygons. Users can save and load rules to help further speed up the process inside the dashboard. Optim is currently in open
Beta, meaning that while the software works there are bound to be a few bugs
with it. One major hurdle for Optim is that Unreal needs to have full admin
privileges to be able to launch the dashboard. It is suspected that because
Unreal needs to launch Optim as an external program, any user without admin
privileges will have that process blocked as it appears suspicious. To view
more about Optim and sign up for the Beta program, please visit https://theia.io/optim/ Ray Tracing in Unreal with NVIDIA RTX graphics cards Starting with Unreal Engine version 4.22, raytracing is now available to use for those who have an NVIDIA RTX graphics card. Ray tracing in Unreal can produce real-time transparency, soft shadows, reflections, global illumination, and ambient occlusion. In previously versions of Unreal, many of the previously listed items had to be prebuilt (or baked) into the scene at a cost of rather long bake times. The image below is a screenshot from Unreal that has real time reflections and global illumination enabled. The time to bake these elements into the scene file was 0 minutes. The same scene as above but with baked global illumination and reflections. The time to bake these elements into the scene was about 45 minutes using production quality settings. While raytracing in real time
is indeed very cool new technology, there are a few important items to keep in
mind when considering using it on any project. Ray tracing is a computationally intensive
process on the graphics card (GPU). Ray traced global illumination is the most
intensive process on the GPU and is better left to use on exterior only
projects. Projects that have interiors should consider using the baked global
illumination method. The scene in Unreal needs to be as optimized as
possible. Enabling ray tracing will cause a loss of the number of frames per
second (FPS) being displayed. If the FPS drops below 30, the experience will
become laggy and unenjoyable. Therefore, the scene needs to be optimized enough
that the loss in FPS due to raytracing is manageable. Ray tracing in Unreal is not an import model,
fire, and forget process. There needs to be time devoted to setting the scene
up properly. For client presentations, the laptops must be
plugged in. Running on battery power is not recommended at all for this process. There recently was a webinar
from Epic and Buildmedia about using ray tracing and RTX cards for
architectural visualization. The replay is available at this link, https://www.unrealengine.com/en-US/blog/ray-tracing-for-architectural-visualization-webinar-replay Universal Material Workflow with the Substance Suite of Tools Substance is a set of material creation tools developed by Allegorithmic and was recently acquired by Adobe. Using Substance, it will be possible to create a master material library that anyone, regardless of software, would be able to use. Here in the Denver studio, we‚Äôve been just scratching at the surface as to how best to implement this new technology. Be on the lookout for some exciting news in the very near future. The image below shows a general overview of creating carpet patterns in Substance Designer.

title: IFC ‚Äì Part 1
content:
A complete IFC Guide for sharing and exchanging BIM
data in Denmark SHL co-authored a complete IFC Guide for the Danish market. Building Information Modelling (BIM) has become the new standard in the architectural process by delivering construction and design coordination improvements, quality assurances, and cost savings. The demand for sharing and exchanging data has increased in recent years at our firm and throughout the industry. The term OpenBIM is being used more and more. OpenBIM is a universal¬†approach¬†to the collaborative design, realization, and operation of buildings based on open¬†standards¬†and¬†workflows. For shared Building Models, ex. a Revit Model, the IFC format is the OpenBIM building model format. Therefore, if one consultant is using Revit and another consultant is using Tekla, the IFC format will be used for sharing geometry and data. Okay, so we just need to export and IFC file of our Revit or Rhino model and all is good? Unfortunately to create good useable files for any recipient is not easy ‚Äì and that is therefore why the IFC Guide has been created. The trick is to get the data and geometry to be structured correctly.   Example a Revit Wall needs to be an IfcWall, and sometimes it is more complicated: We have modeled a Ceiling Shirt with the Revit¬¥s Wall tool. If we just export the model, the Ceiling Skirt will be an IfcWall, which is not correct ‚Äì the IfcCovering.Ceiling is. Ohh my, Why is this important? First, to do OpenBIM and collaborated between vendor¬¥s software we need a format to communicate, and of course, we need to have valid data. We want to have a wall create in ArchiCAD to be wall, when imported to Revit. Second, all Clients in Europe want this. They don‚Äôt want to be locked to the consultant¬¥s chosen software. The facility manager must be able to run their building for many years without struggling to access their own data. Third, with the IFC format, we can use Solibri. Solibri can do collisions controls like Navisworks but also a lot more advanced checks such as EXAMPLES. In IFC part 2, we will go further in detail with the opportunities with Solibri. Beside
describe how IFC is exported from Revit, The IFC guide also cover how to do good
IFC exports form ArchiCAD. More BIM-software are to be added soon as well as chapters
about IFC-imports from different software‚Äôs. The
Danish IFC-guide can be found here: https://www.molio.dk/faa-hjaelp-til-ifc-med-opdateret-guide Unfortunately
only a Danish version of guide is available right now but a English version is
coming soon, you can read a IFC Guide by Autodesk,
which is covering some of the same topics. Also Our microKnowledge site is already has cards showing how manage the IFC-export: How do I export an IFC file from Revit? How do I override the default export for IFC Class and IFC Type for an object type? Any questions, don‚Äôt hesitate to contact Simon saa@shl.dk or Nicklas nvo@shl.dk .

title: Drones for Architecture
content: For our May VizR call, we had a special presentation by the Perkins&Will‚Äôs UAV user group. Our drone experts introduced the UAV user group, its members and missions, then presented how they have integrated the use of drones into their design workflow. Randy Maxwell (Atlanta), Chen Qin (Boston) and Ryan Rideout (Seattle) each presented their projects that used drone and shared valuable lessons learned from their experience. The UAV user group introduced their pulse page, ‚Äú UAV Community ‚Äú, which contains videos of their flights and other very useful information from charts, pre-flight planning, and insurance documentation and reference materials. The UAV Community at Perkins&Will had worked closely with our legal department to obtain firmwide insurance coverage for our drone squad, so that future drone projects will have a smoother process when dealing with insurance and liability issues.

title: What‚Äôs NEXT for Rhino and SketchUp !?
content: The newest version of V-Ray, named NEXT has a number of notable improvements and new features for those working in Rhino and SketchUp. Not all the advertised features are worth mentioning, so Digital Practice has filtered out the hype to give you a concise reading of what you are most likely to find relevant to your design visualization needs. Testing for NEXT at Perkins&Will took place in May. NEXT tested successfully with other Perkins&Will software, nodes and laptops. Expect to see NEXT appear in early June as it is pushed to nodes and laptops or available for install via Software Center. FASTER RENDER TIMES It‚Äôs true. However the results can vary significantly from scene to scene. BOOST x2 for INTERIOR RENDERINGS The new Adaptive Dome Light will easily be considered the best new feature for those creating interior renderings. It eliminates the previous workflow of placing, sizing and tweaking multiple Light Portals at the various windows and openings which bringing light into an interior space. In its place‚Ä¶ Just the new Adaptive Dome Light to the scene as seen in the image below. How‚Äôs that for simple. Furthering its value is reduced render times. Chaos Group claims up to seven times faster. Digital Practice‚Äôs test render times were reduced by half, but that is still impressive. These are really useful improvements that should feel noticeably beneficial to anyone creating interior renderings. ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE ?! Chaos Group is using the term Scene Intellig ence when referring to the automation of both Exposure and White Balance . They claim artificial intelligence is used to ‚Äúlearn‚Äù your scene and automatically apply the perfect settings for both exposure and white balance. Even if it fall just short of perfect, unless you are very good at adjusting these two settings in tandem this new features will be a time saver. While it can be applied to all renderings it will be most beneficial to those creating interior renderings and animations. ASSET EDITOR IMPROVEMENTS are SIGNIFICANT, but RELATIVE No doubt there are many improvements to the V-Ray Asset Editor, but how much time you typically spend there will influence your opinion about the value it brings you. The many improvements to asset management can be summed up as comprehensive and convenient. A few of the standout features are two new buttons across the top for Render Elements and Textures, an organizing outline view for all assets, the ability to add folders and custom libraries including network shareable ones, optimized search that includes sub-folders, a universal asset previewer, and the ability to select multiple assets using ctrl and shift keys to add or delete from scene. DENOISE OPTIMIZATIONS Already a favorite feature of many using V-Ray, the Denoiser is upgraded to include NVIDIA‚Äôs new AI NVIDIA algorithm. This setting is available when using the Interactive Frame Render and delivers significant speed increases. Chaos Group claims the denoise speed is ‚Äúnear-instant‚Äù, but this would obviously be very scene dependent. A second denoise feature targets specific elelemts by allowing individual elements to be chosen. V-Ray for GRASSHOPPER A number of features have been added to allow rendering within Grasshopper. It should be noted that not all V-Ray features within Rhino are available within Grasshopper. EXTENDED CROSS-PLATFORM SUPPORT for IMPORTS V-Ray for SketchUp adds the ability to import any .vrscene into SketchUp to expand the platforms that SketchUp can import and use. Chaos Group claims the import will maintain the size and position of geometry imported this way. NEW UTILITY TOOL BAR for SketchUp V-Ray NEXT for SketchUp gets a new tool bar with features you may find useful. The Hide V-Ray Widgets button allows the visibility of V-Ray widget to be toggled on and off. This adds convenience when creating clean screen captures of the viewport. Other descriptions are mentioned in the in the image below. BLOOM / GLARE EFFECT and METALNESS These are the two final features to be mentioned. Metalness is a new setting available within materials and shaders. It essentially adds a metal layer to materials to create realistic metal finishes. The new Bloom / Glare Effect is best explained by views the two overlapping images below. Hopefully everyone will find at least some of these new features beneficial to their visualization workflow and productivity.

title: SHARPEN YOUR TOOLS: KEYNOTE MANAGER IN-DEPTH
content: Sharpen Your Tools: Keynote Manager in-depth Revit‚Äôs keynote system is a powerful way to integrate data into Revit families, reduce errors, and streamline documentation. The text files, though, are cumbersome and difficult to work with. Keynote Manager was created to provide a simple, efficient interface to edit keynote files. It allows to edit keynotes in a tree view, automatically sequence and easily re-organize and re-sequence keynotes, quickly search and filter. it makes it easy to for multiple people to collaborate, providing commenting and tracking capabilities. There is also an option to edit keynote file in the cloud for BIM360 projects. It makes it easy to compare keynote files to track changes. It even automatically checks the integrity of a keynote file that was edited in other applications like Excel and fix ‚Äúorphaned‚Äù keynotes. Spellcheck is automatic, casing can be set as needed. Additionally, Revit Plugin Keynote Manager Plus interacts with Revit directly, and allows to apply keynotes to selected Revit elements with a single button, synchronizing key values. It clearly shows which keynotes were used in the project, and whether or not they were on the sheet. it makes is easy to find all elements that were using particular keynote for QC. Also, it can help coordinate specs and keynotes by running  and exporting keynote report. Many PW offices  are using the tool, Dallas and Austin office are  utilizing it more then others, But every office has their champions, like Rachel Gruber, Matt Sawasaki,  Diana Reyes, Amber Harris and many others. Digital practice conducted a ‚ÄúTrain the Trainer‚Äù session, and here is the recording And here is a link to mK cards https://mk.perkinswill.com/?_sf_s=keynote&_sft_sub-application=keynote-manager New version of Keynote manager will be rolled out in the next few weeks- will support Revit 2020 and improves support for BIM360

title: Digital Practice Exchange ‚Äì Mass Timber and Robotic Fabrication

author.name: Nick Cameron
author.description: American trucker who has been featured on the History channel reality television series Ice Road Truckers and its spinoff series IRT: Deadliest Roads.

content: Recently, Hakim Hasan of the Building Tech Lab gave an overview of the labs recent work in a Digital Practice exchange. Below is an overview of the talk and a recording. Perkins&Will‚Äôs Building Technology Lab & Digital Practice were able to leverage its previous research into mass timber and robotic fabrication, combining expertise across offices in a year-long effort. Robotics, mass timber, and parametric design are all key technologies that are underutilized in construction. To fully take advantage of these new technologies requires a rethinking of the entire process from design to construction. The Greenbuild Pavilion represents a new design to fabrication workflow, in which a digital parametric model is communicated directly to a robot fabricator. The robot, equipped with various tools, can manipulate dimensional lumber into complex geometries with industrial precision. This workflow has the potential to drastically improve the sustainability, quality, cost, and time of construction. Here is a recording of the presentation.

title: Semantic ‚Äì Add Data to Your Rhino Objects
content: Semantic allows you to add data to your rhino objects. Standard geometry modeling tools provide limited capabilities for integrating data into the design workflow. Meanwhile, conventional BIM tools are often cited as being too ‚Äúdata heavy‚Äù for agile design exploration. Semantic aims to find a middle ground: a new user interface framework has been developed for assigning and managing data properties to raw geometry in Rhino. Check out the video below for an overview of Semantic. Semantic can be used to‚Ä¶ Assign custom data attributes to geometric objects. Define formula-driven calculations across multiple properties. Create custom queries of model data and produce exportable reports. Control model properties using a variety of UI tools. Talk to your local IT/ DA to have Semantic installed on your laptop. Grasshopper plugin: S:_Firmwide\Rhino-Grasshopper\Plugins\ProvingGround.Semantic\ Semantic Videos

title: Those Pesky Pop-Ups

author.name: Nick Cameron
author.description: American trucker who has been featured on the History channel reality television series Ice Road Truckers and its spinoff series IRT: Deadliest Roads.

content: Carl Spackler For the past several weeks we have been playing a wee bit of the old game ‚ÄúWhack a Mole‚Äù. In our case the moles are those pesky pop-ups everyone encounters in the Revit start up screen. For a few reasons these pests have proven difficult to get rid of, but you should have begun to see a reduction these past few weeks. If you still do encounter them, please let your local Design Application Manager know and we will work to remove them. Once the Pop Ups are removed , we will begin to use the new cleaned up start screen to collect feedback. The Digital Practice team is eager to learn where else we can streamline Revit and other design applications. We plan for these micro-polls to be no more than a handful of questions every so often. The effort to whack the moles originated from a few folks letting us know it was a huge time suck, now that we have tamed them, we want to move onto bigger fish.

title: Enscape 2.5.1 ‚Äì What‚Äôs New?
content: The latest version of Enscape rolled out in April with improvements spanning a range of areas you may find beneficial. The most notable is the addition of 150 new entourage assets to Encapes‚Äô library. This brings the total library count to 341. These new items are 3D proxies appearing monochromatic in your scene as an off-white color. A number of the items are from the third party Evermotion and are noticeably more realistic than other library assets when rendered. Example of an Evermotion Asset First under the Image tab of Settings are two new contrast sliders. The previous contrast slider has been divided into two made up of highlights and shadows. Controlling these independently should give more freedom. New Contrast Sliders If you were previously dissatisfied with how crisp or soft Ensapes‚Äô shadows were then you will be interested in this new slider. Found within Settings under the Atmosphere tab is the Shadow Sharpness slider near the bottom. Near the top of the Atmosphere tab is a new fog slider. This slider allows you to set the height of fog in your scene giving you a bit more control over appearance. Shadow Sharpness and Fog Height Also under the Atmosphere tab the Horizon Presets see one new addition, Mountains. In addition to this new preset the White Cubes preset has visible improvements over the previous version of Enscape. New Mountain Preset For Rhino and SkecthUp the Material Editor receives improvements like a list which makes finding materials easier. The Material Editor for Rhino receives exclusive improvements allowing setting for fine tuning materials. A new Clear Coat material creates a much more realistic car paint and  improves the appearance of various metal materials such as certain  mullion finishes. Material Settings in Rhino The Video Editor has an improved Camera Path Automation tool creating a much smoother path than the previous one. There is also a new Total Duration slider to easily control the time length for camera paths. The last improvement on our list is another one for Materials. Previously Enscape may have inaccurately shown reflected textures or not shown them at all. Now when using the Ultra setting materials within reflections are visible including the details of your texture maps. This improvement also includes the ability to render reflected textures that are behind the camera‚Äôs current location.

title: Sharpen Your Tools: CTC Tools Update
content: If you use CTC Tools, you have probably noticed some welcome changes to CTC tools interface: The tab name has been shortened, from Revit Express Tools to just CTC There is a button in the ribbon and in every tool to contact CTC support directly. You do not need to fill out a form, you can just call them directly with questions about every tool. Occupancy Flow Analyzer is a new & exciting tool which has been added to the CTC BIM Project Suite. It allows you to calculate occupancy based on a variety of flexible parameters, define rules of grouping, rounding up and play other scenarios. It also allow you to calculate and visualize critical paths and a minimum path to make code checking easier and more visual. Rules for Occupancy Calculations Occupant Path Settings Occupant Load Report with Calculated Critical Distance Egress Paths and Loads Existing tools highlights: Room Family Manager can be used  to quickly build typical requirements for room content  and automatically check/place families in the modes based on room assignments Build Room Types Assign Room Types Place Families and Validate Room Data Sheets automates creation of Room specific sheets. It automatically creates views (Floor and Reflected Ceiling plans, elevations, schedules, 3D views, legends), creates sheet  for each room and places the views on the sheets.  It can save you hours and hours of time! Configuring the Sheet Automatically Generated Room Data Sheets -One of Many Using Room Family Manager and Room Data Sheets together can dramatically improve  workflows on smaller and medium projects where dRofus may be an overkill because of price or learning curve. here is a link to webinar about using these two tools  together Data Sheets for Rooms from Applied Technology Group on Vimeo .

title: The More You Know
content: Clear Screen There is never enough screen space no matter how many monitors you have. When you have many windows open and you want to quickly get to your desktop (maybe connect to the node?), you can just click on the very bottom right corner of the main screen to temporarily see your desktop. Do not worry- nothing has closed or moved ‚Äì click there again to bring it back. To find many other quick tips and answer to frequently asked questions, use a treasure trove of information ‚Äì our microKnowledge  site https://mk.perkinswill.com/ . You can  use search window or filter search by application and sub-appication. Best of all, you can share your tips and wisdom by making a new mK card. And there is even a card explaining how to make a new card!

title: Integrating Artificial Intelligence into Virtual Reality Models ‚Äì Presented by Emre Aslan
content: For our April‚Äôs VizR meeting, Emre Aslan discussed the workflow of creating the VR model for Canora Station on the new REM line in Quebec.¬† He shared the process of using scripting and materials to create the interactive VR model in Unreal Engine, as well as how Artificial Intelligence (AI) was used in the model for behavior interaction, and discussed the future road map of AI integration with the VR model. Integration of A.I. into UE4 Models: Unreal Engine 4.21 | E. Aslan Figure 1: REM ‚Äì Canora Model in UE4 This article will provide an overview of how one method of Unreal Engine 4‚Äôs (UE4) A.I. may be implemented in VR models for the purpose of  creating dynamic, animated actors capable of navigating a project autonomously. Canora station, of the R.E.M. LRT project (Figure 1) , was chosen as a sample environment to demonstrate A.I capabilities due to the opportunities it presents for vertical circulation ‚Äì use of elevators, stairs and related interactions. Figure 2: A Target Point Asset This initial workflow will discuss the process of scripting basic  A.I. functionality in Blueprints, which will adaptively follow a sequential array of targets throughout the model, while by-passing those it cannot reach This is a very quick method of directing the A.I. Character through the space, and will use the default Third-Person Character with a Forward Walking looped animation asset. This A.I. script will allow for real-time adaptation and avoidance of geometry (such that if the model is revised, the A.I. will adapt without having to revise the script), other A.I. driven characters and the users themselves. This is accomplished by placing Target Points (Figure 2) throughout the model, defining the general path to be taken by the A.I. Character(s). Once an array of targets is established ‚Äì referred to as Patrol Points in the associated Blueprints ‚Äì the Character will determine its own route between them. Although beyond the scope of this article, the use of Behavior Trees facilitates a greater degree of autonomous  decision-making. Their use will be described briefly later in this workflow in order to demonstrate the extendibility of UE4‚Äôs A.I. capabilities. Figure 3: Creating a New Character Using this approach to Artificial Intelligence in the context of UE4 requires several interrelated systems to run successfully (item 2 is optional): A Skeletal Mesh (the representation of the actor ‚Äì the Character) A Behaviour Tree (the decision-making process used by the A.I. for greater autonomy) The Event Graph (which controls the actor‚Äôs actions, created in the Character Blueprint) A Navigation Volume (or Nav Mesh ‚Äì the volume of the model that is accessible by the A.I.) An A.I. Controller (the default A.I. script, providing basic actor movement) Several Target Points (assets specific to defining a vector location in the model) A looping Animation Asset (a walking animation, assigned to the Skeletal Mesh) Figure 4: A.I. Controller Search In order to demonstrate A.I. within a UE4 model, a new Character will be created by right-clicking in the Project Browser and selecting ‚ÄúCharacter‚Äù (Figure 3) and providing a unique name: PW_Canora_Character. Using the same process, an A.I. Controller will also be created (Figure 4). In this case, a search will have to be performed as the Controller is not exposed by default. Renaming the Controller will follow the same convention: PW_Canora_AIController. This A.I. Controller will govern the movement of the Character, and can be modified to add greater functionality. Double-click on the PW_Canora_Character that was just created (located in the Project Browser ‚Äì Figure 5). In the Viewport Tab, a new Skeletal Mesh will be added. Select the Mesh component of this Character in the upper left (Figure 6). In the Details Tab on the right, under Mesh, select the SK_Mannequin Skeletal Mesh (Figure 7) ‚Äì note that the selected mesh must coincide with the animation assets to be used. They are often provided together in the same file and can be found in the Third Person Template.  Under Pawn, also in the Details Tab, assign the PW_Canora_ AIController (Figure 9). Figure 6: Select Mesh Compo- Figure 7: Selecting the Skeletal Mesh The required Target Points will be added. Under the Modes tab in the main editor window, conduct a search for ‚ÄúTarget Points.‚Äù Select the asset that appears and drag it out into the model (Figure 10). This will act as an intermediate destination along a path of Target Points positioned throughout the model. The locations of the Target Points can be arbitrary, but is generally more useful if they define a path through the space. In the case of Canora Station, the path has been based on a sequential series of events, based on the objective of moving from the exterior of the station to the train platform. When another Target Point is dragged out into the model, it will be named ‚ÄúTargetPoint2.‚Äù Each subsequent point that is created will be sequentially numbered. This is to facilitate the A.I.‚Äôs navigation between the Target Points in a user defined sequence ‚Äì not necessarily in the sequence they were created. Each character, therefore, may use the same Target Points, but in a different order. As the characters approach each other on the path, they will avoid a collision based on their Capsule size (the orange wireframe element in Figure 11). This Capsule Component is the collision geometry of the character. Figure 9: Assigning the A.I. Controller Once the character mesh is assigned to this actor, animation asset(s) will be defined. In the Details tab of PW_ Canora_Character, under Animation, select ‚ÄúUse Animation Asset‚Äù from the drop-down list (Figure 12). Then, at the ‚ÄúAnim to Play‚Äù section, select the ‚ÄúWalkFwdLoop‚Äù asset (this is a downloaded asset that will become available on the P+W servers ‚Äì it offers a more natural gait than the default walking animation). The Target Points in this model were placed strategically so as to lead the character through the model in the order that an actual transit customer would use so as to simulate the project‚Äôs actual usage case: Figure 10: Conducting a Search for Target Points Entry Doors Fare Vending Machines or Fare Gates Fare Gates Elevator of Stair Platform Items 2 and 4 in this list define a potential choice that can be made by the A.I. This will be described in greater detail under Behavior Trees. Target Points have been placed at the above locations to facilitate guidance through this sequence of objectives. The PW_ Canora_ AIController serves to interpret input from the script in the character‚Äôs Event Graph in order to determine how to best move between these points, revising as required, in real-time. Once a sufficient number of Target Points have been placed in the model, the character‚Äôs Event Graph can be scripted. Figure 11: Default UE4 Skeletal Mesh and Collision Geometry Under the Event Graph tab of the PW_Canora_Character asset, a script will be written in Blueprints that will dictate this A.I.‚Äôs actions and behavior. It is here that the real-time adaptability of the character will be established. Two of the existing three nodes may be deleted, only the ‚ÄúEvent BeginPlay‚Äù node will be used in this approach. The purpose of this node is to execute the script which follows when the compiled model in launched (or when simulated in the editor). The Blueprint script in it‚Äôs entirety is shown (Figure 13) with notes indicating the purpose of each node. Figure 12: Assigning Animation Assets to the Character In summary, this script indicates that when launched, the A.I. will move to a point within the Target Point Array (Figure 14). The order in which the points are reached is determined by the order in which they appear in the array (the list numbers on the left). Once it has reached a point, it will perform a check to determine if it has reached the final Target Point (based on the length of the array ‚Äì in this case 9 Target Points). If it has reached the end, it will begin the process again. If it has not reached the final Target Point, it will proceed to the next point indicated within the array. Similarly, if the next Target Point in the array cannot be reached (due to an obstruction, another character, or the user), it will move to the next reachable Target Point. It will perform this check each time it reaches a Target Point. As stated, this allows many characters to use the same Event Graph and the same Target Points simply by changing the order of the points in the array. They will all avoid both dynamic and static obstacles. In order to improve the performance of the A.I.‚Äôs actions, an element of choice can be implemented using Behavior Trees. When a Behavior Tree is executed, the logic begins at the top (the Root) and runs down the hierarchy from left to right. This process will allow the A.I. to choose 1 of 2 ‚Äútasks‚Äù randomly using a Selector Node which will reference two integers (1 or 2). Figure 13: The A.I. Script A schematic plan of PW_Canora_Character‚Äôs Behavior Tree is shown (Figure 15). It indicates the process of moving through the station and where the opportunities for choice arise, reflecting actual usage conditions in order to generate more accurate crowd simulations involving multiple characters. It states that a random choice will be made (represented by the integers 1 or 2) when the character reaches a specific Target Point. At this point, a decision will be made regarding how to proceed. The character‚Äôs Behavior Tree was scripted in the following manner to allow this choice (Figure 16). The Selector Node branches into two tasks, each representing an integer ‚Äì and in turn, representing moving to the Fare Vending Machines, or moving directly to the Fare Gates. Referencing the character‚Äôs Event Graph, it will move to the Target Point related to either of these 2 choices. Within the Selector Node is an Event Graph which establishes the parameters of this choice. It includes a reference to the random integer range. Additionally, the Behavior Tree will also integrate with the character‚Äôs Event Graph (in terms of cases when the next Target Point in the array cannot be reached) to implement other animations. The schematic Behavior Tree indicates that an idle animation will be triggered when a Target Point cannot be reached, based on the choice made by the character previously. Therefore, as the character ‚Äúwaits‚Äù for the Target Point to become accessible, it will enter the idle animation. This animation will transition into the walking animation once the Target Point becomes accessible. This behavior facilitates the random formation of queues at certain points in the model, such as at the Fare Vending Machines, Elevators and possibly the Fare Gates. Figure 15: Schematic Behavior Tree Layout Figure 16: Behavior Tree Segment allowing Random Choice Figure 17: Selector Node Script

title: vMaterials ‚Äì Powerful Versatility
content:
There may be much more to Digital Practice‚Äôs Material library than you realize. A quick look at the library shows a substantial number of materials; however, these are only a small portion of the materials available. With few exceptions, each material contains 5 to 16 pre-created variations of the material within it. Some of these materials have exposed textures and patterns allowing you to replace them with your own tileable images. For Example the Material Stone_Granite_Polished #2 in the image below holds 14 different materials within it. 14 of the materials are shown in the drop down list and 12 of the are represented as thumbnails to the left. This material example represents differences in color and pattern brought about by the texture ma used to define the materials. Other materials have distinct pattern differences. To demonstrate this the material Masonry_Brick_Red is show below with the five different materials defined within it that display distinctly different patterns. All of these materials contains one or more color swatches to create new material variations. And these are not just any color swatches. Unique to vMaterials these color swatches function as ‚Äòwhat-you-see-is-what-you-get‚Äù, a.k.a. wysiwyg (pronounced ‚Äúwizzy wig‚Äù) which greatly reduces the time and effort needed to achieve just the right color in your visualizations. The example below using the Masonry_Ashlar_Interlocking material is especially difficult. It purposefully creates a distinct color variation from the color swatch. Despite this you can see the color swatch select for both the stone and mortar remain relatively close to their chosen color swatch . In February, Digital Practice made the decision to divide
the original vMaterial library into 16 smaller .mat libraries found here .
This decision was made to ensure shorter library open times within 3ds Max. To
assist with exploring and creating your own new vMaterials three shaderballs
can be found in the same folder as the vMaterial libraries. Digital Practice
created three distinct types of shaderballs for exploring solids, liquids and
fabrics. Now that vMaterials are faster to access and there are shaderballs for reviewing them we want to ensure anyone interested knows how to get the most out of vMaterials. Using the Slate Material Editor in 3ds Max open one one the vMaterial libraries. Then drag a material to the View1 tab in the middle area. Double click the blue portion of the materials title to apear in the   are brief instructions on where to find the pre-created materials with each vMaterial, how to swap texture maps and examples of wysiwyg color swatches.

title: The value of thermal camera imagery
content:
A few months ago the K-12 practice in the Chicago office invested in a FLiR One Pro camera attachment for an iPhone.   After looking at the many options this small inexpensive device seems to be the correct selection for us based on the information and accuracy we desired from the tool. Example of existing conditions at exterior windows and mechanical system with a thermal camera So
far, we are in the testing phases of using the FLiR camera for field
observations.¬† The camera has proven to be an accurate tool to uncover the
following conditions: Under
insulated walls/floors Inactive
grilles & registers Hot
water piping behind walls Ineffective
thermal breaks Return
air plenums Although more discussion is needed on how to leverage this information on an official field observation report, and any repercussions therein, we see this as another valuable tool to capture additional information on existing conditions that might go unseen when examining existing buildings or new construction.

title: HIVE updates and roadmap
content: Perkins+Will has successfully rolled out HIVE ‚Äì a new Revit content management solution. It was embraced by content users and managers alike and its adoption continues to grow. Note: after the recent update,  all  CTC tools are under CTC tab in Revit (previously Revit Express Tools tab) We expect adoption will soon reach saturation, and are now focusing on improving the quality and find-ability of content. If you have comments about content quality, please  reach out to your local Design Applications Manager and/or use the HIVE comments and rating features. We monitor comments for Firm Wide libraries, and each Design Application Manager can address comments in their studio library. To increase efficiency of your search, please refer to these microKnowledge cards ‚Äì there quite  a few and the collection is growing. Last, but not least, we are actively working with the HIve development team. Below is the road map of improvements, and many of these requests have been generated by Perkins+Will. If you have a suggestion and/or have found a bug, talk to your Design Application Manager, Helen Gorina , or simply use in-app buttons for feedback. Happy Buzzing!

title: Virtual Design + Construction Program
content:
Program
Overview The Virtual Design+Construction program, is a project centered collaborative initiative to validate and assist in the coordination of design elements prior to the issuance of Contract Documents. Throughout the implementation of this process, the model geometry is relied upon to inform the review process and operate on the understanding that the model will provide the base geometry for the contract deliverables. This program is being implemented to reduce the burden of construction administration, reduce RFI‚Äôs, Change Orders, E&O, and to improve the efficiency of downstream trade partners. Goals The primary goals of
this process are to: Validate the constructability of the design by visually understanding the spatial and sequencing requirements of design elements. Validate the design intent by visually understanding the relationship of pre-planned elements. Validate space allocations for disciplines by analytically quantifying spatial conflicts of modeled elements. VDC Foundational principles Firm
Deliverables All firms will be required to post at regular intervals both their current Revit model and Navisworks Cache Files exported from the views defined above.   All firms will be required to participate in the coordination process and a project manager for each discipline should be present for the VD+C coordination the review meetings.  All firms will be expected to work diligently between review cycles to resolve issues identified. Navisworks Design Coordination Constructability Review Deliverables At defined intervals in conjunction with progress postings, Perkins+Will will analyze the constructability of the design models.¬† This analysis will be focused on identifying areas or elements that could result in an RFI being generated, a Change Order being submitted, or a Claim being filed. Following the Constructability Analysis, Perkins+Will will schedule a Constructability Review meeting with the other design partners to review the results. Revit Model
Requirements In order to streamline the VD+C analysis process, the A/E team should set up specific views in their Revit models to export navisworks cache files from.   These views should be created using view templates provided by Perkins+Will and should be organized according to the agreed upon structure.  The consultant is responsible for reviewing the view and adjusting view template settings as necessary to ensure that the relevant scope of work is shown and that elements are not missing or hidden.¬†  Perkins+Will will use these views and the cache files unchanged as the basis for the clash detection and constructability review. Roles &
Responsibilities Matrix In-order to streamline
the process of assigning responsibility to coordinate or resolve issues, Perkins+Will
has developed a simple hierarchy based on the overall flexibility of systems to
define in any clash condition who is responsible for coordinating the
resolution.¬† This doesn‚Äôt automatically
mean that the responsible party has to revise their model, merely who is
responsible for coordinating that the issue does get resolved.¬† For example if mechanical elements clash with
structure it will be the mechanical‚Äôs responsibility to coordinate the
resolution, and while generally the mechanical systems will move; in those
cases where structure needs to work around the mechanical it is still the
mechanical‚Äôs responsibility to lead the coordination on that issue.¬† This allows the process to move forward with
accountability and eliminates the potential for any one party becoming a
bottleneck in the effort of managing all of the issues. Above Ceiling LOD 100 Above Ceiling LOD 200 LOD 200 Constructability Issue LOD 300 Constructability Issue Potential Constructibility Resolution Corridor Cordination Planning Constructability
Review Planning & Scheduling At regular intervals and
in conjunction with project milestones the design team will conduct
constructability reviews of the design models.¬†
The design team should jointly define the milestones and review
schedule, and coordinate this schedule with the VD+C team.¬† Generally, the constructability review should
take place immediately following a deliverable or progress milestone.¬† The last review should be coordinated with
the last milestone and the final deliverable such that adequate time is
provided to the team to make any last coordination adjustments prior to issuing
contract documents. LOD Milestone
Matrix As part of the
implementation of VD+C on projects it is essential to communicate when design
elements will be sufficiently planned, can be included in the constructability
review, and to what level of detail design elements will be shown.¬† Attached as an addendum is the Level Of
Development Milestone Matrix that the design team should review and updated as
needed based on project specific requirements, expectations, and conditions. Mechanical LOD Milestone Matrix Plumbing LOD Milestone Matrix Electrical LOD Milestone Matrix Fire Protection LOD Milestone Matrix Structural LOD Milestone Matrix By appropriately applying this process to your project based on its size and complexity you should be able to greatly reduce the risks of issues with the design and have a more comprehensive review of the entire design.

title: Image Editing Layer Structure

author.name: Nick Cameron
author.description: American trucker who has been featured on the History channel reality television series Ice Road Truckers and its spinoff series IRT: Deadliest Roads.

content:
At the end of the day, there is just nothing more fulfilling than a great rendering that conveys your design intent clearly. There are some best practices dealing with the layers in Photoshop that can help get you there. This video takes you through our workflow at SHL when it
comes to post-producing visualizations, while also displaying the layer
structure we use in Photoshop. At SHL the renders are often made in-house and the common
tool is Vray for 3dsmax. In order to achieve full flexibility during
post-production, we render out many render elements in order to create masks
and have full control of reflections, lights etc. Our layer structure is relatively standard in the
visualization industry and the workflow is simply starting from the bottom
layers and working our way up. It is a very structured approach but it
generates speed, as the visualizer never questions what to do next or where to
start. It also means that we can easily swap or take over files from each
other, as they are almost identical. And finally, we work non-destructive which means that we can always go back and the eraser tool is a no-go.   A thanks to Martin McSherry for sharing this information with the office.

title: The Evolution and Future of Immersive, Real-Time Technologies
content: For our March VRX eXchange meeting, we invited Joel Pennington to share his insight on the state of VR and AR for the AEC industry. Joel Pennington is a Mixed Reality visionary with over 18 years of experience developing experiences and products for Augmented and Virtual Reality. As the Head of Product, he is the leading evangelist of VIM AEC‚Äô s product and solutions. Joel oversees VIM AEC‚Äôs product vision, strategy, design, and development. Before joining VIM AEC, Joel held management, art, and technical positions at Autodesk, Disney, and Electronic Arts.

title: Newforma Update ‚Äì Winter 2019
content: Our planned Newforma downtime is scheduled for Friday, March 8th at 9pm EST / 8pm CST / 7pm MST / 6pm PST / 11pm Sao Paulo / 2 am (Saturday) London / 6 am Dubai / 10 am Shanghai. What should I do? As we update the servers the desktop client will begin to update on all machines that currently have Newforma.¬† ¬†This will be done silently and you should see almost nothing except a new desktop icon that says Newforma Twelve Edition.¬† ¬†You will need to close and reopen Outlook to get the new Newforma addin with the new features.¬† ¬†If you are someone that rarely reboots your laptop, PLEASE RESTART YOUR LAPTOP THIS WEEK IF YOU HAVE ANY PENDING WINDOWS UPDATES.¬† ¬†This will prevent a forced reboot during the Newforma installation process. New Features Generally, these upgrades don‚Äôt show any significant impacts on the interface or functionality you have been used to over the years.¬† ¬†All of the fixes are¬†in the background with stability and performance.¬† ¬†This is particularly true for our external partners who will see almost no changes to the web interface or functionality of our info exchange with which they interact with us in our Newforma network. There will be performance issues in the speed of filing emails to your Newforma projects from Outlook.¬† ¬†There are also some unique email filing conditions that have been resolved and function normally now.¬† ¬†In addition, a new feature enables you to request that Newforma prompt you to file every email you send or you can request your team be enabled to choose how to file their emails all the time. Newforma Update The ability to use the Revit addin is now available for those using Revit 2018 or 2019.¬† ¬†This includes all the functionality that was previously there in older versions of this addin.¬† This was added in one of the recent updates.¬† ¬†Similarly, the ability for Newforma to properly read current dwg files from AutoCAD 2018 or 2019 now functions as well.¬† ¬†Recently they added a Navisworks integration that allows you to load clash reports into the system from their native XML¬†export format through the action items activity.¬† ¬†This allows you to track the completion of clashes through Newforma action items instead of through a file/list from Navisworks or through future clash report comparisons. Additionally, there were small improvements to reports, right-click menus, meeting minute forms, synchronizing project information from Revit model files, the ability to index SketchUp files, improvements to indexing and searchability, external team members improved access to projects and info they are allowed to access, server database tuning for performance improvements.

title: Revit 2019.2 Update
content: For the past few years, Autodesk has adopted a release cycle where new features now get introduced in point releases a few times a year instead of just once.¬† The latest release which has been updated in our firm‚Äôs network continues to fix bugs in the software and improve the stability of the features we use to reduce crashing. While a lot of new features help our engineering consultants deal with MEP and Structure elements better and more accurately, here are a few things that will help us. Functionality to manage images in your model and place images loaded by an instance Removed the warning about elements to small so you can move objects very small distances Ability¬†to zoom in on a schedule view in the model ‚Äì this is done by holding the Crtl button and using the mouse wheel, to set back to 100% use Crtl and 0 More functionality around linking the topography from Civil 3D (typically used by our civil engineers or landscape consultants) Many improvements for cloud worksharing¬†projects and model posting and hosting functionality These along with some of the previous improvements which are already available like multi-monitor support, aligning sections, background fill patterns, levels in 3d views, tiled views and uncropped perspectives make this the version your team should be on right now.¬† ¬†If you would like to see what else is coming soon take a look at the Revit public roadmap that Autodesk released. All new projects should be starting in Revit 2019 from one of the firm‚Äôs templates.¬† ¬†All existing projects should be making every effort to get their entire team upgraded to 2019.¬† ¬†Please coordinate with your consultants and other team members to find a good time in your project schedule to do this and coordinate any questions about the process you might have with your local design applications manager. title: Sharpen your Tools: Reference Views Between Models
content: ViewAQC (formerly known as DRU ‚Äì detail referencing utility) has passed piloting phase with flying colors and is available for use on P+W projects. This tool enables teams to cross-reference views across multiple Revit models. For example, all details can be kept in a separate file(s) and called out from other models. The reference labels will be automatically updated when details are moved to different sheets or their numbers are updated, similar to how it works when you move a detail to a different sheet within the same model. This tool can work with any view type and is not limited to working with details and drafting views. It can also create intelligent text notes when referencing a view in a different model. ViewAQC¬†has a robust user interface and project teams find it easy to learn. It has proven itself very resilient, with utilities to check, diagnose, and repair broken links as well as utilities to track changes. There are multiple project teams that utilized it in Seattle, Los Angeles, Miami, and most recently Dallas office. Feedback from¬† the latest project team: Tyler Ostrozynski (Dallas office) Our team decided to explore the use of ViewAQC as a means to bridge a workflow gap associated with split scope Revit modeling. When dealing with split scope Revit modeling in the past, the process of referencing views in other models was a tedious and highly time-consuming task, often requiring a greater amount of back-checking to ensure duplicated, non-associated annotations matched across the document set. We began implementing ViewAQC into our workflow in late SD and immediately recognized its potential as a time saver. Initial project configuration was fairly straight forward as there are resources and successful precedents available. The user interface is simple, easy to navigate, and reliable. With access to ViewAQC, our team can now cross-reference any view in any model and have the annotations automatically update as needed. This is a great tool for our studio as it lends well to our goals for efficiency and time savings. Having initial success with using ViewAQC, it is difficult to imagine reverting back to the old solution to split scope Revit modeling. We have recently converted our individual licenses into floating concurrent licenses which means that we now have the capacity to add¬† more project teams to the license pool without incurring additional cost Please contact your local Design Applications Manager or the Digital Practice team to implement on your project. More information https://digitalpractice.perkinswill.com/2018/01/30/sharpen-your-tools-2/ https://digitalpractice.perkinswill.com/2017/06/30/sharpen-your-tools-detail-referencing-utility-dru/ Here are some snapshot of the interface. For more details, watch this training video (48 min).

title: SF Urban Designers Show Off Computational Design
content: On January 18th Luca Giaramidaro and Guangyue Cao from our San Francisco office presented their work to the San Francisco Computational Design group (SFCDUG) Urban Development Capacity: design process, workflow, and tools Assessment of the development potential within the existing urban fabric requires designers to efficiently manage and analyze large sets of spatial and geographical data. What tools and processes can be used to effectively assess the potential development capacity of multiple opportunity sites? Using the BART Phase II Corridor in San Jose as a case study, the presentation will illustrate the design process, workflow, and tools adopted for transit-oriented development analysis. With a combination of GIS, Excel, Grasshopper and machine learning, the Perkins+Will team successfully employed an iterative design process to rapidly identify, measure, and assess multiple development scenarios.

title: LAO ADT ‚Äì Grasshopper and Python Continuing Education
content: The LA office has a group led by the LA design applications manager Dean Demko where they discuss Advanced Digital Technology (ADT) with all users in the office who are interested in building their skill set and keeping in the loop with what new workflows and tools are being used and developed in the office. One of our Digital Practice Managers,¬†Luc Deckinga, joined us in the LA office to host ADT as a special guest to talk about some advanced¬†uses of grasshopper in computational design. Below¬†is the recap of the work session. If anyone has any questions, feel free to ask Dean Demko and or Luc Deckinga. Digital Application‚Äôs Continuing Education ADT Topics Passing data into the GHPython node Type Hints Data Structure Access Getting data out of the GHPython node ‚Äòout‚Äô messages from the script Passing data to variables Intro to Python scripting Syntax Comments Importing libraries Variables If/Then Loops scriptcontext Rhinoscript commands in GHPython At the end of the presentation yesterday several people asked what Python allows you to do that Out Of The Box Grasshopper doesn‚Äôt. I mentioned recursion but gave a confusing explanation of what that is and why it matters. Here is a more detailed example: A factorial (!) ¬†function works like this: ¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†4! = 4 x 3 x 2 x 1 = 24 ¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†3! = 3 x 2 x 1 = 6 ¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†2! = 2 x 1 = 2 Factorial can be defined like this in Python: def fact(n): if n == 0: return 1 else: return n *¬†fact(n-1) This function is recursive because it¬†calls itself.¬†Recursion is one of the two flow control mechanisms, along with loops , that give python its incredible power. Grasshopper users that have taken advantage of the environmental analysis capabilities of the Honeybee and Ladybug plugins have unknowingly been using Python, which was used to create those plugins. Because it is one of the most popular programming languages, knowing Python gives you access to a wide range of functions and libraries created by the greater community and enables you to connect to hardware and software that have Python application programming interfaces. Additional Resources: A good intro to Python: https://www.codecademy.com/learn/learn-python-3 Grasshopper Python intro: https://www.modelical.com/en/grasshopper-python-101-introduction/ Python for Rhino references: https://developer.rhino3d.com/guides/rhinopython/ Rhinoscript reference: https://developer.rhino3d.com/api/RhinoScriptSyntax/ Create folder Add file Add comment

title: Do you know where you are? Wrong Node Alert!
content: Wrong Node Alert i s a P+W Revit tool that alerts the user when they open a revit file on the wrong node. The term ‚ÄúWrong Node‚Äù means a user opening a Revit project on a node machine that does not match the city where the project file server is residing in. For example opening a Boston project (P:\Boston\‚Ä¶\Project.rvt), on a New York Node (NYOCN0204) would cause the wrong node alert to pop up¬†and suggest that you log into the Boston node to work on the Boston project file. The reason we care when a user is using the wrong node is because wrong node can causes some serious problems including: Slow performance: It takes longer to load a Boston file from NYO than it is to¬†load a Boston file from Boston. Delay: Saving and synching to central may take longer than normal when working remotely. File Corruption: the delay in performance often causes corruption in the Revit file integrity, which will lead to unpleasant error message and major headaches for the project team down the road. Clearly, no one wants to corrupt their Revit project file. Often this happens unintentionally as people work on multiple projects from different offices and forget to change the node as they swtich between projects. They may have saved a few minutes for themselves from not changing the nodes, but as they corrupted the file by working on the wrong node, the team will have to pay for it by losing many more hours of work just to fix those errors. The moral of the story is don‚Äôt work on the wrong node, always match the node city with the project city and you will work smoother, be happier and live longer! What do I do if I see the Wrong Node Alert? If you see the wrong Node Alert. just Stop, Close and Change Node . Stop what you are doing. Close the Revit file. Log into the matching city Node (Open New York file on New York Node, Boston file on Boston Node‚Ä¶.etc.) Just as a precaution, an alert message will be sent to the Design Application Manager of the office that are affected by your action. You might be getting a call from them soon. Options Close All Documents and Exit Revit : When only 1 document is open, you will see the option to close all and exit Revit. This option will prompt you to save and exit Revit automatically. OK and Continue : This option will close the pop up window, send an alert to the DA, but lets you continue the session as normal. When more than one document is open, this will be the only option given to you, since we don‚Äôt want to force you to close up any other Revit document that is still open. Kindly close the offending Revit file, and log into the proper matching node to re-open the Revit file on the correct node. Read More : Read more will bring you to this page on the pulse! What if I just need to copy a detail from my other project? Question : I‚Äôm working on the right city node, but I just need to copy a small detail from my other project that is not in this city‚Äôs projects, do I still need to change node? Answer : In this case, you can open the other project by detaching it, and that will avoid any problem from corrupting the other project file! and the Wrong Node Alert will ignore all detached file opening events. Note: Wrong Node Alert will only be installed for Revit 2019 and 2018. Create folder Add file Add comment

title: Sharpen Your Tools ‚Äì Content Creation is Never Done!
content: Efficiency in document production can come from many different sources; a faster workflow, an optimized template. Sometimes it comes in the form of a parametric family. In this case we looked at a collection of table families that were functionally similar but were individual families with fixed dimensions and layouts.As the Design App Manager for the Minneapolis office I strive to identify any opportunity to improve efficiency so I decided to tackle the table families. The following are the steps I took: Verified existing Reference Planes, Label Parameters, and Geometry Added additional Reference Planes and Label Parameters after flexing identified issues Separated Extrusions with more than one sketch for proper flexing Created new Seating Arrays Added the necessary formulas and visibility parameters so the seating can grow Good family creation can become great with a little extra controls. If you see a condition where you think something can be improved, streamlined, or more user friendly do not hesitate to reach out to the Digital Practice ‚Äì Design App team!

title: The Latest Clarity Updates
content: Clarity automates many daily tasks for project teams. We have rolled out the latest update. This update has increased the speed and stability of the product as we increase our usage and reliance on it. Few things to point out include: better functionality with Autodesk BIM360 Design projects support for dynamo 2.0 tasks the ability to specify worksets for tasks You should have a clarity project set up for every project you are working on, right from the start. This will free up team‚Äôs time by automating repetitive tasks, like printing sheets or views for presentations or the document set as your design evolves. This way you can always have sheets available in PDF format.¬† Clarity can also help prep models for sharing with consultants and other external team members, and can even be paired with Newforma folder sharing or BOX to automate the entire process of sharing models (or other files).¬† You can also automate other exports that are necessary like DWG, Navisworks, gbXML or FBX Clarity has also developed some good model monitoring tools to help on monitoring the health of your Revit models and reduce the likelihood of crashes and other technical project disruptions¬†in Revit.¬† Under the model metrics area, you can get a¬† real quick view of something you might be able to address to reduce those problems that we all know will happen right at a deadline. Clarity can also assist with model comparisons to help understand the difference as a model is developed, either before we are sending them to our consultants or the models we are receiving from them.¬† ¬†This is done through the model snapshot and model compare tasks, which can also be paired with the clarity add-in¬†called Metamorphosis¬†in Revit to graphically see this information. Make sure your team is taking advantage of all the features in clarity That will help automate typical project tasks and will free some of your time helping you focus on providing our clients with a great design.¬† ¬†If you don‚Äôt have this setup right now for your current project just submit a help request by providing the name of the project and path where the central models are saved.¬† ¬†If you already are using it but have run into questions or problems please¬†refer to the Clarity microKnowledge cards we have on the subject.

title: AEC Hackathon 2018
content: The hackathon event is a great opportunity for meeting other AEC Tech enthusiasts as well as working collaboratively to resolve Industry challenges with people who have various skillsets and different AEC backgrounds ranging from; Lighting Consultants, Construction, Product Designers, MEP,etc.. As well as presence of reps from Rhino and Autodesk Forge to assist projects utilizing either platforms. My team‚Äôs objective was to create a Grasshopper plugin that cultivates encrypted Rendering data from images including camera and light settings (if a user has the passcode) can easily transfer them to new Rhino files, we called it ‚ÄúSneaky Cat‚Äù. The link to all completed Scripts on Github is here https://core.thorntontomasetti.com/aec-tech-2018/aec-tech-2018-hackathon/2018-aec-tech-hackathon-github-repos The link to the videos is here https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLop4Isy6Y0PFcZxfpviJQgwUl23cxhIMx Below are some screenshots from the teams‚Äô presentations. 1. title: New Features in Enscape 2.4
content: The latest version of Enscape 2.4 is out, and there are some great new features that will make your work even easier! Enscape‚Äôs web standalone If you liked the Enscape executable standalone, you will be excited to know that you can now share your Enscape model via Web Standalone. Simply export Enscape as Web Standalone, then share the web link so others can view the model using a web browser. The advantage of viewing the Enscape Web Standalone in a web browser is that high-end graphics card in the computer is not required, so you can now share your enscape model just as you have shared your panorama images. Click HERE for the steps on how to export to Web Standalone. Asset Library Enscape is introducing their own Enscape Asset Library with contents such as accessories, furniture, people and vegetation. Once you select and place an asset into the model, Enscape will place a low-res version of the actual asset, which will render at high res quality when viewed in the Render window. Click HERE for more details on how to use the Ensape Asset Library. Adjustable Grass Can you tell the difference between the grass in the two renderings below? One is flat grass, and the other is 3D grass that Enscape shows in its rendering image. Enscape‚Äôs 3D grass always added more realism to the rendering. Now you can further adjust the height and height variation of the blades of grass. By simply adding the keyword grass into Revit material name, Enscape picks up the keyword, and renders the surface using the grass texture. Now, three more adjectives are added to enable you to adjust the grass material. In addition to the¬†‚ÄúGrass‚Äù¬†keyword, ‚ÄúShort Grass‚Äù, ‚ÄúTall Grass‚Äù and ‚ÄúWild Grass‚Äù are also added. Visit HERE For more details on additional feature of Grass adjustment in sketchup. Faster Video Rendering Lastly, you can now take better advantage of video animation. The Video rendering time has improved by 6X! As always, don‚Äôt forget to PAUSE LIVE UPDATES when you are using the Enscape on the node! Using Live Updates on the node severly impacts the node performance, causing its¬†performance to grind to a halt. To pause the live updates, simply press on the Live Update control, and the button will toggle to ‚ÄúResume Live Updates‚Äù.¬† To refresh the Enscape window, simply close it and reopen it, and hit pause live updates control again.

title: Have You Been Naughty or Nice?
content: Are you always closing Revit and logging out of the node before you leave for the night? Unfortunately this is not always the case. That contributes to accumulation of Revit file corruption and loss of productivity, especially if the files need to be sent to Autodesk for repair. And you know that most of these things happen when you have a looming deadline- aka the worst possible time. Possible problems: Your Revit model can get locked or corrupted = significant productivity loss for your team The node you did not log out from will not get scheduled updates = potential problems for anyone who connects to that node Your DA or IT support may send you annoying messages about the necessity to close Revit and log out at the end of the day. If you do not put your phone on do not disturb, it may wake you up. Santa will put you on the naughty list ‚Äì no chocolates for you! How do we know that you did not close your Revit session We automatically collect Revit Journals to help in fighting Revit file corruption. If the Journal did not close normally, this means that either Revit crashed, or your node session was disconnected before you closed session normally. Why didn‚Äôt you close Revit (select all that apply): I was planning to connect from home and continue working on the project I needed to catch my train (bus, ride) home I did not know i need to close Revit session and log out My significant other called and reminded me that I have life outside of work I was hungry I needed a drink I needed a break My client called and I had to run I was late for a meeting I was feeling sick I was late for gym (school, doctor, party) Other ‚Ä¶‚Ä¶‚Ä¶‚Ä¶‚Ä¶. if you picked answer #1 , why didn‚Äôt you close your Revit session¬† and logged out of the node from home I fell asleep at my desk and my head hit the keyboard My kid (spouse) was crying I was too sleepy to work after dinner I was too drunk after bar My significant other reminded me that home is home By the time I got home, my session was already disconnected I lost (forgot) my laptop There was¬† a disruption in service (electricity, Internet) There was a disaster in my area (fire, flood, gas leak, locust) I had an emergency at home My favorite team lost (won) Other ‚Ä¶‚Ä¶‚Ä¶‚Ä¶. Please add more creative reasons in the comments but remember that if you do not close Revit and log out off the node, you are opening your team to productivity loss and Santa will put you on the Naughty list.

title: Sharpen your tools: Adaptive Components

featured_media.title: mK-WF-How do I Create a Dynamic QR Code (1)

content: Adaptive Components for Design and Documentation Many of you have heard about or worked with Adaptive Components in Revit. They are commonly used to place a family that adapts to a contextual conditions of your design.The Adaptive Components are built on ‚Äúplacement points‚Äù and these points can interact with other elements of your projects. Here are some interesting examples of less known¬†¬†functionality¬†of adaptive components which can make tedious tasks of design iterations and automatic documentation productive and enjoyable. Example 1: Placing simple adaptive component on the divided surface Example 2: Rapid design iterations and form finding for early design (competition) Example 3: Visually driven design, rationalization and documentation in this project the designers wanted a way to rationalize both the random pattern of the glazing panels, as well as a way to add shading devices to the mullions. And of course, an ability¬†adjust everything till the last moment without re-work. The solution took advantage of Adaptive Components ability to ‚Äúcommunicate‚Äù with other geometry and adjust. Designer just needed to move the ‚Äúsphere of influence‚Äù, and the whole design would adjust. Documentation (panel schedules) would adjust automatically. Example 4: Documenting complicated forms Adaptive Components can go into your¬†design, and measure and report the dimensions for effortless documentation in the schedules. Regardless what tools you have used for creating geometry, once the form is in Revit, you can use Adaptive Components for measuring. In this double-curved concrete facade panel, it was necessary to know XYZ in many points to manufacture the correct form. Rather than generating sections and dimensioning in multiple locations in each section, adaptive components were used to generate schedules for XYZ. Unfortunately, the budget was cut and we ended up with flat panels‚Ä¶ Was still fun while it lasted. Example 5: Conceptual Design ‚Äì Fifty Shades of Gray Adaptive components can have rules applied to them in order to create intricate and complex forms.¬† This interior project example has a prominent entry wall that the design team wanted to express a flowing form indicative of water.¬† The wall was modeled in the Mass environment, divided, and an adaptive component was applied.¬† The transforms of the component align to to a grayscale image produced for the project.¬† As the image becomes darker, the Adaptive Component becomes more rotated.¬† As the image becomes lighter, the Adaptive Component becomes flatter. What makes adaptive components so smart? They are based on the placement points, which can be hosted on any other family or project geometry. The distance and rotation between placement points can be parametrized, and used as a reporting parameter for measuring or in formulas to drive other parameters. They can be placed automatically using with repeaters based on divided surfaces, divided paths or both They can be placed programmatically using Dynamo or Python based on any coordinates of the placement points, or by selecting existing geometry They can be used to create family geometry using Revit massing tool set ‚Äì for any¬† 3D category ‚ÄãThey can automate your documentation process, so you can minimize re-work ‚Äã Show me more of what can be done with adaptive components ! If you see an opportunity to improve your project proccess using adaptive components, please reach out to you local DA Please share your stories: adapt, divide and conquer
