title: LA Office ‚Äì Successful VR Projects Use Cases

author.name: Nick Cameron
author.description: American trucker who has been featured on the History channel reality television series Ice Road Truckers and its spinoff series IRT: Deadliest Roads.

content: After DC‚Äôs VR Roadshow with Justin Benjamin and Tim Bakos (coordinated by local DA Dean Demko) visited Los Angeles back in late June, the Los Angeles office has had a number of success stories on many levels. Including, client presentations, client interactive design work sessions, internal design reviews, and internal model reviews. After Interior Project Designer, Tina Giorgadze attended DC‚Äôs road show she has adopted VR and began applying VR instantly. At the happy hour the day of the lunch and learn she was eager to get into VR and begin reviewing the medical facility she was in the process of designing. Instantly she found many design issues which she marked up in VR and took away a report to distribute to the team to make design changes based on her VR experience. After seeing the capabilities, which VR offered to design and its ability to give the user a greater sense of space, she then requested to use the VR equipment for a client meeting to review the furniture and materials. With advance notice, the DA was able to work with her to prepare a scripted experience, which worked in conjunction with the other materials she prepared for the meeting, including a slide show of renderings, floor plans, images of the proposed furniture, and material samples. The client brought a couple of the physicians who have been involved in the design process. Neither of them had ever used VR before this experience but were eager to put on the headset during the meeting. It only took a couple of minutes in the immersive environment of VR before they were completely acclimated to the navigation and controls becoming comfortable moving through the space. In preparation for the meeting, Utilizing Enscape on her local MSI machine Tina made sure the model was well prepared with clean modeling, accurate, materials, and lighting.¬†¬†They were then able to spend productive time navigating the model and reviewing the design giving critical feedback. While they were in VR, there were instances where they commented on some of the patterns and colors, which Tina was able to update on the fly to show instantly other design options. They were then able to compare the material samples with what they experienced in the VR environment to get a full sense of the design intent. After the meeting, they stated it would not have been possible for them to comprehend the impact of the patterns and materials had they not been able to experience the space immersed in VR. This in the end resulted in a critical design adjustment for the client, which would not have been possible without VR. Another example of a designer influenced by DC‚Äôs traveling VR road show was with interior project designer Nina Lahham who was eager to get the client into VR as well. Nina contacted DA Dean Demko early in the morning the day of the client meeting. Asking if he could prepare VR for a client presentation. Even with such short notice, Dean was able to assemble the equipment within 30 minutes and have the model up and running ready to go for the presentation. Nina also had many other materials prepared for the meeting, including renderings and material samples. Once again, neither had been immersed in VR before, they were also first timers. They were able to comprehend the controls and navigation quickly, and within a few minutes were comfortably moving through the space and began providing productive design feedback, which was only possible with the VR experience. The client was so impressed with the VR experience they requested we bring the equipment to their office to show everyone their new design. A few weeks later, they brought the equipment to their office where, Nina presented the design to their office and afterwards they hosted a VR lunch session with Dean‚Äôs assistance. Utilizing VR in the client‚Äôs office was a great success, which brought everyone into the process generating excitement for all the client‚Äôs employees. Since then others have seen the success of the equipment, which now due to the demand the LA office has now purchased another Oculus Rift. The design director Yan Krymsky keeps one headset at his desk and the other one is used throughout the office on many projects.

title: Rendering Machines Available!
content: Since March, approximately 3,000 render jobs have completed on our render farms.¬†¬†An impressive number despite the machines in some offices sitting idle. The render farms are generating more content than ever, but they are not running at capacity. Are you in an office with render nodes being underutilised? Take a look at the pie chart below. It shows the number of jobs completed by office. Aarhus and Copenhagen actually dominate rendering so they were filtered out to allow other office names to be legible. If your office name does not appear in the pie chart the render nodes in your office may be underutilised. The render farms were introduced early in 2018 as part of the High Performance Computing (HPC) project, a partnership between Digital Practice and IT. The HPC render nodes span 24 offices and number 138 machines (see image below). Many of these machines are practically a small render farm unto themselves containing 24 Intel processing cores and 256 GB of RAM each. The potential rendering power of these farms is significant. The types of renderings taking place on the HPC render farms vary. Traditional renderings and animations make up some, but not all of the jobs. Also very popular are live renderings where the images remain on the working desktops of designers. Known as distributed rendering (DR) or distributed bucket rendering (DBR) this gives designers a faster workflow for progress renderings, which account for the large majority of all renderings. It also allows designers to render from our standard production nodes or cnodes without disturbing others on the same node. At present, this technology is available for Revit 2018 & 2019, 3ds Max 2018 & 2019, SketchUp 2018, Rhino v6, and Unreal. If you think render nodes may be sitting idle in your office, we invite you to use the links below to learn more. These past Digital Practice News articles address how to access our render farms and which rendering tools to use. How to Use P+W‚Äôs Render Farm Easier Visualization for All

title: Metrotown LRT Station VR Model Workflow: Unreal Engine 4.14

author.name: Nick Cameron
author.description: American trucker who has been featured on the History channel reality television series Ice Road Truckers and its spinoff series IRT: Deadliest Roads.

content: Metrotown LRT Station VR Model Workflow: Unreal Engine 4.14 | E.Aslan This article will describe the process of re-creating Metrotown LRT Station (Vancouver) in VR using Unreal Engine 4.14. The LRT station was selected for this project because of the interactive opportunities it presented (such as the fare gates, elevators and escalators), along with their related animations. It was intended as a technical demonstration of how UE4 could serve the architectural field in terms of internal review, consultant/internal coordination and as a client deliverable. As such, the information presented in this writing is considered prototypical, and is current as of Unreal Engine version 4.14. This article will discuss the processes, workflows, and several exceptions to these workflows, as well as three Blueprint Scripts that have been implemented to improve the model‚Äôs functionality and UX. To learn more about the process, please download the PDF to read the full article.

title: Digital Information as the Contract Document Deliverable
content: The relationship between design and construction is changing as both adopt more sophisticated tools to execute their work. The way these disciplines collaborate in the future may look very different than how it has in the past.¬† The lean construction institute holds a conference every fall and the presenters showed how the processes used by everyone on every project type could be more effective. One significant way that we can improve communication between the disciplines and reduce waste is to change the medium by which we deliver design intent.¬† We work in 3d during the creation of design, giving us a complete picture of the project.¬† ¬†However, we then lose information translating that model into flat segmented images of the project, organized in the traditional way devised before computers, put together by hand on paper.¬† When we convert our models to drawings we take a complete picture and make it incomplete.¬† We also take what could be real-time, dynamic information and make it static.¬† Contractors most often convert that information back into 3d models, a digital twin from which the physical building is constructed.¬† In the past, our only option was to create these drawings, but now we do this merely because¬†of tradition, not due to the limits of our technology. We need to be more concerned with a handshake of information as we move from design and pre-construction to fabrication and building, instead of the traditional handoff.¬† This will provide us with the same type of quality control process that helps ensure that the design intent stays true as others partner with the team to pull all the elements and systems together that make a building.¬† This will perhaps bring the sub-trade partners on-board earlier to model and work with our architectural teams to finalize the design before construction begins. New tools (which already exist) will enable better issue tracking and coordination.¬† Data review, quality control, and the flow of communication will feel different, but more useful, with all the right people at the table working around a set of shared project information located in a common data environment. This is not the first time this conversation has taken place at our firm, or within our industry. Take a look below at some partners‚Äô comments from the project delivery board on this subject a few years ago. Perkin+Will-Panel Recap from PW Digital Practice This transition from old to new delivery methods will take time and we will have some small hurdles to overcome.¬† ¬†We will have to consider all of our processes as the medium increasingly becomes digital models instead of 2D PDFs.¬† ¬† We will have to look at the language of the deliverables in our contract‚Äôs basic services.¬† ¬†We will need to think about what views are necessary for a model before we send it.¬† ¬†We will have to consider our quality control processes and move to more modern tools to check the information that isn‚Äôt easily displayed on a sheet.¬† ¬† We will have to work with suppliers to understand the submittal process, to obtain the elements of the actual prescribed items for your particular project.¬† ¬†Most importantly we will have to listen to the workers on site who need information to put the building together. They need¬†to find ways to read this data and discover what format helps them build more efficiently. Just as internet mapping services allowed people to understand and navigate their environment in a different way, switching to a high-fidelity means of information exchange promises to enable workers to access information faster, resulting in more time for our design teams to achieve the accuracy they want.

title: So Much Technology, So Little Time. Leveraging Tech at Conferences

author.name: Nick Cameron
author.description: American trucker who has been featured on the History channel reality television series Ice Road Truckers and its spinoff series IRT: Deadliest Roads.

content: The Event Earlier this year, P+W¬†Miami participated in the annual Florida Educational Facilities Planner‚Äôs Association conference, also known as FEFPA. PW MIA attends every year for an Opportunity to connect with past, current, and future potential clients in K-12 and Higher Ed market sector. Typical attendee sponsors with booths consist of architect, interior designer, engineers, and vendors. Facility planners attend over a 2 day period and mingle with sponsors. Typically, our booth setup has consisted of a table, a laptop, and 3 banners. This year, the decision was made to upgrade our presence. This meant reserving two side by side booths, reserving space adjacent to the food and beverage booth, and showcasing the various technology integral to our design process. Next step was making a few decisions. Who would attend? What content would we showcase? What tech would be involved? Team Content Since the target audience would be educators and facility planners that narrowed down the content to K-12 and Higher Ed. We decided to go with two projects that we had built at Florida International University. FIU Science Classroom Center and FIU Robert Stempel College Complex. Projects were very relevant to our target audience Plenty of collateral on these two projects Professionally photographed Project was close enough to do last minute 360 degree capture for uploading to VX app and website Model was somewhat VR ready Both buildings existed in Google Earth VR which allowed us to virtually visit site Team members in attendance were integrally involved in these two projects. Tech In the end, we brought‚Ä¶ ‚Ä¶50 Homido mini VR glasses in PW Digital Practice branded boxes‚Ä¶ ‚Ä¶Wacom Cintiq 27QHD Touch Screen Tablet for navigating showcase project on VX website‚Ä¶ ‚Ä¶3 VR headsets for redundancy‚Ä¶ ..3 MSI laptops. 1 to power a VR display, 1 to run the touchscreen table, 1 to run a continuous loop of marketing images‚Ä¶ ‚Ä¶The resulting tech combo‚Ä¶ ‚Ä¶ and finally, 1 Herman Miller Magis Spun Chair. Things to Consider and Plan for Understanding audience. Vetting appropriate technology to showcase. Preparing for the unexpected. Redundancy. Get those software and hardware updates before the conference. Steam, Enscape, Revit, etc. Make sure you check out an Autodesk license. Plan your Wi-Fi access, or rather plan as if there will be no Wi-Fi. We had to pay $450 for 2 day, 2 device wi-fi access. Revit VR Walkthroughs Upgrading older Revit models. Prepping Revit models for VR Walkthrough. Downloading detached Revit models to 3 laptops. Export to Enscape project. 360 Project Site Panoramas Visiting site and generating 360 spherical panoramas. Coordinate in time with VizLab on uploading to VX app and website. Get the required approvals on VX content. Mini VR-Goggle Giveaways How many do you plan on taking? Unwrapping and re-packaging 50 Homido mini VR glass in Digital Practice branded boxes. How do you get people to take them? Engaging your audience Getting people to and into your booth. Getting people to use VR. Suprises Spun Chair was the biggest draw Kids and consulting engineer community showed the most interest in the technology. Gave away very few mini VR glasses. What Ifs Rethink booth layout to make people comfortable with engaging with technology. Bring our own hotspot.

An improved user interface that better resembles other modern applications.¬† (check out this transition page for tool locations or icons ) The ability to remove windows from the program¬†to another part of your desktop. The ability to customize and export and import keyboard shortcuts. If you want to see what else they have improved take a look at their list here . Also, don‚Äôt forget that we have many quick answers to your Bluebeam questions on the firm‚Äôs microKnowledge site. So what should I do? title: Revit 2019 Released!

author.name: Nick Cameron
author.description: American trucker who has been featured on the History channel reality television series Ice Road Truckers and its spinoff series IRT: Deadliest Roads.

content: Revit 2019 is scheduled to be available to Perkins+Will on September 10, 2019 As we move from summer to fall we are happy to make the newest version of our modeling and documentation software available.¬† ¬†While the number one thing we continue to see is the stability and speed of the new product there are many other small features that will make everyone‚Äôs life just a little easier. In addition to Revit 2019, we are also making available AutoCAD LT 2019, Navisworks 2019, 3dsMax 2019. Should I Upgrade My Project? In the last 2 releases, we haven‚Äôt pushed as hard for project teams to get upgraded, primarily because of the changes Autodesk made to text.¬† This year, if you are in an active design phase, we are going to strongly encourage you to get upgraded to 2019.¬† Here are some of the reasons you should consider upgrading:Our typical C401 contracts compel the consultants to upgrade when we do.You gain efficiency when you take advantage of the latest product new features and bug fixes.Many of our tools only support the latest few versions of software. Don‚Äôt get stuck in CA without access to tools like Clarity or Revit Express Tools.In addition to the Revit 2019 software rollout, the Digital Practice network has been hard at work in several areas to continue to weave design technology into the fabric of the firm .¬†¬†Below are some highlights of what to expect: HIVE HIVE is our new way to manage and place Revit Families in our models. Hive effectively replaces 3 existing tools, simplifying the process of finding the families required for a project. It leverages modern taxonomy constructs to create a flexible system the entire firm can benefit from. Libraries can now be shared across the entire firm, giving designers access to much more content. This new system also allows for the quick creation of ad hoc libraries without loading duplicate content into the system. A group of Science & Technology leaders is working on publising market specific content. Based on the feedback from this summers pilot teams we are excited to share this tool with all of our studios this fall. Click here for more info. Revit Template Rebuilds rebuild all of the Revit templates in the firm from scratch, per Autodesk recommendation on a 2-3 year cycle. MicroKnowledge The Perkins+Will mK Website is constantly being updated with quick ‚ÄúHow-tos‚Äù which will include many of the new solutions and features indicated in this article. Check it out! Dynamo 2 All instances of Dymamo on our nodes will be upgraded to version 2.¬† Dynamo 2 is chaulk full of improvements which will benefit the firm.¬† It is important that script creators are aware that Dynamo 2 introduces a JSON replacement of the old XML file format, causing scripts that are saved in Dynamo 2 to be upgraded and incompatible with old versions of Dynamo.¬† All scripts should be verified to work in the new version. New Revit Home Screen Recent Files, Creating a New Project, Auto Local File Uncropped Perspective Finally, Modeling in Full screen Perspective Double Fill Patterns Using Two Patterns in the Same Material Other New Features Tabbed Views on Multiple Monitors Levels Visibile in 3D Views Selection Box to Scope Box Matching Better Material Rendering Assets Align Section Markers with other Elements To learn more about all of the Revit 2019 New features, click here Create folder Add file Add comment ¬© 2013 Perkins+Will Contact administrator: Mr. Derek Veren

title: Digital Practice Core Skills Continuing Education
content: The content below includes 45-minute continuing education sessions. Each session includes a video of the session along with the powerpoint deck. Click or scroll the content to find a particular item from the agendas. This continuing education conference was given in the Denver studio to better understand how Perkins&Will utilizes our digital practice tools and resources. Our intention is to start offering a conference similar to the one in Denver each quarter offering core sessions for new Perkins&Will designers and ongoing resources for existing team members.

title: The Parametric City: Generative Massing for Urban Design
content: THE CHALLENGE: Generate a podium and tower on a given parcel when provided with site constraints. Any first-year architecture student can¬†accomplish this task for a wide variety of sites. Having a computer do the same proves to be more difficult than it sounds, yet a collaboration between Perkins+Will‚Äôs Digital Practice, Research,¬†and Urban Design groups have accomplished exactly that. Nirvik Saha, a Ph.D.¬†candidate in Georgia Tech‚Äôs computer science program and a member of Perkins+Will‚Äôs research group, along with Urban Designers in our Toronto¬†office,¬†have¬†created a plugin for Rhino to generate building masses on all parcels in a master plan design. This gives the designers a detailed understanding of how their design decisions at the city scale affect the buildings that will eventually occupy that urban fabric. The team developed a general definition for how to create a building from a site boundary by combining the city of Toronto‚Äôs planning code with the design team‚Äôs desires for a ‚Äòpodium and tower‚Äô typology. The script, written in Python, is executed via the Rhino command line. Dimension parameters are input through a pop-up window. The geometric inputs are pulled from specific layers in the Rhino document. This tool fits nicely in the middle of two existing computational tools in the Perkins+Will Urban Design arsenal, the Plan Builder and Area Calculator Grasshopper scripts. Plan Builder generates parcels from road centerlines and right of way dimensions. Area Calculator generates floors from building masses and floor to floor heights and measures the area of those floors. The addition of this building massing script gives Urban Designers a workflow that produces floor areas and building masses, using road centerlines as the only geometric input. That‚Äôs what I call a Parametric City. Inputs to the Massing Generator Geometric InputsParcel BoundariesRoad CenterlinesHeight Bounding Surfaces (optional) Dimension ParametersSetbacks (Parcel boundary to podium ) Stepbacks (face of podium to face of tower ) Podium DepthPodium Minimum Courtyard DepthPodium HeightMaximum Tower Height (used in conjunction with the Height Bounding Surfaces) Minimum Tower SeparationTower Floor Area The Result¬†of the Massing Generator The Full Urban Design Computational Workflow click images to enlarge Road centerlines input into¬† Plan Builder Parcels created by Plan Builder Podium and tower masses created by the Massing Generator Floors created by the Area Calculator Excel file of calculated floor areas If you are interested in using any of the computational tools for Urban Design, contact Luc Deckinga , Digital Practice Manager for Computational Design.

title: Sharpen Your Tools: Keynote Manager Update
content: Many of you are already using Keynote Manager Plus Revit plugin . It was implemented firm wide back in April ( https://pulse.perkinswill.com/content/111799)¬†and is being succesfully used on many projects. This new update introduces new productivity features which will help with QA/QC . and once rolled out, will be available in Revit 2016,2017,2018, and 2019 ‚ÄãNew version of KM+ now allows keynote reporting. Keynote reports show all keynote usages in the project. Keynote Reports can be exported to many common formats including Excel, csv, and pdf for archiving and analysis. While using reporter interface, you can group report by columns and jump to the view containing the element in Revit. KM+ now shows different icon colors based on the usage; black for used only in parameter values (not tagged), purple for used in tags but not placed on sheets; and orange for placed on sheets. Predefined searches now include ‚ÄòOn Sheet‚Äô and ‚ÄòNot On Sheet‚Äô. Renumber allows numbering by increments other than 1 .¬† For example you can set the starting value to 100 and increment to 10 in order to renumber to 100, 110, 120, 130, etc. Renumber can be done recursively to the full depth of it‚Äôs branch.¬† Keynote Manager will use the matching portion of the key value to do an update.¬† For example, if you have a note number 08500 with a sub-note of 08510 and a sub-note to that of 08510.1 and you renumber the top level to 08600 with full depth checked 08510 and 08510.1 will be renumbered to 08610 and 08610.1 respectively. In addition to Keynote Manager improvements, we have another addition (in beta now) to our tool belt. The idea came from Marko Goodwin, a spec writer in NY office. At the end of the process, he wanted to see and compare keynotes in the projects with keynotes in in multiple DOCX files (specs). One can extract keynotes from Revit in many different ways, but this little utility alows users to ‚Äúscrub‚Äù .DOCX files for anything that looks like a Keynote . The search patterns is adjustable, and we can have many selectable patterns if needed. Marko said that what used to take a week of work, now can be done in 15 min Let us know if you have any other suggestions for improvements.

title: I know What You Did Last Model: Slightly off Axis
content: One of the most toxic warnings in Revit looks very innocent: something or other is ‚Äúslightly off axis and may cause inaccuracies‚Äù. But just because it contains the word ‚Äúslightly‚Äù, you cannot assume that it is OK. It is like saying ‚Äúyou are slightly dead‚Äù. I compare the project with ‚Äúslightly off axis‚Äù issue with the person having scoliosis ‚Äì it is a painful condition which gets progressively worse if not adressed early.¬†It is painful for the project to have scoliosis and it gets worse quickly. PLEEEESE, fix items that are slightly off axis right away. If you do not, Revit will try to create other elements parallel or perpendicular to them, and soon you may¬†have much more off-axis elements to fix. They multiply quickly! The main problem with ‚Äúslightly off axis‚Äù is that you can not dimension .Revit dimentions works between parallel objects, and when even one of them is ‚Äúslightly off axis‚Äù you have a problem. Faking dimensions by using detail lines may work occasionally but they become inacurate when design changes. Once you have one misaligned element, it will generate other misaligned element because as you create elements in Revit, they try to align to existing elements Revit considers elements ro be ‚Äúslightly off axis‚Äù if they are at an ange smaller then 0.2 degree to vertical or horizontal directions.¬† It is rare that those angles designed intentionally, so where these warnings are coming from? Most often they come from linking or importing CAD plans to trace the walls or pick the grids. To prevent this, you should check ‚ÄúCorrect lines that are slightly off axis‚Äù when linking CAD. One exception: site survey ‚Äì here things can go in all different directions with small angles Existing conditions building models coming from surveyors may have those warnings, and they need to be resolved or consiously accepted when these angles really exist and matter. On the long walls even small angle makes a differerence.¬† However most important are the grids, because you may want to copy them into your design if you have ignored 20 miles warning, you are back to doom and gloom scenario, including misalignment. see I Know What You Did Last Model: 20 Miles Warning These are most severe ‚Äúslightly off axis‚Äù warnings. which spread quickly to other elements as your model develops. Grid (or reference plane) is slightly off axiis and may cause inaccuracies. Problems with dimension between mis-aligned grids in plan Since grids are a foundation of later geometry, they need to be fixed first! ‚ÄãWall is slightly off axis and may cause inaccuracies . Problems with wall dimensioning in various views The curtain wall might not embed into the host wall.¬†To fix, use align tool or align manually. You can find more information about¬† Revit warning cleanup strategies here

title: Eye on Visualization

author.name: Nick Cameron
author.description: American trucker who has been featured on the History channel reality television series Ice Road Truckers and its spinoff series IRT: Deadliest Roads.

content: Have you ever wondered why someone who is looking at your visualization has missed what you thought was a clear concept? Have you ever wondered why in the heck is the person looking at this image is lost looking in the corners? There has been some budding research by a few visualization companies using eye-tracking software to figure out those very questions. The one in the link below is from Brick Visual and tested various images on a group of people consisting of 3D artists and non-3D professionals. Note, that this study is slightly different than the one MIR did a few years back comparing architects to non-architects when looking at architectural imagery. More on that study is at the bottom of this page. https://brickvisual.com/eye-architecture-visualization/ The video at the bottom of the study is pretty interesting to watch. When nothing catches the viewers eyes, they tend to look at the middle of the screen until a visual queue tells them to look somewhere else. If you skip to this video, just note that red means the most viewed spots. In the end, they found out that as humans we like to look at other humans the most. However, the people in the scene do not detract from the architecture, they provide engagement. That is, of course, if the people are properly placed in the scene. The 2 absolute, brought down from the mountain by Moses Charlton Heston, set in stone, do not ever violate these basic rules of adding people into your scene are:1.¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Never ever have the person placed in the image looking directly back at the viewer. This creates an insane level of discomfort in the viewer and, depending on the space, makes the person added to the rendering look like they are wondering why you are taking a picture of them. 2.¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Sunlit people in an interior space with no natural light. Why does that person look like they have the rays of God shining on them in this basement space with no natural light source? Did they stand in front of the microwave too long or do they just have a glowing personality? Finally, this is a really good overview of what it takes to properly place people into a render by Arui9. I highly suggest checking out Arqui9‚Äôs whole YouTube channel. They have some excellent tutorials on there. This is an interesting topic to me because as a rendering team in Denver we are looking at why our exterior renderings just don‚Äôt have the same punch as our interior renderings. Looking at studies like this seem to confirm my thought that while we spend 98% or more of our time designing the exterior of the building, that‚Äôs not necessarily what sells the image. We spend all of our time on the building but devote very little time and thought to the site, to the landscape architecture, to the surroundings. Yet, it is all of those elements that provide context as to why that building is there in the first place. A perfectly designed building doesn‚Äôt look very well sitting in the middle of a barren concrete pad. In an exterior rendering, you can think of the building as the lead actor in a film, but all of the elements around that building should be considered as the director of a film. The director is telling the actor what to do, why they are there, what is going on around them. When doing an interior rendering, you are almost forced into the need to provide basic context or else the emptiness of the space becomes much more noticeable. However, we still do not provide enough context in most of our interior scenes. We‚Äôll put tables in a scene, but not human accessories on the table. If you have a suite level club rendering full of people, but all of the table tops are completely empty, that just doesn‚Äôt visually connect with the story you are attempting to tell. That being said, taking a rendering to this level requires the proper time to do it. In rendering for architecture in general, we all know time is usually limited so maybe not all projects get this level of detail. However, on those projects that we determine are our marquee projects, we need to make sure we are giving them the right time to hit that level. The MIR study, Julia D Schlegel partnered with the visualization studio MIR to see how architects view their imagery versus your everyday layperson. The results are a little suprising in that architects tend to focus on the building only and your layperson tends to see the whole image.

title: vMaterial Library Adapted for V-Ray
content: Digital Practice has adapted nVidia‚Äôs vMaterial library for use with V-Ray for 3ds Max and V-Ray Next for 3ds Max. vMaterials are a library of physically accurate materials created by nVidia in the Material Definition Language (MDL) format. The library contains 63 materials with each material having one to more than a dozen material variations built-in as presets creating a total of between 350 and 400 materials. How Are vMaterials Accessible to V-Ray? MDL is the original file type for nVidia‚Äôs vMaterials. Chaos Group worked with nVidia to create a special V-Ray material¬† for use with 3ds Max called VRayMDLMtl. The VRayMDLMtl¬†material allows the MDL material type to be placed inside it and an some of its features, like color to be accessible to designers. Digital Practice expanded upon Chaos Group‚Äôs special material making more features available and thus expanding the MDL materials available for use with VayMDLMtl. This is how Digital Practice was able to gain access to nVidia‚Äôs physically accurate vMaterial library. Where to Access the vMaterial Library? The library is stored at S:\_Firmwide\Content\V-Ray\Materials and the filename is vMaterials.mat. A second vMaterials library is also housed at this location. Its filename is vMaterials-Chaos_Group.mat. The 25 additional materials in this second library were created by Chaos Group, but placed in a default location where few people would find them. Digital Practice has organized these materials into their own library and placed that library on the S:\ drive alongside other material libraries. Features That Make vMaterials Different Color control and preset variations are two unique and useful vMaterial features. Changing the color of a material is not new. What makes vMaterials different is how easy it is to get the final rendered color for the material in the scene. This is because the color swatch selectors function as a what you see is what you get (WYSIWYG).Another aspect to vMaterials color manipulation is the frequency of materials to have separate color manipulation for different portions of the material. While this feature may sometimes be found in non-vMaterials it is common to find it in vMaterials. When combined with the WYSIWYG color swatch selectors this features shines and is most noticeable in materials with district patterns.Similar to Revit Families and Family Types each vMaterial may contain numerous types or material presets found under the material‚Äôs dropdown parameter called ‚Äòmdl material‚Äô. All of the vMaterials created by Chaos Group have only one preset. Most of the vMaterials created nVidia have numerous presets. The presets typically change colors, but some change more than color. What is Needed to Open and Render with the vMaterial Library? In September Digital Practice and IT will work together to push setting to the render nodes and computational nodes while providing and designer initiated install for MSI laptops and visualization workstations. In the meantime if you would like to explore these materials on your visualization machine, contact Dan Chasteen to get set up. C

title: What is all the Buzz? Introducing HIVE
content: HIVE is our new Revit Content Management System. It effectively replaces 3 existing tools, simplifying the process of finding the families required for a project. It leverages modern taxonomy constructs to create a flexible system the entire firm can benefit from. Libraries can now be shared across the entire firm, giving designers access to much more content. This new system also allows for the quick creation of ad hoc libraries without loading duplicate content into the system. A group of Science & Technology leaders is working on publising market specific content. Based on the feedback from this summers pilot teams we are excited to share this tool with all of our studios this fall. So what is the latest scoop? How can you get your hands on it? At this time we wil be focusing on using HIVE for Revit content: loadable and system families, schedules, drafting views, entire sheets of details. etc. On September 8 we are rolling out Autodesk 2019 product lineup, and HIVE will be a part of this rollout. But do not worry if your project is still in 2018 ‚Äì we will make HIVE available in Revit 2018 and publish current BIMList libraries for 2018. So for 2018 projects we will have both BIMList+CrossDatabase search and HIVE coexisting. For projects starting in Revit 2019, BIMList will not be available. Below is a conceptual overview of HIVEs¬†orginization system . Develop assets locally and share firm wide¬†‚Äì Designers can search across all libraries seamlessly Store locally and/or on the cloud¬†‚Äì ability for designers to get content without being connected to the P+W network and share content with external teams. Revit metadata search¬†‚Äì automatically captures Revit categories,parameters and properties as metadata Custom tagging¬†‚Äì tagging extends the taxonomy, creating ad-hoc libraries for markets, project phase ,etc. Flexible intuitive search¬†‚Äì ‚Äúchair‚Äù ‚ÄúHaworth‚Äù will find only Haworth chairs, chair Haworth will find all chairs + all Haworth asset In the following weeks we will share more information, begin training sessions and more contetn will be organised and published.

title: Clarity 2019 Rollout
content: Clarity is the firm‚Äôs tool to automate repetitive tasks on our Revit projects. In addition to automating our output tasks like printing, Clarity can also run model comparison¬†reports and/or visualization, run model metrics to help improve the quality and stability of your project models, run Macros or dynamo script to automate other tasks within your model (like cleanup). Friday, August 24th at 7pm Eastern, 6pm¬†Central, 5pm¬†Mountain, 4pm¬†Pacific time and overnight at our international locations clarity will be unavailable during the upgrade process for a couple hours.¬† ¬†Please plan accordingly with your project needs. We have been using Clarity for over 3 years now and it has saved the firm over 92,000¬†hours which equates to about 16 full-time employees for those 3¬† years.¬† Hopefully, this time was repurposed back to design tasks on all those projects by the team. Even with all that time saving we still don‚Äôt have all teams taking full advantage of this tool. Getting your local Design Applications Manager or GTS support to set up your project in clarity is simple.¬† ¬†All you need to tell them is the path to your central files.¬† ¬†After that is completed, it will only take about 10 minutes to get your¬†typical project printing tasks set up and running. This versions new features in clarity 2019 include: Functionality¬†with Revit 2019 New dashboards for model metrics New scheduling dashboard to understand task server resources Check out last year‚Äôs new features here . Please be aware that this upgrade means that the functionality of clarity will NO LONGER WORK WITH REVIT 2015 PROJECTS. If your project is in 2015 and going to continue on for a good amount of time please coordinate with your local design applications manager and consider an upgrade plan.

title: Sharpen Your Tools: Tips From The Trenches
content: This months tips come from Jeremy Franklin, Technical Director ‚Äì Interiors in Chicago office Here is his story: Hi all, I have been jumping around between a lot of projects lately, and I have observed a few items I wanted to send as reminders.¬†Please poke me if you need more clarification, I always have time to answer questions. It is extremely common to have CAD files linked into Revit models so that we can easily show the existing core/shell without modeling the entire building. Please always link CAD files; don‚Äôt ‚Äúinsert‚Äù ¬†them. But before linking, the CAD file(s) MUST be saved to the DESIGN/BIM/REVIT/LINKS folder (of the same project folder to where the corresponding Revit model lives). Why? A lot of reasons. Linking across different job folders is generally hazardous and risky for future broken links The CAD file always needs cleanup to assist with displaying properly (graphically) on our plans.¬† This especially includes purging of hidden and extraneous junk.¬† It is better to do that in a CAD file that is specific to the project you‚Äôre working on, so that you have a ‚Äúmaster‚Äù version to fall back on, if needed. Link to clean-up method Linking from other folders is confusing to anyone other than the person who does it.¬† When someone is trying to help troubleshoot problems with the linked CAD file, the first place they go is the LINKS folder. Be courteous to your coworkers. If you‚Äôre linking from some other master folder, how do you know whether that CAD file is also linked into other Revit models? And then if you edit or corrupt it, you may be affecting the appearance of floor plans in projects you‚Äôre not even aware of‚Ä¶ When you first setup a Revit project, take 5 minutes to set the Revit levels properly using a building section of elevation view.¬† Name the levels to correspond to the actual building levels.¬† Set the floor-to-floor height as accurately as you can. Link to more info about level setup When you first set up a Revit project, take 5 minutes to set the project north (and if necessary, true north) and graphical north arrows correctly.¬† If you‚Äôre not sure, look at Google maps to confirm north orientation. ¬†The building orientation should correspond to true north in its direction in Revit, relative to compass north.¬† If this cocks the building at weird angle relative to your sheet, then rotate the project north to make the plan orthogonal on the sheet. Rotate the project north in Revit on the Manage ribbon tab / Position pulldown: If you need to rotate the plan 90 degrees simply to fit the sheet better, I would recommend rotating the crop frame rather than project north. Better yet, use Section Box and Rotate it. This way all you plans will be cropped and rotated consistently. Think about the plan orientation ASAP to avoid embarrassing situations like having north facing DOWN on the sheet (like in a recent project) Every plan, regardless of phase, needs a north arrow symbol for reference and orientation If true north and project north match, then turn off the ‚Äútrue north‚Äù visibility in the north arrow symbol like this: If true north is slightly skewed relative to the sheet, then leave its visibility on and rotate the true north orientation by editing the ‚Äúdegrees‚Äù parameter of the symbol to set it correctly. For example: If you rotate the plan 90 degrees to fit the sheet: ¬†rotate the north arrow symbol to correspond, then afterwards adjust the true north parameter as described above Don‚Äôt be lazy about workset management.¬† One of the most common answers to ‚Äúwhy isn‚Äôt ____ showing up?‚Äù is because of workset management. Furniture belongs on the Furniture workset.¬† ¬†(this hides them on other plans and allows easy half-toning) Linked CAD files belong on the LINKS_CAD workset. (allows easy master visibility control). Egress distance railings belong on the Code Compliance workset¬† (hides them on all other plans) Anything you model for renderings which you won‚Äôt want in the CDs belongs on the Rendering workset¬† (hide on plans etc) Thin floors which are added for finish tagging belong on the Floor Finishes workset¬† (this hides them on other plans) If you really absolutely need multiple copies of a plan floating around in the model (which I find questionable), please crop down at least one set of plans so the primary scheme is obvious to teammates.¬† I can‚Äôt tell you how many times I get a junior designer asking me for help and we are both completely lost when we open the model, because it looks like a bomb exploded‚Ä¶¬†¬† that isn‚Äôt efficient for any of us. These items don‚Äôt take much¬† (or any) time to do the ‚Äúcorrect‚Äù way. ¬†Being in a rush to do things might save you 5 minutes today, but will cost your teammate 10 minutes tomorrow. Don‚Äôt be shortsighted.¬† Thanks for listening.

title: I Know What You Did Last Model: Duplicate Levels
content: This month we continue our scary story series about¬†mistakes in Revit¬† from which it is very difficult and costly to recover if not addressed early. Link to first scary story Imagine that you do not see any levels in any vertical view (section or elevation).¬†This usually happens early in the project. You check visibility graphics and the workset for levels and grids is on, but still cannot see levels in the view. Resist the temptation to draw levels in any view where you cannot see all other levels! There is a very high chance that in this case you will end up with more than one level at the same elevation, and this can lead to a very messy project where some elements are hosted by one level, and other are hosted by other overlapping level. Your walls, rooms and schedules are not to be trusted after that! Fortunately, there is a quick and easy way to check and manage levels using Perkins+Will Levels tool. You can even resize your levels, and import and export from Excel. Ok, you say, but I still want to see the levels in my vertical views. The levels may not be visible because levels are finite planes and your vertical views simply do not cross them. Here is what you do: Uncrop your vertical view to make sure that the levels are not above or below cropping region Verify that the vertical views (elevations) are close enoupg to the building footprint so the elevation clipping plane reaches just behind the wall if you still do not see the levels, unclip the view temporarily to see levels, select all levels and Maximize 3D Extents. It will expand levels to the¬†extents of your model geometry.¬†Do not forget to clip views back, unclipped views cause Revit performance deterioration. Alternatively to unclipping the views, you can simply create the new temporary level,select it, then select all levels and maximize their 3D extents. Now delete temporary level and any view it has created. This techique works in any version of Revit, but the recording below was done in Revit 2019, where you can actually see the levels in 3D view. Wouldn‚Äôt it be nice to be able to see grids , rooms and reference planes in 3D too? Maybe in future versions‚Ä¶

title: Navigate your PDF set at light speeds w/ Bluebeam

author.name: Nick Cameron
author.description: American trucker who has been featured on the History channel reality television series Ice Road Truckers and its spinoff series IRT: Deadliest Roads.

content: Did you know that you can create hyperlinks in your documents using Bluebeam?¬† ¬†Here is how to do it so you can navigate your information much faster when in PDF form, just like you can in Revit. This has help us navigate the set a lot faster without flipping through the sheet numbers, you simply click on the call outs or section marks and with one click it takes you to the correct view, from there you can review, make comments, etc. 1. From the file menu; Click on ‚ÄúBatch‚Äù> link > new 2. Once Batch link window is open;¬†¬†go to ‚Äúadd files‚Äù and browse to your folder (the easiest way is to add one compile file per discipline). >¬†Click next 3. The window shown below should open, here is where you will tell the program how to create hyperlinks. If your files are name with the sheet number you can use search by¬† file name, otherwise use page region, click on select and draw a window around the sheet number as shown below. 4. After you select page region, the following window should open and you should see the sheet numbers on the preview. 5. Click on generate; this should create a list with all the sheet numbers, if it doesn‚Äôt you will need to create a new search. 6. If you see all the sheets listed on the screen,¬† then you can click run at the bottom on the screen. 7. Now you should have an interactive document that will allow you to jump between plans, sections, elevations, etc.

title: Coordinating in VR ‚Äì Navisworks Style

author.name: Nick Cameron
author.description: American trucker who has been featured on the History channel reality television series Ice Road Truckers and its spinoff series IRT: Deadliest Roads.

content: Collaborative BIM projects need coordinating and while Naviswork is a great tool for automating element clashes towards the end of detailed design and construction, during design, when things are more fluid, it is mostly used to highlight issues by visual inspection and walking the model. Typically this process is part of a coordination cycle where clash viewpoints are saved and compiled into a report that is circulated prior to a regular coordination meeting. While this has been successful, it does take time in federating models from Revit exports then identifying and marking up coordination issues. We have been incorporating VR into the design process for some time but coordination attempts with FBX exports and app markup tools have seemed difficult and cumbersome to track. InsiteVR recently provided a new software release that incorporates some of the workflows that we would associate with Navisworks, which sounded quite exciting. An initial upside was being able to export natively from Revit to InsiteVR and being able to walk/teleport the model in Vive was really intuative. Issues at real scale seemed easy to detect and could be labelled as a text bubble via voice recognition. You press a button, you say your comment out loud, the VR headset records it, and the app will transcribe it into text that you can attach to the elements in question ‚Äì it‚Äôs almost like having your own Siri or Alexa in your BIM model to record your comments. These labels are automatically saved as viewpoints and can be navigated to simply by selecting as you would any saved view. After ‚Äúannotating‚Äù a series of issues an invite was sent from within the hosting VR session to the project leader who joined and appeared as an avatar in the same model to review and confirm the issues were in fact issues. He was really impressed by the speed of both identifying and recording issues.¬†We were walking the model via our standard office Vive set up and Ocullus Go but the same workflow can be shared across multiple VR devices or even laptops simply with a wifi connection and the InsiteVR app. This is especially useful for this project as one of our design partners is based in Italy. ‚Äì Powerful Stuff ! We wanted to introduce VR into the design coordination meeting which was happening the following day but felt some 2D output to form an agenda and provide some continuity between the tried and tested Navis workflows would help engage the team. This is where the App really shines. Once the clashes are identified and annotated, a PDF report can be instantly produced that comprises of a saved viewpoint, an automatic mark up around the area where the annotation was placed, a comment based on the identified issue, timestamp and author comment. The report was tabled at the coordination meeting as an introductory discussion point and the relevant parties then opened the model in VR and discussed each issue by clicking on the saved annotation which teleported directly to the issue in question.¬†The project is at technical design stage and those present were MEP, Structure, Main Contractor along with ourselves as Design Lead. Feedback received was that it was an invaluable tool and the team commented that some of the issues discovered by walking the model at real scale may not have been identified in Navisworks during visual inspection. The contractor in particular was a key advocate and has asked for us to take the set up to their offices so that they can demonstrate the process to their own supply chain. We provided additional feedback to InsiteVR requesting tool enhancements that will support this workflow such as custom reports / sectioning / layer control and transparency. The turnaround has been good, with the next release already incorporating the ability to turn off layers/categories and we hope more of the features requested will make it into upcoming releases. Overall it was a very successful pilot, that simplified what the team consider a time consuming and often difficult process, especially if the team aren‚Äôt that familiar with Navisworks. It also really helped drive project team coordination communication and we plan to utilise this workflow on other collaborative projects at the appropriate time durign the design programme. Click below for a VR Video feedback/interview discussion we had with the developer following the coordination meeting. You Tube ‚Äì Interview/Feedback Discussion

title: High End Interior Scanning
content: The digital practice group got our hands on a matterport camera that the firm owns and gave it a test drive.¬† ¬†This device scans and photographs spaces which then builds a 3d model online in the matterport¬†cloud for you or your clients to navigate.¬† ¬†This is not a quick process and there are many difficulties with lighting and glazing that cause the app to have difficulty aligning views to create the 3d model.¬† ¬†Once you do get the hang of it though it produces some high-end imagery and what they call a 3d dollhouse view online of the space you have scanned.¬† ¬†The example tour below of the Chicago office used a $4k camera, took about 8-10 hours to capture and edit online.¬† ¬†However, the quality of the space and that unique perspective of multiple floors is something you can‚Äôt get anywhere else. The final product is web-based and can be viewed through their website, embedded on another website (like right here on Pulse), viewed on a mobile device‚Äôs web browser, in their matterport VR app or with a full VR headset using the link.¬† ¬†You can create tour¬†walkthrough animations, embed information and other web content, as well as link¬†standard 360 images to the tour for outdoor space.

title: DC‚Äôs VR Roadshow: Making VR Sticky‚Ä¶
content: Thank you to Perkins+Will‚Äôs Los Angelous office for being our ‚ÄúVR Roadshow‚Äù guinea pig! Special thanks to Dean Demko for orchestrating the effort internally. This ‚Äúroadshow‚Äù insists on a minumum of a hour lunch and learn, followed by a happy hour starting at 4:30 and ending around midnight (or until there was no one else to talk to in the office). With the help of Dean‚Äôs efforts, both events proved highly attended. Woot Woot! Thank you good Sir! VR Roadshow??? Tell me more üôÇ Selling Virtual Realitys value in the design industry should¬† seemingly be effortless, as its relevance has almost unamiously been deemed obvious. If you are inclined to agree with that statement, can you also confirm your most recent projects have utilized Virtual Reality? The poll noted within the animation below has been given to audiences across the country‚Ä¶ Mind playing along and keeping your hand raised as it goes from question 1 to 4? Perhaps you are of the few who have their hand still up upon the completion of the poll‚Ä¶ Alas, I would argue you are of the few‚Ä¶ Why is it that we can agree that the ability to walk our designs as they evolve would be super advantageous, but when given the tools and workflows that allow for such inovation, we shy away? Our roadshow reminds you of the possibilities of vitual reality beyond that of an add service. It hopes to help spark an idea or two specific to an active project of your own as to how VR could supplement time consuming and costly efforts with potentially more practical solutions. The image below notes VRs applicability in all phases within the design process. If uncclear on any of the bullets within the mindmap graphic above, know that our presentation addresses most of them‚Ä¶ The impetous for DC to bring our roadshow to LA occured when they feared they might be missing out in how Virtual Reality could assist them in their everyday‚Ä¶ Not to mention, any opportunity for me (Justin Benjamin ‚Äì Presenter) to talk, is an opportunity not wasted üòâ The images shared below were taken during our efforts in LA. If interested in having this VR Roadshow go to your office, have your local Design Applications Manager or Operations Director reach out to Justin Benjamin ( Justin.Benjamin@perkinswill.com ). Friendly FYI ‚Äì¬† I will be presenting on this topic via a webinar hosted by NVIDIA on Wednesday, July 18 For more information, click the link: https://info.nvidia.com/perkins-will-aec-reg-page.html

title: I Know What You Did Last Model: 20 Miles Warning
content: Perhaps all of you have heard about Revit best practices. We emphasize them in training, promote them while working with teams, and document them in our microKnowledge site . But occasionally we see mistakes from which it is very difficult and costly to recover if they are not caught immediately.¬† Even experienced Revit users are not always aware of these dangers, and they can cause serious problems with our models. It does not happen very often, but when it happens, it means Revit disaster, and recovery/mitigation effort can add up to many additional hours of work for the life of the project In this new recurring topic we will tell you Revit horror stories which happened in a galaxy far away on some projects, so we can prevent future Revit disasters in PW projects. One of the worst case scenarios for a Revit project is when you link a dwg file (often a survey) and see the following message Ohh how tempting is it to click OK, which Autodesk made a default choice!¬†DO NOT click OK!¬†Click Cancel! Your project will be in serious trouble and the Whitewalkers will come after you if you click OK! It is not possible to fully fix the problems associated with this issue if you click OK and continue to work on the project. Workarounds will add at least 30% to your production time, and your model will not be reliable and will not be fit for use as a deliverable. This is pretty much a doomsday scenario‚Ä¶ Here is more technical explanation from Autodesk There are many ways you can prevent this disaster, mostly by cleaning up the DWG file before you link them. Here are some of them. But remember the whitewalkers and ask a member of Digital Practice for help if you are not sure.

title: Sharpen Your Tools: Occupancy Heatmap
content: We are continuing to showcase tools created by P+W staff in response to project challenges. Adam Hamilton, the Design Application Manager in our Minneapolis office has created an occupancy heatmap tool which was initially requested for a Higher Education team. Here is his story. OccupancyHeatMap is a Dynamo script that was created at the request of one of our Higher-Ed teams to validate the Room Layout against a ‚ÄòDay-in-the-life‚Äô document supplied by the Client‚Äôs Dean. The Excel Document was a day-by-day, hour-by-hour grid with which classrooms would be needed. The intent was to get good coverage across the floor plate and in stacking and identify any areas that had gaps in occupancy. Input from the client The tool reads from an Excel spreasheet (class schedule) supplied by the Client‚Äôs Dean. This document has days of the week and time of day and the rooms information.¬† Dynamo can read the Excel spreadsheet and produce hourly colored heatmap in the plan. The Tool Using the graphic sliders you can dynamically change the time of day or the day of the week. Set the Dynamo mode to Automatic and as these values are modified you can watch the plan, or a sheet with multiple floor plans, change Auto-magically. The design team was able to visualize the change in occupancy over the course of the day and week and fine tune the floor plate as necessary. This example is tailored closely to this projects supplied data but could be adapted to be more flexible with the data or output.¬†Many similar projects can take advantage of this workflow and the tool to better engage the client.

title: Sketchup 2018
content: As a new licensing model by Trimble, the makers of SketchUp, we need to transition to only utilizing the 2018 version of SketchUp.¬† ¬†We have a grace period of the month of July to still utilize the 2017 version.¬† ¬†You will find the newest version on computational nodes now.¬† ¬†You will also see the install available for you to self-install from the software center on your own laptop.¬† ¬†At the end of July, we will force any existing installs to upgrade to the newest version.¬† ¬†The newest version is more stable with some small new features but this is fundamentally the exact same product. This version comes along with a newer version of Vray¬†which can be utilized with our firmwide render farm through the deadline application.¬† ¬†If you utilize¬†any unique addins for SketchUp¬†please verify if you will have to purchase or reinstall anything with the newest version of SketchUp.¬† ¬†If you have any questions about installation or functionality please reach out to your local GTS and Design Application Manager with those questions.¬† ¬†We also have some resources on Lynda.com if you are looking to improve your skills with SketchUp or any associated program like Enscape. At the end of July SketchUp 2017 will no longer work and you will have to be using 2018.¬† ¬†Make every attempt to transition prior to the licensing deadline so you don‚Äôt have any interruption¬†in the workflow. To self-install¬†open Software center through your start menu or the pwitter¬†icon, then select the package and on the next screen click ‚Äòinstall‚Äô.

title: Immersive Enterprise Conference in Boston
content: The VRX2018 Immersive Enterprise Conference is a conference that brings together global business leaders from AEC, Automotive, Manufacturing, Engineering, Retail, Healthcare and more, it is purpose built for VR/AR professionals to network and share industry insights on how to drive VR & AR adoption across the enterprise. Leaders from the most pioneering enterprises and tech companies shared and discussed where VR & AR content and technology are having a real impact on training, design, worker collaboration and sales & marketing. I was also excited to learn the latest market insights from top analysts and investors on where the opportunities are now‚Ä¶and what‚Äôs coming next. Our AEC Panel had a mixed representation from all three sides of the AEC industry. Three of us represented the design side, myself (Perkins+Will), Cerise Marcela (Gensler) and the moderator, Nirva Fereshetian (CBT), were all from the design side of the AEC industry. Kurt Maldovan (Jacob) represented the Engineering side, and Hal Jones (Skanska) represented the construction side. Our topic was to share how VR has revolutionized the AEC industry. We began the talk by sharing our own background and how we end up working with VR and AR within our own companies. There were many similarities in our experience of working through the early days of VR and CAVE environment, but eventually giving up on the early VR/AR efforts due to the high cost and complexities that made early VR unaffordable and unscalable for all projects. It wasn‚Äôt until two and a half years ago, when Google cardboard and Oculus Rift were introduced to the world, did we see a renewed interest in the VR/AR efforts within our AEC firms. With the availability of these affordable VR headsets and software, plus the change in the consumer culture‚Äôs interest in VR/AR that the AEC industry was able to see a fundamental shift in the use of VR and AR across our enterprise. For Designers and Architects, VR and AR are a natural next gen design tool for our design team. What better way to communicate the unbuilt design work than to get into the design model virtually and experience the space immersively. Instead of explaining the drawings in plans, elevations and sections, and asking our clients to imagine how the double height lobby would feel like, why not let them walk through the space and experience the scale of the space themselves. Instead of looking at the space from a few set angles chosen for rendering purpose, why not dynamically walk through the model and conduct design review in realtime. We are seeing VR being used in all different stages. In early design stage, VR is used for spatial understanding and master planning. In Design Development phase, VR is used for furniture and equipment layout, material and lighting study and virtual mockup, and in construction development phase, VR is used for coordination with consultants and contractors. As a result of incorporating VR and AR into our design process, we are seeing high client engagement rate using VR, high project team satisfaction using VR combined with realtime rendering technology, improved design review process, and faster decision making, and in turn smoother project completion. On the constuction side, Skanska has been integrating AR/MR in various phases from initial pursuit, through Preconstruction, and into Operations, as well as exploring the integration of AR/MR into facility management.¬† They have formed a central VDC group that is focused on developing their XR capability, Their primary focus are in three areas, General design and constructability review , Helping project stakeholders make better decisions related to cost during estimating and Virtual Room Mockups to enhance or replace physical mockup s. On the Engineering side, Jacob is more or less using VR the same ways as the designers have. They are also exploring the AR potential of ‚Äúsee what I see‚Äù or phone a friend feature which is huge for remote site visits or assistance.¬† Being able to record the physical space and the potential design allows not only real time visualization, but review by others who can‚Äôt visit a site.¬† Pulling up data whether it be passive (like an O&M manual) or active (from sensors) gives a great future opportunity for new ways of operating and maintaining facilities. As for common challenges, we all agreed that having devices that are standalone and wireless will certainly improve VR adoption rate, just as the introduction of ‚Äúone-click‚Äù software has already helped make VR a common tool that the designers can use to instantaneously get into the VR realm. Our AEC panel was a refreshing talk in the technology focused conference, where an earlier speaker from Oculus actually said that ‚ÄúArchitects are still drawing on paper‚Äù. Many people came up to me aftewards, and thanked me for the talk and mentioned that even though they don‚Äôt work with Architects, they really learned a lot about how advanced the AEC industry is in using VR technology!

title: Dispatch from BIM Forum 2016

author.name: Nick Cameron
author.description: American trucker who has been featured on the History channel reality television series Ice Road Truckers and its spinoff series IRT: Deadliest Roads.

content:
Below are Doug Green‚Äôs notes from the BIM Forum conference which
took place April 20-21st 2016 in Minneapolis. The BIM Forum‚Äôs
mission is to facilitate and accelerate the adoption of modeling in
the AEC industry. If you have any additional questions or comments
please leave them below and we can get the answer. James Vandezande from HOK was the conference co-chair. Theme throughout ‚Äì do what adds value to the project and process ‚Äì ‚ÄúIs the juice worth the squeeze?‚Äù University of Ohio has a ‚ÄúBuckeye BIM Initiative‚Äù that might be interesting to look at. The Elliott Bay Seawall project in Seattle was presented by Josh Rogers from Mortenson. ¬†They applied VDC from vertical to horizontal, 4D to show sequencing on a very restricted job site. ¬†Made the decision of what BIM tools to use after analyzing the project and project risks. There is no such thing as an LOD (whether level of development or level of detail ‚Äì see later notes) for an entire model. ¬†The model is always a mixture of various LODs. ‚ÄúPerfection is not attainable . . . but if we chase perfection we can attain excellence.‚Äù ¬†Vince Lombardi. The LOD Specification will be published for comment on June 20, 2016. Comment period will run into August 2016. ¬†It will be a downloadable document and intended as suitable for all project delivery types. ¬†The LOD Specification is a ‚Äúdictionary‚Äù and the project and delivery method is the ‚Äústory‚Äù. HITT Construction did a presentation on the use of drones. ¬†Safety and planning are huge issues. ¬†One of their drones had a battery that went out and the drone crashed. ¬†To avoid injury, the fly zone needs to anticipate where the drone would fall if something happens to avoid injury. ¬†A pilot license is no longer needed, but one does need the FAA exemption which takes time (seems to be several months). ¬†Insurance runs about $1500. Holder Construction and others during the course of the conference discussed laser scanning. ¬†The most significant issue is the internal issue: who on the staff actually does the scanning? ¬†Do you train and have on staff scan specialists, or do you have the field teams do the scanning? ¬†Significant issue to set up on a coordinate system, and file size is an issue. ¬†Accuracy was discussed by several, not as accurate as one would think. ¬†And buildings move so even if accurate at one point in time, may no longer be accurate later. Scans should be interpreted, but never imported into a model. There is often a disconnect between the model and the construction. It is much better to go from 3D to 2D for drawings. There was a very interesting ‚ÄúBIMForum Lego Experience‚Äù which recreated the challenges of a team constructing a building. You have to ‚Äúcheat‚Äù software to achieve field reality. Buildings are ‚Äúliving breathing‚Äù and move and change, software does not. ¬†A building is a ‚Äúbody in motion‚Äù. Design modeling and construction modeling are very different things. There is no such thing as a zero-clash model. Version 2 of the ConsensusDocs BIM Addendum was discussed. ¬†For several reasons I do not recommend its use. The document now adds a ‚ÄúLevel of Granularity‚Äù description which deals with dimensional accuracy, in addition to ‚ÄúLevel of Detail‚Äù (the richness of the detail) and ‚ÄúLevel of Development‚Äù (the completeness of the detail). A more detailed review by both legal and digital practice is probably a good idea to understand this document in more detail. ¬†But of concern, it replaces the definition of ‚ÄúContract Document‚Äù in the underlying agreement, has ‚Äúcheck the box‚Äù provisions to over-ride the 2D documents, automatically adopts the LOD Specification, and in my view generally has too many ‚Äútraps for the unwary‚Äù for less sophisticated adopters, who I fear could find themselves in pretty deep water without knowing what they are getting into. I believe it is a document developed by sincere and passionate advocates for pushing the industry to what they consider a better place, but it may not be connected with current industry reality. The document was called a ‚Äúconstruction contract‚Äù and the ‚Äúfirst in the U.S.‚Äù It requires ‚Äútech protect‚Äù insurance policies (we are exploring but do not have and many firms do not ‚Äì no uniformity of coverage and questionable cost/benefit), contemplates the model actually running the building, operates from the standpoint of cutting edge things that are being done, but not commonly. RFI‚Äôs processed in the model. O & M manuals are embedded in the model. A new section on commissioning and turnover, BIM used for training the operations and maintenance staff, and on and on. Expands the design phase considerably, including constructability, life cycle analysis, VE, shop and fabrication modeling, tolerance requirements for digital fabrication, sustainability analysis, record model, conformed design model. It is unclear who tracks changes, or how changes are tracked. Retooled the insurance and BIM IP rights. There was a presentation regarding the use of the National BIM Standard put out by the BuildingSMART Alliance. ¬†The National BIM Standard apparently tracks the various BIM Guidelines that different organizations are using. A lack of consistency was noted in that regard. All of them describe BIM deliverables. The United Kingdom mandates that public projects over ¬£85 million must have BIM. The National BIM Standard is at version 3, there is a relatively small group of people involved and has reference standards. Version 3 includes new content: ¬†‚ÄúPractical BIM Contract Requirements‚Äù, a BIM Planning Guide for Owners, a Project Execution Planning Guide, etc. ¬†Probably worth getting a copy. Who in the firm is tracking this? Pat O‚ÄôConnor and another presented on the AIA Digital Practice Documents. Making the point that the normal disclaimer inhibits the use of a BIM and the expressed desire to get around that. The AIA documents set out a regime within which to share models. The E203 is the contractual framework, the G201 is the digital data protocol form, and the G201 is the BIM protocol for sharing models. The E203 has a ‚Äúcheck the box‚Äù which allows either a selection of the standard type of disclaimer, or that the parties want to share models and will agree on the protocols and rules of engagement in the G202. The G202 is the broad stroke contractual standard and framework on how to share and use BIM. Models carry a lot of information that we do not even know is in the BIM. ¬†For example we can use a placeholder to indicate a sliding door but not the exact kind of door. ¬†So that is the general reason for a disclaimer approach, but a disclaimer essentially throws out the baby with the bathwater. The G202 says parties can only rely on what one says parties can rely on the BIM for. ¬†That‚Äôs where the LOD scheme comes in. ¬†That is, even if what is in the model appears to be a Level 400 if you say others can only rely on it for LOD 200 that‚Äôs all the parties can depend on. ¬†Any other reliance is at a party‚Äôs own risk. The document sets out four steps that are fairly common in BIM development: Conceptual, Generic Placeholders, Specific Assemblies and then Details (note: the G202 does not use those terms, rather uses ‚ÄúConceptual Design, Criteria Development, Detailed Design, Implementation Drawings‚Äù). ¬†This does not correspond to the design phases. The G202 includes definitions of the various LODs (100, 200 etc.). LOD 500 is field verification. Of interest, there is a distinction between a ‚ÄúLevel of Detail‚Äù and a ‚ÄúLevel of Development‚Äù. ¬†A Level of Detail is what it looks like. ¬†A Level of Development is how much it has been thought through. ¬†So even if it is a Level of Detail 400, if you say you can only rely on it for a Level of Development 200, that‚Äôs all. Especially note that deliverable models will have various levels of detail and development. During the Q & A sessions for the ConsensusDocs, National BIM Standard and the AIA Digital Practice documents, some interesting questions and points were made. ¬†One person asked whether setting standards was just setting a level of mediocrity? ¬†It was quickly pointed out that the industry has worked with standard for decades with no ill effect. ¬†It was noted that the implementation of BIM in the U.S. has not really been very good, and that the rest of the world outside the U.S. is ramping up much more quickly. A representative from Gilbane discussed scanning, and said they use the RFI to simply document the discussion and decision that has already been completed, to memorialize it rather than using the RFI as the mechanism for asking the question, which I thought was an interesting approach. The Fall BIM Forum conference will be October 17 ‚Äì 19, 2016, in Atlanta. ¬†The theme is ‚ÄúWhat is the new standard for professional coordination? ¬†Examining the changing standard of care for designers, contractors and owners.‚Äù

title: Virtually Tour our newest offices of Schmidt Hammer Lassen
content: As with many of our offices before, we have put together a virtual walkthrough of the Denmark offices.¬† ¬†We use a newer Ricoh Theta V camera (cost is about¬† $425) to shoot the images.¬† ¬†The camera is put on a standard tripod.¬† The camera is controlled by a theta app on your mobile device.¬† ¬†Once all the pictures are taken we use the web-based RoundMe application to host the pictures and create the interactivity.¬† ¬†There are other apps that do this like Kolor.¬† ¬†One thing to look for is a hotspot¬†on the screen that allows you to ‚Äòjump‚Äô forward or backward to different locations.¬† ¬†Another ability is to embed hotspots of information (including text and/or pictures) into any scene.¬† ¬† These tours took about 45 minutes each to shoot and put together on the website.
