title: Snippets: Libraries of Common Functions for Grasshopper
content: Jens Buch-Dohrmann presented his collection of Snippets, a set of useful functions for Grasshopper, on the last firmwide computational design call (video here ).¬† Since then others have run with the idea, creating Snippets from pieces of their own Grasshopper workflows. This article will show you what they are, what they can do, and how to install them. What are Snippets? Snippets are user-created collections of Grasshopper nodes connected together to create a common function. These functions are distributed as a Grasshopper plugin and when installed they appear as buttons in their own tab, just like any other plugin. Current SHL Snippets ContextPeople MapperTree MapperLandscape from Curves Create GeometryBaluster railingexperimental spiral staircaseGlass¬†railingStairs toolCreate Grasshopper layersdecks from curvesdecks from curves (advanced)Rounded glass fa√ßadeWalls w. openings from curvesWindows from curves RenderRender Sun StudyRender Sun Study w. LayersCapture views w. layersRender viewsRender Views w. LayersRender Views w. SunMaterial Quick-Mapper SHL Green BIMRadiation AnalysisSunlight Hour Analysis ScriptWind Rose ToolsAdvanced area toolCalculate areaDynamic Clipping PlaneExport cameras to 3ds MaxExport layers to DWGLaser-cut¬†sheets from¬†polysurfaces¬†(nest)Make blocks uniqueSuper offsetextrude surfacesRetrieve bottom surface of solid How do I use Snippets? When a Snippet is selected, the nodes that comprise it are placed on your Grasshopper canvas, already connected together. It is good practice for Snippet creators to¬†include text notes explaining the inputs, outputs, and controls. Snippet placed on the Grasshopper canvas, click to enlarge How do I install Snippets? Grasshopper¬†plugins come in two file formats, Libraries (.rfa) and User Objects (.ghuser).¬† Snippets are created as User Objects, where each function is a separate file. To install a User Object move it to¬†C:\Users\<UserName>\AppData\Roaming\Grasshopper\UserObjects\. Restart Rhino. But before you start copying files, read below to see how we‚Äôve automated this process for easy installation. Snippet User Object Files One additional thing to consider in distribution; Snippets can contain nodes from other Grasshopper plugins, which means those plugins need¬†to be installed for the Snippet to work. A script (Install_GH_Plugins.ps1) is included with each Snippet collection that copies the UserObjects, along with all required plugins, to the correct location. Consult the accompanying readme file for detailed instructions. Snippet Distribution Files: Installer Script, Readme, and Plugins folder containing Snippets and Required Plugins. We currently have two Snippet collections: SHL Snippets: O:\SHL\BIM\24 Grasshopper\01 Grasshopper distribution folder\SHL_Snippets\ Detailed PDF documentation included. Video Tutorials https://www.useloom.com/my-videos/SNIPPETS%20Tutorials Process Lab Snippets: \\perkinswill.net\PWresources\Research\Process_Lab\Grasshopper Snippets\DesignSpaceConstruction\ How do I make my own Snippets? Snippets are the product of a plugin called Metahopper that, as the name implies, provides Grasshopper workflow tools. Here is a video showing some of its features ( https://vimeo.com/176764658 ).¬† Metahopper can be found here (S:\_Firmwide\Rhino-Grasshopper\Plugins\Metahopper\) or here ( https://www.food4rhino.com/app/metahopper ) Once you have Metahopper installed follow these steps to create your own Snippets: Select the nodes on your Grasshopper canvas that you would like to save as a Snippet. Go to the Metahopper drop down and select ‚ÄòSave Snippet.‚Äô Set the Snippet parameters in the pop-up. ‚ÄòCategory‚Äô will be the name of the tab created in Grasshopper. ‚ÄòSub-Category‚Äô will be the group within the tab. Press ‚ÄòOK‚Äô A new tab and group will be created if you used a ‚ÄòCategory‚Äô or ‚ÄòSub-Category‚Äô that didn‚Äôt already exist. A new .ghuser file for the Snippet will be created in the C:\Users\<UserName>\AppData\Roaming\Grasshopper\UserObjects\ folder. Share your Snippets with everyone. That‚Äôs it! If you would like additional information or assistance using of making Snippets contact your local Design Application Manager or Luc Deckinga , Digital Practice Manager for Computational Design.

title: Put that 360 image in your plan

author.name: Nick Cameron
author.description: American trucker who has been featured on the History channel reality television series Ice Road Truckers and its spinoff series IRT: Deadliest Roads.

content: Did you know that you can embed a 360 image into your floorplan using Bluebeam?¬† ¬†We did that for an existing high school project to better explain the existing conditions with the team, client, and contractor. For Champaign Cental High School, we needed to a way to organize hundreds of 360 images we captured while surverying the existing building. The 360 images were critical in understanding and documenting the renovation and new construction efforts.¬† The school was over 160,000 SF, comprised of the original 1934 building, with two addtions added in 1954 and 1997. Digging through the windows folder to find and view the correct image was becoming a hassle. We needed a visual, and intuiive way, to organize the 360 images. We found that Bluebeam allowed us to embed panorama images over the existing floor plan. By attaching to markup object, we could now click on specific rooms, and a pop-up would allowing us to zoom and pan around the image using the bluebeams built-in viewer. This has added a lot of value to our project, not only as a time saver, but as a way to share and discuss with our design team, client, and contractor. Bonus Tip: We rigged a markerboard to the camera tripod, and used it to identify the Room# of where the Pano was taken. Create folder Add file Add comment

title: Digital Execution Plans
content: After some informal feedback, we found that very few projects firmwide were creating a BIM Execution Plan let alone using it as a guide to complete their project.¬†¬† Our Digital Practice group took a look at what was impacting such a low percentage of projects taking advantage of what has proven to keep teams out of problems and extra effort in the production and execution of the work.¬†¬† We found that the current landscape of BIM Execution Plans was too complex and provide no value during the project work.¬†¬† To that end, a small group went about simplify a template for people to start from and centering it out of making the simple decision that aligns the entire team to execute the project objectives.¬†¬† We have done this by removing extraneous content and simplifying what information you will include that will be most beneficial for the team. Every project should take a few minutes to put this information together as part of their project work plan to complement the schedule and staffing for each project‚Äôs plan.¬† ¬†We have put together a new modular template that works for any project size and type.¬† ¬†This has been made simpler to edit and can be found in your word templates once your office has been given the overview. You can use this template as a basis to talk to your client about the goals for BIM and the scope of digital deliverables.¬† ¬†It should be simple enough to refer back to by the team over the course of the project to keep the team on the right path and to onboard new team members. The baseline template includes sections on; contacts, goals, collaboration procedures, file exchange, model plan, level of development, and right of reliance.¬† ¬†We then provided modules to supplement that baseline to cover topics like; Visualization and VR, QA and QC, Interiors, Computational Design, Design by Making, Data Management, PW and Associate architects, and Construction contract administration. Every project has a scope defined by what we need to deliver.¬† ¬†With that scope, we put together a team and define the schedule.¬† ¬†Please make every effort to define how the work is going to be completed in your Digital Execution Plan.

title: Pixels and Printing

author.name: Nick Cameron
author.description: American trucker who has been featured on the History channel reality television series Ice Road Truckers and its spinoff series IRT: Deadliest Roads.

content: We have been fielding some requests and questions about our renderings and print sizes in the Denver office.¬†Ultimately this can be a very confusing topic and the best practice is to ask your client who the printing company is that will be doing the actual printing and get their contact information. Printers will be able to give us the exact sizes we need based on their equipment to print at a certain size.¬†In a recent case here in Denver, we needed to print a 24 foot by 13 foot job sign that in the end didn‚Äôt need to be 20,000 or 30,000 pixels wide. After working the the printer, we could easily get by with just a 3,500 pixel wide image. Thanks to some fine people on the Vray Forums, I was able to track down a handy¬† chart to help clarify the size requirements for print. The cells outlined in red are the sweet spot for a print of that size. Create folder Add file Add comment

title: Unreal Engine ‚Äì Tips, Tricks & Workflow
content: Learn how to move your project into Epic Game‚Äôs Unreal Engine. Two of Perkins+Will‚Äôs own share their workflow along with tips and tricks for using Unreal on projects. Whether you are new to Unreal or looking to improve your game engine skills on projects these documents will help. In the Denver office Scott Schroeder reveals his workflow to bring their projects, including large stadiums into Unreal Engine 4 using Datasmtih. Simon Chavez out of our Seattle office shares more than a dozen Datasmith tips & tricks he has used on many of his projects. If you find their content helpful please let them know. Unreal Engine 4 + Datasmith Workflow by Scott Schroeder Datasmith Tips & Tricks by Simon Chavez

title: Let‚Äôs Meet in VR
content:
When Virtual Reality (VR) was first introduced, it was really designed as a single person experience. Only one person can put the VR headset on, and only one person can experience that virtual world all by himself or herself. The only way others can share in that experience is by peeking into the VR headset and stream the VR content onto an external monitor. Even though we may see what the VR user is seeing on the monitor, we are technically not in the same virtual world with him/her. Earlier this year, many VR applications finally began to offer multi-user meeting services. Using the multi-user functionality, you now can have a true shared VR experience with others in the VR world. Host your meeting in VR, invite your project team to join in from anywhere in the world, and you can all review the project by walking through the project site virtually together! Just as the word ‚ÄúSkype‚Äù has become a common verb refering to meeting online, what would the new word for VR meeting be? Will you be using InsiteVR or IrisVR? Let‚Äôs take a closer look at two popular software applications that both offer multi-user VR meeting services, InsiteVR and Prospect 2.0 (from IrisVR). InsiteVR ( https://www.insitevr.com/) InsiteVR released their multi-user meeting feature in late 2017, followed by a series of¬†‚Äú Immersive Projects Showecase ‚Äù where designers offer free VR tours to their virtual project model. With InsiteVR, the one click meeting invite helps you start the VR meeting by sending a url link to your attendees. Through the link, participants can join in using any kind of headset (Vive, Rift or Mixed Reality headsets) or even without a headset by using the browser and a keyboard. Once you join the meeting, participants appear as floating headsets and pairs of controllers with their names on a label hovering over the top of the headset, the movement of the headset indicates which way that person is looking at, and the position of the headset hints at the height of the person. The controllers show where the user‚Äôs hands are pointing at. Our brain magically adjusts and helps us see the invisible person that‚Äôs behind the headset and its controllers. Next, add voice chat to the session, and we naturally start to chat and interact with our invisible teammates in the virtual world. Parkin Architects Ltd. took attendees through their model of the
Electrophysiology Procedure Room at St. Mary‚Äôs General Hospital in
Canada. Jeremiah Hawkins from Schimberg Group in Florida. He guided a group of 10 attendees through the model of the Mar Vista restaurant. In addition to the annotation tools that were already available in InsiteVR, new meeting functions were added to help facilitate the virtual meeting process,¬†such as ‚ÄúBroadcast‚Äù, ‚ÄúGather‚Äù and ‚ÄúGoTo‚Äù functions. The ‚ÄúBroadcast‚Äù function is perfect for fully guided tour that forces participants to always follow you. The ‚ÄúGather‚Äù function helps gather up all the participants to where you are located, so you can start the presentation or discussion with all the attendees looking at the same areas of the model as you are. The ‚ÄúGoTo‚Äù function teleports you to the location of a specific participants, in case you need to see the issue the participants is pointing at in the model. The ‚ÄúCapture meeting annotation to PDF‚Äù feature really helps to generate action items from your VR meeting. One important service that only InsiteVR provides is the ability to offer model navigation on mobile headsets such as Oculus Go. Using InsiteVR app on the Oculus store, you can join in the VR meeting using the brand new Oculus GO, a complete standalone headset that requires no wire, nor graphic PC to power it. This potentially could be the game changer, since the less obstacle there is in getting the user into VR, the more popular the VR tool will become. With InsiteVR‚Äôs 3 headset giveaway (1 samsung Odyssey and 2 Oculus Go) for each new account sign up, the offer is almost too good to give up! IrisVR ( https://irisvr.com/prospect) Prospect 2.0 from IrisVR also introduced the multi-user meeting feature late last month. Unlike InsiteVR where the project is cloud based, you will need to download the project file to open the file locally in the desktop app, but it works the same way with any headset and even without a headset, you can participate using a browser and keyboard (the avatar will wear sunglasses and has a keyboard instead of controllers). The avatars have rounded heads with headsets on and cone shaped body with floating hands holding the controllers. Each user has a different color avatar which helps you to differenciate the users without having to read their name tag. the user interface is nicely designed with easy to understand graphic icons. Our users were quick to adapt to the user interface and were able to sketch, annotate, measure, and change daylight setting with very minimum instruction. Prospect does have plugin for Revit, Sketchup and Rhino, so users of any of these software can easily jump into VR within a matter of minutes. Prospect works best with tethered headsets (HTC Vive, Oculus Rift and Mixed Reality headsets), it does not yet support mobile headset such as Oculus Go. As part of our firmwide multi-user VR meeting testing that I hosted last month, we held three separate sessions of multi-user meetings using Prospect. We invited users from all P+W offices to participate. Some office had the VR equipment setup and encouraged anyone interested to join in the VR meeting to try it out for themselves. Other offices had only 1 or 2 people join into the meeting. But we all met in the virtual model and had the chance to chat with each other and walk around the campus, tag the walls with our own graffitti annotations. and experimented all the fun tools on our tool palette. Some office do not have headsets available in their office, so they only joined in via a browser to follow the meeting. If you have missed the presentation in your office, please reach out to your local DA, and I would be happy to setup a VR meeting for you to try it out! Reach out to me if your office don‚Äôt have a headset, I can arrange for you to borrow one to try out as well. Here is a good anecdote on best use case for VR meeting. One of our project team in the New York office was in the midst of preparing a major client presentation that they were taking with them as they fly 3,000 miles to the client‚Äôs site, they jokingly said, wouldn‚Äôt it be nice to be able to meet on a regular basis with the client in VR, since they are so far awar? Our DA, Vina, responded, ‚Äúof course you can! Give me five minutes and I will get your project setup for you to try it in VR‚Äù.¬† In less than 5 minutes, we had the two designers put on the VR headsets at the same time in the same room and they both walked around inside the model for an interactive review session. The team is excited for the potential of how this technology can help them keep their client engaged more frequently without requiring them to travel so often!

title: Rhino 6 and Grasshopper 1: What You Need To Know
content: Rhino 6 Rhino version 5 was released in 2012, but the folks at McNeel haven‚Äôt been sitting on their laurels in the intervening years. They‚Äôve made significant changes under the hood and added a plethora of new, useful features. This is a primer on how we will be deploying it at Perkins+Will, some of the most useful new features, and links to more information on McNeel‚Äôs website & around the web. Grasshopper 1.0 You read that right, version one. Believe it or not, this is the first official release of Grasshopper. It first appeared in 2007 and has spent the last 10 years as beta software, but a dedicated community of users developed plugins that kept it constantly evolving and improving. With its official release, Grasshopper is now included in the main Rhino install, rather than as a separate plugin. Otherwise, it feels comfortably familiar. Anyone who used the beta version will feel instantly at home. See below for some of the major changes. Perkins+Will Rhino/Grasshopper Deployment: No issues found so far in test files upgraded from Rhino v5 to v6 or Grasshopper files from beta to 1.0. Neither can ‚Äòback save‚Äô to earlier versions once upgraded. P+W‚Äôs computational nodes have advanced 3D graphics cards that can be utilized in Rhino. Yoga laptops do not have this capability, so this feature must be disabled by unchecking the ‚ÄòGPU Tesselation‚Äô box in the Rhino settings, shown in the image below. If you do not turn this off you will see flickering when panning or orbiting the view and some objects are not visible in some display modes. MSI laptops have graphics cards and should not experience this issue. Perkins+Will previously managed Grasshopper plugins in two separate locations, a ‚ÄòCommon Files‚Äô folder that contained the most common plugins, and made them available to all users of that machine, and a ‚ÄòUser‚Äô folder that contained any plugins installed by an individual user. If both locations contained the same plugin you were asked which you wanted to use every time you opened Grasshopper. Super annoying. We will discontinue putting plugins in the ‚ÄòCommon Files‚Äô folder, meaning users will need to manage their own plugins by doing the following: Get plugins from: www.food4rhino.com the P+W Grasshopper plugin location:¬†S:\_Firmwide\Rhino-Grasshopper\Plugins\ plugins included with a script you want to use Only load the plugins you are going to use. ¬†If you load them all UI tabs get very compressed and hard to read. Copy plugins that use the .gha file format to C:\Users\<UserName>\AppData\Roaming\Grasshopper\Libraries\ (most plugins are in this format) Copy plugins that use the .ghuser file format to: C:\Users\<UserName>\AppData\Roaming\Grasshopper\UserObjects\ (Ladybug and Honeybee use this format, but few others) Grasshopper users must include required plugins when distributing their scripts. Links to the Rhino 6 new features sections most relevant to us: Presentation Best Change:¬†‚ÄòViewCaptureToClipboard‚Äô is the screen capture we‚Äôve always wanted. Display Best Change: Out of the box display styles are much nicer Documentation Best Change: Make2D is better and available in Grasshopper Refinements All the micro-improvements that add up to a better user experience Grasshopper Changes Which Plugins work with the new Grasshopper? Here is the list of plugins that developers have confirmed work with Grasshopper for Rhino 6 Food4Rhino . Developers must individually confirm compatibility. Other plugins may work, or they may not. The popular plugins will likely be compatible soon if they aren‚Äôt already. Kangaroo physics engine Included This was one of the most popular plugins so they adopted it into the core Multi-threading being introduced gradually This means Grasshopper can take advantage of multiple processors simultaneously, increasing the speed of executing complex operations or working with large datasets. Only these components first , as a test. More to come later. Two-minute video in a soothing British voice explaining the visual cues on the Grasshopper nodes that indicate multi-threading capabilities. New Components: I don‚Äôt know what a ‚ÄòSplorph‚Äô is, but I want to find out. Make2D Symbol Display Bend Flow Maelstrom Splop Splorph Stretch Taper Twist Create folder Add file Add comment

title: Perkins+Will Dallas Office Virtual Tour
content: The new Dallas office virtual tour (below) used the Ricoh Theta V ($400) and the Cloud-based RoundMe app ($99/year) to put together this virtual tour.¬† If you haven‚Äôt used the roundme interface before, there are circles in each view that you can click on to navigate the tour.¬† There are also hotspots (symbols with an ‚Äúi‚Äù that allow you to learn about the building (customizable for each tour). ¬† There is also a ‚Ä¶ symbol in the upper right that can allow you to go to full screen model.¬† You can use the iOS app to view this information as well which lets you toggle between this current pano mode and a VR mode if you have a cardboard or VR glasses to use. The Dallas office plans to use this as an outward facing tool as well for marketing and recruiting and general knowledge of our space and our committment to Perkins+Will‚Äôs core values in ‚Äúwalking the talk‚Äù with regard to our sustainability initiatives.

title: Sharpen Your Tools: Keynote Manager and CTC Invisibility Advisor
content: In the last few weeks we have rolled out two very useful productivity enhancing tools. Keynote Manager standalone and plugin for Revit Many of you are familiar with Keynote Manager standalone , which allows you to edit keynote file in a collaborative and streamlined way. Depending on your¬† office policy and project needs, editing can be done using Keynote Manager, Excel and/or Notepad. Regardless of your office process we recommend as a minimum to open project keynote file in Keynote manager to check the structure and fix problems. For example,¬† KM¬† finds orphaned keynotes, and also detects and helps to resolve duplicates. If your office process allows multiple people to edit keynote file, they can now do it simultaneously, all changes are saved immediately, but if you make a mistake, there is always a backup here C:\Users\%Username%\Documents\Keynote Manager\Backups saved every 10 min.¬†You can easily add keynotes of every level, renumber them, change hierarchy, insert keynotes from another file or from master file(s). You can also add comments and links to individual keynotes, compare two different keynotes files, compare with backup, and establish master-child relationship between the files to create a subset from the master file. Search is easy ‚Äì with the search window and filters. Each new search is saved as a filter. Easy to convert all to keynotes to upper case, lower case, etc. And you can print visible keynotes , all keynotes or selected branches Keynote Manager Plus is a Revit plugin that in addition to editing keynote file (which may be restricted in your office or your project- please check)¬† offers many additional productivity enchancements. Here are some of them: Graphic indication that the keynote is used in the project and an ability to select all elements using this keynote or list them in the dialog box Additional predefined searches ‚Äì Used and Unused One click keynote adding. Keynote is applied using current keynote application method Find a keynote for selected object(s) Apply keynote to selected object(s) There is also a keynote watcher:¬† feature that monitors keynote sources for open Revit projects and notifies the user of changes and/or reloads the keynotes into Revit. For users who are working on the Revit file while another team member is working on the keynotes, this allows them to ensure that their keynote display is up to date at all times. Keep it closed unless nesessary, it takes resourcesNote- we do not use cloud. Another great tool that was added recently is Invisibility Advisor Did you know that Revit has almost 60 different ways to control object visibility? Even very exprerienced users may spend a lot of time figuring out visibility issues. Add to it that there may be more than one reason that something is not visible‚Ä¶ Invisibility advisor to the rescue! it helps Revit users to find elements that are not displaying properly and can identify the causes of invisibility as well as offer useful information and links to relevant knowledgebase articles for each issue. In many cases, Invisibility Advisor can automatically ‚Äòfix‚Äô the display of the elements depending on the reason. The process starts with selecting elements in question. View where you have visibility issues must be open, but you can also open views which show the elements in question and pick the element from there. as you open more views, you may need to hit refresh . If you cannot find the view where element is visible, you can select the element in the view you are troubleshooting from the invisibility advisor interface. Interface is modeless, which means that you can open and close view, and navigate outside of the tool without closing. Example the view on the left has following visibility issues: there are two banquettes where there supposed to be three stairs are not visible column is not visible Banquette Column Stair

title: How to Use P+W‚Äôs Render Farm
content: Swarm Comparison Demo from PW Digital Practice on Vimeo . Are you already benefiting from P+W‚Äôs render farms? If not, keep reading to learn how. Whether you choose to render in Revit, Rhino, SketchUp or 3ds Max the P+W render farms are accessible through the farm‚Äôs management software Deadline Monitor. The V-Ray rendering engine is also available at P+W on all four applications. Those designers already using P+W‚Äôs render farms are experiencing a performance boost for a range of visualization projects. How to Use the Render Farm with‚Ä¶ V-Ray for Revit. V-Ray for Rhino. V-Ray for SketchUp. V-Ray for 3ds Max. What If Deadline Monitor or V-Ray is Not Installed on My Machine? You may already have access to it on the computational nodes. If you have an MSI laptop or other laptop or workstation capable of producing visualization, then an install package should be available within Software Center (see first image below). The name of the install package is Deadline V-Ray Package (second image below). No V-Ray Licenses Available?! If this happens, please email Digital Practice . We are prepared to expand the number of licenses as the need increases. Unfortunately, the V-Ray license server software provides no log or other means of informing Digital Practice when the number of licenses are too few. We are depending on you to let us know each time licenses are unavailable. Thank you in advance. Why Do I Have to Use¬†Deadline Monitor? The key or gateway to the render farms is an application called Deadline Monitor. This is the only way to access the render machines. Deadline Monitor helps maintain the availability of these machines for rendering, organizes past and present jobs, and maintains the rendering queue for everyone needing to render. P+W‚Äôs render farms are intended as a sharable resource. Deadline Monitor facilitates sharing. Can I Render from a Computational Node? Yes. To avoid negative attention always check the ‚ÄòCap CPU Utilization‚Äù in Rhino and SketchUp or ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt Use Local Resources‚Äù in Revit when rendering from a computational node. Rendering Etiquette As a shared resource, it is important to practice good etiquette with others using the office render farm. This means splitting the resources for simultaneous use, refraining from escalating your job in front of others in the render queue and communicating with one another as needed. It is also important to clean up after your projects. Delete your old jobs once you no longer need them.¬†¬†If your job has errors and you plan to request assistance from a Design Application Manager or other, do not delete the job. Deadline jobs log errors. These logs may help identify the cause of your error. Feedback Concructive critisism is alway welocome, but letting us know if our efforts have been helpful is important too. If you have a suggestion to improve these resources let us know. Also if our work has been helpful to you please share this. It helps us better help you. If you have a positive story share we would love to hear it ( email Digital Practice ). We may even feature your story in Digital Practice‚Äôs monthly ReCap.

title: OPERATIONALIZED VR & INCREASED DESIGN EFFICIENCY
content: We all know that Virtual Reality has become a vital tool within the AEC industry. Still, many struggle with their own implementation‚Ä¶ Perkins+Will‚Äôs Washington DC office continues to push and utilize VR such that it is becoming apart of the ‚Äúevery day.‚Äù What have we done to make such leaps forward? How might you follow in similar steps? Great questions!¬†Watch Justin Benjamin (Design Applications Manager, Washington DC) walk through his offices efforts in embracing these tools. Register for IrisProspects webinar on May 3rd . Watch a previous recording of Justin‚Äôs presentation if you cant make the webinar: https://vimeo.com/263389032

title: Holograms Help London Present S&T Project

author.name: Nick Cameron
author.description: American trucker who has been featured on the History channel reality television series Ice Road Truckers and its spinoff series IRT: Deadliest Roads.

content: The London office looked to the Perkins+Will digital toolset to help become a differentiator in a ‚Äì one of two ‚Äì final bid stage, for a S&T project in middle England, Oxford. As part of the client presentation the concept designed Rhino model was made available in Virtual (VR) and Augmented (AR) Realities via Enscape and Microsoft Hololens respectively. During the presentation it was the Hololens that captured the interest of the client stakeholders with all 5 of our guests viewing the scheme, asking questions about technology use and most importantly, the projects design. Due to a tight timeline no further interaction was built into the AR model but doing so will only make the experience more engaging and is something that the London office will develop for subsequent Architectural presentations following the success of this project taster. The feedback from the client team was extremely positive and London CCC Head, John Drew sees AR as a ‚Äúgame changer‚Äù, ‚Äú having the capability of being able to literally place the building in the real world will help communicate and answer all sorts of project questions from communication and design validation to decision making and planning constraints. The fact it is almost pocket sized, makes it both a portable and powerful presentation tool.‚Äú While the workflow from design model to AR is not as instant as VR the step by step process from Rhino export, to Unity, to Visual Studio, to Hololens deployment is fairly straightforward, the biggest challenge was ensuring the hardware and software builds between platforms were compatible. Fortunately, we were able to draw on the experience of Digital Practice Reality guru, Iffat Mai, to help make this possible in the short timeframe we had between finished design model and port to Hololens. While we wait for a final decision on this particular project we will continue to push projects into this environment and with a subsequent release of Hololens 2 on the horizon we see it as an important and exciting part of the London office digital tool set.

title: P+W Revit Content and Template Workshop
content: Perkins+Will has developed a robust Revit ecosystem which include templates, workflows, loadable and system content. The content steering group of Perkins+Will Digital Practice works to improve and coordinate content and template delivery to the entire firm. The group met for a 1.5 day workshop to evaluate the current state of our Revit ecosystem, identify inefficiencies, and plan improvements. The workshop participants were Josh Moore (DAL), Adam Hamilton (MIN), Chris Coscia (BOS) and Helen Gorina (NYC).¬† We focused on the following two major areas. Content distribution system Currenly we are using BIMList server supplemented with CrossDatabase search to distribute content to project teams.¬† In almost three years of use, the amount of content we have to maintain and intelligently distribute to different¬† offices/market sectors/projects grew to a point that lessens current system efficiency.¬†Meanwhile, there are other solutions which emerged¬† and matured recently that have potential to dramatically improve our content distrubution workflows. In recent months we have evaluated several of those systems. We looked at each solution from both end user and contnent manager points of view and we analysed pros and cons of each. At the workshop we have earmarked one of those system for further testing and future implementation. We asked one of out most passionate ‚Äúuser experience‚Äù advocates, Justin Benjamin (WDC), to look at it from the user point of view, and we are really happy that our front-runner distribution system candidate was unanimously preferred . We will do rigorous testing and ask for user input from various offices and market sectors to make the new system the best it can be. Be on the lookout for future updates. Revit templates Every Revit project starts with a Revit template. Our templates went through a complete overhaul in 2016. The light-weight firmwide template was rebuilt from scratch, and each office developed their templates based on the same foundation and then office templates were further customized to suit the needs of the local office. In the last three years changes have accumulated, and at the workshop we took a look ¬†at a template comparison report to identify the most used and efficient workflows, as well as other deviations from the base. Autodesk recommends to rebuild the template from scratch every couple of years to account for changes in software versions. We will be rebilding the templates for Revit 2019. As part of this work we endeavor to build a ‚Äúkit of parts‚Äù to be able to quickly customise the office templates based on needs identified in the last 3 years and additional user input.Please contact you DA or anyone on the content/template steering group with your comments and suggestions.

title: AEC, Hackathons & Disruption: The Beginning of AI-Based CFD Tools ‚Äì Oakland
content: Dean Demko¬†participated in the AEC Hackathon 5.0 in Oakland, California . Hackathons are intended to break participants out of normal routines and explore the feasibility of projects that can be achieved in a short timeframe using an ad-hoc team. We entered into the weekend with an insight that reflected an important issue: Computational fluid dynamic (CFD) models for heat transfer in buildings can be validated using inexpensive Internet of Things (IoT) technology. Using our hackathon project to explore this insight yielded more value than we anticipated and we think you‚Äôll find it exciting. This post describes what we learned and why it‚Äôs important. Innovation & the ‚ÄúStacking‚Äù of Innovation At BuildingSP, we believe innovation is the process of taking a unique insight and translating it into real, actual value. As people and firms practice innovation, they get better at it. Insights and implementations become more refined and unique and the identification and realization of value is easier. Most importantly, innovation begets more innovation. The process of innovation is an exploration of a unique concept and that exploration creates more insights, which can then go through their own innovative process. We knew the repetitive nature of innovation and how it ‚Äústacked‚Äù going into the hackathon, but the uniqueness and importance of the secondary insight was actually shocking. What We Did The initiating insight for our hack was based on the capabilities of a small temperature sensor. The DS18B20 is a transistor-shaped, solid-state temperature sensor with three leads on it. They cost $1.50 each and each sensor is encoded with a unique 64-bit identifier. The DS18B20 uses a data architecture where a very large number of sensors can be connected to the same wire for data transfer. When connected to a data connection device, like a Raspberry Pi, three wires and a bunch of sensors can collect a huge amount of temperature data. How can the capabilities of the DS18B20 be used in the architecture, engineering, and construction (AEC) industry? The DS18B20 ‚Äúone wire bus‚Äù temperature sensor is an inexpensive device individually encoded with a unique identifier. This enables large numbers of these sensors to be connected in parallel with just three common wires. The AEC industry uses computational fluid dynamics (CFD) models to describe heat transfer in buildings. Understanding heat transfer is important because heating and cooling buildings is a significant operational cost, environmental impact, and requirement for occupant comfort. The combination of heating loads, equipment performance, operational schedules, and other variables changes the interior environment inside buildings. But based on our experience, we knew that CFD models were rarely validated or verified. How accurate are the pretty pictures we create with CFD analysis? Our hackathon room model, showing a space heater and a window, along with proposed sensor positions to validate the CFD model from Butterfly. Our hack this weekend was to prove we could use large numbers of DS18B20s and a Raspberry Pi computer to inexpensively collect lots of temperature data and compare it to CFD models. We used a ten-foot aluminum channel and added 30 DS18B20s at 4-inch increments, connected to a Raspberry Pi running code that output data files of temperature data. Dean Demko, Tyler Davis, and Jake Olsen worked on fabricating our team‚Äôs data collection ‚Äústick.‚Äù Ken Takahashi focused on code and circuitry for the Raspberry Pi while Neerav Mehta used his programming skills to format, move, and interpolate the data. Finally, Stefan Gracik used his CFD analysis skills to create a CFD model of a room at the hackathon. Neerav Mehta with Indoor Intelligence, working on code while Dean Demko figures out wire colors. What was the result? Well, everything mostly worked. We were able to collect data, the data matched the CFD model with an acceptable level of error, and the data collection method was scalable. Based on the experience, we came to the following conclusions: 1.¬†¬†¬†¬†CFD analysis is time consuming. Stefan spent all weekend modeling a single room using the popular CFD program Butterfly. That‚Äôs a lot of time for one room. The Butterfly script for our weekend‚Äôs CFD analysis. 2.¬†¬†¬†¬†CFD models only get more complex with more variables. In the room, we modeled a single space heater and the windows on one wall. This is not a large number of variables and doesn‚Äôt reflect actual usage of a room. More variables would dramatically increase the complexity of the model. 3.¬†¬†¬†¬†CFD approaches don‚Äôt scale. Professor Martin Fischer from Stanford shared his own experience with CFD models. Prof. Fischer‚Äôs students used CFD to model the atrium of The Jerry Yang and Akiko Yamazaki Environment and Energy Building. The result? They were able to predict atrium temperature to within 1 degree Fahrenheit. The problem? The analysis was only possible if you had a PhD from Stanford University. The technology did not scale. An isometric of our hack‚Äôs CFD model, created by Stefan Gracik of Integral Group, using Butterfly. Stacking of Innovation What new insights did we find out during our hackathon experience? Our initial insight that started our project was that we could use cheap sensors to validate CFD models. We got that to work. But we realized that simply validating CFD models wasn‚Äôt good enough because the CFD process of analysis is very broken. But our work at the hackathon enabled a new line of development that could potentially be very, very disruptive. Here is our new insight: Data from cheap sensors, like the DS18B20, can be used to create training data for new CFD analysis tools that use artificial intelligence and machine learning. Data is a critical enabler of AI and machine learning (ML) systems. In AEC, we suffer from the problem of ‚Äúunder-digitalization,‚Äù a fact pointed out very well in the productivity report produced by the McKinsey Global Institute . Our hack demonstrated how cheap technology can gather data at a very high resolution, which doesn‚Äôt exist at scale because of our lack of digital data. In AI and ML, the volume, quality, and variety of data sets has a direct impact on the performance of an AI system. If we start collecting lots of data that documents heat transfer in buildings, we can use AI engines that exist today ‚Äì like Google‚Äôs Tensor Flow ‚Äì to create CFD tools. AI and ML for CFD approaches analysis from a different ‚Äúdirection‚Äù compared to current tools. CFD in current practice involves describing the physics behind building heat transfer. This entails documenting all the physical variables, barrier conditions, heat sources, and geometric situations so formulas can be used to solve large groups of concurrent differential equations. AI largely ignores physics. Instead, it looks at patterns and pattern matching to describe what is happening in the physical environment, then extends those patterns to other, similar situations. Self-learning algorithms replace differential equations that describe physical relationships. Why Is All This Important? CFD analysis for buildings is broken in current practice. But we need to increase our understanding of how buildings operate. AI can be used to revolutionize CFD analysis in the AEC industry and allow us to increase how often we use CFD, increase the number of variables and complexity of CFD models, and make CFD an everyday part of how we analyze buildings. Disruption occurs when technology causes business models to change in an industry. AI and ML applied to CFD will revolutionize our understanding of building operations by lowering barriers to current, state-of-the-art analysis. Raspberry Pi for data collection, shown with Altoids tin for scale and proof of good hackathon hygiene. Special thanks to: Tyler Davis , Stefan Gracik , Ken Takahashi , Dean Demko , Jake Olsen , and Neerav Mehta , as well as the AEC Hackathon organizers . Ken Takahashi and Stefan Gracik with Integral Group‚Äôs Oakland office, performing, CFD analysis and hacking Raspberry Pi at the AEC Hackathon. Dean Demko, Design Applications Manager for Perkins&Will‚Äôs Los Angeles office, soldering DS18B20 temperature sensors on ‚ÄúThe Stick.‚Äù Overhead view of our hack‚Äôs CFD model. If you open the door to the room, it is no longer valid. DeWalt helped sponsored the event which¬† gifts were awareded. Dean happend to win this DeWalt jig saw.

title: At Midwest University: P+W Classes and More
content: This year Midwest University featured four sessions taught by three¬† of Perkins + Will experts. All P+W sessions were enthusiastically received by the students and re-confirm our company positition at the forefront of technical and practical design technology implementations. This year classes by P+W included: Everyday Dynamo: Tips & Tricks for Working Smarter with Process Automation in Revit by Josh Moore and Justin Benjamin Using PARTS to Improve Model Accuracy, Detailing and Visualization by Mathew Engman Identifying Successful VR platforms, Tools and Workflows that compliment the Design Process by¬† Justin Benjamin There‚Äôs a Script for That: Troubleshooting Revit Models using Dynamo & Dashboards by Josh Moore If you are interested in learning from these experts, you know where to find them. Of course, there were other interesting and practical classes. P+W staff who attended the conference will put what they learned to a good use and disseminate the knowledge troughout¬†the firm. Class hndouts are available here , video recordings will be released in late April. One of the highlights of the conference was unveiling of many new tools by Cad Technology Center. We will be rolling out the updates in the coming weeks and will highlight them in the upcuming ‚Äúsharpen your tools‚Äù posts.

title: Moving to a Shared Understanding of BIM Expectations
content: Over the course of the month of March, the legal department and digital practice team offered a number of offerings for a presentation on the contractual and legal aspects of BIM.¬† ¬†The main point of this presentation was the need for talking and educating our clients as to what is possible in the world of BIM including what is realistic in terms of expectations as to the functionality of a model.¬† ¬†It is also talking with our consultants about the BIM expectations as well as engaging the contractor when they become part of the project team on the same topics.¬† Below you can see the recording of this presentation if you were not able to make one of the webcasts as well as the presentation itself.¬† ¬†Please check out all the tools on the legal department pulse page to make sure you are taking advantage of all the resources the Perkins+Will offers its team to start a project with a great contract to effectively execute the work. Project Collaboration and the Digital Reality ‚Äì A look at the legal aspects of BIM from PW Digital Practice on Vimeo . Password: DA Questions to Frequently Ask clients Example questions to discuss with a client regarding BIM understanding and expectations. Note: if the client has multiple internal clients like administration, facilities, and teaching/medical such as higher education, healthcare, or similar, these questions should be asked of each of the client‚Äôs internal clients and any inconsistencies reconciled. 1.¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†Do you expect to operate your facilities with data which could be derived from the project‚Äôs design and construction process? 2.¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†Do you expect the design and contractor Revit models to be set up for that purpose? 3.¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†What type of digital information do you currently use to manage your facilities? 4.¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†What current software system do you use to manage the facility? 5.¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†Do you manage your people, FFE or space allocation in any digital system currently? 6.¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†Do you have someone in your organization that could tell us the exact data format/structure of how building information gets into your existing system? (if applicable from answers above) 7.¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†Do you expect the contractor to create a BIM? 8.¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†Do you expect COBie information as a final deliverable?¬†¬† If so, do you expect that information to come from the contractor?¬†¬† Are there detailed guidelines as to what and how you expect to receive this information? 9.¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†Do you expect us to give our BIM (i.e. a Revit model) to the contractor?¬†¬† If so, do their contracts and fees line up with ours to facilitate this type of workflow? 10.¬†¬†Do you or the contractor have an expectation that the modeled information will be used for quantity take-offs for construction cost estimates or for advanced clash detection methods for constructability means and methods?¬†¬† If so, does the project budget or our fee support the cost for those extra BIM efforts? 11.¬†¬†Do you expect VR as a medium to review design progress and decisions?¬† If so, does the project budget support the cost of that effort? 12.¬† What are you and your contractor‚Äôs expectations for the use of BIM on this project?¬† If so, what are they?¬† When can we engage our respective digital practice staff to work out the details and fees?

title: Easier Visualization for All
content: Producing high-quality visualization just got easier at Perkins+Will. Starting this month Digital Practice and IT will roll out new tools, technology, machines and management software to maximize rendering potential. The aim is to provide access to all Perkins+Will designers, simplify the workflows and reduce the labor and skill needed to deliver quality renderings. New Tools ‚Äì First, look for the award-winning¬†V-Ray render engine to appear within Revit, Rhino, SketchUp, and 3ds Max. This means designers can remain in their 3D application of choice potentially avoiding the recurring labor and special skills required to transfer model geometry between applications. Less time spent mastering technology means more time for design and more designers able to produce visualization. New Machines ‚Äì Adding further convenience and productivity for designers High Performance Computing (HPC) render farms will be accessible from all of the previously mention applications. The computational power of these new render farms gives designers far more rendering speed than the most powerful laptops or workstations alone. Designers using computational nodes can also render to the HPC render farms without disturbing other designers with whom they share a node. New Technology ‚Äì Swarm is the newest development in renderings technology. It is an advanced type of distributed bucket rendering (DBR) allowing designers‚Äô to see the active rendering live on their desktops while rendering to the HPC render farms. This eliminates the time wasted waiting to see the final image after sending the job away to a render farm. Designers can now use the HPC render farm for progress renderings comprising the vast majority of all rendering activity. Reducing the time to produce progress renderings is the biggest opportunity to lower the overall turnaround time for visualization projects. New Management Software ‚Äì Maximizing designers use of the HPC render farms is a suite of applications called Deadline. Within this suite designers only need to use Deadline Monitor . It will act as both a gateway and queueing system for renderings ensuring the designers can squeeze the most out of the rendering farms. Monitor shows designers which machines are available, lists current and past rendering activity, identifies other designers‚Äô jobs and allows new jobs submissions to the render farm. On-the-Job Learning ‚Äì Respecting the need of designers to stay focused on their projects, Digital Practice has created a series of easy to follow microKnowlege cards . Using these cards designers can quickly see the steps needed to begin using these new visualization assets from the 3D application of their choice. Throughout the month of March these new assets will become visible on laptops and workstations used for visualization as well as computational nodes. The Swarm technology has not yet found its way into 3ds Max. However, other exclusive features are available for 3ds Max to render to the HPC render farms. These new visualization assets offer opportunities and new possibilities not just for designers already creating visualization for the firm, but for any designers wanting to create compelling visualization. Your Digital Practice team enjoys hearing back from you. So please let us know how these new visualization resources are improving your work life and projects. During 2018, we will continue our visualization efforts so watch for future announcements in the Digital Practice ReCap.

title: Haptics and VR
content: Have you ever been in a VR experience, and tried to grab an object with your hands? Grabbing objects with one‚Äôs hand is the most natural gesture that human has been using since birth to explore and learn about the world around them. Being able to touch an object, hold it, move it or throw it, these actions all help us form a better understanding of our surrounding and confirm the reality that we are in.¬†The holy grail of designing a perfect VR experience is to create an experience so real that a person‚Äôs body instinctively react as if it‚Äôs in the real world. In order to accomplish that, the combined effect delivered to a person‚Äôs different senses must all be synchronized to create that full immersive experience. Currently the sight, sound and movement are coordinated via the VR headset, VR controllers and 3D surround sound. To add the touch sensation into the mix, one need to rethink how haptic experience can be delivered in the most simple and natural way. Haptics is the science of applying touch (tactile) sensation and control to interaction with computer applications. The earliest attempt of delivering haptics is through vibration. Just like the smartphones, controllers can be programmed to vibrate whenever they touch a virtual object in VR. Using that vibration as a tactile feedback, the person holding the controller can then physically senses the moment of contact with an object in the virtual world. To take it one step further, several companies have designed different VR gloves that are even more natural than a controller in delivering that haptic sensation in VR. We will take a closer look at the gloves by Bend Lab and HaptX, and imagine how we as designers can potentially benefit from using these new interface. Bend Lab Based in Salt Lake City and Seattle, Bend Lab has developed a VR glove that uses a proprietary rubber material that is embedded with nano- scale sensors. Using these sensors, the glove can accurately track the movement of your hand and fingers, then use that data to simulate a highly responsive virtual hand in VR, thus giving the user a hyper-realistic sensation of using one‚Äôs hand to manipulate objects in the virtual world. Though it lack any tactile feedback, the speed and sensitivity of the simulated hands was enough to fool your brain into interacting naturally with the virtual objects. Their demo application offered activities such as building LEGO like blocks, finger painting, and even juggling! I had the chance to try out these gloves at an Expo in San Francisco. It took me all of 2 seconds to forget that I was in VR, and started exploring the virtual world using my hands. Since there are no buttons on the gloves, the program offered on screen menu, which I could use my finger to touch and choose the options that I wanted. Using the gloves felt so much more natural than using a pair of controllers to manipulate the blocks. I didn‚Äôt need any training or instruction on which buttons to click. It was an absolute delight to explore VR in the most natural way I instinctively know, just by using my hands as I would have done so in the real world! After testing their finger painting program, and having a blast painting only with my fingers in VR, I was totally sold on these gloves! I can totally see the great potential of using these gloves for our designers to draw and sketch in the most natural way. HaptX HaptX is a startup company that has designed a true haptic glove. The HaptX glove is covered with a grid of mini air bubbles that can be inflated and defalted to create a pressure sensation onto the area where the virtual object touches your hand. The glove is built with such high density grid of pressure bubbles that you can even feel the sensation of a little spider walking on your palm!¬†Along with the air bubbles are resistance bands on the back of your fingers that help create the force feedback sesnsation when you try to grab an object. Without the force feedback, you only feel the pressure on your finger tips, and your hand can still move right though a solid object. But combine the air bubble pressure with the force feedback, your hand stops at the object when the force feedback pulls your fingers back, the resulting sensation of grabbing a solid object in VR becomes absolutely mind blowing. How can we as designers make use of this technology? We can immediately see a few use cases that could potentially be quite useful. One is for urban design master planning, where designers can use the glove while in VR, to plan and manipulate the building blocks, and get instant design feedback in VR. Another use case would be a friendlier user interface for testing virtual mock up. For example, when testing a surgical room design, the client could wear the VR gloves to test the layout of the equipment and move the equipment with their hands. Using their gloved hands to test the useability of the room and equipment layout in VR would be much more natural than having to use the controllers. Currently, several Perkins + Will offices have already started with the process of testing these haptics gloves, we hope to have a follow up article soon with more in-depth feedback on the result of our exploration into Haptics! title: Charlotte 360 Virtual Office Tour
content: As with so many offices before, we have put together a virtual walkthrough of the Charlotte office.¬† ¬†We use a newer Ricoh Theta V camera (cost is about¬† $425) to shoot the images.¬† ¬†The camera is put on a standard tripod.¬† The camera is controlled by a theta app on your mobile device.¬† ¬†Once all the pictures are taken we use the web-based RoundMe application to host the pictures and create the interactivity.¬† ¬†Two things to look for while navigating this tour is the little compass symbol that appears in the center right of the frame.¬† ¬†Clicking on this will open a map to allow you to jump around to different locations.¬† ¬†This is in addition to the hotspots on the screen that allow you to ‚Äòjump‚Äô forward or backward to different locations.¬† ¬†Another ability is to embed hotspots of information (including text and/or pictures) into any scene.¬† ¬† This tour took 45 minutes to shoot and put together on the site.

title: Project Collaboration and the Digital Reality
content: The Legal department and digital practice group have teamed up to present to the firm on many topics that have been under discussion for a while.¬†Over the course of the month of March, we will be offering this presentation multiple times starting on Tuesday, March 6th, Friday, March 9th, Monday, March 12th, and Tuesday, March 13th. Look for invites coming to your inbox. Joelle Jefcoat of the legal department and Matt Petermann of the digital practice group will team up to cover topics of how we see the contractual language evolving as a result of BIM and newer collaboration techniques. They will also cover some of the internal resources available to client engagement leaders to aid in your conversations and negotiations with our clients and other members of a project team. They will also try to give you some insight into where the industry is headed based on what some of the cutting edge contract language is putting on our profession as expectations on the execution of projects today.

title: Model Metrics NOW available in Clarity
content: Have you ever experienced your model running slowly and wondered if there is anything you can do to prevent that? The digital practice group has set up some new functionality in Clarity to help give you quick insight into the performance of your project models.¬† ¬†When you are on the home page of your project in Clarity you will see a Model Metrics button in the navigation on the left side of the page. You will see a list of the models in your project here (it might be long if the project is not filtering¬†anything).¬† ¬†There is a row of metrics across the top that each model has a red (bad), yellow (caution) or green (looking good) circle associated with it.¬† ¬†When you hover over any of those circles you can get the specific information for the number of the item in a certain model.¬† ¬†This information is coming from one of three tasks we have set up for every project; performance¬†advisor, model metrics, or Revit database export.¬† ¬†We have displayed this information on the page for you broken down into four groups to try and organize the data for your team to take action when appropriate. File Size contributors Number of Views Not on Sheets Number of Purgeable Families Number of Unplaced Rooms Number of InPlace families Linked Information Number of Links Number of CAD Links Number of Revit Links Warnings and Errors Performance Advisor issues Number of Warnings (only functional with Revit 2018 models) Number of Walls Overlapping Groups Number of Model Groups Number of Model Group Instances Number of Attached Detail Groups Number of Attached Detail Group Instances ‚Äã‚Äã This data is here to help teams become more aware of items happening in their models that are known to decrease model performance and health.¬† ¬†Some have easy solutions and others are more difficult to resolve or may only teach us the planning to take for the next project.¬† ¬†We want to start taking proactive measures to make sure Revit is not getting in the way of your team doing great design work on your project.¬† ¬†If you have any questions about this info, please reach out to your local Design Applications Manager or someone from the Digital Practice Team.
