title: Sharpen your Tools: Tools for People by People
content: This month we would like to focus on tools created for Revit¬† by PW talent, You are probably very familiar¬†with Revit plugins ¬†that you can find on Perkins+Will tab of Revit, they have been in production for a long time. Most of these tools were created by Iffat Mai in collaboration with many DAs as subject matter experts If you never used them, please explore! But there are¬† many tasks that can be automated using other, more developer friendly¬† tool ‚Äì Dynamo. Last year Digital Practice has trained many people in Dynamo, and this training yielded a crop of new tool makers. Here are some of their stories ‚Äì challenges and tools Minneapolis ‚Äì EquipThis_v2.0 (Dynamo) In the Minneapolis Studio our Interior team wanted a tool that would rapidly build place-holder families from client supplied excel files. One aspect of the tool that makes it so powerful was a requirement that the tool could be used on Excel documents regardless of format. ‚ÄúNot every equipment list is alike‚Äù they said. The EquipThis tool was designed to read excel documents, regardless of format, and create multiple families with the given data. The only requirments are that the user tells EquipThis which Cells, Columns, and Unit format to consider when parsing the excel document. We also included the ability to map 3 additional parameters if desired. Some uses have been to include Manufacturer or Model information within the family for later scheduling or sorting. The user also needs to specify a family. We intentionally used tthe Firmwide PW_SuperGenericEquipment family as it is used by many of the offices for this purpose and we wanted to retain much of the existing workflows, parameters, and familiarity. Our team did make some minor edits so that it is clean when loaded and if you are interested you can find the Minneapolis copy here: https://S :\Minneapolis\_Revit Resources_MIN\Revit Content\Specialty Equipment¬†¬†¬† ¬†(from Explorer)The tool is able to rapidly generate hundreds of families in a matter of minutes or seconds. The team claims to have saved DAYS of work since this tool was released. If you are interested in saving your team a boat load of time, take this baby for a spin! https://S :\Minneapolis\Dynamo\Development¬†¬† ¬† (From Explorer) Creator ‚Äì Adam Hamilton DA MIN Create Sheets for Design Options¬†(Dynamo) It‚Äôs a very time consuming process for teams to build similar sheet layouts for multiple design options in Revit.¬† Since it‚Äôs important to have things named properly, aligned consistently, etc. it was a perfect candidate for dynamo scripting. Workflow/Logic Diagram Example Design Options Box Dynamo Pop-Up The tool is very simple in it‚Äôs implementation.¬† The script assumes you have at least one design option set created with design options in them.¬† It will do the following:‚ÄãDuplicate the sheet, with it‚Äôs views, to new sheets, in the same location.Automatically name the new views and sheetsCopy Legends if desiredAssign the views to their associated design option.Note: There is a current limitation which prevents elevation and section views from getting the design option assigned.¬† Another limitation prevents this working with ‚ÄúArea Plan‚Äù type of views.Upon launching Dynamo or Dynamo Player and the script, you get the dialog box to the left.¬† There are 3 Selections: Which Sheets do you want to duplicate? Which Design Option Set do you want to duplicate for?¬† The tool will automatically duplicate as many times as there are options within the set. Do you want any legends on the sheet(s) to be duplicated as well?After making your selections, the script will run and create duplicate sheets and associated views, properly named with the same locations as the input sheets. Example Starting Point and Resulting Sheets The script can be located here: ‚ÄúS:\Dallas\Revit ‚Äì Texas Office Families and Details\Dynamo\Dynamo Player Ready\Sheets ‚Äì Create for Design Options.dyn‚Äù Be sure to map your packages as you will need Datashapes, Clockwork, Springs, and SteamNodes. Creator: Josh Moore, Dallas Josh also has scripts for: Creating and Coordinating Consultant Placeholder Sheets from ExcelLink Details Across ModelsRoom Data Sheet CreatorDoor Fire Rating Checker

title: Dispatch from Design Futures Council

author.name: Nick Cameron
author.description: American trucker who has been featured on the History channel reality television series Ice Road Truckers and its spinoff series IRT: Deadliest Roads.

content: This past month the AIA and the Design Futures Council hosted separate but somewhat similar conferences on emerging technologies which are suited to change how we design and run our business. Both events were well attended and helped to spark conversation among the participants. Each had presenters from within and outside our industry speak to advances in Artificial Intelligence & Machine learning and some potential risks in how we must protect not only our data, but also our client‚Äôs data. I learned from listening and speaking with other firms that no one entity has created a fully autonomous design solution by enabling Artificial Intelligence algorithms. There is no simple solution and at this point no large software developer is solely focused on architectural design.¬† However, there are many¬† who are focusing upstream in the construction and manufacturing industry. This year will be very interesting as internal projects at Perkins+Will begin to introduce components of AI and ML, working with outside consultants and possibly other firms to advance the design process. My take away from both events is that Perkins+Will is leading the charge in how AI & ML will have an influence on the design process. I have included a recap to the Design Futures Event below which is an excellent review of the presentations.¬† I particularly enjoyed the presentation by Ana Pinto Da Silva , the Principal UX Design Lead at Amazon.

title: Sharpen Your Tools
content: In Perkins+Will we are striving to use commercially available tools to our full advantage and we create custom tools when commercial tools fall short. Today I‚Äôd like to focus on the tools we already own which many of you are familiar with and use quite frequently but may not have used to your full advantage yet. We hope these very simple and¬† practical tips will save you time and make your project processes easier. ViewAQC formerly known as DRU This Revit Add-on¬†solves the problem of referencing views contained on the sheets in different Revit models. It was initially piloted by Digital Practice in collaboration with the Swedish First Hill project team, and now is also succesfully used on projects in the Los Angeles and Miami offices.¬†The teams feedback is very positive and teams which worked with it want to use it on other large projects, so we would like to remind the large project teams about this productivity tool.¬† Here is a link for more details . Also, there was a live webinar on February 1 which was recorded and you can watch. Password is ‚ÄúDA‚Äù Revit Express Tool:¬† Import and Link manager This is a huge time saver which does what it states really well. find¬† and delete unneeded DWG imports and¬† links- both 3D and 2D. quickly check and change Reference type and Workset of¬† Revit links and 3D CAD links easily export all link information to excel for tracking changes select all links and pin them , so they will not be moved accidentally ‚Äì my personal favorite As with any CTC tools link to the videos is in the tool interface Revit Express Tool:¬† Spreadsheet Link Almost all of you are familiar with this productivity enhancer.¬†But did you know that it can work with properties¬† and parameters that are not possible to schedule natively in Revit? For example, you can quickly check whether or not you have dependend views and whether or not they are on the sheets.(Reminder- primary view should never be on the sheet) Revit Express Tool:¬† BIMList Browser By now there is not a Revit user in Perkins+Will who is not using it. here is a link to previous posting with many tips. One more tip: Many users prefer to keep it in the tree mode and s how current project content as well. (current project content is not searchable in BIMList and there are no previews). Note that library families that have been already loaded in the project are highlighted in the library. In addition, we have created a Cross Database Search dashboard which allows you to search all databases at once If you are new and need an overview of our content ecosystem here is a link to previous¬† post Also there are helpful MK cards, here is the latest External healthcare content source: SEPS2BIM Content from outside sources in general is spotty in quality and using it without cleanup can adversely affect your project. However¬† we would like to remind you about one specific source that we can recommend for consistent quality Healthcare content. https://seps2bim.org/bimobject.html . This content was created and is maintained by DOD and VA, and it is highly searchable and free to use. You can log in with your ADSK account, or create an independent account. Revit 2018 Improvements There are many improvements that Autodesk implemented with new version of Revit. We talked about many of them¬† in previous newsletters here , and here , but there is one tiny interface improvement that makes me happy every day and in every project I open in 2018. Right click Menu in Project Browser has a Collapse All option. No more annoying scrolling! In the next newletter we will focus on tools created by P+W ‚Äì stay tuned

title: VRX Conference Recap
content: On December 7-8, I was honored to be invited as a panelist for the AEC VR panel at the VRX conference hosted by VR Intelligence. VRX is a two-day conference in San Francisco that focus on the business of VR and immersive technology. As a B2B event, the sessions at the event were focused on providing in-depth discussions of how different industry or enterprises have been using VR and AR in their business. With over 80 speakers, VRX has gathered many senior level leaders of VR from a wide range of industries such as gaming, film, broadcasting, automitive, engineering, architecture, healthcare, retail, tourism, hopistality, marketing and more. Our AEC focused session was titled ‚ÄúHow VR and immersive tech are changing the face of architecture and AEC‚Äù. We had four panelists, all VR leaders from our respective firms including Gensler, AECOM, Perkins&Will, and Room Scale Labs. The session was moderated by Nathan Gaydhani of Cityscape Digital. After comparing notes with the other large firms, it is clear that VR has been actively used for project pursuit with positive results for most large firms. We are also seeing VR being integrated as part of the design review process, and AR being used during construction coordination and visualization phases.

title: High Performance Computing 2018

author.name: Nick Cameron
author.description: American trucker who has been featured on the History channel reality television series Ice Road Truckers and its spinoff series IRT: Deadliest Roads.

content: High Performance Computing is a fast-moving and innovative domain; GTS, Infrastructure and Digital Practice continue to monitor advances in the industry as well as your feedback. It is our goal to empower you to continue Perkins+Will‚Äôs tradition of design innovation by elevating the firm‚Äôs access to digital technology. The benefits of planning efforts in 2017 are set to pay off early in 2018. ¬†There are 3 distinct areas, 2 hardware and 1 software. Modeling Laptops CPU Clusters Rendering Engines Working closely with Design teams across the firm, a new ‚ÄúModeling‚Äù Laptop has been spec‚Äôd as an alternative to the Yoga. Tested to handle the latest applications, these laptops are capable of delivering advanced modeling, visualization and simulations to our clients. Late last month these laptops began shipping and will continue to roll out through the first quarter. The infrastructure team has been readying CPU Clusters . These clusters are committed to CPU intensive tasks, like traditional renderings and animations. Maximizing the power of these compute clusters is a new resource management software. This software optimizes the clusters by broadening access to their power with over 80 content creation applications including computational design tasks, video editing and compositing applications. The platform is also expandable for future uses not yet imagined. The CPU clusters will be available soon in a handful of offices, with the majority available by the end of Q1. With these new hardware solutions available, we can now commit to providing best-in-class rendering engines and emerging visualization applications to our designers. This is why Vray for Max, Rhino, Sketchup and [soon] Revit will be available as a firm wide resource. We have also penned agreements with Enscape and Lumion to provide firmwide licensing. Vray, ¬†Enscape and Lumion licensing have been rolled out and are now available. Fueling fast, powerful, and more agile methods of design exploration, these High Performance Computing resources will further enable Perkins+Will‚Äôs strong culture of design innovation.

title: VX ‚Äì New Virtual Reality App

author.name: Nick Cameron
author.description: American trucker who has been featured on the History channel reality television series Ice Road Truckers and its spinoff series IRT: Deadliest Roads.

content: Two months after the beta release of its augmented reality app AX , The Viz Lab and Digital Practice has launched an early version of a virtual reality app that allows both designers and clients to explore, in 360-degrees, some of the firm‚Äôs latest projects from around the world. Known as VX‚Äîshort for ‚ÄúVirtual Experience‚Äù‚Äîthe app is a digital passport to places like an early 20th century high school building in Dallas, Texas that‚Äôs been transformed into a modern-day architecture studio (one of Perkins+Will‚Äôs 24 studios worldwide, in fact), or an 11-story tower annex and renovation project in Lubbock, Texas that houses City Hall and other public agencies and services. The app also reveals project specifications and other design details to allow for a more informative digital tour of the spaces. ‚ÄúVX is another tool in our growing kit of digital experience technologies that ultimately helps our clients immerse themselves in the design process and be part of the design journey with us,‚Äù says Nick Cameron , Perkins+Will‚Äôs director of digital practice. ‚ÄúOur goal is to continuously innovate so that we deliver an ever-richer, ever-more compelling experience for our clients.‚Äù VX can be downloaded for free in Apple‚Äôs App Store , but requires iOS 9 or later. The app can be used with or without a VR headset, though a headset is recommended for a more immersive experience.

title: Builtworlds Hackathon: Autodesk Forge Challenge Winners!
content: Kneeling, Ted Hogan. Back Row left to right, Luc Deckinga, Thomas Trinelle, Rodica Trifan, Jason Tillery, Michael Kelly. Not pictured, Thomas Jacobs Team Otter, seven architects and programmers, including Ted Hogan and Luc Deckinga of Perkins+Will, won first place in the Autodesk Forge development challenge and second place in the overall software challenge category at the Builtworlds 2017 Hackathon in Chicago, December 1-3. The event took place over two days at MHub, a co-working and fabrication space. Teams were formed on Friday evening, and work progressed all day Saturday, finishing Sunday morning for presentation¬†to the judges and other participants that afternoon. Team Otter was composed of four professional programmers with little exposure to the AEC industry teaming up with Luc and Ted of Perkins+Will and Thomas Trinelle, an¬†Application Engineer at Flux.io. The team built Ottereview, a web application to assist in the architectural drawing review¬†process. Using Autodesk‚Äôs Forge platform¬†the team was able to extract information from two sequential versions of a Revit model and create displays and reports showing only the sheets and elements that changed from one to the next.¬† Using this tool would hopefully result in a better and faster review. By highlighting exactly what the reviewer should focus on they are less likely to miss a crucial change, resulting in greater headaches down the road as the project moves into construction. Using this system over the life of a project, tracking what was added, changed or deleted at every step, would give you a histogram of the design process. Autodesk, who sponsored the event along with Flux.io, had several members of the Forge Platform development team on hand who were indispensable in answering questions and providing code examples to build from. 5 minute highlight video: https://builtworlds.com/videos/2017-builtworlds-hackathon-champions-innovation-collaboration/ click to enlarge

title: Sharpen Your Tools
content: We at Perkins+Will¬†are proud of our highly collaborative culture. It encompasses all aspects of our work. The tools we use are a combination of commercial software, ie Rhino,¬† Revit, Bluebeam, third party add-ons,¬†and solutions developed in-house. Digital Practice in collaboration with firm wide experts constantly work on improving our tools, implementing new technologies and processes. Your local DA and other local experts are your first resource and can point you in the right direction. Following is ¬†a quick overview of other resources you may use to find the best tool for the job, use it in the best possible way, and¬† collaborate in process improvement. How do I? For¬† some time now, Digital Practice have been accumulating collective wisdom of Design Application Managers and other firmwide experts and publishing it at Perkins+ Will Microknowledge site https://mk.perkinswill.com/ . If you are looking for information about the best way to do something, this is the place to start.¬† You can always get there from OKTA. Latest and greatest in P+W visualization, VR/AR The AR/VR field develops¬†very fast and the teams use a variety of different tools. Case studies of P+W¬†visualisation tools can be found in previous editions of this newsletter.¬†P+W have regular visualiation calls where teams present and discuss different VR/AR solutions and share experiences. This effort is coordinated by Iffat Mai (Digital Practice Manager)¬†who is working with¬† Design Applications managers and teams from all offices. 2017: The year of Dynamo for Computational Design This year more than 70 designers completed intensive 2-day workshops, given in 5 Perkins+Will offices, where they learned how to use Dynamo to automate Revit tasks and set up parametric systems for design exploration. Attendees have put their new talents to good use, creating over 150 scripts now available for Dynamo Player, an interface that enables non-Dynamo users to execute scripts written by others. The Dynamo Player script library folder is S:\_Firmwide\Dynamo\DynamoPlayerScripts\ with subfolders for each office. See the following¬†microKnowledge¬†cards for step-by-step instructions for accessing Dynamo Player, the script library and additional plugins, called ‚Äòpackages‚Äô. How do I access the Dynamo Player script library? How do I access the P+W Dynamo packages? More training is in the works for 2018. If you are interested in learning more about Dynamo, contributing to the script library or scheduling training in your office, contact your Design Application Manager or reach out to P+W‚Äôs computational design leader, Luc Deckinga . Hackstack There is always room for improvement ‚Äì and if you have an idea of creating a tool that can help you with your design process, please share it here: https://dp.perkinswill.com/hackstack/ . After submitting a tool suggestion, please join our monthly HackStack Tools call where we can discuss your submission in further details. Clarity It is hard to believe that is is just over a year since Clarity was implemented firmwide. The effort was spearheaded by Matt Petermann (Digital Practice Manager). This automation tool is¬†heavily used in all PW offices because it automates a lot of time-consuming and tedious tasks on the projects. If your project does not use it for print/export automation, please talk to your DA! in addition to¬† simple tasks, it can also help with project analytics, comparisons and many other tasks. What‚Äôs new¬†in Revit 2018 Revit 2018 has been rolled out firmwide . There are several noteworthy improvements in Revit 2018¬† functionality¬†which will make your life a bit easier:My favorites so far are: Expand/collapse the Project Browser with right-click commands Browser organization for schedules Dynamo Player¬†supports input for scripts. With more and more people learning Dynamo, we can take advantage of rapid development You can now schedule model groups and RVT links You can now add parameters to model groups, RVT links, and schedules Improvements to Railings Improvements to Multistory stairs for more information and videos : https://help.autodesk.com/view/RVT/2018/ENU/?guid=GUID-C81929D7-02CB-4BF7-A637-9B98EC9EB38B What‚Äôs new in your Revit Ribbon If you had not used CTC tools before, please explore ‚Äì there are many productivity tools in Revit Express Tools tab. Perkins+Will tab got a facelift and an improved Copy Legend tool pyRevit tab contains two new tools¬† ‚Äì to create sheet set based on revision number, and to make pattern from detail lines Add-Ins tab has a Metamorfosis tool ‚Äì to create snapshots in time and compare with previous version of the model. This is a standalone version of what can be done using Clarity. JOTools tab allows you to mass save and mass load families¬† and transfer single project¬†standard item from another project,

title: VR in Realtime with our Healthcare Client
content: For the past year and a half our Atlanta healthcare team has been working on many projects for the Northeast Georgia Health System, including developing ambulatory clinic standards, interior design standards, and renovations across multiple campuses. This growing healthcare system approached Perkins+Will with these standardization projects because of our expertise in Lean processes and design with the goal that the standards would be used for new construction, such as the multi-specialty clinic in Buford, Georgia, as well as retrofitting existing clinics throughout the system. As part of the clinic module development process for the Buford project, we challenged some of the planning assumptions that had been incorporated into the client‚Äôs previous projects to make sure that the new standard would function as desired, be flexible for future reconfiguration, and be the best use of space and resources within challenging budgets. To do so, we spent several meetings reviewing many different diagrams and assessments of floor plan layouts, but the client did not seem to be fully convinced because it was difficult to visualize a critical feature: how the staff could simultaneously have a private-enough workspace to discourage interruptions by patients without completely separating them from the patients as they entered and exited the exam rooms. In one of the final workshops, we decided to model several example configurations and used virtual reality to demonstrate the sight lines and travel distances associated with the options. We brought the HTC Vive VR headset with us to our workshop and let the client experience the space as we presented the design options. Since only one person at a time is able to use the VR headset, we projected the VR presentation onto a wall outside the conference room and shared the VR experience with the rest of the client group. The ability to see the various configurations to scale as if they were really standing in the space helped the group to make a quick and certain decision on the module configuration ‚Äì a true ‚Äúaha!‚Äù moment. Later on, our primary client contact told us that he was impressed with our use of virtual reality because they had previously spent over $80,000 on a cardboard city, which hadn‚Äôt been as successful for them, and had been so labor-intensive and difficult to change and explore multiple options. After this workshop, the Cardiology group reached out to us to renovate a cardiology clinic on one of the hospital campuses. They had really liked our clinic module and the design process using VR. As we progressed with the design for that project, we brought the VR back for an interior design presentation. For this round, we used the Oculus system with Enscape to show more detail in the lighting and materials for the space. The client again took turns using the VR headset or watched on the computer screen if they didn‚Äôt feel comfortable putting on a headset. The client connected with the design and reacted well with the more developed and rendered model. A side benefit of using Enscape while developing the interior design was the interior design team being able to make better decisions very quickly about the scale of certain elements in the space that are not as apparent in static views. After trying out both the Vive and Oculus systems, our team does prefer the easier setup and smaller components of the Oculus system. Both systems have worked well for us and the client. Even when the clients were experiencing virtual reality for the first time, most of them were willing to try on the headset. They were easily able to navigate through the space (with assistance from the design team members standing beside them). Many clients have difficulty visualizing space the way we do, and by immersing the client in the VR model, we are able to overcome this challenge and accelerate design decisions being made. This was especially true when the NGHS group could walk around and verify that they could see all the exam room doors from the team station! We forsee making realtime tools such as Enscape and the virtual reality client experience a permanent part of our design process. It has already proven that it can speed up the design process for both the client and our internal design team without spending hours to render static views or spend thousands of dollars on cardboard mock-ups. Click HERE to view the video recording.

title: Dispatch from Autodesk 2017

author.name: Nick Cameron
author.description: American trucker who has been featured on the History channel reality television series Ice Road Truckers and its spinoff series IRT: Deadliest Roads.

content: Each November Autodesk hosts the largest AEC technology conference, typically attracting 10,000 attendees from around the globe. This year Perkins+Will was well represented by almost each practice and office.The theme for this years conference was ‚ÄúThe Future of Making Things‚Äù, the same as 2016, which may be telling in and of itself. The buzzwords pushed this year and woven into every keynote were AI, Generative Design, and Machine Learning while VR took a backseat. This makes sense as VR and real-time rendering are being embraced in our daily process, hopefully we see this trend with AI in the coming years. The Autodesk Forge platform was also heavily promoted. Forge is the platform many have their hopes pinned on for delivering the next generation of design software, Forge promises to deliver interoperability between apps and data unlike anything currently on the market. We will keep you posted on where this and other emerging tech is going throughout the year. As a team we hosted several social events to meet one another face to face and share what we were seeing & hearing. We also held 5 sessions both live and streaming to over 1,000 conference attendees, once again cementing our firm as a leader in applied design technology. Here is a link to an overview and class materials for each session: Selecting and Integrating the Right VR/AR Workflows for Client Engagement Michael Weiser-Ward and Vina Aboshira jointly presented a wonderful session on VR/AR workflow session. A New Design Paradigm in Mixed Reality using HoloLens for Architectural Design Michael Shyu along with Fei Xie, Chance Heath and Iffat Mai co-presented a session focused on their research for the ‚ÄúAugmented Design‚Äù Innovation Incubator project. You Can‚Äôt Manage What You Don‚Äôt Measure Nick Cameron and Dan Chasteen presented a case study of how the Digital Practice Group at Perkins+Will is able to utilize modeling data in near realtime to measure the performance of the design process. Join the Party in Social VR Iffat Mai and Simon Chavez shared the process on how to setup a shared VR experience for multiple users to simultaneously be in the virtual environment together. Up the Ante Josh Moore and Justin Benjamin teamed up for the second year in a row to focus on core Revit skills and opportunities to increase the reliability of Revit models with better modeling habits. Please reach out to the folks whom attended from your office for additional insight and we will keep you posted on where new and emerging tech is going throughout the year.

title: AU session: Selecting and Integrating the Right VR/AR Workflows for Client Engagement
content: Michael Weiser-Ward (PW-NC) and Vina Aboshira (PW-NY) jointly presented a wonderful session on VR/AR workflow session. As Michael described it, their ‚Äúpresentation covered project presentation case studies discussing how the NYO and NC Practice design teams presented VR/AR projects to clients‚Äù.¬† They ‚Äútalked about how each project progressed as far as development, execution, and reception through our VR/AR Network Diagram that we created for the class, in addition to best practices and tips to keep in mind when using these tools.‚Äù The session even included a hands on demo on-site with Vive headsets for all the interested attendees. Click HERE for more information on the session‚Äôs presentation and handout. Michael Weiser-Ward and Vina Aboshira at AU2017

title: AU session ‚Äì A New Design Paradigm in Mixed Reality using HoloLens for Architectural Design
content: Michael Shyu along with Fei Xie, Chance Heath and Iffat Mai co-presented a session on Hololens use in Architecture at AU 2017 in Las Vegas. The session was titled ‚ÄúA New Design Paradigm in Mixed Reality ‚Äì using¬†HoloLens for Architectural Design‚Äù and had a full room of over 100 attendees. Their presentation focused on their research for the ‚Äú Augmented Design‚Äù Innovation Incubator project. The team consisted of Michael Shyu (PW Boston), Fei Xie (PW Boston), Chance Heath (PW Dallas) and Iffat Mai (PW New York). The team demonstrated how Mixed reality (MR) combines virtual and physical realities into one space which offers an exciting new design opportunity for architects. By projecting the BIM model directly over the physical site in MR, architects can communicate design ideas to the team and clients in an immersive and interactive way. The session demonstrated the Innovation Incubators MR case studies, using Microsoft HoloLens, applied for different phases of architectural projects. We shared our exploration regarding the process of precision alignment of a BIM model with the physical project site, how to use MR for full scale virtual mockups of design options and small scale models, as well as examining the potential of MR tools for construction administration with our vision of an on-site MR clash detection and documentation.‚Äù Click HERE for more details on the Presentation and session handout. (Left to Right) Fei Xie, Chance Heath, Michael Shyu and Iffat Mai Fei Xie live demonstrating the use of Hololens

title: Presenting at Autodesk University 2017 ‚Äì You Can‚Äôt Manage What You Don‚Äôt Measure
content: Speaking at Autodesk University 2017 in Las Vegas, Nick Cameron and Dan Chasteen presented to a full room with an audience ranging from executives to Data Scientists. The topic was a case study of how the Digital Practice Group at Perkins+Will is able to utilize BIM data in near realtime to measure the performance of the design process, delivering proactive guidance to design teams and offering insight to the business operations. During the presentation, Nick and Dan demonstrated how Digital Practice wrangles data from across all of Perkins+Will‚Äôs offices amounting to more than 700 active projects and 1,000-plus designers daily. The advantages of gathering this data was validated in a live demonstration of Model Reporter, a dashboard application developed in house by Digital Practice. Questions following the presentation lasted more the 20 minutes. At one point Luc Deckinga assisted with answering some of the audience‚Äôs questions.¬†After the formal dismisal of the presentation¬†the large majority of the audience remained seated to ask more questions. One audience member stated the presentation was the capstone of his Autodesk University conference.

title: Leveraging Technology to Make a Difficult Project Run Smoother
content: One of our teams in the Minneapolis office¬†recently issued¬†CDs on of the more difficult projects we have had in a while, The University of Minnesota ‚Äì Health Science Education Center. It was a quick timetable with lots of bureaucracy, It also was done with a 50/50 associate architect.¬† After a brief conversation with the Project¬†Architect¬†who is also our Technical Director in the office,¬†he wanted to comment on the game-changing technologies that we utilized on this project that enabled it to be any success at all. Highlighted below are some of those technologies which are available to everyone across the firm. 1. Bluebeam ‚Äì a.¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† For UM review comments and internal document markups. HSEC was the first project for University to test Bluebeam Studio for University review/comments and design team response/feedback b.¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†Reference drawing hot links.¬† This project affected seven different buildings in addition to the new building.¬† We created a site plan showing all affected buildings with hot links (hyperlinks) to immediately send team members to any building‚Äôs original CDs and subsequent renovation CDs. c.¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†Photo Keys: Similar to the item above we created floor plans with arrows to hotlink team members to field verification/survey photographs. 2. One Note ‚Äì simple organization for shared information and ability to simultaneously take and embellish notes/lists/etc. a.¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†Creating agendas for an upcoming consultant, owner, and internal meetings ‚Äì entire team could simply add to agenda when thoughts came into their mindsb.¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†Meeting minutes ‚Äì quick note taking during meetings and rapid distribution (have one or more person ‚Äúassigned‚Äù to take notes during meetings, the ability to immediately share these down and dirty notes immediately afterward ‚Äì or use/modify them for ‚Äúofficial‚Äù meeting minutes)c.¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†Task lists: Multiple task lists for team members/project phases/field verifications needed, etc. d. Addendum narrative: it worked great to allow the entire Perkins+Will team to edit write-up simultaneously, then paste final write-up into Word for addendum issuance. No more having one Word file for narrative and 6 additional ‚Äúsave as‚Äù copies for multiple team members documenting at the same time. (One glitch: we tried to get SLAM, our Connecticut-based partner architect involved in this but couldn‚Äôt accomplish it technically) 3. Clarity ‚Äì daily (overnight) drawing sheet plots and batch plots for major drawing issuances ‚Äì without tying up one team member‚Äôs time and computer 4. VR ‚Äì Enscape a.¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†Used VR session for the design team to ‚Äúwalk through‚Äù and discuss design items observedb. Future: do these sessions with consultants to review overhead ductwork, etc.c.¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†Note: we used this new tool way late in the project CD phase.¬† We plan to use it as a design tool/QA tool on future projects!

title: Join the Party in Social VR with Iffat and Simon @ AU
content: Iffat Mai (Firmwide Design Application Developer) and Simon Chavez (Visualization Designer, Seattle) presented a session on Social VR to an audience of close to 200 attendees at #AU2017 in Las Vegas. They shared the process on how to setup a shared VR experience for multiple users to simultaneously be in the virtual environment together. Instead of the usual isolated VR experience, multiple users can experience the virtual design, and have a discussion together regarding the design as they walk through the space. This is an ideal tool for distributed teams to have instant collaboration virtually. Click HERE to view the presentation and handout.

title: Up the Ante with Josh and Justin @ AU
content: Josh Moore (Dallas Design App Mgr) and Justin Benjamin (WDC Design App Mgr) team up for the second year in a row to deliver a presentation at Autodesk University.¬† While the focus last year was the g reat ways Dynamo can be used in Revit , this year, the presentation focused on core Revit skills and opportunities to increase the reliability of Revit models with better modeling habits. The class this year was live streamed! Click HERE to check it out! Course Description: Many designers often feel it can be difficult to create models that accurately express their design intent, often trying to ‚Äúbeat Revit into submission‚Äù. This often leads to poor modeling habits and in some cases, a complete lack of necessary modeled geometry, causing coordination issues. In this course, we will discuss common challenges encountered when modeling various types of building elements, and discuss some tips & tricks for overcoming them. We will find some solutions are ‚Äúhidden‚Äù right within Revit, and others may be solved with creative modeling ‚Äúhacks‚Äù and techniques. We will discuss modeling tips that overcome common challenges related to curtain wall and stairs/railings as well as discuss families/content created that enable special workflows related code compliance, site plans, and hybrid detailing. All of these techniques, can contribute to increased model reliability, better coordinated designs, and overall increased efficiency and project profits. Learning Objectives: ¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†Identify some of the most common modeling challenges that occur on design projects and ways to overcome them ¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†Identify the pros and cons of various modeling and documentation workflows ¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†Discover specific processes and family creation techniques that enable more coordinated workflows ¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†Increase the value and reliability of their company‚Äôs BIM Models Josh and Justin got a ton of positive comments and feedback and both look forward to more opportunities to present at technology conferences. Here is a link to the course content (presentation, handout, and sample files): https://perkinswill.box.com/s/u5qodjkudvn1x8qbbj9uwsfnwgdstr56

title: Viz Lab & Digital Practice Launch Augmented Reality App ‚ÄúAX‚Äù
content: The Viz Lab and Digital Practice has launched an early prototype of an augmented reality (AR) app that will eventually allow designers to engage with their models in a hybrid real-world/virtual environment. The app, known as AX‚Äîshort for ‚ÄúAugmented Experience‚Äù‚Äîis currently in beta: it allows users to become familiar with its interface by exploring Perkins+Will-designed spaces in a 3D, augmented reality setting. Imagine, for example, seeing scaled models of the Shanghai Natural History Museum or the River Beech Tower right in your own living room, office, or neighborhood‚Äîand then being able to share those scenarios on social media. In subsequent beta versions of AX, users will be able to engage with even more building models and experiment with tools that alter those buildings‚Äô design characteristics, like massing, glazing, and fenestration. Perkins+Will Augmented Reality App ‚ÄúAX‚Äù Demo from Perkins+Will ‚ÄúWe wanted to explore the potential of this new technology and have some fun in the process,‚Äù says¬†Nick Cameron, Perkins+Will‚Äôs digital practice director. ‚ÄúWe couldn‚Äôt wait to tap into the current excitement swirling around AR, so this initial release only scratches the surface of what is possible.‚Äù Ultimately, AX will be refined so that it can be used both in the design process and by developers who want to interact with and see the impacts of certain design decisions to better understand their value. The goal is to positively transform how clients and designers can collaborate during the project-delivery process. AX takes advantage of the augmented reality features in Apple‚Äôs latest operating system and is free through the App Store. It‚Äôs available to users with an AR-capable iPad or iPhone running iOS 11. Navigation within the app is easy, and no headgear or architectural training required. Download the app from the App Store.

title: 2017 TT Hackathon

author.name: Nick Cameron
author.description: American trucker who has been featured on the History channel reality television series Ice Road Truckers and its spinoff series IRT: Deadliest Roads.

content: I got an email from my friend Saeran at Kieran Timberlake a week or so ago, asking if I were attending the annual Thornton Tomasetti-hosted AEC hackathon in New York. I hadn‚Äôt been considering it (I‚Äôd forgotten), but it seemed like it might be fun: get together with peers from around the country for a weekend to solve industry-specific problems, building a real, working product in under 30 hours. Saeran was on my team last year when we won with BEnMap . I bought my $50 ticket‚Äìnot a bad price for a weekend‚Äôs worth of entertainment and learning. I met Saeran, Petr, and Mark at a Thai place on Friday night before the hackathon started. I was late; they‚Äôd already finished their food and a round of beer and were deep into a conversation very familiar to tech-leaning engineers and architects: industry complaints about inefficiency, the sorry state of programming practice and knowledge, the prevalence of pseudo-science and overapplication of buzzy terminology: Big data. Machine learning. Agile-this-and-that. And so on. On any other night, these might have been idle complaints, but starting early the next morning we would be gathering to do the opposite of just talk: we were going to try to make something real. Saeran I knew, the others were new to me. I thought it an appropriate introduction to rant about ‚Äúmachine learning.‚Äù I should state clearly that I am not experienced with ML‚ÄìI‚Äôve messed around with some stats programs and completed tutorials on artificial neural networks, I‚Äôve gotten TensorFlow to recognize STOP signs about as well as a dog might‚Äìso I didn‚Äôt have much to say about the technology itself. Clearly some people have done some incredible things with it. I am experienced, however, with the problem of empty talk in our field, and I know how often ‚ÄúMachine Learning‚Äù-butter gets spread on a problem to make it more palatable, without any understanding of whether or not its use is appropriate or even possible. I was willing to bet someone would be proposing something with ML. I made my skepticism clear. The next morning we met bright and early in the shiny new Cornell campus on Roosevelt Island‚Äìso new I personally got to christen a bathroom. The views of Midtown and Long Island City were absolutely incredible. When an engineer named Margaret from Thornton Tomasetti formed a group around her problem, ‚ÄúCan we teach a computer to recognize geometric shapes using machine learning?‚Äù I of course joined up. What went on for the next thirty hours was a reminder of why I went into architecture in the first place, and why I stay: a group of people fascinated by problems, motivated to learn real skills that allow them to find solutions, working together. Our team consisted of architects and engineers from NBBJ, Kieran Timberlake, Thornton Tomasetti, Dar, and of course Perkins+Will. When identifying pyramids, cones, spheres, and cubes proved relatively easy, the group generalized the problem and started looking at categorizing buildings using New York City‚Äôs LIDAR-generated collection of building meshes. The (minor) sleep-deprivation reminded me of studio, and the last-minute scramble with fragile demos and file permissions felt like any other deadline. My Grasshopper skills are mediocre at best, so my contributions were meager‚Äìunlike last year, I did much more learning than tutoring. I managed to keep myself useful with some straightforward distance calculations and some ray-casting based on previous experience mitigating spherical sampling bias; I also made some nice-ish diagrams. Mostly I kept out of the way of Petr the stats guy (and his imposing beard), and Marc the Grasshopper guru. At somewhere around 10pm on Saturday night we put the pieces together, fired it up, and were pleasantly surprised when eveything worked: we performed visual checks, we ran some regressions to verify what we were looking at, and all signs pointed to a successful building typology categorizer. Once the excitement of having made something died down, we got into an hours-long discussion on implications; we tried adding energy dimensions to the data, we discussed the meaning of a form-based analysis of building typologies as an addendum to zoning and land value studies. The winning project was a tool to automatically generate an HVAC solution in Revit‚Äìdiffusers, VAV boxes, and a complete (sized and located) duct system. Very slick. Ours got positive mention from the ML specialist on the panel, though we didn‚Äôt place. Nobody on our team cared: we had set out to make something and we did it; it‚Äôs real and it works, and you can download the completed script, Metashape, here . The project structure is a little wonky and the Grasshopper dependencies are absolutely annoying‚Äìhey, it was thrown together in 30 hours‚Äìbut with a little work you‚Äôve got a verified Machine Learning script that can reliably categorize buildings in Lower Manhattan purely through their geometric characteristics. Is it useful? Perhaps. Will it make anyone any money? Doubtful. In a field so beholden to sales, sometimes it‚Äôs nice to just make something real.

title: Turning $6k into $5m
content: Following the viewing of a Lumion video costing $6 thousand, a donation of $5 million was contributed towards the building of the new MUSC Shawn Jenkins Children‚Äôs Hospital in Charleston. The generous donation made by Charleston businesswoman Anita Zucker and her family, following the viewing of the Lumion video created in-house by Perkins+Will. According to Jim Fisher, VP of MUSC Development, the decision was made based on the excitement generated by the Lumion video. Randy Maxwell, a Senior Project Designer of Perkins+Will‚Äôs Atlanta office, teamed with Jim to develop and create the Lumion presentation video. Initially, Randy created the Lumion video for a design development presentation and used the Lumion model integrally throughout the entire design development workflow. This same Lumion model was revised to create the donor video presentation. The final video production took approximately 5 working days to create. To run Lumion, a laptop with a compatible and dedicated graphics card like Perkins+Will‚Äôs VR laptops is required. The Digital Practice team identified these laptops as a critical need early in 2017 and pushed for their availability. Many Perkins+Will offices now have these laptops as a resource to enhance the capabilities of visualization. In an interview with local NBC Channel 2 News Anita Zucker stated, Zucker said her family‚Äôs decision to support the atrium was rooted in their shared belief in the therapeutic importance of ‚Äúdown time‚Äù to hospitalized children. ‚ÄúWe know that children generally have a better hospital experience when they feel safe and relaxed,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs why a space like this is so important. It gives them a place where they can work through their fear in a really fun way, where they can just be kids and not patients.‚Äù Lumion is an extremely intuitive visualization tool that allows designers to create and visualize places and spaces in real-time. An extensive content library of animated materials, people, vehicles, etc. as well as an intuitive interface to study and alter lighting and atmosphere, makes this a design tool of choice for Randy. The final video was post-produced in Adobe Premiere which incorporated 10 video clips from Lumion. The initial competition video that was used as part of the request for proposal submittal for the MUSC Shawn Jenkins Children‚Äôs Hospital, was outsourced at a cost of $20,000 and did not compare in quality to the Lumion donor video. The cost of the Lumion video produced for this effort compares in cost to typically more than twice the cost of still renderings. Depending on the client and the situation, there may be an opportunity to charge even more for the service. The value of being able to create this kind of visualization in-house for the client opens many opportunities for additional services and client satisfaction. In the case for MUSC, Jim Fisher has asked to team with Perkins+Will again to generate more donor videos. SJCH Child Life from PW Digital Practice on Vimeo . Password: DA

title: Revit 2018 now Available
content: While there are many new features in Revit 2018 below I have narrowed them to the ones of most interest for people transitioning to the newest version of Perkins+Will‚Äôs core software.¬† ¬† The biggest reason to move to the newest platform is the speed and stability that they continue to work on to reduce errors and corruption in our models. Perkins+Will Addins We have simplified our internal tools to remove the redundancy with other addins that we purchase and make available.¬† ¬†We also worked on some small bugs and improvements to the existing tools.¬† You will also see a brand new look and feel. Multi-Story Stairs There have been significant improvements to this feature to allow you to have a single stair element even when the floor to floor height changes on different levels of your project. Railings You can now use topography to host railings as well as better automatic adjustment of railings related to the stair improvements. Coordination Models You can now link a Navisworks model into Revit to give you better context and check downstream models from any other model¬†types through Navisworks. In addition to these enhancements and new features listed above, there are many smaller improvements that have been made.¬† ¬†These include; scheduling model groups and Revit links and adding parameters to those elements, organizing schedules in the project browser, dynamo player improvements to include user inputs from a script that would be run, small improvements to section box interactivity, improvements to the fill pattern tool and remembering the location of last loaded family. You can read more about these here; 2018 2018.1 2018.2 CAUTION Revit 2016 and older models to Revit 2017 or 2018 models With a few of these new features, there are some known bugs with upgrading models. ¬† Please consult with your local DAM and run tests before upgrading a project. ¬† Our recommendations are that projects heading toward issuing CDs or already in the construction phase should seriously consider whether they should stay with the current version or if there is a serious benefit with stability or new features that would warrant the upgrade to 2018. ¬† Projects earlier on in the design process should just plan an upgrade into their project schedule at a convenient time and run test to see the consequences of the change. ¬† As always any project model upgrades should be part of a BIM Execution Plan and should be well coordinated with all our consultants and others impacted by the use of Revit models. The most important known issue is the movement of text as a result of the fundamental rebuild of the text tool in Revit.¬† ¬†In 2018 this text improvement now includes tags and other annotations in addition to general notes and text.¬† ¬†This means the location of returns and layout of text dialog boxes on your sheet might not always be identical to what you saw in your 2016 or previous version models. ¬† This includes text overlaps, word wrap changes, and text alignment issues in tags, marks, and text elements. ¬† All of these are really easy to fix but it will take time to review your sheets and find them as there is no way to automate this process. ¬† We have already made the fixes to our firmwide standard content so moving forward any new projects will just enjoy the benefits of this new feature. ¬† (see examples below) In addition to text issues, there have been reported problems with railings as a result of the new hosting features so pay attention to those in your upgrade testing.

title: Dividing your project into multiple models
content: Most projects that we do at our firm are large (in Revit terms) and thus require us to split our Revit model into multiple files. There is an infinite number of ways this could be done on any project but below are some best practice guidelines to use in order to maximize efficiencies while going through the process of designing and documenting for your project.¬† ¬†Unfortunately knowing these key considerations does not mean there aren‚Äôt competing interests between them that force you to make a choice, there is no perfect model split.¬† ¬†It is, however, necessary to keep the software running effectively and keep teams moving forward on work and less time waiting for the model to ‚Äòcatch up‚Äô. Split models to as few as possible .¬† More model splits will generally equate to more time managing things that need to be consistent between the models, such as view templates, sheet noting such as general notes and legends, and other standards.¬† It also will take more effort keeping modified families consistent for a project that occur in multiple models.¬† Splitting models are much easier than combining.¬† Start lean, with fewer models, and split later as required. MODEL SPLIT CONSIDERATIONS There are four primary things to think about to determine the best way to divide your project. Building / Space design Task assignments Total size (SF which equates to MB) Deliverables and packages 1. THE DESIGN We never want to divide our models such that part of a design feature, space layout, element or other is part of two separate models. If we did something like this it would negatively impact the team members experience while trying to work on that part of the design, it will also impact the model size as the same elements will now be required to exist in multiple models. Think of building expansion joints as logical divisions, or wings of a building, or stacking of different uses in a tower all of which could be logical splits in the design.¬† Also, consider how our engineers and other design partners need to split their models. It is nice when model splits across all disciplines lineup but you can also use a combination of model division and worksets so that if architecture needs to be broken by building area but MEP needs to be broken by a system you can still accomplish this without needing to link too much into any given model. 2. THE WORK This decision should go hand in hand with the design but on complex teaming projects it may become an issue. When there are only a few people on the team getting the modeling and documentation done there is typically only one standard way to divide a project; shell & interior architecture. As the project gets larger and we introduce associate architects or multiple offices working on a project, who is actually tasked with which part of the work needs to be considered carefully? If you have team members who constantly have to open multiple models on a daily basis to move their part of the design forward you are creating a counterproductive situation. You also need to consider the number of people that will be on your team working in Revit and its busiest time (typically right before a deadline when everyone needs to move fast).¬† We see that there is a significant drop in model performance as you pass 6 concurrent users in a single model. It is not that you can‚Äôt go past this and in fact, Autodesk actually recommends a few more people but in order to keep your team working and not waiting for the software to catch up (since we are all accessing one central file even when we don‚Äôt realize we are), you want to keep your max team size per model to no more than 6. No amount of additional hardware or file size can fix that. 3. THE SIZE We are getting better and better metrics on just how much square footage (or meterage) equates to file size. Generally, we shoot for model sizes that don‚Äôt exceed 500 MB or so as a target. This isn‚Äôt a rule without some leeway but generally speaking, models that perform better (and thus quicker moving teams) start to reduce past that point without considerable due diligence by the team for model maintenance and care. This has gone up in some market sectors as our Revit teams are more skilled at Revit and our goals and use for the model increase to other things beyond documentation. At this point, our best guess is that 1,000 SF for your project will be about 2-4MB depending on the level of development and design density. So 100,000sf gets you to that 200-400 MB model give or take (design complexity also increases this factor). This can fluctuate greatly depending on what actually happens in a model and what content is used and the Level of Detail that content has. The point here is don‚Äôt expect a 1,000,000 SF building to be 1 single model and function effectively for the team. Now I am sure some of you might think, let‚Äôs just get better computational nodes but the problem is not our hardware. We already have more than enough hardware to run Revit efficiently, it is the software itself that has limitations on utilizing all the hardware we could give it. Thus, there still will always be a need to consider how we are going to split your project into multiple models. 4. THE SHEETS As much as possible, keep the live model and documentation elements together.¬† ¬†We are almost always required to deliver some sort of document packages for every project engagement we have. It is still one of our primary forms of communicating the design intent. On any basic design-bid-build project we have one single set going out at one point in time. This makes things easier from a planning point of view because now we only need to know which sheets relate to which parts of the building. That is why the most basic model division is shell & interior architecture because most of the shell sheets (except any full building sections) can easily be separated out and have minimal if any interior architecture that needs to show up on those sheets. This type of split also typically lines up with team task assignments with a few people working the exterior and the rest working the interior layout. When you are dealing with a project that requires multiple bid packages that go out at separate times then this might be an additional driver that helps the team determine how to divide the model. When you can make it work it is nice to have a single model that has the part of the building that is one system and made up of one document package. CONCLUSION Many factors contribute to the model size and the model size is only a part of the equation for Revit performance. Having a good plan in place in your BIM Execution Plan is really important. This does not mean you need to break up your models on the first day of design but have a solid plan with some reasoning from the points above for why you will be splitting things a certain way. Try to stick with it since moving parts from a model to another model is never an easy process and it is usually time-consuming. Anything you can have planned and set with Revit setup only helps the team to have time later for the design work itself instead of remedial steps to reconfigure Revit to work. Also make sure that the team follows best practices and avoids some of those things that contribute to large model size and poor model performance like; forgetting to purge and compact your model regularly, using in-place families instead of loadable families, importing items instead of linking them, exploding imported items, and using overly detailed manufacturers models without having a need for that detailed use.

title: DiSCovery Workshop Vancouver, Facade Optimization
content: Perkins+Will researchers and designers joined forces for a two-day workshop in Vancouver, September 11th and 12th, to implement DiSCovery , a¬† collaborative multi-objective optimization process developed by the Process and Energy Labs. Based on the Design Space Construction framework, DiSCovery is a social and computational performance-based workflow in which designers guide stakeholders to set goals for their design and enables Perkins+Will‚Äôs computational designers and analysts to unleash a suite of analytical tools to rapidly test a large number of parametrically-generated design options and find versions and trends that best achieves those goals. Process Lab members and Vancouver designers during the workshop. Look at the focus on those faces. SETUP & GEOMETRY CREATION For this workshop, the participants focused on the second floor of an arts and sciences building ( fig. 1 )¬† of a project the Vancouver office is currently taking through schematic design. The goals were to maximize the percentage of floor area that achieves daylight autonomy and minimize energy use. The design team developed a series of modular panels with various glazing sizes and locations ( fig . 2 ). Designers selected a panel variant for each location on the facade and recorded those selections in an excel spreadsheet ( fig . 3 ) that controls the parametric model, built using Rhino and Grasshopper. In addition to selecting the panel type for each location, the designers also controlled the depth of window shading on the South, East, and West sides. The resulting geometry ( fig . 4 ) is passed to the next step in the workflow where it is processed by the daylight and energy analysis engines. fig . 1 fig . 2 fig . 3 ‚Äì¬†Each row in the excel file represents one configuration of panels and shading depths to be tested. fig . 4 ‚Äì One configuration of the design model ENERGY & DAYLIGHT ANALYSIS The geometric elements from the design model ( fig . 5 ) are separated by how they function in the analysis engines and assigned the parameters necessary for the analysis engines to perform their calculations. For lighting analysis, glazing is given a light transmittance value. Opaque elements, such as window shades, floors, and interior and exterior walls, are defined as shading objects. For energy analysis, the glazing is given a U-Value and a Solar Heat Gain Coefficient. Insulation and heat absorption properties are defined for walls, floors, and the roof; the elements that make up the building enclosure. Additionally, the interior zones are assigned heating loads based on the program of those spaces, along with HVAC parameters such as heating and cooling set points, ventilation, equipment load, and more.¬†Each configuration takes about 3 minutes to analyze. fig. 5 ‚Äì Building elements are separated and assigned analysis parameters DISCOVER*¬†THE BEST DESIGN(S) The input values and analysis results are uploaded to a web application that visualizes the data as a parallel coordinates plot (PCP, fig. 6 ) alongside images of each configuration‚Äôs lighting analysis diagram (f ig. 7 ). Each column in the PCP is one of the panel or shading selection parameters or analysis result. Each blue polyline represents a single design configuration, tracing its values as it moves from column to column. Designers can filter which configurations are visible by restricting the range of values in any of the columns. For example, if you only wanted to show the results which performed well in the energy use analysis you would clamp that column to only show those lines in the upper portion of the column. Multiple columns can be clamped simultaneously. An individual design can be shown by clicking on its blue line. * See what I did there? fig. 6 ‚Äì Parallel coordinates plot of the inputs and results of all design configurations. Click here to access the interactive PCP. fig . 7 ‚Äì Diagram showing illuminance values (lux). Anything between the two extreme colors is considered an acceptable result. RESULTS Prior to the 2-day workshop Process Lab members, with the assistance of Cheney Chen , Vancouver‚Äôs sustainable building advisor, used this workflow to run 288 unique design configurations and several met the Passivhaus standard for energy use, which the project is targeting, while still achieving stellar daylight autonomy. These 288 combinations obviously only represent a small fraction of the possible window and shading combinations and several preliminary runs were executed to narrow the final tested combinations. For more information on the process used to achieve this reduction contact Victor Okhoya .¬†Given the workshop‚Äôs short time frame, and the three minutes required to analyze each combination, the participants were only able to compare a limited number. Even so, they produced results approaching those of the Process Lab. FUTURE OPPORTUNITIES The primary goal of this workshop was to familiarize designers with the DiSCovery workflow, and in that, it was incredibly successful. The project team will continue to use it for design exploration and analysis of the facade, but DiSCovery is already being adapted to assist with other design problems.¬†On the afternoon of the workshop‚Äôs second day, several of the Vancouver office‚Äôs design leaders and the Process Lab discussed the other potential uses for DiSCovery . The next implementation will focus on generating and analyzing options for overall building massing to be used in conceptual design. GET INVOLVED If you‚Äôre inspired to take advantage of the power of DiSCovery or have ideas for other ways in which it can be used reach out to John Haymaker , Perkins+Will‚Äôs director of research and leader of Process Lab. title: P+W ‚ÄúGo‚Äù
content: The DC office has decided to take venture into the world of augmented reality on mobile devices (think Pokemon Go). As we have explored this potential for augmented reality, we have set out to find (and produce) some practical applications for the technology. The first application we have discovered is the reason for this write up: We have utilized AR to make all PW business cards to life! How? Let me explain. Let‚Äôs imagine you are at a networking event talking to a new friend. Eventually, you start talking about Perkins+Will, but instead of just telling your new friend about the type of work P+W does, what if you could show them a scalable, rotatable, 3D model projected onto the table in front of you? Now you may be thinking, ‚ÄúWhat!? I thought only Elon Musk could conjure such fantastical sorcery?!‚Äù ¬†But, as it turns out, you don‚Äôt actually need Elon Musk to do such a thing. All you need is our new app and a P+W business card! Simply open the app, place the card (back facing up) on a table, and point the camera at it, then watch as your business card comes to life. title: Events: The Future of Making Summit in Portland

author.name: Nick Cameron
author.description: American trucker who has been featured on the History channel reality television series Ice Road Truckers and its spinoff series IRT: Deadliest Roads.

content: Recently, our own Yehia Madkour presented at the ‚ÄòFuture of Making and Digital Construction summit‚Äô at the University of Oregon, Portland . Yehia‚Äôs presentation was on Digital Fabrication in Architecture ‚Äì Future Vision , including the pavilion prototype work. A summary of the session: Today‚Äôs advancements in digital design techniques and manufacturing technologies are giving space for physical creation to recover its place in innovation, by the way both influence and open possibilities within design and construction.¬†Yehia‚Äôs presentation will touch on the future of fabrication and advancements in wood construction, giving examples of Perkins+Will efforts to revive traditional Japanese wood joinery, prototype complex curved nail laminated timber panels for a landmark project in Vancouver, and develop components for mass timber towers.

title: Facades Plus ‚Äì Miami Demo Video
content: Password: DA This short animation was created for the Facades Plus conference held in Miami on January 2017. The projects featured in the animation were the Miami-Dade Kendall Academic Support Center, and the Florida International University Academic Health Sciences 4. Under the guidance of Pat Bosch and Angel Suarez, the animation evolved from an ambition to narrate the logic behind the making of the two facade systems. Rather than showing a catalog of still images in the facade logic, the fluid transitions and transformations, we believed, conveyed a more effective sequential narrative of the design intent. At the same time, different than a rendered walk-through or fly-through animation, which are often used to represent the final stages of design, our aim was rather to create a diagrammatic animation of the thought process from the initial concept phase to the completed building. The software used for the animation were Rhinoceros 3D with Bongo as well as AfterEffects for post production. Our original strategy was to use 3dMax and V-ray to generate the animation, but later found the diagrammatic graphics more easily generated through Rhino and its ability to export vector lines. The entire process took approximately two weeks, including the initial storyboarding process, the remodeling and simplifying of Revit geometry in Rhino, as well as the production of diagrams, drawings, and collages included in the animation. One lesson learned from animating and storyboarding each project is that this process can also serve as a design tool to map, organize, and clarify our design and the relationship between its components and systems. For further details, please feel free to contact me: Juan.Yactayo@perkinswill.com FacadesPlus-CreativePlayback from PW Digital Practice Create folder Add file Add comment

title: Revit model upgrades ‚Äì Then vs Now

author.name: Nick Cameron
author.description: American trucker who has been featured on the History channel reality television series Ice Road Truckers and its spinoff series IRT: Deadliest Roads.

content: In the past the process of upgrading models was a painful and dangerous road. ¬† Revit was not the most stable platform 5-6 years ago and the amount of change between versions was always causing issues with our existing models. ¬† This was always something that took time and energy to test and/or commit to doing for any team and project. The process to upgrade your project to the next version of Revit is not as scary or difficult as it used to be. The development team has had performance and stability as two top priorities in any new Revit version over the last 6 years. ¬† Not only does this mean that a newer version of Revit is better for you and your project models but also the upgrade process is producing less and less issues. In addition to Revit becoming better, our internal tools to assist this process have greatly improved. ¬†Now you can use a tool like Clarity to archive your models before the upgrade. ¬† You can also use Clarity to print all the sheets to PDF before the upgrade and then again after. ¬† This will allow you to use bluebeam to compare the documents and show you if there are any changes between the two. ¬†It is still best practice to upgrade through each version of Revit if you are moving up multiple versions, so don‚Äôt just go straight from 2014 to 2017, but rather step through 2015 and 2016 on the way. ‚ÄãYou should still ¬†have covered this in your project‚Äôs BIM Plan and you should communicate and coordinate with all consultants and others who also use Revit so there is a coordinated movement of entire project team to the next version of the product. ¬† One other thing to be aware of is that there was a fundamental change to how text is created in Revit so anything 2016 and older that would be converted to 2017 or 2018 would possibly experience some small text realighment to watch out for. ¬† Again this can be discovered by comparing printed sets before and after using bluebeam. title: BiLT North America Conference 2017 ‚Äì Toronto

author.name: Nick Cameron
author.description: American trucker who has been featured on the History channel reality television series Ice Road Truckers and its spinoff series IRT: Deadliest Roads.

content: ‚ÄãAfter returning from the BiLT NA 2017 Conference my personal take on the experience was really a ‚Äúback to to work‚Äù kind of mentality. In the last couple of years I felt that classes and speeches were gimmicky; check out VR‚Ä¶look what I can do with dynamo that means really nothing‚Ä¶but when i showed up for my first class I got a sense of ok‚Ä¶now that the wow is over here is how we can actually do something! ‚ÄãThis years event was held at the Westin Harbour Castle on the shores of Lake Ontario. A very cosmopolitan city it was quite the experience. There were over 500+ attendees for the Revit centric technical conference making it one of the larger non-Autodesk events. The classes were intermediate to advanced which has always been the reason I choose to go to the BiLT (formerly RTC) conference and was not disappointed. In one of my classes I got an interesting take away regarding tags that were sized for Furniture Spec sheets which I will also apply to our Room Data Sheet Tag here in MIN. As I stated, a back to Revit solution to common problem that just hadn‚Äôt crossed my mind that way before. ‚ÄãI will continue to attend BiLT in the future and I recommend you join me! Any questions please feel free to reach out! I agree with Adam ‚Äì this was not about Autodesk sales, it was about achievable goals using techniques available today. The conference focus was not only on Revit user techniques, but also included dashboards for project performance which help to identify ‚Äúteachable moments‚Äù as well as additional tools like Bluebeam, Revizto, anaytics using Power BI and other available¬†technology. Here is a simple but elegant tip that we can¬†use immediately: When preparing your project for upgrade, in addition to usual procedures, print all views and sheets to PDF. After upgrade, print again, then use Bluebeam compare function. This will help in identifying missing dimensions, differently sized text and other pesky visual issues often associated with upgrades. Perkins+Will¬†was recognized ¬†as Autodesk‚Äôs partner in developing Project Fractal ‚Äì ‚Äúnext big thing‚Äù Conference materials- handouts, presentations and lab datasets will be made available for you to peruse when they will be updated on conference site (couple of weeks) Create folder Add file Add comment ¬© 2013 Perkins+Will Contact administrator: Mr. Derek Veren

title: Reduce headaches and Unexpected cost during Construction
content: We have developed a robust design coordination workflow, which we define as the process of validating the constructability of the design intent, to reduce project delivery risks through the early detection and resolution of constructability conflicts. Our teams use digital tools and good modeling workflows¬†to more efficiently discover and resolve potential issues that could result in unexpected costs and delays during construction. We achieve this through facilitating engagement between different team members, connecting the silos of information, and creating accountability between all parties, to resolve the complex issues that occur in every design process. At defined intervals, in conjunction with other quality control reviews, the design models are aggregated and analyzed for constructability by design teams or in-house specialists. The identified issues are quantified based on risk scores and distributed to the design team for resolution in real-time through a cloud-based, collaborative issue tracker. The key to this process is an organized and consistent workflow, allowing the team to find solutions to the complex challenges they face in delivering modern buildings. This proactive approach to early resolution of constructability issues during design streamlines project delivery and construction efforts. Our clients have embraced this process as a strategy for reducing project risks associated with constructability, related RFI‚Äôs, and Change Orders during construction, thus mitigating the unknown costs that can mount during the building process.This allows projects to stick to their budgets and meet their schedules. For projects that have early contractor involvement in design, we have successfully used cloud collaboration services to extend Lean‚Äôs ‚ÄúBig Room‚Äù strategy of collaboration beyond the limits of collocated teams. The flexibility provided by this virtual collaboration technology creates significantly more productive and well-timed collaboration engagements without the productivity compromises involved in collocating large teams. As a result, the project benefits from reduced cost and fewer headaches during construction. These design coordination methods enable us to deliver a great design, as it was intended, for our clients. *If the document above requires login to view click on this link to log into box and then return back to this Pulse page and refresh the page. Background: All office technical design directors were given the opportunity to participate in the above presentation, that was put together by a small group of practicioners at the firm and the digital practice team. They looked at finding the most effecient tools and process to go through this risk mitigation process, that every project should do at some level, based on the project‚Äôs complexity and size. Revizto and iConstruct are currently office or project expenses, but have been piloted and have already proven a great deal of value in improving efficiency and quality of going through these design efforts.
