title: Real-Time Design using Enscape

author.name: Nick Cameron
author.description: American trucker who has been featured on the History channel reality television series Ice Road Truckers and its spinoff series IRT: Deadliest Roads.

content: Real-time rendering has finally arrived! By running Enscape on a High Performance graphics machine, real-time renderings and live walkthroughs can be created instantaneously with a click of a button. Unlike traditional visualization software, Enscape uses the computer‚Äôs GPU (Graphics Processing Unit) to create real-time renderings for visualizations and animations. What does this all mean for our designers? It means reduced rendering time, faster design iterations, real-time design reviews and interactive client presentations. Before Enscape, the standard process for creating rendered images or a walkthrough was a somewhat tedious process. It required the designer to assign materials and lighting inside Revit or export the model to 3D Studio Max for a higher quality rendering. After the prep work is completed, the designer would then submit the job to a rendering queue and wait for the image or video to be processed. The rendering process itself could take minutes, hours or even days depending on the size and complexity of the scene. After the rendering is finished, the images or video often need to be post processed in software such as Photoshop or after effects for the finishing touches. With Enscape, the prep work is simplified and directly done within the design application without the need for exporting to another rendering application. With one click of a button, you can visualize the live rendered model in a matter of seconds. The live model allows you to walk through the design using a mouse and keyboard, an Xbox controller or a VR headset. You can also export out as many rendered still images, panoramas, walkthroughs and fly-by videos directly from Enscape. Currently, Enscape works as a plugin for both Revit and Sketchup, which is great news for all the SketchUp designers in the firm. You can use Enscape to ‚Äúquickly put together presentation renders as you design‚Äù, says Michael Wiser-Ward from our North Carolina office. He added that ‚ÄúEnscape allows us to ‚Äòhit print‚Äô on our design rather than go through a longer process of generating presentation quality material.¬† Not only do we produce refined presentation images effortlessly, we can walk through the space live with the client and make changes and adjustments in the presentation.¬† Enscape for SketchUp is easy to use and has a very quick turnaround.¬† Most people in our NC office already know how to use SketchUp. Bringing them up to speed with Enscape takes around half an hour of overview.‚Äù Enscape‚Äôs interactive sun and shadow feature has also proven to be a very useful tool in helping project teams resolve design issues related to sun and glare issues.¬† Senior Project Architect, Floyd Cline II, shared how the Atlanta office used Enscape to resolve a major design issue that the team had been dealing with for month. ‚ÄúWe were able to bring in the Revit model that was started in 2012, into Enscape and do a live simulation of the sun‚Äôs impact to the atrium space by dragging the time scale and following shadows. ¬†We conducted the meeting over a live  and we were able to refine our solution [in] real-time.¬† Being able to walk around the space and rotate the view to test the sun impact from any vantage point was a major positive for us.‚Äù Using Enscape for real-time design review and client presentation has proved to be a great time saver for project teams. Design issues get resolved at a much faster pace than the traditional design review process of showing plans, elevation or static renderings. According to Project Architect Damian Ponton, ‚Äúthe Miami office has been very happy with Enscape. We have done walkthroughs with four separate clients to great success. The clients were very happy with the process, as is leadership. I think the success of Enscape has something to do with how easy we can get the Revit model into VR. We saved time by not having to create multiple perspectives to communicate the design intent. We do have to make sure the model is clean, but that just means we have to be disciplined on how we model. Enscape is a great addition to our design process‚Äù.¬†Project Designer, Christopher Karlson from our Boston office also added that with ‚ÄúEnscape‚Äôs ‚ÄòWhite Mode‚Äô feature, [they were] able to keep views diagrammatic if necessary (with no materials shown)‚Äù to better understand the design concept and the geometry of the space. As designers become more familiar with the Enscape tool, they have started to use Enscape while they are designing. Our DC Design Application Manager, Justin Benjamin, reported that the designers have started using the graphics laptop that has Enscape loaded along with their regular laptop that they use to run Revit on the nodes. They would make changes in the Revit model, then save to central and refresh the model in Enscape to view the design changes instantaneously. We have also found that their preferred method of presenting Enscape live is using the Xbox controller while projecting to a large screen. Even though Enscape is quite an amazing visualization software, it does not solve all the rendering problems we have. It will not be replacing the very detailed and refined high-end renderings anytime soon. ‚ÄúEnscape also requires a near flawless Revit model for it to work,‚Äù commented Dan Creekmore, director of Viz Lab, ‚ÄúWe ultimately couldn‚Äôt use it because none of our active projects were constructed at a level that we could show a client.‚Äù Another restricting factor is Enscape‚Äôs system requirement. To achieve real-time rendering performance, Enscape needs to run on a super graphic machine with a¬†High Performance¬†graphics card, which currently is an expensive and limited resource that is not available to all the staff. This hardware requirement explains the limited adoption rate of Enscape around the firm. However, as more designers and project architects see the value of using Enscape, the technical and resource issues will be resolved to meet the need of our design teams. Hopefully, in the near future, everyone can enjoy real-time design right on their desktop! Create folder Add file Add comment

title: 360 Virtual Office Tour of New York
content: After a visit we used the Ricoh Theta S ($350) and the Cloud based RoundMe app ($99/year) to put together this quick virtual tour (about 60-75min prep time). ¬†If you haven‚Äôt used the roundme interface before, there is a small compass symbol on the right side of the screen that allows you to navigate using the floor plan that has the images placed based on picture location. ¬† There is also a ‚Ä¶ symbol in the upper right that can allow you to go to full screen model. ¬† There is also an iOS app that you can view this information through which lets you toggle between this current pano mode and a VR mode if you have a cardboard or VR glasses to use. title: VizLab Uses Drone Photography in VR

author.name: Nick Cameron
author.description: American trucker who has been featured on the History channel reality television series Ice Road Truckers and its spinoff series IRT: Deadliest Roads.

content: Two of the most rapidly advancing technologies in architectural media are drone photography and virtual reality.¬† Both have seen major advances in the last two years and are becoming more and more common tools used to talk about architecture. Today, we can represent interior spaces in VR with a fairly high level of fidelity and realism.¬† Exteriors, however, present some unique challenges when we try to represent full site context with the same level of realism.¬† Landscaping is notoriously complex and therefore computationally intensive.¬† Urban landscapes and their mixture of buildings, cars, benches, street lights and other entourage are even more complex by several orders of magnitude. To produce these scenes in a reasonable amount of time and within a practical budget, artists find ways to simplify the scene.¬† Surrounding buildings might be represented as simple masses.¬† Items closer to the horizon tend to get replaced with generic billboard scenes.¬† Landscaping and entourage beyond the immediate site gets skipped or significantly simplified. We recently had the opportunity to develop a virtual-reality scene for a confidential urban project.¬† This scene was an outdoor terrace on a high-rise in the middle of a dense urban setting.¬† This immediately presented a variety of challenges for VR.¬†¬† The landscaping complexity within our project was going to consume a large amount of our computational capacity leaving little if any left over for all the modeling required to show the streets and buildings surrounding the site.¬† Furthermore, we needed to show views from multiple levels, so simple tricks we often use in the rendering world weren‚Äôt going to work. The solution we arrived at was to use drone photography to represent the surrounding detail.¬†¬†A local drone photographer was able to take full (or nearly full) panoramic images at the proposed site at a couple altitudes. We incorporated this imagery into our scene by mapping it onto a sphere around the scene.¬†¬†Initially we struggled with curvature issues when the user was viewing the model from off center of the capture point, especially on tall buildings close to the site.¬†¬†But after some trial and error with positioning and scale of the image, we achieved a convincing effect that was stunning when viewed with our scene in VR. Using real photography brought a dramatic improvement to the realism and immersiveness of the project.¬†¬†Users could walk to the edge of balconies and look out over the city exactly as they will be able to in the completed structure. We were also able to write a custom script that selects the most appropriate drone photography to match the elevation the viewer is at.¬†¬†So views from upper floors correctly represented the scenes users saw from windows and balconies. We have been enthusiastically exploring the wide range of possibilities virtual reality brings to the table and were excited to see what happened when we merged media together from these two emerging technologies.¬†¬†Looking forward to pushing this even further! title: Sharpen your tools: PW Revit Content Ecosystem
content: Perkins+Will Revit content ecosystem encompasses several major elements Assets :¬†loadable families, system families, drafting views (details), graphic elements, visualization content and more. Distribution system : we use BIM List¬† Browser supplemented by custom made Cross Database Search DA Assist -Content tool Robust system for monitoring of BIMList use, maintaining libraries and harvesting actively used project content implemented in Power BI. This helps DAs to stay informed and be pro-active in managing content for their offices. BIM List¬† Browser Provides access to a collection of databases (libraries) containing loadable families, system families, drafting views (details), graphic elements, visualization content and more. 01 Firmwide databases contain content developed and vetted collaboratively by subject matter experts and the DA group. Firmwide databases are curated by Digital Practice 02 Project databases are ¬†for projects¬†spanning multiple offices, they are maintained and curated by project content managers 03 Office Databases¬†which, in many cases, also include firmwide content ‚Äì curated by local DAs Sandboxes are places for harvesting and distributing office-specific content. Your local DAs will guide you to the best library to start with for your office/project. Regardless which library you are connected to, here are some tips and tricks for using BIMList to save screen space, dock BIMList t to search within a BIM List database to connect to another library ‚Äãto switch display between tab and tree mode for browsing or search ‚Äã to change size of previews If you receive any error messages, first disconnect from the library, and then connect again Cross Database search If you did not find an asset you were looking for in the library you are normally connected to, you can use Cross-database search here . Use filters to narrow your search and a bar chart to see which library contains more of what you are searching for. DA Assist tool If after searching in your local libraries and cross database search you still did not find what you are looking for, please use DA Assist tool to request assistance in finding/making appropriate content. Depending on the situation, a DA may recommend some additional resources like seps2bim healthcare ibrary published by DOD and VA administration or provide assistance in making custom content.

title: Top 10 Advantages of Bluebeam over Acrobat

author.name: Nick Cameron
author.description: American trucker who has been featured on the History channel reality television series Ice Road Truckers and its spinoff series IRT: Deadliest Roads.

content: The Bluebeam Advantage ‚ÄãIn the following article we will look at some of the many tools that make Bluebeam stand above our old Adobe Acrobat. While there is a plethera of functions and tools that let it stand apart we will discuss 10 of the popular functions that will help you get the most out of this efficiency building application. Customizable Interface and Profiles Revu comes with a variety of different default profiles which will optimize your interface for different workflows. You aren‚Äôt limited to just these profiles though; the entire interface is customizable. Display the tools you actually use, hide the ones you don‚Äôt care about, and set up your toolbars exactly the way you like them. Once you‚Äôve gotten everything set up to your liking, you can save these settings as a new custom profile. If you‚Äôd like to share these profiles with other users, you can easily export them for emailing or saving to a team network drive. For other users to import your profile, it‚Äôs as simple as just double clicking on the file. Tool Chest Creating and customizing markups in Revu is extremely easy, but you don‚Äôt want to have to keep re-creating the same markups again and again. This is where the Tool Chest shines, allowing you to¬†create custom toolsets¬†where you can save those markup tools for future use. Just like profiles, tool sets can be exported and shared with other users. This not only cuts down on wasted time from various team members recreating markups, but it also helps tremendously with standardization. You can create color-coded markups for specific subjects or workflows (blue for electrical notes, green for plumbing, etc.), for different teams, or whatever makes sense for your uses. Markups List As you‚Äôre making notes on a document, the markups list provides an easy way to keep track of all of your markups in an interactive spreadsheet-style interface that you can sort and filter. Like the rest of Revu, you can customize the columns in the markups list however you prefer. In addition to simply toggling certain columns on or off, you can create custom columns with drop-down options or formula calculations. You can then use these to assign statuses, set material types, perform takeoffs, and more Import CommentsLet‚Äôs say that you‚Äôve emailed a drawing to multiple people, they‚Äôve added their markups and then sent their copies back to you. If you‚Äôd like to import all of those markups from the separate PDFs onto your master copy, ‚Äúimport comments‚Äù allows you to do so with a few clicks. You will never have to waste any more time tracing or recreating other peoples‚Äô markups, you can simply import them right onto your own drawing. You can find the import comments tool along the top of your markups list after you‚Äôve expanded it. Compare Documents When you are working with multiple versions of drawings, it can sometimes be difficult to determine exactly what has changed between revisions. Having to visually scan between drawings to find differences is not only time consuming, but also leaves plenty of room for human error. Bluebeam offers two different methods of document comparison to solve this problem; firstly, you can ‚Äúoverlay documents‚Äù, which produces a light table effect with color coded revisions stacked on top of one another. Also, there is ‚Äúcompare documents‚Äù, which automatically compares drawings pixel-by-pixel and adds clouds around all of the differences. Either of these methods will allow you to find the differences between drawings far more quickly and accurately Visual Search The concept of searching within PDFs is not a new one, but with Revu you can not only search for text, you can also search for symbols in your drawing. It will even catch these symbols if they are rotated, a different color, or have lines passing over them. Once you‚Äôve generated your search results, you can highlight them, hyperlink them, count them, and much more. There are many different applications for this, such as quickly hyperlinking all of your details or performing quantity takeoffs. Automark If your document doesn‚Äôt have page labels properly set up, quickly navigating to the correct page you need can be difficult. Until recently, if you wanted to update all of your labels it was a long and manual process of typing them all out, page by page. AutoMark allows you to automatically rename all of your page labels by using bookmarks or a page region (such as the page numbers at the bottom of your sheets). In Revu 12 this feature was further refined by letting you select multiple page regions, as well as setting prefixes and suffixes. Batch Link Batch Link is only available in Revu eXtreme, and we feel is probably the most compelling reason to invest in that version. As we outlined in our prior blog post, it allows you to automatically batch create hyperlinks using file names, page regions, or page labels. Setting up hyperlinks in your document is tremendously helpful not only for you, but for anyone that ever uses it. It makes navigation much faster and easier, especially if you‚Äôre working with large document sets. PDF Creation Plugins All 3 versions of Revu come with direct plugins for the MS Office Suite (Word, Powerpoint, Excel, Outlook, etc) that add PDF creation buttons right into your menu ribbon. Revu CAD and Revu eXtreme also provide plugins for AutoCAD, Navisworks, Solidworks, Revit, and SketchUp Pro. Batch creation of high quality, vector-based PDFs has never been easier! Studio All versions of Revu come with free access to Bluebeam Studio, their collaboration platform. You have unlimited storage space, can upload any file type, are able to have up to 500 simultaneous users marking up a PDF, and best of all you can even collaborate with users that don‚Äôt even own Bluebeam. You can simply invite them to join your Session or Project by using their free PDF viewer, Bluebeam Vu. As long as they‚Äôre working within Studio, that free viewer unlocks the full suite of markup tools to allow the user to fully take part in project collaboration. ‚ÄãThere are many more reasons why we are switching to Bluebeam, take some time to explore the software and find your own benefits! title: Sharpen Your Tools: Detail Referencing Utility (DRU)
content: Managing details across multiple Revit models can be a time consuming chore in any Revit project. On a large project a with distributed team and multiple models it can become a daunting task and take many hours of coordination. Detail Referencing Utility (DRU) solves this problem of referencing views contained on the sheets in different Revit models. It was initially piloted by Digital Practice in collaboration with the Swedish First Hill project team, and now is also used on projects in the Los Angeles and Miami offices. Based on the results of the pilot projects, Digital Practice recommends implementing DRU on large projects where it will be most useful, those with multiple models and large teams. It works well with distributed teams in multiple offices, making collaboration much easier. This tool enables teams to cross-reference views across multiple Revit models. For example, all details can be kept in a separate file(s) and called out from other models. The reference labels will be automatically updated when details are moved to different sheets or their numbers are updated, similar to how it works when you move a detail to a different sheet within the same model. This tool can work with any view type and is not limited to working with details and drafting views. It can also create intelligent text notes when referencing a view in a different model. DRU has a robust user interface and project teams find it easy to learn. It has proven itself very resilient, with utilities to check, diagnose, and repair broken links as well as utilities to track changes. An additional advantage of using DRU is being able to set up separate detail models and have some team members work in those detail models, while others work in the main models. It is huge help in minimizing the number of concurrent people in any one model. For successful implementation of DRU it is important to have a plan for which sheets reside in each model and which views reside on the sheets. Special consideration should be given to projects which have deliverable packages that may share details but need to be delivered separately. In this scenario, details which are not part of all packages should not reside on the same sheet. However DRU has utilities for splitting models and patching the connection later in the project should the need arise. Notes: All Revit files (within P+W‚Äôs scope) for a project need to be pre-configured to use the utility. The plugin will not work in any project that is not pre-configured for DRU. Piloting project teams are: Swedish First Hill (Contact: Julie Adler, Seattle) Providence Tarzana Med Ctr. (Contact: Dean Demko, Los Angeles) JHS West (Contact: Jose Barcelona, Miami) It is best to start working with DRU at the very beginning of the Design Development phase If ‚Äúdummy‚Äù callouts were used in early phases, they need to be replaced Contact your office‚Äôs Design Applications Manager or Helen Gorina for more information and updates.

title: Revit versions
content: Currently the firms active version of Revit is 2017. ¬† We encourage all new projects starting up to begin in this version. ¬† We also encourage all projects that can update and understand the differences between 2015/2016 and 2017 to make that upgrade (in parallel with your extended team of consultants). For those that follow Autodesk news, you probably already know that the 2018 versions of their products have been released. This includes Revit, 3d Max, Navisworks, AutoCad and others. Perkins+Will has a team of people that work to prepare the rollout of software. This includes preparing an installation, creating new templates & content, updating internally developed tools and having a rollout plan for the entire firm. As quickly as we want to move, there are many steps and precautions that need to be taken, in order to minimize any impact to our design teams. To that end we also follow the release cycle of Autodesk which has slightly changed over the last few years to include a major improvement to their Revit product in the fall with many new features. After they release updates to this we typically start piloting the software and rolling it out for everyone. As you can imagine the licensing, installations on nodes, connection to other products, 3rd party addins and library of resources are all interconnected we need to make sure all of that is ready for everyone before we can make it available to you. You will see information on the availability of Revit 2018 in the fall when all those things mentioned above come together. ¬† As your project partners ask about this please inform them it will not be ready at our firm till later this year at which point you can update your project models to take advantage of its new features.

title: Red-Lining in a BIM World

author.name: Nick Cameron
author.description: American trucker who has been featured on the History channel reality television series Ice Road Truckers and its spinoff series IRT: Deadliest Roads.

content: Building Information Modeling (BIM) is nothing new. Revit was first released in 2000 and Perkins+Will adopted BIM processes over a decade ago. Yet even given how integral these data-rich models have become to our work, our deliverables often remain stacks of paper.¬†Before BIM, drawing was the design process, and while the transition from paper to computer screen involved a technological shift, a line with a pencil is conceptually similar to one drawn with a mouse. Designs emerged piecemeal by combining individual drawings. The challenge was to coordinate these myriad separate documents into a coherent whole, maintaining consistency between them. Switching from drawing to modeling as the primary production activity fundamentally changed how designs are generated,¬†and while having a 3D representation of a design enables us to analyze and communicate our ideas in ways that were previously impossible, such as daylight analysis and computer-generated renderings, it also introduces a gap between developing a design and producing drawings of it.¬†Drawing has become a secondary activity in the design process. This gap between modeling and drawing is apparent when marking desired revisions, an activity commonly known as ‚Äòred-lining‚Äô. The intent is to refine the drawing so it communicates the desired information in a clear and concise way. This task is rightfully executed by the more experienced members of a project team, those who have significant practice producing drawing sets have a more finely developed understanding of what the final product should look like. However, experience usually distances these people from executing production tasks themselves. If they haven‚Äôt done so in the past ten years they may have never used Revit on a regular basis and therefore not be familiar with how the changes that they are requesting will be executed in a BIM environment. Here are a few things to keep in mind when red-lining drawings produced in Revit: BIM is object-oriented. Most of what you see in drawings are objects in 3D space. Objects can be physical, such as a wall, or conceptual, like a room, the space bounded by walls, a floor and a ceiling. Revit has a pre-defined object taxonomy that it uses to organize and keep track of these objects. From largest to smallest they are‚Ä¶ Category > Family > Type > Instance Category: The broadest object classification, e.g. ‚ÄòDoors‚Äô, ‚ÄòWindows‚Äô, ‚ÄòWalls‚Äô‚Ä¶ Family: Available objects that belong to a particular category. Loadable families are individual .RFA files which are loaded into a revit project (.RVT file). System families live within a project and cannot be saved as external files. Type: A family can contain multiple pre-defined types. One type is different from another because they have different parameter values. Instance: A single element placed at a particular location in the 3D model. Views are slices through the objects placed in a project. How those objects appear are a combination of the view properties and the object properties. Views properties include: View Range: Plans, sections and elevations all have a plane that defines the view and settings for how far in front of and behind (or above and below) that plane you want to see. Visibility/Graphics Settings: This is the motherlode of graphics control! These settings determine what categories of objects are visible in the view and the outline and fill styles of those objects. Below is a list of object properties that you can use to affect its graphic display style. These settings can be shared between multiple views using View Templates, updating all views when the View Template is modified. Filters: Can be used to control an object‚Äôs visual style based on the value of one of its parameters. Object properties used to control graphic style: Cut or Projection? Does the view plane cut through the object or is the object behind that plane? You can control both the outline and surface fill for each of these situations. Category and Subcategory: E.g. ‚ÄòDoor‚Äô is a category. ‚ÄòPanel‚Äô and ‚ÄòFrame‚Äô are subcategories within the ‚ÄòDoor‚Äô category. Display settings can be controlled down to the subcategory level. Annotations can also be coordinated between drawings by using tags and keynotes instead of text boxes. Tags: A tag displays the parameter values of an object. Using tags instead of view-specific text boxes ensures consistency between all drawings and schedules that reference that object. Keynotes: Drawing notes can be kept in an external text file and referenced by a code known as a ‚Äòkey‚Äô. If a note relates to a particular object the key is a parameter value stored in the object. General drawing keynotes are selected from the text file as you place the note. This method allows you to update that note in all drawings by changing the referenced text file or changing the object‚Äôs key parameter value. Type and Instance Parameters: Parameters can be defined as either ‚Äòtype‚Äô or ‚Äòinstance‚Äô. Type parameters will have the same value as all other objects of the same type. Instance parameters can be different from one element to the next, even if they are the same type. (See the taxonomy above) When creating detail views it is not necessary to model a 3D object exactly as it exists in the real world. Model only the 3D geometry necessary to coordinate the location of the object relative to those around it, then add detail components (see below) and drafted lines in the view for additional information. Similar to blocks in AutoCAD, detail components are families made up of only 2D elements, such as drafted lines and filled regions. They do not have any 3D geometry, but they do have parameters which store information about them. Use detail components whenever you want to show standard or repeated elements in your detail views. If you change a detail component family it will update in all the drawings where it is used. Combining detail components with keynotes is a powerful detailing workflow. If you only remember one thing, remember this; drawings are connected to one another because they are views of a single 3D model . Use this connection to your advantage by modeling accurately and use an object‚Äôs properties to store information about it, rather than drawing isolated lines in a single view. There will be times when it will be necessary to draw flat lines to communicate design intent, but try to use the object-oriented nature of BIM to your advantage. The benefits are better drawing coordination, fewer errors and a more efficient production process. Happy red-lining! Create folder Add file Add comment

title: Augmented Design using HoloLens ‚Äì Innovation Incubator Project

author.name: Nick Cameron
author.description: American trucker who has been featured on the History channel reality television series Ice Road Truckers and its spinoff series IRT: Deadliest Roads.

content: Written by: Michael Shyu Our innovation incubator project focused on utilizing Augmented Reality and Mixed Reality as an all-encompassing architect‚Äôs toolset which can be used from initial conceptual massing, to real scale design visualization in space through construction administration phase as an on-site clash detechtion tool. Our team was diverse and widespread and consisted of Michael Shyu, Xie Fie, Chance Heath and Ryan Zhang of MIT Media Lab/GSI, with Iffat Mai as our lead advisor. The Hardware The platform we utilized was the cutting edge Microsoft HoloLens which is a fully immersive, standalone headset that overlays 3D spatial information over a transparent OLED screen. The headset is equipped with top of the line sensors and cameras that are capable of overlaying a 3D virtual mesh (SLAM) over a real physical space. The HoloLens itself is¬†currently still a development tool that is sought out by VR developers to experiment with the potential usage of Augmented Reality (AR) and Mixed Reality(MR) in real spaces. The Process Our initial project focused on trying to utilize HoloLens for an outdoor site, but due to technical hardware limitations, construction schedule, and the need for frequent field test of the device that limited us under that scope. We refocused the project onto an empty floor above the Perkins + Will‚Äôs Boston office and created a hypothetical project that would allow us to rapidly test and create content, which would become the basis for future¬†Augmented Reality / Mixed Reality (AR/MR)¬†work in Perkins&Will.¬†In order to execute this lofty idea, the process and project had to be goal and milestone driven, while also being agile enough to adjust to the research challenges of developing on a brand new hardware while learning to code using the Unity3D game engine. We conducted seven field tests and interviewed multiple people of different roles and skill sets to refine the scope of a tool needed for the office. Each test pushed specific limits of the hardware and software and tested our assumptions of what was needed for the office and how it would be represented and could be presented on the HoloLens screen. The Product The product consisted of three main functions, the Model Observatory, Interior Design Options, and the CA Assistant, which could all activated by voice and ‚Äúair tap‚Äù command, as well as curated by a series of visual tutorials. The Model Observatory mode is how Augmented Reality was traditionally used to view a virtual model of a small object within the physical world. For our project, the Model Observatory was envisioned as a conceptual massing tool that could rapidly test out models en lieu of physical models. Interactions, such as turning on and off different layers and moving and hiding pieces of the building were pre built into our Model Observatory platform. With the Interior Design Options feature, we pushed the boundaries of immersive AR/MR design. We created a series of design options for a reception desk in the lobby space at full 1:1 scale, which tested the HoloLens‚Äôs ability of alignment as well as the representation of high fidelity materials and textures that could reflect and refract to virtual environmental lighting.¬†Model alignment was achieved by matching the physical space with the virtual model through Spatial Localization and Mapping (SLAM), and it was scaled by a scalar modifier function.¬†The user interface is how one interacts with the various design options and is a floating semi-transparent window that can be repositioned and hidden as one moves through the space.¬†The materials were optimized video game materials that were able to dynamically reflect and refract based on the position of the user, this level of realism in physical on site space can only be achieved by the HoloLens as of the writing of this post.¬†The model geometries were created in both Rhino and Revit, as a test of model fidelity in the HoloLens. There were both curvilinear forms and orthogonal forms, which were intentionally created to test the limits of the hardware on the material interactions. We selected a myriad of materials from concrete, marble, wood, and metals of varying shades of reflectivity and tones. The CA Assistant was the third and final function of the test. We wanted to demonstrate the HoloLens as a tool that could be used throughout the lifecycle of a project. We created a hypothetical situation in which we were outfitting the existing space with a new set of ductwork. The Hololens would detect a clash between the existing and the proposed and highlight that as a potential issue for review through a large red pulsing sphere. Once you click on the clash, an image and report was generated in plan, section and photograph, and the area would be flagged for further review back in the office. As the technical limitations of actually creating a software that could literally understand the space through machine learning was outside the scope and expertise of our project, we ‚Äúpre-cooked‚Äù the scenario to demonstrate the future possibilities of this technology. Conclusions Augmented and Mixed Reality is a new territory generating a lot of buzz through major industry players. Microsoft, Apple, Facebook, and Google are all investing a lot into this technology but it is still very much in development industry wide. The ability to see each other and interact together in a shared experience is the real power of the technology and this social interaction is something that is very human. In order to understand how to use this tool, a few things need to be understood on a fundamental level. First one being AR is not VR and understanding that difference is critical.¬†¬†VR is essentially industry standard at this point and has been optimized as a one-click solution whereas AR requires a lot of technical knowhow just to deploy. VR is an enclosed experience where one visualizes a new built space. AR relies on the real world and existing conditions in order to overlay information. The representation of AR is very different. You want it to be object focused and rely on as much of the existing background as possible in order to create the sense that the object is really there. Overlaying virtual elements that represent existing physical objects on top of the actual objects creates an unrealistic overlap which is visually unappealing and mentally confusing to the viewer. Presentation is everything. You have to test and walk through how you want to present and interact. The style is very different, and in order to utilize AR to its potential, one really needs to rethink how they present and interact with an audience. Put the HoloLens on. Test it. Use it and rehearse. An industry focused AR/MR will be the future and it is not a gimmick. The technology and sensors of SLAM, machine learning and simple raw computing power are all developing and converging. While there will always be bumps along the way, as HoloLens is still just a Beta platform, everyone will soon be using and experiencing AR/MR as commonly as the cellphones are used today in 5-10 years down the road.

title: Perkins+Will @ Midwest University!

author.name: Nick Cameron
author.description: American trucker who has been featured on the History channel reality television series Ice Road Truckers and its spinoff series IRT: Deadliest Roads.

content: ‚ÄúMidwest University is a regional professional development conference where attendees learn about new and emerging technologies, new features of Autodesk software, tools and techniques that keep building and infrastructure firms competitive. This two-day event features breakout sessions taught by the region‚Äôs top instructors and Autodesk technical experts. The general sessions and networking opportunities allow you to share ideas and insights with your peers, network with experts in your field, and explore the latest trends and technologies.‚Äù ‚Äì Midwest-u.com The overarching themes would be Dynamo uses and Big Data in BIM. Classes are meant for the intermediate users to high-level BIM workflows. The conference brought together users from all AEC industries which allowed for good interoperability discussions and networking with different subs. Many of the big name firms from the Midwest had users in attendance. Classes were robust and easily of national conference quality, many speakers gave the same presentations as national level conferences at half the cost. Very enjoyable and definitely worth it. We were not just in attendance‚Ä¶ Oh no, we presented!¬† Below are the (2) courses to which we were responsible. Everyday Dynamo: Automating Simple Solutions That Bridge Workflow Gaps Within Revit Presenters: Josh Moore (Dallas Office) & Justin Benjamin (Washington DC Office) Are you a Building Information Modeling (BIM) manager seeking to increase the efficiency of your company and project teams? Are you a model manager struggling through workflow issues? Or maybe you‚Äôre neither of those, but you work in Revit software every day and want to learn ways to work smarter. This class will focus on using visual programming in the Dynamo extension to bridge everyday workflow gaps within Revit software. The class will provide a brief overview of Dynamo and the many available packages that the Dynamo community has already created that can be used to automate many tasks. The class will also go over some basic tips and tricks you can use when setting up Dynamo, and we‚Äôll troubleshoot. The remainder of the class will focus on specific examples that bridge workflow gaps and/or increase automation within Revit software. Example scripts will include the following: finding annotation styles within legends for model cleanup; coordinating dummy view tags across linked models; binding models without losing workset/phase information; swapping ceiling-based lights for face-based lights. This session features Dynamo Studio and Revit. AIA Approved Just a Shell Game ‚Äì Utilizing Design Options to Maintain a Master Model Presenter: Adam Hamilton (Minneapolis Office) ‚ÄúThe workflows of the BIM age are hitting obstacles. In my office we are faced with discipline specific challenges that have been solved using a unique method I wish to share. First, our Interiors team needed a method of remodeling different areas of a single building at the same time. Each team and area would need its own document package displaying the building as-constructed without any of the proposed changes in the other parallel projects. As a repeat client the intent would be to maintain the record model while tracking these progressing changes, and in the end unite all the work into one model.¬† Second, our Landscape team working on a commercial campus project needed to issue phasing packages for construction while continuing to develop the Master Scheme due to a restrictive time table. An unlikely ally emerged; utilizing Design Options in a Master Model we were able to manage an Existing building and Site model while developing in parallel multiple CD sets. This class will discuss the reasoning behind this method, the extent of management, and the issues and successes our teams were able to achieve. ‚Äì Methods discussed could benefit all disciplines though examples shown relate to Architectural, Interior Design and Landscape.‚Äù All and all, this was a much more intimate setting than Autodesk University.¬† Which lent itself to a more friendly/collaborative chit chat amongst our peers.

title: Sharpen Your Tools: FormIt
content: Phillip Leidy is a project architect in NY office. He is sharing an efficient workflow utilizing FormIt, that he learned at Autodesk University 2016. As a long time¬†¬†Sketchup and Revit user I was intrigued and excited¬†¬†when I first saw FormIt while attending Autodesk University.¬†¬†FormIt for me is very promising solution. FormIt gives you the modeling speed and flexibility of Sketchup with the integration and power of Revit. The program‚Äôs interface and behavior are very familiar to those accustomed to using Sketchup. Its basic structure of ‚Äúpush/pull‚Äù modeling and grouping for model structure are very similar to Sketchup. This for me is a huge advantage in attracting new users. It‚Äôs not a big learning curve for people accustomed to using Sketchup. I personally was able to get in and work with FormIt within about five minutes of playing around.¬†Here was a program that looks and feels like Sketchup but is in the same family line as Revit. Modeling in FormIt is easy and intuitive for a Sketchup user, and without its big drawback which has always been that it lacks integration with a BIM workflow and that it was never intended for construction documentation. Before FormIt, I would use Sketchup for designs and presentations, and then use Revit for documenting and executing the project. This meant a good bit of wasted effort remodeling at each stage with every change. Also, when it comes to building families and really modeling anything in Revit, the modeling interface is a bit of a nightmare. It‚Äôs not very intuitive and speed isn‚Äôt really what the designers had in mind. Revit is most concerned with r elationships and information. This isn‚Äôt to say that modeling in Revit is impossible. I‚Äôve met plenty of Revit geniuses, but for me and many users I‚Äôve talked to, the modeling interface is a big problem. It sc ares off new users and frustrates competent modelers from other programs. The real power of FormIt comes from the programs interface with Revit. The two programs remain separate but fully compatible both forward (FormIt to Revit) and backward (Revit back to FormIt.) When brought into Revit, the grouping model structure is converted to the family structure that Revit users are familiar with. FormIt also allows you to assign Revit family types in FormIt so when you bring groups into Revit, Revit already knows how to classify and treat them. This means if you build out a basic site model or topography, you can just assign that as a site family, and Revit treats it like a site element. Any users who have had to model exactly how topography meets a building at an entrance know that Revit‚Äôs site tools are not exactly great for that kind of precision work. With FormIt you can model it exactly the way you want. Just assign it as a site element in FormIt and bring it into Revit. (If that topography changes, you can update it just as quickly and bring it back in.)¬†In the past, when I used Sketchup, the big problem with my earlier design workflows was the lost time and effort when it came to double modeling. FormIt allows you to keep and work with that early geometry. This means that effort isn‚Äôt lost. Furthermore the back compatibility also means you can update and revise that geometry as needed. FormIt also has some powerful tool integration that remains was a big strength of Revit as well. FormIt has Dynamo and Energy Modeling built in. This means that in addition to quickly changing and modifying early design iterations, they can be driven dynamically with parametrics and analyzed for site and energy impacts. Basic building types like parking garages or hotels with set space requirements can be fully driven with dynamo scripting and dropped directly into your project site. My first live test of the FormIt to Revit workflow was on one of my current projects. The project‚Äôs team is well into construction, and needs to rework a lobby design (quickly!). We have a basic concept of what all the lobby millwork should look like, but it has not been fully modeled or drawn yet. Normally when it comes to checking millwork detailing (or detailing from shop drawings) I would quickly model this out in Sketchup to show the designer how the detailing changes impact the final design. This time, instead of double modeling here and building a separate 3D model of the millwork and then having a junior staff member draw and model it in Revit, I figured I‚Äôd give FormIt a try as comparison against my normal workflow. I built the millwork in FormIt and went through the design with the designer as usual. We were able to correct and change the design as needed to meet both the technical and design requirements. But now instead of handing the whole thing off to be rebuilt in Revit, I just converted my FormIt model into a millwork family for Revit and dropped it straight into the building model. From here junior staff were able to draw out the documentation details from the live geometry ‚Äî no double modeling required. While I found this new workflow to be somewhat faster, the biggest advantage was the minimizing of mistakes from remodeling. The look that was modeled with the designer was exactly the geometry that was put into the Revit model and detailed without any additional effort. I do not claim to be a FormIt expert just yet, but I can already see the advantages to using this new program. I believe FormIt is able to solve two of Revit‚Äôs biggest shortcomings: it significantly increases both the speed and flexibility of design and pre-design modeling for Revit, and provides a way to easily and intuitively create complex geometry fully compatible with Revit environment. I am actively trying to get more people interested in FormIt so that we can further develop new workflows that can both speed up and reduce redundancy in our firms design process.

title: MassMetrics 2.2
content: We have advanced from version 2.1 to version 2.2 of the Mass Metrics toolset. Included in this revision are refinements to existing scripts, a new tool, and additional real-world example files. Within CityBuilder, geometry IDs are now stored in Rhinoceros, making them persistent between sessions. On the Excel side, we have added an additional dashboard for use with MassReporter to help teams generate reports of building program area. We have also introduced a new tool: SetbackCalculator, which can be used to identify buildings with frontage on major roads, for use with CityBuilder-generated schemes. As always, MassMetrics can be downloaded at https://dp.perkinswill.com/catalog/ (search for ‚Äúmass‚Äù or click on ‚Äúgrasshopper‚Äù). Feedback is greatly appreciated by the team, and we look forward to working with your team!

title: AIA Healthcare: Virtual Reality Showcase ‚Äì Los Angeles

author.name: Nick Cameron
author.description: American trucker who has been featured on the History channel reality television series Ice Road Truckers and its spinoff series IRT: Deadliest Roads.

content: Herman Miller Showroom ‚Äì March 22 nd 2017 Produced and Presented by: Dean Demko ‚Äì Design Applications Manager Justin Brechtel ‚Äì Senior Computational Designer Perkins + Will (P+W) was invited to the AIA Healthcare: Virtual Reality Showcase to demonstrate how they utilize Virtual Reality as a design tool for Healthcare. P+W maintains a close relationship with the medical professionals who will be users of the spaces designed during the design process. This design process includes reoccurring meetings with the user to gain valuable feedback which is used to help inform the architects and planners as to how the highly technical medical spaces should be planned. To help communicate the design to the medical professionals P+W uses many different methods to communicate the space. Amongst these methods are 2d lines drawings (plans, elevations, axonometric), renderings, full scale mock ups, and Virtual Reality. Full-scale mock ups are the closest thing to reality, but the cost of constructing the mock ups can add up and only a limited amount of spaces can be constructed. Virtual Reality allows P+W to rapidly create many more spaces than could be constructed and provides an environment, which medical professionals can immerse themselves and interact with the spaces as if they were in the finished building. For this demonstration, P+W used the model from an ICO Patient room, which they are currently designing. P+W uses a variety of design and production tools. The main production tool is Revit. Revit does not have the capability of creating Virtual Reality out of the box. To create the Virtual Reality environment P+W developed a workflow involving Revit, 3D Studio Max, Unity with the Unity Asset VRTK, and Oculus Rift with Oculus Touch. Seen below is the workflow diagram. This workflow allowed P+W to take the production model and add realistic materials, lighting, physics, and an interactive environment. This allows the users to not only step through the space as if it is real but also interact with the objects in the room, including moving tables, opening and closing doors and cabinets, and adjusting medical equipment which operate with overhead booms. This interactive environment allows the medical professionals to actually use the space, by walking through the space, moving equipment, and move through their standard working routines like they would in a finished building in operation. Medical professionals can then provide real working experience feedback to the designers that they could not provide by just reviewing 2d plans or renderings. https://www.aialosangeles.org/calendar/healthcare-committee-march-2017#.WQPM_ogrLmE Create folder Add file Add comment ¬© 2013 Perkins+Will Contact administrator: Mr. Derek Veren

title: Designing with Hololens
content: What is a Hololens? The latest buzz on the VR/AR scene is the Hololens. The Microsoft Hololens is such a revolutionarily new device that even among the VR/AR aficionados, the first question they ask is ‚Äúwhat exactly is a Hololens?‚Äù The Hololens is a mixed reality (MR) headset device that projects virtual objects as 3D holographic images inside the headset over real physical objects. Unlike a VR headset, the Hololens headset is a clear visor that is transparent which enables user to see the virtual holograms overlaid on top of the real world environment and delivers a mixed reality experience for the user. In addition to projecting 3D holographic imagery, the Hololens is equipped with multiple cameras and sensors to help it understand the surrounding environment and establish a consistent inside-out tracking of the user and his location relative to his environment. With solid tracking, Hololens users can interact naturally with the virtual holograms inside the Hololens using gaze, gesture and voice control. What can designers do with the Hololens? For designers, the Hololens is a natural extension of a designer‚Äôs canvas. What better way to envision how a design will fit into a space than to immerse yourself into it? Put on the Hololens headset and insert the 3D design directly into the room you are designing and immerse yourself in a mixed reality space where the virtual objects appear, as a hologram, exactly where it would be in the real world. With the inside out tracking system, the Hololens scans the environment and creates an internal spatial mapping database to track where all the objects and surfaces are, such that if you insert a window on the wall, it will remain there even if you walk out of the room and come back later. You can interact with the 3D holograms by walking in it in this mixed reality space as you experience the design from every angle and every vintage point, just as you would in the real world. What‚Äôs more, you can dynamically make design changes and see the impact instantaneously in your mixed reality environment. Though most Hololens user‚Äôs first reaction to this mixed reality experience is a fantasy like surprise, the fact that mixed reality still maintains a strong connection to the physical world makes it so much easier for them to comprehend and accept the holograms as part of the new ‚Äúreality, the mixed reality. Adding interactivity to the mixed reality further reinforces the realism of the holographic objects, making it easier for our brain to comprehend the experience thus resulting with none of the discomfort that is sometimes associated with VR experience. Socially, the Hololens experience is also much more socially engaging than the VR experience. As the Hololens users can still see through the headset, they are fully aware of their surroundings, and can continue to engage with the people around them. In fact, the Hololens can enhance the social experience as it can function as a collaborative tool. One way the Hololens can help collaboration is to bring collaborators together virtually. Imagine a user in the field surveying a site condition. If an issue arises and the user needs to consult with an expert remotely, he/she can simply call up the expert through skype using the headset, share with the expert what he/she sees through the headset, and collaborate on a solution right there on site. Another way the Hololens can help collaboration is through networked MR experience. By hosting a multi-user session that consists of multiple Hololens users, a project team can collaboratively discuss and work on their design model in the mixed reality world. The team can work in multiple scale modes as needed. Working in a model scale, the team can place the design model on a tabletop allowing the team to see the full extent of the project. ¬†When they needed to explore a specific room, the team can switch to full-scale mode and immerse the whole team into a specific location inside the full-scale virtual model. Adding design option review to the process the team can review multiple design option this way instead of having to build many different physical models or physical mock up. Just imagine the efficiency that the project can gain simply by getting all the stakeholders into the same ‚Äúroom‚Äù whenever you need to, even when everyone is ‚Äúdialing‚Äù in from different physical locations. How is Perkins&Will using the Hololens? Our Digital Practice (DP) team joined the early developer program for the Microsoft Hololens as soon as the device was released to developers, and has been working with several pairs of the Hololens headsets since then. Some of our project teams in Chicago and Seattle office have since been exploring the presentation features of the Hololens as they used the Hololens to share their design model with the client for design review and approval process. Several other Hololens research projects are currently underway around the firm. The ‚ÄúHololens for design and construction process‚Äù project is being conducted as a joint effort by the Digital Practice team along with a Boston innovation incubator team and an MIT media lab researcher. ¬†Another Hololens research project is the ‚ÄúHololens for Multi-user Collaboration‚Äù which is a joint effort by the Digital Practice team, Viz Lab in Dallas and our Seattle office. title: Mass Metrics 2
content: WHERE CAN I GET IT? https://dp.perkinswill.com/catalog/ (includes C+S Layer Naming Manual) WHAT IS MASS METRICS? Mass Metrics 2 is a collection of digital tools built to specifically for our planning and large scale design projects. Each toolset includes a Rhino or Revit file and an Excel file with a client-facing dashboard. By scripting real-time takeoffs in Rhino and tying those takeoffs directly to a client-facing dashboard, you can eliminate data-drag on scenario testing and work in a seamless data-rich design modeling environment. ¬†Use these toolsets at your desk, with your colleagues, or right in front of our clients. Mass Metrics 2 has 3 toolsets.¬† These toolsets can be used by themselves or in conjunction with one another. Mass Reporter Scenario Builder City Builder WHICH TOOLSET SHOULD I USE? Mass Reporter allows users to report takeoffs of their proposed massing in real-time.¬† That reporting can take place in a heads-up display within Rhino, as well as in an Excel dashboard. ¬†This client facing Excel dashboard could be pre-populated with program targets and development metrics to evaluate relative success of the proposals.¬†¬†Typical use case: Small-medium scale planning where forms are irregular and design is a priority. Scenario Builder allows users to develop programming scenarios within an Excel dashboard and then have masses automatically generated in Rhino that represent program targets.¬† Those masses can be categorized by use and their proportions constrained to pre-determined building footprints sizes or ratios.¬† After manual manipulation of the masses, Mass Reporter can report program yields and planning metrics back into a client-facing dashboard for comparison against program targets.¬†Typical use case: A range of planning scales with minimal variation in building typology.¬† Program variation and basic site capacity is a priority. City Builder allows users to model whole urban environments with grasshopper scripts from a single-line street network, drawn in either CAD or Rhino.¬† Right-of-Way widths, curbs, setbacks, building footprint and other information can get generated from grasshopper scripts. New typologies and modifications to boilerplate script elements can easily be generated within Grasshopper to make the environment project specific.¬† Using Mass Reporter, program yields and planning metrics can then be reported to client-facing dashboard.¬†Typical use case: Large scale planning where rule-based modeling and overall program tracking are a priority. WHAT‚ÄôS NEXT FOR MASS METRICS? We would love for you to show us! Our practice is continually evolving and our tools need to do the same.¬† If toolsets in Mass Metrics 2.0 doesn‚Äôt support your specific project please reach out to the development team (Mike Aziz, Brad Rogers, and Andrew Salveson).¬† The development team is here to assist and advise project teams on how we can improve on these toolsets. Most importantly, there is now a P+W repository for all those improvements.¬† So, as quickly as they are made, they can be shared. WHAT‚ÄôS IN THE MASS METRICS STARTER PACK? Mass Metrics User Guide Required Grasshopper plugins 2. Rhino and Excel Templates 3. Layer Naming Manual 5. Links to Sample Videos General Notes: 1.¬†Mass Metrics was developed to improve our planning work in the broadest sense.¬† The sample files were developed as templates, and customization will be required.¬† The Mass Metrics development team can assist and advise on customization during project start-up.¬† A ‚Äúscoping call‚Äù is recommended before implementation to discuss any changes. 2. Use of Mass Metrics requires adherence to standard layer naming conventions.¬† See more information in the Mass Metrics layer manual for details. 3. If improvements to the scripts or dashboard were made during the project, please upload your files back to the Digital Tools resource center so that we can share your improvements in later editions of Mass Metrics. Installation Instructions You will have to install all of the plugins included in the INSTALL ‚Äì plugins linked folder. If you have questions about how to do this, contact your local DA person. Usage ¬∑¬†If you are using the sample Rhino file (TEMPLATE.3dm) there should be no problems with the script. ¬∑¬†If you start from scratch you have to first check the unit system of Rhino. Work in the correct unit system. (VERY IMPORTANT!) Work with meters or feet. ¬∑¬†Try to create centrelines as continuous as possible. If they follow each other just join them. It increases the performance of the script and also makes it work. Try to avoid small centrelines. ¬∑¬†Make sure centrelines don‚Äôt extend after hitting one another. Also make sure centrelines touch to prevent funny geometry. ¬∑¬†For correct calculations, Phase and Use zones should not intersect with other Phase or Use zones; for instance, Phase 01 polyline should not collide with Phase 02 polyline. ¬∑¬†Don‚Äôt have extra phase layers and polylines within these layers otherwise all of the calculations will be incorrect. ¬∑¬†Don‚Äôt try to work on two different areas which are not combined in one Rhino file. If you have to use the script for another area, it is recommended to have it on another Rhino file and reuse the script. ¬∑¬†Provide your site boundary to the Centreline_0 Layer (NOTE: this is currently broken somewhat) ¬∑¬†You can create as many centrelines as possible in the same format, providing the street width after the underscore. For instance if you want the centreline to be 20m wide, the layer name which contains these objects should be named as: Centreline_20 You can colour the layers in the way you want, however for the Grasshopper script to see any newly created layers you must toggle the ‚Äúauto-update‚Äù boolean at the top left on and then off again. ¬∑¬†You can create as many phase layers and objects as you want with only one closed polyline within. Name the layers with this in this format. Phase 01, Phase 02, etc. Just be sure that they don‚Äôt overlap. Furthermore, don‚Äôt create empty ones. ¬∑¬†For the Use Zones you don‚Äôt have a limit of layers you can create as many layers as you want even if they are empty. Whenever you create a polyline within these layers script will allocate the blocks within to these functions and show you the total areas on your screen. ¬∑¬†If you want to write the numbers to a spreadsheet, open one excel file and click on the button in the Grasshopper script called ‚ÄòWRITE TO EXCEL‚Äô Version History 2.2 Improvements to Mass Reporter and City Builder based on project use feedback. 2.1 New Mass Reporter script with in-Rhino heads up display and improved functionality MassReporter now Script-based, EXE program installation no longer required (still linked through the _ARCHIVE folder) Renamed CityBuilder and ScnearioBuilder files, easier to find in folder structure Automated C+S Base Plan reporting built into Mass Metrics Excel 2.0 Introduction to CityBuilder, MassReporter, and ScenarioBuilder

title: Sharpen You Revit Tools ‚Äì Room Data Sheets
content: After publishing some Revit tool articles in previous newsletters we received positive feedback and many inquiries about available Revit productivity tools, and we continue talking about better Revit workflows using the tools we already have.¬†Today Jeff Ziemann (DTL in NYO) shares improved project workflows using the new tool ‚Äì Room Data Sheets (CTC Revit Express tools) and a well- known tool BIMLink (Ideate Software): After completing the first phase of a 25-story ambulatory care center in NYC, the team wanted to take a step back and think about how we could be more efficient in the second phase planning stages of the project, using tools available to us in Revit. There are two tools/workflows that we intend to use going forward in order to streamline planning and preparation for end user meetings. ¬∑ One is using BIMLink (or Spreadsheet link ) and existing room schedule templates to integrate user-generated program lists into Revit test fit plans. This workflow is already used across the firm in many projects. ¬∑ The other is using the new CTC tool Room Data Sheets ‚Äì a brand new tool which was rolled out with the latest update of CTC tools. It allows a utomate the tedious and time consuming task of creating consistent documentation for each room including plans, elevations, 3D views and schedules of finishes, fixtures, equipment and furniture. It even adds a filter to your schedules to filter information by room! https://ctcexpresstools.com/product/bim-project-suite-2017/#roomDataSheet In the early stages of the project, we generated program lists for 7 different departments, each with varying specialty rooms and requirements. Keeping these requests in line with the initial layouts became cumbersome because of the variety and quantity involved. In order to add another layer of organization, we wanted to use a workflow that keeps the program in check within Revit as the layouts developed from blocking plans to more realistic plans. Within the NYO project template is a schedule called ‚ÄúProgram ‚Äì Room Variances‚Äù . It‚Äôs a handy schedule for planning, as it allows you to compare the actual area of drawn rooms, to ‚Äútarget areas,‚Äù and highlights rooms that are outside of the boundary of the allowed variance from the target (You can insert PROGRAM ‚Äì Room Program Area Deltas schedule into your project from BIMList firm wide library). We used BIMLink , to maximize the effectiveness of this schedule, by exporting the schedule as a base, and then using excel to transition department programs into a format that will import all the desired rooms and areas into the Revit project. When re-imported back to Revit, all the required rooms will now exist in the project, ready to be placed. (Note: you can also use CTC Spreadsheet Link tool . The difference is it will not import automatically, you will need to trigger manual import ). Once placed within the test-fits, we can reference the ‚ÄúRoom Variances‚Äù schedule to confirm which rooms are missing, and which are overly generous or undersized, all in a single schedule. This saves the time of having to check back to the various excel program lists constantly, and keeps the test fits honest. It‚Äôs a method of making sure we are truly including all the users‚Äô requests and highlighting where we are compromising. As the team got further into the process and began laying out individual rooms, we ended up developing over 100 enlarged plans and corresponding elevations for use in end-user meetings, and eventually documentation. This became quite time consuming for the sheer volume we had to produce. For Phase 2, we intend to use the Room Data Sheets (RDS) CTC tool to expedite this process. After some exploration into this, the new tool is highly effective in generating all the desired views for a room data sheet (plans, elevations, ceilings, axons, schedules) with a few simple clicks. Once you set up the desired options for the view development, you can easily apply this to dozens of rooms to create many views and sheets very quickly. Without the tool, this process requires calling out the plan, calling out the ceiling plan, picking each elevation individually, and then picking your schedule. All this is done at once with this tool, and it should greatly increase the efficiency of the next phase of our project. Jeff has authored a MicroKnowledge card about how to use Room Data Sheets tool which you can fine here: https://mk.perkinswill.com/ Links to previous Revit tool articles: https://pulse.perkinswill.com/content/92872 https://pulse.perkinswill.com/content/92868 https://pulse.perkinswill.com/content/87071

title: Dynamo Player for Revit 2017
content: Dynamo is a visual scripting platform that extends Revit‚Äôs functionality, enabling you to perform operations that are unavailable in the standard interface or automate repetitive tasks. It has been available as an add-in to Revit since version 2015, but 2017 includes an additional feature called Dynamo Player, which allows you to run Dynamo scripts at the push of a button, without needing to open the Dynamo authoring environment. Dynamo and Dynamo Player are both accessed through the ‚ÄòManage‚Äô tab in Revit 2017. Dynamo Player simply provides a list of all Dynamo scripts that are stored in a particular directory. The library of P+W Dynamo scripts can be found at: S:\_Firmwide\Dynamo\DynamoPlayerScripts\. To change the directory Dynamo Player is accessing press the ‚Äòfolder‚Äô button in the upper left hand corner of the Dynamo Player window. To run a script press the ‚Äòplay‚Äô button to the left of that script. If custom inputs are required to run the script a separate window will pop up asking for additional information. (Note to developers: Use the ‚ÄòData Shapes‚Äô package to create these custom input windows.) To edit a script press the ‚Äòpencil‚Äô icon to the right of the script. Doing so will open that script in the Dynamo authoring environment. If you have an idea for a script that you would like to see developed and deployed to the Dynamo Player library submit your request via the HackStack custom tools request form here: https://dp.perkinswill.com/hackstack/ . All requests are discussed and vetted for development on the bi-weekly Custom Tools call led by Iffat Mai , 12-1 Eastern the 2nd and 4th Tuesdays of the month. If you‚Äôre pretty handy with Dynamo and want to develop scripts reach out to Luc Deckinga , P+W‚Äôs Digital Practice Manager for Computational Design.
