title: Finding IrisVR Prospect‚Äôs Limits
content: In search of the best combination of quality, workflow and scope Senior Project Designer in Atlanta, Randy Maxwell chose to explore IrisVR Prospect following his use of Enscape, Lumion and Kubity. An avid technologist Randy made a personal purchase of the newest Oculus Rift including the additional Touch controllers to use alongside the Atlanta office‚Äôs HTC Vive. On two separate occasions, Randy presented virtual reality to the client, Saint Jude Children‚Äôs Hospital.¬† The first presentation paired Prospect with the HTC Vive/Steam.¬† Later, Randy brought the new Oculus Rift to use with Prospect during the second presentation.¬† Prospect recognized the Touch controllers as Vive controllers which prevented their use, but did not lessen the experience for the clients. Both presentations were very successful and generated excitement in the client.¬† After their experience with the VR presentations, they felt more engaged and better able to understand the design and scale of their projects, having fun in the process. Workflow The original geometry in Revit was exported to SketchUp 2017 where the foliage and tree maker plugin, 3DArcStudio was used to add vegetation. ¬†The SketchUp file used for the presentation was 160 MB, 7 million triangle and 4 million faces.¬† The processing time for Prospect was two minutes and with the ability to save a ready-to-present file to a local hard drive. ¬†This critically important feature allows for the VR presentation to be opened without an Internet connection. VR Hardware Preference Randy prefers the Oculus Rift over the HTC Vive.¬† During the course of the project the Oculus Rift proved to have two compelling advantages. First, it took less time and was more straight-forward to setup than the Vive.¬† The Vive‚Äôs larger ‚ÄòVR Room‚Äô(16 feet diagonally) requires more physical room and its sensors and stand take more time to set up.¬† Randy notes he has never witnessed anyone‚Äôs movement exceed more than a few step in any direction.¬† The smaller VR room of the Oculus Rift is sufficient and its small compact sensors are quick to set up. Travel with the Oculus Rift is easier as well.¬† When flying all of the Oculus Rift equipment fits in a carryon.¬† Since the Vive equipment needs stands for the sensors it has to be checked. Another difference between the two is the weight of the headset.¬† Randy found the Vive headset to be heavier and more cumbersome.¬† Although both the Vive and Oculus Rift headsets require a tethered connection to a computer the lighter weight of the Oculus headset made it more comfortable. Randy could not discern a notable difference in resolution between the headsets, but did find the Oculus Rift‚Äôs environment to be a bit brighter. Software Comparisons In his efforts to create VR Randy has used Prospect, Enscape, Lumion and Kubity.¬† Enscape and Prospect can process both Revit and SketchUp.¬† Prospect provides free accounts with some limitations. Kubity works primarily with Sketchup and the VR is in beta. It looks like it has potential. Randy finds the real-time rendering of Enscape interesting, but the resolution of its VR environment subpar.¬† Enscape has very nice atmospheric editing that can be reflected in its VR environment.¬† Like Enscape, Lumion provides real-time rendering.¬† Although it creates 360-degree panoramas, it does not have true VR capability. Lessons Learned Randy‚Äôs biggest lesson learn is not to heighten the client‚Äôs expectations and promise them a VR presentation in the first place.¬† Plan to use VR as an added surprise and enhancement.¬† This is such new technology and so many things can go wrong.¬† Randy notes some of his co-workers whose presentation went badly when an Internet connection could not be establish on location.¬† He also points out that not all spaces can accommodate larger VR rooms.¬† Before the client experiences the VR environment, be sure to communicate the VR presentation is representational, and not real or photorealistic. Processing Statistics for Prospect Below Randy provides his latest tests using SketchUp files of the Saint Jude Children‚Äôs Hospital project at varying levels of detail. SU/Prospect Test 1 161 MB, 7 million triangulations, 2 minutes to process SU/Prospect Test 2 171 MB, 23 million triangulations, approximately one hour to process SU/Prospect Test 3 179 MB, 38 million triangulations, approximately one hour to process, but did not always process successfully

title: Experimenting with Microsoft Hololens During the Design Process

author.name: Nick Cameron
author.description: American trucker who has been featured on the History channel reality television series Ice Road Truckers and its spinoff series IRT: Deadliest Roads.

content: Chicago recently had the opportunity to test the Hololens during a master planning competition, focusing heavily on the hardware‚Äôs application to the design and concept phase of project delivery. The learning curve for development was initially a bit difficult, as developing for the Hololens requires working with and publishing models through Unity. Having never used Unity before and having little experience with writing scripts I reached out to Simon Chavez in the Seattle office to help get started. ¬†After working together for two weeks on and off I was able to get a functional understanding of how the software works to write and develop for the hardware. Initially it showed promise, having the ability to effectively produce a ‚Äúphysical‚Äù model with a few clicks was a quick way to get a better feel for the composition of the master plan we were developing. It quickly became apparent shortly after getting the process to work that there were three big drawbacks to the hardware‚Ä¶ 1.)¬†¬†Isolating the Experience 2.)¬†¬†Little Interest after Initial Impact 3.)¬†¬†Comfort of Use Isolation: While exciting to experience a new technology, we found that the Hololens makes engagement very unrewarding to those not seeing the project through the headset. Our first impression was that it would make the design more immersive both for internal design development and for design delivery. As we used it through the course of the project it became clear that the lack of tools within the model viewer was one of the biggest drawbacks. We were able to program the ability to scale, move, and rotate the model through verbal and hand gestures, but in the end we found that it became more of a gimmick when compared to the other presentation materials developed. Initial Impact: After the initial impression of trying the Hololens or the fanfare of seeing a co-worker wearing the hardware we found that interest quickly dropped off. People would differ to simply asking how it looks as opposed to trying it on for themselves. Internally you could see rooms light up when someone was playing with the device, but after everyone had a go, there would be very little interest or follow-up after having tried the hardware. Comfort of Use: This wasn‚Äôt necessarily a revelation after having used the Samsung Gear in numerous client meetings already, but as with that headset, clients can be very apprehensive when it comes to wearing the hardware. This made larger scale engagement difficult, as the headset was also viewed with a degree of stigma in our actual client meeting. And as mentioned above, the isolation of the experience made conveying the concepts too difficult to integrate into the presentation itself, making it more of an add-on after the Q+A. Additionally the commands and interface are hard to get comfortable with so most first time users find it intimidating and quickly take it off after trying it on for a few seconds. The current state of the Hololens makes its integration with our design process both difficult and distracting. For what we got out of it in our client interactions it feels like a tool that you bring out to ‚ÄúWow‚Äù a client for the purposes of winning a project, but then shelving it once the project is won. For the Holoens to make sense as a design tool I think a few features would need to be implemented in the devloper build kit to make it more useful. First would be the ability to design within the software on the Hololens. Ideally having the ability to generate shapes or place pre built objects would be a great feature. If it were possible to actually generate, or at the very least manipulate a scheme and then export it back into a software such as Rhino, I would have found much more value in the peripheral from a design perspective. Even giving it a real time link up in the way Enscape or Lumions Live Sync work with another modeling software would be a step in the right direction. The second feature that would bring some merit without dramatically overhauling how the software currently works would be the ability to generate new views. Features like a section box would allow for the design to be observed on more than just an aesthetic level. The ability to examine the building closer in section in ways that could be actively manipulated would bring attention to design critiques that could be translated during the design process. This could also make the Hololens more integral in client interactions because the depth and complexity of the model can quickly be translated beyond drawings in a visual manner for the client to quickly understand, taking out the need for the client to internally visualize a conversation. Making it possible to stream line the communication and reduce the possibility of things being lost in translation during design review and coordination meetings would further immerse users in a Minority Report style enviornment that many have the expectation of experiencing before even trying the Hololens. A similar method could also be useful if given the ability to place perspective cameras into the model to generate stereo panoramic views in real time, the same way that the Gear VR is used. Giving the client the ability to place a person akin to Google Maps street view anywhere in the model and having it properly scale would make the design more relatable and the tool more valuable. Generally I‚Äôm glad to have had the opportunity to work with the Hololens. While I am disappointed in the current state of the hardware it is important to keep in mind that this is still being developed for and the future will undoubtedly hold vast improvments to the way we read and write for the Hololens. It‚Äôs just a question of how long it takes to get there.

title: VR PROJECT STORY DEVELOPMENT
content: VR PROJECT STORY DEVELOPMENT GUIDE FOR A SUCCESSFUL PRESENTATION A VR PROJECT PROCESS FOR STORY AND PRESENTATION ADAPTED FROM IRIS VR ARTICLE ON STORY AND PRESENTATION IN VR Project teams have the desire to now make the best of VR for help in conveying their specific story and process for the design of the client‚Äôs building, product, or plan. ¬†The hardware and technology make this possible. ¬†But how to use the hardware and software in a manner reminiscent to the craft of storytelling¬†remains an allusive practice that can do the most in the least amount of time and effort. ¬†Please consider the following questions in defining the story that VR should convey. WHAT WILL BE THE PRIMARY OBJECTIVE FOR THE PRESENTATION THAT WILL USE SOME ASPECT OF VR? ARE THERE ANY KEY EXTERIOR OR INTERIOR SPATIAL THEMES THAT ARE MOST IMPORTANT TO THE PROJECT? DID THE PROJECT TEAM USE AN INNOVATIVE PROCESS,¬†PARTI, BIG IDEA, OR CONCEPTUAL GESTURE? We now have a good understanding of the parti and process for why this is a great project. WHAT WERE THE SERIES OF DECISIONS MADE BY THE TEAM TO DEVELOP THE PROJECT DESIGN? HOW DID THESE SET OF CHOICES OR THE DECISION-MAKING PROCESS BEST REPRESENT THE CLIENT‚ÄôS ORIGINAL REQUEST FOR DESIGN SERVICES? We now have the steps that reinforce the project process that elaborates the decision-making narrative which is why the project team answered the client‚Äôs initial question with the project proposal. CONSIDER THE USE OF VR AS AN AID IN A MORE PERSONAL OR FIRST-PERSON EXPERIENCE THAT MOVES THROUGH THE CENTRAL MOMENTS THAT SHAPE THE DECISION-MAKING PROCESS,¬†PARTI, AND DEVELOPMENT OF THE PROJECT. REFINE THE CRITICAL DECISION MAKING MOMENTS OF THE PROJECT DESIGN ¬†TO 5 AND NO MORE THAN 10 STEPS ALONG THE PROCESS OF THE PROJECT WORK. CONSIDER THE AVAILABLE DIGITAL PROJECT MODEL AND MATERIALS FOR THE KEY¬†DECISION-MAKING¬†MOMENTS. IT MAY NOT BE NECESSARY THAT THE MODELS AND MATERIALS DEVELOP TO A PARTICULAR LEVEL OF FINISH. In the next article, we can discuss the various levels of software and hardware for development of the digital story in VR and if the project story and process is appropriate for this medium.

title: Stingray VR Pilot: Is Stingray for You?
content: VR Pilot Using Stingray with Autodesk Consulting The Atlanta Dairies Project Team and Digital Practice recently finished piloting Stingray with assistance from Autodesk Consulting. Autodesk‚Äôs Stingray is a gaming engine for creating real-time design visualizations and virtual reality experiences. As an Autodesk product, Stingray benefits from integration and workflows with other Autodesk products. Exploring these workflows and benefits was one of the key objectives of the project. Thank you to Justin Cooper, Steve Summerford and Allen Post of the Atlanta Dairies project team for their participation in this pilot. Project Description The Atlanta Dairies consists of 40,000 sf retail & entertainment space surrounding a 17,000 sf or 0.4 acre courtyard, featuring dozens species of plants and trees. The courtyards were the primary focus of the presentation. In particular representing the range of vegetation realistically and as recognizable species was a high priority. The Outcome The completed VR scene was console-driven as a standalone executable on a Windows computer. Due to the vegetation‚Äôs level of detail and quantity, the Vive headset was unable to maintain a rate of 90 frames per second. Reducing the vegetation‚Äôs detail or dividing the scene up would allow the Vive to maintain the 90 fps. Quickly swapping the vegetation for less detail was counter to the presentation‚Äôs purpose. Unfortunately, dividing the scene up required labor beyond our available time. Even so, the project was successful at helping us to understand Stingray‚Äôs capabilities, limitations and workflow. Why Consider Stingray? It may be the most viable option for designers and teams looking to utilize VR with varying degrees of commitment and skill. Three features adding to this are an integrated workflow, access to material shaders and visual scripting. Integrated Workflow ‚Äì Many game engines familiar to the AEC industry require workflows developed for the game industry. A big reason these workflows are different, is the VR scene is the end product for game companies. Stingray‚Äôs workflow should feel familiar to those in our industry. It integrates with Revit through a one-click cloud service called Autodesk Live. This service optimizes the geometry, maintains BIM information and converts Autodesk materials to standard materials that all game engines need. After automatically downloading, the resulting file can be explored as-is in a real-time environment using Live. If the file is opened in Stingray, minimal effort is needed to advance it to a true VR scene for use with the Vive or Occulus Rift. Those willing to expand their skills a little may apply pre-created enhancements¬†of various kinds. Access to Material Shaders ‚Äì Another application is not required to change materials. The modifying, swapping and creating of materials can occur within Stingray. This includes animated materials such as fire and water, which where both used in the Atlanta Dairies project. Materials can also be saved and shared between Stingray VR scenes. Visual Scripting ‚Äì This user-friendly feature allows those without programming knowledge to add interactivity to VR scenes. Blocks of logic called flow nodes can be wired together to author experiences for our clients. ¬†A few common examples would be doors opening and moving furniture or other ojects within the scene.¬†If you prefer text-based scripting instead Stingray uses the Lau Language. The Lua scripting language is known for being lightweight and fast. ¬†It is a great choice for beginners and advanced scripters. ¬†Both Lau scripts and the visual scripts can be saved an reused on future projects. Hardware Requirements Like other game engine providers, Autodesk‚Äôs official hardware requirements are the minimal required to run the application, not an immersive VR experience. To develop and deliver VR for architecture and interior design projects Digital Practice recommends a Core i7 at 2.6GHz or higher, 32-48 GB of RAM and an nVidia 980Ti, GTX 1070 or GTX 1080 graphics card. Stingray, like other gaming engine software will not run on Perkins+Will‚Äôs standard production nodes. VR Equipment Compatibility Both the Vive and Occulus Rift are compatible with Stingray as well as Gear VR and Google Cardboard. Autodesk is developing compatibility for the Hololens.

title: VR NEWS: NORTHEAST GEORGIA HOSPITAL SYSTEM CLINIC MODULE WORKSHOP, ATLANTA OFFICE

author.name: Nick Cameron
author.description: American trucker who has been featured on the History channel reality television series Ice Road Truckers and its spinoff series IRT: Deadliest Roads.

content: NGPG BUFORD CLINIC MODULE WORKSHOP NORTHEAST GEORGIA HOSPITAL SYSTEM A VR EXPERIENCE WITH NGHS CLIENT BY KATIE ANDERSON and DAMIEN LINNEN, ATLANTA OFFICE Northeast Georgia Hospital System ‚Äì NGPG Buford Clinic Module Workshop Our team has been working with the Northeast Georgia Hospital System to develop a clinic module standard, implemented first at a new 60,000 square foot facility in Buford, Georgia, but designed for future renovation and new projects. During our most recent workshop, we utilized the VR system to help the client understand space and sight lines within the team work core, which they had previously had difficulty with understanding and imagining possibilities through diagrams and drawings alone. One of the objectives of the workshop was to evaluate the differences between a six exam room and a 12 exam room clinic module. We had previously held meetings showing diagrams of module options but had been unable to reach a firm consensus. Using the VR system, they were able to quickly determine that a 12 exam room module was too deep and would lead to undesirable travel distances for clinical staff and patients. We were also able to demonstrate that the six exam room configuration allows for greater penetration of daylighting into the teamwork core, which was a desirable feature. Additionally, they were able to experience multiple configurations of on-stage off-stage work environments for the staff, which helped them solidify their decision. 6 Exam Room Module Repeated 12 Exam Room Module 6 Exam Room Module: Staff Work 12¬†Exam Room Module: Staff Work In a previous experience, the client with another architectural firm and their Lean consultant had built a ‚Äúcardboard city‚Äù of their clinic design, which cost more than $80,000. The client team reported to us that it was a lot of money, a lot of effort and that they didn‚Äôt get the desired results from the exercise. After our meeting, we received many compliments from the client about the work we had done, including how powerful the VR experience had been for them. One member of the client team said: ‚Äúhere comes P+W with this virtual reality approach that would have saved all of that money!‚Äù One member of the client team said: ‚Äúhere comes P+W with this virtual reality approach that would have saved all of that money!‚Äù Perkins+Will, Genesis and Client Team We set up a projector to display the view from the VR headset onto the wall outside the conference room so that multiple people could watch while one wore the headset. Perkins+Will Damien Linnen with Client Representative in a Full VR Environment Multiple client team members tried the headset and helped to quickly reach a decision on the direction to proceed with the design of the clinic module.

title: CTC Tools for Revit Update
content: Last month we have rolled out an upgrade for CTC Tools in Revit. This upgrade not only improves the tools we already had (some of them are teams‚Äô favorites), but also introduces ¬†new productivity tools for project teams and model managers. All these tools ¬†can be found under Revit Express Tools tab in Revit. ¬†Each tool has a link ¬†to YouTube video.¬†. Note: YouTube Videos may not play on the node ‚Äì copy and paste the link to your laptop browser. If you have additional questions, ask you DA or contact CTC support. You can email support@ctcexpresstools.com or call toll free:¬†866-941-1181¬†Local: 952-941-1181. Following is a brief overview of most popular productivity tools currently available to PW users. CTC BIM Project Suite: BIM Project Suite Is a collection of very useful and widely used in PW tools. Some PW favorites in this group are: BIM List Browser Must know Gives you an access to PW content libraries. More info can be found here: BIM LIst 101 For Users Quick Select Selects elements by filtering specific categories or parameter values. Search elements that match filter criteria can either be added to, removed from or replace the currently selected items. Renumbering Provides a fast and simple way to renumber your rooms and doors . Auto-swapping avoids duplicates. Alphanumeric sequential numbering. Add separators and suffices to room and door numbers. Revision Manager Lists revision information, including view and sheet associations, and allows the results to be saved to a spreadsheet file. Identify which parts of a model were affected by a revision. Validate that revision best practices are being followed. Use together with Revit Cloud Remover from BIM manager Suite Room Data Sheets¬†New! Generates 3D, Plan, Reflected Ceiling, Elevation, Schedule and Legend views. Controls naming, order, placement and presentation of views on sheetsPreview sheets to be created and adjust spacing, size and scaleManaging hundreds of sheets containing room and space data throughout the projectSave and load settings of previous configurations.¬†This tool in new and can potentially save teams a lot of time. Give it a try! Room Family Manager¬†Unsung hero Room Family Manager enables defining, maintaining, and validating the family content of each room type definitions.Build room type definitions in a spreadsheetBuild room type definitions from existing Revit roomsAutomatically place family content in your model based on room type assignmentsValidate that rooms in your model contain required families Especially efficient when used together with Room Data Sheets! Schedule XL Available to all PW users now Creates Schedule View or a Drafting view from Spreadsheet Data so the data from sources outside of Revit can be included on sheets and printiedCan create schedule views from one or more worksheets in one or more spreadsheets.Can update the schedule views when the original spreadsheet has changed.Can be configured to automatically update when the Revit project is opened if the original spreadsheet has changed ‚Äì be careful with your settings. Spreadsheet Link Popular in PW Facilitates Bi-Directional Spreadsheet Linking. Exports data (including type and/or ¬†instance parameters) from Revit elements to a spreadsheet where the data can be edited and then imported and applied back in to the Revit model. Can also be used to create new unplaced rooms, spaces, areas, zones and sheets. CTC BIM Manager Suite: BIM manager suite ¬†tools are intended to be used for model and content maintenance. The new tool in this Suite is Family Checker . However PW has other and perhaps more useful tool available for this purpose. More Info here Library analysis tool (content analyzer) Some of PW favorites in this group are: Project Cleaner Deletes views, sheets and Revit Links.Useful for preparing models for consultants and or to lighten¬†consultants¬†models ¬†before linking them into your projects.Note: Etransmit has similar functionality but less configurable. Revit Cloud Remover This tool makes it fast and easy to remove non-issued revision clouds from your project. use together with Revision Manager from BIM Project suite. Dimension Checker Identifies dimension strings which are using the dimension override options and presents for review. Additional filter options can be used to narrow the search results Family Processor Content maintenance favorite! Allows ¬†to define one or multiple changes to one or more Revit family files, and then process those changes in batch. Can audit families, batch upgrade ¬†and compact them and do many other tricks with parameters and materials. CTC SuperDoor Configurator : SuperDoor includes content (Revit families) for building a nearly infinite variety of doors, and software which provides a graphical wizard interface that guides Revit users through selecting/configuring door components and then placing them into their Revit project. PW uses our own content on CTC software platform. It includes curtain wall doors, wall-hosted doors with size by instance, and wall-hosted doors with size by type. They are color coded. CTC BIM Batch Suite: New Suite of tools . Family Exporter Use to extract families before file purging, for archival and to harvest loadable families from projects. Family Loader Configurable, can be used to ¬†batch load previously archived families in case of file corruption. Project and Family Upgrader This tool is avable in PW for evaluation and testing.¬†Currently we use Etransmit. Note: revit files need to be audited and cleaned up prior to upgrade

title: Design Application Assist in Revit
content: Have you ever submitted a request about a Revit problem only to be asked additional questions including, file name, location, sync status, worksets, node name, etc, etc? The Design Application Assist tool in Revit (2016 & 2017) will collect that information and additional data automatically from your open file and submit it to the helpdesk. There is also an option to submit a request for assistance in finding/creating Revit content. DA Assistance creates a helpdesk ticket which will be assigned to your office DAM . The tool automatically collects data from currently open document: name and location, size, version, workset info, active view name, etc. ¬†You just ¬†just need to describe the problem. Content Assistance creates a special helpdesk ticket which will be visible to all DAMs through helpdesk and a dedicated slack channel. Additionally, your office DAM will be notified in his/her own slack channel. This will minimise duplication of efforts and promote collaboration in content creation. Additionally each of these tools has live links to useful self-help and learning resources. Special cases: When submitting from cloud nodes, the tickets will be routed manually ‚Äì not clear which office they belong to based on the machine name. These tool are not intended to be used by admin account. Under the Hood ‚Äì Information for DAMs DA ¬†Assistance creates ¬†and handles the routing of helpdesk ticket exactly the same way as PWitter Helpdesk tool, and it also collects additional troubleshooting information. Content Assistance tool creates a ticket in a special helpdesk category ‚Äì Content Request. This category is visible to all, but it will not send you an email.¬†Roboandrew will notify all DAs via Content_request slack channel and ¬†also individual DAs based on office code in user machine name. title: HTC VIVE Office Fit-Out Gear for VR
content: HTC VIVE GEAR RECOMMENDATION CONSIDER THE FOLLOWING FOR A VR-CAPABLE OFFICE Virtual Reality¬†(VR) continues to gain momentum in more and more Perkins+Will offices around the world. ¬†In some offices, the equipment has become a dedicated environment for project development and experience in VR and others; it travels with the project team to client meetings, pursuits, speaking engagements, and marketing events. title: Computational Design Experience @ P+W
content: ‚ÄúThe future is already here ‚Äì it‚Äôs just not very evenly distributed‚Äù ‚Äì William Gibson In an attempt to identify individuals with experience using Computational Design tools, specifically two common visual scripting platforms, Grasshopper and Dynamo, the Digital Practice team conducted a survey of people in all Perkins+Will offices who had expressed interest in computational design. Some of our findings are shown below. If you would like to be included in our findings you can take the survey here . # of Respondents: 133 # of Offices Represented: 18 # of Grasshopper Users and Experience per Office (Darker Color = More Experience) # of Dynamo Users and Experience per Office (Darker Color = More Experience) What are we trying to do? Our goal is to support the network of computational designers throughout the firm and create a framework in which the effort and knowledge of a single person can benefit everyone in the firm, regardless of their location. Additionally, we want knowledge of how to execute a computational workflow to be exchanged between offices as readily as the work created from it. In many ways Perkins+Will operates as a network of individual offices rather than as a monolithic entity. Using this structure as a strength, we leverage people‚Äôs unique insights into their local markets and react nimbly to local conditions. Unfortunately, this distribution also presents challenges to efficiently collaborating and sharing resources between offices. Even within a single office, one studio or practice area may not be aware of the work being done by others. By their nature, computational design processes must be well-defined and, once created, a script may be used by many people. The barrier to sharing this work isn‚Äôt technological, but rather a lack of communication, both within and between offices.¬†We want resources and knowledge to have value beyond the silo of their creation and to have positive effects throughout the firm. How does the information from this survey help us? The information we collected in the computational design survey gives us a strategy to support the use of computational tools in every Perkins+Will office. From the data collected we have a picture of who at Perkins+Will have experience with or interest in visual scripting tools, as well as where those tools reside. Applying the economic metaphor of supply and demand, each office can be thought of as a market. The graphs above illustrate the supply of computational knowledge that exists in each office. The demand is the degree to which design leadership wants to use computational tools on their projects. Offices, studios, and practice areas that want to leverage computational design can now see if they have resources in their location to undertake those tasks themselves. If the supply doesn‚Äôt meet the demand within an office they need to either develop those skills or reach out to the firm-wide computational design network for support. For offices where these skills are insufficient, there are two solutions: we can train designers to be proficient, or we can use existing talent in another office. Ideally both are used in combination.¬†To build skills, designers are first trained to use computational design tools through online courses, followed by in-person workshops. Eventually designers are paired with a mentor, a more experienced computational designer, on a project. It is the mentor‚Äôs role to guide development efforts and get the less experienced designers over the hurdles they will encounter. One of the most difficult aspects of learning computational tools is getting stuck trying to debug errors during the initial learning curve, which can be steep. Having a mentor to steer the designer around obstacles helps alleviate this roadblock. The goal is for the designer to be self-sufficient by the end of the project and for them to operate autonomously on their next computational task. If an appropriate mentor exists within the office they can help to bring up the proficiency of those around them; if not, a computational designer from another office can be brought in to temporarily fill the skills gap until local staff are independently capable.Knowledge has momentum. Offices that have a critical mass of computational design knowledge are able to support and mentor other interested individuals and to execute computational workflows on local projects. Design leaders quickly recognize the power of computational workflows once they are exposed to them through projects in their office. One successful project inevitably leads to other projects looking to replicate and build upon that success. We must both support¬†designers‚Äô skill¬†development and bring awareness of their value to those who direct projects. How are we supporting these efforts? There is a Slack team for designers to communicate with one another regardless of location, so they can support and learn from each other. Join the conversation at PWcomputationalDesign.slack.com/signup Join the bi-weekly call the 1st and 3rd Thursdays of the month, where we feature projects using computational design and discuss the ever-evolving use of these tools within Perkins+Will. Contact Luc Deckinga , Digital Practice Manager for Computational Design to be added to the meeting invitation. 2-Day workshops training staff in Dynamo for Revit¬†have begun. Contact your office Design Applications Manager for more information and let them know you would like to attend. Dynamo scripts created by designers across the firm that extend the functionality of Revit and automate repetitive tasks have been collected in a central location. They can be found here ( S:\_Firmwide\Dynamo\DynamoPlayerScripts ) or accessed through the Dynamo Player in Revit 2017. We are currently developing a central repository of all computational scripts created by Perkins+Will designers. This catalog ( dp.perkinswill.com/catalog ) is currently in beta. Stay tuned for more information in a future Digital Practice newsletter. If you have any comments or questions about this survey or other Computational Design efforts at Perkins+Will please reach out to Luc Deckinga , Digital Practice Manager for Computational Design. title: 2017 AEC Technology Symposium + Hackathon ‚Äì New York

author.name: Nick Cameron
author.description: American trucker who has been featured on the History channel reality television series Ice Road Truckers and its spinoff series IRT: Deadliest Roads.

content: check out the map here! Every year Thornton Tomasetti hosts an AEC hackathon in New York to bring together technologically-minded AEC professionals. In a two day hackathon, teams prototype new technology and processes to advance the field. This year, the symposium and hackathon were attended by Anton Szilasi of Dallas, Saeran Vasanthakumar of Toronto, and Andrew Salveson of New York. Saeran and Andrew‚Äôs team, BEnMap ‚Äì Building Energy Map Our won for the greatest potential impact. Project BEnMap ‚Äì Building Energy Map Inspiration With federal- and state-level support for sustainability politically unlikely, the future of sustainable building will fall to the municipal level. Thankfully 15 major cities across the United States have passed legislation requiring reporting of building energy metrics. Boston is one of those cities. What we made We created a map to visualize various energy metrics for buildings within the city of Boston, including site and source EUI, greenhouse has intensity, EnergyStar score, and others, as well as calculated metrics such as the percent difference from 2030 targets. What it does The map filters and displays information about the buildings that have been reported by metric and by building type. A user can also look up a building by address. The aim is to inform people about how their cities and citizens are doing with respect to energy use: the map shows them who has reported and who hasn‚Äôt, as well as how those who have reported are doing. With the map a user can answer questions like, ‚ÄúWho are the highest producers of greenhouse gases in my city?‚Äù or ‚ÄúHow green is the building I work in?‚Äù How we built it We had to clean data from the public repository listed at https://data.cityofboston.gov/ to more accurately represent buildings and ignore outliers. We filtered the data, matched it to building footprints by tax parcel ID, and added additional, novel metrics. What‚Äôs next for BEnMap We would love to add more cities, perhaps even a GIS server and database to keep track of the entire country! Built With OpenLayers Google Places API City of Boston Data P+W Participants Saeran Vasanthakumar (Toronto) Andrew Salveson (New York) AEC Hackathon 4.0 ‚Äì San Francisco AEC Hackathon 4.0 was held in San Francisco January 6th through January 8th at the Microsoft Reactor Space in SOMA, San Francisco. Luc Deckinga and Andrew Salveson joined an engineer from Integral to create CaptainHook , a tool to help teams version control their files using Git. Traditional version control does not work for many project files because the differences between files are understood by the differencing algorithms. CaptainHook provides a way to send files to a custom differencing service, automatically adding difference reports to a project repository as a team works. The P+W team did not win the grand prize, but they did receive recognition for producing a tool that was actually complete and usable on Monday morning! title: Make donning VR gear your resolution for 2017!

author.name: Nick Cameron
author.description: American trucker who has been featured on the History channel reality television series Ice Road Truckers and its spinoff series IRT: Deadliest Roads.

content: In keeping with a long tradition of using innovative research and new technologies to advance both design and client experience, Perkins+Will DC office now offers virtual reality (VR) immersion to enhance client participation in the design process. The firm‚Äôs Collaborative Area for Virtual Exploration, or CAVE, enables use of state-of-the-art VR immersion tools in their design process so their clients now can more directly share the excitement, wonder and resolution of practical solutions as the design process unfolds. ‚ÄúCAVE makes it possible to communicate the complexity of shapes and forms that would not otherwise be apparent in 2D plans or elevations. Clients can be immersed early on as the built environment is being designed, and experience the space as if it is already completed,‚Äù says Tim Bakos, Principal and Director of Operations for the Washington, DC office. CAVE offers a simple, one-button click from the most commonly used design tools (Revit, Rhino or SketchUp, for example) to provide a wholly immersive design experience for the project team and their clients. As clients explore the evolving design process, Perkins+Will also builds a deeper level of stakeholder agreement earlier in the design process, when confirmed buy-in is so critical to schedule and budget management. ‚ÄúWe can save our clients both time and money by eliminating the ambiguity or hesitancy that might come from an incomplete understanding of the proposed design.¬†Ultimately, we can also improve satisfaction with the finished project,‚Äù says Bakos. Perkins+Will uses their CAVE to prove, or edit, important features of their designs, for example, confirming sight lines connect doctors to patients in a hospital project, or to remove blind spots from security in a public lobby. ‚ÄúWe have photorealistically rendered immersive environments in different color and material palettes, too, so stakeholders can experience key features of the design ‚Äì as we study them ‚Äì so we can more convincingly earn their buy-in.‚Äù Once schematics are complete and construction documents are underway, Perkins+Will also uses virtual immersion to better detect cross-disciplinary conflicts. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs hard to miss a sprinkler or duct conflict with an architectural bulkhead when you‚Äôre staring right at it in virtual 3D space,‚Äù says Justin Benjamin, a Perkins+Will digital applications manager who sees this as an evolution of the more typical digital clash detection performed with Revit model files received from Perkins+Will engineering partners. ‚ÄúWe haven‚Äôt had a single new user enter their own, process model without discovering something new about their work ‚Äì at times running back to their desk to act on their findings right away.‚Äù In addition to enriching the design process at every phase, Perkins+Will plans to use the technology with commercial building clients to create virtual showrooms that will entice prospective tenants to lease vacant suites.¬†Multiple personalized virtual versions of space can be created for marketing at a fraction of the cost of building a spec suite.¬†Perkins+Will is also exploring the rapid delivery of virtual test-fits for brokers who are marketing turnover spaces, giving clients a leg up when trying to secure new anchor tenants. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs clear this tool is allowing our clients to experience evolving design ideas in a whole new way,‚Äù says Bakos. ‚ÄúAnd while we augment stakeholder engagement with this and other innovative technologies, we are improving the ROI for all parties.‚Äù

title: Revizto Pilot
content: Last year several offices and project have tested Revizto for collaboration and visualization. Revizto is a collaboration and visualization software which integrates with multiple platforms: Revit, Navisworks ,AutoCAD, Civil 3D, SketchUp and ArchiCAD. It enables easy collaboration between all project stakeholders and allows effortless workflow from quite large Revit models directly to VR (Oculus and HTC Vive viewers). Revizto VR on Unilever project from PW Digital Practice on Vimeo . ¬†Password is DAIt has several unique and useful features : Issue Tracker enables efficient team collaboration workflow with different levels of details for various stakeholders. It seamlessly connects team collaboration workspace with the various software platforms for production and management. 2D-3D integration allows jumping from sheets directly to 3D model Bi-directional integration with Navisworks and Revit for clash detection and resolution. After the project is uploaded to the Revizto cloud, it is immediately available to be viewed in VR ‚Äì Oculus and HTC Vive viewers are included with install. NYO Unilever (PM- Danny Maghuyop, DTL ‚Äì Phillip Leidy) team pioneered many features of Revizto on a large project. Following is some of their feedback: The overall ¬†experience with Revizto has been positive. We have made good use of the visualization and were using some of issue tracker functions early on. Team Engagement We have had buy in on its use from the Architectural and MEP teams as it helped with visualizing locations and made finding routing for mechanical systems much easier. Structural was much less engaged though there can be a great value in having them be part of the coordination effort it Revizto. User Value In coordination meetings it was extremely easy to work through difficult or tight locations and find solutions when all the team members were together and looking at a live model. The rendering is simple and the model is reactive. It was also valuable on conference calls and we needed show the model or explain a location more thoroughly. Cutting a simple section and creating a quick visualization was its strong suit. While overall experience was positive and Unilever team recommended using the software on the next large NYO project, we did have some technical difficulties: In the middle of the year there were some issues with Revizto running on the nodes ‚Äì this has been resolved in the new version which is installed and works without glitches on the nodes since September. Licensing schema was not flexible and license tracking was lacking details. Revizto team is working on better license tracking for next version, to be available in February.

title: Clarity upgrade to v2017.1
content: On Tuesday January 31st we update our clarity software to the newest version. ¬† This new version has plenty of small fixes and improvements. ¬† You can see more information in the Clarity help section here . ¬† The two primary features that you may be interested to use are; scripted tasks for Revit macros and Dynamo scripts, and the ability to create task sequences. If you‚Äôre not familiar with Dynamo yet, one of the main advantages of the new Dynamo Player in Revit 2017 is that you don‚Äôt need to know anything about visual scripting to take advantage of the process automations scripts that have been created by others, which can now be run by Clarity on a schedule basis. ¬† The firmwide script library on our S drive is accessed through clarity for task setup. ¬† We are constantly collecting new scripts and posting them there to further increase the ability of all projects to automate more day to day tasks. ¬†With this new feature in Clarity you now have the option to run scripts manually in dynamo player (for Revit 2017) or schedule them through clarity . ¬† In addition to dynamo scripts we can also use macros (which is like an addin without the button) which can be used in various ways; to save back to central (changing your file), to pre-process an operation on a detached model just for printing and export (similar to an old addin we had called NPLT) or to extract information to excel. Task sequences introduces the ability for you to put a bunch of tasks bundled together. ¬† This makes sure that they will run in a certain order, which may become important as we introduce running macros and scripts on your model. ¬† This is as simple as creating a task that allows you to select from all the other tasks you have in your project. ¬† This will allow you to perform ‚Äòpre-task‚Äô items to your model with scripts or macros. ¬† It will also allow you to bundle together regular weekly tasks, for example if you always need to publish PDFs, Dwgs and Models for the extended team. ¬†The bundled tasks could also help to speed gains if they are all for the same model. If you are not currently using Clarity on your project please put in a ticket to get your project setup or contact your local design applications manager for more information. ¬† You can also find more information about Clarity on our Pulse page .

title: VR + Website = Project Interview
content: Perkins+Will pursued and WON! healthcare work with a client we‚Äôve never had before ‚Äì UNC Rex Hospital. Since I was on the interview team and because were specifically put on the short list due to our VR work ‚Äì we tried out a unique strategy in interviewing with the client. No use of PowerPoint I created a website that discussed ourselves and the project Includes RoundMe link for the client to view once the interview was over Includes team images / descriptions Showcases the design of the patient room / nurse stations Links to our perkinswill.com website The RoundMe page includes their existing hospital spaces and you can switch back and forth between the old and new. The group was very excited about their VR boxes and we assembled them in the interview and had them download the RoundMe app to their phone. We had backup iPads and Smart Phones in case, but everyone was willing to go through the process and there were no technological hiccups. Because we were not using a traditional PowerPoint presentation we were constantly interacting with the client group. The agenda broke down as such: Brief project introduction (Main webpage on display) Team introductions (Fun images, no corporate photos, we told our unique stories) Had the client team introduce themselves Had the client team discuss what they wanted in their renovated space. We essnetially treated the interview like a kickoff meeting ‚Äì focusing on their project ‚Äì not project history. Showed the existing hospital images in RoundMe, discussed what could be improved and adjusted. Had the client team open and assemble our PW branded VR boxes, installed RoundMe and directed them to the RoundMe page. Once they had enough time to play around with it, we walked through the RoundMe page on the projector We did end with a very quick PDF presentation of a similar healthcare space we rennovated. At the end there was further disucssion from the client team ‚Äì question about the space, technical MEP issues, and challenges for the project. The interview lasted under 1-1/2 hour, which was our allotted time. There was no issues with technology and everyone was very open minded about the whole thing. There were no plans, elevations or P+W boilerplate imagery shown. We just found out recently that we won the project. Modeling was done in SketchUp, rendering¬†in 3D Studio Max. https://rex.perkinswill.com/

title: Future Design: DesignSpace VR Day in Atlanta
content: The Atlanta office hosts a bi-weekly hour where the latest showcase in VR technology and design featuring hardware and software innovations. ¬†This week, participants were invited to experience DesignSpace. ¬†DesignSpace is a Virtual Reality interface built from conventional game engine based software design tools by Thomas Van Bouwel. ¬†The platform hosts an experimental virtual room where architects and urban designers find themselves in an immersive environment for sketching in 3D their potential design intervention. ¬†Participants can import an image into the virtual space such as a sketch site plan and then build up a basic massing representation using their hands and arms via Virtual Reality hardware such as the HTC VIVE and VR capable laptop already in Perkins+Will offices. ¬†The toolset features model movement, rotation, and scale all the way up to 1:1 and smaller. ¬†DesignSpace allows participants to import their models into the environment. Video: The interaction is fluid and intuitive with nearly flat learning curve DesignSpace began as a development for the HTC VIVE during the 2016 AEC Hackathon in London. ¬†The innovative VR platform has won an award for the ‚ÄúBest Use of Virtualization Technology‚Äù. ¬†The code is open-source and available on Github. ¬†There are plans to modify the code and add new features for other uses by Perkins+Will projects. title: Seattle Office ‚Äì Life Science Building in AR

author.name: Nick Cameron
author.description: American trucker who has been featured on the History channel reality television series Ice Road Truckers and its spinoff series IRT: Deadliest Roads.

content: The University of Washington‚Äôs Life Science Building was Seattle‚Äôs first project that utilized the Unity engine and Microsoft HoloLens. The design was viewed by the UW community in augmented reality, with an emphasis on the art wall designed by local artist Claude Zervais. We brought the Revit model into 3ds Max at over 13 million polys (not including the casework!) and the initial cleanup involved deleting all non visible assets and merging repeated assets such as windows and mulions. A few scripts were used to automate mesh cleanup and lower the poly count to a size that a game engine would be capable of rendering in real time. Simple UVW mapping followed, and materials and textures were applied inside of 3ds Max. materials applied in 3ds Max Due to the large size of the building, applying colliders was an important step. The quick and easy method is to import the FBX file into a game engine and click on the ‚Äògenerate colliders‚Äô button, but this can slow down the game and make walking up or down stairs jittery. While still in 3ds Max, the building was separated into four layers: 1) Normal meshes, that can be simplified and don‚Äôt require collision. 2) High detail meshes that can‚Äôt be simplified and don‚Äôt require collision. 3) Meshes that can be simplified collision can be applied. 4) Meshes that are not visible in the game, but that the player could collide with. Using invisible objects, we could make ramps for the stairs so that the player could move up and down, without jittering. This project needed to be viewed in the Hololens. Unity is the only engine that has HoloLens support. The large user community and assets store were a big plus too. Each layer was exported as a separate FBX and imported into Unity with the correct settings applied to each layer. The model then required material clean-up and with the correct reflectivity settings and textures. Once materials had been applied, the exterior was populated with a mix of plants from the environment asset pack, and plants from the Unity Store. adding plants helped populate the space and bring it to life Unity cannot import IES lights, and due to the size of the scene, baking it in 3ds Max would‚Äôve been next to impossible. Without lights, the interior lacked depth and dimension. Setting up a mix of self illuminating materials and point light, a lightbake was created for the entire building that took roughly a day. The lightbake had a huge impact on the space. lighting made the space more ¬†defined Once lightbaking was complete, the only steps left were to simplify the scene, and to publish for both HoloLens and PC. Claude presented the artwall¬†to the University of Washington‚Äôs students and faculty. A walk around of the building was projected for viewers to experience the space, and a separate station was available for the UW community to experience and see the artwall at full scale in the HoloLens.
