title: 2016 Digital Practice Workshop: Chattanooga

author.name: Nick Cameron
author.description: American trucker who has been featured on the History channel reality television series Ice Road Truckers and its spinoff series IRT: Deadliest Roads.

content: Recently the Digital Practice team set out to host an event that would be focused on outcomes and interaction rather than presentations. This event would effectively replace what had been an annual summit, in which all Design Application Managers were invited to attend. This smaller format made up of invitees was modeled on a workshop rather than a summit. The workshop was developed to have a three-fold purpose. The first is to communicate the current state of the Perkins+Will Digital Practice platform to its extended network of Design Application Managers & subject matter experts. The second, debate & decide what forces, internal and external are affecting Digital Practice at Perkins+Will, followed by how to counteract or accelerate those forces. The third and most important, to collaborate in person for the advancement of the core Digital Practice projects. Attendees of the smaller Digital Practice workshop are made up of Design Application Managers and Subject Matter Experts who are invited to be part of a four-person task force, focused on a Digital Practice project. Each task force is led by a Digital Practice manager and assembled several months in advance. Teams are challenged to create a set of goals and a series of objectives focused on a core area of the Digital Practice organization ‚Äì Content, Data Centric Design Processes, Visualization including Virtual Reality, Computational Design and Continuing Education.The inaugural Digital Practice workshop took place in late October in Chattanooga, Tennessee. Six weeks prior to the workshop, teams assembled remotely to develop work plans and deliverables to support the projects goals. The actual face to face workshop was the opportunity for teams to roll up their sleeves and complete the work. Each team presented their work on the final day of the workshop. That work has been compiled into the following executive summary. Each team will also be sharing the outcomes on Pulse and face to face meetings throughout the firm. Based on the success of this inaugural workshop the Digital Practice is planning to hold 3 workshops in 2017. Below is the full summary, please read and offer any feedback.

title: PW Autodesk University 2016 Recap
content: Every year Autodesk holds a conference focused around new software offerings and updates facilitating more efficient workflows and training. ¬†The emphasis of this conference is on expert training and feedback. This year, like many in the past, we had a strong group of Perkins+Will employees from across the firm. ¬†We got the opportunity for all of us to meet face-to-face, enjoying each other‚Äôs company and exchanging ideas. ¬†AU in general gave us a wide variety of learning opportunities and some good conversations between our own employees across the firm and other industry experts. ¬†This year discussions branched out well beyond BIM as this is the present state of the industry. This encompassed many opportunities to try VR, discuss generative design, and see the latest in machine learning and aritficial intellegence. ¬†Below is a recap of some specific bigger picture themes we took away from AU2016. Dynamo , a visual scripting tool which can connect to Revit is being adopted at lightning speed. There were many labs, classes and conversations about this tool and its use. If you are not familiar with it yet, you can find it in the addins tab of Revit 2016 or the manage tab of Revit 2017. It allows us to write scripts to tell the software to execute something even without knowing how to write any scripting language, this is called visual scripting. This will allow us to design better with Revit by executing complex operations that you might not be able to model by hand. It allows us to automate repetitive, mundane tasks freeing time to focus on the important things. It will allow more people to build tools for Revit that do standard project tasks. There were many classes that covered different ways to use this tool. We can utilise it for Computational Design (just like we can use grasshopper with Rhino). It can also be used to extract information, perform some file maintenance tasks and more. Two of those classes were given by some of our PW family that are experts in this realm; Josh Moore (DAM-Dallas) and Justin Benjamin (DAM-WashingtonDC) gave a talk on automating everyday tasks with dynamo and Jeremy Luebker (DAM-SanFransisco) and Luc Deckinga (Digital Practice Manager out of SF) gave a class on the workflows of moving geometry from SketchUp and Rhino into Revit using dynamo and other tools. Daqri Construction Helmet Many of us got the chance to try on the construction helmet which was available at the Daqri booth in the exhibitor hall. ¬†This is a custom built device to bring spatially aware data to the construction working onsite. ¬†It is Augmented Reality for work as opposed to the next Pokemon Go craze. ¬†It is meant to map your surroundings and overlay specific information based on your location and the elements of the building you are looking at with systems or data of the final product. ¬†This type of device is the bridge for us to deliver design intent to the contractors in the form of models instead of drawings. This device is similar to the HoloLens that we are currently testing in some our PW offices. ¬† Generally speaking the experience with those is much more stable than this Daqri helmet which you could feel heating up your head after only 5-10 minutes. ¬† Between the speed of the hardware of these devices and more limited range of view vs the HoloLens, we felt that these still had a ways to go before they will become mainstream and help contribute to a change in the process of delivery and consumption of design intent. ¬† On the upside it is built on a Linux platform which is more open than the Windows platform of HoloLens. One other nice thing that they have already developed construction specific application ‚Äì ¬†a heat sensing camera and visualization app in order to see how much heat is flowing through a wall or pipe or other building elements. Password: DA Semi-autonomous_Mason from PW Digital Practice Robotics was very prominent on the exhibitor floor. ¬† This starts to blur the lines between design and fabrication. ¬† This also will impact our process as design intent modeling will more effortlessly transition to fabrication modeling which will drive these robots to create our designs. ¬† A handful of us got to see this previously as we visited Branch Technology is Chattanooga, TN in October for a digital practice work session. ¬† We have also been fortunate as a firm to be the only design focused business to utilzie Autodesk‚Äôs new Build Space . ¬† In addition to these robotic arms that ‚Äòprint‚Äô the design with different materials you can also see in the video above the automation of standard building construction leaving the specialist to focus on the unique parts of our design. ¬† Although these robots are in their infancy when it comes to development you can already see the advantage of something that can work 24/7 and complete everything with precision per our specifications and design.

title: Detail Referencing Utility (DRU) Pilot

author.name: Nick Cameron
author.description: American trucker who has been featured on the History channel reality television series Ice Road Truckers and its spinoff series IRT: Deadliest Roads.

content: Managing details across multiple Revit models can be a time consuming chore in any Revit project. On a large project with distributed team and multiple models it can become a daunting task and takes many hours of coordination. To alleviate this challenge, Digital Practice in collaboration with Swedish First Hill project team has completed testing and piloting a new productivity tool for Revit ‚Äì Detail Reference Utility (DRU) This tool enables teams to cross-reference views across multiple Revit models. For example, all details can be kept in a separate file(s) and called out from other models, and the reference labels will be automatically updated when details are moved to different sheets or their numbers are updated, similarly to how it works with details in the same model. In the pilot project the team was¬†able to split out the details models and reduce the number of people working in each model at any given time from 12-16 to 5-8 people gaining productivity by reducing responce time. This effort was led by myself and Julie Adler from the project team side. Based on the team experience, we ¬†can recommend ¬†DRU for implementation on other large projects. If ¬†you consider using the¬†utility on your project, please reach out to your local Design Applications Manager. Here are some comments from the team: It is a great program to share details and organize them in sheets. Easy to use and easy to learn It worked just as it claimed to and updated automatically to follow sheet and detail number changes, once it was set up and linked properly. Liked that it logged everything so you could investigate all the updates by timestamp and user A great tool, especially for big projects with multiple Revit models Much faster to have the models split and split up the team, which wouldn‚Äôt have been possible without DRU Filtering of the details by model, sheet or detail number was very helpful The support was very responsive. ¬†All issues were addressed quickly and responses were prompt. The workflow and interface seemed clear and consistent. No one found the tool difficult to use or to learn, and the process was pretty self-explanatory after training. it would be useful for large projects of any type, especially projects with multiple models and large teams. ¬†The advantage of being able to set up separate detail models to reference from and have some team members working in the detail models while others work in the main models is a huge help in trying to keep the number of people in the models down, and it can‚Äôt easily be done without using DRU. I think the main factor in usefulness would be project size rather than type, market sector or phase. It is hard to say how many hours of coordination we would have saved, because we didn‚Äôt get far enough along in the project to begin to determine savings. ¬†I would guess that it would be many, many hours, based on our previous experience with trying to use dummy tags and then having to have someone go back, check and edit all of the tags before each submittal. The only problem that users had was with graphics of the callout bubble ‚Äì mostly because the expectation was that it behaves exactly like a live Revit callout. Since the testing, the developer had improved the bubbles. It should also¬†be ¬†noted that the utility has tools for diagnosing and repair of broken links ‚Äì in a very controlled way. Here are some snapshot of the interface. For more details, watch this training video (48 min). Password is DA. DRU Training from PW Digital Practice on Vimeo .

title: microKnowledge: Know-How-Now
content: Want quick ‚Äòhow-to‚Äô answers about digital design tools? Starting December 1st, find bite-sized nuggets of know-how on Digital Practice‚Äôs new microKnowledge website .¬†Based on the Pareto Principle (80/20 rule), microKnowledge is a repository of quick solutions to your real-time design tool challenges. Simple filtering narrows results down to visual, screen-sized answers called mK cards. Favoring images over text, the content of each mK card is easily grasped, faster than reading an explanation of the same information. Expanding the knowledge of digital tools in parallel to project work means teams can stay focused on design, not software. A living website, microKnowledge content will continually grow and evolve ‚Äì with your help. Using a mK Card Template ,¬†anyone can create and share their expertise in the same easily-digestible format.¬† And if you need to know how to edit your first mK card, just refer to the mK card titled How Do I Make a microKnowledge Card .¬†¬†To complete your contribution, simply upload your know-how . Example mK Card

title: Revit 2017 availability
content: Information for New Features for 2018 can be found here. While there are many new features in Revit 2017 below I have narrowed them to the ones of most interest for people transitioning to the newest version of our core software. ¬† If considering upgrading an existing project additional caution is warranted this year. ¬† First however the improvements. Depth Cueing Automagically showing depth with line weights Off On Facade recessions More railing hosts We can now sketch railings onto the¬†top¬†faces of floors, slabs, slab edges, walls, or roofs. Rebuilt text fuctionality In addition to the above new features there are many other items such as; dynamo player to run scripts without opening dynamo, more editing options in a perspective view, linking native rhino models, more functionality with global parameters which makes your project environment like the family editor, energy settings and further capabilites with Insight360, better connection to FormIT to improve workflow between products, removal of mental ray render engine now only including RT render engine like the cloud rendering service, adding formulas to tags, combining fields into one in schedules, improved point cloud capabilities, and many other small fixes and improvements which will help your daily workflows. CAUTION With a few of these new features there are some known bugs with upgrading models. ¬† Please consult with your local DAM and run tests before upgrading a project. ¬† Our recommendations are that projects heading toward issuing CDs or already in the construction phase should seriously consider whether they should stay with the current version or if there is a serious benefit with stabilitiy or new features that would warrant the upgrade to 2017. ¬† Projects earlier on in the design process should just plan an upgrade into their project schedule at a convienent time and run test to see the consequnces of the change. ¬† As always any project model upgrades should be part of a BIM Execution Plan and should be well coordinated with all our consultants and others impacted by the use of Revit models. The most important known issue is the movement of text as a result of the fundamental rebuild of the text tool in Revit. ¬† This means the location of returns and layout of text dialog boxes on your sheet might not always be identical to what you saw in your 2016 or previous version models. ¬† This includes text overlaps, word wrap changes, and text alignment issues in tags, marks and text elements. ¬† All of these are really easy to fix but it will take time to review your sheets and find them as there is no way to automate this process. ¬† We have already made the fixes to our firmwide standard content so moving forward any new projects will just enjoy the benefits of this new feature. ¬† (see examples below) In addition to text issues there have been reported some problems with railings as a result of the new hosting features (see the link for text above for more info from Autodesk).

title: Current State Rendering
content: The goal of this research is twofold. First, share the range of workflows in use across the firm. And second, seek commonalities to unify our direction so that teams might be adequately equipped and supported to yield the visual quality and quantity that meets the expectations of our design leaders and clients. To better understand visualization at Perkins&Will an interview style survey was conducted for each office. Four levels of visualization style and quality were defined for interviewees. ¬†Questions focused on the digital tools, available hardware, workflows and frequency of output for each level of visualization. The results reveal numerous workflows without a means of sharing resources, a majority driven toward plainness of quality resulting from convenience and limiting hardware options, and trending uses of Virtual Reality and Real Time rendering.

title: ACADIA 2016 Workshop ‚Äì Design Space Construction
content: Perkins+Will‚Äôs Process Lab taught a workshop in Design Space Construction at ACADIA in Ann Arbor Michigan October 24-26, 2016. Participants from Architecture firms and schools around the country gathered to learn a methodology and associated tools for formulating, executing, and communicating design spaces to support performance-based decisions. To see the final results created during this workshop or for more information about the building program and performance objectives visit the Design Space Construction challenge page: https://designspaceconstruction.org/portfolio-item/acadia-2016_workshop/ Design Space Construction ‚Äì Defining, optimizing and communicating performace-based building design spaces Abstract: In day one, participants learned the methodology and associated tools for formulating, executing, and communicating a design space in support of performance-based decisions. Specifically they learn to: Formulate a design space, including Objectives, Alternatives, Impacts, and Value; Create a parametric model exploring building form and materials; Define energy, light, and view analysis; Explore a design space, including understanding importance and sensitivity of design parameters; Define a value equation, and optimize the building design; and, Report the results into an online database capable of storing and comparing design spaces. After a day of learning these methods, participants broke into teams and spent two days in a collaborative project constructing new and more challenging design spaces to meet the real world Perkins+Will challenge of designing a child care center. The Workflow: Six teams, consisting of 3 or 4 people per team, learned, used and expanded upon a multi-software workflow that includes Dynamo, Rhino/Grasshopper, Ladybug/Honeybee, EnergyPlus, Flux, GoogleDocs and a Parallel Coordinate Plot tool developed by Perkins+Will to visualize large data sets.¬†This workflow is broken down into three major parts; Design of Alternatives, Performance Analyses, and Visualization and Optimization. Participants were only required to engage the first of these three parts by developing a parametric system to generate multiple Design Alternatives based on the permutations of all input variables. Each design was then run through the Performance Analyses provided with the workflow and the results visualized with the Parallel Coordinate Plot tool. Bonus: Space Plan Generator! Teams were also given the option to utilize the Space Plan Generator (SPG), a Dynamo tool developed by Subhajit Das in a collaboration between Autodesk, Perkins+Will and the Georgia Institute of Technology. SPG takes a building program spreadsheet and automatically arranges program elements within a defined site boundary and according to their adjacency desires. Alternatives generated by SPG are pushed into Grasshopper where they can be run through the existing Performance Analyses. Teams that chose not to use SPG developed their own parametric systems for creating Design Alternatives in either Dynamo or Grasshopper or some comibination of the two. Workshop leaders/facilitators: John Haymaker, Perkins+Will Hakim Hasan, Perkins+Will Mohammed Asl, Autodesk Wei Yan, Texas A&M University Marcelo Bernal, Perkins+Will Justin Brechtel, Perkins+Will Luc Deckinga, Perkins+Will Victor Okhoya, Perkins+Will Anton Szilasi, Perkins+Will

title: Parametric Tool Crafting

author.name: Nick Cameron
author.description: American trucker who has been featured on the History channel reality television series Ice Road Truckers and its spinoff series IRT: Deadliest Roads.

content: This talk is focused on the intimate relationship between fabrication and form. For centuries, architects have appropriated the tools around them to bring their designs to fruition, but we have passed a remarkable milestone in which architects no longer need to rely on out-of-the-box software to fulfill their needs. Architects are now crafting new tools to accomplish new forms. The first aspect of this ‚Äútool-smithing‚Äù occurs when architects use visual programming to ‚Äúhack‚Äù existing software packages like Rhinoceros and Revit. Rather than using code to break into the database of macros deep within each software package, user-friendly visual programming interfaces have emerged that allow users to string together primitive blocks into a bespoke command that accomplishes exactly what they want, or generates a solution beyond what they could have manually modeled. The second realm in which Architects are crafting their own tools is in bespoke robotics. This category encompasses both industrial robots and microcontrollers. Architects are approaching industrial robots with a different agenda compared to other industries. While other industries look to robots to automate a process, architects are asking how they can move fabrication forward to realize otherwise impossible forms and techniques. Industrial 6-axis robot arms are being used to weld, bend, stack, cast, and distort materials with digitally-derived precision. This is the differentiator between traditional uses of robotics and the exploratory nature of architects. Micro-controllers are small business-card-size computer chips with open-ended potential for writing custom commands. These small chips can be sent custom commands from computer software and will run their programs in the physical environment. When the microprocessor is attached to sensors and motors, new adaptive machines can be created to respond to the environment, all programmed from the architect‚Äôs laptop. Architects are combining the two realms, attaching microprocessors and sensors onto the ends of 6-axis robot arms, giving them new capabilities to sense their environments as they perform their construction processes. In both areas of invention, the open-source community is a thriving component of their success, with forums ( Grasshopper ), video tutorials ( Youtube ), and step-by-step instructions ( Instructables ). These forums help ease the traditionally steep learning curves for such software and hardware. The first project discussed is Fabric Forms, which takes the precision of robots and the freedom of fabric and creates a new casting technique for concrete. Rigid formwork is replaced by Lycra, which is stretched by 6-axis robots to precisely create unique shapes that can be bolted together. The second project is Minafold Pavilion by Perkins+Will. Aluminum is re-considered as both cladding and a self-supporting structural material. Curvature and folding are used to build this 100lb canopy for the 2016 Greenbuild Expo in Los Angeles. 192 laser cut, brake-formed aluminum pieces are riveted together to create a parametric minimal surface. 20 employees out of the Los Angeles office of Perkins+Will volunteered for the design and construction of the project.

title: Fenestra PRO Review ‚Äì Lots of potential but still a long way to go

author.name: Nick Cameron
author.description: American trucker who has been featured on the History channel reality television series Ice Road Truckers and its spinoff series IRT: Deadliest Roads.

content: I recently had the opportunity to test the new Fenestra PRO software (v3.0) for energy and sustainability analysis. According to them: ‚ÄúFenestraPro Premium for Revit is an intuitive and easy to use add-in that enables architects to design energy efficient building fa√ßades to comply with building regulations and required performance, without compromising the aesthetic of the fa√ßade.‚Äù Plus the fact that it is a ADD-IN for Revit and therefore discards the hassle of exporting and import, it sounded really promising. Could they have finally figured out a way of having a realtime energy analysis that could prove itself useful and help when designing? So I chose a project in the office for testing. The project is a residential tower, which is part of a masterplan in Sao Paulo, developed in a competition led by Jo Palma. This project was perfect as it had a really interesting curvy massing. The idea was to try to understand how the massing shape would influence self shading. On the meeting we had with Simon Whelan, from FenestraPRO, he had already showed some reserves to import a model with curves to be analysed. And he was right, the model didn‚Äôt work. His suggestion at the meeting was to breakdown the curve into a series of straight lines and then it would work. I found that Workarounds like those render softwares useless when it comes to competitions. That was disappointing as the information contained on the software is indeed very comprehensive and useful. Not only does it provide energy analysis on the massing but it compares it to different standards and advises if one is compliant or not with a particular rating system or requirement. I decided then to quickly change the massing and update the model to try the detailed model analysis. Yet another dispointment. Apparently FenestraPRO only analyses horizontal shading and not vertical. So no good. Maybe next time we develop a building with a horizontal shading system I might think of this software again. Another point that for me was not great was the information output. It does provide a lot of data, but in a spreadsheet format not as an appealing graphic. In a competition that would mean that someone from the team would have to run the analysis, digest it, and then produce the graphics to make competition-ready. That‚Äôs just time that we don‚Äôt have. All and all, the software does have some potential as it provides lots of data. However and sadly these things seem to continue to be designed with no real connection to how architects work and therefore they do not reach their full potential. I tried it later in a really basic model and it did work eventually however the graphic output was always never great. For the studio where I am working at the moment this does not seem to be a useful tool but perhaps it will help somebody at Perkins+Will who really wants to justify a design decision based on sustainability and energy performance. As long as they have the time to translate the information to make it presentation ready.

title: Autodesk BUILD Space: Curved NLT prototype
content: The following is intended for an internal Perkins+Will audience. During the second week of October, Yehia Madkour (Vancouver), and Jeremy Leubker (San Francisco), were working at the new Autodesk BUILD Space facility in South Boston, on this prototype (image below) ‚Äì A 1 to 1 slice of the Great Northern Way (Vancouver Project) Pavilion, 2√ó8‚Äôs cut, nailed, assembled on the rig and ready for 5 axis CNC milling: For more photos taken during their time at BUILD Space, follow this link . WHAT IS AUTODESK BUILD SPACE? The facility is¬†an innovation studio and industrial R&D workshop for digital fabrication in the building industry. Follow this link to see a video of the BUILD Space Opening Day. WHAT WAS BEING WORKED ON BY PERKINS+WILL? Yehia and Jeremy were building a complex-curvature nail laminated timber (NLT) panel as a proof of concept prototype for the Great Northern Way (GNW) Pavilion construction. This is a corporate research effort to explore various forms and assemblies achievable with wood construction and made possible through digital fabrication. They used standard 2√ó8 lumber, laminated them together with aluminum nails into a faceted shell. The shell was then milled by a 5-axis CNC router to achieve a smooth interior finished surface. WHAT IS THE GREAT NORTHERN WAY PAVILION PROJECT? This is a project of the Vancouver office of Perkins+Will: A single storey food and beverage retail pavilion situated within St. George Plaza, at the heart of the future Emily Carr University campus at Southeast False Creek in Vancouver, BC. It signifies an entrance and provides a landmark to the campus. The pavilion sits next to our recently-designed Great Northern Way office building, the Central Valley Greenway bike route and the planned future Millennium Line Skytrain station. Rendering of Great Northern Way (GNW) Pavilion For more information about the process that Yehia and Jeremy followed, please see the PDF below.

title: Design in VR

author.name: Nick Cameron
author.description: American trucker who has been featured on the History channel reality television series Ice Road Truckers and its spinoff series IRT: Deadliest Roads.

content: Virtual Reality (VR) is transforming how we design and collaborate in Architecture. VR is no longer just a gimmicky toy used to impress the client, but rather a tool that designers and architects are using for themselves on projects to expedite design process, improve design communication, and enhance the design experience in order to produce a much better product. Inspired by how VR could be used for design, Senior Project Designer and Architect, Sarika Bajoria took on the challenge and embarked on a week-long integrated VR in design collaboration with CityScape Digital, a London based visualization firm specializing in Virtual Reality. The University of Pennsylvania Health System (UPHS) Center for Healthcare Technology project was selected for this effort. Specifically, the lobby entrance area of the new building was chosen for¬†the¬†VR collaboration since it has a reasonably defined scope. The lobby was large enough to have an interesting VR experience, yet small enough to be completed within the timeframe of a week. Sarika and her team‚Äôs mission was to design the overall entry experience starting from the landscaped plaza, lobby, caf√©, informal meeting space, reception area, all connected by a feature sculptural folded wall which transitions into a folded ceiling plane to integrate LED screens for ‚Äúimmersive‚Äù technology display. Using the VR system as an experiential design tool, Sarika hoped to experience the lobby as she and her team design every aspect of the building entrance. Joel from Cityscape joined Sarika for this VR collaboration and was seated next to her as they worked together for the week. An adjacent open area (about 120 square feet) was used to setup the room scaled VR system (HTC Vive) for the VR experience. The first task for the VR collaboration was to convert the project‚Äôs current 3D BIM model into the gaming software (Unreal Engine). The 3D model was gathered from various sources of different formats including Revit, Rhino and 3D Max. By the end of the first day, a VR version of the building and lobby was ready to be examined in VR on the HTC Vive system. Sarika and her team members were able to walk around the building lobby in its basic form, with default shading and lighting. The immediate reaction from our designers was one of a delightful surprise. Even though the designers were familiar with every inch of the lobby space, they were still surprised at their own feeling of how it felt to walk around the lobby space in virtual reality. The next step was to refine the lobby space by mapping the finished materials onto the various different surfaces, and adding in all the lighting conditions as designed. Once the material and lighting were added, the space started to look and feel almost photo realistic. Sarika then focused on redesigning the ceiling panels adjusting the panel tessellation angles based on what she had experienced in VR. The process was an iterative process of adjusting and reviewing in VR, then making the changes in the modeling software. Once the design was reasonably set, the design team members were invited to critique the design by experiencing the design themselves in VR. As the designers themselves had said ‚Äúthe VR gives you an immediate sense of scale and dimensionality that is better than any combination of plans, elevations, sections or 3D perspectives can give you.‚Äù Robert Goodwin, Design Director and Principal, even added that ‚Äúin VR you instantly see and feel the space. You see all the good as well as the not so good things in your design from every angle in the Virtual Space‚Äù. Sarika noted that in addition to design iteration of the ceiling panels, in the VR environment the design team tested different material options, scales and patterns of floor and wall panels, adjusted the angles and scale of folded ceiling and wall, tested design options for the reception desk and articulated many design details. They also studied the relationship between the exterior and interior space of ground floor ‚Äúurban room‚Äù and how it connects the pedestrian movement and activates the streetscape. Even though the original mission of the VR collaboration was for internal design purpose only, the Project team was so delighted with the VR experience that they decided to share the VR experience with the client as well. After a successful client VR showing in the New York office, the client requested to have the VR setup brought to the client site in Philadelphia to show the rest of the client team. The client was incredibly excited with the VR technology and is looking forward to see more VR used for future design review and collaboration. The VR in design experiment was a success, as Sarika puts it, ‚Äúthis was a true collaboration with Rob Goodwin, Christine Kim, Cityscape and myself which was the strength of this exercise‚Äù, being able to engage the clients and expedite design review process using VR was just an added bonus to the experiment. P+W Workshop with CityScape VR from PW Digital Practice on Vimeo .

title: Minafold Pavilion
content: MINAFOLD PAVILION Too often in the design profession, sustainability is treated like a check-list one must to go through in order to satisfy a certain quota to ‚Äògreen-wash‚Äô a project, resulting in dull sustainability ‚Äòsolutions‚Äô and even duller buildings and forms. But what if we could re-evaluate the way we apply technology to traditional materials, discover ways to maximize performance to achieve minimal waste and design a new construction methodology along the way? For Greenbuild 2016, we decided to answer these questions with the Minafold Pavilion. PW Minafold Pavilion Video from PW Digital Practice The Minafold Pavilion is an exploration in material performance. This canopy poses the question, ‚ÄúCan the properties of a single material be maximized to achieve minimal waste and compose a visual performance?‚Äù The pavilion encompasses a 10x10x8‚Äô volume, while only weighing 100 lbs. This structure removes traditional columns and beams and uses double curvature to create rigidity. The Minafold Pavilion uses 177 square feet of recycled sheet material (18 Gauge Aluminum) and turns it into a self-supporting structural element through bending (at the macro scale) and folding at the micro scale. The surface is then triangulated and perforated with a variable size aperture. The perforations transform from small holes at the base, where stiffness is required, into a lattice at the top where flexibility is needed. Each of the 192 unique panels is laser cut with holes and labels built into the algorithm. A brake form is used to fold the connection tabs where a rivet is driven through to join them. All aspects of the design were parametrically controlled from the location of rivet holes to the laser-etched connection labels. The construction process was streamlined by a ‚Äúpaint by number‚Äù catalogue system that made it easy for someone to build without prior experience, or even an understanding of the final design intent. A 3D file and 2D drawing of each component was provided on site to create a set of easily-understood instructions.¬†To achieve the Minafold Pavilion, we employed a novel construction process that re-thinks traditional notions of lightness, sustainability, and structure. The Pavilion made its debut at the 2016 Greenbuild Expo in Los Angeles on October 6th, 2016 and was warmly received by attendees, gaining its own following with the hashtag #Minafold . ‚Äã This project represents a critical point in time when architecture is emerging out of a drawing-based industry and utilizing design-to-fabrication workflows. Both the laser cutter and brake form were computer-controlled, removing much of the human interface, traditionally associated with a project of this size. Not only was the 3D model necessary in communicating the design, but it was essential for calculating structural behavior, simulating the effects of gravity, and studying the material characteristics of aluminum. A much more involved synergy between architect, engineer, and fabricator was essential to the success of the pavilion, and will pave the way for future collaborations. The strategy employed in this canopy can be easily translated into a building fa√ßade, interior partition, or stand-alone sculptural element. These interventions into the realm of architecture are challenging not only the forms we create, but are expanding our role as architects. As most contractors are not familiar with the methods employed, the architect is essential in alleviating doubt and streamlining the fabrication and mock-up phases. Architects should no longer be afraid to employ their own assemblies and systems as long as they are working closely the fabricator in alleviating the cost-overruns typical in custom work. Parametric design is known for its ability to create variation and experimental forms, but the often overlooked aspect of parametric design is the ability to rationalize sculptural work into easily fabricated elements, even making the fabricator‚Äôs job easier by adding details like rivet holes and laser etching numbers. This aspect of parametric design will advance the profession not just in what we build, but in how we build. Minafold Pavilion Project Designer: Joseph Sarafian Build Team: Joseph Sarafian, Hrant Varozian, Eric Brossy de Dios, Davon Johnson, Oliver Aus Der Muhlen, Anish Reddy, Justin Brechtel, Tim Pettigrew, Andrew Tsay Jacobs, Sandy Ghaly, Jorge Mutis, Aram Hernandez, Kylie Gaines, Mohsen Ghanbari, Eric Aukee, Doug Mayer, Devika Tandon, Jessica Radparvar, Abby White, Tina Giorgadz Coordination/Planning: Sandra Cervantes, Yuriva Bueno Sustainability Coordination: Eric Brossy de Dios, Lorraine Polanski Fabrication: Ampersand Contract Signing Group Videography: Nathan Ingalls Photography: Carlos De La Rosa Jr.

title: Lean Construction Institute ‚Äì 2016 Fall Congress keynote
content: This years fall congress was held in Chicago the week of October 3rd. ¬† The following are the notes based on the keynote address based on how we must organize to maximize our skills in a less ordered environment. The keynote speaker, Chris Fussell was a former special forces leader in the middle east and now works for the McChrystal Group and helped write Team of Teams . Today‚Äôs Environment: Complex The Problem: Efficiency The Solution: Adaptability This talk was based on the Cynefin Model which is a framework that helps you sense what model you are functioning out of in order to make better decisions and avoid problems. So based on a simple system where best practice is the right way to execute you can see as things become more unordered because of the evolution of human behavior and technology there becomes a gap from the traditional top down org charts and processes in place that can‚Äôt account for the new framework in place. The fundamentals of an Elite Small Team are; Trust Common Purpose Shared Consciousness Empowered Execution So organization leaders need to lead like a gardner, you don‚Äôt make the plants grow but enable, tend, and protect them to give them the right environment to thrive in. Silos among departments and studios are typically tribal and not logistical. ¬† So how do you break the silos; There are many deep cultural barriers you have to recognize and acknowledge one way to break them down is exchange key individuals to understand the other culture and bring back the connection to their own team create a structure and transparency for the autonomous team to make decisions & have high levels of accountability find ways so process and leadership behaviour come together We need to find the balance to gain the adaptability, agility and comradery of a small teams but the resources and vast knowledge of a large organization

title: A Virtual Mock Up for Mayo Clinic

author.name: Nick Cameron
author.description: American trucker who has been featured on the History channel reality television series Ice Road Truckers and its spinoff series IRT: Deadliest Roads.

content: A physical mock up for an interior project is often quite costly and requires dedicated space and a construction crew to be built, which cost our clients precious resources and time. As a proof of concept, our project team wanted to test the theory that a Virtual Reality mock up could eliminate the need for the construction of a physical mock up or at least speed up the process of creating one. Proposed. Although in the end our experiment did not completely eliminate the need for physical mock ups (just yet), it certainly demonstrated the tremendous benefit that VR brings to the project and more importantly the potential that VR has in transforming the design review process for future design projects. How it all started After experiencing a demonstration of augmented reality using the Hololens, Senior Project Architect, Diana Davis, wanted to bring her project into Virtual Reality. Diana proposed to use a small Patient Exam Room on her Mayo Clinic project to be used for a Virtual Mock Up. The idea was to test how a virtual mock up would fare in comparison to a physical mock up, and to explore how VR can be used to improve the interior design review process. A typical patient exam room was chosen for the VR experiment for various reasons. First, the patient exam room has a small footprint. The room fits within the 15‚Äôx15‚Äô size of the VR operating space, which means the user can comfortably explore the space without the need to ‚Äúteleport‚Äù in the virtual world. Second, the client was already familiar with other existing patient exam rooms of similar design, thus experiencing a familiar virtual space will make it less shocking to the client, and probably easier to relate to the virtual room. And finally, since the proposed design change to the room is minimal, the client should have an easier time to comprehend the design differences in the virtual environment. As the VR coordinator, I enlisted the help of our visualization expert, Dan Creekmore, from the P+W Viz Lab in Dallas to collaborate with the rest of the design team in Atlanta. Dan‚Äôs mission was to bring the Revit model into the VR HTC Vive system. The process involves exporting the 3D model from Revit into 3D Studio Max to polish it up by applying texture mapping and proper lighting, then render and ‚Äúbake‚Äù the texture maps onto the 3D geometry. The design team provided finish material specifications for all the different surfaces in the model. The visualization team filled in the scene with additional equipment and accessories that were not in the Revit model and constructed them as 3D models by referencing the manufacturer‚Äôs specification provided. The final rendered model was then imported into Unity 3d, a gaming engine software, where VR rigs were setup and special effects (such as reflection probes, and laser pointers) were added into the model. Meanwhile, the HTC Vive system was shipped to Atlanta. Tyrone Marshall, Atlanta‚Äôs Design Application Manger, setup the Vive system for testing within the office. The system requires a dedicated computer, minimum of 225 square feet and two tripods to support the cameras which monitor the headset in space. After a quick calibration of the room boundary, the VR system was ready to be shared with the team. The team was excited to test the setup themselves and went through a few design iterations, refining finish materials and aditional details to the room. Everyone was surprised by the high fidelity of the virtual space, and how immersive the experience was. When all of the design changes were complete, the project team took the whole VR system with them and travelled to the Mayo Clinic in Florida. They setup the VR system in a small conference room at the Mayo Clinic and shared the Virtual Mock Up of the Patient Exam Room with the client‚Äôs design team, as well as many other curious doctors and nurses on site. After the VR experience, the clients were interviewed about their experience and offered invaluable feedback to our project team. Here is a sample of the questions: Have you ever used VR before? And in what capacity? What were your expectations around the design of the space prior to experiencing the virtual environment? In what ways were your perceptions altered by the space virtually? Does the experience impact your feeling of the space different from just looking at it on the paper? Did experiencing the space virtually at all change the feedback that you gave to us, vs. maybe having reviewed this in a different format? Would you consider the VR environment an improvement over the typical design review process? And in what ways did this differ from how this process normally proceeds? What would you suggest Perkins + Will incorporate into its virtual reality environment in order for you to get the most realistic experience possible? Overall, the experience was very positive. No one had any discomfort in using the VR headset, even though this was the first time any of them have ever used VR in any capacity. The clients found the color scheme of the space looked real, however the lighting looked very different ‚Äì they commented that ‚Äúit felt brighter than their current Exam Rooms‚Äù. They noticed even the smallest details ,pointing out things like ‚Äú, such as the counter was being lit but there was no light fixture‚Äù. One thing they found quite surprising was how a design change felt completely different in VR than a change to a plan or elevation, and how they had imagined the space would have felt like. For example, the proposed design included eliminating a soffit and replacing it with a wall sconce. Previously, they were quite convinced that the change would have negatively impacted the feel of the room, and would have spent a lot of time discussing that change and required a much longer time to get final approval. As they said, ‚Äúit would take a lot longer than 40 hours of render time, maybe two months from now, to give it to contractor, we would still not be sure if we want to remove the soffit‚Äù. However, after experiencing the room in VR without the soffit, they were perfectly convinced that the proposed change is a non-issue, and said ‚Äúit‚Äôs good to see it, and feel it [in VR], [the change] made the room really look bigger‚Äù. Proving that using VR can expedite design decisions from our clients. What the clients found lacking in this virtual mockup was social interaction. In a physical mockup, it helps that multiple people can simultaneously explore the same space. Others can see what you are seeing, and even when low fidelity foam board were used, they were able to move things around and were able to write their comments on the wall. Whereas with the VR headset, it is one person at a time, not only does it take much longer to explore the. Even though they can see what you are seeing on the projected screen, the interaction is not the same. Additional feedback included to have the ability to interact with equipment in the room. The client had asked, ‚Äúis it possible to move the exam table?‚Äù, which is possible , but the feature was not included in this experiment. Although, the clients were not quite convinced that the Virtual mockup could replace a Physical mock up, they all agreed that ‚Äúit could get you pretty quickly to a point where you feel pretty comfortable with what you are building in a mock up before you started‚Äù. For small rooms, Virtual mock ups can be supplemental rather than a complete replacement of the physical mock up. However, there are many cases for replacement when it is physically impossible or financially unfeasible to construct a physical mockup. As the clients all agreed, they all ‚Äúwant[ed] to open the door and go down the hall‚Äú to check out the rest of the building. Their suggestion was to do another VR experience of the double height lobby space that would most likely not be possible to have as a physical mock up.

title: Copy Legends and Copy Sheets

author.name: Nick Cameron
author.description: American trucker who has been featured on the History channel reality television series Ice Road Truckers and its spinoff series IRT: Deadliest Roads.

content: Our latest new additions in P+W Revit tools are Copy Legends and Copy Sheets . Copy Legend Import Legends from PW Digital Practice on Vimeo . Password: DA Copy Legend is a tool that helps you import legends from other revit files. Click on the Browse button to specify the Revit file that you want to copy from, The tool will automatically extract a list of all the legends in the source file (list loading process may take longer for larger Revit files). Then check and select all the legends that you wish to import, and click the ‚ÄúImport‚Äù button Note: Items in grey do not exist in your current (destination) file. Items that are not in grey already exist in your current file, and if you choose to import items that already exist in your file, then select the Duplicate Option on what you want to deal with the duplicate situation. Duplicates can either be renamed with a suffix (‚Äú-Duplicate‚Äù) or be ignored during the import process. Copy Sheets Copy Sheets is a tool to help you duplicate sheets within a Revit file, or bring in sheets from other Revit file. The default setting is to copy from your Current Revit File. Check and select the sheets that you want to duplicate, then click on the ‚ÄúCopy‚Äù button to copy the sheets. When a sheet is duplicated, everything on the sheet is also copied onto the new sheet. Viewports will be duplicated and given a new view name with a suffix at the end.

author.name: Nick Cameron
author.description: American trucker who has been featured on the History channel reality television series Ice Road Truckers and its spinoff series IRT: Deadliest Roads.

content: The Digital Practice team has ordered a pair of virtual reality (VR) headsets for your office! The new headsets use Google‚Äôs Cardboard platform , a low-cost and effective introduction to VR. The best way to describe Cardboard is to think of it as an updated View-Master , the red binocular looking toy you had a few years back. Ask your local Design Applications Manager to take one for a test drive and learn more about how you can use them in your design process or with clients. ¬†We have also made a custom template available [ here ], so your team can create a branded version for your client and/or office. To see an example of how the viewers can be leveraged, look no further than the North Carolina practice, here are a few examples of client engagement. If your client requires a higher-level of VR refinement, ¬†then please ask your Design Application Manager about Oculus, Vive, Hololens, and Samsung Gear. The firm has access to all of these technologies and can help put them in the hands of your clients.

title: Position on Autodesk Collaboration 4 Revit & Other cloud applications
content: As of February 2017 this recommendation still is 100% valid. Over the past several years Autodesk has released a portfolio¬†of¬†‚ÄúCloud‚Äù enabled applications which they refer to as BIM360. The Digital Practice team¬†have reviewed¬†and even piloted¬†these new applications¬†on projects across the firm.¬†¬†None of these products are part of our firmwide subscription with Autodesk although we have access to all of them.¬† At this time we are not¬†recommending¬†their broad use. We have¬†tools and workflows already in place to achieve¬†similar¬†results.¬†The technology will¬†improve [or be¬†discontinued]¬†and our team will continue to poke and prod¬†these new applications and let everyone know if/when they are ready.¬†¬†Below¬†is a short list of products, their intended purpose and our recommended workflow, please share with anyone you feel this list can help.¬†If you have any questions you can reach out to me or anyone else on the Digital Practice team. Collaboration for Revit ‚Äì¬†¬†Used to collaborate with associate designers who are not on our network ‚Äì¬†not recommended to use¬†at this point, product needs more maturity. ¬†Some current issues include; occasional (this has consistently happened over the last year almost every week) unexpected downtime during working hours with no warning, inability to link dwg or reference unique materials that will function at our associates site without workarounds. ¬† There is also an added project cost. o¬†¬†¬†¬†We have our internal cloud that can bring associate architects into our environment to work on models with us.¬†¬† There is also an added project cost o¬†¬†¬†3 rd party cloud vendors can be investigated to host ¬†models and Revit application just like our nodes.¬†¬† This is an additional cost to the project. o¬†¬†¬†¬†The recommended work flow is to properly divide the work either by building area or chronologically when possible so that a model split can occur between Perkins+Will and outside designers o¬†¬†¬†¬†Some other technical considerations before about using this product. ¬† The functionality of the software only allows for one model to be opened from C4R on a node, so only one user at a time could be working on a C4R model on any single node. (this has been resolved with Revit 2017) ¬∑ BIM 360 Docs ‚Äì Used to share documents across the entire team as the single source of truth ‚Äì¬†not recommended to use¬†at this point, product needs more maturity.¬†¬† There is also added project cost. o¬†¬†¬†¬†The recommended work flow when the contractor does not have a platform is to suggest utilizing Newforma and their mobile apps o¬†¬†¬†¬†Most construction field applications or document management solutions can provide this and should be part of an initial conversation with the contract manager. ¬∑ BIM 360 Glue ‚Äì Used to collaborate with the entire team on clash resolution ‚Äì this works well as a product and can be used but does not typically fit into a¬†Perkins+Will¬†needed workflow.¬† There is also added project cost. o¬†¬†¬†¬†Recommended¬†workflow is to use Navisworks and Skype meetings screen share when team members can‚Äôt be physically present. o¬†¬†¬†¬†If this is the preferred tool after construction documents are issued then it should be led by the construction manager. ¬∑ BIM 360 Field ‚Äì¬†Used to enable construction contract administration workflows like RFIs, Submittals,¬†Punchlists, etc. ‚Äì can be used but is a project cost and should be decided in conjunction with a Construction Manager.¬†¬† This cost could be taken on by the CM or possibly be shared among the parties depending on the project and requirements. o¬†¬†¬†¬†This is typically a shared decision between all parties, unless we specify something in the general conditions of the specifications o¬†¬†¬†¬†Many platforms accomplish these types of tasks, like PlanGrid, Aconex, E-builder, Prolog, Procore, and others.¬†¬† All work in similar ways but Perkins+Will main concern with choosing any of these is to get an output of ALL activities at the completion of construction. o¬†¬†¬†¬†The recommended work flow when the contractor does not have a platform is to suggest utilizing Newforma and their mobile apps ¬∑ A360 Drive ‚Äì used as a file share and file viewing platform ‚Äì this is free as part of our subscription but we have other products that achieve similar outcomes and create an audit trail. ¬† Also serves as their online file viewer which works with mobile apps. ¬† Good for sharing and viewing CAD, DWF, Navisworks and Revit models online.

title: Realtime Rendering Revit Plugin ‚Äì Enscape Review

author.name: Nick Cameron
author.description: American trucker who has been featured on the History channel reality television series Ice Road Truckers and its spinoff series IRT: Deadliest Roads.

content: Overview Enscape is a live rendering plugin that works within Revit.¬† Creating a live walk through (navigating in real time with a controller) is as simple as creating a camera view (using its visibility settings to hide objects that are not need to be rendered), and pressing run.¬† A new window will pop up during loading, and, depending on the complexity of the geometry and the power of the computer, the live rendered scene will be done in several minutes.¬† The navigations are simple ‚Äì either keyboard (WASD) + mouse, or the use of a game controller (XBox) ‚Äì allowing a simulating walk or fly through.¬† With this scene window open, changes made in the project view will update in the view, allowing for (almost) instant feedback on design changes.¬† Oculus Rift VR is supported. Dionysus Cho and I have been testing Enscape 3D on a number of our projects using different hardware configurations (more details below). We would like to share this insight for the things we learned so far: What works Enscape is quick and easy.¬† With the Coalition office, the project has some complex Rhino/Grasshopper geometries that are imported in Revit.¬†¬†Loading an Enscape scene took about 2 minutes, and we instantly had a fully walkable and textured space.¬† We could work through the design live, panning and orbiting around the space to get a sense of the installation, facilitating quick edits.¬† Work done back in the project view (or syncing) will update the scene automatically.¬† After changes were made, the team needed some quick renders that show the space rather than being photo-realistic.¬† Instead of setting up cameras and ¬†rendering them out on the A360 cloud (our typical workflow), within minutes, we were able to run through various angles, producing captures and¬†a dozen views in 10 minutes rather than hours.¬† These views can then be post-processed, supplementing the live scene. What doesn‚Äôt work In testing with the SFU SUB building, a Higher Ed project which is¬†fairly large and complex, Enscape ran into problems that are typical with normal renderers¬†‚Äì multiple overlapped geometries causes constant flickering (eg. Multiple instances of floors, columns in walls), lighting was strange in areas, and materials worked in some areas, but were off in others.¬† I believe that these issues were not entirely the fault of Enscape, but a model that was not tuned for rendering.¬† With a better understanding of the requirements of Enscape, and with access to the plugins so we would be able to model and view throughout the process, these issues should be smoothed over. ¬†The limitations of the rendering engine, however, were noticeable in comparison with other live-rendering engines (eg. Unreal Engine), though the timeframe of the process makes it a different tool.¬† The loading time was significantly longer (several minutes) than the previous project, but the ability to export a standalone scene would negate this issue.¬† I plan to evaluate this with our nodes / laptops to see how well they run these scenes in testing.¬† I also tested the Oculus Rift VR setup with a previous version of the software (they have been pushing out updates to add features and stability) and there were some bugs that made it hard to use (eye level was off, and quality was rather low). Use in design Enscape has an incredible potential in the design process.¬† Not only was I able to quickly visualize spaces and changes, I was able to review these with others live ‚Äì we could look at any angle and range, allowing for us to scrutinize design choices that we might otherwise have had to rely on a still render (or guess).¬† Moreover, the ability to produce very quick screen captures at will dramatically cut down the tedious workflow of setting up cameras and pushing renders to the cloud.¬† Using Enscape in the workflow (Coalition interior) rather than testing it after completion (SFU SUB), showed a dramatic difference.¬† Enscape is quite promising, and with their push for updates, it will be both a great design tool and a replacement for still renders. Next step is to¬†test¬†differnet¬†hardware setups with Enscape and report back. We¬†will be updating this page soon. Stay tuned. 1.¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†Lenovo 450s (Enscape not reliable, slow panning, crashes often) 2.¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†Lenovo X1 Yoga (not yet tested) 3.¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†Alienware 15R2 (works¬†very well) 4.¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†Alienware with Oculus Rift (buggy, needs further testing) 5.¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†Node with remote desktop connection (not yet tested)

title: Comparison of AR and VR devices

author.name: Nick Cameron
author.description: American trucker who has been featured on the History channel reality television series Ice Road Truckers and its spinoff series IRT: Deadliest Roads.

content: With all the different Virtual Reality(VR) gadgets that are available today, it is really difficult to differenciate between these VR gadgets and decide which one you should be using or buying for your next project. Basically, most of these gadgets are just VR goggles, with the exception of the Hololens which is considered an Augmented Reality(AR) or Mixed Reality(MR) goggle. Let‚Äôs take a closer look at what the VR and AR goggles do and why you should use one over the other. Virtual Reality As soon as you put on a VR goggle, you are completely blocked off from the real world and transported into a virtual world. With a VR goggle on, you cannot see the real objects around you, but you can see all the virtual object displayed within the goggle. VR Goggle is an ideal tool to use to bring your audience into an imaginary world, where they can experience what a newly designed space could look like and feel like as they move around in that space. VR experiences can be presented in any place, it can be a mobile VR or a tethered VR system, all depending on the quality of the experience, and the portability of the system you need. Augmented Reality On the other hand, Augmented Reality first appeared as an iPad and iPhone apps a few years ago, later gained popularity with the infamous Goggle Glass. But the latest buzz is all about the Microsoft Hololens, the newest AR/MR goggle. Putting on a pair of Hololens will feel more like wearing a helmet with a glass mask over your face. You can still see through the glass and look at the real objects surrounding you, except now there are virtual objects appearing on top of ¬†the real objects and thus augmenting your experience of this mixed reality. In this mixed reality world, you can simulate how a virtual object would interact with the physical objects in the real world. Place a full size virtual sofa in the corner of a room and see if it will fit in that space or not. Bounce a virtual ball off the real wall and watch it bounce back. Punch a virtual hole in the wall and take a peek at the MEP and Structural data that goes behind that gyp board in the wall. With the Hololen‚Äôs front depth sensing cameras, you can also share what you see with others who are far away through the built-in camera. You can collaborate remotely with your design team and redesign the building as if they are right there. You can be watcing a live football game in front of you, and have instant analysis of the play appear over the real players and the field just as they would appear on a TV or in a video game. The possibilities of using the Hololens in this mixed reality world are endless, but we are still actively exploring and developing tools and apps that could eventually change the way AR is used for the AEC industry. Mobile VR If mobility is high on your priority list, then you should choose one of these mobile VR options. Mobile VR solution typically involves a goggle running on a mobile phones. Mobile VR offers great convenience for the traveling teams that need to present to clients at different sites. They are easy to transport, fits right in your bag, and easy to setup. But it does not have the highest image quality nor the smoothest experience as it is limited by the processing power of the mobile phone. Mobile VR is great for panorama and simple 3D models. Samsung‚Äôs GearVR and Google Cardboards are two options presented here. GearVR ($99 plus Samsung Galaxy phone $500-$680) The Samsung GearVR is still the most convenient VR option for decent quality VR experience (60 frames per second). GearVR offers both 360 panorama and 3D model viewing options. Most P+W offices already have a pair of the GearVR, and we have firmwide cloud services setup with InsiteVR to help design team with the Revit to GearVR transfer process. Contact your local DA for details. Google Cardboard ($10 plus user provides the phone) Google Cardboard is a good affordable option for mobile VR. We now have P+W branded cardboard boxes that project teams can give out to clients as a leave behind. Typically, Google Cardboard is best used for viewing 360 panoramas. Using tools such as RouneMe will give you the option to showcase your design work on the web. Contact the Digital Practice Group for P+W branded cardboards. Tethered VR: For a higher quality VR experience than what the mobile VR can provide, you can try one of the tethered VR system listed below, HTC Vive or Oculus Rift. ¬†A tethered VR system uses a goggle that is powered by a strong graphic PC or laptop, typically the machine needs to be VR certified in order for the system to run smoothly. With a tethered VR system, users can experience a refresh rate of 90+ frames per second and you can load up a much larger files than a mobile system can handle. The smoothness of the VR experience is directly tied to the Graphics processing power¬†(GPU)¬†of the PC. Typically you will need a VR certified PC system with a multi core CPU, 32 GB RAM, and a single or double GTX980 or higher graphics card. Depending on which system you choose, you will need to visit their website to find the list of certified VR PC that will work with that specific system. HTC Vive ($799 plus a VR ready machine $1800 ‚Äì $2800) The HTC Vive is the only room scale VR system on the market (for now). The room scale VR tracks the user‚Äôs position within the room and provides the user a fully immersive experience. The user can simply walk around the space (max of 15‚Äôx15‚Äô) to explore the virtual environment. With two hand held remotes, the HTC Vive also offer hand tracking, which enables the user to see their virtual hands as remote controllers inside the virtual world which further enhances their presence in that Virtual world. Compared to all the other VR systems, users on HTC Vive have the best VR experienced and almost never complains about any motion sickness. For a list of HTC Vive ready PC, visit https://www.htcvive.com/eu/ready/ . Also, for portability, order a pair of tall tripods with swivel heads when you don‚Äôt want to attach the lighthouse boxes onto the walls. Oculus Rift ($599 plus a VR ready machine $1800 ‚Äì $2800) The Oculus Rift is similar to the Vive, but it offers more of a seated experience or a standing experience within a much smaller area than the Vive‚Äôs. Oculus is on-par in terms of resolution and refresh rate as the HTC Vive system, it also needs a VR ready PC to power the VR experience. Currently its tracked remote controllers(Oculus touch) are not yet released. Instead, users are using an xbox controller to navigate within the space.¬†For a list of Oculus ready PC, visit https://www3.oculus.com/en-us/oculus-ready-pcs/. ; Augmented Reality (AR): Hololens ($3000) The Hololens is truly one of a kind Augmented Reality goggle. As a fully standalone unit, the Hololens does not need any external PC to power it. With a pair of Hololens, one can see virtual objects appear as holograms on top of real world objects and one can interact with these holographic objects directly using voice and gesture control. It also has an amazing spatial mapping capability which starts by scanning your surrounding area, storing it as a map and reconstruct it as a virtual model which can interact with any virtual objects that bring into this mixed reality world. For example, you can throw a virtual ball onto a real wall and see it bounce off the wall inside the Hololens. Because of its transparent visor, the Hololens works best in a dimly lit area with darker walls. For viewing large scale building, it is recommended to view the model in a large open space with no furniture in it. This will allow you to move around freely without running into obstacles. A few caveats of the Hololens are its limited Field of View(FOV), heaviness of the device and the lack of fully developed apps in the Window‚Äôs app store. The small FOV of the Hololens makes it feel like you are looking through a window frame, you will need to turn your head around a lot more than you would normally do just to be able to see objects that are in your peripheral vision. As a self contained unit, the Hololens basically has a mini PC inside the visor. It is noticeably heavier than the other VR goggles listed above. One can only wear the goggles for a short period of time before it becomes uncomfortable. If you have any good ideas on a project that would work well in a mixed reality environment using the Hololens, please contact the Digital Practice group.

title: FLUX Site Extractor
content: We know that developing a detailed site plan can be slow and painful;¬†gathering data from multiple sources, consolidating it¬†into a¬†single document, and finally hoping that there are no quirks in the dataset requiring creative work-arounds. Worry no more! This app dramatically simplifies the process. After searching for a location, you can tweak what gets sent by moving or resizing the selected area on the map. Then just send¬†to Flux, and you will get the following sweet geometry, all neatly divided up into separate Flux data keys: Mesh representations of surrounding buildings, using height data from Open Street Map . Additional building meshes using a pre-defined height range for when data is not available (the default randomly extrudes profiles to between 10m and 20m). Building profiles as polylines. A super sweet topographic mesh, at a resolution of ‚Öì arc second (10 m) from the US Geological Survey , which sources its data from NASA‚Äôs Shuttle Radar Topography Mission . Topographic contour lines, based on user defined elevation intervals (default is 1m). Roads as polylines Parks as polylines Water features as polylines Once you have the data in Flux, you can move it into SketchUp, Rhino or even Revit¬†with the click of a button. The latest update to the Site Extractor adds a whole lot more awesome to your workflow. With a single click you can generate a¬†4 square kilometer model of detailed topography, surrounding buildings, roads, parks and waterways. Go to Flux Site Extractor

title: Blender for Design
content: Blender is a free and open source 3D creation suite. It supports the entirety of the 3D pipeline‚Äîmodeling, rigging, animation, simulation, rendering, compositing and motion tracking, even video editing and game creation. John Bittenger has been leveraging Blender in the design process and has shared examples of the work below. The work is broken into 6 categories: Camera Mapping: The process uses a single photo (existing site) and recreates a scene that can have animation or host an insertion for a ¬†proposed renovation Camera Tracking: This process allows the project team to insert a design model into existing video footage and track the model for an animation. Composting Single Elements: This process shows John‚Äôs work with adding artistic elements to render including animation samples Design and Digital Diagram: This is a fairly new graphical design element to show the big idea of a project concept. Animation and VR Work: ¬†This process shows various techniques for design, articulation, and rigging. Vignette Work: Short animation pieces that have found their way into some of John‚Äôs projects. Please click on the links and examples to explore the work. title: How Does the new Yoga X1 laptop enhance our design process?
content: Perkins+Will has begun to make an investment in updating the standard-bearer for all of its staff in terms of mobile computers. The new system is a Lenovo Yoga laptop which provides a thin flip book design that easily allows one to sketch right on top of the screen.¬†This will allow the use of lightweight applications like Microsoft OneNote, Autodesk Sketchbook, and Bluebeam for quick hand sketches, written meeting notes, and natural markup of construction documents or other design documents reminiscent to pen and paper. In a very simple process, it is now easy to flip between notes, email and design work.¬†The diagram on this page will help teams focus on relevant tasks and application selection that can be accomplished by many types of applications that will be available on the Yoga.
