title: RhinoInside ‚Äì Pass Geometry Back and Forth
content: Rhino.Inside ‚Äì Pass Geometry Rhino to Revit and Back Download Click Here to Download the Script Geometry Transfer Both Ways Click Here to Download the Script There are many ways to interact with your Revit and Rhino objects using Rhino.Inside. The first step is to select elements to operate on. Next, decide what you want to do with them. In this example, we are selecting all Revit elements of a single category (Floors). All floors (2) in Revit are passed out of the node. The yellow panel in the middle shows those elements (Revit Floor : Concrete). Every aspect of the Revit elements are available to be used or modified, including parameter values. In this example, we are simply extracting the element geometry (Closed Brep). Grasshopper holds data within nodes that are connected together to form a script. To make geometry available natively in Rhino or Revit it must be ‚Äòbaked‚Äô into Rhino or put in Revit using ‚ÄòDirectShape‚Äô. Both functions are very simple to perform. See the image above. The Revit to Rhino process is shown in blue; Rhino to Revit in red. (The ‚ÄòBake‚Äô node is part of the Elefront plugin. It is optional. Right-click to bake any node.) There is much more that Rhino.Inside can do. We‚Äôre still exploring all of the options but wanted to get these basic workflows out to everyone and encourage you to explore more on your own. Reach out to Luc Deckinga or Mario Romero with any questions. How to Use Grasshopper in Revit We will have a one-click install for Rhino.Inside available soon in the software center. Until then download the latest Rhino.Inside build here . Close Rhino and Revit before installing, then restart Revit. OPEN REVIT FIRST! Rhino.Inside (and Grasshopper) must be launched from within Revit to connect the two environments. If you accidentally open Rhino separately the Rhino.Inside tools and menus will not appear in Grasshopper. Open Revit, Add-ins tab Rhino button Rhino Tab Grasshopper button Revit tab in Grasshopper There are many ways to interact with your Revit and Rhino objects using Rhino.Inside. The first step is to select elements to operate on. Next, decide what you want to do with them. Here is an example of selecting elements from the active Revit project by category and then extracting the geometry from those element, here two floor slabs. What is Rhino.Inside? Rhino.Inside breaks down the barriers between designing in Rhino and documenting in Revit. Without getting too technical, Revit, Rhino and Grasshopper are all running in the same ‚Äòsession‚Äô, which means the data in one is available to all others.¬† Open a Revit file. Open a Rhino file. Pass geometry and data back and forth using Grasshopper. We no longer need to export/import through a third-party file format and lose data in the translation.

title: PW Revit Tools  ‚Äì 2021
content: PW Revit Tools Perkins + Will‚Äôs custom developed Revit tools can be found inside Revit on the Perkins + Will Tab. These tools were custom developed to work with the workflow that are specific to Perkins + Will. Project Create We have streamlined the process of project creation by providing Project Create. This tools will help you create new projects using our P+W Templates. To start a new project, use the ‚ÄúProject ‚Äì Create‚Äù command under the Project Creator button. This will open the Create Project window. Step 1: Select a project template Select a template option from the drop down list. Templates are listed by Offices and some offices have special Market sector templates, Contact your local DA for office specific Templates. Firm-wide templates are general templates with common basic elements. Step 2 : Select a Save Option Select a save option from the three choices: BIM360, Network (P: drive) and Do Not Save Yet. BIM360 ‚Äì save file to the local drive temporarily, before taking the next step to upload to BIM360, open MK card for Collaborate in Cloud for BIM360 . Network(P: drive) ‚Äì saves to network, Sync to central and relinquish user created worksets, opens MK card on how to save a new Central File . Note: this option will be removed in Revit 2021 version. Do Not Save Yet ‚Äì gives you the option to save later, if you are not sure what ti do. Open MK card automatically checkbox ‚Äì uncheck to disable MK card from opening automatically. Step 3: Save Filename as ‚Ä¶ Fill out the text boxes that prompts for the Client name and Project Name, the tool will use these names to form the final file name (ClientName+ProjectName.RVT) as per our PDM standard. Step 4 ‚Äì Save to File location Click the ‚ÄúSave To‚Äù button to specify the location that you want to save the file to. You can adjust the filename in this dialog box to suit your need. When you are ready to create the project, simply click on the ‚ÄúCreate‚Äù button to start the process. This command will copy the selected template as a new project (and detach from central). Depending on the save option selected, it will save the file using the name you specified in the folder you selected. If you selected Do No Save Yet option, then you will need to save the project to a project location on the network as the new central file manually. The firmwide baseline template contains the minimum baseline settings and content that are deemed necessary for all teams. The Office specific template contains baseline content, basic annotation settings etc that each office has determined to be included in a starting project template. After clicking the ‚ÄúCreate‚Äù button, you will need to wait a few seconds for the tool to create your new project. As soon as your project is created, you will see this notification window telling you that the project creation is now complete, Click OK to continue. The standard PW template file will look something like this: By default, the PW templates will contain only the basic content need, such as schedules, legends and details. For additional content and settings, please use Hive to import content as needed. ‚ÄúBrowse‚Äù button: enables you to load various Templates from around the Firm . ‚ÄúCancel‚Äù button: will close the window and exit the command. ? button: will open the MK card for ‚ÄúHow Do I Create a New Revit Project?‚Äù Levels Levels Manager Window ‚Äì batch create multiple levels and associated plan views. ‚ÄúAdd Batch‚Äù ‚Äì this button helps you to batch create levels. Simply specify how many levels you‚Äôd like to create, what prefix you‚Äôd like to call the levels, what number you want the new levels to start from, what elevation height the new level will be on, and the typical floor to floor height of the new levels. (use a typical floor to floor height for now, and you can resize later using the RESIZE tool if there is any non-typical floor height on some of the floors). Click on ‚ÄúCreate Levels‚Äù to see a list of the levels. You can edit Level Names, and Shared Elev in this window as well. Click OK to save the changes. If you also want to create new Floor Plans and Reflected Ceiling Plans of the newly created levels, place a check mark on the last column of the levels that you want to create the views for. Click OK to create the views. Export level information to Excel ‚Äì export existing level information to Excel format Import level information from Excel¬†‚Äì Use the exported existing level information in Excel, add in new levels name and height information, then re-import that data back into Revit to create and adjust the levels inside Revit. Levels Resize Manager window: This is a tool to quickly batch adjust floor to floor height. Use Level Resize Manager to adjust floor to floor height of certain number of floors, while maintaining the existing floor to floor height of levels that are not changing. Import Legend Import Legends from PW Digital Practice on Vimeo . Password: DA Import Legend is a tool that helps you import legends from other Revit files. Click on the Browse button to specify the Revit file that you want to copy from, The tool will automatically extract a list of all the legends in the source file (note that it may take a while to load all the legend if the Revit file is very large). Then check and select the legends that you wish to import, and click on the ‚ÄúImport‚Äù button Note: Items in grey do not exist in your current (destination) file. Items that are not in grey already exist in your current file, and if you choose to import items that already exist in your file, then select the Duplicate Option on what you want to deal with the duplicate situation. Duplicates can either be renamed with a suffix (‚Äú-Duplicate‚Äù) or be ignored during the import process. Copy Sheets Copy Sheets is a tool to help you duplicate sheets within a Revit file, or bring in sheets from other Revit file. The default setting is to copy from your Current Revit File. Check and select the sheets that you want to duplicate, then click on the ‚ÄúCopy‚Äù button to copy the sheets. When a sheet is duplicated, everything on the sheet is also copied onto the new sheet. Viewports will be duplicated and given a new view name with a suffix at the end. When copying from another Revit file, sheets with details views, legends and schedules can be copied, but model views will not be able to be copied. Copy Views Copy Views is a tool to help you copy one or more views onto existing sheets. The typical use case is when you have a series of related sheets that all have the same standard layout, with the same legends, and notes or detail views placed in the same locations. Instead of manually placing them on each of these sheets, you would setup one sheet with all the elements placed correctly. Then select this typical sheet as the sample sheet, specify the views that you want to copy, then specify what sheets you want the views to be copied onto, then click ‚ÄúCopy‚Äù to start. View Genie The View Genie contains various tools that streamlines the view creation process, allowing you to batch create the views if you have a specific pattern that repeats, saving you precious time needed to create all your project views. View Genie > Duplicate Views For most projects, we often have a series of standard annotation views that we create for each floor plan. Use Duplicate Views¬†to batch create¬†annotations views with¬†view templates. View Genie > Create Dependent Views Use Depedent Views¬†to batch create a series of dependent views controlled by scope boxes. View Genie > Place Views on Sheet Place Views on Sheet does exactly what the name implies, except you can batch create many sheets each with a single Main view and a legend on¬†each sheet (optional). View Genie > Batch Create Workset Views Batch Create Workset Views is a tool designed to help you setup views that contains a single visible workset, so your user can check and see if there is anything that is in the wrong workset. By default, the workset views will have the WKS_ followed by the workset name as the view name. The views will be created, and all the elements will be turned off, except for the elements in the workset of the same name. The ‚ÄúUpdate All Views‚Äù button will update the view visibility in case new elements were created and were turned on by default/ When new worksets are created, by default the element in those workset will be visible in all views. To fix that, the Update All Views button to automate the visibility update on all the workset views. For more info on View Genie, here is a video from the Shanghai office on View Genie. Update Doors Update Doors helps you batch change the door numbers to match the room numbers. Since doors are phase based, you need to first select a phase that doors are on. Next, you pick the Room Option which the door number will follow. ‚ÄúTo Room‚Äù means the room that the door swings into, ‚ÄúFrom Room‚Äù is the room that the door opens from. Default is the ‚ÄúTo Room‚Äù option. There are three ways to batch update the door numbers. By Level, Pre-Select Doors, and All Doors. By Level ‚Äì select a level from the drop down list of levels, and all the door numbers on that level will be updated. Pre-selected Doors only ‚Äì First you need to pre-select the doors that you want to change, then click on the Update Doors to use this option to update just the selected doors. This is a good option to update just a few doors. All Doors in Building ‚Äì this will update all the doors that are in the file that are of the specified phase. Click ‚ÄúUpdate Door Number‚Äù to start the process. Tool Tips Tool Tips will open our PW Revit QuickStart Guide ‚Äì https://digitalpractice.perkinswill.com/quickstarts/revit-quickstart/

title: CCA Modernization
content: CCA Modernization QuickStart Guide Applying Perkins&Will‚Äôs technology platform to age-old, analog Construction Contract Administration (CCA) processes, will enable us to streamline many arduous tasks. Over the course of the firm‚Äôs Deliver Different initiative, a team of experts from across the firm has studied and investigated our current CCA process with the charge of creating a more efficient and modern process. The assumed solution was to either replace or enhance the existing software application, Newforma. The expert team worked closely with Newforma as well as innovative project teams within the firm for well over 6 months. It was finally determined that the most effective solution was to neither replace nor enhance Newforma, but rather allow our technological advances to remove Newforma entirely . An ambitious plan is being put into action beginning in August to modernize not only our CCA process but also Project Information Management (PIM). Teams currently relying on Newforma in the CCA phase can continue as planned without interruption if they complete their project by June 2022; however, no new Newforma projects will be created. Also, any projects with construction lasting past June of 2022 will need to plan a transition to the new tools and workflows.¬† Instead, we will work with project teams to prepare and transition to our new processes. Training, best practices, and supporting collateral will be documented and published throughout August on this QuickStart Guide. Below you will find the overall project schedule, key new workflows, and a compilation of Frequently Asked Questions. A virtual Town Hall was held on August 5th and was the first step of the conversation of modernizing our project information management and construction contract administration. If you were not able to make it, check out the recording. We will continue to add more answers to our FAQ on this page, as well as some more resources on the technical specifics on how to proceed on the many processes we are talking about moving into. Please reach out to us with any questions in the Digital Practice , Technical Design or Project Management Teams pages. Schedule / FAQ File Transfer RFI‚Äôs Submittals Project Email Field Observations Previous Previous Previous Next Next Next 2022 Plan The second phase of the modernization plan kicked off this year. Many of the related tasks revolve around project teams, working with them to adapt to new work processes. The new solutions are designed to be a flexible framework to accommodate and better adapt to our various practice areas and project sizes. Overburdening projects with unnecessary processes are against the initiative‚Äôs goal of becoming hyper-efficient. Frequently Asked Questions Will I still be able to access past projects? All the data generated or filed with Newforma is accessible on the P: drive, in the project folder.¬† ¬†All Newforma specific data will be stored on our servers and have specific access points when requested. Will there be internal training? Yes, Core eXchange sessions and Lab exchange sessions will be held in the coming weeks. This QuickStart guide will evolve¬† and new microKnowledge cards created. We have existing microKnowledge cards and Core eXchange session recordings focused on BIM360 and Microsoft Teams. These recordings and cards will be curated into a library. If you have a need for specific instructional material, please contact your local Design Applications Manager. Is there any change in Newforma support for projects that remain? Newforma support will remain available if we have active projects on the platform. Utilize our Digital Practice Teams channels, Digital Practice office hours, or our helpdesk support email for technical problems. Will someone reach out to our project team and ask us if we are willing to transition away from Newforma or is it out of our hands? We would prefer to transition projects away from Newforma, so Digital Practice will contact your team to determine if that is a good option. If your project requires its use for construction contract administration, and your team is happy with the current Newforma workflow, you can keep using it until project completion. If you are interested in moving away from Newforma, your local Digital Practice will be able to answer any questions about other tools for use. I really liked using Newforma, can I keep using it? Projects starting in August 2021 will not have Newforma available and only projects that started CCA before this date will continue to have Newforma access after we sunset our regular use. Please discuss alternative software platforms with your Design Applications Manager to replace Newforma functionality that you like. Is there an application that will replace Newforma? We will be using several existing tools which we have found to be better at the individual task Newforma used to cover. Nothing new is being added. Is there anything I need to do to my Digital Execution Plan or my General Division Specs? Digital Execution Plans should always describe the tools and process for completing project work so continue to do this. Division 1 new language is being written right now by Technical Directors, our Legal group, and our specifications writers to require GC/CM‚Äôs to provide construction management software for our projects and to provide the design team with access to it. Please coordinate this with your Technical Director for projects currently in the design phases. If a client requires Newforma for a particular project, is that an option as a project cost or office cost? The current licensing model for Newforma does not lend itself to this scenario. A future cloud version of Newforma is under development and may become a solution. In the meantime we can work with Newforma to review solutions. How do I keep track of my project team (and other project management tasks)? The Microsoft platform provides several ways to do this, one option is a simple excel spreadsheet shared in the Teams project. Please contact your Digital Practice Team member to discuss options. GC is requiring Newforma, do we have to comply, and will Digital Practice be able to support those teams? In most contract situations we do not answer to the GC. We can have a discussion on the best process and practice with both our client and the contractor. Digital Practice supports whatever tools teams are using. We do however have recommendations for best practices that might not align with your selected tools. What will replace Info Exchange? SharePoint/Teams/OneDrive/BIM360 can share files with external parties. BIM360 also can share files, of any format, with external parties. Anyone can create a BIM360 login for free. I am working on construction contract administration on my project right now in Newforma, when will it stop working? If you are happy with your current Newforma workflow, you can keep doing what you‚Äôre doing until the project is complete and closed out. If, however, you and your team would like to transition away from Newforma, you can do so at any time by contacting your local Design Applications Manager. Is BIM360 an option for CCA activities? We can leverage some of BIM360s Document Management tools for certain field activities, but it is not intended to replace the constructor‚Äôs construction management system. We will not be using BIM360s Construction Management‚Äôs modules. Newforma is a single software solution, how many platforms will I need to go when Newforma is not available for RFIs, submittals, change orders, punchlist? We don‚Äôt anticipate the need to use more than 1 or 2 software platforms, and these will typically be platforms you are already using. Please talk to your Technical Director and Design Applications Manager to develop a project-specific plan. Does filling in the gap with 2 or 3 other pieces of software meet the industry standard of care for CCA? Tools do not define the standard of care; they are merely our instruments of service. Our activities and the outcomes define it. File Transfer Microsoft SharePoint will be the underlying platform for transferring most large files. Sharepoint can accommodate individual file transfers or entire project folder structures, to collaborate with sub-consultants, GC/CM, trade partners and clients. BIM360 is the platform for sharing and collaborating with Revit Files, BIM360 can be further extended for document management. Together, these systems are highly adaptable for our teams deliverables. Overall file management is an evolving ecosystem as more software relies on their cloud systems to extend functionality. Our Perkins&Will systems will continue to adapt. The current recommendation is that while collaborating on ‚Äúlive‚Äù files, utilize the platform, ie BIM360, Office 365, Miro, etc. When a document is issued than the corresponding file should be archived in the ‚ÄúP‚Äù drive. Frequently Asked Questions How do I create transmittals for file transfers? The e-mail we use to send the file link and/or the log from Microsoft Office 365 can be utilized as a transmital. What about doing a transmittal for physical items we are sending someone? We have a template in word that can be utilized for the situations where it is needed because the process is not digital in exchanging information. RFI‚Äôs The process of double-logging RFI‚Äôs is coming to an end! A thorough review of how most our CM/GC partners use Construction Management systems allows us to download or request an editable log on demand. These CM/GC-generated logs typically provide all the information we need as a project record and to keep track of RFIs. If your CM/GC partner is not on a modern system we have recommendations for them and/or can provide a RFI log template we can utilize through Office 365. A template has been created that you can download for excel from the image below to use to capture log information for most CCA activities. CCA Log CCA Log Consultant Tracking Only Frequently Asked Questions Where do we do our double-entry of construction activities? Our current tools and processes and those used by our constructor partners have made the double-entry of CCA information obsolete and unnecessary. In most scenarios, we can rely on the RFI, and submittal logs created by the constructor‚Äôs construction management software. When this is the case, the team must download and save these logs regularly (weekly at a minimum) as part of the project file. If this is not possible, please discuss with your Technical Director and Design Applications Manager to develop a project-specific plan. We are required to log information during construction as part of our contract, how will I do that now? There is no single solution to this question, but we acknowledge that this is still necessary to keep records of what is happening during construction on your project. Most scenarios will involve using the platform the contractor provides to track submittals and RFIs and then downloading a report or log from these web platforms weekly (or more frequently if your projects warrant it) to keep for our records. If necessary, we will supplement those downloads with our own notes or adjusted records if we do not feel like the information contained in them is correct. Please contact your Technical Director to formulate a process for your project. Will we need to manually create logs, and manually file all of construction contract administration correspondence now? Please continue to file all construction contract administration e-mail correspondence but use the new shared project folders. For logs, we can generally rely on the logs created by the constructor‚Äôs construction management software and do not need to recreate our own. Please note that this will require that we download and save submittal and RFI logs regularly (weekly is the minimum frequency.) Please talk to your Technical Director to develop a process and workflow for your project that meets the project needs and our contractual obligations. How do I create transmittals for RFIs and Submittals? Most of the construction management software used by our constructor partners (e.g. Procore) creates a transmittal when we return the RFI or submittal. The e-mail we receive when we return RFIs/submittals serves as the transmittal for our records. For this reason, it is critically important that these e-mails be filed in the project shared folder. How should we track RFIs/Submittals if the Contractor/CM is not providing a software solution for this on my project? First, we should push back on the CM/GC for not providing a modern tool. Plangrid is our current recommendation for a low cost software solution the CM/GC can purchase for the project team. We also have existing collaborative tools that can be used for RFI and submittal tracking, Microsoft Excel 365 spreadsheets being the most straightforward. If you are in this situation, please talk to your Technical Director and Design Applications Manager to develop a project-specific plan. The requirement to supply a modern web based tool will be included in¬† Division One of our specifications. Submittals The process of double-logging submittals is coming to an end! A thorough review of how most our CM/GC partners use Construction Management systems allows us to download or request an editable log on demand. These CM/GC-generated logs typically provide all the information we need as a project record and to keep track of submittals. If your CM/GC partner is not on a modern system we have recommendations for them and/or can provide a submittal log template we can utilize through Office 365. A template has been created that you can download for excel from the image below to use to capture log information for most CCA activities. CCA Log CCA Log Consultant Tracking Only Frequently Asked Questions We are required to log information during construction as part of our contract, how will I do that now? There is no single solution to this question, but we acknowledge that this is still necessary to keep records of what is happening during construction on your project. Most scenarios will involve using the platform the contractor provides to track submittals and RFIs and then downloading a report or log from these web platforms weekly (or more frequently if your projects warrant it) to keep for our records. If necessary, we will supplement those downloads with our own notes or adjusted records if we do not feel like the information contained in them is correct. Please contact your Technical Director to formulate a process for your project. Will we need to manually create logs, and manually file all of construction contract administration correspondence now? Please continue to file all construction contract administration e-mail correspondence but use the new shared project folders. For logs, we can generally rely on the logs created by the constructor‚Äôs construction management software and do not need to recreate our own. Please note that this will require that we download and save submittal and RFI logs regularly (weekly is the minimum frequency.) Please talk to your Technical Director to develop a process and workflow for your project that meets the project needs and our contractual obligations. How do I create transmittals for RFIs and Submittals? Most of the construction management software used by our constructor partners (e.g. Procore) creates a transmittal when we return the RFI or submittal. The e-mail we receive when we return RFIs/submittals serves as the transmittal for our records. For this reason, it is critically important that these e-mails be filed in the project shared folder. Where do we do our double-entry of construction activities? Our current tools and processes and those used by our constructor partners have made the double-entry of CCA information obsolete and unnecessary. In most scenarios, we can rely on the RFI, and submittal logs created by the constructor‚Äôs construction management software. When this is the case, the team must download and save these logs regularly (weekly at a minimum) as part of the project file. If this is not possible, please discuss with your Technical Director and Design Applications Manager to develop a project-specific plan. How should we track RFIs/Submittals if the Contractor/CM is not providing a software solution for this on my project? First, we should push back on the CM/GC for not providing a modern tool. Plangrid is our current recommendation for a low cost software solution the CM/GC can purchase for the project team. We also have existing collaborative tools that can be used for RFI and submittal tracking, Microsoft Excel 365 spreadsheets being the most straightforward. If you are in this situation, please talk to your Technical Director and Design Applications Manager to develop a project-specific plan. The requirement to supply a modern web based tool will be included in¬† Division One of our specifications. Project Email Microsoft Outlook will be the primary tool for filing and searching project email. To be successful, it is critical to file project email . For now, the simplest way is to create individual Project Correspondence Folders for each of your projects and file your e-mails there. This process requires no syncing and will even capture ‚Äúthreaded conversations‚Äù, saving a ton of time.¬† You can create additional subfolders for specific project issues, phases, etc. Outlooks rule-based automation can be utilized to aid in filing not only received but also sent messages. A new Hub app named Outlook Connect is under development and will connect your Project Correspondence Folders with your teams Folders . Frequently Asked Questions Since Outlook Connect isn‚Äòt available yet, how can I gather all the team members‚Äô filed e-mails in one place? If you‚Äôre working on a team that fully utilized Newforma‚Äôs e-mail filing capabilities, you can replicate that today by taking 2 simple steps: Create this subfolder in the project‚Äôs P:/ Drive folder: DOCS/10.0-sharedprojectdata/10.01-email. Have each team member drag and drop all emails from the Project Correspondence Folder into the 10.01-email folder on a pre-arranged schedule. The Project Manager or Project Architect should set the cadence for this activity and inform the team. You can then search the contents of the 10.01-email folder using Microsoft Explorer. How will I file my emails without Newforma? Create individual project folders, much like the Newforma Items to File folders you already have. You can then just drag and drop your e-mails into that folder. This process does not require a sync and will include ‚Äúthreaded messages‚Äù saving a lot of time.¬† For the moment these will remain in your Outlook, but once the Outlook Connect app becomes available, it will consolidate e-mail correspondence from all team members‚Äô Project Correspondence Folders.¬† ¬†The typical way anyone shares emails with team members in any industry is simply to forward them to the appropriate people on the team.¬† ¬†It might be beneficial to include a communication plan in your Digital Execution Plan on who to copy on project communication so everyone always has the necessary information.¬† ¬†Another option is to move project conversations to MS Teams channels where all members have access no matter who communication was flowing to or from, even when they join the project team later on. As a Project Manager, how can I find team e-mail communication that I have not been included in? If the e-mail originated with an employee who is no longer with Perkins&Will, please discuss options with your local Operations Director and HR representative. For e-mails that originated with current employees, please tell them directly about transferring the e-mails to the shared project folder. How will we find project information once it has been closed out, if an issue arises or we go to litigation? How searchable is the e-mail, do we have an alternate indexing method of finding e-mails? E-mails that are not filed are saved in a firmwide repository that includes ALL EMAIL including those deleted or misfiled. Access to these e-mails is controlled and you will need to discuss with your local Operations Director, HR Manager, and Technical Director, and our Legal team. IT/HR/Legal will work together with the project team leadership to access what is needed during any type of legal scenario. How can we access emails from employees that no longer work for Perkins&Will? If e-mails are filed in the shared project folder, they will continue to be available there. We strongly encourage everyone to file all project-related e-mails in these folders. All e-mails sent from Perkins&Will addresses are saved by the firm, but access to these must be coordinated with your local Human Resources Manager and Operations Director. Please do not store project information in locations that are tied only to your accounts like OneDrive or your inbox. Doing so will make life difficult for your project team when you move off a project or decide to leave Perkins&Will. What is going to happen with the emails currently archived in Newforma, how will I find them? All emails that were filed in Newforma are stored in the related P drive project folders under DOCS\10.0-sharedprojectdata\10.01-email as msg files.¬† ¬†You can search using windows explorer.¬† ¬†After you search a folder in the advanced options of the search tab in windows explorer there is an option to index the file contents of a non-indexed location so that your search results will include text inside the emails. Field Observation The cloud-based process we‚Äôve adopted with BIM360 will now allow us to streamline the process of doing Field Observations and creating our Field Observation Reports. Using the software tools we already have and some simple hardware setups, you and your team will be able to take site observation images, pin them to the project plans, identify issues, and then create a Field Observation Report immediately. The days of taking a whole day to download your site photos and write up the report are over! Reach out to Digital Practice or your Technical Director for a demonstration on how mobile devices can speed up your site walk workflows. title: Core Exchange Calendar Q3 2021
content: Scroll to next section Scroll to next section Digital Practice Core Exchange Q3 2021 Th is quarter‚Äôs Digital Practice core eXchang e will start on Tuesday, July 13th, and continue through Thursday, July 22nd . These sessions will again provide you awareness and knowledge on how to do many day-to-day tasks of a design team as well as provide AIA continuing education credits.¬† We have reduced the typical schedule down to nine sessions over six days will cover a wide range of topics.¬† We will cover some internal tools developed at the firm for our use as well as some more classes around using data more effectively for design.¬† ¬†We will complement our typical learning sessions with another keynote on Spatial technologies as well as hear from a panel on the topic of how data can improve equity. All of these sessions are now also being complemented by ongoing hands-on workshops we are calling Digital Practice Lab eXchange.¬† ¬†These labs will take all the same subjects and try to give you some real examples to click through and learn various subjects.¬† ¬†Look for these classes happening in the Practice Lecture Hall channel on an ongoing basis. The Digital Practice eXchange i s an educational series hosted by Perkins&Will‚Äôs Digital Practice department for the exchange of ideas, information, knowledge, and expertise . S essions are held weekly throughout the year, with two-week events each quarter. Th is quarter‚Äôs sessions are listed below . Click on any session to add it to your calendar. content:
Scroll to next section Scroll to next section Technology Can Enable Great Things At Perkins&Will, design, technology and research converge, empowering us to create places that improve how we live and work. To continue our tradition of being at the forefront of innovative design, the Digital Practice Team works across all studios and practices to ensure the latest innovations from across the firm are applied to our high-performing, interdisciplinary design process. Through creating and applying digital tools we, improve quality, accelerate project delivery and exceed our client‚Äôs aspirations. News The latest news and updates from Digital Practice. Events Find upcoming and past presentation and training sessions. Resources Browse the Resource tab for Quickstart Guides, marketing and microKnowledge materials. Team Meet and get in contact with the Digital Practice team. Scroll to next section Scroll to next section Latest News AECTech NYC 2025 Recap February 3, 2026 / by Anthony.Samaha@perkinswill.com File Sharing Permission Changes January 28, 2026 / by Daniel.Prager@perkinswill.com Core eXchange 2026 Q1 Recap A look back and recap of the April 2025 Digital Practice Core eXchange. January 27, 2026 / by Daniel.Prager@perkinswill.com FacadesPlus Los Angeles 2025 Tina Giorgadze and Luc Deckinga were onstage at the last FacadesPlus conference of 2025 in Los Angeles on December 12th. They presented ‚ÄòFrom Artwork to Architecture: Translating Community Identity into Facade Design‚Äô which shared the inspiration behind and design process used to create a tiled mosaic artwork for the Kaiser Permanente Watts Medical Building & Watts Counseling and Learning Center. Their presentation was followed by a hands-on workshop that walked the participants through the Rhino and Grasshopper files used to create the mosaic tile patterns. January 6, 2026 / by Luc.Deckinga@perkinswill.com Chicago Innovate Hackathon December 2, 2025 / by Mario.Romero@perkinswill.com Speckle-Con 2025 SpeckleCon 2024 brought together AEC technology leaders from around the world to share invaluable advancements and knowledge aimed at accelerating the application of technology in the AEC industry. This year, the meetup took place on November 13-14 in London‚Äîthe global hub for innovation in design, construction, and BIM. December 2, 2025 / by Adam.Burnham@perkinswill.com CDFAM This recent CDFAM symposium held this Fall in New York at Newlab in the Brooklyn Navy Yards had a wide range of speakers from different industries. This year‚Äôs keynote speakers Markus J. Buehler from MIT and Ian Pegler from NVIDIA each shared their perspectives on AI and product development respectively. Buehler makes the case that LLM‚Äôs will give us ‚Äúbrilliant parrots‚Äù, but they will not give us discovery. Behler defines discovery as the art of ‚Äúasking the right question to express ideas. LLM‚Äôs cannot express ideas‚Äù. AI models cannot be trained on data and expect it to discover something outside of that data. Discovery requires outside perspectives. AI can help convert complexities into principles and create graphs which humans can use to help discover relationships. Pegler claims that a lot of innovation happens at one‚Äôs desk √† people at work, by themselves in momentary isolation, able to think and question, something that AI cannot do. November 24, 2025 / by Charlie.Portelli@perkinswill.com Revit Survey Winners November 4, 2025 / by Mario.Romero@perkinswill.com The Team [av_textblock fold_type='' fold_height='' fold_more='Read more' fold_less='Read less' fold_text_style='' fold_btn_align='' textblock_styling_align='' textblock_styling='' textblock_styling_gap='' textblock_styling_mobile='' size='' av-desktop-font-size='' av-medium-font-size='' av-small-font-size='' av-mini-font-size='' font_color='' color='' fold_overlay_color='' fold_text_color='' fold_btn_color='theme-color' fold_btn_bg_color='' fold_btn_font_color='' size-btn-text='' av-desktop-font-size-btn-text='' av-medium-font-size-btn-text='' av-small-font-size-btn-text='' av-mini-font-size-btn-text='' fold_timer='' z_index_fold='' id='' custom_class='' template_class='' av_uid='av-jpvw6wyh' sc_version='1.0' admin_preview_bg='']
The Digital Practice is comprised of a human network of enthusiastic experts working across all of our studios. The Digital Practice team enables a high-performing, interdisciplinary design organization through the intelligent application of technology. The network shares its collective expertise with teams to align their design process with technology, and develop new capabilities that advance our design process.

title: Virtual Gallery Quickstart

author.name: Nick Cameron
author.description: American trucker who has been featured on the History channel reality television series Ice Road Truckers and its spinoff series IRT: Deadliest Roads.

content: Virtual Gallery Quickstart Virtual Galleries allow us to Spatialize Two-Dimensional Presentations Create a More Immersive Experience than a Slide Deck Integrate Rich-Media Types Showcase Our Design & Technology Abilities Create a Lightweight, Platform Agnostic Leave-Behind Scroll to next section Scroll to next section What Sort of Content Can We Show? Virtual Gallery Examples Bellow are a few examples of projects that have effectively used our Virtual Gallery platform for client engagement: Previous Previous Previous Next Next Next https://vizlab.perkinswill.com/tours/colliers/ https://vizlab.perkinswill.com/tours/macro/ https://vizlab.perkinswill.com/tours/ACE2021/ https://vizlab.perkinswill.com/tours/uva/ Tools Used and Responsibilities There are 3 different tools that are used in the creation of a Virtual Gallery. Each of which a certain person will be responsible for in order to ensure a successful gallery. Below is a list of the tools used and which group may be responsible for each aspect. Rhino Design Team/Digital Practice Enscape Design Team/Digital Practice Pano2VR Digital Practice/Vizlab The Anatomy of the Gallery Gallery Layout Gallery Camera Locations Bay Layouts Previous Previous Previous Next Next Next The gallery space is broken up into 9 separate Bays Each Bay contains 8 boards (A-H) Each Bay also contains 4 camera locations These camera locations are used to render out the 37 panoramas that make up the virtual gallery This diagram shows all of the camera locations Interior Elevation Plan Axon Axon 2 The 4 Camera locations are located directly in between each board pair. Each Board is set to a 16:9 aspect ratio to make translating your current slide decks as easy as possible. Getting Started It‚Äôs recommended that you place the folder either in your project directory or within a sharepoint directory that all team members can access. To the right is a diagram of the Virtual Gallery folder structure The download for the Virtual Gallery files is located below Download Virtual Gallery Folder Making the Boards Boards in Rhino Boards as Materials Board Naming Convention Board Templates Board PNG Location Previous Previous Previous Next Next Next Each board is a simple rhino surface with a corresponding material Each material is mapped to a corresponding PNG file Rhino supports transparency with png image maps so you can get a little creative with the boards Each PNG file follows the same naming convention: ‚Äú B xx BOARD y .png‚Äù Where xx is the Bay number, and y is the board location There are two templates that can be used to generate the boards: An InDesign and a Powerpoint Template file Each Bay points to a corresponding Bay folder for its Board material maps Each PNG is named logically So just export your boards into these folders, replacing the PNGs Rendering the Panos Enscape Template Load Settings Load HDRI Rendering Previous Previous Previous Next Next Next We‚Äôve gone ahead and created an Enscape view setting that works for 90% of use cases It uses an HDRI for lighting HOWEVER, feel free to render this space out however you want. In Enscape 3.0 click this button and browse to the Template folder Then select the Dramatic Lighting.json file Finally, back in Enscape, you should be able to click on the imported preset Open the Visual Settings dialog box and click on the Sky tab Then click on the folder in the Load Skybox from File section Then browse to the HDRI in the Template folder Then just render out your panoramas, replacing the ones in the template folder Each pano file follows the same naming convention: ‚Äú B xx y .jpg‚Äù Where xx is the Bay number, and y is the camera location (e.g. B01A.jpg ) Finalizing the Gallery From here, the team will simply need to coordinate with Digital Practice or Vizlab to get the panoramas uploading to the web. Coordinate Content with either Digital Practice or Vizlab. This could be adding videos, QR codes or links to the final space. Figure out the Address What do you want the address of your Virtual Gallery to be? Final Quality Check Digital Practice or Vizlab will give you a URL while the Gallery is in-progress so you can make sure the gallery is exactly as you want it.

title: About Us
content: HOME ABOUT US NN GIS 101 NN TOOLS GUIDES AND SAMPLES HANGOUT R ABOUT US DMA ‚Äì Data, Modeling and Analytics ‚Äì (also known as Team Data internally) offers modeling, data analytic and visualization services. We specialize in modeling, GIS, R, Python, advanced statical analysis, Big Data, and data visualization tools such as dashboards and interactive storyboards. The team consists of seven full-time modelers, GIS analysts and Data Scientists: Chris Johnson, Team Lead, specializes in modeling (Portland) Bibhas Dey, modeling (Orland) Jin Hong Kim , GIS, Python, R, interactive tools (NY) Meng Gao, GIS, R, PowerBI, and interactive tools (Seattle) Michael Carraher , GIS, AGOL, and cartography (NY) Tomoko DeLaTorre , GIS, AGOL, and cartography (Portland) Ulises Hernandez-Jimenez , R, interactive tools (Seattle, remote) Data Leads Data Leads are advanced users who act as a point of contact at each office. They are your local resource for quick technical support. Jenny Choi (Boston) Sam Ergina (Austin) George Maier (Atlanta) Find us on Slack! Use Slack for ask question, work request, share interesting news, etc. Team Data: team-data R & Python: r-python-users

title: Digital Practice Core eXchange ‚Äì Innovation Incubator Showcase
content: Presenters: Jason Pieper, Jesce Walz, Nikki Liu and Kimberly Seigel Description: Overview of the Innovation Incubator program and the Hub App used to view previous incubators Learn about two recently completed Innovation Incubator projects, highlighting the breadth of Innovation project types. Hear from the team behind Embodied Carbon Calculator for Early Design. This research advances a model-based approach to embodied carbon analysis by integrating Carbon Leadership Forum (CLF) data directly into architectural and structural design workflows. Learn about The Juggle Guide , which explores how caregiving shapes the lives and careers of design professionals, particularly at Perkins&Will, Through surveys, interviews, and focus groups, this research identifies opportunities to strengthen flexibility, empathy, and equity across studios. Target Audience: All Designers Collateral: View Slide Deck View Presentation Video Presented: January 2026

title: Digital Practice Core eXchange ‚Äì Back to Basics: Teams + SharePoint
content: Presenters: Lincoln Jyo¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬†Razan Altiraifi Description: Learn the roles of SharePoint, Teams, and OneDrive and apply best practices for permissions and file sharing. Organize project files using standard folder structures and naming conventions. Compare Sync and OneDrive Shortcuts, and manage folder linking effectively. Integrate Microsoft tools and workflows for collaborative project management. Target Audience: All Designers Collateral: View Slide Deck View Presentation Video Presented: January 2026

title: Digital Practice Core eXchange ‚Äì Back to Basics with Pull Planning
content: Presenters: Jason Diamond¬† ¬† ¬†Joe Jamgochian Description: Breaking work into clear, actionable tasks driven by downstream needs Using buckets and sequencing to align tasks with project phases and commitments Improving visibility, ownership, and handoffs across project teams Establishing shared expectations around task readiness, due dates, and accountability Practical tips for maintaining Planner as a living coordination tool, not a static task list The session emphasizes habits and structure that help teams work backward from milestones, reduce rework, and keep projects moving smoothly. Target Audience: All Designers Collateral: View Slide Deck View Presentation Video Presented: January 2026

title: Digital Practice Core eXchange ‚Äì Overview of Bio-Based and Natural Materials
content: Presenters: Kendall Claus¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† Jesce Walz Description: Bio‚ÄëBased Materials Overview: Guide to available bio‚Äëbased materials, their uses, and how designers can find products for near‚Äëterm application. Research & Industry Context: Overview of North America‚Äôs bio‚Äëbased material landscape within embodied carbon, circularity, and regenerative design. Frameworks & Tools: Material taxonomy, TRL framework, and matrices linking commercial and emerging materials to building elements. Adoption & Design Impact: Market trends, barriers, and how early design choices expand material options, reduce risk, and support confident use. Target Audience: All Designers Collateral: View Presentation Video Presented: January 2026

title: Digital Practice Core eXchange ‚Äì Back to Basics with CCA
content: Presenters: Stephen Grant¬† ¬† ¬† ¬†Daniel Prager Description: Back to Basics ‚Äì CCA¬†is an overview of core tools and workflows that support efficient project execution. This presentation will cover document control and field reporting using BIM360/ACC, along with an introduction to automating Submittals and RFIs through Microsoft Power Automate to streamline file organization, communication and reduce manual effort. Target Audience: All Designers Collateral: View Slide Deck View Presentation Video Presented: January 2026

title: Digital Practice Core eXchange ‚Äì Back to Basics: Conceptual/SD Analysis
content: Presenters: Harish Palani¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬†Yiwei Huang Description: We cover functional updates as well as providing: Explore the available programs and processes at Perkins&Will Learn how to get access to the programs and setup. Getting started with analysis ‚Äì requirements and best practices. Target Audience: All Designers Collateral: View Slide Deck View Presentation Video Presented: January 2026

title: Digital Practice Core eXchange ‚Äì Foundations of Accessibility in Design
content: Presenters: Kate Dailey¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬†Joanne Koola Description: Understand the important foundations for implementing accessibility in the built environment. Learn how an accessibility surveyor works ‚Äì what they measure, how they measure, and how to keep your designs in compliance. Explore common misconceptions regarding inclusion in both renovation work and new construction. Examine requirements for accessible furniture and learn how we can ensure our designs will be compliant. Target Audience: All Designers Collateral: View Slide Deck View Presentation Video Presented: January 2026

title: Digital Practice Core eXchange ‚Äì Hub Apps Overview
content: Presenters: Matt Petermann¬† ¬† Ian Braud Description: Our current Hub apps, their function, and who uses them. The latest updates and apps and what they do now. Development in progress and what is coming soon. Target Audience: All Designers Collateral: View Slide Deck View Presentation Video Presented: January 2026

title: Digital Practice Core eXchange ‚Äì Back to Basics ‚Äì Area Sync
content: Presenters: Dustin Schipper¬† ¬† Zuzanna Czapla Description: This session introduces the fundamentals of Area Sync, our custom tool for managing program data directly within Revit. Participants will learn how to use project models to synchronize room and area information and apply the new features in Area Sync to maintain alignment between design intent and program requirements throughout the project lifecycle. title: Business Analyst
content: HOME ABOUT US NN GIS 101 NN TOOLS GUIDES AND SAMPLES HANGOUT R Go Back to Main Page Business Analyst Esri‚Äôs Business Analyst is an alternative data source that provides demographics, business information, and consumer activity across the US. Multiple workflows and datasets from Business Analyst are useful for NN projects when traditional sources are not available or accurate. Use Cases Job counts by Census block group. When employment data (LEHD) is not available for your study area or existing data is not accurate/recent, use Business Analyst. Example includes: any project in Mississippi because the state does not participate in LEHD program. Employee counts per business/building. Business Analyst can provide a count of employees per business if you need extremely detailed information. This is useful when block groups or other geographies are too large for your study area, and you need to do a more nuanced analysis. Points of interest by type. With Business Analyst you can search for specific types of business (such as grocery stores or pharmacies) if other sources are not helpful. Do note that these would only include business POIs, not recreational POIs or other places without any commerce. Additional data sets (by geography ‚Äì ex: block groups) that may be useful for projects include: Jobs counts by sector (NAICS code) Daytime population counts (employees + visitors) Projected population growth (2030) Esri Consumer Spending index (modeled spending patterns ‚Äì ex: public transit, bike share, parking) Esri Market Potential index (modeled likelihood to use a product ‚Äì ex: Lyft/Uber) Access Anyone with an ArcGIS Online account can access Business Analyst. Please note that usage of this tool can consume ArcGIS Online credits. Credits cost the firm money, so be aware of your potential credit usage. Esri credit guidance (and detailed in guides below per analysis) Guides Download data by polygons Job counts by block groups, daytime population, Esri indices Download data by point Employee counts by business, points of interest

title: Remix
content: HOME ABOUT US NN GIS 101 NN TOOLS GUIDES AND SAMPLES HANGOUT R Go Back to Main Page Remix Remix (by Via) is a transit planning platform for cities and transportation agencies that helps design, analyze, and schedule multimodal transit systems‚Äîincluding fixed route and on-demand services. Features include: Route planning: Draw or modify transit routes and stops quickly on a map. Scheduling and rostering: Generate and modify network schedules, assign drivers and vehicles. On-demand service planning: Draw and modify zones, estimate costs, and analyze demand. Travel time analysis (‚ÄúJane‚Äù): Use isochrones to show how far someone could travel by transit and analyze access to opportunities. Data and demographic layers: Overlay demographics, destinations, or other datasets to understand impacts of network changes in study area. Remix offers built in calculations and statistics to see real time estimates including demographic and cost changes. Multiple output options: Generate standard exports to use in other software like GIS (shapefiles, GTFS, KML, excel), as well as maps for use in reports and presentations. License Access For more information see CeNNtral Station . You can access Remix via NN‚Äôs licenses or via a client agency‚Äôs license. If your client has licenses, that‚Äôs preferable as NN only has a limited number of seats. When licensed via a client agency, you should only actively work on project for licensed client agencies. NN has 25 licenses for Remix Transit. Contact James Zhang (NY) to request a license. Resources Headways and Speed Extract Tool Use an excel template to calculate headways and speeds per hour automatically from Remix outputs. Instructions and template can be found in this folder . Contact James Zhang (NY) for more info.

title: GTFS
content: HOME ABOUT US NN GIS 101 NN TOOLS GUIDES AND SAMPLES HANGOUT R Go Back to Main Page GTFS GTFS (General Transit Feed Specification) is a standardized format for storing transit agency schedule and service information. GTFS data is typically distributed as a zipped file containing multiple text files, which include route linework, stop locations, and schedules. Because transit data from across the country‚Äîand even the world‚Äîis stored in the same format, many tools are available that allow us to bring this data into GIS for further analysis. GTFS data can be downloaded from: Transit agency‚Äôs data portal Mobility Database https://mobilitydatabase.org/ NN Guides and Tools Tools: G:\Resources\How To\GTFS Tools How to guide: G:\Resources\How To\GTFS Tools\Transitsheds with GTFS.pdf Past Training Hangout (2024/10): Open Transit sector meeting (2025/06): G:\Resources\How To\GTFS Tools\Transit Sector (202506) GTFS Transitsheds.pptx

title: Digital Practice Core eXchange ‚Äì Forging a Comfy Path
content: Presenters: Scott Schroeder / Paul Cattaneo Description: In this session we‚Äôll learn about two interfaces to Stable Diffusion and how they are integrated into real project examples. ComfyUI and Forge WebUI are user interfaces designed to make working with Stable Diffusion more accessible. ComfyUI provides a node-based visual interface, allowing users to interact with and manipulate the model‚Äôs workflow easily, making it more customizable and intuitive for those without coding experience. Forge WebUI , on the other hand, offers a text-based interface that simplifies the process of running and interacting with Stable Diffusion in a browser, providing more user-friendly features and tools to enhance image generation and editing. Both UI tools help streamline the process of utilizing Stable Diffusion‚Äôs capabilities, making it more approachable for a wider audience. Target Audience: All Designers Collateral: View Slide Deck View Presentation Video Presented: October 2024

title: Digital Practice Core eXchange ‚Äì AU Preview: From Concept to Creation: Bridge the Gap Between Architecture and Manufacturing Using Informed Design
content: Presenters: Harish Palani Objectives: Have you ever poured your heart into a design, only to discover later it‚Äôs impractical to build? Architects are constantly challenged by the manufacturability of products during design. The ability to assess this early is a critical need for architecture teams. To maintain details, design teams often resort to copying elements from past projects leading to outdated solutions. By the time designers and manufacturers connect, the design is largely set, leaving limited options. What if you could design with the certainty that your vision can become a reality, seamlessly integrating into the world of industrialized construction? Autodesk Informed Design for Revit software is a solution that brings manufacturing information to the beginning of the design process. In this session, we‚Äôll learn how architects can use informed design to collaborate with subcontractors to share manufacturing model data. We‚Äôll discuss how this workflow can improve project certainty and prevent reworks . Collateral: View Slide Deck View Presentation Video Presented: October 2024

title: Form-Found Shell Structure
content: Form-Found Shell Structure: Phase/Frameworks: Development Description For more information about the project this script comes from check out This newsletter post. This script employs a form-finding method that relies upon Kangaroo, a Grasshopper plugin that enables you to apply real-world physics forces to your Rhino geometry. Kangaroo can convert a surface into a grid of points, connected to one another by springs. This effectively turns the surface into a piece of fabric that can be draped, pinned, stretched, and deformed based on the forces that you apply to it. In the example, the perimeter points have been ‚Äòanchored‚Äô in place so they do not move. All points are connected to one another with lines that try to maintain the same length. This turns the surface into a spring network. Finally, a uniform ‚Äòup‚Äô force is applied to all the points, stretching the springs, eventually arriving at a catenary surface that is fit to the courtyard. Workflow Screenshot: Workflow Experts: Luc Deckinga¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† Mario Romero Resources: Download Grasshopper Script

title: Setting Up Project Folder
content: HOME ABOUT US NN GIS 101 NN TOOLS GUIDES AND SAMPLES HANGOUT R Go Back to Main Page Folder Convention Saving data in G Drive There is ‚ÄúR‚Äù folder in the Project Folder in G drive. If the project just started and the project folder doesn‚Äôt exist in G drive yet, follow this guide (Step 2) to set up a folder. If you need assistance, please reach out to Team Data. Review the ‚ÄúNelson\Nygaard R Standards‚Äù (Github page) in the ‚ÄúR‚Äù folder. Saving data in Sharepoint Download a sample folder from the Nelson\Nygaard R Standards Github page Script Titleblock Snippet In R studio go to Tools -> global options ‚Äì> code ‚Äì> bottom of page ‚Äúedit snippets‚Äù ‚Äì> scroll to bottom and paste the below in, change your name in the Author field. snippet header ## --------------------------- ## ## Script name: ## ## Purpose of script: ## ## Project Name: ## ## Project Number: ## ## Author: Esther Needham ## ## Date Created: `r paste(Sys.Date())` ## ## --------------------------- ## ## Notes: ## ## ## --------------------------- ## set working directory here or make sure there is a .Rproj file ## --------------------------- options ( scipen = 6 , digits = 4 ) # view outputs in non-scientific notation ## --------------------------- ## load up the packages we will need:  (uncomment as required) require (tidyverse) require (sf) ## --------------------------- ## load up functions from other scripts into memory # source("functions/summarise_data.R") #example ## ---------------------------

title: ShinnyApps / AWS / Google API Access
content: HOME ABOUT US NN GIS 101 NN TOOLS GUIDES AND SAMPLES HANGOUT R Go Back to Main Page ShinnyApps Web Hosting / AWS SQL Server Hosting / Google API Access ShinyApps Web Hosting Management Dashboard https://www.shinyapps.io/admin/#/profile Management Account shinyapps@nelsonnygaard.com This account is accessible to various people (Jin, Yonghyeon, Tomoko, Oren) You can add it to your email by: Outlook -> Accounting Settings Email Tab -> New Enter shinyapps@nelsonnygaard.com -> Next Restart Outlook and you should see the mailbox at the bottom of the left navigation toolbar. Email is also forwarded to each of the above individuals. Forwarding is set up using a server side rule by logging into Outlook 365 web mail. If others need to be added, this can be done by: Log into Outlook 365 (this link should take you straight to the account) If not, go to icon in upper right -> Open Another Mailbox -> Shinyapps@nelsonygaard.com Settings icon in upper right of Outlook Mail settings -> Rules ‚ÄúShinyapps Email Forwarding‚Äù Rule -> Edit Rule Password See here Uploading to shinyapps.io Use rsconnect package in RStudio to deploy using a token in the Shiny dashboard In Shiny Dashboard, go to Account -> tokens -> Show -> Copy to Clipboard One-time: paste the commend from the Shiny Dashboard ‚Äì rsconnect::setaccount‚Ä¶ In RStudio, run: rsconnect::deployApp() Set working directory to where Shiny app lives Setwd‚Ä¶ (may need to comment and uncomment) AWS SQL Server Hosting To learn more about AWS SQL Server, talk to Yonghyeon (Hannah) Kweon in NY Google API Access Individual accounts needed, threshold beyond (~2500 per day) which you are billed per query

title: Using R Locally
content: HOME ABOUT US NN GIS 101 NN TOOLS GUIDES AND SAMPLES HANGOUT R Go Back to Main Page Using R Locally Installing R / R Studios You can download R and R Studios from Software Center. The package gets updated every six months (in April and November). Relocating Local R Package Folder These steps redefine the R user packages folder in R to use a ‚ÄúLocal‚Äù folder within your R user profile, which for me is: C:/Users/EshelO/Local/R/win-library/3.4 . The username will need to be modified The R version will need to be modified Any user-writable folder will work; IT has agreed on this as a standard location. The same folder can be used for the ArcGIS default geodatabase, Github repository directory, etc.). Relocate your existing R user library folder (which for me was in C:/Users/EshelO/Document/R/win-library/3.4 (if Documents has already been migrated, this would be C:/Users/EshelO/OneDrive - Perkins and Will/Documents) to C:/Users/EshelO/Local/R/win-library (or per above) Test the change: Run .libPaths("C:/Users/EshelO/Local/R/win-library/3.4") (modifying as necessary) ‚Äì this is only for your current R session Run .libPaths() and you should be able to validate this worked Run a test require() and install.packages() to verify R can both read and install to the new location require ( dplyr ) install.packages ( "tidycensus" ) Installing and Configuring Git & GitHub Git is a version control system, a tool that tracks changes to your code and shares those changes with others. Git is most useful when combined with GitHub , a website that allows you to share your code with the world, solicit improvements via pull requests and track issues. Git + GitHub is the most popular version control system for developers of R packages (thousands of R packages are hosted on GitHub) and many other types of software. Git and GitHub are generally useful for all software development and data analysis, not just R packages. To use Git/GitHub with R, you will need to set up a GitHub account and configure RStudio to interface with GitHub. Detailed instructions for this can be found here . File a help ticket with IT to have Git installed. To get an Enterprise P+W account: ‚Äì Create your own personal github account; recommend setting up using your personal e-mail ‚Äì Email Joel Register your github username and ask to be added to the Nelsonteam ‚Äì ‚ÄúCould I request to join the enterprise GitHub account? My username is XXXXX.‚Äù Installing RTools RTools is a collection of development tools that are essential for writing and releasing packages. The latest RTools package can be downloaded from the CRAN website . File a help ticket to have it installed. If everything goes well, you will have a new directory on your computer called C:/Rtools. More detailed information and instructions can be found here . Related Resources Using R on Node Setting up a project folder

title: Using R on Node
content: HOME ABOUT US NN GIS 101 NN TOOLS GUIDES AND SAMPLES HANGOUT R Go Back to Main Page Using R on Node First Steps DO THIS FIRST ‚Äì SETTING UP YOUR R PACKAGE LIBRARY The first thing to do before opening RStudio on node is to set your R package library to the shared package library on the G Drive. You will only have to do this once, as the environment variable should be remembered on your user account even if you are using a different node computer. Step 1: Open the Environment Variables Settings for your User Account The easiest way to access the environment variables settings is to open up Control Panel (within your Start menu), and then search for the settings using the keyword ‚Äòenvironment‚Äô. You will want to click on ‚Äòedit the environment variables‚Äô link to open the dialog, as shown in the screenshot below. Step 2: Create a New Environment Variable Click the ‚ÄòNew‚Äô button to create a new environment variable. Type in R_LIBS_USER for the variable name and G:/Resources/r_package_library for the variable value. Press OK. Step 3: Confirm Your New Variable has been Saved Confirm your new variable is reflected in the list of user environment variables as below. Press OK to confirm. Step 4: Verify Settings in RStudio You can verify that this environment variable is set to the correct value you set above anytime by running the following line of code: Sys.getenv ( x = 'R_LIBS_USER' ) It should return the path you just set above ( 'G:/Resources/r_package_library' ) . If it does not for some reason, please contact Team Data or #team-data. Related Resources Using R locally Setting up a project folder

Both teams discussed Large Language Models (LLM). Sao Paulo Studio presentation delves into the integration and application of images generated through artificial intelligence in the design process, examining how architects can incorporate this innovative tool alongside traditional design methods, while Boston team discuss how Large Language Models (LLM) can assist you when interacting with specification documents, and showcase a proof of concept tool for responding to submittals, and how designers from the firm used it in a controled study. title: Digital Practice Core eXchange ‚Äì AU Rerun: BIM Management and Collaboration
content: Presenter: Jason Diamond¬† ¬† ¬† ¬†Jordana Villagomez Objectives: Explore the crucial role of standards and classification systems, focusing on collaboration and BIM management. Learn how adhering to ISO 19650 can improve project outcomes by delivering greater consistency, accuracy, and efficiency. We‚Äôll show the importance of open standards such as IFC and COBie, which facilitate interoperability between different software platforms and promote collaboration across different teams and disciplines. Furthermore, we‚Äôll highlight the importance of classification systems like UniClass, and UniFormat, which can greatly improve collaboration and communication between project stakeholders by providing a common language for sharing information. In addition, we‚Äôll present how Autodesk Interoperability Tools can effectively support the implementation and use of these standards and classification systems. Collateral: View Slide Deck View Presentation Video Presented: January 2024

title: Sky Exposure Factor
content: Sky Exposure Factor: Phase/Frameworks: Development Description The primary purpose of Sky Exposure Factor analysis is to assess the availability of sunlight at a particular location. This information is crucial for designing efficient solar energy systems, including PV arrays and solar thermal systems. SEF is usually calculated as a ratio or percentage, representing the amount of sunlight received on a horizontal surface compared to the total available sunlight. It takes into account factors like shading, obstructions, and the local climate. The description of the toolset can be found on their website 2023/07 ‚Äì We updated the license to 12.6. Please see this guide for installing the new version. Accessing the tool ETGeo Wizards toolbox should be located under Toolboxes in Catalog pane If you do not see the toolbox, you can add the toolbox from G:\Resources\0.Startup\Toolboxes\ETGeoWizards12_Pro (Please see this guide for how to add a toolbox) You can also use open the tool from Add-in Toolbar (available only if you register the software. Please see this guide for how to register) Important note about¬† ETGeo Wizards Can be added in Model Builder (drag and drop the tool into Model Builder) Shows up in History if the tool was run from Toolbox (instead of Add-in tab) Does NOT support GDB Feature Dataset as an output location. Save output layers in Scratch GDB and copy it over to the Project GDB If using multiple input layers, make sure they are using same projection

title: Computational Design Library ‚Äì WalkShed Diagrams
content: Walkshed Diagrams: Phase/Frameworks: Pre-Design / Schematic Description This workflow helps teams quickly produce walkshed/drive-time diagrams to aid in site analysis in early design. ‚ÄúNeighborhoods should be compact, pedestrian-friendly, and mixed-use,‚Äù and ‚Äúmany activities of daily living should be within walking distance,‚Äù according to the Charter of the New Urbanism . These diagrams provide a visual representation of the accessible walking distance from a specific point or area, taking into account various factors such as pedestrian infrastructure, land use patterns, and urban form. By analyzing and mapping the walkshed, designers can understand the extent to which key destinations and amenities, such as schools, parks, public transportation, and commercial areas, are within a comfortable walking distance for potential users. This information helps inform the placement and layout of buildings, streets, and open spaces, ensuring that the design promotes walkability, encourages active transportation, and fosters vibrant, livable communities. Walkshed diagrams also enable designers to identify gaps or barriers in the pedestrian network, guiding decisions for improving connectivity and enhancing the overall pedestrian experience in the urban environment. Workflow Description: We are using ArcGIS Online to do this. Contact Elton Gjata for access if needed. Step 1) Find the Start Location on a map. a) Sign in to ArcGIS Online. https://nelsonnygaard.maps.arcgis.com/ b) Click on Map at the top. c) Search for a location using the magnifying loop icon. Step 2) Set this location as the center of the study. a) Add this location as a pin on a new sketch layer. A new layer will be added to the map document, on the left hand side of the screen. b) Rename your layer to something logical. We suggest the address of the location. Step 3) Create Walk-Time Areas a) Click on Analysis on the right hand edge of the screen. Under the Tools hammer, look for Generate Travel Areas . b) Configure the type of study. Options include: Walking Time, Walking Distance, Driving Time, Driving Distance. The cutoff distances and cutoff units are important. This controls the radii that we want to use for the study. c) Export the results layer. The walkshed layer will be added to the current map. Step 3) Edit the layer style. Edit the properties of a layer to change the color ramp for the walkshed a) Click the dots on the layer, and click on Show Properties. b) Click on Edit Layer Style. c) Edit the style options to your liking. Workflow Experts: Elton Gjata Sam Ibrahim Resources: Access ArcGIS Online

title: Batchgeo
content: HOME ABOUT US NN GIS 101 NN TOOLS GUIDES AND SAMPLES HANGOUT R Go Back to Main Page Batchgeo www.batchgeo.com How to Guide Open Guide Batchgeo is an online geocoding platform where users can geocode addresses by pasting data onto the website. It generates a Google map with geocoded points, which can be downloaded as KML and then converted into GIS layer. While there is a free version available, Nelson\Nygaard subscribes to BatchGeo Pro which offers enhanced geocoding service. Pros: Easy to use Free Cons: Web-based platform ‚Äì if you are using confidential data, you should not use this tool Not unlimited ‚Äì 250K limit per month for all NN accounts combined Need an Pro account? Contact Tomoko DeLaTorre or Michael Carraher for log-in information.

title: Computational Design Library ‚Äì Sound Attenuation
content: Sound Attenuation: Phase/Frameworks: Ideation Description This script is designed to visualize the impact of sound sources on occupant acoustic comfort levels. By Adding input parameters, such as site, building geometry, and sound source characteristics, the script generates a visual representation of sound attenuation at grade and building open areas. The output can be used to gain quick preliminary insights into the site and to inform design decisions related to acoustic comfort. Workflow Description: The script follows the law of sound attenuation below: The sound source is highlighted with its simulated range. The sound source is subsequently projected on both the ground plane and building facades. And finally, the projected sound levels are overlaid on the surface to estimate impact. Workflow Experts: Mohamed Imam Benyi Hu Resources: Download Grasshopper Script Download Sample Rhino File View Tutorial Video
