title: Computational Design Library ‚Äì Outdoor Comfort (UTCI)

featured_media.title: Outdoor Comfort Urban Micromap – Digital Tool

content: Outdoor Comfort ‚Äì Universal Thermal Climate Index (UTCI): Phase/Frameworks: Ideation/Development Description This script aids in decision-making for redevelopment projects to offer new & better alternatives based on the thermal quality of public places and lowering energy usage by establishing and choosing better microclimate locations. UTCI is a thermal comfort model strictly for the outdoors. It is an international standard for outdoor temperature sensation (aka. ‚Äúfeels-like‚Äù temperature) and is one of the most common of such ‚Äúfeels-like‚Äù temperatures used by meteorologists. UTCI that attempts to satisfy the following requirements: Thermo-physiological significance in the whole range of heat exchange conditions. Valid in all climates, seasons, and scales. Useful for key applications in human biometeorology. Assumptions While UTCI is designed to be valid in all climates and seasons, it assumes that human subjects are walking (with a metabolic rate around 2.4 met) and that they naturally adapt their clothing with the outdoor temperature. For outdoor situations that do not fit these criteria, the Physiological Equivalent Temperature (PET) model is recommended. Workflow Description: Below is an example of the script library analysis process: Inputs air_temp [Required] Data Collection or individual value for air temperature in C. mrt Data Collection or individual value for mean radiant temperature (MRT) in C. Default is the same as the air_temp. rel_humid [Required] Data Collection or individual value for relative humidity in %. Note that percent values are between 0 and 100. wind_vel Data Collection or individual value for meteoroligical wind velocity at 10 m above ground level in m/s. Note that this meteorological velocity at 10 m is simply 1.5 times the speed felt at ground level in the original Fiala model used to create the UTCI model. Therefore, multiplying air speed values at the height of the human subject by 1.5 will make them a suitable input for this component. Default is a low speed of 0.5 m/s, which is the lowest input speed that is recommended for the UTCI model. utci_par Optional comfort parameters from the ‚ÄúLB UTCI Comfort Parameters‚Äù component to specify the temperatures (in Celcius) that are considered acceptable/comfortable. The default will assume a that the comfort range is between 9C and 26C. run [Required] Set to True to run the component. Outputs report Reports, errors, warnings, etc. et to True. utci Universal Thermal Climate Index (UTCI) in Celcius. comfort Integers noting whether the input conditions result in no thermal stress. Values are one of the following: * 0 = thermal stress * 1 = no thremal stress condition Integers noting the thermal status of a subject. Values are one of the following: * -1 = cold * 0 = netural * +1 = hot category Integers noting the category that the UTCI conditions fall under on an 11-point scale. Values are one of the following: * -5 = Extreme Cold Stress (UTCI < -40) * -4 = Very Strong Cold Stress (-40 <= UTCI < -27) * -3 = Strong Cold Stress (-27 <= UTCI < -13) * -2 = Moderate Cold Stress (-12 <= UTCI < 0) * -1 = Slight Cold Stress (0 <= UTCI < 9) * 0 = No Thermal Stress (9 <= UTCI < 26) * +1 = Slight Heat Stress (26 <= UTCI < 28) * +2 = Moderate Heat Stress (28 <= UTCI < 32) * +3 = Strong Heat Stress (32 <= UTCI < 38) * +4 = Very Strong Heat Stress (38 <= UTCI < 46) * +5 = Extreme Heat Stress (46 < UTCI) comf_obj A Python object containing all inputs and results of the analysis. This can be plugged into components like the ‚ÄúComfort Statistics‚Äù component to get further information. Workflow Experts: Elton Gjata¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† Kart Gopinath Resources: Download Grasshopper Script Download Sample Rhino File

This card utilizes the Rhino inside Revit interface to connect data between the Revit/Rhino models. This workflow relies on the City of Vancouver Zoning and Development Bylaw guidelines. ‚ÄúEach exterior window must be located so that a plane extending from the window and formed by an angle of 50 degrees, or two angles with a sum of 70 degrees, will encounter no obstruction over a distance of 24.0 m.‚Äù Workflow Description: Below are the steps to automate the H.A.D. study: Workflow Experts: Mohamed Imam Benyi Hu Resources: Download Grasshopper Script

title: Computational Design Library ‚Äì Rhino To Revit with RhinoInside
content: Rhino.Inside.Revit: Phase/Frameworks: Ideation/Development Description Rhino.Inside is a new technology that allows embedding Rhino into other 64-bit Windows applications. Rhino.Inside.Revit is based on this technology and provides a platform for an unprecedented level of integration between Rhino and Revit, adding over 300 Revit-aware components to the Rhino ecosystem through Grasshopper that can query, modify, analyze, and create native Revit elements Technically , it is an add-on for Revit that loads Rhino and its plugins (e.g. Grasshopper) into Revit‚Äôs memory, just like any other Revit add-on. Grasshopper brings a collection of new components for interacting with Revit, as well as providing access to the two software APIs (Application Programming Interfaces) using its script components. Rhino.Inside.Revit provides a set of tools for bridging the gap between Rhino‚Äôs free-form modelling and the world of BIM, opening Grasshopper‚Äôs rich ecosystem to the Revit environment, and enabling completely new design workflows and possibilities. Workflow Description: To access the Grasshopper script library, you can open Rhino Grasshopper from inside Revit by using the Rhino tab. Workflow Experts: Mohamed Imam Benyi Hu Resources: Download Grasshopper Script View Tutorial Video

title: Computational Design Library ‚Äì Site Maker

title: CTG Skill Matrix
content: HOME ABOUT US GUIDES AND TOOLS RESOUCES HANGOUT PROJECT SAMPLES R & INTERACTIVE MAPS VIZCOMM WEBSITE ENGINEERING CTG Skill Matrix Michal and I did a quick ‚Äúhello chat‚Äù with the former CTG members to understand their skillsets, so that we can better collaborate on projects. Open CTG Skill Matrix Here are some key highlights: GIS ‚Äì Several strong GIS users! However, please note a few items: Due to ongoing IT transitions and updating our own NN GIS workflows and templates the past few weeks, we still have to give the full Team Data orientation to most CTG staff. This includes explaining our folder structure, software access, templates, styles, tools, etc.). There will be a transition period of them getting up to speed with everything like any other new hire. Until then, they cannot immediately jump into NN projects fully without support from other staff and more experienced NN GIS users. NN primarily uses ArcMap for GIS. Many CTG staff are more comfortable with ArcPro (the newer version of GIS software). Please be aware of this as CTG staff may need additional time and/or support to re-acclimate to doing things in ArcMap. There will also need to be coordination with NN GIS users for any work CTG staff would like to do in ArcPro ArcGIS Online ‚Äì Some have experience in ArcGIS Online such as developing Storymap. CTG has their own ArcGIS Online account. We are planning to merge CTG and NN‚Äôs ArcGIS Online account in March Tableau ‚Äì several Tableau users! R ‚Äì we already started working with R users! Please also see the ‚Äúnotes‚Äù column . Some expressed interest in specific types of projects

title: Transit Propensity Index
content: HOME ABOUT US GUIDES AND TOOLS RESOUCES HANGOUT PROJECT SAMPLES R & INTERACTIVE MAPS VIZCOMM WEBSITE ENGINEERING Transit Propensity Index The Transit Propensity Index is used to display likelihood of transit use in a study area. The index value is calculated based on densities of demographic groups (i.e. density of seniors) by census block groups or tracts. Areas with darker color indicate higher concentrations of transit supportive population. Commonly Used Population Data American Community Survey 5-year estimates (block group or larger) Age (65 or older) Youth (10-17 year old) People with disabilities Low income population Zero vehicle households How to Guides What is TPI? Open Document How to Guide Open How to Guide ACS Download Tool This tool provides an interface for downloading American Community Survey (ACS) data typically used in Nelson\Nygaard analyses. title: Terrain-based Bike Shed Analysis

featured_media.title: 2015.0437 Bike Share Demand (SCTA Transportation Mode Shift Action Plan)

content: HOME ABOUT US GUIDES AND TOOLS RESOUCES HANGOUT PROJECT SAMPLES R & INTERACTIVE MAPS VIZCOMM WEBSITE ENGINEERING Go Back to Main Page Terrain-based Bike Shed Analysis The terrain-based bike shed analysis is used to identify ‚Äúareas accessible by bike‚Äù ‚Äî areas bicyclists can access to with a reasonable amount of expended energy. The analysis calculates calories required to travel based on slope and distance traveled. The resulting bike sheds are bigger on a flat topography than areas with various terrains as it requires more energy to bike on hills. The tool, developed based on the Iseki-Tingstrom study, does not consider street types, intersections, or bike facilities. Level of Effort Difficulty : High Estimated Number of Hours: Medium (8-16 hours) + Map Production. How to Guide & Tools How to Guide and tool are saved in G drive G:\Resources\How To\Terrain based bike shed External Resources A new approach for bikeshed analysis with consideration of topography, street connectivity, and energy consumption; Hiroyuki Iseki a,‚áë, Matthew Tingstrom (2014) Past Projects Confidential¬† Client: Seattle-area Employer (2017, 2019, 2022) PMs: Thomas Brennan / Brie Becker GIS: Tomoko DeLaTorre Santa Cruz Rail to Trail Feasibility Study (2016) PMs: Dru VanHengel GIS: Tomoko DeLaTorre Bottineau Blue Line Bike Study ‚Äì LRT Station Access (2015.0248) PMs: Dru VanHengel GIS: Will Sherman /Alyssa P. title: Ped / Bike Demand Analysis

featured_media.title: 2015.0437 Bike Share Demand (SCTA Transportation Mode Shift Action Plan)

content: HOME ABOUT US GUIDES AND TOOLS RESOUCES HANGOUT PROJECT SAMPLES R & INTERACTIVE MAPS VIZCOMM WEBSITE ENGINEERING Go Back to Main Page Ped/Bike Demand Analysis Bike and pedestrian demand analysis is similar to transit demand analysis in that it identifies areas where there is likely to be higher demand for bike and pedestrian facilities. The input data can include demographic/equity measures, such as low income or zero car households, land use/destinations, and/or employment data. When overlaid with other area characteristics such as missing sidewalks and network barriers, bike and pedestrian demand analysis can help shape project prioritization. Level of Effort Difficulty : Medium Estimated Number of Hours: Medium (8-16 hours) + Map Production. title: Level of Traffic Stress (LTS) Analysis

featured_media.title: Bike LTS (Lomita Bike & Ped Master Plan)

content: HOME ABOUT US GUIDES AND TOOLS RESOUCES HANGOUT PROJECT SAMPLES R & INTERACTIVE MAPS VIZCOMM WEBSITE ENGINEERING Go Back to Main Page Level of Traffic Stress (LTS) Analysis Level of traffic stress (LTS) analyses are used to assess the current conditions for bicyclists or pedestrians. Using an industry-accepted methodology developed by The Mineta Institute, various roadway characteristics are assessed to determine a ‚Äúscore‚Äù for the street segment or intersection. Links/intersections with higher scores indicate a greater stress of travel to the bicyclist or pedestrian. Once project recommendations are developed, it can be useful to conduct the LTS analysis for the recommended bike or pedestrian network to show improvements to LTS scores associated with proposed improvements. Level of Effort Difficulty : High Estimated Number of Hours: High(16+ hours) + Map Production. Depending on input data availability.¬† For example, you may need to collect input data such as number of travel lanes using Google Map if the data is not already available Internal Resources Level of Stress Write up ‚Äì ¬†R:\Closed-Projects\I\INDIANAPOLIS Integration Plan 2016.0208\11 Draft Text\Bike Plan\Analysis Methodologies\LTS Methodology.docx Bike and Ped Level of Stress methodology writeup P:\A-E\CORVALLIS TSP Update 2013.0950\11 Draft Text\TM7 Ex Conditions\Active Transportation\PLOS and BLTS External Resources MINETA Low-Stress Bicycle and Network Connectivity Open Page Northeastern University Level of Traffic Stress Open Page San Jose State University Low-Stress Bicycling and Network Connectivity (2012) Open Link Past Projects Lomita Bike & Ped Master Plan (Add Project Code) Indianapolis Integration Plan (2016.0208) Glendale Citywide Pedestrian Plan (Add Project Code) Corvalis TSP Update (2013.0950) Sample Graphics

title: Ease of Crossing
content: HOME ABOUT US NN GIS 101 NN TOOLS GUIDES AND SAMPLES HANGOUT R Go Back to Main Page Ease of Crossing Ease of Crossing analysis is used to identify the relative density and ease of pedestrian crossing opportunities through the study area. Scores are calculated for each street segment based on roadway infrastructure, such as number of lanes and posted speed. Narrower roads with low posted speeds receive higher points, as they are often easier for pedestrians to cross. By contrast, wider roads with high posted speeds receive fewer points, as they are generally more difficult to cross. The proximity to a signalized crossing is also considered, and street segments within a certain distance from a signalized intersection receives additional points. Level of Effort Difficulty : High (requires Network Analyst) Estimated Number of Hours: Moderate (8-16 hours) + Map Production. Depending on the cleanliness of the data. For example, you may need to manually digitize signalized intersection locations using Google Map if the data is not already available in GIS How to Guide Ease of Crossing How to Guide Open Link Past Projects Walk Safe San Jose 2021.0445 Salt Lake City Transportation Master Plan 2019.0665 MARC Connectivity Study 2016.1103 DesMoines Walkability 2015.0456 Glendale Citywide Pedestrian Plan 2015.0758 Sample Graphics

title: Maptionnaire
content: HOME ABOUT US NN GIS 101 NN TOOLS GUIDES AND SAMPLES HANGOUT R Go Back to the Samples Main Page Maptionnaire Maptionnaire is a third-party webmap based survey tool. It has similar features to SurveyMonkey, with the added benefit of map-based questions. https://new.maptionnaire.com/ Benefits: Easy to use (similar to SurveyMonkey) Includes typical survey question (+ map-based) and logic capabilities Mobile friendly Discussion questions (allows for responses to other submission) Bring map-based results into GIS Pre-made analysis of results (charts, heatmaps, AI available to analyze open ended questions) Easy translation process (table based for quick input, or AI for auto translation) Cost $800 per survey To recoup the cost, we are charging $800 per survey to a client. Please coordinate with your project accountant to charge the client this cost. Contact Tomoko DeLaTorre (Portland) or Michael Carraher (NY) with any questions. How to use: NN has a corporate account. You can create your account using your NN email address. Contact Tomoko DeLaTorre (Portland) or Michael Carraher (NY). We will add your account to the NN workgroup You should receive an invitation email to set up your account Create a draft survey (draft survey is free of charge) Publish the survey (coordinate with accounting to charge client) Note There is a limit of number of surveys we can have in our workgroup (including draft surveys). If you want to create a ‚ÄúTest‚Äù survey to learn about Maptionnaire, please include ‚ÄúTEST‚Äù in the name of the survey and archive them when you are done with them. Examples of questionnaires Demo: map-based demo questionnaire mpt.link/demo-questionnaire Demo: Map and theme based budget restriction questions: https://new.maptionnaire.com/q/2bsv8k9hgk9c Demo: Comment on the new plan: https://new.maptionnaire.com/q/32tsb3uz84bj Customer Stories and live examples: Project for the City of Las Vegas, USA ‚Äì Developments around a rapid mass transit : https://new.maptionnaire.com/q/3s2v22l32i9b City of Sacramento, California ‚Äì Transportation Plan ‚Äì https://new.maptionnaire.com/q/88up9izi7xi3 San Diego University Community Plan: https://new.maptionnaire.com/q/9uj2sgw7p89a City of Santa Barbara ‚Äì Future of State Street: https://new.maptionnaire.com/q/2lm3acv4dne9 More about the analysis tools here: https://support.maptionnaire.com/hc/en-us/categories/360002857940-Results-and-analysis Ability to manage and export collected data sets ‚Äì also for analysis in other GIS tools Sample Projects Westchester County Mobility & Transit Plan (contact person ‚Äì Michael Carraher) Park City LRTP (Layne Wyse) Stockton Boulevard Community Survey (Layne Wyse) Lynnwood Active & Accessible Transportation Plan (Layne Wyse) Denver Moves (Oren Eshel) Sample Images Images saved in Sharepoint Open the folder

title: 07 81 00 Applied Fireproofing
content: Topic: Applied Fire Proofing in Steel Building and Exposed Ceilings Project Name: FPL PGA Project Phase: Construction Project Team Member: Carlos Chiu Lessons Learned: Specifying skip-troweled finish over spray applied fire proofing, colored topcoat after finishing. Quality can vary a lot. For labor purposes, spray applicators and plasterers are in the same union and can take on both scopes. However, keep in mind that specifying spray applied only application and asking the spray applier to knockdown will not have the same quality results as having a plasterer do the work. What is shown in these images is a trowel grade (TG) cementitious product that is spray applied and then troweled smooth(ish). Maybe a multi-person operation and requiring skilled labor. Upon further review, the spec just needed to specify the right product that matched the application method.

title: Collision Dashboard
content: HOME ABOUT US GUIDES AND TOOLS RESOUCES HANGOUT PROJECT SAMPLES R & INTERACTIVE MAPS VIZCOMM WEBSITE ENGINEERING Go Back to Main Page Collision Dashboard Using R Interactive collision dashboard developed by using R-Shiny. Users are able to dig into data using filters and interactive map. The biggest advantage of this tool is that it is highly customizable ‚Äì ability to adapt client‚Äôs needs and design requirements. Key Features: Highly customizable. Can be embedded in a website; or sent as file attachment to open in browser as quick share method The scripts for both analysis and map production are stored in R and can be easily shareable as part of project deliverable Consideration Requires R knowledge if a client wants to maintain the dashboard Cost None. Already subscribed to annual subscription plan (though max 2,000 active hours). Example Portland Pedestrian Master Plan Collision Dashboard (2017.0108) ‚Äì see example below Using ArcGIS Online Esri‚Äôs ArcGIS online has Dashboard tool with interactive map, filter functions, charts and tables. The biggest advantage¬† of using ArcGIS online is that it is easy to develop ‚Äì no programing language required. This tool requires ArcGIS online account. Contact Team Data for account information. Key Features Easy to develop, no programing language required Can develop a ‚Äúwebsite‚Äù (multiple pages with tabs) with dashboard by using Experience Builder. Can add a page for data source or guides. Reads GIS layers and symbology set up in GIS Can incorporate GIS layers already hosted in ArcGIS online (for example, city boundary layer hosted on the client‚Äôs data portal) Easy to transfer data to client‚Äôs ArcGIS online account when the project is done (or develop using their ArcGIS online account) Consideration No password protection option Limited design customization. It uses Esri‚Äôs template as a base Ideal to host the dashboard on the client‚Äôs ArcGIS online because collision dataset is typically large (which consumes a lot of Esri credits) Cost Cost ‚Äúcredits‚Äù to store data in ArcGIS online Example Vancouver TSP Update Collision Dashboard (2019.0208) ‚Äì see example below Sample Projects PDOT Collision Dashboard (2017.0108) Vancouver TSP Internal Tool (2019.0208) Vancouver TSP Public Dashboard (2019.0208)

title: Wikimapping
content: HOME ABOUT US GUIDES AND TOOLS RESOUCES HANGOUT PROJECT SAMPLES R & INTERACTIVE MAPS VIZCOMM WEBSITE ENGINEERING Wikimapping Wikimapping is a third-party webmap based survey tool. Cheaper than Maptionnaire but survey functions are not as comprehensive. If you want to develop more robust survey like SurveyMonkey, you may want to consider using Maptionnaire . https://wikimapping.com/blog/ Key Features Survey functions are not as comprehensive as Maptionnaire Commenting and voting allowed on other‚Äôs input Can incorporate general survey per user or survey per item drawn Each language version needs to be purchased separately Some aspects of interface cannot be translated Can be used on mobile but certain features can become hidden Cost $449 for one year (can repurpose project for another if within year, at no additional cost Sample Projects Austin Butler Trail Safety & Mobility Study (2019.0418): English Open the survey Spanish Open the survey this one is live at the moment and was enhanced for mobile-phone access to ensure equitable reach ‚Äì without an intro screen, wikimap is not as phone-user-friendly‚Ä¶why that matters Open the survey Rt. 119 Complete Street : Open the survey Fayetteville Mobility Plan : Open the survey Grand Rapids Vital Streets (150247) : Open the survey ‚Äì Survey 1 Open the survey ‚Äì Survey 2 COIC Coordinated Plan Update (2014.0976): Open the survey Outputs to synthesize the results : R:\GIS-Archive\C\COIC_Central_OR_Transit_Planning_(2014.0976)\To Client\WikimappingResults Puyallup : Open the survey Sample Images Sample images saved in Sharepoint Open the folder Austin Butler Trail Safety and Mobility Study - Spanish Version Austin Butler Trail Safety and Mobility Study Rt 119 Wave Transit

title: ArcGIS Online ‚Äì Web Maps
content: HOME ABOUT US NN GIS 101 NN TOOLS GUIDES AND SAMPLES HANGOUT R ArcGIS Online Web Maps Esri‚Äôs interactive web mapping tool. It is ideal for map(s) with multiple overlapping layers to display. Can build in a simple comment tool (place a point/line/polygon and add comments). This tools requires ArcGIS Online account. Key Features Can build in simple comment tool Reads GIS layers / map symbology set up in ArcGIS Can host multiple maps with one link (Like this example) by using Experience Builder Can transfer data to client‚Äôs ArcGIS online account when the project is done (or develop using their ArcGIS online account) There is no password protection option . The map(s) have to be either: shared publicly (anyone can access to it) limited to ArcGIS Online users (viewers need to log into ArcGIS Online to view the map(s) If the maps have to be password protected, consider using R instead. Level of Effort Medium (10+ hours) What influence the budget? Questions to ask. How many webmaps do we need to produce? Are the maps complicated? How many layers do we need to¬† include in the map(s)? Do we have GIS layers already developed for this? If not, make sure to add extra hours for data acquisition,¬† development, and clean-ups. Sample Projects WAKE CO Transit Plan Update (2019.0622) SFMTA Transit Corridor Study (2018.1026) DC DOT Safe Route to School (2020.1176) Capital Metro MetroBike Strategic Expansion Plan (2020.0955) Bainbridge Island (2019.0328) El Paso COA 2021.0168 Esri's Gallery

title: Bus Delay Analysis Tool (BDAT)
content: HOME ABOUT US GUIDES AND TOOLS RESOUCES HANGOUT PROJECT SAMPLES R & INTERACTIVE MAPS VIZCOMM WEBSITE ENGINEERING Go Back to the Sample Projects Main Page Bus Delay Analysis Tool (BDAT) Bus Delay Analysis Tool (BDAT) is an interactive dashboard that displays transit service performance at a segment level. Bus delay is typically quantified based on aggregated AVL data and is calculated as the difference between the 80th percentile travel time and the 20th percentile travel time. The BDAT tool is used for transit agency‚Äôs project prioritization process for the bus service network. Level of Effort High This more complex iteration of BDAT was developed in a combined project between the two agencies and is expected to cost between $100-150k when complete. Using the codebase for another project, some cost could be saved, but there are custom elements/costs for each agency that must be developed from scratch. Marketing Materials Qual sheet: Link Sample Projects King Co Metro Transit Mobility Framework and Regional Planning (2019.0221) TriMet Bus Delay Analysis (2018.0756)

title: Replica
content: HOME ABOUT US NN GIS 101 NN TOOLS GUIDES AND SAMPLES HANGOUT R Go Back to the Sample Projects Main Page Replica https://my.replicahq.com/ Nelson\Nygaard has a contract with Replica until December 2025, which give us access to a number of different datasets. Replica‚Äôs information sheet provides a good overview of the product Open the link Do you need an account? We have unlimited access to Replica with our contract. You can create an account using your NN email address at any time from the Replica website here NN Resources OD analysis tool Open How to Guide Hangout sessions Replica 101 (Hangout ‚Äì August 2022) Link Replica update (Hangout ‚Äì July 2023) Link Replica OD analysis tool (Hangout ‚Äì September 2023) Link Slack Channel ‚Äì nn-replica Use the slack channel nn-replica to ask questions! What is Replica? Multiple datasets are available through Replica and can be found in the left-hand tab menu on the home page after logging in. ‚Äî Places (Studies) ‚Äî Replica Places (also called Studies) are high-fidelity activity-based travel models that simulate the movements of residents, visitors, and commercial vehicles in a given area. Replica produces Places models as ‚Äúmegaregions,‚Äù each covering about 30 million people, for a typical weekday and typical weekend day in a given season. Data outputs can be queried down to the network link level. ( Replica 2022 ) At NN, we most often use Places data to map travel flows over a study area, with the additional ability to break down flows by demographic group and other trip characteristics (for example: time of day, mode, etc.). ‚Äî Trends (Dashboards) ‚Äî Replica Trends (also called Dashboards) is a nationwide activity-based model updated each week with near-real-time data on mobility, consumer spending, and Covid-19 cases. Trends has census-tract-level fidelity with mobility data including origins and destinations, trip mode, and trip purpose, and consumer spending data in aggregate and across a number of sub-categories, including retail, grocery stores, restaurants, and travel. Replica generates its data by running large-scale, computationally intensive simulations. These simulations allow us to deliver granular data outputs that match behavior in aggregate, but don‚Äôt surface the actual movements (or compromise the privacy) of any one individual. ( Replica 2022 ) Trends is useful for quickly viewing travel patterns, up to the latest week, for a study area. You can create a custom dashboard to track data over time. ‚Äî Traffic Data ‚Äî Found via the ‚ÄòData Downloads‚Äô menu from the home screen, in the Traffic section, this data includes: Annual Average Daily Traffic (AADT) ‚Äì Daily traffic per network link by season. Turning Movement Counts ‚Äì Motor vehicle trip counts at most signalized intersection for each day of the week, bucketed into 1-hour intervals. Free-Flow Speeds ‚Äì Annual average free-flow speed per network link. Quarter Hourly Speeds Profile ‚Äì Average observed speed per network link, provided in quarter-hourly buckets for a typical week. ‚Äî Reference Downloads ‚Äî Found via the ‚ÄòReference Downloads‚Äô menu from the home screen, this data includes: Geographic Data ‚Äì Files that include the geographic boundaries, street network, and transit services used in other Replica products (such as Places and Trends). Any tabular data in Replica can joined to geographic data in GIS for spatial analysis and mapping purposes. Land Use ‚Äì Current use of land and buildings for the area included in your geography. This data can be used if no other land use data is available for your study area. Replica land use data in more generalized and not officially produced by a local jurisdiction. Parking Spaces ‚Äì One-street and lot (off-street) parking data includes the number of spaces, rate structures, opening hours, operators, and other attributes. Note, this dataset is not comprehensive over a study area. On-street parking spaces are often available in limited areas of a city, typically where there‚Äôs the highest competition for an on-street spot. Off-street parking is also limited to commercial lots and public facilities. For example, restricted commercial spots (parking allowed only for customers of a store) will generally not be included. See coverage map for more detail. ‚Äî Report Data ‚Äî Transit Data Report ‚Äì Replica provides transit summary reports such as transit mobility patterns or transit rider summary at a high-level. You should use BigQuery transit dataset for detailed information. Click link to access this data. Transit Routes (Stops Level Data and Counts Report) ‚Äì This report displays detailed information about modeled transit ridership. Click link to access this data. ‚Äî Big Query ‚Äî Replica offers direct access to Places data outputs through Google BigQuery. This dataset is the same format as Places, but includes transit route info with trip start/end point (lat/lon) info instead of generalized to block groups. In other words, each trip activity is associated with transit route information if trip takers are using public transit as their primary mode for their trips. It allows you to analyze origin-destination trip patterns of a specific transit agency‚Äôs riders. Notes: The email account must be associated with an active Google account To have access to BigQuery, fill out this form Data can be queried with SQL or Python See User Guide for more information For support, reach out to Team Data, support@replicahq.com , or use the in-app chat for help or ask question Data Source & Methodology See Replica‚Äôs documentation about how Replica develops the data: Public articles on Replica website Public articles with links to methodology and source data Click here Public-facing document. OK to Share with a client. title: LEHD Analysis
content: HOME ABOUT US GUIDES AND TOOLS RESOUCES HANGOUT PROJECT SAMPLES R & INTERACTIVE MAPS VIZCOMM WEBSITE ENGINEERING LEHD Analysis About LEHD The U.S. Census Longitudinal Employer-Household Dynamics (LEHD) program is used to examine employment density and commute patterns by job sector, demographic characteristics and income category. The data is updated annually and available at census block level, but can be easily aggregated. Income is defined by state unemployment insurance law, but it is generally pre-tax. IMPORTANT! Data collected at Headquarters: employment data is collected at headquarters, such as the administrative building for all the schools in the area. Make sure to review the result carefully to make sure the result ‚Äúmakes sense‚Äù. Example : In the map below, the largest blue dot on the left represents the tax address of 65% of the jobs in Los Alamos County, but in reality they are spread out across the county. LEHD Data Download Tool The LEHD download tool was developed by Paul Leitman using R/Shiny. The tool allows users to download data for the number of jobs or for employee travel flows between home and work geographies. It relies on data from the US Census Bureau‚Äôs LODES datasets. To improve Nelson\Nygaard‚Äôs analysis capabilities and reduce the staff hours to extract LEHD data, the tool exports data as CSV, Excel and as shapefiles. Additionally, the tool allows data to be summarized into 14 different geography types, as well as custom geographies or into a grid of squares or hexagons (which are generated directly in the tool). Thanks to Paul Leitman for setting this up. LEHD Download Tool How to Guide > Employment Data from OnTheMap ( Open Link ) Additional how to guides are saved in this folder: G:\Resources\How To\Census LEHD > Path of Travel Analysis ( Open Link ) Map Samples Washington Co Origin by County Rte 9 Active Transportation Corridor WWVMPO Emp (2018.0047) VTA Core OD Interzon (2015.0108) VTA Core OD WithinZone  (2015.0108) COIC Commute Patterns (2014.0976) Kitsap Transit LRTP Inter flow (2020.1043) Kitsap Transit LRTP Intra flow (2020.1043) Maui travel flow

title: Core eXchange ‚Äì Panel: Data and Equity
content: Panelists: Serra Uzun¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬†Jason Diamon¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† Gautam Sundaram¬† Brad Rogers Preface: The term ‚Äúdata equity‚Äù captures a complex and multi-faceted set of ideas. It refers to the consideration, through an equity lens, of the ways in which data is collected, analyzed, interpreted, and distributed. It underscores marginalized communities‚Äô unequal opportunities to access data and, at times, their harm from data‚Äôs misuse. It raises the issue of data sovereignty and the democratization of data. And data equity pushes us to consider the ways that data can reinforce stereotypes, exacerbate problems like racial bias, or otherwise undermine social justice. Collateral: View Panel Discussion Video Presented: July 2021

title: Demographic Analysis Basics
content: HOME ABOUT US GUIDES AND TOOLS RESOUCES HANGOUT PROJECT SAMPLES R & INTERACTIVE MAPS VIZCOMM WEBSITE ENGINEERING Demographic Analysis How to Guides To add a link ACS Download Tool This tool provides an interface for downloading American Community Survey (ACS) data typically used in Nelson\Nygaard analyses. Currently, only 5-year estimates are available through the tool. Data is available at the country, tract, and block group level for 2010 ‚Äì 2021 (as tables are available for particular years). More features and variables will continue to be added to the tool, please request features by taking this short survey . You can download the data with or without geometries (i.e. shapefiles), and you must join the data yourself after making any edits (if necessary) to the tabular data. Comparing ACS data over time You may need to compare multiple ACS datasets to examine trends over time. Keep in mind the following when comparing ACS data: Make sure the data periods do not overlap . For examples, it is OK to compare 2005-2009 ACS 5-year estimates to 2010-2014 ACS 5-year estimates Some ACS variables change over time . When comparing multiple datasets, use the Census web page below to make sure a specific subject/topic is comparable over time. Census Bureau‚Äôs guide https://www.census.gov/programs-surveys/acs/guidance/comparing-acs-data.html Common Variables to Use Variables ACS 5-Year Estimates Tables Geography Total population B01003 ‚Äì Total Population Block groups Housing units B25001 ‚Äì Housing units Block groups Average Household size B25010 ‚Äì Average household size of occupied housing units by tenure Block groups Age (Youth and Senior) B01001 ‚Äì Sex by Age Typically, youth are those younger than 18 (or 10-17) and seniors 65+, but this can sometimes vary by region, project, etc. ‚Äì check with your project manager Block groups People with disabilities B23024 ‚Äì Poverty status by disability status (age 16- 64 years ) Block groups B18101 ‚Äì Sex by Age by Disability Status Tract Zero vehicle households B25044 ‚Äì TENURE BY VEHICLES AVAILABLE Block groups Renter / owners B25003 ‚Äì TENURE Block groups Language B16007 ‚Äì AGE BY LANGUAGE SPOKEN AT HOME Block groups English Proficiency B16004 ‚Äì Age by Language Spoken at Home by Ability to Speak English for the Population 5 Years and Over Block groups People in poverty B17021 ‚Äì POVERTY STATUS OF INDIVIDUALS IN THE PAST 12 MONTHS BY LIVING ARRANGEMENT Block groups People whose household income is less than 150% of federal poverty line C17002 ‚Äì RATIO OF INCOME TO POVERTY LEVEL IN THE PAST 12 MONTHS You may want to use 175% or 200% depending on how the local government / transit agency defines ‚Äúlow income‚Äù in your study area. Check with Project Manager before you run the analysis. Block groups Household income B19001 ‚Äì HOUSEHOLD INCOME IN THE PAST12 MONTHS (IN 2015 INFLATION-ADJUSTED DOLLARS) Block groups Median household income B19013 ‚Äì EDIAN HOUSEHOLD INCOME IN THE PAST 12 MONTHS (IN 2014 INFLATION-ADJUSTED DOLLARS) Block groups Race B03002 ‚Äì HISPANIC OR LATINO ORIGIN BY RACE Block groups Foreign Born B99051 ‚Äì ALLOCATION OF CITIZENSHIP STATUS Block groups Non-traditional work hours B08302 ‚Äì TIME LEAVING HOME TO GO TO WORK Block groups Basic Analysis Samples Minority Population (MNDOT Statewide Investment Plan) 2019.0314 Westchester  Change in Jobs 2010 to 2017-01 2019.0314 Westchester Pop Density Population Density (Los Angeles) SANTA CRUZ Rail-Trail Feasibility 925004.A01 2015.1004_Page_2 Emp Change_San Antonio(2014.0831)

title: ArcGIS Online ‚Äì StoryMaps
content: HOME ABOUT US NN GIS 101 NN TOOLS GUIDES AND SAMPLES HANGOUT R Go Back to the Sample Projects Main Page ArcGIS Online ‚Äì StoryMaps StoryMaps is Esri‚Äôs interactive storyboard that can be used to present project summary or highlight key findings as part of public engagement process. StoryMaps often contains text, web maps, static images and infographics. A simple survey can be also added into StoryMaps. StoryMaps has two sharing options: Public (anyone can access to it). Restricted ArcGIS online group:¬† Requires ArcGIS online account. There is no option to add a password protection. What influence the budget? Questions to ask. How many¬† webmaps do we need to produce? Are the maps complicated? How many layers do we need to¬† include in the map(s)? Do we need to produce custom graphics (for example,¬† infographics by VizComm) Do you want to add a survey to the storymap? Simple StoryMap 10 hours : 5 hours for storymap itself, 5 hours for setting up webmaps. Note that this does not include hours for GIS analysis or custom graphic production (i.e. infographic produced by VizComm). Examples (See Map Collection below) Go Norman Transit Study (2020.0529) Complex StoryMap 20+ hours: Make sure to budget enough hours for additional components such as survey or custom graphics. Examples (See Map Collection below) Austin¬† Butler Trail Safety and Mobility Plan (2019.0418) Lynnwood Citywide Multimodal Transportation Planning (2017.0871) Guides Embedding Wikimap Open link Embedding R-dashboard Open link Sample Projects Go Norman Transit Study (2020.0529) Austin Butler Trail (2019.0418) Lynnwood Citywide Multimodal (2017.0871) SEPTA Bus Revolution Network Option (2019.0467) Kitsap Transit LRT Plan (2020.0143) SLC TMP (2019.0665) CapMetro EDOT (2021.0129) White Salmon TSP (2021.0341) White Salmon TSP SPANISH (2021.0341) IndyGo Mobility On Demand (920601.002) Study UTA Long Range Transit Plan 2022.0158 GPCOG Transit Together 2021.0007 z.Esri's Storymaps Gallery z.Esri's Hub Gallery z. title: Streetlght

featured_media.title: Streetlight Flows within and between Jurisdictions_Full

content: HOME ABOUT US GUIDES AND TOOLS RESOUCES HANGOUT PROJECT SAMPLES R & INTERACTIVE MAPS VIZCOMM WEBSITE ENGINEERING Go Back to the Sample Projects Main Page Streetlight What is Streetlight? StreetLight is a dataset that provides insight into how, where, and when people travel. The dataset itself is based on anonymous data collected from mobile devices (e.g., cell phones, tablets), which is then cleaned and processed. This data processing considers under sampling that may occur for a given area, based on known Census population data and traffic counters installed by municipalities. Data is typically defined based on zones, which can be either user-defined (with a shapefile) or picked from standard geographies (e.g., census geographies like tracts, block groups) that Streetlight has saved for a given region. Data Access and Cost Need to purchase the data. If you want to learn more, please reach out to Team Data. Materials StreetLight Training Session (Oct 2022) Open Recording Open PPT NN‚Äôs Streetlight Guide Open Document Big Data Comparison table Open Document Past Projects DUTCHESS CO Transit Study (2020.0088) Final¬† Report ‚Äì See page 17 for travel flow analysis Open Document AUSTIN Downtown Circulator Study (2019.1204) Streetlight Analysis Writeup Open Document StreetLight Overview Memo Open Document Vancouver TSP Updates (2019.0208) To add Westchester Bus Redesign (2019.0314): Final¬† Report ‚Äì See page 43 for travel patterns analysis Open Document Graphic Samples WESTCHESTER County Mobility Bus ReDesign (2019.0314)

title: ArcGIS Online: Bainbridge Island Interactive Map
content: HOME PROJECT SAMPLES RESOUCES R & INTERACTIVE MAPS ABOUT US Go Back to the Sample Projects Main Page Bainbridge Island Interactive Map (2021) During the first phase of the Bainbridge Island (WA) Sustainable Transportation Plan , the team developed an interactive map and summary gap analysis that was used to identify projects and programs in the next phase of work. Bainbridge Island has ambitious climate goals‚Äîincluding a 90% GHG reduction target‚Äîand the Sustainable Transportation Plan is key piece of their strategy to meet those goals. To support the identification of infrastructure, program, and policy gaps, the team created an interactive map that brings together dozens of data layers (including existing data, NN analyses, and community input). By turning on and off different combinations of layers that connect to plan goals, our Sustainable Transportation Task Force and City Council have been able to see behind the analysis curtain and participate in the process we‚Äôve used to identify needs. (Radical transparency is the name of the planning game on the Island.) content: HOME ABOUT US PROJECT SAMPLES RESOUCES R & INTERACTIVE MAPS VIZCOMM WEBSITE ENGINEERING Go Back to the Sample Projects Main Page City of Portland Crash Analysis and Dashboard We completed this crash analysis as part of additional Vision Zero related analysis done for the Portland Pedestrian Master Plan. The primary goal of the analysis was to develop a crash typology for pedestrian, bicycle, and severe/fatal vehicle crashes that would assist the City of Portland in countermeasure identification. We also developed an interactive crash dashboard to help them visualize these data, especially in relation to the High Crash Network identified for Vision Zero. Project Information Project name : Portland Pedestrian Master Plan Project code : 2017.0108 Sector : Transit Hub page : Link Level of Effort High (16+ hrs) Assuming the crash data are in relatively clean shape, the basic elements of the crash dashboard do not take long to develop (e.g., can go from raw data to dashboard in 30-40 hours). The most time consuming aspect of a crash analysis is the typing process, because it is necessarily subjective and based upon local knowledge and a variety of factors that exist outside of the crash data and may be in various states of data cleanliness. For example, for Portland, the crash data were clean, but their number of lanes dataset for their streets was not, and we spent another 20-30 hours just cleaning up this single dataset. So adding more supplemental datasets that are not already well prepared will add time to the analysis. Major Deliverables Dashboard Link Full Citywide analysis memo Link Full HCN specific analysis memo Link VizComm developed summaries Citywide Crash Analysis report Link High Crash Network report Link Proposal Materials Proposal: ADD A LINK

title: BDAT: King County Metro and SDOT Bus Delay Analysis Tool
content: HOME ABOUT US PROJECT SAMPLES RESOUCES R & INTERACTIVE MAPS VIZCOMM WEBSITE ENGINEERING Go Back to Main Page King County Metro and SDOT Bus Delay Analysis Tool Nelson\Nygaard worked with King County Metro and the Seattle Department of Transportation to adapt the successful work done on TriMet‚Äôs iteration of BDAT to the regional transit network in the Seattle metro area, and to add additional features beyond the initial version of the application. Using a similar methodology to TriMet, a segment network was developed to represent all bus service in the region, allowing for geographic aggregation of transit performance data across multiple routes and agencies. Bus delay was quantified based on aggregated AVL data over the Fall 2019 and 2020 service periods, and is weighted and/or normalized in a variety of metrics by passenger loading and service level. This dashboard is facilitating ongoing project prioritization for the bus service network in the Seattle region. Open dashboard (ask Oren Eshel (oeshel@nelsonnygaard.com if you need access to dashboard) Project Information Project name : King County Metro Transit Mobility Framework and Regional Planning Project code : 2019.0221 Sector : Transit Open Hub Page Level of Effort High (16+ hrs) This more complex iteration of BDAT was developed in a combined project between the two agencies and is expected to cost between $100-150k when complete. Using the codebase for another project, some cost could be saved, but there are custom elements/costs for each agency that must be developed from scratch. Major Deliverables Open dashboard (ask Oren Eshel (oeshel@nelsonnygaard.com if you need access to dashboard) Proposal Materials Qual sheet: Link

title: BDAT: TriMet Bus Delay Analysis Tool
content: HOME ABOUT US PROJECT SAMPLES RESOUCES R & INTERACTIVE MAPS VIZCOMM WEBSITE ENGINEERING Go Back to Main Page TriMet Bus Delay Analysis Tool (2018) Bus transit is typically analyzed by route, but in many cities, buses share roadway segments for some portion of their routing. As part of ongoing work for TriMet‚Äôs Enhanced Transit Corridor Program , Nelson\Nygaard developed a segment network to represent TriMet bus service. This segment network was used as the basis for a Dashboard that enables interactive examination of bus delay. Bus delay was quantified based on aggregated AVL data over the Fall 2018 and Fall 2019 service periods, and is calculated as the difference between the 80th percentile travel time and the 20th percentile travel time. This dashboard is facilitating ongoing project prioritization for the bus service network in the Portland region. Open Dashboard Contact Bryan Blanc (Portland) for login information Project Information Project name : Regional Enhanced Transit Corridor Assistance Project code : 2018.0756 Sector : Transit Open Hub page Major Deliverables 2020 Better Bus Final Report Link Open Dashboard Contact Bryan Blanc (Portland) for login information Level of Effort High (16+ hrs) BDAT was developed as part of this larger Enhanced Transit Corridors project. Currently, given the early state of development of BDAT, you would want to budget $50-100k for custom development for another city, depending on features needed. Proposal Materials Qual sheet: Link

title: 3D Parameter Influence
content: What is SPEED? Why did we create SPEED? Who is the SPEED team? How does SPEED ‚Äúfit within our design process? SPEED Project Portal Page SPEED General Structure of Pages SPEED Project Information Page SPEED Site Context SPEED Geometry Page - Parametric Shapes SPEED Envelope Page SPEED Construction Page SPEED Space Layout Page SPEED Space Load Page SPEED HVAC Page SPEED Daylighting Page SPEED Photovoltaic Page SPEED Parametric Study SPEED Result: Single Run Chart SPEED Result: Multiple Run Chart SPEED Result: PCP SPEED Result: 2D Scatter Plot SPEED Result: 3D Scatter Plot SPEED Result: Sensitivity Analysis SPEED Result: 3D Parameter Influence About Instructions Result Tutorials Examples FAQ https://vimeo.com/507747566/e36c1c5e2f What Is Interaction Chart? 3D Interactive Chart (also called 3D Surface Plot, 3D Response Surface Model, or Parameter Influence chart) is a general-purpose multi-dimensional ‚Äúbest fit curve‚Äù. Given a set of data points (a set of inputs and outputs), we can quickly use mathematical models and statistical analysis using R to generate this surface plot so you can start to understand how changes in two inputs and one output effect the other averaged over all the other inputs and outputs not shown in the chart. This is one the powerful benefits of running a large number of simulations in your parametric study. ‚Äå 1. Select Two Design Parameters 2. and One Performance Choose two design parameters ( 1 ) and one building performance ( 2 ) to see the 3D parametric influence surface ( 3 ).‚Äå You should first click on the display boxes next to two design parameters you wish to evaluate and identify what axis to shown the parameters on, from x, y, and z axes. Then select one building performance by clicking on the display box next to it and identify the axes.

title: Sensitivity Analysis
content: What is SPEED? Why did we create SPEED? Who is the SPEED team? How does SPEED ‚Äúfit within our design process? SPEED Project Portal Page SPEED General Structure of Pages SPEED Project Information Page SPEED Site Context SPEED Geometry Page - Parametric Shapes SPEED Envelope Page SPEED Construction Page SPEED Space Layout Page SPEED Space Load Page SPEED HVAC Page SPEED Daylighting Page SPEED Photovoltaic Page SPEED Parametric Study SPEED Result: Single Run Chart SPEED Result: Multiple Run Chart SPEED Result: PCP SPEED Result: 2D Scatter Plot SPEED Result: 3D Scatter Plot SPEED Result: Sensitivity Analysis SPEED Result: 3D Parameter Influence About Instructions Result Tutorials Examples FAQ Sensitivity Analysis A (global) Sensitivity Analysis can generate variable importance plots that illustrate the relative impact of a set of design inputs on a building performance output. By focusing on inputs that are most influential (and by placing less emphasis on those variables with little influence), this chart can significantly reduce the complexity of the design challenge. ‚Äå 1. Select One Performance Parameter You only need to select one building performance to see the importance of the design parameters listed on the left. If any design parameter is not shown within the chart, it means that it has no effect on the performance. 2. Sensitivity Chart The sensitivity analysis result is a bar chart; the higher the value of each design parameter in the chart, the higher effect it has on the variation of the performance.

title: 3D Scatter Plot
content: What is SPEED? Why did we create SPEED? Who is the SPEED team? How does SPEED ‚Äúfit within our design process? SPEED Project Portal Page SPEED General Structure of Pages SPEED Project Information Page SPEED Site Context SPEED Geometry Page - Parametric Shapes SPEED Envelope Page SPEED Construction Page SPEED Space Layout Page SPEED Space Load Page SPEED HVAC Page SPEED Daylighting Page SPEED Photovoltaic Page SPEED Parametric Study SPEED Result: Single Run Chart SPEED Result: Multiple Run Chart SPEED Result: PCP SPEED Result: 2D Scatter Plot SPEED Result: 3D Scatter Plot SPEED Result: Sensitivity Analysis SPEED Result: 3D Parameter Influence About Instructions Result Tutorials Examples FAQ https://vimeo.com/507648259/069b345116 What Is 3D Scatter Plot? 3D Scatter Plot is used to display data points in a three-dimensional view, and is most useful for looking at how the data is spread throughout a design space. Similar to the 2D scatter plot, 3D plot uses both sphere and footprint icons to display multi-dimensional data. The features are similar to 2D scatter plots. You can choose the points (spheres) to be shown as the building geometry: Do it by switching the ‚ÄúSphere‚Äù toggle to ‚ÄúBuilding‚Äù You can activate the ‚ÄúEUI Target/Benchmark‚Äù button and compare the results with the energy use intensity target and benchmark, which are represented as lines or surfaces By hovering over each point in scatter plot, you are able to see the corresponding design model with the main building information listed along with the plot.

title: 2D Scatter Plot
content: What is SPEED? Why did we create SPEED? Who is the SPEED team? How does SPEED ‚Äúfit within our design process? SPEED Project Portal Page SPEED General Structure of Pages SPEED Project Information Page SPEED Site Context SPEED Geometry Page - Parametric Shapes SPEED Geometry Page - BST SPEED Envelope Page SPEED Construction Page SPEED Space Layout Page SPEED Space Load Page SPEED HVAC Page SPEED Daylighting Page SPEED Photovoltaic Page SPEED Parametric Study SPEED Geometry Page - BST SPEED Result: Single Run Chart SPEED Result: Multiple Run Chart SPEED Result: PCP SPEED Result: 2D Scatter Plot SPEED Result: 3D Scatter Plot SPEED Result: Sensitivity Analysis SPEED Result: 3D Parameter Influence About Instructions Result Tutorials Examples FAQ What Is Scatter Plot? 2D Scatter Plot consists of a grid of 2D plots, where two variables under investigation are building performances plotted against each other. The data results are displayed as a collection of design points, each having the value of one building performance determining the position on the horizontal axis and the value of the other building performance determining the position on the vertical axis. ‚Äå 1. Select Performance Parameters Select two items from the list of building performances to be shown in x an z axes. ‚Äå 2. 2D Scatter Plot By hovering over each point in scatter plot, you are able to see the corresponding design model with the main building information listed along the plot. ‚Äå 3. Limit Design/Performance Parameters You can limit the values of ‚ÄúDesign‚Äù or ‚ÄúPerformance‚Äù in the exploration, by putting constraints on these parameters on the right side of the scatter plot. Those values of parameters outside the constraints are grayed out in the plot. 4. Modifying Scatter Plot Visualization n order to better investigate what point corresponds to what footprint shape, you can choose the points (spheres) to be shown as the building geometry: Do it by switching the ‚ÄúSphere‚Äù toggle to ‚ÄúBuilding‚Äù. You can change the size and view angle of the footprint shapes by clicking on the lock button at the top of the chart. If one of the performance you are evaluating is EUI, you would be able to click on the ‚ÄúEUI Target/Benchmark‚Äù toggle and change it to Yes. the EUI Target is shown as a green line and EUI Benchmark as a red line in the EUI axis. One important features you can activate in scatter plot is the Pareto Front line. A design point is defined to be Pareto Front, or Pareto Optimal, if no other design in the set is better in both objective values. In other words, the design points within the Pareto Front line represents the best or the most optimal designs for the two building performances selected in the plot. Change the toggle of pareto front to Yes in order to show it in the plot. If you click on the ‚ÄúReset Shading‚Äù button, you‚Äôll see that the color of each design point, either shown as sphere or building, changes showing the worst to the best design options according to the legend at the right side of the plot. The default assumptions for the color of each design point is that you prefer to minimize both building performances evaluated in the plot, and also both performances have the same importance for you. You can change these assumptions by toggling between Min and Max as your goal for each building performance (for instance, in the example below, we want to maximize Daylight Autonomy, while minimizing EUI). You can also change your preference on the importance of each performance by changing the value of the Output Preference Shading. If it is in the middle, in which both performances are 50, it means that both performances are equally important (in the below plot for instance, we changed preference shading to be 25% for Daylight Autonomy and 75% for EUI, because energy performance were more important for us).

title: PCP
content: What is SPEED? Why did we create SPEED? Who is the SPEED team? How does SPEED ‚Äúfit within our design process? SPEED Project Portal Page SPEED General Structure of Pages SPEED Project Information Page SPEED Site Context SPEED Geometry Page - Parametric Shapes SPEED Envelope Page SPEED Construction Page SPEED Space Layout Page SPEED Space Load Page SPEED HVAC Page SPEED Daylighting Page SPEED Photovoltaic Page SPEED Parametric Study SPEED Result: Single Run Chart SPEED Result: Multiple Run Chart SPEED Result: PCP SPEED Result: 2D Scatter Plot SPEED Result: 3D Scatter Plot SPEED Result: Sensitivity Analysis SPEED Result: 3D Parameter Influence About Instructions Result Tutorials Examples FAQ Parallel Coordinates Plot Parallel Coordinates Plot (PCP) is useful for identifying outliers, unusual patterns, and correlations. It shows data in multiple axes aligned in parallel to each other. Each vertical axis represents a different variable that the designer wants to evaluate. A line passes through each design criteria point in the data set. SPEED shows the values of a design point at the intersection of the polyline and vertical axes, and you can ‚Äúbrush‚Äù the vertical values to assign constraints to the input or output variable. ‚Äå 1. Select from the Design Parameters and 2. Performance Parameters Select the display boxes next to each design parameter and building performance to be shown in a parallel coordinate graph. ‚Äå 3. Interactive PCP Chart SPEED shows the values of a design point at the intersection of the polyline and vertical axes. By hovering the mouse over each polyline, users can find the specification of the design and see the corresponding geometry at the top left of the window. Users can ‚Äúbrush‚Äù the vertical values to assign constraints to the input or output variable. ‚Äå 4. Toggle EUI Target and Benchmark Users can also toggle the EUI Target/Benchmark button and view your project‚Äôs benchmark and target entered in the very first page of the GUI overlaid on the chart to see where your design options fall in comparison.

Select Design Option Users only need to select the design option with characteristics chosen from the design parameters dropdowns ( 1 ), and see the results in the next tab, ‚ÄúPerformance Parameters‚Äù ( 2 ), and visualize the results in the next tab, ‚ÄúBuilding Performance Breakdown‚Äù ( 3 ).‚Äå 3. title: What is SPEED?
content: What is SPEED? Why did we create SPEED? Who is the SPEED team? How does SPEED ‚Äúfit within our design process? SPEED Project Portal Page SPEED General Structure of Pages SPEED Project Information Page SPEED Site Context SPEED Geometry Page - Parametric Shapes SPEED Envelope Page SPEED Construction Page SPEED Space Layout Page SPEED Space Load Page SPEED HVAC Page SPEED Daylighting Page SPEED Photovoltaic Page SPEED Parametric Study SPEED Result: Single Run Chart SPEED Result: Multiple Run Chart SPEED Result: PCP SPEED Result: 2D Scatter Plot SPEED Result: 3D Scatter Plot SPEED Result: Sensitivity Analysis SPEED Result: 3D Parameter Influence About Instructions Result Tutorials Examples FAQ The Technical Researchy Explanation‚Ä¶ SPEED is a cloud-based energy simulation platform with a web-based user interface that enables designers to enter parametric inputs, visualize geometry, run shading and solar studies in seconds, and run thousands of design options on the cloud very fast to generate energy and daylighting performance outputs in a consistent, effective manner using advanced visualization techniques. SPEED will allow project teams to compare their designs against energy performance benchmarks and targets enabled with the EUI Generator. SPEED provides a new opportunity for early design exploration at P+W, assisting/validating design intuition and enabling all projects to internally run energy models at the most useful point in the design process. What Are the Value Propositions of SPEED? ‚Äå Easily generate a parametric study and run a large number of simulations very fast, cheap. Allow designers to energy model without being energy modelers.‚Äå One day turnaround for most projects. No cost to project.‚Äå You can use it in a client meeting in real-time! Win new projects.‚Äå The results are stored in a central database so we retain IP, can re-use the data, and mine it (AI) for more accurate design assumptions and rules-of-thumb. Eventual Google-like interface.‚Äå Enables a certain degree of parametric design capabilities for those who have no experience in it.‚Äå Risk mitigation.‚Äå Control over the development of the tool to meet the specific needs of our designers.‚Äå With everyone in the firm using the same input/visualization GUI, easily trainable to how to generate their designs and parametric studies, and interpret the results of the analysis. Meaningful and intuitive visualizations.‚Äå Easier collaboration with consultants, they see assumptions, HVAC modeled correctly, more efficient, effectively pass off results to consultants, better coordination, and knowledge of design parameters so can talk more intelligently.‚Äå Provides blueprint to IT for migration of other data sources and services.‚Äå $$ saved on credits/licensing costs, consultants, re-work, etc.‚Äå No other design firm has anything remotely competitive. A powerful marketing tool.‚Äå Lays out infrastructure for other early design analyses to be integrated.

title: Why did we create SPEED?

Energy Modeling at P+W: Current and Proposed‚Äå Current State of Energy Modeling @P+W Proposed State of Energy Modeling @P+W Enter a caption for this image (optional) ‚Äå What Is the Problem with Early Design Tools Now? 1. Long Preparation Times ‚Ä¶ it took Energy Lab 40 pages to explain i360! (doubt anyone read it;))‚Äå 2. Poor/Unknown Assumptions ‚Äå Insight 360: Baseline Assumptions vs. Revised 3. Black Box Syndrome ‚Äå ENERGY LAB Tool Comparison Study ‚Äå 4. Very Few Options Analyzed ‚Äå 5. Visualization to Decision Gap ‚Äå 6. No Knowledge Management and Re-Use ‚Äå 7. Often no Mechanical/Energy Consultant on the Team Yet (and if there is, they are too slow to meet our rapid early design process!).‚Äå 8. No One Uses Them Anyway! Note SPEED has the requirements that it must (1) overcome these shortcomings (2) be scalable firm-wide; (3) be comfortable for designers to use so they may learn to be proficient with it; and (4) needs to be trainable, which requires consistency, repetition, and on-demand support.

title: Who is the SPEED Team?

We have programmers, PhDs, energy and daylighting simulation experts that are all at the top of their field, visualization experts, collaborations with industry, academia, and government labs, and of course a Director of Research (Dr. John Haymaker) and a supportive Research Advisory Board that gave us the freedom and the resources (and patience;) to make this a reality. Here‚Äôs a quick overview of the team: Benjamin Welle, Anton Szilasi, Roya Rezaee Tyrone Marshall, Cheney Chen, John Haymaker Joel Register Nikhil Kapoor, Sumit Bansal, Abhishek Gupta, Amit Pandey, Amitesh Anand, Harsh Mishra Chien Si Harriman Zack Rogers ‚Äå Mattew Dahlhausen, David Goldwasser, Amir Roth, Brian Ball, Henry Horsey Theo Armour ‚Äå

title: Design & Delivery ‚Äì Dynamo scripts for documentation and Perkins&Will Details Database
content: Dynamo scripts for productivity Presenter: Adam Hamilton EnlargeElevatePlace automates creating sheets contatining enlarged plan and elevations for selected rooms CADtoWalls automates converting CAD plans into Revit walls Perkins&Will Searchable Details Database Presenter: Luc Deckinga Luc Deckinga introduces Core.Aiprentice.com , a site that collects drawings from past Perkins&Will Revit projects and delivers them in an online, searchable database, It is now open to everyone at Perkins&Will! This site is the result of a close collaboration over the past year between the Digital Practice team and AiPrentice, a software developer. Our Technical Directors have taken the last few months to test drive the site and provide their input into how it can be used and how it should be developed. Please join us for a demonstration of the site‚Äôs current features, see how it can benefit project teams, and get a sneak peek into the improvements just around the corner. Collateral: View Presentations Video Presented: November 12,2020

Project Summary It shows the summary of project including project‚Äôs name, location, primary building type, climate zone, energy code and number of runs. This tab is going to be repeated for all types of results visualization; you can collapse this tab. ‚Äå 2. Visualization Type SPEED offers several types of visualizations to interpret your analysis results. Select from one of the following:‚Äå Selected Runs: Single Run Chart Multiple Run Chart All Runs Parallel Coordinates Plot (PCP) 2D Scatter Plot 3D Scatter Plot Statistical Analysis Sensitivity Analysis Chart 3D Parameter Influence Chart 3. List of Design Parameters or Performance Parameters Depending on the visualization type you select, you see the list of design parameters on the left and performance parameters on the right side. ‚Äå Design Parameters : lists all design parameters that are included in the parametric study and the options available. ‚Äå Building Performances : lists all building performance indicators analyzed in SPEED. Note This structure is the same for all result visualization types. Details on each type of visualizations are shown in the following section.

title: Parametric Study Page
content: What is SPEED? Why did we create SPEED? Who is the SPEED team? How does SPEED ‚Äúfit within our design process? SPEED Project Portal Page SPEED General Structure of Pages SPEED Project Information Page SPEED Site Context SPEED Geometry Page - Parametric Shapes SPEED Geometry Page - BST SPEED Envelope Page SPEED Construction Page SPEED Space Layout Page SPEED Space Load Page SPEED HVAC Page SPEED Daylighting Page SPEED Photovoltaic Page SPEED Parametric Study SPEED Result: Single Run Chart SPEED Result: Multiple Run Chart SPEED Result: PCP SPEED Result: 2D Scatter Plot SPEED Result: 3D Scatter Plot SPEED Result: Sensitivity Analysis SPEED Result: 3D Parameter Influence About Instructions Result Tutorials Examples FAQ What Is Parametric Study? A parametric study is the exploration of relationships and tradeoffs between different design parameters and the building performance result from the simulation of those design parameters. By using a parametric study, designers can assess the impact that changing certain parameters can have on the design of their energy and daylighting performance goals. The more design options you analyze in a parametric study, the more information you will have available to you to understand the impacts of your design decisions. However, there are certain things you should keep in mind when building your parametric study, as more is not always better. Until you become more familiar with SPEED and how the statistical analysis works, we recommend running parametric studies between 500-2000 design options (or simulations). Less than this, you will lose the power of doing statistical analysis on your runs. More than this, and you start to get into some more challenging decisions to make that require some more training such as whether you should choose fewer design variables with more options each, or more design variables with fewer options each. Energy Lab will assist you in learning how to make these decisions once you feel comfortable with navigating the GUI and interpreting the results visualizations. 1. Model Input This dropdown shows the design inputs that are available for your parametric study. Select model inputs one by one, and ‚ÄúAdd‚Äù them as Design Variables to run simulations for various values of the input. A Model Input should not be defined as a Design Variable if only one option is to be evaluated. 2. Select Design Options Design Variables : This list shows the parameters you choose for your study from the Model Inputs window. By clicking on a Design Variable after adding it to your study, a list of available Design Options for your analysis will be shown in Design Options Available. ‚Äå Design Option Available : This is the list of options for each Design Variable. Select the ones you would like to compare, either one or multiple at a time, and click on the forward blue icon to push them into the Design Options Selected window. You may also drag and drop them into the Design Options Selected window. ‚Äå Design Option Selected : This is the list of your selected Design Options for your parametric study. You may remove selection options by highlighting them and clicking the back button or dragging and dropping it. 3. Parametric Study Profile The Parametric study profiles show the number of runs resulted from the design option you have created, and the time needed to run the study.
