Run PV Simulation Check this box to run a PV simulation to determine how many kWh of energy can be generated each year on the roof.‚Äå % Roof PV : Select the percentage of the roof you believe PVs are feasible for. This number already assumes an optimal tilt for the PV panels given the building‚Äôs location.

title: Daylighting Page
content: What is SPEED? Why did we create SPEED? Who is the SPEED team? How does SPEED ‚Äúfit within our design process? SPEED Project Portal Page SPEED General Structure of Pages SPEED Project Information Page SPEED Site Context SPEED Geometry Page - Parametric Shapes SPEED Geometry Page - BST SPEED Envelope Page SPEED Construction Page SPEED Space Layout Page SPEED Space Load Page SPEED HVAC Page SPEED Daylighting Page SPEED Photovoltaic Page SPEED Parametric Study SPEED Result: Single Run Chart SPEED Result: Multiple Run Chart SPEED Result: PCP SPEED Result: 2D Scatter Plot SPEED Result: 3D Scatter Plot SPEED Result: Sensitivity Analysis SPEED Result: 3D Parameter Influence About Instructions Result Tutorials Examples FAQ Daylighting The Daylighting page enables you to run daylight simulation in addition to energy analysis. Daylighting is the controlled admission of natural light into a building to reduce electric lighting and save energy.‚Äå 1. Run Daylighting Simulation Check this box to run a daylighting simulation in addition to an energy simulation for spaces with exterior windows. The daylighting simulation is run first, then the results are used to create modified lighting schedules for the energy simulation.‚Äå Daylight Simulation Engine : There are two daylight simulation engines available for daylight assessment:‚Äå EnergyPlus: Selecting EnergyPlus to do the daylighting simulation is much faster than using Radiance. However, it only generates a modified lighting schedule for EnergyPlus, and is less accurate than Radiance. Radiance : By selecting Radiance, you may calculate building-level climate-based, dynamic daylighting metrics such as continuous daylighting autonomy (cDA), useful daylight index (UDI), and daylight saturation (DS), though the calculation of these metrics will take quite a bit longer to run. SPEED also calculates the less useful metric Daylight Factor (DF) for comparison and because it is the metric most familiar to designers.

title: HVAC Page
content: What is SPEED? Why did we create SPEED? Who is the SPEED team? How does SPEED ‚Äúfit within our design process? SPEED Project Portal Page SPEED General Structure of Pages SPEED Project Information Page SPEED Site Context SPEED Geometry Page - Parametric Shapes SPEED Geometry Page - BST SPEED Envelope Page SPEED Construction Page SPEED Space Layout Page SPEED Space Load Page SPEED HVAC Page SPEED Daylighting Page SPEED Photovoltaic Page SPEED Parametric Study SPEED Result: Single Run Chart SPEED Result: Multiple Run Chart SPEED Result: PCP SPEED Result: 2D Scatter Plot SPEED Result: 3D Scatter Plot SPEED Result: Sensitivity Analysis SPEED Result: 3D Parameter Influence About Instructions Result Tutorials Examples FAQ HVAC HVAC page helps you define the mechanical systems for heating, cooling, and ventilation. ‚Äå Most of the time there is a strong relationship between the HVAC System chosen and the passive design elements of the building envelope, so HVAC should be considered when evaluating building form and passive design elements. The most common selection for designers at the earliest stages of design is ‚ÄúIdeal Air Loads‚Äù. This system simply assumes there is enough heating and cooling energy used to meet setpoints, and does not take into account the energy consumption of systems such as chillers, fans, pumps, cooling towers, etc. It often leads to misleading results. SPEEDprovides a list of other 30 high-performance systems to select other than the ideal load system.‚Äå 1. HVAC Type ‚Äå Select the Heating Ventilation and Air Conditioning (HVAC) system you would like to evaluate from the drop-down menu or select the Default.¬†The following HVAC Types are available:‚Äå ‚Äú VAV Reheat ‚Äú: Variable air volume system with air-side economizer, served by a condensing boiler and air-cooled chiller. ‚Äú PVAV Reheat ‚Äú: Packaged RTU VAV system with air-side economizer, served by a condensing boiler and DX cooling. ‚Äú VRF with DOAS ‚Äú: DOAS system served by DX coils and VRF terminals served by air-cooled VRF outdoor unit. ‚Äú VRF with DOAS with DCV ‚Äú: DOAS system with DCV served by DX Coils and VRF terminals served by air-cooled VRF outdoor unit. ‚Äú Ground Source Heat Pumps with DOAS ‚Äú: DOAS system served by DX coils with zone heat pumps served by a ground-source heat pump loop. ‚Äú Ground Source Heat Pumps with DOAS with DCV ‚Äú: DOAS system with DCV served by DX coils and zone heat pumps served by a ground-source heat pump loop. ‚Äú Fan Coils with DOAS ‚Äú: DOAS system with zone fan coils both served by a condensing boiler and water-cooled chiller with a water-side economizer. ‚Äú Fan Coils with DOAS with DCV ‚Äú: DOAS system with DCV and zone fan coils both served by a condensing boiler and water-cooled chiller with a water-side economizer.

title: Space Loads Page
content: What is SPEED? Why did we create SPEED? Who is the SPEED team? How does SPEED ‚Äúfit within our design process? SPEED Project Portal Page SPEED General Structure of Pages SPEED Project Information Page SPEED Site Context SPEED Geometry Page - Parametric Shapes SPEED Geometry Page - BST SPEED Envelope Page SPEED Construction Page SPEED Space Layout Page SPEED Space Load Page SPEED HVAC Page SPEED Daylighting Page SPEED Photovoltaic Page SPEED Parametric Study SPEED Result: Single Run Chart SPEED Result: Multiple Run Chart SPEED Result: PCP SPEED Result: 2D Scatter Plot SPEED Result: 3D Scatter Plot SPEED Result: Sensitivity Analysis SPEED Result: 3D Parameter Influence About Instructions Result Tutorials Examples FAQ Space Loads Use the Space Loads page to define and edit the loads associated with each space type. ‚Äå Based on the space types users have defined in the previous tab, they can see the list of space types with the associated loads. The default values are defined according to ASHRAE requirements, however, users can uncheck and change the values as required.‚Äå Space Type : The space type is used to populate certain defaults for parameters of commonly used spaces, such as occupancy, lighting and equipment loads, and schedules. Most of these parameters can be overwritten by the user.‚Äå (1) Lighting Power Density: LPDis defined as the installed lighting power, in wattages, in a building space divided by the space area in square meters or square feet (watts/ft2 or watts/m2). (2) Equipment Power Density : EPD is the energy used by products that are powered by means of an ordinary AC plug and are measured in watts per square foot or square meter (watts/ft2 or watts/m2). (3) Outside Air : OA is used for ventilation and also to provide free cooling whenever possible. SPEED uses the OA default value based on the ASHRAE requirement for each space type and has another option of having 30% better. (4) Cooling Setpoint : Temperature at which the system will maintain the cooling in all spaces in the zone. SPEED currently has only one default value for the cooling setpoint as 75 F. (5) Heating Setpoint : Temperature at which the system will maintain the heating in all spaces in the zone. SPEED currently has only one default value for the heating setpoint as 70 F. Apply to all Space Types for Parametric Study? If the user wants to define only one Space Loads page input in the parametric study, then they should check the box under the desired input. For example, if you click the box under Lighting Power Density, then in the parametric study only one design variable will show up called ‚ÄúLPD‚Äù, and any values assigned to it will be applied to all Space Types. If you keep it unchecked, then in the parametric study you will see ‚ÄúLPD-Space Type X‚Äù. ‚Äú. For the Beta release, we have hard-coded this checkbox to true do minimize the number of simulations run for debugging purposes.

title: Space Layout Page
content: What is SPEED? Why did we create SPEED? Who is the SPEED team? How does SPEED ‚Äúfit within our design process? SPEED Project Portal Page SPEED General Structure of Pages SPEED Project Information Page SPEED Site Context SPEED Geometry Page - Parametric Shapes SPEED Geometry Page - BST SPEED Envelope Page SPEED Construction Page SPEED Space Layout Page SPEED Space Load Page SPEED HVAC Page SPEED Daylighting Page SPEED Photovoltaic Page SPEED Parametric Study SPEED Result: Single Run Chart SPEED Result: Multiple Run Chart SPEED Result: PCP SPEED Result: 2D Scatter Plot SPEED Result: 3D Scatter Plot SPEED Result: Sensitivity Analysis SPEED Result: 3D Parameter Influence About Instructions Result Tutorials Examples FAQ Space Layout The Space Layout page provides information related to the layout of the thermal spaces within the building. ‚Äå 1. Building/Facade Mode There are two modes of ‚ÄúBuilding‚Äù and ‚ÄúFloor‚Äù:‚Äå Building : By checking this box, you are allowed to assign only one Space Type to all the zones in the model. This is the only available option when in Analysis Type=1 mode. Floor : By checking this box, you are allowed to assign different Space Types on a given floor plan to different zones. In SPEED, zones are considered the same as spaces. If there are a fixed number of floors, you can assign different Space Types to multiple floor plans. This mode is available when using Analysis Type=2 or Analysis Type=3. ‚Äå 2. Space Type The Space Type is assigned to various zones in the floor plan to determine default internal loads, outside air requirements, conditioning setpoints, and conditioning schedules. To enable the specification of multi-use buildings, the input Space Type in SPEED is actually a combination of Building Type and conventional Space Type (Building Type-Space Type). For example, for a private office in an office building, the designer would see ‚ÄúOffice-Private Office‚Äù. For a private office in a retail building, you would see ‚ÄúRetail-Private Office‚Äù. The same space type in different building types often has different input assumptions based on energy codes. Therefore, this format allows the user to be able to define the appropriate inputs for multi-use buildings. 3. Area Breakdown A box on the right top of the building geometry views shows the summary of the breakdown of the areas ( 3 ), in which the total area should be equal to 100%. 4. Add Floor Template When using Analysis Type=2 or Analysis Type=3, you are able to assign different space types to multiple floor plans.

title: Constructions Page
content: What is SPEED? Why did we create SPEED? Who is the SPEED team? How does SPEED ‚Äúfit within our design process? SPEED Project Portal Page SPEED General Structure of Pages SPEED Project Information Page SPEED Site Context SPEED Geometry Page - Parametric Shapes SPEED Geometry Page - BST SPEED Envelope Page SPEED Construction Page SPEED Space Layout Page SPEED Space Load Page SPEED HVAC Page SPEED Daylighting Page SPEED Photovoltaic Page SPEED Parametric Study SPEED Result: Single Run Chart SPEED Result: Multiple Run Chart SPEED Result: PCP SPEED Result: 2D Scatter Plot SPEED Result: 3D Scatter Plot SPEED Result: Sensitivity Analysis SPEED Result: 3D Parameter Influence About Instructions Result Tutorials Examples FAQ Construction The Construction page enables you to define the assembly type and the thermal properties of the building envelop‚Äô materials. 1. Exterior Walls SPEED automatically assigns code-compliant constructions or R-Values to exterior walls. First, select your Assembly Type, then choose whether you want to be in Wall Type or Wall R-Value mode. These are simply two different ways to evaluate the impact of improving wall insulation. If you select the Wall Type mode, then you are also able to evaluate the thermal mass effects of various constructions‚Äå Assembly Type : Choose from the list of the assembly types. Wall Type : you can choose a particular wall type from the list of available options. The default is set to the ASHRAE requirements based on the building type, climate zone, and energy code. Wall R-Value : in case you wish to have a different wall type that is not available in the list, you can choose this option to insert R-Value directly. The default is set to the ASHRAE requirements for wall R-Value based on the building type, climate zone, and energy code. ‚Äå 2. Roof SPEED automatically assigns code-compliant constructions or R-Values to roofs. First, select your Assembly Type, then choose whether you want to be in Roof Type or Roof R-Value mode. These are simply two different ways to evaluate the impact of improving wall insulation. If you select the Roof Type mode, then you are also able to evaluate the thermal mass effects of various constructions.‚Äå Assembly Type : Roof Type : you can choose a particular roof type from the list of available options. The default is set to the ASHRAE requirements based on the building type, climate zone, and energy code. Roof R-Value : in case you wish to have a different roof type that is not available in the list, you can choose this option to insert R-Value directly. The default is set to the ASHRAE requirements for roof R-Value based on the building type, climate zone, and energy code. ‚Äå 3. Interior Walls/ Floors/ Foundation Select from the lists of options for each element, or leave it as default.

title: Envelope Page
content: What is SPEED? Why did we create SPEED? Who is the SPEED team? How does SPEED ‚Äúfit within our design process? SPEED Project Portal Page SPEED General Structure of Pages SPEED Project Information Page SPEED Site Context SPEED Geometry Page - Parametric Shapes SPEED Geometry Page - BST SPEED Envelope Page SPEED Construction Page SPEED Space Layout Page SPEED Space Load Page SPEED HVAC Page SPEED Daylighting Page SPEED Photovoltaic Page SPEED Parametric Study SPEED Result: Single Run Chart SPEED Result: Multiple Run Chart SPEED Result: PCP SPEED Result: 2D Scatter Plot SPEED Result: 3D Scatter Plot SPEED Result: Sensitivity Analysis SPEED Result: 3D Parameter Influence About Instructions Result Tutorials Examples FAQ Envelope The Envelope page provides information related to the building facade. ‚Äå 1. Building/Facade Mode There are two modes available as ‚ÄúBuilding‚Äù and ‚ÄúFa√ßade‚Äù.‚Äå Building : By checking this box, you are able to define envelope inputs that apply to the entire building, independent of fa√ßade orientation. Only the ‚ÄúBuilding‚Äù tab will be active. Fa√ßade : By checking this box, you are able to define envelope inputs to different fa√ßade orientations. The ‚ÄúBuilding‚Äù tab is deactivated, and the tabs for ‚ÄúSouth‚Äù, ‚ÄúWest‚Äù, ‚ÄúEast‚Äù, and ‚ÄúNorth‚Äù are active. The default values are the same for all south, west, east, and north facades; however users can make changes by clicking on each orientation tab located at the top of the window. Check the Building tab to apply data to the entire building Check the Facade tab to apply data to each facade separately FACADE MODE | Apply to all Facades : When the user is in the ‚ÄúFacade‚Äù mode, they can define all the glazing and shading inputs by facade orientation. However, sometimes the designer may not want to vary an input by orientation, for example for the input Window Type. In this case, if you simply check the box in front of the input here, then that parameter is disabled for the West, East, and North tabs and is assigned the same input value as the South tab.‚Äå 2. Windows Size/Configuration The glazing for the envelope is defined by the WWR, # of Windows, Window Ratio, and Window Type: By choosing the default option for glazing, the ASHRAE requirements for baseline criteria for the WWR is used given the building type, climate zone, and energy code. The # of windows and window ratios is always set to 4 and 40% respectively as default, but you can change them if you unclick the default option. These latter two inputs determine the design of the window array placed on the facade.‚Äå WWR : by unchecking the default, you can choose the percentage of windows to wall area as a value between 10 to 90 percent. The default is 40%.‚Äå # of Windows : you can choose the number of windows as a value between 1 to 10. The default is 4. ‚Äå Window Layout : this parameter is associated with the spread of the window within the wall. The higher the value, the more horizontally is the window. You can choose the window ratio as a value between 0 and 1. The default is 0.4. Choose the percentage of WWR from the drop-down menu Choose the number of windows from the drop-down menu You can change the window layout ‚Äå 3. Windows Type/Assembly Assembly Type : The type of assembly can be one of the options of ‚ÄúMetal Framing Curtain Wall, Metal Framing, and Non-Metal Framing.‚Äå Window Type : by choosing the default option for glazing type, the ASHRAE requirements for baseline building is used given the building type, climate zone, and energy code. By unchecking the default, you can choose from the available library of window types. ‚Äå 4. Shading Overhang/Fin Depth : The shading for the envelope includes overhangs and fins. If you do not wish to have overhangs or fins, simply keep the value of the length at 0. ‚Äå 5.  Display Options/ Solar Analysis Note Any info you use inside the Envelope tab will be applied to all footprint shapes.

title: Geometry Page ‚Äì BST
content: What is SPEED? Why did we create SPEED? Who is the SPEED team? How does SPEED ‚Äúfit within our design process? SPEED Project Portal Page SPEED General Structure of Pages SPEED Project Information Page SPEED Site Context SPEED Geometry Page - Parametric Shapes SPEED Geometry Page - BST SPEED Envelope Page SPEED Construction Page SPEED Space Layout Page SPEED Space Load Page SPEED HVAC Page SPEED Daylighting Page SPEED Photovoltaic Page SPEED Parametric Study SPEED Result: Single Run Chart SPEED Result: Multiple Run Chart SPEED Result: PCP SPEED Result: 2D Scatter Plot SPEED Result: 3D Scatter Plot SPEED Result: Sensitivity Analysis SPEED Result: 3D Parameter Influence About Instructions Result Tutorials Examples FAQ https://vimeo.com/495268505 Geometry The Block & Stack Tool is a simple yet powerful way to quickly create your custom geometry. It‚Äôs designed so the geometry you create must follow the rules of energy models so you always have valid geometry input file for EnergyPlus. ‚Äå 1. Create New Floor Plan Polygon : Polygon drawing tool 2D/3D : View both 2D and 3D‚Äå drawings or full canvas in 2D Erase: Boolean eraser to make rectangular cuts out of existing spaces Selection: arrow button to switch into selection mode DXF import: You may export floorplan DXF files from Revit and import them into BST for tracing geometry all at once. the DXF files are all imported into BST, auto-scaled, and placed at the center of the 2d drawing canvas. Select from the dropdown menu here which Level you want to view on that Story. You may drag the DXF file to re-position it by holding down the left-click button and rotate it using the handle at the bottom. Construction Line: The construction lines are snappable, and will serve as your primary guide in creating spaces. Place a construction line by clicking on a starting point with the left click button, and dragging your mouse to create the desired length and angle, and finish the construction line by left-clicking again. As you draw the line, you see the dimensions of your line. 3. Project Navigation Tree To the left of the 2D canvas is the project navigation tree where you can see the hierarchy of the building floors and spaces, the height of each floor, and the area of each space. When you drew a space, the area of the space shows up in the navigation tree with the Space Name. Spaces are color-coded in 2D view, and updates with the same color in 3D view. If no space type is assigned, its color is grey in 2D and 3D views and in the Project Navigation Tree. 4. Add Story/Space You can add a new space, a new story, or a shading element into your project. It is important to remember that when you draw your first space on a story, you DO NOT need to click the Add Space button, you are already in the draw space mode as you can see above in the Project Navigation Tree to the left with space highlighted in bold and underlined. Whenever you draw a space, the area of the space shows up in the Project Navigation Page on the left with the Space Name and the area. Space : Click this every time you want to add a new space to a story. A new space appears in the building tree with 0 area until you draw the space. All your spaces must be drawn adjacent to another one, or within another space. Note that the dotted lines here represent interior walls, and solid lines exterior walls. If you see a solid line that should be a dotted line, that means you drew your geometry with a small gap in between it. Delete one of the spaces and redraw until it‚Äôs a dotted boundary. Space Type : At some point, you must assign a space type to every space in your model. This is how we know what defaults for space loads, schedules, etc. to assign to each space. When you click Add Space Type, you will see a drop-down list appear of all the available SPEED Space Types. Select the ones you want to add to your project, and you will see them appear in the white box. This means that this Space Type I loaded into your project and is available to assign to spaces. To do this, first, click on the Space Type name in the box, then go to your 2D canvas and start clicking on spaces. Assign Space Types to all the spaces on your floorplan. Story: You create new stories with the Story button. First, fill in the height of the story, then click the add story button. You will see a new story added to the Building Tree, and you will automatically be in the draw Space mode, so you don‚Äôt need to click Add Space for your first space on the story. You can see the story below is made semi-transparent so you have a reference when drawing your spaces on the second story. You may change the story height at any time. Alternatively, when you have floorplans that are quite similar, it‚Äôs best to simply duplicate a floor you already spent the time drawing. You can do this with the Duplicate Floor Button by highlighting the Story in the Project Navigation Tree, and click the Duplicate button to copy the floor above it. You can then modify it. Shading : You can create site context or shading buildings using the shading button. First, fill in the height of the shading building you desire, then click the shading button. You will see a shading building appear on Story 1 in the Project Navigation Tree with no area assigned yet until you draw it. By default, the rectangular tool is selected, but you may switch to the polygon tool if you wish. You may change the height of the shading building at any time. You may always delete a shading building by clicking the ‚ÄúX‚Äù next to it. ‚Äå 7. Utilization Tab You can add a new space, a North : You may rotate the scene which represents the true north displayed on the map. As you rotate the scene, you are rotating true north off of Project North which is always the top of the drawing canvas as can be seen by the compass in the upper left-hand corner of the scene. Story Below : You can enable or disable the display of the story below Map : You may toggle on/off the visibility of the floor below. You are able to snap to the geometry on the story below. Grid : You can toggle on/off the grid display. DXF : You may turn on/off the visibility of the DXF lines in case you have imported one. The drawing tools for spaces do not snap to the DXF as it‚Äôs saved as an SVG image. C-Line : Toggle on or off this button to enable or disable the visibility of the construction lines. Spacing : You are able to change the grid spacing and resolution based on the scale of your project. About Length, Width, & Thickness ‚ÄúLength‚Äù is associated with the total length of the building in the x-direction, and ‚Äúwidth‚Äù is the total length of the building in the y-direction when the orientation is set to zero (starting position). These dimensions for each footprint shape may be visualized by hovering your mouse over the building‚Äôs 2d view. If the building is rotated, these relative dimensions stay the same. Length: overall length in the x-direction Width: overall length in y-direction Thickness: is automatically calculated in the current Shape Generator 1 mode. Perimeter Depth: is automatically estimated based on the shape and size of your building. It will be defined by users in the future version of the tool. 8. Display Option SPEED provides the user with a wide range of display options. You may toggle on or off the grid, a ground plane, a Google Map.‚Äå Display Grid : Check or uncheck the box to display or hide the grid. Display Ground : Check or uncheck the box to display or hide the green ground surface. Display Map : In case you had inserted a valid address for ‚ÄúLocation‚Äù in the ‚ÄúProject Information‚Äù tab, you will be able to overlay the map over the ground in the 2D and 3D views. Map Type : This menu is expanded when you check the Display Maps button. You can choose from Google Maps, Google Terrain, Google Satellite, or Google Hybrid maps. 5. Solar Analysis SPEED provides the user with real-time solar analysis. You may activate menus to do rapid, accurate solar analysis for shadow analysis, sunlight hour analysis, and solar radiation analysis with or without a sun path diagram. Display Sun Path : Sun path diagrams provides a broad overview of the sun on a site as they map the path of the sun across the sky at different times during the day throughout the year. They can help establish the position of the sun relative to a site and can be used to visualize the effect of sun and shadows cast by buildings and other structures on and around the site. This option is active if you select Display Shadows, Display Sunlight Hours, or Display Solar Radiation. ‚Äå Display Shadow : This menu is expanded when you check the Display Shadows button. Shadow analysis is used to determine the shading impacts of the existing and proposed project structures. This feature calculates the shadow lengths of the structures and projects their patterns on buildings and sites at different times of the year. You may move the slider for Hour and see accurate shadows being cast. If you uncheck the Hour button, then you can select a Month and Day and click Run Shadow Analysis, and a sun range diagram will be generated giving you a view of the shadows cast throughout the course of a day. You may click on the zoom icon at the top right of the geometry views to expand the view and shadow analysis inputs. Enable Display Shadow, and remove hours to see shadow ranges ‚Äå Display Sunlight Hours: This menu is expanded when you check the Display Sunlight Hours button. This analysis calculates the number of hours of direct sunlight received by the building as well as the ground. You can choose if you want the sunlight hour analysis to be annual, seasonal, or for a given month and day. SPEED uses Radiance and an innovative analysis method to generate Radiance results in 95% less time than most other tools with 98% accuracy. ‚Äå Display Solar Radiation : Solar radiation analysis enables you to map and analyze the effects of the sun over your project for specific time periods. This menu is expanded when you check the Display Solar Radiation button. This insolation analysis calculates the incident solar radiation in kWh/ft2 received by the building as well as the ground and adjacent buildings. You can choose if you want the solar radiation analysis to be annual, seasonal, or for a given month and day. SPEED uses Radiance and an innovative analysis method to generate Radiance results in 95% less time than most other tools with 98% accuracy. ‚Äå

title: Geometry Page ‚Äì Parametric Shape
content: What is SPEED? Why did we create SPEED? Who is the SPEED team? How does SPEED ‚Äúfit within our design process? SPEED Project Portal Page SPEED General Structure of Pages SPEED Project Information Page SPEED Site Context SPEED Geometry Page - Parametric Shapes SPEED Geometry Page - BST SPEED Envelope Page SPEED Construction Page SPEED Space Layout Page SPEED Space Load Page SPEED HVAC Page SPEED Daylighting Page SPEED Photovoltaic Page SPEED Parametric Study SPEED Result: Single Run Chart SPEED Result: Multiple Run Chart SPEED Result: PCP SPEED Result: 2D Scatter Plot SPEED Result: 3D Scatter Plot SPEED Result: Sensitivity Analysis SPEED Result: 3D Parameter Influence About Instructions Result Tutorials Examples FAQ Geometry THE GEOMETRY PAGE ENABLES YOU TO DEFINE BUILDING MASSING AND DISPLAY SUN-PATH, SHADOW, AND SOLAR ASSESSMENTS. ‚Äå 1. Building Information Building Area: This is the total building area for your project. As you change inputs like # of Floors and Length/Width building area is maintained.‚Äå # of Floors : Select a value from 1 to 25 as the number of floors. ‚Äå Floor Area : This field will be calculated automatically based on the area of the building and the number of floors.‚Äå Floor Height: Select a value from the list of the floor heights between 8 to 15 feet that is closest to your project. This value should account for the total floor height that is conditioned. For example, if the actual floor to floor height 15 ft, but there are a ceiling and unconditioned plenum that is 3 ft, then the floor height that should be entered is 12 feet. This convention is used to make sure the energy simulation doesn‚Äôt overestimate energy consumption. 2. # of Footprint Shape ‚ÄåIdentify how many footprint shapes you like to compare. When SPEED is in Analysis Type=1 mode, you may compare up to 4 different footprint shapes at once. A minimum of two must be defined. Each footprint shape should be unique. For Analysis Type=2 and Analysis Type=3, only one footprint shape may be defined and this field is deactivated. 3. Massing Generation Footprint Shape : Select from the list of footprint shape closest to your imagined project. The shapes supported by the current version of the tool include Box-Shape, L_Shape, H_Shape, T_Shape, U_Shape, Plus_Shape, Courtyard_Shape. ‚Äå Orientation: Select building orientation from the list. ‚Äå Parametric Length/ Width : You can parametrically change the building dimensions for a given footprint shape and building area by varying Length (x) and Width (y) extents, with the thickness auto-calculated to maintain the proper floor area as well as the perimeter depth to ensure reasonable thermal zoning of the model. About Length, Width, & Thickness ‚ÄúLength‚Äù is associated with the total length of the building in the x-direction, and ‚Äúwidth‚Äù is the total length of the building in the y-direction when the orientation is set to zero (starting position). These dimensions for each footprint shape may be visualized by hovering your mouse over the building‚Äôs 2d view. If the building is rotated, these relative dimensions stay the same. Length: overall length in the x-direction Width: overall length in y-direction Thickness: is automatically calculated in the current Shape Generator 1 mode. Perimeter Depth: is automatically estimated based on the shape and size of your building. It will be defined by users in the future version of the tool. Opacity : Use the toggle to define your preferred opacity of the building. 4. Display Option SPEED provides the user with a wide range of display options. You may toggle on or off the grid, a ground plane, a Google Map.‚Äå Display Grid : Check or uncheck the box to display or hide the grid. Display Ground : Check or uncheck the box to display or hide the green ground surface. Display Map : In case you had inserted a valid address for ‚ÄúLocation‚Äù in the ‚ÄúProject Information‚Äù tab, you will be able to overlay the map over the ground in the 2D and 3D views. Map Type : This menu is expanded when you check the Display Maps button. You can choose from Google Maps, Google Terrain, Google Satellite, or Google Hybrid maps. Display or hide ground by checking/unchecking ‚ÄúDisplay Ground‚Äù Display Google Map Display Google Map Sattelite 5. Solar Analysis SPEED provides the user with real-time solar analysis. You may activate menus to do rapid, accurate solar analysis for shadow analysis, sunlight hour analysis, and solar radiation analysis with or without a sun path diagram. Display Sun Path : Sun path diagrams provides a broad overview of the sun on a site as they map the path of the sun across the sky at different times during the day throughout the year. They can help establish the position of the sun relative to a site and can be used to visualize the effect of sun and shadows cast by buildings and other structures on and around the site. This option is active if you select Display Shadows, Display Sunlight Hours, or Display Solar Radiation. ‚Äå Display Shadow : This menu is expanded when you check the Display Shadows button. Shadow analysis is used to determine the shading impacts of the existing and proposed project structures. This feature calculates the shadow lengths of the structures and projects their patterns on buildings and sites at different times of the year. You may move the slider for Hour and see accurate shadows being cast. If you uncheck the Hour button, then you can select a Month and Day and click Run Shadow Analysis, and a sun range diagram will be generated giving you a view of the shadows cast throughout the course of a day. You may click on the zoom icon at the top right of the geometry views to expand the view and shadow analysis inputs. Enable Display Shadow, and remove hours to see shadow ranges ‚Äå Display Sunlight Hours: This menu is expanded when you check the Display Sunlight Hours button. This analysis calculates the number of hours of direct sunlight received by the building as well as the ground. You can choose if you want the sunlight hour analysis to be annual, seasonal, or for a given month and day. SPEED uses Radiance and an innovative analysis method to generate Radiance results in 95% less time than most other tools with 98% accuracy. ‚Äå Display Solar Radiation : Solar radiation analysis enables you to map and analyze the effects of the sun over your project for specific time periods. This menu is expanded when you check the Display Solar Radiation button. This insolation analysis calculates the incident solar radiation in kWh/ft2 received by the building as well as the ground and adjacent buildings. You can choose if you want the solar radiation analysis to be annual, seasonal, or for a given month and day. SPEED uses Radiance and an innovative analysis method to generate Radiance results in 95% less time than most other tools with 98% accuracy. ‚Äå

title: Site Context Page
content: What is SPEED? Why did we create SPEED? Who is the SPEED team? How does SPEED ‚Äúfit within our design process? SPEED Project Portal Page SPEED General Structure of Pages SPEED Project Information Page SPEED Site Context SPEED Geometry Page - Parametric Shapes SPEED Geometry Page - BST SPEED Envelope Page SPEED Construction Page SPEED Space Layout Page SPEED Space Load Page SPEED HVAC Page SPEED Daylighting Page SPEED Photovoltaic Page SPEED Parametric Study SPEED Result: Single Run Chart SPEED Result: Multiple Run Chart SPEED Result: PCP SPEED Result: 2D Scatter Plot SPEED Result: 3D Scatter Plot SPEED Result: Sensitivity Analysis SPEED Result: 3D Parameter Influence About Instructions Result Tutorials Examples FAQ https://vimeo.com/491491449/c615e3e975 Site Context The Site Context Page is where you are able to define shading or context buildings that affect the microclimate around the building being designed and analyzed. They may block solar access and provide shade, modify the path and intensity of airflow, and/or impact glare from the reflection of their surfaces. 1. Add Adjacent Buildings In Parametric Shape Mode, create context buildings by generating a simple box massing at the appropriate distance and direction from the building being designed which is centered at the global origin 0,0,0 using the diagram below as guidance. You can add up to four adjacent buildings. The global axis grid you see assumes positive y is true north. ‚Äå Consider You can use positive or negative values for Offset X and Offset Y, compared to the global axis. Length, width, and height can get any integer values Select the orientation of each context building from the list of Site Orientation You can zoom in or out inside the Site Context visualization to adjust the view. 2. Display Options SPEED provides the user with a range of display options throughout your project. You may toggle on or off the grid, a ground plane, and a Google Map Overlay. If you check the Map box, a menu will appear where you can choose from Google Maps Street, Google Maps Satellite, or Google Maps Hybrid map types. If the latitude and longitude obtained from the Project Information Page don‚Äôt put your geometry grid in exactly the right location, you may move the map overlay to exactly position the center of your building by pressing the Ctrl button and holding the right-click button, and dragging the map in the 2D view.

title: Project Information Page
content: What is SPEED? Why did we create SPEED? Who is the SPEED team? How does SPEED ‚Äúfit within our design process? SPEED Project Portal Page SPEED General Structure of Pages SPEED Project Information Page SPEED Site Context SPEED Geometry Page - Parametric Shapes SPEED Geometry Page - BST SPEED Envelope Page SPEED Construction Page SPEED Space Layout Page SPEED Space Load Page SPEED HVAC Page SPEED Daylighting Page SPEED Photovoltaic Page SPEED Parametric Study SPEED Result: Single Run Chart SPEED Result: Multiple Run Chart SPEED Result: PCP SPEED Result: 2D Scatter Plot SPEED Result: 3D Scatter Plot SPEED Result: Sensitivity Analysis SPEED Result: 3D Parameter Influence About Instructions Result Tutorials Examples FAQ Project Information The Project Information page provides all the high-level information about your project to get things going. ‚Äå 1. Location Address : SPEED uses a Google Maps API using the address typed in by the user to automatically look important information about the project site for energy and daylighting analysis. First, SPEED looks up the latitude and longitude of the site which is used to (1) identify the most appropriate weather file to use for the simulation from a Department of Energy database; (2) place the center point of the building at the grid global origin (0,0,0) at that latitude and longitude; and (3) is used to scale a Google Map Overlay on the grid in the following pages. The Country, State, and Zip Code are automatically populated and the Zip Code is used to (1) lookup the ASHRAE Climate Zone and Energy Code to be used for prescriptive code-compliant constructions R-Values and space loads such as Lighting Power Density and (2) the fuel factors, emission rates, and utility rates for that region using a tool called eGrid. You might see several drop downs appear once you start typing in an address. One is from the Google Maps API and one is from your local browser (it‚Äôs the thinner drop-down menu). Make sure to select from the Google Maps API and not your browser. Country : USA and Canada now, all the other countries where we have offices or projects will be added soon.‚Äå State and City : Auto-populated! Just for your reference.‚Äå Zip Code : The Zip Code of your project is very important. With this input as well as Country and State, SPEED automatically (1) looks up the ASHRAE Climate Zone and Energy Code to be used for automatically looking up prescriptive code constructions and space loads; and (2) looks up the fuel factors, emission rates, and utility rates for that region. Energy Code : Right now we only support ASHRAE 90.1-2007/2010/2013. If you wish to use a more stringent version of ASHRAE 90.1 than is currently required for your location, you may do so by unchecking ‚ÄúDefault‚Äù and selecting the desired one.¬† If a state uses IECC as the required code, it‚Äôs very close to the ASHRAE ones and we just use the best fit. The next step will be to allow for all sorts of Energy Codes to be used such as Title 24 in California or whatever other code all of you want and need for your project. 2. Project Profile Project Name : The Project Profile is a brief snapshot describing your project, including Project Name, Project Description, your preferred Unit system, and Primary Building Type. Since you logged into SPEED with Okta, it knows what projects you have access to given your home office. These are the projects that will appear in the drop-down menu. Since SPEED is free to project teams, the Project Name is only used as a reference. If you are in pursuit or prefer not to use a specific Project Name, you may select the options ‚ÄúTest‚Äù or ‚ÄúPursuit‚Äù. The Project Description is only used for your own personal summary and to more easily identify your project in the Project Portal. For Units, we currently only support IP, though SI will be supported in the next release. Project Description : This field is not used by SPEED for anything other than providing the designers with a useful description in the Project Portal Page.‚Äå Units : This field can be IP or SI units. The IP option is the only one available for the first version, but soon the SI option will be available as well. ‚Äå Primary Building Type : The Primary Building Type is the building‚Äôs main function that will strongly influence its design and operation and is used to determine the number of assumptions in SPEED. For offices, a Small Office is <50,000 ft2, a Medium Office is 50,000 ft2 ‚â• X < 100,000 ft2, and a Large Office is ‚â• 100,000 ft2. Later in the Space Layout page, you will have the ability to specify multi-use building details. Note Originally, we had each Project Billing Number appear with the Project Name. This was because we thought the project may get billed for the time/cost of using AWS for their simulations. But thanks to how quickly and inexpensively we can run simulations (500 energy simulations cost $6!), our CEO Phil decided to make this a free service to all its designers. Thanks, Phil!! 3. Performance Benchmarks and Targets Having a building‚Äôs Energy Use Intensity (EUI) benchmark is the first step to understanding and comparing your energy performance and carbon footprint to a similar existing building stock. Based on the benchmark, energy performance targets such as Architecture 2030 may be determined. Click on the link for EUI Generator to obtain these values based on the building type, size, and climate conditions. While these inputs are not required, they are very useful later in SPEED as you may visualize them alongside the performance of the designs you choose to analyze. EUI Benchmark/Target: Though not required, if you enter this information here, we can show them in the visualizations of the results of your project so you know how your designs compare to your benchmarks and targets! Please let us know what other building performance benchmarks and targets you‚Äôd like to see here‚Ä¶energy is only the starting point. About Length, Width, & Thickness Most input fields that are to be typed in by the user are NOT required. You may leave them blank and complete the page without filling them in. These fields are used for your reference only. 4. Geometry Mode SPEED was designed to give designers flexibility in how they create their building geometry.¬†Select Parametric Shapes if you would like to generate geometry using up to 4 pre-defined footprints (e.g. ‚ÄúL‚Äù, ‚ÄúH‚Äù, etc.) that may be parametrically driven using a few simple inputs. Select Block & Stack Tool if you would like to draw custom geometry for up to 4 footprint shapes. The final option, Import gbXML , allows you to import up to 4 massings from Sketch-Up, Rhino, or Revit. Depending on what Geometry Mode you select, the entire Graphical User Interface (GUI) is put into several different modes to optimize how you create your project, simulate it, and evaluate the results. For example, in BST Mode, no Site Context or Space Layout Page appears since shading buildings and Space Type assignments are all done within the Geometry Page. Parametric Shapes: Depending on the project and design stage, you will want to choose the appropriate analysis types for your SPEED project. Each Analysis Type enables/disables different features to ensure that your parametric study at the end of your project is giving you the most useful results.‚Äå Comparing Multiple Footprint Shapes Together (Type 1) : This option should be selected if the building footprint shape is not yet fixed and you want to explore the energy performance of various massing shapes side-by-side. When the tool is in this mode, some inputs are limited to be able to isolate the impact of the different footprint shapes. For example, the user can only assign one Space Type to the entire building to isolate the energy impacts of the different shapes and prevent the energy output metrics from reflecting different internal loads and number of zones rather than the different building forms. When we say Fixed Footprint Dimensions , we don‚Äôt actually mean you can change the relative dimensions of the Footprint Shape. You most certainly can. We just mean that in the Parametric Study, you will not be able to make the input design variables Length and Width a part of the study. Comparing Different Number of Floors for a Fixed Footprint Shape (Type 2) : This option should be selected if the building footprint shape is fixed but you want to evaluate the impact of varying the number of floors on building performance. In this mode, while some inputs are limited, it is less restrictive than Analysis Type=1, such as enabling the assignment of different space types to multiple floors in the model. Comparing Different Massing Aspect Ratios for a Fixed Footprint Shape and # of Floors (Type 3): This option should be selected if the building footprint shape is fixed as well as the number of floors. There are no restrictions on inputs in this third mode, and footprint dimensions may be included in the parametric study. A graphical way of summarizing the various Analysis Types. ‚Äå Block & Stack Tool (BST): If you cannot create your geometry from the current footprint shape in the parametric shapes mode, you would be able to create your own specific geometry by selecting the BST tool.‚Äå gbXML Import: This functionality has yet to be built into SPEED, but will be included in the next several releases.

title: General Structure of the Pages
content: What is SPEED? Why did we create SPEED? Who is the SPEED team? How does SPEED ‚Äúfit within our design process? SPEED Project Portal Page SPEED General Structure of Pages SPEED Project Information Page SPEED Site Context SPEED Geometry Page - Parametric Shapes SPEED Geometry Page - BST SPEED Envelope Page SPEED Construction Page SPEED Space Layout Page SPEED Space Load Page SPEED HVAC Page SPEED Daylighting Page SPEED Photovoltaic Page SPEED Parametric Study SPEED Result: Single Run Chart SPEED Result: Multiple Run Chart SPEED Result: PCP SPEED Result: 2D Scatter Plot SPEED Result: 3D Scatter Plot SPEED Result: Sensitivity Analysis SPEED Result: 3D Parameter Influence About Instructions Result Tutorials Examples FAQ General Structure of the Pages Before we jump into the details of each page, we do want to review the general structure of the pages and point out important features to help you along your way.‚Äå 1. Home Page By clicking on the home page, you go back to the project portal page. Make sure to Save your page before clicking on this button. ‚Äå 2. Submit Feedback If you click this, you are able on every page to give us the type of feedback you are providing, a description of the feedback, and you can also attach an image that is very valuable to the development team. Here‚Äôs what it looks like: 3. SPEED User Profile This button is what you click to automatically bring you to our SPEED documentation, which is the link you are reading from now and is intended to have all the information you need to successfully use the platform. It includes detailed descriptions not discussed in the Tooltips, Q&A, Known Issues, as well as other supporting documentation. 4. Video Tutorial You can find a video tutorial related to each individual page at the top of the page, which briefly provide the necessary information to complete the page. 5. Tooltips Another important item is the Tooltips that we‚Äôve provided throughout the GUI. These are intended to give a brief explanation of the inputs and how they are used. Not everything has a tooltip, and if you think we need more, just let us know! ‚Äå 6. Navigation Pages When creating a new project, you need to fill out pages in order. You can go back to any previous page, but not able to jump into the next page unless you finish it and save the page.‚Äå 7. Save/Next Make sure to save your page if you are going to any previous page or you are not planning to continue at any point. Ok, let‚Äôs jump into some of the detail. Remember, this isn‚Äôt a black box, it‚Äôs a completely transparent one and we can give any piece of information you want about SPEED, it‚Äôs assumptions, methodology, etc. Just ask!

title: Project Portal Page
content: What is SPEED? Why did we create SPEED? Who is the SPEED team? How does SPEED ‚Äúfit within our design process? SPEED Project Portal Page SPEED General Structure of Pages SPEED Project Information Page SPEED Site Context SPEED Geometry Page - Parametric Shapes SPEED Geometry Page - BST SPEED Envelope Page SPEED Construction Page SPEED Space Layout Page SPEED Space Load Page SPEED HVAC Page SPEED Daylighting Page SPEED Photovoltaic Page SPEED Parametric Study SPEED Result: Single Run Chart SPEED Result: Multiple Run Chart SPEED Result: PCP SPEED Result: 2D Scatter Plot SPEED Result: 3D Scatter Plot SPEED Result: Sensitivity Analysis SPEED Result: 3D Parameter Influence About Instructions Result Tutorials Examples FAQ https://vimeo.com/491459277/ae8f4d2bc3 Project Portal Page The Project Portal is your own personal dashboard of all your projects, either completed, in the middle of running simulation, or still in draft status (meaning you haven‚Äôt submitted it for analysis). 1 . Project ID: Each designer will have their projects named like this: FirstNameLastName-1,2,3, etc.‚Äå 2 . Project Name: This comes directly from Okta. Once you log in, Okta determines which projects you have access to select from. Based on user feedback, we now have an option to simply select ‚ÄúTest Project‚Äù or ‚ÄúPursuit‚Äù at the top of the list. This is because often Pursuits have not made their way to Okta yet, but it‚Äôs one of the most valuable phases of design to use SPEED! ‚Äå 3 . Date Completed: This is the date that the Status field was completed. ‚Äå 4 . Total Submitted Runs: This is the total size of your design space, i.e. how many runs or simulations you had in your project.‚Äå 5 . Total Successful Runs: Hopefully this matches (4), but sometimes it won‚Äôt. Fear not. Some runs can fail and your study is still valid and useful. Our cut-off for whether or not say a project is successful or not is if less than 10% fail.‚Äå 6 . Status: The options are (1) Draft; (2) Submitted for Analysis; (3) Analysis in Progress; (4) Simulation Complete; (5) Analysis Complete (meaning we did some post-processing on the simulation results to give you some useful design guidance); and (6) Analysis Failed. We hope you don‚Äôt get the last one, but it will happen, particularly during the first months. We have a lot of kinks to work out. If your project fails, someone will get in contact with you directly to explain why we think it failed, and what needs to happen for you to successfully re-submit it.‚Äå 7 . Project Description: This is for your own reference. If you have a pursuit, you‚Äôll probably want to put the name in this field, which is discussed later.‚Äå 8 . View, Copy, or Share : By selecting View, you can open up old projects, finish them or view their results (unless it‚Äôs still running). You can copy a project and modify it for new sets of analysis. Or you can share a project with another PW user, which will have all information except the results. Note If you open up a project that has been submitted or is complete, the GUI inputs are disabled so you can still see them but not change them.‚Äå 9 . Add Project/ Demo : If you want to create a new project, click the ‚ÄúAdd Project‚Äù button. If you want to see an example of what a successfully completed project looks like, click the ‚ÄúDemo‚Äù button.
