title: Perkins&Will UK BIM Capability Assessment Response
content: Section¬†1 Introductory Questions 1.1 ‚Äì General Competence 1.1.1 ‚Äì Do you have a BIM policy for your organisation? If yes, please provide details / attach. ‚Äì yes / https://pulse.perkinswill.com/content/60379 1.1.2 ‚Äì Who within your organisation is responsible for your organisation‚Äôs BIM strategy? Please provide CVs for applicable staff. At Perkins&Will global BIM strategy falls under the responsibility of the Digital Practice Group who work across Perkins&Will‚Äôs projects and offices to enable a high-performing, interdisciplinary design organisation through the intelligent application of technology. The team have a broad understanding of design practice, coupled with significant technical depth in each Digital Practice domain: Digital Project Delivery; Design Computation; Analysis, Simulation & Visualization; and Information Management. In addition to the above the Digital Practice Group manage the development of custom applications and digital tools to advance our practice beyond preconceived and prepackaged technology solutions. Each office has a Design Applications Manager to ensure implementation locally is aligned with the firmwide strategies and regional standard methods and practices. 1.1.3 ‚Äì Who within your organisation will be responsible for BIM on their projects? Who will support this person? Please provide references for a maximum of 3 Level 2 BIM maturity projects with case studies. Perkins&Will have taken the role as Project BIM Coordinator during the design stages for projects to provide guidance and direction over the BIM process to facilitate coordination and integrated design solutions. This would include authoring the BIM processes required to work collaboratively with our design partners allowing us to coordinate and exchange data using common protocols and industry-standard guidelines with the aim of providing a data set that can be used by the construction team moving forward. Each project also has a dedicated BIM Coordinator responsible for ensuring the data being produced internally conforms to the BIM standards that have been established. Office wide the Design Application Manager provides software support to the Perkins&Will teams in their use of all BIM applications. IT Site Infrastructure lead implements and manages all other aspects of Information Technology. Level 2 BIM Projects ‚Äì (current at 10/2015) Perkins&Will London¬†have yet to complete what is defined as full Level 2 BIM but have delivered a number of projects using Level 2 BIM methods through Design and also into operation. COLT ‚Äì (IT Telecoms) Project Value ¬£18m Jan 2014 ‚Äì June 2016 Project BIM Scope ‚Äì Delivery of Federated Model up to and including Stage 4. Novated by Contractor to act as BIM Manager for trade information including coordination and data extract for use with digital O&M manuals. SHELL, 20 York Road, London, UK (Corporate) Project Value (confidential) 3 Year Project Project BIM Scope ‚Äì BIM level 2 Coordinated model provided up to Stage D information in accordance with Level 2 project BIM requirements. One the Square Cambridge (Commercial) Project Value (¬£37m) May (2012) ‚Äì (July 2016) Project BIM Scope ‚Äì BIM Coordination using Level 2 workflows during Design. Novated by contractor sub-consultant models used for procurement and construction 1.1.4 ‚Äì Please provide a list of your core BIM software including design related software. Enclose a copy of your licence agreements. Our suite of design software includes numerous interoperable applications in addition to our primary core BIM authoring application, Autodesk Revit. Additional core applications include dRofus, for building program and FF&E management, Autodesk Navisworks for model coordination, and McNeel's Rhino 3D and SketchUp for conceptual modeling. Additionally, we use Newforma Project Center and Bluebeam for project information management and construction administration activities. We also use a series of support applications and ‚Äúplug-ins‚Äù developed by third-party vendors and our own applications developers. We are actively engaged with major software vendors to inform, test, and in some cases, co-develop the next generation of AEC software applications. In addition to these tools, Perkins&Will make use of computation design technology allowing us to create efficiencies and opportunities from informed data-driven decisions. Perkins&Will license agreements are regulated via our platinum agreement with Autodesk. Section¬†2 Staff Competency 2.1 ‚Äì Staff Competency Gateway 2.1.1 ‚Äì Do you have arrangements for training employees in BIM related skills and do you assess their capabilities? Please provide details. Training is completed in a number of ways. We provide a standardised firmwide 3 day training course for all new staff members covering the basic fundamentals of Revit through to our standards and workflows. Project teams also attend weekly workshops focussed solely on the use of BIM tools. These have included external project team members as well as internal teams. All staff has instant access to long-established online training resources such as Lynda & CADLearning. We monitor the progress of BIM capability by using Knowledge Smart assessment tools to evaluate our staff progress and identify areas where further training is required. 2.1.2 ‚Äì If you train staff, who provides the training and how often? Training is provided by the local Design Application Manager 2.1.3 ‚Äì Can you provide CAD / BIM related qualifications and Continual Professional Development (CPD) Certification for proposed team members? Proposed team members can be identified via a skills matrix based on the assessment tools noted above. 2.2 ‚Äì Overall company Structure BIM Resource 2.2.1 ‚Äì Overall BIM Structure Project role The number within the company fulfilling this role BIM competency Digital Practice 5 Firmwide Experts in all aspects of Digital Project Delivery. Design App Manager 3 UK 28 Firmwide Firmwide BIM strategy implementation. Support for BIM Coordinators and project teams. Initial BIM lead on project kick-off. Solid understanding of regional standard methods and practices. Project BIM Coordinator 7 UK 100+ Firmwide Strong authoring capability, use of coordination tools and workflows good understanding of BIM process Project Architect/Designers/ Technologists 45 1500+ Firmwide Digital modellers using BIM tools to facilitate design, coordination and delivery. Computational Designer 2 UK 10+ Firmwide Specialist in algorithum scripting to automate rapid design iterations, analysis, and complex geometries. VD+C 1 Firmwide Specialist in VD+C and the workflow processes to ensure constructability Sustainable Building Advisor 5+ Firmwide Produces iterative analysis models during design phases to optimize the building for energy, daylighting, airflow or other sustainability metrics. Section 3 Model Drawing & CAD Management 3.1 ‚Äì Approaches to model Management 3.1.1 ‚Äì Please indicate the drawing and Model / CAD modelling approaches that are used in your organisation. Globally Perkins&Will have a firmwide mandate to utilise parametric modelling methods. This is complemented by a variety of design approaches from hand sketching, surface modelling, computational design, visualisation and physical printed model. 3.1.2 ‚Äì Provide an approximation of the proportion of your outputs that use each method in a typical year. UK BIM Authoring ‚Äì 45% Concept Surface Modelling ‚Äì 15% 2D CAD ‚Äì 30% Hand Sketches / Visualisation ‚Äì 10% This is based on the last calendar year. The focus is to convert the office fully to BIM Authoring at a minimum of the next 2 years. 3.2 BIM / CAD Standards 3.2.1 ‚Äì A re sta n dards us e d to produce y o ur C A D / B IM m ode l s? Yes ‚Äì Modelling standards are documented on the company intranet and built into a PW template. BEP‚Äôs will also refer to project-specific modelling standards in accordance with the project deliverables. 3.2.2. ‚Äì If y o u d o n ot w ork to a C A D / B IM S t a nda r d. W h y n ot? ‚Äì N/A 3.2.3 ‚Äì Do you work to the standards outlined in the EIR document? ‚Äì Yes 3.2.4 ‚Äì If your standards differ from those outlined in the EIR document, what are they based upon? ‚Äì N/A 3.2.5 ‚Äì How do you demonstrate or what measures do you have in place to ensure compliance with your CAD / BIM Standard ? Each project is assigned a BIM Coordinator that verifies that the models authored internally to comply with both internal BIM standards and also align with the project BEP. This is part of the model coordinators designated role on any project. 3.2.6 ‚Äì Do you produce a BIM as an iterative process? e.g. the Plan of Work stages. Yes in accordance with the RIBA POW but not always from the very early stages of design 3.2.7 ‚Äì Please confirm your Quality Management System allows you to adopt the Employer‚Äôs CAD standards including title blocks, file naming conventions, version controls if required? Yes ‚Äì subject to review 3.2.8 ‚Äì How do you carry out spatial co-ordination using CAD / BIM? Virtual Design + Construction methods are applied during early design stages with formal coordination workshops being carried out at identified project stage timelines. The frequency of these workshops increases as we move into Stage 4 (Technical Design). Less formal coordination working in a model environment is encouraged as the way we work with design team partners. 3.2.9 ‚Äì In a single paragraph please explain your experiences with linked, attached and embedded attribute data within 3D models Geometric elements have the ability to be populated with additional data providing the ‚ÄúInformation‚Äù associated with BIM. Embedded data allows the building model to move beyond typical 3D geometry and move into further dimensions of time cost and asset information. (4/5/6D) Section¬†4 Experience with Electronic Data Exchange 4.1 ‚Äì Web-Based Project Tools 4.1.1¬†‚Äì Please indicate your experience with web-based project tools such as extranets or web-enabled document management systems. Perkins&Will have worked with project extranets and document management tools provided by clients for well over a decade. Internally our firmwide integrated project delivery solution is Newforma. 4.1.2 ‚Äì Which project collaboration or web-enabled document management tools have you worked with? Please list. Newforma, 4Projects, Asite, Buzzsaw, Acconex, Procore, Plangrid, Conject etc 4.2 ‚Äì In-House Data Storage 4.2.1 ‚Äì Please provide details of how work in progress files are stored within your project office ensuring your teams work collaboratively with up to date data generated by your team and from other interfacing designers through the use of web-based collaboration tools. Perkins&Will operate a mobile infrastructure with access to global computation nodes (powerful physical machines) allowing both internal and external project cloud environments. Using Newforma for informal model exchange allows us to track and audit data flow. We replicate CDE methods internally to ensure model information received and published is used for a purpose. 4.3 ‚Äì Professional Indemnity Limitations 4.3.1 ‚Äì Please describe any limitations placed on your ability to exchange electronic information by your PI insurers, eg. a requirement to send parallel paper copies of electronic documents? ‚Äì No limitations Section 5¬†‚Äì Technical 5.1¬†‚Äì Software Applications 5.1.1 ‚Äì The following are the software applications currently prescribed by the Employer on their projects. Please respond indicating where your company complies / does not comply: Project role BIM authoring tool Compliance with requirement (Yes / No) If ‚ÄòNo‚Äô ‚Äì what BIM authoring tool do you propose to use? Version currently in use Architecture Autodesk Revit (Architecture) Yes 2019/2020 Autodesk Navisworks Manage Yes 2019/2020 BIM360 Design 2019/2020 5.2¬†‚Äì Maintenance 5.2.1 ‚Äì Are your CAD / BIM tools covered by a yearly maintenance agreement? ‚Äì Yes ‚Äì Perkins&Will have a platinum contract with Autodesk 5.3 ¬†‚Äì Use of Aggregators / visualisation software 5.3.1 ‚Äì Visualisations and clash detection is to be undertaken using Navisworks. Do you currently use Navisworks (Yes / No)? ‚Äì Yes If yes what products do you use and how are they deployed? ‚Äì Navisworks Manage ‚Äì available to all staff. Automated workflow to Link to PIM platform. If no ‚Äì what clash detection and visualisation packages do you propose to use? 5.3.2 Other packages may be used to provide visualisation. ‚Äì 3D Studio Max Design / Maya / Showcase / Lumion / Vray / Enscape Please indicate the approach your organisation takes with regard to the provision of visualisation? ‚Äì Visualisation is generated both internally and also outsourced to a preferred list of suppliers 5.4¬†¬†‚Äì Use of 3rd Part Organisations 5.4.1 ‚Äì Is all of your BIM / CAD work done in-house or do you engage third party authoring consultants? If third party consultants are used, please provide details. In house with the exception of some visualisation above Section¬†6¬†‚Äì Industry Foundation Class (IFC) 6.1 ‚Äì IFC Experience 6.1.1 ‚Äì Briefly describe your experience of using IFC as a file exchange format. Perkins&Will UK¬†have used IFC on projects to supply FM teams with an open-source format for use with digital O&M manuals. We have also used IFC as an open format for collaboration but this wasn‚Äôt without its challenges. Processes had to be refined to ensure models when exchanged were fit for purpose notably when the exchange was between differing software authoring tools. Section¬†7¬†‚Äì IT Resillience 7.1 ‚Äì Disaster Recovery Systems & Procedures 7.1.1-Briefly describe your disaster recovery systems and procedures. Being part of a global company, we start from a position of all essential Active Directory and other services being replicated at offices across North America, Brazil, London, Paris, Dubai, and Shanghai. VPN connections are managed by Sprint and are routed inbound through their POPs, so users can VPN into other offices. Internal systems are also replicated to a co-location site in Chicago. Email services are hosted externally by Microsoft. We use Nasuni cloud filers which push all changes to cloud storage, and the volumes are also replicated to other Nasuni filers around the globe so that in the event of a loss of a filer users are connected to a surviving filer through DFS. The loss of a single office should, therefore, have minimal impact on data processing capabilities. All staff have laptops rather than desktops so a large number could be expected to have their laptops with them. 7.1.2 ‚Äì Briefly describe your archiving systems and procedures. Our use of the Nasuni filer means we are able to keep all information online. It is stored in the cloud storage part of the filter, and pulled into the onsite cache when needed. This means we currently don‚Äôt archive any material offline, but move it to a different tier of storage instead. 7.1.3 ‚Äì Do you have an anti virus system that continuously monitors all your incoming and outgoing traffic? Provide details. Yes, we use Microsoft SCCM for virus scanning. 7.1.4 ‚Äì How often do you update your anti virus software? ‚Äì Constantly via automatic updates 7.1.5 ‚Äì Do you have systems for protecting against spyware and other covert activity logging systems? ‚Äì Yes, we use SCCM for desktop protection 7.1.6 ‚Äì Do you have a firewall system, is it mainstream and are there limitations / Outgoing & Incoming ? Yes, Dell Sonicwall firewalls, no limitations. Section¬†8¬†‚Äì Contectural Understanding 8.1 ‚Äì Primary BIM Uses 8.1.1-Design Construction Intelligent 3D modelling ‚Äì Architectural Evidence ‚Äì Our approach to design using BIM at Perkins&Will involves complete integration. The 3D model is our primary design tool. BIM tools provides the ability to explore ideas quickly within context, and allow our designers to occupy, interact with, and experience the space/building while creating it. The design experience is deepened through lighting studies, various forms of environmental analysis, and exploration of new geometries, forms, and textures. Building Information Models are used to develop and deliver all design documentation, including plans, sections, elevations, axonometric and perspective views of projects by using a series of firmwide standard and real-world elements to enable consistent outputs. Data is embedded within these elements that can be extracted and re-used by members of the construction team and FM managers when the building is in operation. Project partners often dictate how active our use of collaborative BIM methods are but we look to team up in any way possible and often provide assistance and support to our project partners who are new to working this way. PBPW has implemented the above on a number of collaborative projects including projects that have developed As Constructed models and links to FM data systems moving through RIBA Stages 1-6. 8.1.2-Facillities Management Perkins&Will have worked with FM providers to understand the requirements and provide the relevant fields for contractor embedded information. Using a geometric model that is imported into the providers software, links have been provided to enable preventive scheduled maintenance and digital connection to O&M and warranty data. We have also provided COBIE data but are unsure if use was made of the information delivered. 8.1.2-Quantity Take Off / Costing Perkins&Will model to allow for cost information to be scheduled via take off from the model. Not every building element is modeled but what is and what is not modelled will be written into the MPS. We model as much as possible to allow us to both quantify as a means of validation and to ensure that access pinch points are accurate and finishes are represented as true model elements. 8.1.4-Visualsisation / Marketing Visuals, walkthroughs and 3D printed replicas can be can be relatively simple to extract from the¬†models and can be used as effective communication tools. These model bi-products help the client and team better understand the proposed design. Because the model is live, renderings can be easily developed at all phases of the design providing the client with a tangible visual product before construction begins. Our models are used as a baseline for our visualisation teams when high end marketing imagery / animation is required. 8.1.5-Safety Planning ‚Äì N/A 8.1.6-Clash Detection¬†‚Äì Perkins&Will utilise a VD+C Workflow through the design stages to ensure that design models are coordinated between disciplines prior to hand over to construction contractors. These workshops help validate against the MPS table to ensure that model information is as described. Clash rules are set dependent upon project stage. Initially as identifying simple hard clashes but as the project moves into the final stages of technical design the clash rule sets becoming more defined to include access, install and service space requirements. We use clash validation to ensure our design intent documentation is constructible rather than target a zero clash model. 8.1.7-4D Scheduling ‚Äì While as designers we do not implement 4D during construction we often add the time dimension into our design via the project phasing tools built into our authoring software. This is more appropriate when working on a renovation of in use existing estate. 8.1.8-Construction BIM¬†‚Äì N/A 8.1.9-Procurement¬†‚Äì N/A 8.1.10-Supply Chain Management¬†‚Äì N/A 8.1.11-Simulation- Perkins&Will use BIM tools and 3rd party plug-ins to analyses / verify and optioneer throughout the design process. We find these tools most useful in the early stages of a project enabling us to review building orientation, glazing types, shading options, carbon emissions and daylight simulation. Our tools are also accredited for compliance against UK statutory requirements. Using these tools give us confidence that our designs are robust and can provide a solid foundation for more detailed engineering analysis provided by our design partners. 8.1.12-Research & Education- Perkins&Will supports small, focused explorations proposed by staff members with micro-grants of money and time through the Innovation Incubator program. Innovation Incubator provides opportunities for proactive idea investigation, technical development, and design collaboration. The results of these explorations further our design work and contribute to the knowledge base of our industry. AREA is a non-profit research organization, which conducts research related to the built environment for the benefit of the public interest. Our vision is to engage in scientific research that results in a higher quality of the built environment, and by extension, the lives of its inhabitants. Our mission is to provide a platform that bridges traditional research disciplines and design through collaborative research efforts and the acquisition of research funding. The Perkins&Will Research Journal is dedicated to documenting and presenting practice-related research associated with buildings, their occupants and their environs. The aim of this journal is to capture and document research questions and methodologies that arise prior, during and after the design process. Section¬†9¬†‚Äì Project Experience Provide details of a minimum of 3 BIM projects for use as reference. Section¬†10¬†‚Äì Further Supporting Statements Please use this section should you wish to append any further supporting statements or clarifications. Evolution of BIM Much of the recent evolution in our BIM approach has been focused on cultivating a building information ecosystem by aggregating data sources and tailoring information delivery to downstream processes. The original promise of BIM is the creation and management of information-rich digital representations of buildings ‚Äî 3d geometrical models containing all of the information necessary for the building design and construction process. Over the course of BIM‚Äôs evolution, a few things have become clear: The information required in the design and construction process exceeds the amount of information that can be easily or efficiently managed through a single BIM authoring application; The information required in planning, programming, and design processes is not exactly the same data needed to fabricate building components or assemble a building, and requires a different approach to information management; A combination of design and construction data, complemented by operational data, is highly valuable to building owners and facilities managers beyond construction. Data-centric delivery Beginning with our healthcare practice, we have created program databases, which represent a ‚Äúsingle source of truth‚Äù for storing and managing information about a facility. These program databases are then linked to other databases that manage medical equipment, furniture, fixtures, mechanical equipment, special construction, as well as design knowledge, all of which are connected with our Building Information Models. The information contained in these databases can be delivered strategically, throughout the life of the project, including into building operations. Post Construction BIM Properly developed, the Building Information Model and ancillary databases become an asset that is transferred from phase to phase and built upon as more information is gathered to ultimately help the client to maintain their facilities. Facilities management database practices vary widely from project to project. Some clients prefer a basic spatial database that supports lifecycle assessments for capital investments such as renovations, long or short term planning. Other clients require complete equipment inventories with detailed parameters such as asset numbers, warranty information, and condition assessments. Due to the wide range of potential needs, we work with our clients to identify their unique facilities management data needs and create a clear vision of how they intend to manage their facilities in the future. Design Analytics While many of our practices have long maintained sophisticated analytical capabilities, we are now also developing new processes for data gathering and analysis, which are proving successful in our planning practices, both at the workplace scale and the campus or urban scale. In one example, we have developed a mobile application that makes polling and data gathering by our workplace team more dynamic and less intrusive. Survey queries can be served individually and strategically, over a broader timeframe, and keyed to locational triggers through Bluetooth beacons. This technology allows user polling to be seamlessly integrated into the workplace or urban environment. Using both internally developed and freely available data analysis and visualization resources, we are able to provide a rich source of information and knowledge that improves design decisions, as well as our clients‚Äô operations. Management Intelligence Perkins&Will project teams and firm management all operate across multiple software platforms and applications, for design, delivery, project management, collaboration, communication, human resources, and financial management. Taking queues from business intelligence and analytics, we have been working to extract and federate data across these disparate platforms in order to analyze and view aggregated information. ‚ÄúDashboard‚Äù type data visualizations, which we use to manage our projects and to communicate with our clients, offer insight in to project health, success, progress in terms of our key performance metrics. In addition, it gives firm leadership the ability to quickly take data snapshots of the firm‚Äôs operational health. This capability has enabled our leadership and our clients to see and to manage progress in ways never before available.

title: Perkins&Will Project Team Collaborative Workflow Statement

author.name: Nick Cameron
author.description: American trucker who has been featured on the History channel reality television series Ice Road Truckers and its spinoff series IRT: Deadliest Roads.

content: As a global firm Perkins&Will have a fully connected infrastructure that allows us to interact seamlessly within the Perkins & Will framework of studios. Our fully mobile solution not only means our live data is available anywhere and everywhere, avoiding data duplication, coordination issues and rework but also enables us to resource projects globally, leveraging experience and expertise from across the firm. This solution can be extended beyond our internal infrastructure and into a ‚Äúproject cloud‚Äù or ‚Äúvirtual project office‚Äù where dedicated project stakeholders can gain access to live and secure information from any location ensuring a single source of truth for all project data. As our standard practice is of model-based project delivery we carry out our design coordination in a 3D environment to ensure design intent is in-line with the project program and fully coordinated prior to being handed to a constructor during the pre-construction phase. Typically we use a coordination tool that federates stakeholder models from which we can validate our designs collaboratively issuing resolution actions and responsibilities in a controlled process to help identify issues in a transparent way to the whole team. These coordination meetings are often run virtually over our Microsoft Teams with project partners having the ability to control and author what is being shared collaboratively from any location with an Internet connection. We would schedule out the frequency of these coordination workshops along with the agreed processes detailing the methods of collating the models, agreeing file formats, clash rules, and reporting methods as part of a project plan. Perkins&Will also has a platinum subscription contract with Autodesk and we have access to the collaborative platforms that are being currently provided via the BIM 360 suite such as Revit Model Cloud in BIM360 Design, BIM360 Build, and BIM360 Coordinate all supported on top of BIM360 Docs. *** Note ‚Äì Prior to agreeing to use any 3rd party cloud-based collaboration platforms please check with your local DA or reach out to Digital Practice to ensure these products are compatible with our own internal systems.

title: Perkins&Will UK BIM Statement ‚Äì Condensed
content: In the UK the request for a BIM policy statement along with a supplier capability set of questions is becoming a more frequent request as it aligns with the Level 2 Govt procedures. I have drafted this based on the BIM Statement page. Purpose This statement is intended to detail Perkins&Will's firmwide attitude and approach towards BIM methods. This document is reviewed regularly and is circulated to all production staff. BIM Baseline Statement Building Information Modeling (BIM) is fundamental to our collaborative design approach. BIM enables team communication and collaboration, disciplinary integration, and systems coordination. BIM allows us to more fully evaluate design, planning, and performance options; to actively participate in the value analysis of alternative design decisions, and to improve the coordination and quality of our services. Effective design and delivery depend on sound decisions, and our BIM process enables faster, more-informed design-making by our teams and clients. We have been committed to BIM globally since 2006, and during this time, we have delivered hundreds of BIM projects. With a robust technology toolbox and a deep knowledge base, we continue to provide project solutions that efficiently and intelligently address client needs. Our UK operation has been utilizing BIM methods in accordance with the recent industry acceleration and UK Government BIM mandate. Our workflows align with that of the mandate in regard to sharing information on a common platform collaborating to help bring teams together and avoiding rework and uncoordinated information. Commitment We see the intelligent application of technology as the enabler of a high-performing, interdisciplinary design organization. As such, our commitment to BIM starts with our firm's leaders and permeates our organization, down to each team and individual. This document has been authored by our firmwide digital practice team in collaboration with Leadership and approved by our head of Engineering Excellence. The digital practice team possesses a broad understanding of design practice and process, coupled with technical proficiency and significant depth in one or more Digital Practice domains: Digital Project Delivery; Design Computation; Analysis, Simulation & Visualization; and Information Management. Collectively, the team has managed technology, BIM implementation, planning, and execution on some of Perkins&Will‚Äôs largest, most complex projects across all market sectors. Implementing the strategies associated with this document are the responsibility of Digital Practice, local Design Application Managers and project BIM leads. Project leaders are also required to implement this strategy on BIM projects. Project Implementation We emphasize the planning and management of the BIM process throughout the life of the project. Each project has a dedicated BIM Coordinator who works with the project team at project outset to define a project-specific BIM Execution Plan, which clarifies the intended uses of the model, the roles and responsibilities of team members, and the protocols for data exchange between team members. Looking forward, Perkins&Will is pushing our practice beyond BIM‚Äôs baseline as a design, documentation, and collaboration tool because we recognize that the wealth of building, construction, and operational information developed with BIM is highly valuable to our project partners and owners. As such, our approach to Digital Practice facilitates a comprehensive and collaborative project delivery method that begins in project pre-planning and can continue through building operation. Signed by : ? Date : ?

title: Perkins&Will BIM Statement ‚Äì DRAFT

author.name: Nick Cameron
author.description: American trucker who has been featured on the History channel reality television series Ice Road Truckers and its spinoff series IRT: Deadliest Roads.

content: This statement is intended to be a comprehensive, yet modular, statement of Perkins&Will‚Äôs attitude and approach toward BIM. It is a compilation of several documents. It is not intended to be used in its entirety, but rather as a resource that contains language to address a variety of requests. BIM and Design Technology at Perkins&Will Baseline BIM We have established ourselves as industry leaders in BIM by pioneering its adoption and implementation in our design processes. At the heart of our collaborative design approach lies Building Information Modeling (BIM), which enables our teams to communicate and collaborate seamlessly, integrate disciplines, and coordinate systems effectively. With our extensive experience and deep understanding of BIM‚Äôs capabilities, we are able to evaluate design, planning, and performance options thoroughly and engage in value analysis of alternative design decisions. BIM empowers us to improve coordination and service quality, making effective design and delivery possible. Our commitment to innovation and excellence in BIM has been recognized by our peers and clients alike, cementing our reputation as leaders in this field. Philosophy We see the intelligent application of technology as the enabler of a high-performing, interdisciplinary design organization. As such, our commitment to BIM starts with our firm‚Äôs leaders and permeates our organization, down to each team and individual. Looking forward, Perkins&Will is pushing our practice beyond BIM‚Äôs baseline as a design, documentation, and collaboration tool because we recognize that the wealth of building, construction, and operational information developed with BIM is highly valuable to our project partners and owners. As such, our approach to Digital Practice facilitates a comprehensive and collaborative project delivery method that begins in project pre-planning and can continue through building operation. Typical BIM Uses Space Planning: Multiple plan and adjacency configurations are quickly explored to provide the client with options to review and approve during the design phases. Programmatic Prototyping: The model will generate detailed room data sheets used to convey room layouts showing all furniture, fixtures and utilities for the engineers and users to review and approve. This is now live information tied to the actual plans. We can also re-design spaces in real-time with the faculty to make the design process more effective and enjoyable. Site & Context Design: Existing Site Conditions will be modeled so the design can respond to building orientation on the site and context. Site prep, site improvements and utilities are then developed from these conditions at all phases of design. Conceptual Massing: The building massing will be studied in 3D to quickly convey composition and context during the design phases. Design Visualization: Renderings help clients and team better understand the proposed design and are a good resource for fundraising activities. Because the model is ‚Äúlive,‚Äù continually reflecting the latest state of design, renderings it can be easily developed at all phases. Environmental Analysis: Exterior response to daylight, energy consumption and computational fluid dynamic analysis is developed using the model to better inform the engineering systems related to actual energy needs and consumption. We can demonstrate ways to reduce capital and operating cost by use of building elements such as shading devices. Quantity Verification: The model database provides quantities which allow the design team, architects and engineers, to validate scope with the cost estimates and the contractor beginning as early as the first two weeks of the project and throughout the entire design phase. We have also successfully used BIM quantities during bid interviews to confirm scope. The model will be used to generate schedules for all equipment and devices based on the database which eliminates data entry errors. Advanced Collaboration: Frequent exchange of models between architecture and engineering disciplines allows an almost real-time degree of coordination at all times and facilitates QA/QC. With automatic uploads on a defined periodic basis, as often as daily, everyone sees what the other person is developing across the entire team. The model is also shared with the construction manager for better integration between design and construction. The construction team not only uses this information for estimating but more importantly for constructability and sequence of construction input so the design can be improved before it is completed. Perkins&Will and our consultants will work side by side with the CM and prime subcontractors to capitalize on all the attributes the BIM can bring to your project to minimize risk and to provide the best value. Systems and Design Coordination: BIM offers the ability to identify conflicts between modeled building systems and to document and resolve these conflicts during design. This process begins as early as there is sufficient information in the model, usually during design development. This process reduces the amount of RFIs during construction. The most effective approach is to include the design team and construction team in this review to further integrate the team towards holistic and cost-effective solutions. At the conclusion of design the BIM model can be delivered to the construction team to help accelerate the initial phases of contract documents, construction and coordination with their sub-contractors. BIM Planning We emphasize the planning and management of the BIM process throughout the life of the project. At the start of the project, we develop a project-specific BIM Plan, which clarifies the intended uses of the model, the roles and responsibilities of team members, and the protocols for data exchange between team members. When contractors are integrated into the project team, we encourage their participation in the development of the plan. This allows the model to be used jointly by the design and construction teams. The BIM Plan defines the following items: Model use: How the model will be used at each stage of the project‚Äôs design and construction. Levels of development: The level of modeling detail of building components for each phase. Collaboration and communications protocols: The exchange of electronic information and collaboration procedures. Analysis plan: How the model will support other analysis platforms to enable the project team to make informed decisions. Non-graphic data: Specific information including area tabulations, equipment lists, and similar data, to be extracted from the model to inform project team decision-making. Quality assurance: Procedures to ensure the model contains the information appropriate for the design of the project. Technology infrastructure: Hardware, software, and network infrastructure required to execute the plan and maintain the model. Digital Practice and Design Computation Successful BIM relies on people, including proficient project teams and dedicated design-technology specialists. Perkins&Will‚Äôs Digital Practice team works across Perkins&Will‚Äôs projects and practices to enable a high-performing, interdisciplinary design organization and culture through the intelligent and effective application of technology. This team possesses a broad understanding of design practice and process, coupled with technical proficiency and significant depth in one or more of Digital Practice domains: Digital Project Delivery; Design Computation; Analysis, Simulation & Visualization; and Information Management. The Digital Practice team works with project leadership on technology strategy, integrated Building Information Modeling (BIM) and design technology planning, and workflow implementation for design and project execution. Collectively, the team has managed technology, BIM implementation, planning, and execution on some of Perkins&Will‚Äôs largest, most complex projects across all market sectors. Emerging technologies also enable us to creatively address the complexities of the design process by building new tools. Our firmwide network of design computation specialists expands our design teams‚Äô resources beyond the scope of commercially-available software packages. Our ability to engage in parametric modeling, iterative simulation, design optimization, and application customization through scripting and software programming offers our clients‚Äô uniquely agile and attentive design teams. New technological exploration is always anchored by Perkins&Will‚Äôs broad and deep practice expertise. Infrastructure Built for Collaboration Perkins&Will has developed an advanced technology infrastructure to support engagement among our teams, our collaborators, and our clients. In 2009, Perkins&Will designed and implemented internal computational ‚Äúclouds‚Äù that provide the computational power and bandwidth needed to develop and manage large, complex project models and datasets. These secure clouds also play a vital collaborative role at Perkins&Will by creating virtual hubs that allow distributed client, design, and construction teams to meet and work together. This infrastructure makes Perkins&Will uniquely capable of integrating and coordinating large, extended teams that are either physically co-located or geographically distributed. Design Software Our suite of design software includes numerous interoperable applications in addition to our primary BIM authoring application, Autodesk Revit. Additional primary applications include¬† McNeel‚Äôs Rhino 3D for conceptual modeling. We also use a series of support applications and ‚Äúplug-ins‚Äù developed by third-party vendors and our own applications developers. We are actively engaged with major software vendors to inform, test, and in some cases, co-develop the next generation of AEC software applications. Perkins&Will uses advanced analysis tools for energy, daylighting and comfort studies. Honeybee/Ladybug is an environmental plugin for Rhino 3d. Revit geometry is imported into Rhino for analysis in the Honeybee/Ladybug plug-in. Honeybee/Ladybug provides a variety of 3D interactive graphics to support the decision-making process during the initial stages of design. It provides rapid feedback to give architects a stronger understanding of their decisions on energy and cost performance. Honeybee/Ladybug helps architects to understand and optimize the performance of a set of building massing parameters through an energy demand and daylight analysis. Project Information Management Accurate record keeping is crucial to managing design team information, and using technology to communicate, store, and index information efficiently is vital for project success; therefore, we utilize a suite of web-based tools throughout the project lifecycle for communication, decision-making, and teamwork, including project timeline strategy, design coordination, CCA, punchlist, and archival, on both mobile and desktop versions. Advanced BIM Beyond our baseline use of building information modeling for design, documentation, and collaboration, BIM information enables a number of more advanced capabilities from which complex projects can benefit. As part of the planning process for each project, we define with the client a customized approach for using BIM. Some of the advanced uses of BIM include the following: Note: This section needs updating Operations Simulation Modeling Tests and validates design options Evaluates programmatic efficiencies Set-Based Design Methodology Allows concurrent development of multiple design options Allows continuous real-time cost/benefit comparisons Virtual Prototyping Facilitates prefabrication and modularization Standardizes program spaces for operation efficiency Facility Management Supports progressive scheduled maintenance Optimizes operation of building systems Evolution of BIM Much of the recent evolution in our BIM approach has been focused on cultivating a building information ecosystem by aggregating data sources and tailoring information delivery to downstream processes. The original promise of BIM is the creation and management of information rich digital representations of buildings ‚Äî 3d geometrical models containing all of the information necessary for the building design and construction process. Over the course of BIM‚Äôs evolution, a few things have become clear: The information required in the design and construction process exceeds the amount of information that can be easily or efficiently managed through a single BIM authoring application; The information required in planning, programming, and design processes is not exactly the same data needed to fabricate building components or assemble a building, and requires a different approach to information management; A combination of design and construction data, complemented by operational data, is highly valuable to building owners and facilities managers beyond construction. Data-centric delivery Beginning with our healthcare practice, we have created program databases, which represent a ‚Äúsingle source of truth‚Äù for storing and managing information about a facility. These program databases are then linked to other databases that manage medical equipment, furniture, fixtures, mechanical equipment, special construction, as well as design knowledge, all of which are connected with our Building Information Models. The information contained in these databases can be delivered strategically, throughout the life of the project, including into building operations. Post Construction BIM Properly developed, the Building Information Model and ancillary databases becomes an asset that is transferred from phase to phase and built upon as more information is gathered to ultimately help the client to maintain their facilities. Facilities management database practices vary widely from project to project. Some clients prefer a basic spatial database that supports lifecycle assessments for capital investments such as renovations, long or short term planning. Other clients require complete equipment inventories with detailed parameters such as asset numbers, warranty information, and condition assessments. Due to the wide range of potential needs, we work with our clients to identify their unique facilities management data needs and create a clear vision of how they intend to manage their facilities in the future. Design Analytics While many of our practices, have long maintained sophisticated analytical capabilities, we are now also developing new processes for data gathering and analysis, which are proving successful in our planning practices, both at the workplace scale and the campus or urban scale. In one example, we have developed a mobile application that makes polling and data gathering by our workplace team more dynamic and less intrusive. Survey queries can be served individually and strategically, over a broader timeframe, and keyed to locational triggers through bluetooth beacons. This technology allows user polling to be seamlessly integrated into the workplace or urban environment. Using both internally developed and freely available data analysis and visualization resources, we are able to provide a rich source of information and knowledge that improves design decisions, as well as our clients‚Äô operations. Management Intelligence Perkins&Will project teams and firm management all operate across multiple software platforms and applications, for design, delivery, project management, collaboration, communication, human resources, and financial management . Taking queues from business intelligence and analytics, we have been working to extract and federate data across these disparate platforms in order to analyze and view aggregated information. ‚ÄúDashboard‚Äù type data visualizations, which we use to manage our projects and to communicate with our clients, offer insight in to project health, success, progress in terms of our key performance metrics. In addition, it give firm leadership the ability to quickly take data snapshots of the firm‚Äôs operational health. This capability has enabled our leadership and our clients to see and to manage progress in ways never before available. TL;DR Building Information Modeling has been fundamental to Perkins&Will‚Äôs collaborative design approach since 2006. We use BIM to streamline our design and delivery processes, as well as to enable interdisciplinary design coordination, visualization, and analysis to facilitate decisions by the client and design team. Perkins&Will executes BIM projects through a suite of software applications and a collection of supporting tools for conceptual and computational design, energy and environmental analysis, and visualization.

title: Snippets ‚Äì People Mapper
content: Snippets ‚Äì People Mapper This video shows you how to use the people mapper script in Grasshopper. The People Mapper tool allows you to easily place people into your scene. It works by using blocks which will be placed on points that you create on a layer. This way you can avoid people ‚Äòfloating‚Äô above the landscape¬†and quickly create a scene for fx. white renders.

title: Snippets ‚Äì Landscape from Curves
content: Snippets ‚Äì  Landscape from Curves The ‚ÄòLandscape from curves‚Äô tool allows you to generate a landscape from a set of curves (fx. contour lines, roads, etc).  It works by dividing all the lines and connecting the division points with triangles ‚Äì then to make a smooth mesh or surface it projects a grid onto this triangulated mesh.

title: Potential Profit
content: Potential shows profit and multiplier if contingency is not used. Target Multiplier is the factor used to dial up/down your labor Target Labor is a calculation of NSR divided by Target Multiplier calculated Plan NSR is calculated as Potential NSR minus Contingency. calculated Plan NSR is calculated as Potential NSR minus Contingency. Booked NSR If you have already added Consultants to the Team they will be listed here. Otherwise you will be prompted to Add Consultant. Only the Total will be displayed in the main budget view. Contingency Contingency is a percentage of your Potential NSR held in reserve to cover project overruns and salary adjustments. The firm recommends 10% at the beginning of a project and 5%¬† at start of construction. Use 10% Default button to autofill. Plan NSR Plan NSR is the number used to develop the Labor plan. Calculation Plan NSR = Potential NSR ‚Äì Contingency

title: Target Multiplier
content: Target multiplier is a factor used to calculate Target Labor. Target Multiplier is the factor used to dial up/down your labor Target Labor is a calculation of NSR divided by Target Multiplier calculated Plan NSR is calculated as Potential NSR minus Contingency. calculated Plan NSR is calculated as Potential NSR minus Contingency. Booked NSR If you have already added Consultants to the Team they will be listed here. Otherwise you will be prompted to Add Consultant. Only the Total will be displayed in the main budget view. Contingency Contingency is a percentage of your Potential NSR held in reserve to cover project overruns and salary adjustments. The firm recommends 10% at the beginning of a project and 5%¬† at start of construction. Use 10% Default button to autofill. Plan NSR Plan NSR is the number used to develop the Labor plan. Calculation Plan NSR = Potential NSR ‚Äì Contingency

content: Plan NSR is the number used to develop the Labor plan. Plan Multiplier is the Labor is the calculated Plan NSR is calculated as Potential NSR minus Contingency. calculated Plan NSR is calculated as Potential NSR minus Contingency. Booked NSR If you have already added Consultants to the Team they will be listed here. Otherwise you will be prompted to Add Consultant. Only the Total will be displayed in the main budget view. Contingency Contingency is a percentage of your Potential NSR held in reserve to cover project overruns and salary adjustments. The firm recommends 10% at the beginning of a project and 5%¬† at start of construction. Use 10% Default button to autofill. Plan NSR Plan NSR is the number used to develop the Labor plan. title: Understanding the Budget ‚Äì Line by Line
content: Budget Section Groupings

title: Plan NSR
content: Plan NSR is the number used to develop the Labor plan. Update your Booked NSR (Sales) periodically. This must be done manually as sales come in. Contingency is the amount of money held in reserve to cover project overruns and salary adjustments. calculated Plan NSR is calculated as Potential NSR minus Contingency. Booked NSR If you have already added Consultants to the Team they will be listed here. Otherwise you will be prompted to Add Consultant. Only the Total will be displayed in the main budget view. Contingency Contingency is a percentage of your Potential NSR held in reserve to cover project overruns and salary adjustments. The firm recommends 10% at the beginning of a project and 5%¬† at start of construction. Use 10% Default button to autofill. Plan NSR Plan NSR is the number used to develop the Labor plan. Calculation Plan NSR = Potential NSR ‚Äì Contingency

title: Contract Fees & Potential NSR
content: The Contract Fee can be entered from known information, can be developed in stages through guiding wizards, or can be derived from your labor plan. When editing the Contract Fee cell for the first time, you must decide how you want to build your fee using the Fee Model Type chooser . optional Direct Consultants are consultants that we are not reimbursed for. o ptional Direct Expenses are expenses that we will not be reimbursed for. calculated Potenial NSR is calculated as Contract Fees minus Direct Consultants minus Direct Expenses . Direct Consultants If you have already added Consultants to the Team they will be listed here. Otherwise you will be prompted to Add Consultant. Only the Total will be displayed in the main budget view. Tip: Start using a single Generic Consultant if you want to quickly complete your budget. You can always come back later and sub-divide into real Consultant buckets. Direct Expenses In this dialog, estimate your total out of pocket expenses that you do not expect to be reimbursed for. Until you itemize , you will have the single default expense bucket, Miscellaneous Expense Code 639.XX . Itemizing Expenses If you want to itemize your expenses, toggle to ‚ÄòAll‚Äô to see more Expense Codes . Running Total . This number will be displayed and used to calculate Potential NSR in the main budget view. Potential NSR Calculation Potential NSR = Contract Fees ‚Äì Direct Consultants ‚Äì Direct Expenses Fee Model Type

title: Compensation
content: is the amount of money that‚Ä¶ Reimbursable Consultants and Expenses are not required on all projects so these cells are optional. Expand the section heading to add them. The Total Compensation field is calculated by the equation = Contract Fees + Reimbursable Consultants + Reimbursable Expenses Reimbursable Consultants are consultants that we pay out of pocket and expect to be reimbursed for. Finance will invoice Consultants to recover these expenses. Reimbursable Expenses are expenses that we pay out of pocket and expect to be reimbursed for. Finance will invoice Clients to recover these expenses. Reimbursable Consultants In this dialog add as many consultants as needed. If you have already added Consultants to the Team you will see them listed here. Only the Total will be displayed in the main budget view. Tip: Start using a single Generic Consultant if you want to quickly complete your budget. You can always come back later and sub-divide into real Consultant buckets. Reimbursable Expenses In this dialog, estimate your reimbursable out of pocket expenses. Miscellaneous Expense bucket You can enter a single lump sum under the Miscellaneous Expense Code 539.XX . Miscellaneous bucket is the default. However, you can still itemize your expenses . Itemizing Expenses If you want to itemize your expenses, click ‚ÄòAll‚Äô to show all Expense Codes. Running Total . This number will be displayed and used to calculate Total Compensation in the main budget view. Calculations Total Compensation = Contract Fees + Reimbursable Consultants + Reimbursable Expenses

title: Budget Math & Calculation Guide
content: Overview and visual guide to all of the budget calculations in the main budget view.

title: I want to calculate from Labor
Navigating the interface
content: Budget columns ETC, EAC, and JTD (Deltek) Target and Profit These rows relate to your Staffing labor plan. These are collapsed by default. Save Snapshot Test and iterate multiple budget plans and test them against your Staffing labor plan. Show/Hide Columns Use to view your Saved Snapshots or minimize the clutter by hiding columns. Decoding the Budget Columns A. EAC . Estimate at Completion. This is your planned budget. Interact with the cells in this column to build your budget. B. ETC . Estimate to Completion, Is a reporting column of EAC minus JTD. This is the remaining budget. C. Deltek Info Center or JTD Reports all the billing activity from Deltek Vision. This is labor that has occurred and been reported from staff Timesheets.

title: Managing Labor
content: Budget Cards Budget Cards are quick-glance metrics displayed at the top of the Staffing module. They are designed to alert you to the health of the project. Each displaying the latest Vision data as it relates to project labor vs the plan. Hide Budget Cards Sometimes you may need to clear up screen space for planning purposes. Budget Cards are visible by default, but can be hidden by sliding this toggle. Target Labor Budget Card (no budget) Budget Card displays NA until you provide more information in the Budget. Cards will continue to say ‚ÄúTarget‚Äù until the budget approved. Target Labor Budget Card (approved budget) The Target Labor Budget Card may appear full prior to Budget Approval. This is the likely view you are building a ‚Äútop down‚Äù plan where you develop a budget first then staff hours second. In this scenario, your labor bucket is full and shows 100% of the planned bucket available to draw from. As you add hours to your Roles or People, the Labor Budget will reduce. It will go down to 0 to show you balanced. As you add more hours and thus cost and go past your target this will show negative and turn red once you are more than 5% past your target. Approved Labor Budget Card Shows Approved Labor Budget (fixed) vs Planned Labor Budget. The label of this card changes from ‚ÄòTarget‚Äô to ‚ÄòApproved‚Äô after you have submitted your budget and gotten approval. In this example, the Budget has been approved and is set at $153,505. The PM has gotten approval with a top-down plan and now needs to assign all their hours to People or Roles. This project has not assigned more hours for people than the cost allowed in the plan, so the Budget Card appears green. Unbalanced Labor Budget Card In this example, the Budget has been approved and is set at $400,920, but has been over-planned by $26,800. The Budget Card appears White to indicate that the Budget is over budget by less than 5% and to reduce your labor or adjust the plan. Planned Labor is at least 10 % higher than the Approved Labor Budget. Reduce labor drastically or resubmit an adjusted Labor Budget. JTD Labor Budget Card This is a live snapshot of the projects earned revenue through today. It is labor that has already occurred (‚Äúthe past‚Äù). JTD Labor increases as people record their time in Deltek Vision. EAC Labor Budget Card Estimate at Completion. This is the remaining budget to work with and how we expect the project to perform. EAC = JTD + ETC (Actual or ‚Äúthe past‚Äù + Remaining or ‚Äúthe future‚Äù). Profit % Budget Card Profit = (Revenue ‚Äì All Expenses). Measured as a percentage of NSR. Phase Bar Chart Refer to the Phase bars along the top of the Staffing Matrix to help plan hours. Any Milestones added to the Schedule will appear here. Try hovering over a phase bar to see its full name, duration, and percent complete. A Milestone hover state shows date and Notes (if added). Reviewing Rates, JTD, and ETC Expand the HOURS column to see a detailed breakdown of hours billed (JTD), hours planned (ETC) and the persons blended rate (labor cost). Project Role, Studio, and Rate are only visible when viewing Rows of Staff. Note: This information is hidden to most Staff and is made visible by Role based permissions just like Vision. Your rates are not going to be made public. Week Columns The Current Week will be outlined in black. With Previous weeks (JTD) to the left and Future weeks (ETC) to the right. JTD data is reporting from Vision and is read-only. Future hours will be editable. Cell Coloring and Icons The Staffing Module has a lot of color. It is used to draw attention to important project health metrics or to a detail you may have overlooked. Cells from the past (JTD), use conditional formatting to help communicate discrepancies between planned and actual hours. Past Cells (JTD) If a person was planned for hours, you will see the planned number in the bottom left corner. The actual hours billed in Vision will be shown in the center of the cell. In the scenario above, a person was planned to work 4 hours on a project, but did not bill time that week. Non-planned hours billed to project (not planned) In this situation, the team member was planned for zero hours (not planned) and then billed 3 hours to the project. This cell is colored yellow to indicate the person billed slightly over plan. Under-booked Here, the person was planned for 19 hours but billed 22. They are billing more than planned. Increase their labor allotment or reduce labor. Balanced (under) A cell colors blue when actual (billed) hours is less than planned by a factor of 5% or more. Balanced (equal) When actual equals planned we see no colors. Weekly Totals Review the weekly totals for a aggregated view of labor performance. Other Project assignments or PTO Use your mouse to hover over cells while planning. The calendar icon indicates a person is overbooked for that week. They are either planned for other projects or have PTO that week. Click the icon to see the breakdown of hours. Note: PTO hours must be submitted into the Timeoff Hub app for those hours to appear in Staffing. The Planned Hours window showing Matt being overutilized.

title: Filter/Sort/View your Data
content: Filter dropdown The Filter dropdown options depend on your List by toggle setting (previous section). When using these filters your options are All (default) or one filter selection. Use these to view and work with one row of data at a time. This filter will not be available if View by Toggle is set to Role, Studio, or Sub Team. Filter by Staff This Filter is available when Listing by Staff (previous Section). The default setting is All. Use this filter to work with one Person or Role at a time. Filter by Phase This Filter is only available when Listing by Phase (previous Section). The default setting is All. Use this filter to work with one Person or Role at a time. Sort by Toggle Changes the sort order of the list. Available Sorting options: ‚Ä¢ First Name (default) ‚Ä¢ Studio ‚Ä¢ Rate Ascending ‚Ä¢ Rate Descending ‚Ä¢ Current Week Ascending ‚Ä¢ Current Week Descending ‚Ä¢ Next Week Ascending ‚Ä¢ Next Week Descending View by Toggle The View by Toggle helps you customize your view of the Labor plan even more. View by Team (default) You will use this View by mode most of the time. Staffing is a people focused task so that is why this is the default. In this View mode you will see actual Perkins&Will staff members and placeholder Roles. View by Role Focused on viewing just Roles of People and placeholder Roles. In this mode, expand Roles to see associated People. When Viewing by Role, the Filter and Sort dropdowns will become unavailable. View by Studio Focused on viewing just Studios. In this mode, expand Studio to see associated People. When Viewing by Studio, the Filter and Sort dropdowns will become unavailable. View by Sub Team If you have a large team and want to organize your team members into custom groups, you can create Sub Teams in the Teams module. You must first assign your team members to Sub Teams to view them in Staffing. Date Range Filter When you first land on the Staffing module page, the date range will show the previous two weeks (from today) and the end date will be the project end date. If you edit the date range then navigate away from the page, the page resets to default.

title: Changing your view
content: Staff or Phase You can switch between viewing rows of People (Staff) and Phases. Note: All features related to Phases will become activated when a project Schedule has been completed. View Staff (default) Lists People and Roles as rows. Expanding a Person (or Role) shows a breakdown of hours by Phase*. View Phases* Lists Phases as rows. Expanding a Phase shows a breakdown of hours by People. Active/All People toggle Toggles between listing just Active people (default) or All. Listing by All will display people who are no longer on the project or those who have left the firm. This is to maintain an accurate project history.

title: Managing Roles
content: There are similar management options for Roles. Manage Roles by using the ellipses icon ( . . . ) next to the Role name. Move hours to another role Moving hours subtracts from the first selection and adds them to the second selection. First, select the Role whose hours you want to move from and click the ( . . . ) Then select the Role you are moving hours to. No hours are lost; only shifted. Designer I role remains in the project. Move hours to another person Moving hours subtracts from the first selection and adds them to the second selection. First, select the person whose hours you want to move and click the ( . . . ) Then select the person who you are moving hours to. This simply moves Designer III‚Äôs planned hours over to Jordan. Designer III stays in the project and all future hours reset to zero. Fill The fill option is a quick way to change hours for a single Role. Assign hours per week for each phase. Or use the filter dropdown to focus on one phase at a time. The hours will be distributed automatically after submitting. Set the hours per week by phase. The Fill menu has a memory for each Role. If you accidentally clear all the hours for a role you can recover the hours by using Fill. You can focus on one phase at a time using the filter dropdown. Remove Role Removing a person from the team is a delete and will remove all future planned hours. You will not be allowed to delete a Team member if they have any JTD hours billed and will only be able to Make Inactive. Only Remove from Team if they were mistakenly added and not planned to work on the project. You will have a chance to confirm. Important: Removing a Role will remove all its planned hours. You cannot make a Role Inactive. As a best practice, move hours to a person first, then Remove Roles from the project to keep your Staffing Matrix free of unnecessary rows. Remove all Future Planned Hours Removes all Future hours only. Roles only have future hours. You will have a chance to confirm. Tip: If you mistakenly remove hours, you can refill a person‚Äôs hours by using the fill tool‚Äôs memory (see above).

title: Managing Staff
content: Manage staff using the ellipses icon next to a persons name ( . . . ) Move hours to another person Moving hours subtracts from the first selection and adds them to the second selection. First, select the person whose hours you want to move and click the ( . . . ) Then select the person who you are moving hours to. This simply moves Brian‚Äôs hours over to David. Brian stays in the project and his hours reset to zero across the board. Move hours to another role You must have Roles added to your project to use this option. First, select the person you want to move hours from. Then select the Role to move hours to. Fill The fill option is a quick way to change hours for a single person. Assign hours per week for each phase. Or use the filter dropdown to focus on one phase at a time. The hours will be distributed automatically after submitting. Set the hours per week by phase. The Fill menu has a memory for each Person or Role. If you accidentally clear all the hours for a person or role, you can recover the hours by using Fill. You can focus on one phase at a time using the filter dropdown. Other Projects See the list of projects that a person is a Team Member of. This only means they are part of the Project Team, and not that they have been planned hours (see Planned Hours cell). Select a project from the list to go to its Hub site. Opens a list of Hub projects. Remove all Future Planned Hours Removes all Future hours only. Past hours (JTD) cannot be deleted. You will have a chance to confirm. Tip: If you mistakenly remove hours, you can refill a person‚Äôs hours by using the fill tool‚Äôs memory (see above). Make Inactive Apply the Inactive status to people who were on the project but are no longer active. This will retain any planned hours so do not use this option if you are trying to reduce your labor cost. Use this when a person is no longer planned or billing hours to the project. This keeps them in the project record but helps to clear up the Staffing Matrix from showing unnecessary blank rows. Inactive person appearance in Team module. Remove from Team Removing a person from the team is a delete and will remove all future planned hours. You will not be allowed to delete a Team member if they have any JTD hours billed and will only be able to Make Inactive. Only Remove from Team if they were mistakenly added and not planned to work on the project. You will have a chance to confirm.

title: Navigating the interface
content: Vision Resource Planning is being discontinued. Project Managers will be required to plan and assign hours to their team in the Staffing module of the Project app moving. Timesheets will still be done in Vision for all staff. All actual JTD (Job to Date) hours will be fed into the Project app from Vision at a scheduled frequency. Quick Fill Use Quick Fill to quickly update all staff labor for an entire phase or person instead of manually entering hours week by week. Filters Use the filters to focus on a single phase or a single staff member. Lock All Using Quick Fill means you are making broad changes to your labor plan. The cells are locked by default to prevent accidental changes. Unlock Staff Unlock an individual team member to make changes to only their hours. Clear All Use the Clear All button to remove all planned hours. Warning: This resets each week to zero. There is no undo button for this action. It is suggested that you only use this feature during project planning or prior to budget approval. If you need to clear a whole phase Add Role Roles are used to plan your project without real people. They are designed to be swapped with a real person at a future time. They will retain all previously planned hours and simply give them to a Team Member. Note: you may see a labor cost difference after replacing with a real person. This is because Roles use blended labor rates, where people have fixed rates. Roles are defined by Studio, so the dropdown will only show you Roles from that person‚Äôs home Studio. Add Person Use the + Add Person button to add an internal team member to the project. Use the search and select the person. This list is from the People app and is only contains internal staff. Adding a Role or assigning to¬†the Core Team is optional and can be done from the Add Person dialog. This adds a simple tag next to their name in the Project Team module. Core Team is an organizational label and has no implications on labor cost.

title: Table
content: Viewing the phases as a table displays more text and dates. This view makes it easy to precisely edit Phase Type, Start Date, Duration (weeks) and complete work percentage. The Table view is broken into 3 sections, Staffing Phases, Non-Staffed Phases, Milestones. Non-Staffed Phases Phases that are independent of the schedule or staffing. Milestones are listed below all phases in this view.

title: Calendar
content: Displays all your schedule in a traditional calendar format. Filtering and Viewing Set your view scale to Month, week, or day The navigation arrows will jump you forward and backward based on your view scale. For example, if your view scale is set to ‚ÄúWeek‚Äù the navigation arrows move you forward/backward one week. Filter by Event Tag Selecting a Tag will show you Events with that tag only and hides all other items. You can select both tags at once. Calendar Icons

title: Gantt
content: Gantt visualization displays Phases as bars on a chronological timeline. The interface allows you to easily stretch the phases by clicking and dragging either the beginning or end point. Linked phases are controlled by Phase Dependency and is displayed with an arrow connecting the graphic bars. It means that the phase will only begin after the previous (‚Äúthe parent‚Äù) one ends. Stretching or shortening one end will affect all the future phases as well. Be sure to check your budget if your schedule phases change in any way. Unlinking phases allows you to create gaps or overlapping phases. Stretching or shortening one phase shouldn‚Äôt affect the following ones once the parent link is broken. To unlink a phase, click the connecting arrow between phases and choose ‚ÄúUnLink‚Äù. To unlink a phase, click the connecting arrow between phases and choose ‚ÄúUnLink‚Äù. Linking of Phases is controlled by Phase Dependency in the Edit Phase panel.

title: Events
content: Events are designed to work inside the Project app Calendar only. There is currently no connection to your Outlook calendar. They can be single meeting time or multi-day events and can be tagged. Add Event Add an Event from the button here Or hover over the Day in the Calendar and click the + Fill out the event info from the Add Event panel Meetings and Deadlines These are tags that can be assigned to an Event for organization and filtering. Meetings on the Calendar appear with an Event icon and are colored Green. Deadlines on the Calendar appear with an Event icon and are colored Red Review Event Details and Edit by clicking on it in the Calendar.

title: On Hold
content: Placing your project On Hold is a flexible Status. It flags Finance and locks certain features of the app. A project can be identified as being on hold by the Status badge To place your project on hold, go to the Actions dropdown. This action can only be done by members of the Core Team . Specify the start of the hold. Default is always today‚Äôs date, but you can choose a day in the future. Then choose to set the duration in weeks or specify the end date. If you specify duration (weeks) the end date automatically calculates. The other option is to select the actual end date to the day. Your Schedule view will display the hold as a vertical gray bar overlay. If you are in a Hold, you can extend or reduce the length of the hold by clicking on the gray bar. <screenshot> To remove the Hold, go back to the Actions dropdown and select Restart Project. Then select ‚ÄòYes‚Äô and set the Stage from the dropdown.

title: Quick Update
content: This tool is in the Actions dropdown. Once your schedule has been started you will no longer be able to bulk load phases using a template or from another project. You can still quickly edit phases in one view by using Quick Update.

title: Milestones
content: Mark single dates in time by adding Milestones. Once created, they appear on the timeline as red diamond icons with a dashed vertical line. Milestones seen on the Gantt chart Because Milestones are single dates in time they can be thought of as simple, custom labels. They have no dependencies to phases and are markers to use as needed. They can be moved forward or backward in time, at any point in the project. Use them for target dates like pencils down, QA/QC quality pauses, or reminder to complete Living Design reporting. Milestones do not connect to Outlook emails so be sure to create any calendar items manually. Milestones seen in Table view Milestones seen in the Calendar view (yellow)

title: Navigating the interface
content: A project can have only one schedule. Schedules consist of 3 main components: Phases, Un-Staffed Phases, and Milestones.

title: Add/Edit Phases manually
content: Add/Edit Phases Manually You can add phases manually at any point of the project. To manually add a new phase, click +Add and fill in the popped-up window with Phase Name and Short Code. Then set from the drop-down menus the Phase Dependency (whether it will be parent linked or not), phase type (design, construction, etc.), fee type (lump sum, hourly, etc.). Set Start or End Date, type in the date in the correspondent field and set the phase duration in weeks. You can also add the percentage of completed work, choose the phase color, and add tags. If the staffing page is set, it will return to you the amount of planned hours and cost and the actual hours and cost already spent on the project. Name Click in the search bar and select from preloaded phase names. However, phase names can be custom. Type what you want then select +Add. You can also assign an abbreviated Short Code name. If starting from a phase template all the names and Short Codes will be prefilled. Phase Dependency (Linked) When you want your phase to start at the end of a previous phase, set the phase dependency. Phase Type Phase Type is mostly used as an organizational label. Best viewed from the Table view where it appears as a data column. Phase Type options are Design, Construction, and Other. If selecting Other, you will not be able to use Phase Dependency. Phase Type ‚ÄòOther‚Äô Phases designated as Other behave differently from Design and Construction types. They do not have phase dependency and live in their own swim lane of the Gantt chart. Fee Type Each phase can have its own Fee type and can be independent of the project budget fee type. Lock End Date This is different from Phase Dependency. Locking the end date of a phase will freeze the end date entry field. A locked end date will be identified by the Red pad lock icon when hovering over the phase. Use this feature to secure your schedule from accidental changes. Include in Staffing Most phases are labor based so this option is checked yes by default. This lets a phase appear in the Staffing module for planning. Do not Include in Staffing Use this option for creating Non-Staffed Phases. Some examples are Bidding or AHJ Review or when we are not incurring labor costs or have different fee structures. If you uncheck this box, your options will be reduced. You no longer have the option for Phase Dependency. And the phase does not appear in the Staffing module. Since these phases do not show up in Staffing, you must view them from the Table or Calendar view of the Schedule. It is recommended that these phases also be classified as Phase Type ‚ÄòOther‚Äô for organizational purposes.
