Start / End Date Each Phase requires you to select either the start OR end date, and then the duration in weeks. The other date will be automatically calculated for you. Weeks are the smallest planning unit within the Project app. Note: The Project app will not allow picking the start AND end date. The entire finance industry works on firmly established weekly cycles. We aim to simplify the whole experience of planning by reducing complexity. Work Percent Complete Because labor production does not directly correlate to weeks complete, this field must be manually set by the PM. The bars on the Gantt chart graphically display phase completion. Weeks Complete / Weeks Remaining These are automatically calculated from the Duration on either side of the Current Day. Notes Only appears in the Gantt chart. Hover over a phase to see any Notes added. Financials Displays a snapshot of the ETC and JTD numbers. You must have a Budget approved for the ETC data to appear. JTD will display any time a person reports hours to Vision. Phase Color You can change the color of the phases. Tip: Building a schedule from a template will load pre-colored phases. Deltek Phase IDs* For Finance and administrative use only. This is how your Project app phases are mapped to Deltek Vision phases. Once these have been established they can only be changed by Finance.

title: Building a Schedule
content: When setting up a new project, you can start a schedule by choosing one of the options below. Phases are required before a labor plan can be approved by Finance. If you select any of the first three options, you will not be able to go back and select another method. The only exception to this is the Add Milestone tool. Choose from Template Template Schedules import standard phases organized by professional organizations of each country. You can choose an imported template or a general (single-phased) one. Select a Template from the dropdown, then add the start date and the planned duration in weeks. Phases in each Template AIA ‚Ä¢ Programming ‚Ä¢ Schematic Design ‚Ä¢ Design Development ‚Ä¢ Construction Documents ‚Ä¢ Bid ‚Ä¢ Construction Administration RIBA ‚Ä¢ One ‚Ä¢ Two ‚Ä¢ Three ‚Ä¢ Four Nelson\Nygaard ‚Ä¢ One ‚Ä¢ Two ‚Ä¢ Three ‚Ä¢ Four Planning & Strategies ‚Ä¢ One ‚Ä¢ Two ‚Ä¢ Three ‚Ä¢ Four General ‚Ä¢ General (custom) Import from Project This option allows you to duplicate a schedule from an existing Project. The Project you are importing from must have a schedule created for this option to work.

title: Project Team
content: The project team can be entered manually from the Team module. A person can be added manually by anyone including themselves. They will also be listed if they bill any time to the project number in Deltek. Starting / Create Project The Managing Principal and Project Manager will already be selected. This happens during the initial project setup using the button from the Project Browse page. Import from other Project ‚Äì Building your Team quickly The quickest way to build your team is from an existing team. Use the Actions dropdown menu to Import from another project . Quick Update ‚Äì Building your Team from scratch If you don‚Äôt have an existing project to import from, use Quick Update from the menu. Inside the Quick Update tool, you will notice some team members are already filled out. The Managing Principal and Project Manager will already be assigned during the Create Project process and will appear as read-only. Design Principal will be available to assign here ‚Äì the team member ultimately responsible for the design outcome of the project. CELs at our firm are ‚ÄúClient Engagement Leaders‚Äù ‚Äì assign these here, as well. Use the + Add Member button to add the remaining members under Team. This allows you add multiples in quick succession. Click +Add Member Search by typing their name. Select the name. Click Submit *Tip* ‚Äì if somebody is already on your team, they will not show up in the Add Members dropdown. If you cannot find them on your Project Team page, try getting rid of the preselected filters. Organizing your Team Placeholder Roles If you do not have a labor plan yet, use a placeholder to identify and add hours for people you believe you will need but don‚Äôt know specifically who yet. These roles (i.e., Designer II) can be replaced with real paper later, who then take on the hours you have planned for this role. These roles will appear in the PMTK Staffing tab. Click Unassigned Roles under the Actions dropdown Click Add Role in the top right corner Select your desired Studio, Rate Level, and Project Role(s) Click Submit *insert pic* Use Sub Teams to place team members into custom buckets. This is a simple label for organization purposes only. It does not correlate to a person‚Äôs title or role and can be different on each project. Sub Teams will sort alphabetically by default. For custom sorting, use the number sort parameter. Use Roles to define what a person will be doing or contributing to the project. This is also different from the person‚Äôs HR title. Roles are simple organizational labels to help to better organize and visualize your team in the Staffing module. Roles are optional. Roles do not have any impact on labor cost. Editing your Team Edit an individual Project Team member‚Äôs details by clicking on their profile photo in the list of team members. Edit Member Team Members who are classified as Managing Principal and Project Manager are automatically assigned to the Core Team during Create Project process. These will be read only for most Project app users and can only be changed by Finance admins after initial setup. All other Team Members can be assigned a Role, made Active/Inactive, and be assigned to the Core Team. Add Roles Predefined labels for organization. Roles available to assign: CEL Design Principal Interior Designer Other Project Architect Project Coordinator Project Designer Technical Coordinator Planner Sustainability Landscape Architect Urban Designer Design Team Currently Active There is no deleting a person from the Project app. If they have worked on the project and billed hours in Vision they will be locked in the project indefinitely to maintain an accurate project history. The alternative is to make a Team Member Inactive. Uncheck the box ‚ÄúCurrently Active‚Äù in the Edit Member panel. This hides them from all modules but can be seen with filters. A person who has left the firm will automatically be made Inactive. Core Team The Core Team is comprised of the Managing Principal, Project Manager, Design Principal, and all CELs. The Core Team is meant to denote project leadership, however, additional members can be added manually in the Edit Member panel. They can be identified by the ‚ÄúCore Team‚Äù badge ¬†next to their name in the Team list. Viewing your Team Active/All People toggle Toggles between listing just Active people (default) or All. ¬†Listing by All will display people who are no longer on the project or those who have left the firm. This is to maintain an accurate project history. When viewing All, any Inactive staff will appear black and white. Their planned and actual hours remain intact so you can address your labor plan. Core Team By default, you will see All team members listed. Toggling on Core Team filter allows will show only those who have been assigned the Core Team tag. Reference the Team help document for steps on how to assign this tag. The Managing Principal, Project Manager, and Design Principal for your project will automatically be assigned to the Core Team. Group by Project Role By default, the Team will be grouped under Project Role headings. The sort order for Project Roles: Leadership (Managing Principal, Project Manager, Design Principal, and all CELs) Other Project Architect Project Coordinator Project Designer Technical Coordinator Planner Landscape Architect Urban Designer Team (have not been assigned a Role) Group by Studio You can choose to view your team by studio. This view setting will group all team by Studio and sort them by the Studio with the most staff (not alphabetically). If two studios share the same number of people, the next sorting method is number of Core Team members. Team Member count Displays the total number of staff members in your project. Team Display view By default, the Team page displays as a list view. Change the Team display view to Grid for a more presentation-ready page. Quick Glance ‚Äì Staff Labor burn This bar chart is only visible in the List view. The value on the left indicates the total number of hours a person has billed to the Project from Vision. The value on the right indicates the total number of hours planned. Use these charts to identify team members who are approaching their allotment and make adjustments to fee or reduce labor. Actual (JTD)¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† ¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Planned (EAC) In this situation, this team member was only planned to work 86.5 hours, but worked and billed 144 hours. The chart does not change color or loudly indicate that they are over budget. Contact your Team There are three options available. Start a Chat in Teams Clicking the message icon will launch MS Teams and start a chat with the individual. Start a Call in Teams Clicking the phone icon will launch your web browser and ask you to select a calling app. You may see a notification in Chrome like this, choose ‚ÄòPick an app.‚Äô Next select MS Teams to ‚ÄòAlways‚Äô be your calling app. Start and Email in Outlook Clicking the e-mail icon will launch your Outlook and start a draft to that person.

title: Request Deltek Number Wizard
content: Request Deltek Number Another Wizard that is used to define all Finance-specific information. There are 14 required fields to submit. Click the Request Deltek Number button to start the process. Note: This wizard allows you to leave and return to complete later. There are 7 screens with a total of 14 required fields. These will be annotated with a red *. Click Next or Previous to navigate forward/backward or bounce between sections by clicking the titles on the left side. Tip (optional): In the Billing Information tab, use the Notes field to communicate specifics about your billing/your fee. Finish Click the Submit for Request button to submit to your Studio Finance team. Finance Next Steps At this stage, your Studio Finance team will see your request in the Deltek Sync Management Hub app. In this app, Finance Managers are assigned, information can be revised, or additional information provided prior to issuing the Deltek Number. Deltek Request Status Once Submitted Look for an incoming email confirmation. Once at the ‚ÄúRequested‚Äù status the Wizard will disappear, and the ball is in Finance‚Äôs court. You will receive another email once the Deltek number has been ‚ÄúCreated.‚Äù You can also verify that a number has been assigned in the Project Info card. Please coordinate directly with your Studio Finance Team to resolve any issues related to pending Deltek numbers.

title: Navigating the interface
content: The Project Info Center module is where we capture all the required project information. You can edit the individual tiles, but the fastest way to enter information is by using the Wizard (10). Basic Details . Project Client, Project Name, Deltek Number, Primary Studio, Practice, Discipline, Project Type, Status, Stage, Project Category, and Currency. Studios & Practices . This information comes from Deltek during project set up. Description . Long format text field. Add a paragraph describing your project in your own words. Project Keywords . Select all that apply. Location . Choose the location of your project using the embedded Google Maps viewer. Facts . Define the project a little more. Enter the Practice/Discipline, Building Type, Scope, and Delivery Type. Size . Add multiple lines and set primary to describe the work area. Units in Imperial or Metric. Budget . Add multiple lines and set a primary. Functionality for multiple currencies. Dates. Design and Construction Start & End dates. Top Bar . Under the Actions dropdown, use the Project Info Wizard to quickly fill out all the required project information from one interface. It will keep track of your progress and allow you to return to complete later. This dropdown also gives the ability to put your project on hold and submit FIR. You can locate this info page, and other Hub info manuals, using the Help button. The percentage bar will keep track of your project completion. Team Leadership Snapshot. Managing Principal and Project Manager, which are assigned in Deltek, will be displayed here. Design Principal can be selected with the edit button. Links . Custom per project. Enter all the links related to the project so your team can find them in one place.

title: Wizards
content: Wizards are implemented across Hub to organize key fields for particular workflows. Opening and filling out a wizard is beneficial for timesaving and ensuring you don‚Äôt miss filling out any essential information.

title: Project Info Wizard
content: Project Info Wizard You will land in the Info Center module immediately after creating a project. The Project Info Progress Bar will display that you have already provided 95% of the required info from the initial Create Project setup. Use the Wizard to guide you to 100%. When in the wizard, click Next or Previous to navigate forward/backward or bounce between sections by clicking the titles on the left side. You may not have all the information yet, so you can revisit this area and complete it later. The wizard contains 5 tabs with a total of 13 fields. After filling the entirety of the wizard, selecting the Finish button will auto-fill the fields on the Info Center, and you have officially undergone a strong start to your project.

title: Project interface
content: Project Info Card Module Navigation panel Back button ‚Äì returns you to the Project Browser Inside of a project the interface shows the same Project Info card stacked on top of the Module Navigation panel. The site is optimized for desktop, but if viewing from a phone or tablet you will see a button that allows you to expand and collapse this menu. Project Info Card This is the same card you see on the Project browser page. Always on top, consistently visible in all modules and throughout the app experience. Module Navigation panel Use this navigation panel to bounce around to different areas of the same project. Back button The Project app icon will navigate you back to Project browser page from anywhere in the app ‚Äì just hover over it, and a back arrow will appear. If you need to stay in the project but go back one page, use the back button in your web browser.

title: Create Project
content: Create Project All projects will start out in the Pipeline app as an opportunity or a direct select and then needed to be converted to a won project. Once the project is converted, a Deltek number can be requested from Finance (steps below). Please note that marking a project as Won does not automatically request a Deltek number. FOR EXISTING PIPELINE OPPORTUNITY Go to the Pipeline App . Use the filters and Search to see if the opportunity already exists. Tip: make sure you have the view toggle set to ‚ÄòAll‚Äô From the Pipeline browser view, click on the opportunity, click on the Won on the Opportunity Info page. On the popup that will show up, select Show this opportunity in the Project App. Go to the Project App . Use the filters and Search to see if the opportunity already exists. Tip: make sure you have the view toggle set to ‚ÄòAll‚Äô Suggested next step: Use the Project Info Wizard in the Actions drop down in the upper right to fill out the project info. NEW PROJECT WITH STREAMLINED PIPELINE OPPORTUNITY Go to the Pipeline App . On the main page, choose Add Direct Select from the Add dropdown in the upper right corner. Fill out the required information and confirm by clicking the Submit button in the lower right corner. Choose Open in Projects in the popup. Suggested next step: Use the Project Info Wizard in the Actions drop down in the upper right to fill out the project info. TO REQUEST A PROJECT NUMBER Go to the Info Center page for your project Use the Request Deltek Number button on the Actions dropdown in the top right corner to start Navigate through the sections and answer all required information Click Submit for Request . That‚Äôs it! You can continue using the Project app like normal. Finance will receive the request in our Deltek Sync Management app where the connection to Deltek is made.

title: Search, Filter, View, & Sorting
content: Search bar Tips: The search function defaults sort order to be the highest matching results, similar to Google‚Äôs PageRank algorithm If searching by Project Number, search using the first 6 digits Using quotation marks around your search will look for exact matches Filter tools The default selection is ‚ÄòMy,‚Äô which will display any project you are a part of. Switch to ‚ÄòFav‚Äô to see projects that you‚Äôve starred as favorites or to ‚ÄòAll‚Äô to see projects that you are not a part of. Tip: You can see all the projects that someone is on from their profile in the People app . Clicking into someone‚Äôs profile, navigate to the Projects tab on the left. Here, you are able to filter for someone‚Äôs project history. View Modes Change the way projects appear in the Browser. Respectively, the three options are: Fit View (default) Fit is designed for maximum card visibility. You will see the full card when a Featured Image has been uploaded to your project. If there is no image, the card will condense to just the text information. List View Lists out projects as data rows. Stack View Displays projects in a card view, similar to Fit View, but gives the choice to expand cards to view related projects when those have been assigned. Sorting Sorting options: Name* Created Date** Updated Date** Stage Status Deltek Number** Primary Practice** Total EAC Compensation** * Only Ascending ** Ascending and Descending

title: Modules
content: Modules are separate pages in the Project app. Each one contains different tools and capabilities for specific tasks. Module visibility depends on the project requirements and an individual‚Äôs role permissions. Some modules are nested. For example, the PMTK contains 5 individual modules specific to the Project Management tasks. Some modules activate once a piece of information is added. For example, the AreaSync module which is nested under Performance appears only after adding a link to the AreaSync PowerBI dashboard in the Info Center. The Module Navigation panel is accessible from the left-hand side of the user interface and stays on top in all areas of the app. For smaller resolutions, you may see this Module Navigation disappear. In this case, you will see a button in the bottom left to expand module visibility. List of currently active modules in the Project app: Home (beta) Info Center Team Project Team Client Team Consultant Team Extended Team Design Storyboard Design Drivers Design Reviews Other Design Info Miro Board (Activates when a Miro Board link is added) PMTK Schedule Budget Staffing Details By Phase Contracts Cash Management (beta) RAMP Performance AreaSync (Activates when an AreaSync link is added) 2030 Challenge Marketing Awards, Certs & Media Coverage Settings

title: Launchpad
content: ‚ÄúThe Launchpad‚Äù is the start screen for the Perkins&Will Hub ecosystem. It is a collection of our internally developed business applications. On the left of the page, you will see a list of predetermined groups that you could use to find the apps. We have put all our apps into their categories.You can use this if you would like and just pin one of those groups as your starting point when you come to Hub. You will also notice when you hover over any of the apps that there is a star in the upper left corner that allows you to favorite apps. You can use this with the favorites grouping and make that your default start point if you would like. The search still exists at the top right to type an app name and hit return to find it. Expect to see our app library grow.

title: Project Browser
content: From the Project Browser you see a list of projects identified as ‚Äúcards.‚Äù Each card represents a project, and each project will be associated with a single Deltek number. We aim to have a one-to-one project to Deltek¬† data stream. They can be created at any stage and can appear in multiple apps of Hub as they advance towards completion. For example, a project may start as a marketing pursuit in Pipeline. Once it is awarded its status changes to Active and will now appear in the Project app where a Deltek number can be assigned. Project Cards These cards display only important high-level information. Featured Image, Primary Client, Project Name, Project Number, Studio & Practice, Discipline, Project type, Status, and Stage. These parameters will largely be unchanged through the course of the project and will appear read-only in many areas of the app. Once established these can only be changed by Finance. Cards display differently when changing the view mode. Project type Projects must be classified as Small, Large, or Related to another project. The cutoff between Small and Large is typically $50,000. If your project is for $50,000 or less, it is considered Small, and we do not require building a plan or submitting an approved budget. You will still need to request a project number. If you do select Small as your project type, you will be able to set up PMTK basics with schedule and contract fee, so you do not have to enter PMTK to do it. Deltek Statuses Status can be manually changed by individuals with Project Manager role permissions.¬† If a project pursuit was started in the Pipeline app and was awarded it becomes Active.¬† Once Active, the project appears in the Project app. Stages There are 7 pre-defined Stages to choose from: Pending Start, Design, Completed ‚Äì Design only, Under Construction, On Hold, Completed ‚Äì Unbuilt, and Completed ‚Äì Built.

title: Settings
content: If you see this tab in your project, that means you are a Project Admin ‚Äì either you are the Managing Principal or Project Manager of the project, or you have been added as a PMTK Admin by one of the two. If you do not see this tab, and you believe you should, talk to your project leaders. They will be able to able to add you from the Settings page. The Features section of the Settings page gives you the ability to check project pages on and off. All projects start with all boxes checked (in other words, all pages showing). If your project has no need for a certain page, uncheck that box. If you would like to lock down your Budget and Staffing after completion, open the Schedule Budget Staffing Editable sidesheet and check the box to make it read-only. To toggle your Staffing between Cost Rate and Bill Rate, open that tab and switch the toggle, and you will see those changes automatically reflected across your project. The only place you will not see this change reflected is on the Budget page ‚Äì the Budget page is always Cost Rate because of how our Finance Team runs their numbers. The Permissions section is where you are able to add Additional PMTK Admins to your project. You have the ability to add any team member to this section ‚Äì once added, they will be able to see and do everything that a Project Manager is able to. If your project is on a need-to-know basis, even within our firm, you can mark it as Confidential for everyone except the project team and security groups.

title: Marketing
content: Awards, Certs & Media Coverage The Marketing tab on Project is where Project awards, certifications, and any media coverage live. To add any of the three to your project, hover over the words of what you‚Äôre looking to add, and you will see a ‚Äò+ Add‚Äô button appear. This will pop open a sidesheet for your input of the information. When filling out this sidesheet, keep in mind that this is calling for the specific name of the award, institution, and/or closest to the exact date. For any media coverage, enter the exact publication link, the name of the article, the name of the news organization that covered the story, the exact publication date, and ensure you check the Cover Story checkbox if it was one. If an actual PDF was shared with you, feel free to upload that. Continue to scroll to tag the specific employee that was interviewed or include a summary statement. When adding any third-party certifications, when you select a Rating System, you will be presented with subsequent Category and Version options in those dropdowns if that Rating System has any. The Certification Status field is looking for your current status; select Pursuing when you are actively seeking to achieve it; select Registered when it has been submitted after the project; if the certification has been officially approved, select Certified. Selecting any one of these options will present other fields in the sidesheet. If you have selected Certified, please update your scoring and/or proof of certification if you have those files on hand. These can be an email file, if necessary. If any options are not available, please reach out to firm Living Design leaders.

title: Performance
content: 2030 Challenge Note that much of the information on the 2030 Challenge page is pulled in from the Info Center page of the project. However, a lot of the information remains editable. When editing the Details section of the page, ensure that a Tag is shown as black in the sidesheet ‚Äì this means that it is currently selected. If a tag is shown in gray, it is currently unselected. When selecting ASHRAE Climate Zone and Energy Code from their dropdowns, these are the only options that AIA 2030 accepts ‚Äì the list is exhaustive. Click the arrow¬†logo next to Design Drivers to navigate to that page of your project. Ensure that you fill all Design Drivers fields out, as this is necessary for 2030 Challenge completion. Ensure you have denoted your primary size area in the Size section by checking the Primary checkbox in the sidesheet. The primary size area is shown with an orange star. Finally, double check that your Studios & Practices are accurate. If something seems inaccurate, contact your local Finance Team to make any necessary changes in Deltek. For more information on 2030 Challenge itself, go to the 2030 Challenge and Commitment page in the Living Design Toolkit.

title: PMTK-RAMP
content: The Risk Assessment Management Program (RAMP) helps us identify projects we are undertaking that have elevated levels of Ethical, Financial, Legal, and Professional risk versus the average project. All projects should be aware that they operate under normal levels of risk and still need to be properly managed and maintained.¬† The RAMP page is not visible to everybody in our firm or even all team members ‚Äì it is only visible to Project Admins (listed on the Settings page).

title: PMTK-Contracts
content: The Contracts page serves three main purposes : Requesting draft contract reviews from our in-house Legal Department Facilitating the e-signature process Storing executed project contracts with clients and sub-consultants The lefthand side of the Contracts page contains the Primary Client information ‚Äì this is directly pulled from who is listed as the client on the Client Team page within the project. On the Contracts page, you can upload any contracts you have with your Primary Client and designate which contract is the Prime Contract. When the signed final contract has been marked as Executed and is uploaded, it will then relate back to RAMP. This lets the firm know that we have an executed contract with this client, on this project. Other files that could show up in this area are files that get added to Add Services in the Budget page. The righthand side of the page contains Sub Consultant information ‚Äì this is directly pulled from the Consultant Team page (those consultants that are listed) and the Budget page (Direct and Reimbursable information). Each consultant has their own card with their name and Direct/Reimbursable designation. If the consultant has an active MSA with your studio, an MSA button will appear on that consultant card, as well. You can upload as many contracts for any single consultant as you‚Äôd like. When you expand a consultant card with the arrow button, you‚Äôll see that this is where you upload your yearly COI ‚Äì you need these from every consultant for their professional coverage specific to this project. Each card will have either a green checkmark or a red X based on the COI‚Äôs current status. Request Client/NDA Contract Review Insert photo here.

title: Design
content: Storyboard Opening Storyboard, you‚Äôll notice that the tab is organized into boards which can contain multiple media resources. Every board has a status, Active or Archived, to help manage historical data. There is one featured board per project that shows up on the Home Page of the project and the card view of the Design Management app. Storyboard does not hold the Hero Image ‚Äì that is located on the Info Center tab. Once your storyboard is created, you will have the ability to upload files, edit, delete, mark as Featured, and more. Reference the count of images, files, and links within the storyboard to get a feel for what each one contains. Uploading a file allows for many different image types (JPG, PNG, Movie, 360 Images, Splat). Before you click into a storyboard, you will notice that one of the images is larger than the rest on the thumbnail ‚Äì this is the first image listed when you open your storyboard. If you would like to change the image, open the storyboard, and then you can drag and drop in whatever order you would like. Once you are inside the storyboard, there are many functions you can perform. When uploading a link, you have the ability to add a thumbnail. After uploading the link, simply click on that thumbnail to open the link. After a link, file, or image is uploaded, hover over the image and click the Edit button to replace the media, change the File Name, and manually choose the Sort Order. Other operations you can perform upon hovering over the image is download, delete, view images/files in full screen mode, and even play videos directly in Hub. Design Drivers Our design drivers are carefully crafted to best serve our clients and planet: that is, every living species and the habitats they depend on. Each driver is measured by key performance indicators that assess qualitative or performance-based impact. By being more intentional in our process and purposeful in our outcomes, we‚Äôre doing our part to create a healthier world. The Living Design Framework empowers‚Äîand challenges‚Äîus to apply our values to the specific context of a given project. When we are intentional in allowing each driver to shape our work, we uncover purpose-driven design solutions and achieve something greater: Living Design. Our approach to Living Design fully embraces the mission of the International Living Future Institute, whose values we share and best practices we employ. Definitions: Poetics & Beauty ‚Äì Enduring design that is aesthetically moving and imbued with meaning Conceptual Clarity ‚Äì Context, design intent, and reasoned position Research & Innovation ‚Äì Exploration and discovery that leads to new knowledge, pushing beyond the limitations of today to solve the most complex problems of tomorrow Technology & Tectonics ‚Äì The seamless assembly of the many disparate parts of a built environment into a cohesive, elegant, and well-crafted place Community & Inclusion ‚Äì Empathy and compassion nourish our culture of justice, equity and bring diverse voices to the process. Design has the power to touch lives, make memories, and bring people together around a common vision Resilience & Regeneration ‚Äì Design solutions that protect, restore, and enhance the functioning of natural systems and a diversity of life ‚Äì a must in a rapidly changing world with finite resources Health & Well-being ‚Äì Design that promotes physical, mental, emotional, and social vitality for life in all its many forms, resulting in a thriving and diverse ecosystem Creating your Framework Click the black ‚Äú+ Building‚Äù button to start your own Living Design Framework Selecting this button will have multiple buildings under the same Deltek Number Once the Design Drivers modal appears, choose your Type, your Measurement Units, and your building‚Äôs Name. You can make this this Primary option if you choose. After pressing Save, you are able to start updating your petals with your project‚Äôs design information. Use the Update button at the top right of the screen to do this. Note that each petal and field within each petal have their own set of directions. Completing all information within each petal will give you a Completion Percentage of 100%. Beneath the diagram of the petals, you will see the Type listed, along with an Edit symbol. This edit will allow you to change any of the information listed in Step 2 above. The Actions dropdown will contain a few options. Resources will take you to the Living Design Toolkit. Retired will take you to the fields that were created in the first iterations of Design Drivers that you may have filled out but are no longer requested. Click on Actions -> Active to get back to your Active Drivers. Reports is a way to see everything on one page as you fill your information out. Once everything is filled out, this should be a length document all contained on one page. Project Aspirations, released in October 2025, allows you to select which petal(s) are your design aspirations for your building. Important items to note: There are 7 petals, and each has its own place to upload files. When inputting information on petals, occasionally, depending on your answers, there are follow-up questions that will appear. Transcendent details information is on the Technology & Tectonics petal, which relates to TDC Submission. On the Resilience & Regeneration petal, Third-Party Certifications also shows up in the Marketing tab of your project. The Embodied Carbon Table on the Resilience & Regeneration petal goes to full screen, so ensure you select Save in the top right corner before exiting to go back to the Design Drivers tab. When viewing the table, click on each header to pick your input at the time. The Health & Well-Being petal has a link to the Switch List app, explained here . Design Reviews To add a Completed or Scheduled Design Review: Click the Add Review button in the top right of the Design Reviews tab Enter whether the review type is In-Studio, Peer, or Other Enter the date, past or present Add any reviewers you‚Äôd like. This can be anyone at the firm Select whether the review status is Completed or Scheduled Add any Review Notes and/or Feedback Select if this is referring the Boards or Images Important items to note: You can create this on behalf of your peers who may be talking during the design review You are able to add an entire board if you choose Other Design Info This section will only appear on your left side navigation menu if your project existed prior to PMTK. This tab now acts as a holding ground for data that no longer has a place within your project. For example, anything that was input into the old Living Design or Storyboard apps, as well as old Biennale and DEAR information, would be shown here. Awards Information TDC Submission This section will appear once your project has been added to the Transcendent Detail Competition app. Once it‚Äôs been added and you navigate to the newly shown TDC Submission tab of your project, you will find a lot of the general information has been populated from the Info Center and places like the Project Team page. You will see places to enter your Project Narrative, PDF, optional Video, and Special Conditions. Once all your pertinent information is entered, select the Submit Project button at the top right of the page.

title: Info Center
content: The Info Center displays the key top-level properties for a project.

title: Home
content: The Home page is in Beta. We are actively improving the page, so you may notice new features being added over time. Currently, our Home page includes snapshots of some of the most pertinent features of your project. Included is Storyboard, Living Design information, Health status, your project‚Äôs timeline with a hover state of important financial data, and necessary actions to take.

title: General
content: Launchpad ‚ÄúThe Launchpad‚Äù is the start screen for the Perkins&Will Hub ecosystem. It is a collection of our internally developed business applications. Apps will be visible by role-based permissions or by individual need. Expect to see our app library grow. Project App tile The Project App tile on the Launchpad. Opens you onto the Project Browser page. Return to Launchpad Once inside of an app you will see the Launchpad button, use this button to return to the Launchpad. This button appears throughout the Hub 365 interface. Project Browser Navigating the Project Browser 1. Launchpad ‚Äì this button takes you back to Hub 365 Launchpad 2. Filter tools 3. Search bar 4. Search Result count 5. View modes. 6. Sorting drop-down 7. Create Project Project Card From the Project Browser you see a list of projects identified as ‚Äúcards.‚Äù Each card represents a project, and each project will be associated with a single Vision number. We aim to have a one-to-one project to vision data stream. They can be created at any stage and can appear in multiple apps of Hub as they advance towards completion. For example, a project may start as a marketing pursuit in Pipeline. Once it is awarded it‚Äôs status changes to Active and will now appear in the Project app where a Vision number can be assigned. Cards display differently when changing the view mode. These cards display only important high-level information. Featured Image, Primary Client, Project Name, Project Number, Studio & Practice, Project type, Status, and Stage. These parameters will largely be unchanged through the course of the project and will appear read-only in many areas of the app. Once established these can only be changed by Finance. Duplicates can occur; to Mark as Duplicate for merging, use on the project card to update. Please leave additional notes so the development team can respond efficiently. Projects that are related can be associated manually. Project type Projects must be classified as Small, Large, or Related to another project. Statuses Status can be manually changed by individuals with Project Manager role permissions. If a project pursuit was started in the Pipeline app and was awarded it becomes Active. Once Active, the project appears in the Project app. Stages There are 17 pre-defined Stages to choose from. Modules Modules are separate pages in the Project app. Each one contains different tools and capabilities for specific tasks. Module visibility depends on the project requirements and an individual‚Äôs role permissions. Some modules are nested. For example, the PMTK contains 5 individual modules specific to the Project Management tasks. Some modules activate once a piece of information is added. For example, the AreaSync module which is nested under Performance appears only after adding a link to the AreaSync PowerBI dashboard in the Info Center. The Module Navigation panel is accessible from the left-hand side of the user interface and stays on top in all areas of the app. List of currently active modules in the Project app (Mar 23): Home (beta) Info Center Team Storyboard Design Drivers Design Reviews Other Design Info Schedule Budget Staffing Contracts RAMP AreaSync (Activates when an AreaSync link is added) 2030 Challenge Awards & Publications Settings Search bar Tip: If searching by Project Number, search using the first 6 digits. Exclude the ‚Äú.000‚Äù for better results. Filter tools Tip: You can see all the projects that you or others are on from your profile in the People app. View Modes Change the way projects appear in the Browser. Fit view (default) Fit is designed for maximum card visibility. You will see the full card when a Featured Image has been uploaded to your project. If there is no image, the card will condense to just the text information. Grid view All cards are the same size and layout as a grid. List mode Lists out projects as data rows. Sorting Sorting options: ‚Ä¢ Name* ‚Ä¢ Created Date** ‚Ä¢ Updated Date** ‚Ä¢ Stage ‚Ä¢ Status ‚Ä¢ Vision Number** ‚Ä¢ Total EAC Compensation** *only Ascending ** Ascending and Descending Create Project All projects will start out in the Project app. Once created, a Vision number can be requested from Finance (steps below). Review First, check to see if the project has already been created. Use the search and filter tools to help narrow down the query. If the project has already been started your next step may be Requesting a Vision number, see steps below. Create Initiate the process by clicking the Create Project button from the Project Browser page. There are 6 pieces of information you are required to provide before submitting. The only optional field here is the check box for ‚ÄúRelated project.‚Äù 1. Project Name. Important: The Name will not be editable by most users after submitting. Editing a name must be done by a Hub admin. Please take care in naming projects regarding consistency or established naming conventions. It is recommended that you consult with your Studio‚Äôs TRT to set out or maintain consistency. 2. Related to another Project? 3. Stage will change during the project and must be manually updated by the PM. 4. Primary Studio Use this field to nominate ONE studio. You will be able to add more studios after the project has been created. 5. Primary Practice Like Studio, you are required to pick one here. Additional practices can be added later. 6. Client Name Type to search for existing entries first. This field pulls from our ‚ÄúOrganizations‚Äù Hub app. Use existing or create new here. You will be able to add individual Contacts later. 7. Project Type Asks you to define the project size. Small ($50k or less) or Large (greater than $50k) Wizard You will land in the Info Center module immediately after creating a project. The Project Info Wizard will display that you have already provided 25% of the required info from the initial setup. Use the Wizard to guide you to 100%. You may not have all the information yet, so you can always revisit this area to complete it later. Refer to the help document on the Project Info page for more information. Project Interface Inside of a project the interface shows the same Project Info card stacked on top of the Module Navigation panel. The site is optimized for desktop, but if viewing from a phone or tablet you will see a button that allows you to expand and collapse this menu. 1. Project Info Card 2. Module Navigation panel 3. Back button ‚Äì returns you to the Project Browser Project Info Card This is the same card you see on the Project browser page. Always on top, consistently visible in all modules and throughout the app experience. Module Navigation panel Use this navigation panel to bounce around to different areas of the same project. Back button The Project app icon will navigate you back to Project browser page from anywhere in the app. If you need to stay in the project but go back one page, use the back button in your web browser.

title: Install
content: To install Area Sync Rhino , go through the following steps: Open the Rhino Package Manager by typing the command PackageManager or through the top bar menu. Search for ‚Äú AreaSync ‚Äù. If AreaSyncRhino is not showing up on the search, please follow the guide to setup the Perkins&Will Rhino Package Manager on your computer. Choose the latest version, or any older if that‚Äôs the case. Press install. Did it work? Make sure the installation worked out by opening the Area Sync panel using the AreaSyncRhinoPanel command. If you can see the Area Sync panel, you‚Äôre ready to get started .

title: Thumbnails
content: FamilyBatchThumbnail Macro runs on multiple families to cleanup thumbnail view ATTENTION:do not start when any project file is open. run in an empty project. Opens every family in Folder to Process (optionally with subfolders), ¬†turns off ref. lines, ref planes, dimensions then ¬†zooms extent¬†and saves as family ¬†to an output folder (with subfolders) families remain open in Revit session, so sometimes it crashes (usually when you process more then 200 families or some of them are corrupted ‚ÄãIf session did not crash, close Revit without saving. new tool : PIG installed on PWTCN0201 ‚Äì powerful, Preview Image Generator but injects¬† extensible storage in families, and it is unknown if it can be harmful. use with caution, keep family backups. you can manually update preview image by using Save As-> Options

title: Styles
content: CTC Tools (installed everywhere) Type swapper ‚Äì to manage duplicate families, text styles, dimension styles, line styles Quick Select selects and finds elements based on variety of criteria. Good to find and see outliers .

title: Subcategories
content: Standard categories and subcategories to check categories, use following tools BIMHelper Category Report run BIMHelper tool -Subcategories , select all project families and run report. Open the report in excel. Note that we are are only interested in user added subcategories, they have positive element ID, filter by positive element ID to get manageable list find subcategory you are hunting for. the list¬†of ‚Äúcarrier‚Äù families will be in the right column. If it is empty, tha suncategory exists in the project but not in the families Macro reports, outliers Run macro subcat3 (installed on PWTCN0201) to find outliers and generate reports of subcategories in the project or in the family. It requires baseline file C:\Temp\PWMacro\categories\PWcategories.txt ¬†to generate outliers report. If that file does not exist, run macro on a baseline Revit file (template), rename the resulting file to PWcategories.txt, then run macro again Outliers will be reported in the file ¬†¬†C:\Temp\PWMacro\categories\Outliers. download PWcategories.txt

title: Family Reporter
content: FREE tool ‚Äì install on your MSI if needed Installed on common machine PWITCN0201 in add-ins- spicetools Shows info about families in project, including sizes, hierarchy, types, preview, parameters, etc. Great for spotting irregularities within the project. Has some great cleanup options: Purge CAD¬† Styles and it can also delete selective imports. Very well developed interface with table and tree views. Slow to scan families initially (better work in detached), Can create reports in CSV and full hierarchy report and nested export when (Create Project Xml)

title: CTC Family processor
content: Very powerful tool for batch family processing Need to be in the family editor to activate the tool Works with lookup tables, materials, parameters, also can extract some information, audit and upgrade families, set units, and change family-level settings It cannot help you with subcategories, use BIMHelper tool or PW Macro for subcategories

title: Parameter tools
content: To report all parameters, use BIMHelper family parameter editor reports parameters from folders or from families within project. Reports all parameters, including hidden, and which families are using them Open results in Excel. Use CTC Family Processor to clean up parameters in families to change parameter values in project , use CTC SpreadsheetLink

title: Project Full Report
content: macro and report sample

title: BIMHelperTools- Triage
content: This tool is available on PWITCN0201 as part of the BIMHelperTools suite Licence credentials are: Helen.Gorina@perkinswill.com. password is PWDA Additionally, standalone version¬† of Library analisys tool can be installed from here X:\Projects\DA_BIM_Resources\Tools\BIMHelper ‚Äì please read Lib_analyzer.txt first it does not require licensing but cannot co-exist on the same machine ans the full suite Library Analysis tool is intended for quick triage of families, it generates a report¬† in Excel: What it can do: 1.Generate a report from a folder of families (with subfolders) 2.Generate a report from families in the project 3.Sort families into the folders using one check criteria 4.Extract nested families into a folder hierarchy 5.Extract nested families into a folder hierarchy, purge and recursively reassemble if it encounters unhealthy family (broken constrains and¬† other warnings, it may fail on it) Download [3.15 MB] Note: CTC Family Checke r can also be used, however it is slow and too detailed for quick sorting and triage other tools you may need for cleanup are: Use Parameters , Subcategories, and Family hierarchy to generate detailed reports Note: the BIMHelper suite conflicts with Avail. Disable Avail plugin while using it. There is practically no support from developer, Use other tools with caution

title: Check Shared parameters
content: You can check conformance of shared parameters for families using Model Review Configure Model review on the machine you will be running the check(need to do once). Give yourself write permissions to C:\Program Files\Autodesk\Revit Model Review 20xx Copy the file PW-SP.bcf (attached to this page) to C:\Program Files\Autodesk\Revit Model Review 20xx. Edit it using notepad for version of Revit as needed In Model Review addin, go to Manage Profile Edit Add the check as shown Point Revit to SP file you want to use. It is saved in the user profile, so please check. Run Model Review check on families. It will run of folders and subfolders, faster if on the local drive After check is completed review the results and export to html if desired. Note: to check the families loaded into the project file, first export them out using free CTC batch tool Or Revit Save as Library

title: Export and Import
content: CTC Family Exporter (free tool) allows to extract families into a folder structure by category. It supresses¬† warnings and cannot be used to screen families for corruption. Iven if it comes across bad family, and stops, you cannot see the name of a bad family Built ‚Äì in Save As Library tool¬† can be used to screen families for¬† warnings and corruption. it stops on a bad family and you can see its name To batch load families, you can use CTC Family Loader or simply drag and drop them from Windows explorer into the Project Browser. be mindful of nested shared families when extracting and loading

title: Guardian
content: very powerful tool, updated manual will come soon credentials for admin mode: user helen.gorina@perkinswill.com password PWDA1 intercepts bad/unused/incoming new stuff and lets make decisions before contaminating can be used for libraries cleanup, but mostly used for template maintenance at this time

title: Cleanup Tools
content: The tools below are just some of the tools we use for family triage, diagnostic and cleanup. the tools may update or be retired with time

title: Best Practices
content: Reference planes and lines Name Reference Planes Use in-sketch reference planes if necessary Turn off for previews Use reference lines in traditional families only when you need to control the angle Reference plane assignments (set to not a reference if it is overkill) Hosting Families can be level hosted, floor or ceiling hosted, face based, two level hosted, wall hosted. They also can cut their host. Not all categories can have all hosting conditions. Perkins&Will lighting families are mostly face based. when creating new families consider hosting and how it will work with Design Options Use Library Analysis tool to check hosting Use family processor to change hosting when possible Units Family will¬† inherit units from the project, however it is desirable to keep separate metric libraries Use CTC Family Processor to push units into multiple RFAs Flexing families Practice flexing families as you create them. Additionally, to check family type flezing, run Library analyzer or save families from the project as a library. Both tools will stop on the family that had types which cannot be made.

title: Broken families
content: Sometimes families are broken when they went through too many upgrades or when they are copy/pasted from one project to another. Check for warnings Check for corruption Check for nested families and shared families. Open and look: Does everything belong Purge Unused (3 times) Look at browser to see if there are nested things that shouldn‚Äôt be there (screwy things that shouldn‚Äôt happen but sometimes do) Legends Drafting views System Families Why curtain panel in keynote family???

title: Complexity
content: Consider following complexity issues Geometry Very small in¬† size families can put a heavy load on Revit performance. For example a keyboard family with every key modeled in 3D is less the .5 mb when key ia nested family, but if you have 100 of these families in plan view or 3D view, the view may take very long to regenerate. Minimize geometry to what is absolutely necessary, use detal level and visibility settings to minimize unnecessary processing. Even when the family size is relatively small, the count of 3D surfaces matters most. Nesting and sharing Plan family nesting ahead. Do not nest more than 3 levels deep. Purge nested families before inserting them in the main assembly. In case you are planning to nest shared families, consider that not shared¬† families with the same name might exist in the project. Also consider that shared families will appear in the project browser and schedules and can be tagged even when nested. Formulas Formulas are powerful family tool. However too many formulas in the families may be slowing down Revit performance. Consider creating type catalogs in excel, where the same formulas were used in excel to pre-create certain number of types.

title: Graphics
content: PW North American Imperial and Metric graphic standards use the same, Line Patterns, Line Styles and Fill Patterns. The Dimensions and Text styles in the imperial Revit files are based on imperial graphics standards while the metric ones are based on the metric graphics standards. In addition, the templates¬† includes a sheet that catalogs the above graphic standards in visual form.¬† The view, is found here: Please start from one of the existing PW family , create the new content in the family editor and then purge all several times.

title: Categories and Subcategories
content: Revit has built-in categories and subcategories and allows creation of user subcategories. Start family creation from the correct category template . While it is possible to change category later, the behaviour of the family in plan view when getting crossed by the cut plane depends on its category Firmwide subcategories for models use prefix ‚Äú_PW_‚Äù Firmwide subcategories for lines: Project specific subcategories can use project abbreviation as prefix. Subcategories names without prefix could be system defined subcategories or ‚Äù invaders‚Äù which were brought in with external content. System subcategories cannot be changed or deleted. Full list of all PW categories is here:

title: Parameters
content: Parameters names should be fairly clear as to what they do ‚Äì both shared and family For example, instead of ‚ÄúD1‚Äù use ‚ÄúLength‚Äù. Use BIMHelper Parameter tool or CTC Family processor to create full parameter report per family batch Shared parameter file is located¬†in S:\_Firmwide\Revit\PW_SharedParameters.txt file. Shared Parameters are orgranized into groups by workflow or category. Copy the file to your project folder if you need to add/edit project specific parameters. _PRJ_Custom group is intended to hold project specific parameters (use project ID as prefix and ‚Äù PRJ‚Äù as suffix for project specific shared parameter names. You may have several project specific shared parameter files to hold model specific parameters. zUtil group is phased out in 2016. It was used for content management. Complete list of all parameters Open it in Excel and use filters to see which parameters are used in which loaded families, filter by ‚Äúshared‚Äù, by category or any other way you see fit. (needs updatring) To check a bunch of families and find shared parameters which are not conforming to current Shared Paremeter file , follow instructions here Naming Convention Prefix:¬†Start with category or usage abbreviation Siffix: _PWProj for project only parameters ‚Äã _PW for project only parameters which are shared parameters. ‚Äã Tip: Many project parameters are used in schedules and the name in the schedule header could be different from parameter name. Open the schedule to see which parameters are used under each heading.

title: Family Naming
content: Family Naming Rules: In the P+W firm wide Standards, no spaces are allowed, use ‚Äú_‚Äù and ‚Äú-‚Äù as separators. use UpperCase notation to improve readability. Use only alphanumerical symbols. Never use symbols like: \ / ? ‚Äù ‚Äò = Format: SpecSection_Description-MoreDescription_PW see naming for the doors starting with 081000 or specialty equipment starting with 102800) in the pictures below Modified P+W families and new project specific families shoud be prefixed by an abbreviation of the project name. This will help idenfy the families that need to be vetted and added to the P+W library in the future ‚ÄãExceptions from the Rules: Families which cannot have spec section assigned ‚Äì for example placeholders for equipment or nested parts of other families. Legacy families which are updated in the release of template 2016 ¬†(in the example below- all casework and many doors)‚Äã Rules for exceptions: PW_Description-MoreDescriptions Special case: Sometimes we have smart tag which reports parameters for other families and also generic annotation symbol. All smart tags have suffix ‚Äú-Tag‚Äù, all symbolic (dumb) annotations have prefix ‚Äú-TagSymb‚Äù

title: Loadable family quality
content: Intelligent behaviour of Revit content depends on parameters and subcategories. We overhauled ¬†and standardized Shared and Project Parameters and Sub-Categories¬†to achieve consistency across all offices and projects. Minimum requirements to the quality of loadable families include following standards and recommendations shared parameters catergory and subcategories Graphic language ‚Äì line types, line patterns, fill patterns, lineweights complexity geometry nesting and sharing formulas check for warnings and corruption generate meaningful preview Revit version consideration no imports Materials

title: Published content folders
content: Folder Taxonomy for all office libraries Root to Level 2.¬† All office libraries are starting with 03 pre-fix Consistent structure makes it easy for all to understand Opportunities for automation of content promotion, management, etc. when folder structure is consistent between offices Universal Access and knowing where to look Implemented for 2018 and later versions Each library folder should start from the same root S:\OfficeName\ Revit Office Families\RevitVersion Under the root folder, the first level of folders is based on Revit category. Second and¬† third levels can vary per office It is recommended to group content in folders by hosting and/or by logical grouping Examples: Folder Taxonomy for Firm Wide libraries Root to Level 1. (01 prefix) Firm wide libraries include PW content as well as some standard Autodesk content, these two groups are kept in the separate root folders because Autodesk content gets updated every year and we do not have to maintain it. Below is an example of 2019 Imperial folder structure. Folder Taxonomy for External source libraries Root to Level 1. (04 prefix) Autodesk content is located in S:\_Firmwide\Revit20XX\Libraries SEPS2BIM content is located in S:\_Firmwide\Content\Revit\SEPS2BIM folders

title: Content asset types and sources
content: Most of the Perkins&Will content types are distributed using HIVE. HIVE content is available in or out of the office. 3D Loadable families (doors, furniture, toilets etc.) 2D Loadable families (detail items, annotations) System families (walls, roofs, etc.) Drafting views Sheets with Drafting views Schedules Fill patterns (as drafting views) Model and Detail groups Additionally, we have details and sheets of details , Firm Wide Legends and a content factory tool Superdoor

title: Superdoor
content: Superdoor tool is used firm-wide for creating a large variety of door configurations on demand. The firmwide library in AVAIL has some basic doors that were created with superdoor tool, and schedules to go with them. Some offices have their own door collections in AVAIL (Boston, Atlanta, Vancouver) which are built differently than Superdoors.¬† They come with their own schedules and work well for these offices. If not sure, please check with your office Design Application Manager. Superdoor is a tool from CTC, the components are developed in Perkins&Will. Superdoor step-by-step: 1. Select the main door assembly We are using three groups of doors assemblies: Curtain panels (no frame,¬† size by instance) ‚Äì magenta frame, CW in the lower left corner of the icon Wall hosted ‚Äì Size by type ‚Äì yellow frame, Inst-WH in the lower left corner of the icon Wall Hosted ‚Äì Size by instance ‚Äì green frame, WH in the lower left corner of the icon 2. Select Door Frame Only door frames compatible with your main assemblies will show up. CW doors are frameless. Frames are the windows category in Revit. 3. Select Door Panel Only door frames compatible with your main assemblies will show up. Panels are shared families if Doors category in Revit. Use pre-filtered door schedules from HIVE to filter the doors out from the schedules. you only need to schedule entire assemblies. 4. Set Parameters you can adjust the parameters later, but it is easiest to do it before the assembly is made 5. Create a Door check and adjust components and assembly names, and save the family. It is recommended NOT to load it directly to the project, but review outside and keep in mind that the panels are shared so if the panel with this name already exists, it can be overwritten on insertion of a new assembly with the same panel name Additional Resources: Superdoor microKnowledge cards

title: Firm Wide Legends
content: A group of technical experts from across the firm has developed a package of legends for firm wide use . Please begin by reviewing the PDF on the S drive ‚Äì it has additional notes (in red) S:\_Firmwide\BIMListContent\ 20XX -Imperial\StandardLegends20XX.pdf The Firm Wide Legends are a starting point for your project. It is the project team‚Äôs ¬†responsibility to review and adjust for your project‚Äôs needs. Below the index of legends are instructions to load the content into your model. LEGEND LIST : ARCHITECTURAL WOODWORK¬† GENERAL NOTES EXIT NUMBER AND ARRANGEMENT FOR LEVEL 01 CODE COMPLIANCE PLAN GENERAL NOTES CODE COMPLIANCE PLAN LEGEND DEMOLITION GENERAL NOTES DEMOLITION LEGEND DOOR TYPES DOOR FRAME TYPES DOOR SCHEDULE GENERAL NOTES DOOR SCHEDULE REMARKS EQUIPMENT PLAN GENERAL NOTES EQUIPMENT PLAN LEGEND FLOOR PLAN GENERAL NOTES FLOOR PLAN LEGEND ABBREVIATIONS LEGEND(Healthcare and Labs) ABBREVIATIONS LEGEND MATERIALS AT LARGE SCALES SYMBOLS LEGEND GENERAL PROJECT NOTES SYMBOLS GLAZING LEGEND INTERIOR ELEVATION GENERAL NOTES INTERIOR ELEVATION LEGEND MISC. EQUIPMENT MOUNTING HEIGHTS FINISH LEGEND NOTES INTERIOR FINISH PLAN GENERAL NOTES INTERIOR FINISH PLAN LEGEND FLOOR PATTERN PLAN GENERAL NOTES FLOOR PATTERN PLAN LEGEND FURNITURE PLAN GENERAL NOTES FURNITURE PLAN LEGEND FURNITURE PLAN MOUNTING HEIGHTS INTERIOR PARTITION DETAILS GENERAL NOTES PARTITION TYPES GENERAL NOTES PHASING GENERAL NOTES PHASING LEGEND RCP GENERAL NOTES RCP LEGEND ROOF PLAN GENERAL NOTES ROOF PLAN LEGEND ARCHITECTURAL SITE PLAN LEGEND STAIR DETAILS GENERAL NOTES PLUMBING LAYOUT GENERAL NOTES TOILET ACCESSORIES LEGEND & MOUNTING HEIGHTS Some local offices have included their legends in their office template or may have different source files available to you. Please consult with your Design Application Manager if not sure To utilize the legends published in S:\_Firmwide\BIMListContent\ 20XX -Imperial\StandardLegends20XX.RVT use PW tool Import Legend

title: Details
content: Firm wide details A group of technical experts from across the firm has developed a package of details for firm wide use . In addition to sample and loadable details, the subject matter experts have included recommendations and instructions for Project Architects. Please begin by reviewing the Recommendations and Instructions document¬† located in the S:\_Firmwide\Content\Revit\20XX-Imperial\Details_MergedComments.pdf and refer to them as you develop the details for you project. The Firm Wide Details are a starting point for your project details. Regardless of the source of detail, it is the project team‚Äôs ¬†responsibility to review and adjust for your project‚Äôs needs . Below the index of¬† firm wide detail sheets STAIRS: Please note that stair details are just examples, they¬†have to be developed from a live model, Review¬†the stair detail sheet PDF‚Äôs for best practice of documenting stairs. A41-01 ‚Äì STAIR ‚Äì PLANS & SECTIONS A41-50 ‚Äì STAIR DETAILS A41-51 ‚Äì STAIR DETAILS ALL OTHER DETAILS can be loaded as an entire sheet or a‚Äôla carte from HIVE (2018 and later) ‚Äã‚ÄãA50-01 ‚Äì ARCHITECTURAL CABINETS AND COUNTERTOPS A51-01 ‚Äì CEILING DETAILS ‚ÄãA61-01 ‚Äì INTERIOR PARTITION TYPE CHARTS A61-02 ‚Äì INTERIOR PARTITION TYPE CHARTS A61-50 ‚Äì INTERIOR PARTITION DETAILS A62-50 ‚Äì INTERIOR DOOR AND FRAME DETAILS A62-51 ‚Äì INTERIOR DOOR AND FRAME DETAILS A62-52 ‚Äì INTERIOR DOOR AND FRAME DETAILS A63-01 ‚Äì INTERIOR WINDOW DETAILS G02-01 ‚Äì FIRE RESISTANCE DETAILS AND DIAGRAMS G02-02 ‚Äì FIRE RESISTANCE DETAILS AND DIAGRAMS It is recommended to load entire sheets of standard details and delete the ones you do not need for your project. They come with neutral titleblock, after you are done reviewing them, swap the titleblock to the project specific one. Office Specific Details Some offices have published¬† in HIVE their own detail collections. they are intended to use only in the office which had published them. If you want to find appropriate details for your project. search in YOUR office library and a firmwide collection first if not found, search other offices collection ‚Äì and check with your technical authority whether it needs to be modified for your project.

title: CMS HIVE
content: New CMS HIVE is a standalone Revit agnostic application capable of storing and and intelligently searching various¬† files. You can start it from Revit or from the desktop shortcut. If you see both Published libraries contain following asset types 3D Loadable families (doors, furniture, toilets etc.) 2D Loadable families (detail items, annotations) System families (walls, roofs, etc.) Drafting views Sheets with Drafting views Schedules Fill patterns (as drafting views) Model and Detail groups Content is available in and out of the office. Our designers can use HIVE seamlessly regardless if they are in the office or work remotely. It is possible to share some libraries with a consultant when collaborating on the project. The same asset can be exposed in multiple libraries without duplication.

title: Content Maker Guide
content: Perkins&Will¬† has many offices in US and internationally,¬† with various needs, local standards¬† and workflows. All our practices are important to the overall health of the company. Company wide standards¬† and based on them templates establish a common foundation for compatibility between offices and projects so we can collaborate successfully across offices on various projects Foundational standards Not negotiable for compatibility: Shared parameters User subcategories Graphics line weight, line styles, line patterns, fill patterns, text styles, dimension styles, arrows, tags, annotations All our templates and published Perkins&Will content are based on the firm wide standards. Templates Our Revit template are rebuilt from scratch every three years to be fully¬† compatible with new Revit formats released by Autodesk. Last full rebuilt happened for 2019 version of Revit. In- between three years rebuild we just upgrade the current templates to the new version of Revit. All office templates start with a Firmwide Baseline or Firmwide¬† Plus template, and each office adds their flavor, workflows and efficiencies and publishes their own template(s). When starting a project, use the Project Create tool and select the template appropriate for your office and practice.

title: Revit Content Overview
content: Most of Perkins&Will approved content is distributed using our content management system ‚Äì¬† HIVE Assets type published in HIVE are: ‚Äì¬† 3D Loadable families (doors, furniture, toilets etc.) ‚Äì¬† 2D Loadable families (detail items, annotations) ‚Äì¬† System families (walls, roofs, etc.) ‚Äì¬† Drafting views (details) ‚Äì¬† Sheets with Drafting views (detail sheets) ‚Äì¬† Schedules ‚Äì¬† Fill patterns (as drafting views) ‚Äì¬† Model and Detail groups In addition, some approved content is available outside of HIVE Firm Wide Legends ‚Äì Revit legends cannot be distributed by HIVE The Superdoor tool is used firm wide for creating a large variety of door configurations on-demand. Some offices have created their own door collections ‚Äì check with your local DA if not sure whether or not to use Superdoor All published content is screened and cleaned up Filtered out toxic Broken families ‚Äì crash Families with imports Families with warning Mis-categorized No 3D when expected Just broken /over-modeled Other considerations Nesting Sharing Parameters (shared and not, Instance and Type) User subcategories Materials ‚Äì parametric or by category Unused purgeable stuff Unused not purgeable stuff (line patterns, empty subcategories, etc.) Open and look for weird stuff

title: Revit Standards and Templates
content: Revit Standards Each Perkins&Will studio has unique needs due to local workflows, deliverables and the strive to continuously improve our design and delivery process, effectively making one ‚Äúfirm wide standard‚Äù unrealistic. However, a common foundation of tools and workflows are adhered to so projects can be successfully collaborated on between studios. Here is an outline of the foundational framework common to all Perkins&Will model authoring: Common Shared parameters Common User subcategories Line weights, styles, and patterns Fill patterns Text styles, dimension styles Arrows, tags, annotations All Perkins&Will templates are forged from the centrally managed ‚ÄúBaseline‚Äù template. Templates The Baseline template is rebuilt from scratch every three years, so as to be fully compatible with the latest requirements released by Autodesk. On the off-years, the template is evaluated, new features/content added or removed, and then upgraded to the latest version. All studio templates begin with the Baseline template, each studio may add to their template based on unique circumstances. When creating a new Revit project, use the Project Create Tool and select the template for your studio and practice. See How it Works

title: Introduction
content: This guide focuses on what designers need to know about our content ecosystem so they can be successfully delivering solutions for our clients. The ecosystem is made up of various templates, workflows and content. To aid in organizing the vast number of moving parts in this ecosystem, both an underlying framework from which all Revit projects begin, and a content management system [CMS] are in place at Perkins&Will. This guide will review each of these components and point you to additional information so you can leverage them in your projects. Additional chapters are included for those who create, plan and maintain content. These chapters focus on content creation standards, quality checks, template maintenance, tools for re-using content assets as well as managing our CMS.

title: Tally Quickstart Guide
content: Key Information: Please use these Tally tutorials to get started. Tally is available for free download in our Software Center. It comes with a free trial. Please contact Elton Gjata or Jesce Walz for a full license key. Other Resources: Perkins&Will Core Exchange: Quantifying Embodied Carbon in Tally For advanced questions, please reach out to our Carbon Forecast Team ‚Äì General Channel

title: Folder Structure
content: Rhino files are kept in the project folder under DESIGN / BIM / RHINO.

title: Layer Structure
content: Rhino files are primarily organized by Layers. Those of you familiar with AutoCAD should recognize the Rhino system. Layers can have sub-Layers and object properties, like lineweight, color, material‚Ä¶ and many more, can be associated with the Layer. This system is incredibly flexible and allows a Team to  customize it to suit their needs. The template below provides a starting point for design studies, collaboration, model analysis and interoperability with Revit. Additional workflows may require additional layers be added. Coordinate changes to the Rhino layering system with the entire Team. Include Rhino layering starting point in BIM XP? DESIGN Layer Most of your work will take place in this folder. Be your cool designer self. Make sub-layers. ANALYSIS Layer The ANALYSIS Layer contains sub-Layers that feed into the various Analysis and computational design workflows that are executed through Rhino, which are often very picky about the type of geometry they work with. Occasionally a program will need a root-level layer, not under ANALYSIS, communicate this to your team. CONVEYOR Layer Being able to import data-rich geometry from Rhino into Revit eliminates the remodeling that was previously necessary when switching between software platforms. The Semantic and Conveyor plugins translate Rhino geometry and parameters into native Revit elements that show up in drawings and schedules. This is accomplished by having particular Rhino Layers associated with Revit Families. Import the Rhino File, Create the Revit Element. Refer to the Conveyor documentation for detailed information on the Layer structure and the types of Revit Elements Conveyor can produce.

title: Introduction
content: Rhino is a flexible 3D modeling program that is already being used broadly across Perkins&Will‚Äôs practice. These templates will help project teams get up and running quickly, helping them to organize their work, accomplish common design tasks, and facilitate interoperability with other programs.
